column2: TOKYO, June 16 -- The first public hint of differences of opinion in government quarters appeared today in the strongly nationalistic newspaper Nichi Nichi. In an article on the relations between Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye and Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka, Soho Tokutomi, Nichi Nichi's premier political commentator writes:

ALBANY, June 16 (AP) -- Refusal or inability of counties to obtain rights-of-way is delaying nearly half of New York's 1941 highway building program, all of which is dedicated to expansion of a "defense" road system.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We have recently read in THE TIMES about the vast amounts of wheat in storage on the wheat-growing farms, and how there seems to be likely a real "bumper" crop of wheat this year, which will make the quantity of wheat in storage greater than ever, to the extent that there may not be buildings enough to contain it all.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended June 11 aggregated 59,453,000,000.

ROME, June 16 (UP) -- One thousand unhappy Americans in Rome, cut off unexpectedly from all revenue by the Italian Government's retaliatory freezing of all American assets in Italy, tonight pooled available cash resources and organized cooperative eating clubs to stave off hunger until the situation is clarified.

A change or plan finds Ted Hainmerstein, instead of Hope Lawder, listed to operate the Spa Theatre at Saratoga Springs, where an eight-weeK season trill start about, July 15. The plays, which Mr. Hammerstein will direct, will include one new one, not yet selected.

As a result of further restrictions on mill activity, consumption of cotton in Great Britain this season is expected to be 2,110,000 bales and to drop to about 1,500,000 bales in the season beginning on Aug. 1 next. In pre-war years Britain used between 2,500,000 and 3,000,000 bales annually.

BAYONNE, N. J., June 16 -- The Danish freighters Nora, Marna and Jonna were taken over here today by the United States Maritime Commission. Captain Granville Conway, district manager of the commission, posted notices to that effect on each of the ships.

CINCINNATI, June 16 -- Bounding back with that astounding resiliency that so frequently has forced their severest critics to concede they must have more lives than a cat, the supposedly skidding Giants turned on the Reds today and routed the world champions in the semes finale, 6 to 0.

Billy Conn came to town last night, having completed the training campaign for the most important ring battle of his life, the heavyweight title meeting tomorrow night with Champion Joe Louis at the Polo Grounds.

Charles H. Mullens, former Assistant State Controller, admitted on the witness stand in General Sessions yesterday that, while his salary never was more than $15,000 in any year, he obtained loans running into the hundreds of thousands of dollars from banks that were depositories for State funds.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : And now police action is called for by Stephen G. Rich in a letter to THE TIMES against the tendency to leftism or, rather, middle-of-the-roadism.

The Westport Country Playhouse, which opens June 30 with Tallulah Bankhead in "The Cardboard Lover," also has selected its closing bill -- Tyrone Power and Annabella (Mrs. Power) In "Liliom," the week of Aug. 25. It will be staged by Eva Le Gallienne, who is to work with Theresa Helburn and Lawrence Langner next season on the Theatre Guild's Revival Series.

BELLEVILLE, N. J., June 16 -- John Kinder, State open champion, and Charles Whitehead, State amateur titleholder, won the New Jersey P. G. A. weekly pro-amateur tourney on the Branch Brook links today.

A year ago today the words of a tired old man in Bordeaux stirred mingled emotions in the peoples of the free countries. Marshal Henri Philippe Petain had come to the Premiership of France in an unhappy hour. He was known as the defender of Verdun, where the Germans had not passed.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A survey of all "critical" machine tools delivered since 1929 and now required for the defense program has been undertaken by the Office of Production Management, it was revealed today in a talk by Howard W. Dunbar of the machine tool sectin, before about 100 field agents of the OPM contract service called for a three-day conference.
Several fur firms were among the concerns reported yesterday as having taken new commercial quarters in office, store and loft structures throughout the city.
VICHY, France, June 16 -- "My uncle came up from the south yesterday,' said a woman today, "and he got so thin I scarcely knew him."
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Courtlandt D. Barnes Jr. have come to the Savoy-Plaza from Alexandria, Va.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- A resolution condemning Thurman Arnold, assistant United States Attorney General in charge of the anti-trust division, for "smearing" the food industry by the manner in which he has publicized his department's investigations in that field was adopted here today by 5,000 independent retail grocers, attending the forty-fourth annual convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers in the Palmer House.

McKEESPORT, Pa., June 16 -- While street sweepers and repairmen dropped their brooms and shovels to shoulder strike placards, the McKeesport City Council today voted to seek an injunction against a strike of municipal workers in this Western Pennsylvania industrial community of 57,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, sent a letter to all C. I. O. affiliates today declaring that he had never encouraged "the current slander campaign against the loyal Americans who represent the C. I. O. and its unions," and denying the "great many speculative and often highly fantastic stories in the public press about splits, purges, Red-hunts * * * taking place in the C. I. O."

On its finding that various official German agencies in this country, including German consular establishments, have been engaged in "improper and unwarranted" activities, "wholly outside the scope of their legitimate duties," our Government has taken the only proper course open to it by demanding the prompt closing of these offices.

The English-type residence with nine rooms and three baths at 93 Overlook Road, Upper Montclair, N. J., has been purchased and is now occupied by Preston H. Kelsey, an executive of Marsh McLennan, New York insurance brokers. The seller was A. E. Westendorf.

ROCHESTER, N. T., June 16 (AP) -- The Red Wing's outhit Jersey City tonight, 18 to 13, but a wild eighth inning in which John Berly walked five batters and allowed two hits gave the Jerseys a 12-to-8 decision.

GREAT NECK, L. I., June 16 -- Mrs. Ruth Torgerson and Jimmy Hines, home club pro, combined to shoot a 76, four over par figures, in the one-day alternate shot tournament of the Long Island Golf Association at the Lakeville Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Senate approved and sent to the House today a bill authorizing $250,000,000 for a network of strategic roads for defense purposes, with 400 "flight strips" to serve as emergency landing and take-off fields for war planes.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- All-air delivery of American planes destined for British forces in Africa was discussed today as plans moved forward for perfection of the new Air Force ferry command.

ATLANTA, June 16 -- Appeals for coordination of efforts "to keep alive the ideal of freedom" were sounded today as nearly 5,000 delegates from all sections of the United States and Canada opened the twenty-fifth annual convention of the Kiwanis, International.

Mayor La Guardia explained the operation, of his civilian defense plans in detail last night over the nation-wide red network of the National Broadcasting Company, and assured the radio audience that an effective civilian defense force would soon be created for the protection of all Americans.
BERLIN, June 16 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

TORONTO, June 16 (AP) -- The Newark Bears unfolded a thirteen-hit attack behind the six-hit flinging of John Lindell tonight to trounce the Toronto Maple Leafs, 6 to 0. It was Lindells eighth victory of the season.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Roosevelt canceled today a projected trip this week to Hyde Park and Harvard University. He conferred with Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, and later talked with Army, Navy and British-aid officials.

South American and Mexican winners in the Museum of Modern Art's industrial design competition were honored at a luncheon yesterday in the museum's penthouse, 11 West Fifty-third Street. The purpose of the design composition was to select a group of designers capable of creating a useful and beautiful environment for today's living, in terms of furniture, fabrics and lighting.

It is a serious situation when a loyal American citizen is barred from the defense industries because of his race, his national origin or his religion. Yet, as the President stated in his memorandum to the Office of Production Management, this situation exists. The OPM protested against it in a letter sent to holders of defense contracts on April 11.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One can agree only in part with your editorial "Settling Future Strikes." May I elaborate somewhat. However, by way of introduction it may not be amiss to set forth a few postulates.

BERLIN, June 16 -- It was stated in official circles today that no decision had been reached regarding the reaction of the Reich Government to the freezing of German credits in the United States. There was likewise no comment on President Roosevelt's order today closing German consular and propaganda offices and calling for the expulsion of their German employes on charges of improper activities.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 -- In dedicating a new $1,250,000 armor plate plant on the grounds of the Henry Disston Sons factory in the Tacony area, C. Jared Ingersoll, civilian head of the Philadelphia ordnance district, urged industry today to forget holidays in its drive to overtake Germany's production of war materials.

Although showings were more than three weeks earlier than usual manufacturers opening their Fall lines of dresses, coats, suits, blouse and lingerie yesterday found their showrooms crowded with retail buyers who were actually writing orders rather than merely "shopping around."

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 16 -- In the commencement address at Smith College today Professor Roy D. Welch of Princeton suggested that graduations of 1941 might stand out as symbolic of the faith of American society in freedom of thought and of its determination to maintain its belief in the triumph of reason and human dignity over the threat of brutality and human degradation.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 16 -- A world at war and a world to be reshaped in a peace to come were depicted today to Yale seniors by their chosen Class Day speakers.

MADRID, June 16 -- There was still no comment here today on President Roosevelt's action in the impounding of credits held in the United States by European countries, including Spain. Dispatches published here have given the impression that Spain, along with other countries not taken over by the Axis, was exempted from the order.

Michael Dabonka, 26 years old, boatswain's mate on the American President liner President Harrison, which arrived at Hoboken yesterday after a world cruise, refuses to find anything very amusing these days.

Out of a worn leather coin purse, Tobias Wildstein, who is 109 years old, scooped $18.75 yesterday to buy a national defense bond and started a small rush among residents of the Home of the Sons and Daughters of Israel, who also wanted to join in the national defense effort.

WATERVILLE, Me., June 16 -- Urging all-out union with Great Britain as insurance against "the danger of being suddenly exposed to invasion by a separate peace," Clarence K. Streit addressed the graduating class of Colby College today.

BELL BUCKLE, Tenn., June 16 -- A war of nerves developed in this manoeuvre area of Middle Tennessee when early today fast reconnaissance units of the Second Armored Division, described by its commander, Major Gen. George S. Patton Jr., as "the strongest force ever devised by the mind of man," began probing soft spots in the lines of its psychologically at bay "enemy," represented by the comparatively slow-moving Twenty-seventh and Thirtieth (square) divisions.

The council of Actors Equity Association elected eight new members yesterday to replace the eight who resigned a week ago, charging Communist control of the governing board of the players' union. No action has been taken to replace the two vice presidents who also resigned, the council wishing to have acceptances from its new members and a full board before doing so.
LONDON, June 16 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 14:

Mayor La Guardia warned racketeers to stay away from the new Brooklyn Terminal Market in an address yesterday morning at the official opening of the market on a twenty-five-acre plot bounded by Remsen Avenue, Foster Avenue, East Eighty-seventh Street and the Long Island Railroad tracks.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 16 -- In the last twenty-four hours the British and imperial forces in Syria have registered a large advance against General Henri Fernand Dentz's main army defending the Lebanese coast, and tonight it is reported here that the Allies are less than ten miles from Beirut.

WASHiNGTONV June 16 -- Because of the "increasing difficulty in obtaining adequate persons to fill many of the positions essential to the prosecution of the national defense program," the Civil Service Commission applied to all Federal agencies to employ more women in a greater variety of positions.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, June 16 -- The stoutest and most unafraid of all the thirty-five survivors of the Robin Moor reaching here today was by common consent the smallest -- 2-year-old Robin McCullough, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. McCullough.

Though reports from several capitals contend that the Germans have mobilized some 120 divisions on the Soviet border and that Russia has mobilized some 155 divisions to oppose them, there is no way to confirm whether there have actually been such concentrations. Certain basic factors, however, are reasonably clear.

ROME, June 16 -- Italian banks told inquiring Americans today that they could not cash their checks because all United States funds had been blocked. Inquiring as to when money would be released brought evasive replies. They were informed that the Bank of Italy would issue regulations in due time.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 16 -- British and Indian troops, using many tanks and armored cars, moved forward along the Egyptian-Libyan frontier yesterday, precipitating fighting on the escarpment between the Solum area and Sidi Omar, more than twenty miles to the southwest, it was announced today.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, June 16 -- A British vessel, the name of which was withheld, arrived here today with thirty-five survivors of the United States freighter Robin Moor, torpedoed by a U-boat in mid-Atlantic on May 21.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 16 -- Princeton University will confer 624 Bachelor's and advanced degrees in the 194th commencement exercises on the green facing historic Nassau Hall tomorrow morning.
The Third Avenue Railways System and the Transport Workers Union will start negotiations tomorrow on a new contract covering the company's 3,500 employes, the union announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 16 (AP) -- The British Army of the Nile was on the march in Italian Libya again today, and motorized troops darting ahead of the main force were declared to have thrust forty miles within that colony.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 16 (AP) -- New German and Italian schemes for fanning Arab violence against British authority in the Middle East to counteract strategic reverses of the Axis in Iraq and Syria were reported today.

HOLMDEL, N. J., June 16 -- A tea will be given here tomorrow at Button Wood, the home of Mrs. William Barclay Harding, for members of the junior committee aiding in the plans for the Monmouth County Horse Show to be held July 17, 18 and 19 on Thornton Farm, adjacent to the Rumson Club, for the benefit of the Defense Council of the River Boroughs on the Shrewsbury River.

Bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States on May 31 amounted to $215,005,000, a decrease of $4,556,000 in the month, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This decrease followed substantial increases in the two months immediately preceding.

Dr. Hans Thomsen, German Charge d'Affaires at Washington, who is the chief German diplomatic representative in the United States, said here yesterday that he had no idea how many German nationals would be affected by the United States order closing German consulates and certain other German agencies in this country.

ITHACA, N. Y., June 16 -- President Edmund Ezra Day of Cornell declared today that this country should do all in its power to speed aid to Britain, even if such a policy involved the loss of American men and ships.

Just when it appeared that the Yankee winning streak was doomed, the Cleveland infield collapsed behind Lefty Al Milnar at the Stadium yesterday and the McCarthymen, grateful for all favors came on with a rush to beat the Indians, 6-4.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, June 16 -- Melvin Mundy, chief officer of the torpedoed United States freighter Robin Moor, who landed here tonight with the rest of the missing survivors, gave this account of the ship's encounter with the German submarine that sank her:

JERUSALEM, June 16 -- An authoritative military spokesman in Jerusalem this evening said that difficult terrain around Merdjayoun in the central sector of the Syrian front had caused a "very obscure situation" owing to a penetration by a body of Vichy troops, whose advance units had reached a point called Iblis.
MANCHESTER, N. H., June 16 (AP) -- The Amoskeag Manufacturing Company, around which some of the most tragic and brightest stories of the depression were written, passed out of existence today.

Security transactions initiated before the close of the market on Saturday for the account of German, Italian or other nationals whose funds were frozen by the Presidential order issued on Saturday afternoon may be completed under certain conditions, according to rules made public yesterday at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
BUENOS AIRES, June 16 -- News that Brazil is negotiating with the United States concerning bases was not unexpected in Argentina, but it created a deep impression in all sectors of public opinion.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 16 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

POUGHKEEFSIE, N.Y., June 16 -- Oar blades that have dipped into waters that flow into the Pacific today dug into the Hudson as that river flowed to the Atlantic this afternoon. The Poughkeepsie regatta squad of Washington, along with the Wisconsin oarsmen, joined the others in preparation for the races of June 25.

PITTSBURGH, June 16 -- Walter D. Fuller, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, called upon the Federal Government tonight to adopt a firm policy to discourage strikes in defense industries, but expressed opposition to governmental seizure of industrial plants.

WOODMERE, L. I., June 16 -- The annual women's New York State clay court tennis championship got under way today at the Woodmere Country Club, but after eleven matches had been played showers caused postponement of further competition until tomorrow.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 17 -- For the second time within ten days, United States Ambassador Joseph C. Grew yesterday delivered to Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka a sharp note of protest against Japanese bombings of American property in Chungking, which are endangering American lives.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A new Federal radio law with a provision for direct licensing of networks was urged today by William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System as a means of ending "the state of terror which literally exists in this industry today."

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., June 16 -- One hundred and seventy-six were graduated at the commencement of Middlebury College and the Women's College of Middlebury today in Mead Chapel. Seven received master's degrees. President Paul D. Moody conferred the degree of Doctor of Laws on Dr. Hu Shih, Chinese Ambassador, who gave the commencement address.

ROCHESTER, June 16 -- Following are the texts of the citation read by President Valentine of the University of Rochester, in conferring the degree of Doctor of Laws upon Winston Churchill, and the Prime Minister's reply:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 16 -- The danger of a Russo-German war seems from here today greater than yesterday, although some observers still believe that Germany will not drive Russia to despair and that the present tension will end In a compromise.

BOSTON, June 16 (AP) -- Finding plenty of running room on the turn for home after getting away slowly. Hal Price Headley's Crowfoot, 7 -- 10 favorite, galloped to a length and a half triumph through the slop today in an allowance dash at Suffolk Downs.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 -- Giving a superb exhibition of ring generalship, Lou Salica of Brooklyn retained his bantamweight championship tonight by taking everything Tommy Forte had to offer, then rallying to win a fifteen-round decision over the Philadelphian before 14,500 spectators at Shibe Park.

Moving to take immediate advantage of the Federal Communications Commission's new rules permitting commercial operation of television beginning July 1, the National Broadcasting Company filed applications yesterday for commercial television stations in New York, Washington and Philadelphia.
Worcester, Mass., will enter the market tomorrow with $1,035,000 of relief, water and sewer bonds for which bidders are to name the rate of interest. The bonds are to mature from 1942 to 1951.

While drenching rains fell, under the somewhat doubtful protection of a carnival tent, 198 members of the first class to enter Queens College yesterday afternoon received their bachelor degrees, becoming the first graduates of the four-year-old institution, at commencement exercises on the campus of the college, 65-30 Kissena Boulevard.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- When Boston newspaper men today approached Dr. Herbert Scholz, the German Consul there, they heard him say:

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The fact that the remaining thirty-five passengers and crew members of the torpedoed American Robin Moor had been saved was hailed here with relief but was not expected to alter the attitude of this government toward the torpedoing.

A resolution urging the government to consider the door-to-door collection of aluminum through established peddlers and scrap dealers, rather than through Boy Scouts and other such organizations, will be sent to "Washington by the Empire Metal Merchants Association, it was decided last night at a meeting in the Hotel New Yorker.

All national organizations primarily concerned with credit on consumer goods will be asked to participate in a conference to be held July 15 in Chicago at which a code to control the extension of installment and other retail credit will be drafted, according to a resolution adopted unanimously yesterday at the opening session of the twenty-ninth annual convention of the National Retail Credit Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 16 -- while British and Free French troops yesterday were capturing El Kesweh, on the outskirts of Damascus, and Saida, twenty-five miles south of Beirut on the coast road, heavy fighting developed between these fronts along the Metulla-Beirut road.

WASHINGTON, June 16 --The funds of the German-American Bund and other Nazi or Fascist organizations will be immobilized by President Roosevelt's freezing order, it was stated today by John W. Pehle, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, who is in charge of control of foreign funds.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- All diplomatic observers in Vichy agree that Henri Moysset's share in governmental work is greater than any other's. Admiral Francois Darlan, on assuming his office as Vice Premier last January, appointed him Secretary General to the Vice Presidency of the Council.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Harold L. Ickes, defense oil coordinator, prevented today the shipment of 252,000 gallons of lubricating oil to Japan on the Japanese tanker, Azuma Maru, which was awaiting its cargo at Philadelphia. A spokesman for Mr. Ickes said that the action was taken "not on a question of international oil policy but on coordinating supplies on the East coast."

At the Old Stand New York has many more old business firms than people imagine. When a newspaper celebrates its centennial it is a pleasant custom for its contemporaries in the commercial field to offer their congratulations in print.

BERLIN, June 16 -- Prices of securities on the Boerse were soft and dull throughout today's session with most listings losing between 1 and 2 per cent. Harburger gained 3 1/2 and Accumulatoren 5 1/2 while Licht and Kraft lost 3 1/2.

The fresh run salmon have finally arrived in the northern Maine rivers, and according to a letter from Dick Reed more than a dozen nice fish have been taken recently from the Dennys, Narraguagus and Pleasant Rivers.

FORT BENNING, Ga., June 16 -- The first class of the United States Military Academy, here on a five-day visit, joined classes of the infantry school to view a demonstration of communications in units ranging in size from the regiment down.
LONDON, Tuesday, June 17 -- Sharp air battles above the Strait of Dover and the invasion ports of France in the late daylight yesterday marked heavy British bomber-fighter raids across the Channel.

Does New Jersey look as queer to many of its inhabitants as it does to the outlander? In his campaign for Governor last Fall Charles Edison earnestly and constantly urged the calling of a constitutional convention. The New Jersey Constitution is almost a hundred years old.

CLINTON, N.Y., June 16 -- "Whether we as a nation are to be a passive recipient of blows or the strong striker of blows to protect the freedom which we have inherited from our ancestors, you young men will decide," President W. H. Cowley told Hamilton College seniors at commencement this morning.

VICHY, France, June 16 -- On the Syrian front, according to the French communique issued tonight, the respective positions remain virtually unchanged despite severe attacks and counter-attacks in most sectors, especially in the vicinity of El Kesweh and Casale Gezin.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 16 -- Supreme Court Justice Francis D. McGarry, sitting here without a jury, today heard opening statements in six separate actions brought by holders of preferred stock of the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company and the Nassau and Suffolk Lighting Company against these companies and the Long Island Lighting Company and the E. I. Phillips Company.
"This is nice weather for ducks," say the people who buy food for a Fifth Avenue department store. Ducks in divers guises are appearing this week on their grocery shelves to prove their point.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The House Military Affairs Committee voted late today to grant deferment from the Selective Service Act of men over 27, and proposed to report the measure to the House for consideration probably next week.
BAR HARBOR, Me., June 16 -- Baron and Baroness Alphonse de Rothschild of New York and Vienna have leased Hillcrest for the Summer.

MONTREAL, June 16 (AP) -- Secretary Frank Knox of the United States Navy Department, told Canadians tonight that President Roosevelt in his recent "epochal address" left no doubt that the United States would follow the same "self-respecting route" as Canada in "defiance to those who seek military dominion over us."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 (AP) -- Captain. Fritz Wiedemann, German Consul General here and Adolf Hitler's superior officer in the World War, shrugged his shoulders and said, "I don't know where I am going to go," after discussing the United States order closing all German consulates.

PITTSBURGH, June 16 -- Unrestricted and indiscriminate use of vitamins was criticized here today by Dr. Russell M. Wilder, who declared that our national goal along the nutrition front should be to restore to basic foods the vitamins lost in processing, rather than trying to improve on nature by putting vitamins into foods which do not naturally contain them.

FORT DIX, N.J., June 16 -- The last shipment of more than 400 vehicles consigned to the Forty-fourth Division in the last week arrived by freight today bringing the organization's total rolling stock to within thirty-three of the 2,752 vehicles authorized by the War Department.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Testifying today before the Senate Committee investigating the national defense program, Secretary Ickes charged the Aluminum Company of America with seeking to maintain its monopoly with little regard to the nation's need for the vital metal which it produces.

The "Freezing" Orders One of the busiest places in Wall Street yesterday was the Foreign Property Control Department of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which, is situated in the Reserve Bank's Annex at Gold Street and Maiden Lane, in the shadow of the main building.
The farmer's wife in Kansas and the debutante in Philadelphia after July 1 will bear the New York skyline, silhouetted on a small label, on their backs.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 7 -- This capital is the headquarters of German, activities in South America. Here the Nazi High Command oversees and manipulates, with military precision and efficiency, a system of coordinated diplomacy, propaganda and trade that is amazing in its completeness and far excels in effectiveness the equivalent American and British activities.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 16 -- Somewhere down back of Cape Cod tonight the yachts in the Eastern Yacht Cub race from New London to this point were still on the way.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 17 -- According to British opinion, expressed today, of Prime Minister Churchill's radio appeal to the United States yesterday for immediate aid to Britain, made to Rochester University in accepting an honorary degree, the speech was interesting not so much for what he said as for what he implied.

LONDON, June 16 -- At least twenty-three persons, including men and women and possibly children, lost their lives when Nazi planes early Friday morning dive-bombed and sank the St. George's Channel steamer St. Patrick while she was nearing the end of her trip from Rosslare, Ireland, to Fishguard, Wales, officials disclosed here tonight.

Mayor La Guardia commended the civic spirit of the late William W. Cohen, former Representative and guiding spirit of the Police-Fire baseball games, as he distributed proceeds of the 1940 game among the relief funds of the two departments and a group of relief agencies at City Hall yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, June 16 -- Donald M. Nelson, director of purchases of the Office of Production Management, called upon manufacturers tonight to reduce the number of "fashions, styles, models, colors, shapes and brands" of goods offered to consumers.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y, June 16 -- Herbert C. Gerlach of Ossining, Finance Commissioner of Westchester County for the last two and a half years, was chosen late this afternoon by county Republican leaders as their candidate for County Executive in the November election.

While there has been much discussion recently as to why department store linage in newspapers doesn't show gains somewhat comparable to increased sales volume, the May total was the highest on record, with the exception of May, 1929.

ROCHESTER, June 16 -- One of the strongest pleas yet made for Anglo-American unity came across the Atlantic today from Winston Churchill, British Prime Minister, as he accepted, in absentia, the degree of honororary Doctor of Laws from the University of Rochester.

Meeting little upside resistance yesterday, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange added another 9 to 15 points to their seven-day gains and again moved to the highest levels since 1937. In the course of the day's trading, the July option followed the other active months to above the 14-cent level.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Wheat developed an easy undertone in the early trading today on the Board of Trade here and prices declined around 1/2 cent a bushel on scattered selling and a forecast for clearing weather over most of the Winter wheat belt.
MONTREAL, June 16 (Canadian Press) -- Asked if he thought the British Isles will be able to hold against Nazi onslaughts, Colonel Knox today replied emphatically: "You bet."

TRENTON, N.J., June 16 -- On the ground that New Jersey's Summer resort and fishing businesses, described as "two of the major industries in the State," would suffer great hardship, the Legislature appealed today to Secretary Harold L. Ickes in his capacity as Federal Fuel Administrator not to impose "gasless Sundays" unless absolutely essential to national defense.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, in Syria, June 16 -- Touring the district between the Lebanese coast and Merdajoun, which recently fell into British hands, the writer saw two forms of warfare, ancient and modern, and listened to apologists for each.

Attorney General Robert H. Jackson's move to force the German dye trust to answer criminal charges in Federal court here by tying up the organization's assets in this country had its effect yesterday, two days after President Roosevelt had ordered the freezing of all German funds in the United States.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 16 -- The return of Grand Circuit harness racing to the metropolitan area after an absence of thirty-two years marked the program of the Old Country Trotting Association under the floodlights at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Ways and Means Committee was disclosed today to be studying an excess profits tax plan designed to raise not less than $1,000,000,000 and presented by the Joint Congressional Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation.

"Man Hunt," which opened Friday at the Roxy, played to 46,522 admissions through Sunday night, thereby chalking up the best week-end attendance which that house has had since the opening there of "Tin Pan Alley" last November, the management reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- Packing houses bid freely for hogs in the livestock market today, holding prices steady to 10 cents higher in a fairly active market. A top of $10 was again paid for choice offerings, equalling the year's peak established on Friday. Last week's upturn in cattle prices created a greatly increased run of arrivals today.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, June 16 (AP) -- All missing survivors of the torpedoed American freighter Robin Moor were landed here tonight by a British ship that happened to see their lifeboats on the hot mid-Atlantic.

Four tow-haired chidren, with hands clenched in tight fists and tears glistering on cheeks white with dread, stared hopefully at the robed figure sitting above them and holding the scrap of paper on which they had scrawled in pencil the fear that was upon them.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 16 -- Opposition to the "weakening" of our local governmental system, upon, whose strength "depends the preservation of our democratic form of government," was expressed today by Governor Saltonstall, who gave the commencement address at Williams College.

Daily average production of crude oil in the United States last week amounted to 3,822,750 barrels, an increase of 6,050 over the 3,816,700 reported for the preceding week, according to a summary by the American Petroleum Institute. Last week's figures were 23.050 barrels above the calculation 3,799,700 daily by the Bureau of Mines for May.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 17 -- Victor Mature, who went unnoticed in Hollywood until he scored in Manhattan's "The Lady in the Dark," was cast today in the leading roles in two pictures, according to announcements by United Artists and Twentieth Century-Fox.

Clifford T. McAvoy resigned his $5,000 post as second deputy commissioner in the Department of Welfare yesterday under pressure from Welfare Commissioner William Hodson, who disagreed with his "liberal" activities.

Town Hall was jammed to capacity, and the doors were closed by the police last night as the Ring of Freedom, an anti-Nazi group headed by Miss Dorothy Thompson, held its first mass meeting. All those entering signed pledge cards signifying their belief in the ten articles of faith of the group, which stress tolerance, equality and freedom.
ROME, June 17 (AP) -- The following is the teat of today's Italian order regarding American credits:

Graduation exercises for 73,000 New York City school children will get under way today and continue until June 27, the last day of the current school year, Board of Education officials announced yesterday. Many of the schools, especially in the secondary division, are planning elaborate ceremonies.

Investment demand reappeared in the stock market yesterday, and traders returned quickly to active positions with, a resumption of the recovery movement. Although the majority of the best gains failed to average more than a point, the upward swing was fairly general throughout the list, especially in the senior groups of securities.

An unofficial investigation into the causes for the sharp rise in cottonseed oil, which on Monday reached a four-year high, has been instituted by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, it was learned yesterday. It was indicated that, while the OPACS concedes that the statistical position is tight, there is some belief in "Washington that prices are being run up by undue speculative activity.

Miss Brenda Diana Duff Frazier, heiress and "glamour girl," will be married this month to John Simms (Shipwreck) Kelly, insurance broker and former football player, it was announced last night by her mother, Mrs. Frederic N. Watriss of 22 East Forty-seventh Street.

While the Municipal Civil Service Commission announced yesterday that it had completed the classification and transfer into the civil service of all the operating and maintenance employes of the old IRT and BMT systems, the Transport "Workers Union filed with the Corporation.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Jimmy Wasdell's tenth-inning home run off General Bill Lee with two mates aboard finally overcame a series of bad breaks against the Dodgers to give them a 7-to-6 triumph today, their first at Wrigley Field this year.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- In the first four months of this year there were about 20,000 more births in the United States than in the same period last year, the Bureau of the Census reported today. This indicated a birth rate for 1941 of 18.5 per 1,000 population, the highest since 1930, and close to the latest birth rate reported from Germany, which was 18.8 in 1937.

J.T. 'Wilson, chief of the foreign department of International Business Machines Corporation, was elected president of the Export Managers Club at the annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday. Oren O. Gallup was elected to his eighteenth consecutive term as secretary.

VICHY, France, June 17 -- General Jean Bergeret, Secretary of State for Air, hag arrived in Syria from Vichy, according to an official statement released this evening. The object of his visit, it is explained here, is to inspect air formations that have recently arrived in Syria from North Africa and France and have already been in action.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 17 -- French troops launched strong counter-attacks yesterday aimed at Merdjayoun and El Kuneitra, but latest information reaching here indicates that both these points, which are considerably south of the center of the Damascus-Beirut line, remain in British hands.

Prince Ludovic Pignatelli, 63-year-old Spanish nobleman, marksman and a veteran of General Franco's army in the Spanish revolution, denied from the witness stand in Federal Court yesterday that he had ever tried to extort money from Prince Guido Pignatelli or Prince Guide's wife, the former Mrs. Henrietta Hartford.

Josefita Arias. Consul General of Panama, said to be the only woman to hold such rank in the United States, has leased quarters for the consulate general on the ninteenth floor of the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center. The Panaman consulate thus will become the twenty-first in the consular colony quartered in the Rockefeller group.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 17 (AP) -- The battle resulting from the British thrust into Libya developed fiercely today, with hundreds of tanks employed on both sides and United States-made planes holding German dive-bombers at bay, according to British reports.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 17 -- Seven members of the Grand Army of the Republic are attending the Department of New York convention, their cumulative ages being 672.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 17 -- With the intercollegiate rowing regatta only one week off, hopes for California's Golden Bears received a sharp blow today when the rumor leaked out that Marshall Robertson, No. 3 in the junior varsity boat, was ill with what "looks very much like a case of the measles."

The first death of diphtheria in New York City in the last fourteen weeks and the second such death this year was reported in the week ended last Saturday, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, was informed yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records in the Health Department.

NEWMARKET, England, June 17 -- A lack-luster field of twenty-one thoroughbreds, headed by the Duke of Westminster's Lambert Simnel, was named today to run tomorrow in the 162d English Derby, once the most famous horse race in the world, but now just an ordinary event carried on in the face of wartime perils.
VICHY, France, June 17 (AP) -- The text of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's broadcast today follows:

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), June 17 -- Rost van Tonningen, president of the Central Bank of the Netherlands, in his annual report makes known that free banking and payments traffic within the German "Lebensraum" are being organized, with the Reichsmark as the dominant currency unit and Berlin as the economic and financial center.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some of your correspondents apparently do not know that passing an automobile on the right side is sanctioned by law in New York City; the ordinances provide specifically that a car may be passed on either side.
OSLO, German-Occupied Norway, June 17 (AP) -- Kirsten Flagstad, opera star, will remain here until the war is over, her husband, a Norwegian lumberman, said today.

As had been expected, men's wear buyers who poured into the New York market this week, seeking off-price merchandise for July and August sales, found the various wholesale markets comparatively bare of desirable goods, they reported here yesterday.

One highly beneficial result of the closing of the German consulates in this country will toe to put a stop to the efforts of these agencies to recruit "German-American" support for Hitler. There cannot be the slightest doubt that efforts of this kind were among the "improper and unwarranted" activities to which our Government objected.

A $10,000 cash loan that George W. Loft, the 76-year-old Rockville Center banker, swore two weeks ago in General Sessions that he made to Charles H. Mullens, former Republican Assistant State Controller, in August, 1935, at the Saratoga race track, was the main target yesterday of Assistant District Attorney Murray I. Gurfein in his cross-examination of Mullens.

CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- Buyers paid a top of $10 for choice hogs on the livestock market again today, but efforts of commission men to push the price above that figure met resistance. The bulk of Offerings gained 5 to 10 cents. It was the third successive trading session, excluding Saturday's reduced market, in which the $10 level was attained.

How three low-salaried salesmen posed as intimates of John D. Rockefeller Jr. and numerous other prominent men in a $3,000,000,000 "liquor syndicate" was related yesterday to Judge James Garrett Wallace and a jury in General Sessions after Mr. Rockefeller and several other prominent men had sworn they never had met the trio nor knew anything of their bogus representations until after their arrest.

In an effort to keep list prices unchanged, some manufacturers are starting to cut corners by eliminating cash discounts or cutting trade discounts and are looking at advertising allowances with a view to either reducing or dropping them, reports indicated yesterday.

Theatre operations of Paramount Pictures, Inc., for 1941 to date are somewhat better than for the previous year, with increased taxes offsetting the improvement in earnings, Barney Balaban, president of the company, said yesterday at the annual meeting: of stockholders.

ST. LOUIS, June 17 (AP) -- The Cardinals routed the Phillies by 11 to 3 today in a continuation of their drive toward a pennant, but for all practical purposes the game could have ended after the first inning.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, June 17 -- Brazil and Paraguay, agreeing to give each other ample economic help, today signed ten treaties covering commerce, transport -- both land and river -- and cultural relations. Luis Argana, Paraguay's Foreign Minister, and Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, Brazil's Foreign Minister, signed the treaties this morning.

Buyers' Arrivals Higher The number of out-of-town buyers reported in the market last week was 867, against 782 in the previous week and 670 in the like period a year ago, according to THE NEW YORK TIMES listings. Arrivals yesterday totaled 535, which compared with 396 for last Tuesday.

With the foreign exchange market now only a shadow of its former importance as a result of the cessation of trading in the currencies of nations whose accounts are "frozen" here by executive order, banks and foreign exchange dealers devoted much time yesterday to a checking over of their records on recent transactions involving the sales of actual dollar currency, and more particularly of bills of large denomination.

PITTSBURGH, June 17 -- The Giants arrived here today to find their old friend Onkel Franz Frisch recovering from a painful operation on his right toe and immediately commiserated deeply and profoundly with the stricken Corsair skipper.

The Western Union Telegraph Company yesterday acquired one of the outstanding men in the railroad field to be its new president. The communications company, the largest in the world, chose Albert N. Williams, who began his business career at the age of 16 by swinging a pick and shovel in a railroad gang for the Denver Salt Lake Railroad.

MADRID, June 17 -- The text of the new agreement between Nationalist Spain and the Vatican, published in the official bulletin today, shows that the Catholic Church, which had already got back the privileges it held under the monarchy, has retained virtually the same power over the appointment of the hierarchy and lower clergy that it enjoyed under the republic.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter from John C. Kalish In THE TIMES is an example of the confused thinking which is causing so many people to feel that there has been an extreme advance in food prices.

LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- British bombers flying in a sandwicn formation between layers of fighters attacked French coastal objectives tonight in fierce continuation of the R.A.F.'s new superbomb offensive, stepped up by the increased flow of American-built planes.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 18 -- The closing of all German consulates in the United States came like a bombshell in Japanese official quarters, and Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka immediately presented the latest available details to a Cabinet session yesterday.
NEW YORK Count and Countess Andre De Limur and Miss Helen De Limur have come from Washington to the Sherry-Netherland.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), June 17 -- The Bourse was generally firm today with a good investment demand in evidence. Netherlands Indies shares were firm on more reassuring views regarding the position of the islands. Amsterdam Trading rose 5 points to 394 1/2 Amsterdam Rubber 2 1/4 to 241, Royal Dutch 2 1/4 to 241 and Philips 1 to 205.

McKEESFORT, Pa., June 17 (UP) -- Striking service employes of the City of McKeesport unanimously rejected tonight a compromise agreement worked out by city and union officials to end a two-day strike which has tied up many of the normal services.

LOS ANGELES, June 17 (AP) -- World records in the one-mile relay and the high jump were beaten tonight as the Pacific Coast Conference swamped the best of the Big Ten in their fifth annual dual meet before a crowd of 10,000.

Massachusetts has decided to experiment with prepaid medical care, but in a way that is new and that seems bound to yield needed information. The State Legislature has passed two bills with different objects in view. One bill, sponsored by the State Medical Society, permits the creation of the usual voluntary health insurance plan approved by the American Medical Association.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The strangling of Miss Jessie E. Strieff, 23-year-old War Department worker, prompted Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today to caution young women flocking here for defense jobs to be wary of strangers.
The Midtown, Greenwich Village, Central Park. West End Avenue and Riverside Park sections all snared in the residential activity reported by brokers yesterday.

A record class of 2,717 seniors will receive degrees, diplomas and commissions at City College's ninety-fourth annual commencement exercises tonight in Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Nineteen thousand parents, guests and members of the faculty are expected to attend.

CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- Defending Champion Don McNeill of Gambier, Ohio, led the parade of seeded stars today into the third round of the national clay-court tennis championships, breezing through Gerald Crowther of Hermosa Beach, Calif., 6-1, 6-2, 6-4.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Roosevelt is expected to resolve soon conflicts in priorities controls between the Office of Production Management, whose Priorities Director is Edward R. Stettinius Jr., and the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, headed by Leon Henderson.

The longshoremen's strike against the Morgan Line and the Maritime Commission spread yesterday to Baltimore, but representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association expressed the hope that a settlement would be reached soon.

Universal's "Tight Shoes," a screen version of the Damon Runyon story, which was filmed by Mayfair Productions with Jules Levey as producer, will open tonight at the Rialto Theatre. Broderick Crawford, Binnie Barnes, John Howard, Leo Carrillo, Anne Gwynne and Samuel S. Hinds are featured in the comedy, which was directed by Albert S. Rogell. . . .

Abe Simon, Richmond Hill heavyweight, added another knockout to his record when he stopped James D. Turner of Sweetwater, Texas, in the feature bout, listed for ten rounds at the Queensboro Arena last night. Simon was declared the winner when Turner was unable to answer the bell for the sixth.

No 'Defrosting' Yet There was still no word yesterday regarding probable issuance of general licenses by the Treasury for releases of accounts here of non-invaded nations such as Switzerland, Sweden, Spain and Portugal, aside from special licenses issued to a few agency banks.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, June 17 (AP) -- The Japanese accepted failure today in their long negotiations for vastly increased supplies of strategic raw materials from the Indies and promised moreover that the Netherland refusal would make "no change in normal relations."

LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- Informed sources said today that Britain had stopped granting navicerts for ships going to the Finnish Arctic port of Petsamo because "several German divisions" now are stationed in Finland.

FORT DIX, N.J., June 17 -- Reports from Washington that the 174th Infantry would be demobilized in September were considered highly speculative today by Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell, commanding general of the Forty-fourth Division, of which the 174th is a component.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Roosevelt disclosed at his press conference today that activities of the German consulates, all of which in the United States and its possessions are to be shut under this country's order of yesterday, were of a subversive character.

"WASHINGTON. June 17 -- Finished and semi-finished manufactured goods, which constituted 91 per cent of United States exports in April, included $66,000,000 of aircraft shipments, a gain of $16,000,000 in such shipments over March, the Department of Commerce reported today.

The fourteenth annual report of Remington Rand, Inc., which is being mailed to stockholders today, shows consolidated net profits for the year ended with March of $4,263,249 after all charges, including $1,375,000 provision for income taxes.

It might have been any block in London after a bombing. Lumber from demolished buildings was strewn about in the dirt. A small yellow tractor, its shovel nosing ahead, lumbered around in an excavation loading debris into a truck.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The United States must proceed on the theory that the war will last a long time. Secretary Stimson and Adolf A. Berie Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, told the Rivers and Harbors Committee of the House today in advocating immediate legislation approving the agreement with Canada for development of the St. Lawrence seaway.
Reports from the Atlantic Highlands area indicate that the fluke fishing there is improving every day, and some of the veteran angrlers who have been trying it have taken up to twenty fish a tide.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 17 -- Five thousand harness racing fans saw a newcomer take the spotlight during Roosevelt Raceway's Grand Circuit program tonight.

The five-story store building at 600 Madison Avenue and the four-story tenement and store structure at 24 East Fifty-eighth Street were sold as one parcel at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street sales-rooms to T. Gaillard Thomas, as plaintiff, for $238,000.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, June 17 (AP) -- Thousands of words of official statements were taken today by United States consular officials from the officers, crew members and passengers of the Robin Moor, telling exactly how their ship was sunk.

CINCINNATI, June 17 (AP) -- Art Johnson, young southpaw up from Hartford. Conn., lasted just long enough to get one man out today as the Reds reached him for four runs on four hits in the first inning and went on to defeat Boston, 5 to 3.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- The favorable weather for the Winter wheat harvest dominated the action of the market for wheat futures today, and prices averaged lower, although trade was light. Closing sales on the board of trade here were at losses of 1/4 cent a bushel.

Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church yesterday dismissed the complaints In two suits that were entered to compel the Singer Manufacturing Company, the world's leading fabricator of sewing machines, to pay dividends out of allegedly excessive and unwarranted accumulations of surplus and undivided profits.

Service clubs to be maintained "by the United Service Organizations will remedy the main complaint of the men in camps -- "the monotony and impersonality of the whole procedure," the Rev. Robert G. Gannon, president of Fordham University, told 200 divisional chairmen gathered at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday for the third report meeting of the Metropolitan New York Women's Division of the United Service Organization.
Following is the text of the speech by Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King before the Associated Canadian Organizations of New York City last night:

IF the new British push into Libya turns out to be another large-scale drive, Raoul Aglion's "War in the Desert,"* published today, comes at exactly the right time. Written in English by a young Free Frenchman who resigned last Fall from the staff of the French Legation in Cairo, it is one of the few eye-witness reports we have had of recent goings-on in North Africa and the Near East.

Guenther Tonn, German propagandist held without bail at Ellis Island, pending deportation proceedings, cut one wrist and his throat just after midnight Monday morning in what Byron H. Uhl, district director of the United States Immigration Service, described as "a pluff at suicide."
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Recent shipping losses show more clearly than ever before that the course of the Battle of the Atlantic depends upon this country.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman, in a ceremony at his residence, 820 Park Avenue, purchased yesterday a $1,000 savings bank life insurance policy from Harris A. Dunn, president of the North River Savings Bank. The bank was recently authorized to sell life insurance, and the Governor received the bank's policy No. 1. Ed-ward A. Richards, president of the Savings Bank Life Insurance Fund, was present at the presentation of the policy.

NEWARK, N.J., June 17 -- Enoch L. (Nucky) Johnson, Republican leader of Atlantic County, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on three counts of personal income tax evasion. The indictment was identical to one recently handed up in Camden, N.J., but quashed by Federal Judge Albert Maris on the ground that the jury, which held over without authorization, was "legally non-existent."

With its publication date more than a month away, A.J. Cronin's new novel, "The Keys of the Kingdom," is already printed and ordered in numbers that assure its being a best seller. The advance enthusiasm of the publishers, Little, Brown, for this first novel in four years by Dr. Cronin is shown by printings totaling 230,000 copies.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 17 -- Two Long Island Sound sloops, Arthur W. Page's 32-footer Rampage II, of Cold Spring Harbor, and James E. Eyre's Week-Ender Neap Tide of Northport were winners in the Eastern Yacht Club's race here from New London, Conn.

Voters in Nassau and Suffolk Counties went to the polls yesterday in the Spring elections, choosing Mayors and trustees in sixteen villages in each county. Except for five contests in Suffolk County, the elections were routine and there were few changes.
BERLIN, June 17 (AP) -- The German High Command today issued this communique:

The twenty-first annual awards yesterday of the E. H. Harriman Memorial Medals for safety on the railroads emphasize more than individual achievements on the part of certain carriers. The railroads as a whole have improved spectacularly their safety record at the same time that they have been increasing their performance.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Orders not to permit any German national, whether a diplomat or an ordinary citizen of the Reich, to depart from the United States were issued tonight to immigration officers and customs officials.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 17 -- British mechanized forces, led by tanks and armored cars, penetrated Cyrenaican territory as far as Fort Capuzzo yesterday, it was announced today, despite heavy opposition fire that broke out as soon as the attackers had reached the frontier about four miles east of the fort.

A syndicate headed by B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., and including "Welsh, Davis Co. and Sullivan, Nelson Goss, Inc., has received the award of $2,228,000 of special road and bridge district refunding bonds of Hillsboro County, Fla., on a bid of 103.07 for fixed interest rates of 3 and 4 per cent.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Elimination of price-cutting and "cut-throat" competition such as have tended to disrupt the renting business for nearly a decade, and the establishment and maintenance of "fair" values to stabilize the market for office space were urged by speakers it today's sessions of the convenion of the National Association of Suilding Owners and Managers.
Interest in downtown Manhattan loft properties again was evidenced yesterday when a number of buildings of this type went into new control.

LONDON, June 17 (UP) -- Allied armies in Syria were reported tonight to be storming strategic hills commanding the gates of Damascus while reinforcements sped to the central front to stem French counter-attacks on Merdjayoun and El Kuneitra.

Proposals that installment terms on heavy appliances should be reduced in order to compensate for reduced production necessitated by the defense program were translated into definite action yesterday, when Consolidated Edison Company revised its financing terms on 'major appliances to twenty-four months, instead of thirty-six, and Increased required down payments.

Although the acute food shortage in Spain imposes heavy hardships on the war-weary Spanish people, it may be the means of preventing even further burdens on them by causing Germany to hesitate in invading the Iberian Peninsula, Frederick T. Caldwell, manager in Spain for the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, reported yesterday when he arrived here aboard the Yankee Clipper.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 18 -- Swarms of British fighter planes made an offensive sweep over the Strait of Dover in a cloudless sky last evening at the end of the hottest day of the year. The Channel was scarcely ruffled by a light southerly breeze that was welcomed, however, by hundreds of persons who came out of their homes to watch the attack.

The announcement that oil pipelines, "gasless Sundays" and decreased heat in buildings might be necessary for national defense was assailed yesterday by Julius G. Luhrsen, executive secretary of the Railway Labor Executives Association, who said the railroads had 19,000 tank cars available for carrying oil and now lying idle.

WOODMERE, L.I., June 17 -- Miss Helen Germaine of New York, national public parks champion, reached the semi-finals ahead of the rest of the field by playing two rounds today in the women's New York State clay-court tennis championship at the Woodmere Country Club.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 17 -- The situation, in Syria changed overnight when General Henri Fernand Dentz's army launched a sudden and swift counter-offensive from three directions, cutting behind the Allied lines to recapture Merdjayoun and threatening El Kuneitra and the main communication lines of the Free French force fighting south of Damascus.

Retail Inventories of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 8 per cent during May, while sales during that months rose 14 per cent over a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank, of New York.
VICHY, France, June 17 -- On the anniversary of assuming power in the midst of the debacle Marshal Henri Philippe Petain today broadcast a message asking the French for their faith and patience.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- The "War Department gave authority tonight for the construction of five munitions projects costing $89,925,000.

BERLIN, June 17 (UP) -- The German High Command reported in a special communique that twenty British planes were shot down by German fighters tonight when the British attempted to fly into occupied territory from the Channel coast.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 17 -- A source hitherto extremely well informed and reliable in regard to German matters said today "with the highest degree of certitude" that the reason for German troop concentrations on the Russian frontier was that Adolf Hitler had definitely made up his mind to reach a complete "alliance" with Russia.

Noel Coward's new play, "Blithe Spirit," opened in Manchester, England, last Monday night, and John C. Wilson, who will produce it here, was saying yesterday that he hopes Mr. Coward will come to this country to stage the play in the Autumn. By way of preparation Mr. Wilson already has engaged Leonora Corbett for one of the three leading feminine roles.

CANBERRA, June 17 -- Declaring that civil industry must henceforth be limited to what could be afforded after totally organizing the Commonwealth for war, Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies tonight, in an Australia-wide and overseas broadcast, announced a comprehensive series of new measures for extending and consolidating the war effort.

WITH THE BRITISH ADVANCE FORCE, Before Solum, Egypt, June 15 (Delayed) -- For the first time in this war the British have met the Germans on approximately even terms. For the first time in this war they have accumulated enough equipment -- tanks, airplanes and the like -- to be able to take the offensive with a fair chance of winning.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Plans for speeding collaboration between the United States and Canada to use their resources to a greater degree to aid Great Britain and strengthen the defenses of the Western Hemisphere will be pushed by joint economic committees appointed tonight by the two governments.

LONDON, June 17 -- The wartime development of a radiolocator that finds invading planes through fog, darkness and clouds and helps to guide defending fighters to them was announced here today coincident with a radio appeal by Lord Beaverbrook, Minister of State, that was directed in part to the United States and asked for technicians to help in the further improvement and more widespread use of the apparatus.

WEEHAWKEN, N.J., June 17 -- A gold embroidered bull fighter's costume and a monoplane used in the government's civil pilot training program shared top honors with scores of industrial and commercial exhibits at the opening today of the six-day Good Neighbor Nations Exposition in the new Weehawken High School here.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Spokesmen for the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations criticized today the revised Vinson bill for dealing with strikes. They said it would nullify the Norris-La Guardia anti-injunction act, fasten compulsory arbitration, on workers and deprive employes of the right to strike.

Louis Tufano's Market "Wise, preparing for a meeting with Whirlaway in the $10,000 added Dwyer Stakes on Saturday, won the featured race of yesterday's Aqueduct's program, the Class C, $2,000 Water Pearl Handicap, at one mile and a sixteenth.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- A complete ban on exports of oil from the east coast of the United States, without prior government approval of individual shipments, was proposed to the petroleum industry today by Secretary Ickes, defense petroleum coordinator.

RYE, N.Y., June 17 -- Frederick J. Perry completed his sweep of the major professional tennis tournaments of the season today when he carried off the Eastern championship on the turf courts of the Westchester Country Club.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 17 -- The Russian-German situation is worsening rapidly, according to usually well-informed diplomatic and military sources here this evening and there is a growing belief in some quarters that the present secret negotiations between Berlin and Moscow are only a German diplomatic feint before an actual attack and Blitzkrieg.

LONDON, June 17 (UP) -- Juan T. Trippe, President of the Pan American Airways system, predicted tonight that within two years vastly improved transatlantic airplanes would be carrying passengers between the United States and Great Britain on 12-hour schedules.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Strange methods of payments, billing and accounting were revealed today when the government introduced evidence to show the interlocking of Amtorg Trading Corporation, Mezhkniga, the Soviet book and periodical monopoly, and Bookniga Corporation of New York.

Larry MacPhail, president of the Brooklyn Baseball Club, charged yesterday that "the America First Committee is attempting to force the Brooklyn Baseball Club into extending permission for the use of Ebbets Field for 'Lindbergh Rally' by threatening to 'abolish night baseball' or 'boycott the Dodgers.' "

Joe Louis, one of boxing s greatest heavyweight champions and certainly the most active titleholder in all the long history of the sport, will defend his crown tonight for the eighteenth time since the June night in 1937 when he knocked out James J. Braddock in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- When United States border patrols and customs men were ordered tonight to prevent any of the 330,000 German nationals in the United States from leaving the country, "pending further instructions," the official explanation given was that the government wanted to assure compliance with President Roosevelt's order freezing foreign funds in the United States and forbidding removal without permission.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 17 -- Degrees in course were conferred by Yale University today upon 664 seniors in Yale College, the Sheffield Scientific School and the School of Engineering, 477 receiving the Bachelor of Arts degree, 133 Bachelor of Science and 54 Bachelor of Engineering.

PITTSBURGH, June 17 -- Crude, old-fashioned packaging methods characteristic of the cracker-barrel era may be revived because of shortages of materials for modern packaging, R.S. McBride, a consulting chemical engineer and former assistant chemist of the Bureau of Standards, told members of the Institute of Food Technologists at the second day's session of their annual food conference.

The General Motors Corporation's policy of dividing part of the profits of each year -- above a certain minimum -- among salaried employes and officials of the organization was defended and praised in Federal court yesterday by Lammot du Pont and John J. Raskob, directors of the corporation.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 17 -- Dr. Miguel Culciatti, Minister of the Interior, will appear tomorrow before the Chamber of Deputies to detail measures taken by the government to check Nazi propaganda and curb "anti-Argentine activities."
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 16:

Does Thursday morning dawn dark and drear with the mournful knowledge, realized each week anew, that Thursday is maid's night out? Does a vision arise of disheveled dishes piled high in the sink and a supper table bestrewn with crumbs?

CHICAGO, June 17 -- State price control legislation works to the advantage of large corporate and voluntary chains rather than to that of the small independent merchant, Corwin D. Edwards, economist for the anti-trust division of the United States Department of Justice, asserted here today in a speech before 5,000 independent grocers attending the forty-fourth annual convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers at the Palmer House.

BERLIN, June 17 -- Berlin has protested "sharply" to the United States against closure of all German consulates, the official news agency D.N.B. reported tonight after an announcement that "necessary measures" had been ordered against some $450,000,000 worth of United States property in the Reich.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- A major reorganization of the Army Air Corps to provide a greater degree of autonomy and to answer a growing popular demand for a separate air service is being planned by the War Department.

Army Draft Rejections Any day now and for a great many years to come we may expect to see it stated that in the 1941 Selective Draft 52 per cent of all Army candidates were rejected as physically unfit.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The National Broadcasting Company has taken stags to delete those clauses of its contracts with affiliated stations which have provoked criticism from James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Niles Trammell, N.B.C. president, revealed today.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The State Department has issued flat instructions to all its representatives in the field that visas for entry into the United States are not to be given to refugees from Germany and German-occupied territories if the refugees plan to leave close relatives behind.

Jolting Joe DiMaggio was lucky, but the same couldn't be said of his Yankee mates at the Stadium yesterday. A ground ball that was labeled an easy out in the seventh suddenly took a bad hop, hit LuKe Appling on the shoulder and DiMaggio's hitting streak zoomed to thirty consecutive games, an all-time Yankee record.

TORONTO, June 17 (Canadian Press) -- An eighth-inning seven-run outburst gave the Toronto Maple Leafs a 9-5 decision over the Newark Bears in the second game of tonight's double-header, after the International League leaders had gone two extra frames to win the scheduled seven-inning opener, 2-1.

The massing of German and Russian troops along their common border began when these countries occupied Poland and was extended along the Rumanian-Russian border after cession of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina to Russia. The Russians answered each German advance with strategical counter-moves.

Before a distinguished audience that included high American, Canadian and British officials at a dinner in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night. Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King of Canada declared that his country is throwing her entire resources into a "total effort" in, support of Great Britain for the sake of "the common cause of freedom" in North America as well as in all other parts of the world.

Sixty-six awards for participation in Manhattan's recently completed Spring sports campaign were announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics. Twenty-eight major insignia, eight minor letters and thirty sets of freshman numerals were granted by the athletic administration.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 17 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 (AP) -- A wild pitch by Phil Marchildon permitting Gerald Walker to score from third base in the eighth inning shattered a 2-2 tie and gave Cleveland an uphill 3-to-2 victory over the Athletics at Shibe Park, tonight.

A new crosstown bus service along 180th and 181st Streets for residents of Washington Heights will be started next Tuesday as the first line to be established under the franchise that eventually will result in the replacement with buses of all trolley lines in the city.

The strike of municipal service employes at McKeesport, Pa., has presented a situation which other American cities may soon face. How McKeesport solves the problem will be studied in City Halls throughout the country. New York, with its municipally owned subways manned by the Transport Workers Union, has a special interest in the matter.

UNION, N.J., June 17 -- Taking advantage of his nine-stroke handicap, Dr. W.A. Radcliffe, one-time Suburban Golf Club champion, today captured the handsome William, Henry Beers Memorial Trophy in the Metropolitan Golf Association tournament over his home course with a net 62.

Members of The New York Post Unit of the New York Newspaper Guild, C.I.O., joined yesterday in the denunciation of Milton Kaufman, executive vice president of the American Newspaper Guild, for his "presumptuous and completely unwarranted interference" with the C.I.O. auto union's condemnation of the unauthorized North American Aviation Company strike.

The cotton futures market again moved upward yesterday in the face of heavier hedge selling. Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed with net gains of 16 to 21 points, extending their advance for the current upward movement to more than 1 cent a pound for all he active deliveries except the July.

The plan proposed by Park Commissioner Robert Moses to extend the Battery Park seawall sixty feet to recompense for two acres of park land taken for approaches to the Battery-Brooklyn Tunnel would increase marine traffic congestion and might affect the flow and direction of tidal waters to the detriment of shipping, objectors to the plan declared yesterday at a hearing before Lieut. Col. L.S. Dillon, United States Engineer Corps, at 90 Church Street.

ROME, June 17 -- All debts owed to United States citizens and all shares, property and other goods belonging to Americans were ordered blocked in an official decree issued today which, set forth the general outlines of Italy's retaliation against the freezing of Italian funds in the United States.

BOSTON, June 17 (AP) -- Hai Price Headley'a Third Covey, winner of the Puritan Handicap at Suffolk Downs, chalked up his second consecutive stake triumph for the course today before some 18,000 fans when he won the Bunker Hill Handicap, $5,000 added mile, which featured the holiday program.

Voluntary regulation of consumer credit through larger down payments and shorter maturities, rather than Federal control, was emphasized yesterday at the annual convention of the National Retail Credit Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

Donald M. Nelson, director of purchases of the Office of Production Management, is calling for "more room" for defense. Mr. Nelson makes two points. He says first, that in order to overtake the German military machine we must step up the rate of defense spending to $35,000,000,000 a year, contrasted with a rate of $6,000,000,000 in the current fiscal year and one of $15,500,000,000 scheduled for the year beginning next July 1.

A personal message of good will from President Manuel Avila Camacho of Mexico to the people of the United States was brought here yesterday by Dr. Salvador Mendoza, attorney and president of the Mexican Friends of the American People, who came to New York to conduct a round-table discussion of hemisphere solidarity under the auspices of the hospitality committee of the Department of Cultural and Commercial Relations between the American Republics.

TRENTON, June 17 -- By a vote of 3 to 2, with two of the four Republicans joining Governor Charles Edison, Democrat, the State House Commission rejected today all bids for installation of voting machines in Hudson County, Democratic stronghold.

LONDON, June 17 -- The British Navy will protect the trade route on which the Robin Moor was sunk, A.V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, said today. Speaking before the Royal Empire Society he said the fleet had been facing an ordeal probably without precedent in naval history in the last year.

Memories of New York World's Fair were aroused yesterday as a time capsule, duplicate of the one buried in Flushing Meadows in 1938, was presented to the Hayden Planetarium by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company. Unlike its predecessor, this cylindrical copper crypt will remain above ground in the view of the public.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17 -- The determination of one government in exile and another government a war to see it through, no matter what the cost, was expressed today at the 194th commencement of Princeton University, when Crown Princess Juliana of the Netherlands and William L. Mackenzie King Prime Minister of Canada, received honorary degrees of Doctor of Laws.

An underwriting group headed by A.G. Backer Co., Inc., will offer today 20,000 shares of 4 1/4 per cent cumulative preferred stock, series A, of the Heyden Chemical Corporation. The shares, of $100-par value, will be priced at $100.50 and accrued dividends from June 1.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- A limited number of Selective Service trainees will be permitted to enlist in the Regular Army for service with the parachute troops, under new regulations made public today by the War Department. Heretofore, this service has been reserved exclusively for Regular Army soldiers who have' already, demonstrated all-around proficiency.
