WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The demands by Germany and Italy for the closing of United States consulates in their territories and those under their occupation brought to still narrower dimensions tonight the line separating the United States and the Axis from an outright rupture of diplomatic relations.
MONTREAL, June 19 (AP) -- The Royals snapped a four-game losing streak by beating Newark tonight, 6-5, in an International League thriller.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), June 19 -- Dutch Indian shares were soft in today's trading, which was light. Amsterdam Trading lost 7 1/2 points to 390; Amsterdam Rubber 4 1/4 to 241; Royal Dutch 3 to 225 1/4; Philips 1 3/8 to 205 1/4 and Unilever 2 3/8 to 112 3/8.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 19 (AP) -- Forty-five birdies and an eagle flew off the blazing clubs of sixteen of the country's top-flight professionals today as Sammy Byrd, former Yankee outfielder, and his partner, Johnny Bulla, flashed into the lead in the first round of the 126-hole Inverness four-ball golf matches.
The Pennsylvania Railroad announced yesterday that it had ordered 150,000 tons of rail, its largest purchase of the kind since 1931. The rail will provide about 700 miles of track.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (AP) -- Cleveland's league-leading Indians blasted three Philadelphia pitchers for nineteen hits, including three home runs, to swamp the Athletics, 12 to 1, today for a clean sweep of their three-game series.
BERLIN, June 19 (AP) -- D.N.B. issued this statement today on the German Government's action against United States consular and American Express Company employes:

CHICAGO, June 19 -- In a decision which may have large effects on retailing, Federal Judge Philip L. Sullivan ruled today that the Fair Labor Standards Act did not apply to 1,000 employes of warehouses operated by Goldblatt Brothers, Inc.

Applicants flocked to the British Consulate General's offices, 25 Broadway, yesterday in answer to Great Britain's call for American radio and other technicians to enroll in the new Civilian Technical Corps to maintain and repair airplane radiolocators and the highly technical equipment of the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Extension for another two years of Presidential power to devalue the dollar further would completely nullify the constitutional principle of legislative "control of the purse" and carry a threat of disastrous inflation, Professor Edwin Walter Kemmerer of Princeton told the Senate Banking Committee today.

BERLIN, June 19 (UP) -- Authorized Nazi spokesmen denied flatly today that a German invasion of Russia had started or that border clashes had occurred, although they admitted that a "tremendous flood of rumors" had burst out concerning Nazi-Soviet relations.

The enrollment of 64,000 volunteer air-raid wardens, to begin the work of giving New York City the same civilian defense that London employs, will begin at 9 o'clock this morning at each of the eighty-two police precincts in the city. It marks the beginning of public participation in a plan carefully worked out by Mayor La Guardia and Commissioner Valentine, the latter in his capacity as Police Defense Coordinator.

LONDON, June 19 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England today showed a further rise in note circulation to a new record of u637,531,000. Constantly growing currency demands due to the British war efforts show no sign of any let-up.

The Independent Club of the Five Towns (Hewlett, Cedarhurst, Woodmere, Inwood and Lawrence, L.I.) made public yesterday an "open reply" to the Five Towns branch of the America First Committee, challenging the committee to disavow Charles A. Lindbergh and other spokesmen for the committee.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Owners of independent radio stations affiliated with the national networks have overwhelmingly denounced the new rules of the Federal Communications Commission as injurious to broadcasting, the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee was told at today's hearing on Senator White's resolution for suspension pending an inquiry.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- An intimation that the National Guard would be mustered out of Federal service at the end of its ordered year of training was given in military circles today while officials maintained strict silence as to any formal decision on this question.

The spectacular heavyweight championship battle between Joe Louis and Billy Conn, which went into ring history Wednesday night, left in its wake confusion and disappointment for some of the challengers who are swarming around the Brown Bomber.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Roosevelt signed an executive order authorizing government workers on cantonments, air fields and fortifications in the Canal Zone and Alaska to work longer than eight hours a day. His callers included Secretary Stimson, Chairman George of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Representative Joseph A. Gavagan of New York, Gerald Cruise of the New York State Power Authority and John Blandford Jr., assistant budget director.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Parachute troops became recognized today as a permanent unit of the Army when the Parachute Group School at Fort Benning was put on a continuing basis. It will train 1,400 parachutists a year.

LONDON, June 19 -- A measure to impose a wider and more inflexible price control on consumer goods and a more thorough control of middleman profits was read a second time in the House of Commons today after Oliver Lyttleton, President of the Board of Trade, had explained that it was part of a "large design and extends over all the financial, industrial, commercial and social activities of the country."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 19 -- Doubles by Captain-elect Jim Carton and Tom Whelan gave Yale the margin to beat Harvard, 3--1, today at Soldiers Field. The contest was a continuation of yesterday's Harvard Class Day game which was suspended after four innings because of a thunderstorm, and it gave the Elis a two-game sweep in this year's series.

Milton Kaufman, executive vice president of the American Newspaper Guild, C.I.O., made public yesterday his reply to R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers and national vice president of the C.I.O., who had accused Mr. Kaufman of "presumptuous and completely unwarranted interference" in the affairs of the auto union.
ROME, June 19 -- The Italian Government ordered today the closing by July 15 of all United States consular offices in Italy and her possessions and in territory under occupation by Italian troops.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., June 19 -- Leading a small but select field, Miss Virginia Guilfoil of Syracuse established a new women's competitive course record and won the qualifying medal in the seventh annual invitation tournament of the Briar Hills Golf Club today with a card of 38, 43 -- 81.

After a lengthy wrangle the Board of Estimate adopted a resolution yesterday approving a low rent public housing project to be known as Amsterdam Houses on a site at West Sixty-second Street between Amsterdam and West End Avenues.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- No general exemption has yet been granted to European neutrals from the general freezing order affecting the funds of Continental countries, the Treasury Department stated today, but negotiations are going on with the diplomatic representatives here of Portugal, Finland, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and Russia.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Partial revenge for treatment accorded them by the Cubs on Brooklyn's first visit here came to the Dodgers today. Pounding: Claude Passeau and Vance Page for fifteen hits and twenty-three total bases, they took the series finale, 9-4, to give Kirby Higbe his eighth triumph of the campaign.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 19 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Culminating negotiations which began on March 11 and which were interrupted by a thirty-day nation-wide coal strike, the United Mine Workers of America and eight associations of bituminous coal operators in the Northern Appalachian area signed today a two-year wage agreement.

CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) -- Hogs advanced 10 to 20 cents, touching a new high for the past several years at $10.25, in active trading on the livestock market today. Cattle and sheep shared the hog upturn. Livestock men said reduced receipts were largely responsible for the gain in swine prices. Arrivals at principal markets this week were considerably below both the same periods of last week and last year.

WOODMERE, L.I., June 19 -- Opposed by an adversary whose skill she could at no time discount, Mrs. Millicent Hirsh Lang required three sets to assert her superiority over Mrs. Louise Raymond Ganzenmuller in the women's New York State clay court tennis championship at the Woodmere Country Club today.

MONTAUK, L.I., June 19 -- The wind was right, the tide was O.K., and the weather was perfect at daybreak this morning, but we joined the dejected ranks of the other surf casters who had arisen long before breakfast in hope of getting a striped bass, and finally went to lunch without realizing our desires.

Members of the New York Newspaper Guild, C.I.O., reversed last night the action of a previous membership meeting in condemning the use of troops to end the North American Aviation Company strike at Inglewood, Calif., and, while upholding the right to strike, condemned the Inglewood strike as a subversive abuse of labor's right effected by "the tactics of Communists, Nazis and Fascists."

The Sterling National Bank and Trust Company has made building loans of $350,000 and $320,000 on six-story apartments to be erected on West 190th Street. The former was made with Carlton Estates, Inc. on the southeast corner of Fort Washington Avenue, and the latter with the Overlook Realty Corporation on the building to go up on the south side of West 190th Street, 94 feet east of Fort Washington Avenue.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 19 -- The campaign for a national referendum, or vote of the people, on the question of war is being pushed by isolationist groups in Congress. Claiming that the American people have had no opportunity to vote officially on this "greatest of all issues," these groups propose a national roll-call in which all eligible voters would participate.

Large quantities of scrap metal, including aluminum, copper, brass and bronze, were sold at public auction yesterday at the Army Base at First Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, in a two-and-one-half hour sale conducted by Lieut. Col. J.B. Canfield, salvage officer.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The combined assets of 218 operating electric and gas utilities concerns in thirty-nine registered public utility holding company systems aggregated $11,498,983,735 on Dec. 31, 1940, according to a report today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
LONDON, June 19 (UP) -- Demands in Parliament for a comprehensive statement on the mysterious parachute arrival of Rudolf Hess on a Scottish farm were firmly refused by the Government today.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 19 -- The campaign for a national referendum, or vote of the people, on the question of war is being pushed by isolationist groups in Congress. Claiming that the American people have had no opportunity to vote officially on this "greatest of all issues," these groups propose a national roll-call in which all eligible voters would participate.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 19 -- The special convocation of the University of Oxford held at the Harvard commencement today, when the honorary degree of Doctor of Civil Law was conferred on President Roosevelt in absentia, was heralded by a fanfare of trumpets in accord with the ancient ritual of the English university.

"Out of the Fog," Warner Brothers adaptation of the Irwin Shaw play, "The Gentle People," will open this morning at the Strand. The drama co-stars Ida Lupino and John Garfield and includes Thomas Mitchell, Eddie Albert, John Qualen, Aline MacMahon and George Tobias among its supporting players.

The Yankees turned on their tormentors, the White Sox, at the Stadium yesterday and gave them thorough lacing for the two defeat Chicago had administered in the other games of the series. The Bombers were blasting as if they had the new Sperry bombsight, and flattened the, Sox, 7 to 2.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Dutch Leonard was in form today and the Senators came up with all kinds of hitting to defeat the Browns, 12 to 0, and even their abbreviated series at a game apiece.

HILLSIDE, N.J., June 19 -- Edward Earle, 14 years old, of 1041 Fairview Place, and William Mullican, 13, of 1537 Franklin Street, were reported recovering today from gunshot wounds as Adolph Benitz, 69-year-old garden fancier, who shot them and seven other boy. pupils of the Hillside Junior High School yesterday, was arraigned before Police Recorder Ellsworth J. Sterner on a charge of atrocious assault.

The Appellate Division unanimously approved yesterday the validity of an amendment to the constitution of the New York Stock Exchange permitting under certain circumstances the use of the principal of the Exchange's gratuity fund to reduce the quarterly assessments against members of the Exchange under the institution's gratuity plan.

Henry Street Settlement receives 550,779 from the estate of Miss Lillian D. Wald, founder of the settle-ment, it was disclosed yesterday when the estate tax appraisal fixed the value of the residuary estate which Miss Wald left to the institution Her estate was appraised at $92.094 gross and $87,919 net Miss Wald died on Sept. 1. 1940, at her home in Westport, Conn.
PITTSBURGH, June 19 -- Coming out of a heavy slumber after their prolonged game last night, the Giants and Pirates renewed, hostilities today and fell upon each other with considerable violence.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Defense supply contracts awarded today by the War Department totaled $25,177,611.63. Among these were the following, not previously published, which went to firms in the New York area:

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Communism as an issue before American labor was denounced today by the American Federation of Labor and Representative Woodruff of Michigan, who demanded that Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, be removed from the National Defense Mediation Board if he "continues to oppose the purging of subversive agents from the labor unions of the United States."

When I went to Berchtesgaden, Spring was making a late debut. Dr. Sallet, a Harvard graduate, the American press representative of the Foreign Office, had come with me from Berlin, and also Dr. Frolich, another Harvard man. We rode from the air field to a spacious mountain hotel where, on a sunlighted dining veranda, Dr. Paul Schmidt, the celebrated interpreter, was waiting for us.

The demand for most classes of traefer meats in yesterday's trading was only fair to slow. The market on steer hinds and ribs was about steady. Fresh pork trade was moderately active at uneven prices. The market on veal hindsaddles had a weak undertone. Lamb prices were uneven, carcasses weighing from 42-50 pounds brought strong prices, but the lighter weights were steady to weak.
BERLIN, June 19 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of June 14 shows the following changes for the week, in thousands of reichs-mark:

More than 500 persons jeered the names of foreign dictators and references to unnamed "American appeasers," at a rally held during the noon hour yesterday at the north end of Times Square under the auspices of Fight for Freedom, Inc. This organization is composed of leaders from every field of American life whose aim is "to aid Great Britain in every way."

THOSE who witnessed the Louis-Conn collision at the Polo Grounds the other night saw boxing at its best. A great crowd, a fine night, a whale of a fight for the heavyweight championship of the world. Two good men and true were in the ring. Make it three. The referee, Eddie Joseph, did his work in shipshape form, too. Referees as well as fighters can ruin an evening for the onlookers.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Continuing to advance, department-store sales in the week ended June 14 were 13 per cent higher than in the corresponding week of 1940, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Last week the board reported an increase of 6 per cent (revised).

BERLIN, June 19 -- Germany requested the United States today to withdraw its consular officials and close its consulates in Germany and German-occupied territory by July 15 on the ground that their activities, of a "grave" nature, had proved inimical to the interests of the Reich.

Competition yesterday for the new issue of $15,000,000 of New York Central Railroad one-to-ten year equipment trust certificates was restricted to two groups. Salomon Brothers Hutzler and associates received the award on their bid of 100.539 for 2 1/4s, an interest cost basis of about 2.15 per cent.
LONDON, June 19 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill flatly refused today to debate the shipping situation publicly in the House of Commons.

The basic real estate tax rate in New York will be $2.80 for each $100 of assessed value in the coming fiscal year, provided the City Council enacts a local law making the proceeds of the business tax available to the general fund, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick has calculated.
A gala benefit entertainment for British war aid, called "Hands Across the Sea," was given in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor last night.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- After having shown by testimony and documents the payment of thousands of dollars to Bookniga Corporation of New York by an organ of the Soviet Government, the government's case against the company and its officers for failure to register with the Secretary of State was momentarily imperiled today.
Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned upward yesterday after an easier start and recovered almost all of the previous day's losses. The close was at net gains of 13 to 17 points.
A gala benefit entertainment for British war aid, called "Hands Across the Sea," was given in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor last night.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- After having shown by testimony and documents the payment of thousands of dollars to Bookniga Corporation of New York by an organ of the Soviet Government, the government's case against the company and its officers for failure to register with the Secretary of State was momentarily imperiled today.

Concerned over the sharp drop in enrollment for the study of French here since the formation of the Vichy government, New York City teachers of French plan to wage a campaign to induce high school students to continue the study of this language for its "cultural values," Mrs. Sarah Wolfson Lorge, chairman of the French Department at James Monroe High School, announced yesterday.

The construction of the 58,000-ton super-dreadnoughts Maine and New Hampshire, two United States Navy warships which will be the mightiest fighting ships ever to be constructed, is expected to begin in December, 1942, it was revealed here yesterday.

IT was a hot day and Coach Bing Miller of the Detroit ball club was urged to keep cool. But he couldn't do that when the name of J.J. Dykes, manager of the White Sox, was tossed into the casual conversation.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- President Roosevelt put all petroleum products under export controls today and forbade shipments from Atlantic Coast ports to any countries except the British Empire, Egypt, and those in the Western Hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The War Department announced today that defense contracts amounting to $9,198,541.43 had been awarded. Included among the large list of awards were the following, not previously published, to concerns in the New York area.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 20 -- Qualifying in the Cherry Valley Club's annual invitation best-ball golf tourney today, Ray Billows, former New York State champion, and his partner, F.B. Hamilton of Cherry Valley, scored a 67 to lead sixty-five other pairs.

The Army last night staged a spectacular test of its aerial photographic equipment, dropping flash bombs from a plane at the height of 8,000 feet over the bay and North and East Rivers, off the Battery, Brooklyn Heights and midtown Manhattan.

"The Duty of the Church in This Time of Crisis" will be the general subject of many sermons preached in the churches of the city tomorrow. Clergymen will ask every parishioner to contribute to the campaign being carried on by the United Service Organization for National Defense, in which Protestants, Catholics and Jews are participating.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 20 -- The news that posters have appeared throughout Finland calling up all men born in the year 1897 has created a sensation in Stockholm, and the Aftonbladet says in a headline, "Finland is fully mobilized."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 20 -- Constance Bennett, at one time one of the screen's most highly paid stars, was signed today by Metro for a supporting role in the current Greta Garbo picture and will receive an estimated $15,000 for the engagement.

TOKYO, June 20 -- New davelopments in the international situation resulting from Russian-German tension and the Turkish-German friendship pact are watched by Japan with keen attention because of their inevitable effect on Japan's own policy.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Immediately after word was received early this afternoon of the disappearance off Portsmouth, N.H., of the submarine 0-9, Admiral Harold R. Stark, Chief of Naval Operations, ordered all rescue efforts set in motion.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- While wheat borrowed considerable strength from soy beans and other commodities today there was no material pressure on the market and closing sales on the Board of Trade here were at gains of 7/8 cent a bushel. A report that the Department of Agriculture would issue a revised estimate on Monday, on the Winter wheat crop in nine leading Central Western States tended to restrict pressure.

VICHY, France, June 20 -- In Syria, according to the French communique tonight, the defending forces, despite continuous action without hope of relief, are still holding their own and the assailants were not much nearer Damascus at the latest news.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 20 -- A master plan for the home defense of Westchester County, entailing creation of an operating organization of 15,000 civilians, was announced tonight by the Westchester County Defense Council at a meeting in the County Office Building here of Mayors and defense council chairmen of the cities, towns and villages of the county.

BERLIN, June 20 (UP) -- V.G. Dekanozoff, Russian Ambassador to Berlin, was revealed today to have visited the Foreign Office Wednesday at the peak of a flood of foreign rumors regarding relations between Germany and the Soviet Union.

NEWARK, N.J., June 20 -- Seven more Italian seamen, Captain Giovannl Maglio and six members of the crew of the Arsa, were convicted in Federal Court here tonight on a charge of tampering with the machinery of the vessel in violation of a law adopted by Congress in 1917.
BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., June 20 -- All favorites advanced as two rounds were completed in the seventh annual women's invitation tournament over the Briar Hills Golf Club course today.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Sears Roebuck Co. has begun the distribution of a "Summer money savers" sales booklet to mail order customers that cuts prices on a number of items not included in the big mid-Summer sale "flyer" appearing late last month.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 20 -- County Executive William F. Bleakley of Westchester announced today that he Would resign from his county position between July 7 and Aug. 1, to accept appointment as counsel to the Joint Legislative Committee on Reapportionment and that he would be succeeded as County Executive by Herbert C. Gerlach of Ossining.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., June 20 -- Field meets, entertainments and theatrical attractions vied with intensive military training to hold the interest of the citizen soldiers of Brig. Gen. Henry W. Baird's Fourth Armored Division at Pine Camp cantonment this week.

SHANGHAI, June 20 -- Japan's establishment of monopoly control systems in Manchuria and North China is slowly but surely ruining both countries, and unless changed will completely bankrupt the rich northern areas within two years, according to foreign business men and travelers who have been making detailed inspection trips in the hope of increasing their imports.

Headlines in the morning papers brought home to the New York breakfast table yesterday the fact that civilians over and under the draft age, or otherwise ineligible for active service, can still "do their bit" in civilian defense, and the result was a crowding of police stations by willing volunteers, even before the scheduled opening hour of 9 A. M.

A new Pulitzer prize in journalism for an outstanding example of news photography and the division of a present category into two representing telegraphic reporting of national affairs and telegraphic reporting of international affairs were announced yesterday by Dean Carl W. Ackerman, secretary of the advisory board of the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University, which makes recommendations for the awards.

FORT MONMOUTH, June 20 -- The new replacement center theatre, with seating accommodations for 1,000, will be formally opened on Sunday evening. Soldiers of the post will be guests of the National Broadcasting Company, which will broadcast the regular Sunday night program of Phil Spitalny and his "Hour of Charm" orchestra from the theatre stage.

FORT DIX, N.J., June 20 -- The entire Eighty-seventh Brigade was ordered "confined to the area" to the week-end today by Brig. Gen Ralph K. Robertson, brigrade commander, to enable the men to "police" their cantonment area. More than 4,000 troops were affected by the order.
Archbishop Francis J. Spellman announced yesterday the transfer of twenty-six assistants and the assignment of twenty-four newly ordained priests in the Archdiocese of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Roundlot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on June 7 amounted to 2,311,230 shares, compared with 1,565,740 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: There has been much argument as to which players are the best at their positions in the major leagues. One nomination about whom I have no doubts whatsoever is George (Birdie) Tebbetts, the catcher of the Detroit Tigers.
RED BANK, N.J., June 20 -- Combat troops of Fort Hancock returned to their barracks at 2 o'clock this morning after games in which they cooperated with the Navy's inshore patrol off Sandy Hook.

Stamping as false the oft-heard expression that "a democracy ceases to be a democracy when it goes to war," Sir Wilfred Arthur Green, President of the Court of Appeals of England and Wales, yesterday declared that he would "like to see a general come into my court and interfere."

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- President Roosevelt's special message condemning the German sinking of the steamship Robin Moor was accepted by his leaders in Congress today as a signal for future drastic action to deal with the general menace of which the President said that incident was only a part.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., June 20 -- With the assertion that "we are substantially in war now and before Autumn will be actually at war," Leon Fraser, president of the First National Bank of the City of New York and former president of the Bank for International Settlements, prefaced tonight an address in the Queensbury Hotel here before 250 Warren and Washington County bankers and guests and officials of the New York State Bankers Association.

MACON, Ga., June 19 -- Two battalions have completed their thirteen-week basic training course at Camp Wheeler. The battalions, said to be the first in the nation to finish the course, are beginning specialized training at Camp Blanding, Fla.

The second issue of The Bridge, magazine published by English children evacuated to this country for the duration of the war, will be published next week, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Evelyn F. Turner, founder and editor of the publication, at the magazine's offices, 17 East Forty-ninth Street.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 20 -- A corporal's guard of the Grand Army of the Republic in New Jersey, three of the eight veterans left in the State, convened here today for the seventy-fourth annual encampment of a State organization that once sent as many as 8,000 to reunion bivouacs.
BUFFALO, N.Y., June 20 (AP) -- The Bisons beat the Jersey Giants again tonight, taking the third game of the series, 5 to 3, behind the three-hit pitching of Earl Cook.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), June 20 -- Owing to the hesitation of entering fresh commitments over the week end the share market today was very dull with slight offerings, especially of Dutch Indian issues. Amsterdam Trading was 4 1/4 lower at 385 3/4;

LONDON, Saturday, June 21 -- After the ninth successive night of Royal Air Force bombing raids on Western Germany over Thursday night, the air war between Britain and the Reich was still -- in so far as Nazi attacks on this country were concerned -- comparatively quiet early today.

Business and industrial companies throughout the country have contributed to date $564,000 to the United Service Organizations fund, it was announced yesterday by John W. Hanes, chairman of the USO's national corporations committee, at a luncheon at the Recess Club, 60 Broadway.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by fifty-two municipalities aggregates $29,539,580, compared with $18,544,313 for this week. The weekly average for new offerings for the year to date now stands at $35,837,897.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- Frankie Parker, who conquered Don Mc Neill only five days ago to win the St. Louis Triple A tournament, did it again today to reach the final of the national clay courts tennis tournament.

More restriction of steel for commercial uses rather than the Office of Production Management's "fantastic" scheme to expand production by 10,000,000 tons is necessary unless the United States wishes to face loss of the war, according to an article by J. Leonard Replogle, director of steel in the 1918 War Industries Board, in the current issue of Iron Age.
LONDON, Saturday, June 21 (AP) -- Morning newspapers featured today President Roosevelt's Robin Moor message, and editorial comment expressed hearty appproval.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 20 -- A woman has been chosen for the first time as a winner of one of the annual journalistic achievement awards of the National Headliners' Club, it was announced today. Honors also will go to twelve men, a weekly newspaper and a news reel company.

HAZLETON, Pa., June 20 -- With the formal signing of a contract between the anthracite operators and mine workers, here today, the Anthracite Board of Conciliation began its thirty-ninth year in the settling of labor grievances within the framework of a collective agreement.

Most motorists who park in midtown Manhattan, whether at the curb or in offstreet facilities, walk from their cars to their destination and eight out of ten who complete their journey on foot walk five minutes or less from car to door, according to a statement issued yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.

WITH BRITISH FORCES IN COASTAL SECTOR OF SYRIA, June 18 (Delayed) (UP) -- The British Navy appeared today to be well on its way toward winning the war in Syria, or at least contributing heavily to the achievements of the Imperial forces.

HOLLYWOOD, June 20 (AP) -- Charles A. Lindbergh said tonight the alternative to a negotiated peace in Europe was "either a Hitler victory or a prostrate Europe and possibly a prostrate America as well."

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- The American Meat Institute, one of twelve defendants in a Federal anti-trust case, denied today that it or its members "at any time ever under any circumstances suppressed competitive trading in sheep and lambs on the Chicago livestock market."

Apparently the Yankees never heard the bell signal the end of batting practice. They kept flailing away at Bobo Newsom and Archie McKain for seventeen hits that totaled twenty-nine bases at the Stadium yesterday and rolled right over the Tigers, 14 to 4.

LONDON, June 20 -- Together with the announcement that total British, Allied and neutral ship losses for May were 461,328 tons, the Admiralty today published a revision of the loss schedule from May, 1940, to April, 1941, in which the monthly losses were revised from 5,000 to 100,000 tons in alteration of the previously published figures for these months.

A few months ago, during an especially severe wave of defense strikes, demands arose that Congress "do something." In a subsequent lull in defense strikes these demands were largely forgotten. Nothing was done. The inaction proved costly. In the next wave of defense strikes some of the very people who had been most confident that no new legislation was needed suddenly began clamoring for such drastic and dangerous remedies as factory seizure and compulsory arbitration.

One Fund Ends As philanthropic Foundations go, the Garland Fund was a modest enterprise, but its history of twenty years is a record of many good causes. It started out with something under a million dollars and through capable management succeeded in accumulating total resources of two millions.
BOSTON, June 20 (AP) -- Although outhit 11 to 7, by the St. Louis Browns, the Boston Red Sox took the series opener today, 4 to 2, making better use of their blows.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- With only 4,000 salable bead of hogs arriving in the livestock market today, buyers bid vigorously for offerings and prices advanced about 25 cents to new peaks for the past four years. A top of $10.50 was paid freely for choice swine, highest since Ocober, 1937. The average cost went above $10, more than $1 over the objective announced by the government when Federal purchasing of dressed pork started.

ST. LOUIS, June 20 -- Lashing into the opposition with an eighth-inning surprise attack, the Giants tonight floored the National League-leading Cardinals by a score of 6 to 2 in the opening clash of a four-game series.

Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. ordered yesterday in General Sessions, over vigorous protests of the defense lawyers, that both sides must sum up the evidence on Monday in the trial of William Solomon, a Tammany Assembly district leader, and Charles H. Mullens, former Assistant State Controller, on a bribery indictment.
CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- The United States Army gave John Dungan Rigney back to baseball today.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 20 -- Tugging at anchor or berthed in slips here tonight were nineteen yachts ready to start tomorrow on the Storm Trysail Club's race down to Hampton Roads, Va., which is the big ocean contest of the year.

The Columbia Broadcasting System submitted to ASCAP yesterday a counter proposal -- covering a period expiring Dec. 31, 1949, with a five-year extension at rates and terms to be arbitrated, if necessary -- for the use of ASCAP music on the Columbia network and the eight CBS-owned and operated stations.

LONDON, June 20 -- The lavishness with which THE NEW YORK TIMES presents ''All the news that's fit to print," especially in the Sunday issues, has excited the envious admiration of British publishing circles, particularly those editors who, because of the rationing of newsprint, must confine themselves to thin, densely packed four-page papers.

The public-spirited are thoughtfully volunteering for duty as airraid wardens. Should the unhappy day ever come when they are called to active service, and should a warden stop at your home-or shelter -- for a few minutes, give him a slice of bread generously spread with butter or margarine.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Bluntly accusing the German Government of acting as an "international outlaw" engaged in "piracy," President Roosevelt today branded the sinking of the American ship Robin Moor on May 21 as an attempt to intimidate the United States and drive its commerce from the seas as part of a Nazi scheme for world conquest.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 20 -- President of the Chamber of Deputies, Dr. Jose Luis Cantilo late last night appointed a committee of seven members to Investigate Nazi-Fascist and other foreign activities in Argentina.

Whirlaway, accepted as the 3-year-old champion, will run again this afternoon at Aqueduct, facing five rivals in the Dwyer Stakes, which is expected to gross more than $12,000 in value. Robert Morris and Market Wise, strong rivals in the Belmont Stakes and Kentucky Derby, respectively, now will have an opportunity of showing what they can do with a weight advantage.

The National Power and Light Company, an intermediary holding unit in the Electrical Bond and Share Company system, announced yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan looking toward the liquidation of its outstanding $6 preferred stock by offering to holders of such stock its common stock holdings in the Houston Lighting and Power Company.
Langdon B. Wood Co. have been permitted to continue as a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange for a period not exceeding forty-five days from June 15, despite the death of their senior partner.

MOSCOW, June 20 (AP) -- There was no outward indication in Moscow today that Soviet Russia expects an invasion, but the government newspaper Izvestia declared that "neither through the forests nor the steppes, mountains nor seas will the enemy ever step across the forbidden boundary."

Comments on President's Roosevelt's message on the Robin Moor were issued here last night for the governing committee of the Keep America Out of War Congress and by the national headquarters of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies.
WOODMERE, L.I., June 20 -- With play in the singles at a standstill, the semi-finals of the doubles were held in the women's New York State tennis championships today at the Woodmere club.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., June 20 -- The Second Battalion of the 207th Coast Artillery, New York's old Seventh Regiment, will move to Fernandina, Fla., Monday for the second time to engage in firing of .30 and .50-caliber machine guns.

It is reported that the demands of Germany on Russia are autonomy of the Ukraine under German protection, the demobilization of the Red Army, German control of the Baltic shipyards and a guarantee that Russian heavy industry will be devoted to German use. There is still no means of confirming that these are actually the German demands or even, despite the enormous smoke screen of rumor, that any new German demands have been made.

CINCINNATI, June 20 -- Hugh Casey today gave a repeat performance of the act he put on at Crosley Field last month, but it wasn't done at the request or with the approval of the Reds or their 5,845 followers who were present.
Lieutenant Howard Joseph Abbott, who was in command of the submarine 0-9, had a record of naval service on surface and submersible vessels in many parts of the world.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- In full settlement of damage claims filed against Branch 1 of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers as a result of the forcible entry of the Apex Hosiery Company's plant here in May, 1937, and a subsequent seven-week sitdown strike, the union has arranged to pay the company $110,000, one of the largest damage claims ever paid by a labor organization.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Treasury issued tonight general licenses releasing Sweden and Switzerland and their nationals in this country from the executive order of a week ago freezing the assets in the United States of all Continental European countries.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- President Roosevelt issued an Executive order today under which the Navy and the Coast Guard Geodetic Survey traded three vessels each for the duration of the emergency. The Survey gave to the Navy its vessels Guide, Pioneer and Discover, complete with all supplies and appurtenances, and receives the Andradite, YP-96 and Jamestown.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Hope H. Barroll Jr., a Baltimore radio station executive, asserted today that the large networks had used coercion to "force their affiliates to do their bidding." The manager of WFBR gave this testimony after four owners of small stations had told the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee that new rules promulgated by the Federal Communications Commission threatened their connections with networks and might damage their financial position.
BERLIN, June 20 (AP) -- The German High Command ed this communique today:...

PALO ALTO, Calif., June 20 -- Giant Archie Harris, great Negro athlete, from the University of Indiana, cloaked himself in international glory today by bettering the world record in the discus throw trials at the National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field championships.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 20 -- Strapping Jim Knott, one-time Yale oarsman, today flashed a two-over-par 72 on the Nassau course to give him and his partner, Jimmy Walker (not the ex-Mayor), the medal in the qualifying round of the thirty-ninth annual invitation tournament at the famous old lay out where Jerry Travers, one of golf's outstanding figures, got his start.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, June 11 -- In the government palace, which seems oddly like a Spanish villa set on the banks of the Mississippi, the new soldier-President of Paraguay and his professor-Foreign Minister explained yesterday their "national revolution," as it is called, and some of its aspirations.

BRUNSWICK, June 20 -- The nominations of John L. Baxter, '16, of Brunswick, and United States Senator Ralph O. Brewster, '09, to the board of overseers were reported to the annual meeting of the Bowdoin General Alumni Association today.

The State's chief witness in the perjuhy trial of Morris U. Schappes, suspended City College English tutor and former Communist, became slightly confused in General Sessions yesterday as defense counsel examined him regarding notes made at a college Communist meeting, which were produced as written evidence to confirm the writness's story that he was himself a former Communist.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The prospective oil shortage on the Atlantic Coast was ascribed today to diversion to British use of part of the tanker fleet which normally carries oil from Southwestern fields to Eastern seaboard points.

Appointments to standing committees of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America by Will H. Hays, president of the organization, were announced yesterday at the regular quarterly meeting of the association's board of directors at 28 West Forty-fourth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- Leaders of the Philadelphia chapter of Labor's Non-Partisan League repudiated today the latest attack by John L. Lewis, national chairman, on the Roosevelt Administration for its handling of West Coast strikes, including the use of troops in the North American Aviation Corporation walkout.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 20 -- The countries of Central Europe from Slovakia to Sweden were reported today to be making emergency preparations to face any eventuality arising from the prevailing fears of an imminent war between Germany and the Soviet Union.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. House of the Plaza are in Barnstable, Mass., for a week before going to Calais, Me., for the Summer.

In the world-wide guessing game on what's going on in the minds of Hitler and Stalin, two highly pertinent questions seem to be overlooked. In the first place, supposing the tension is real, is it only a clash between the two dictators, or is it complicated by a contest within both regimes?

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Senate, without a record vote, adopted today a House amendment of a World War law to give the President almost unlimited authority to regulate or prohibit the movement into or out of the country of both citizens and aliens.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Ford Motor Company today signed a contract with the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) covering some 130,000 employes in plants all over the United States. About 85,000 are in the River Rouge plant, largest automobile factory in the world.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Six separate motions for a directed verdict of acquittal in the trial of the Bookniga Corporation of New York for failure to register with the Secretary of State as propaganda agents of a foreign principal were denied this afternoon by Justice F. Dickinson Letts in the District of Columbia Federal Court.

The five-story tenement at 592 Second Avenue, near East Thirtysecond Street, has been sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank and will be replaced by a one-story taxpayer which has been leased from the plans. The Unimer Realty Corporation, represented by J. Howard Katz, attorney, is the buyer.

DARIEN, Conn., June 20 -- Top ranking hunters and jumpers of the metropolitan district shared the spotlight with entries from Mrs. Sallie Jones-Sexton's Bryn Du Farm of Granville, Ohio, as the fifteenth annual two-day Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show opened today on the club's spacious grounds.

In one of several leases of business space along Madison and Park Avenues reported yesterday Gloria Swanson, the former motion picture star, took a suite of offices in 501 Madison Avenue for Multiprises, Inc., of which she is president.

Katharine Cornell's revival of Shaw's treatise on the medical profession, "The Doctor's Dilemma," will wind up its season at the Shubert tonight, and at the same time "Johnny Belinda" will end its engagement at the Longacre. The two closings will reduce the number of Broadway shows to thirteen.

AKRON, Ohio, June 20 (AP) -- Major tire companies plan to set up retreading stations in large cities to help take up the slack occasioned by the government-ordered curtailment of rubber consumption, rubber men said today.

High ranking military and naval officers and persons prominent in civil defense work from this area have been invited to be the guests of Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of the Stadium Concerts, and Mrs. Pierpont Morgan Hamilton, executive vice chairman, at tonight's concert of the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra In Lewisohn Stadium, when service men in uniform will be granted free admission.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- Larry French, sidetracked from two starting turns because of his disappointing record, came back to shut out the Braves on four hits today while the Cubs cashed passes for three runs and added two more on homers by Phil Cavarretta and Babe Dahlgren for a 5-0 triumph.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., June 20 -- Floating on the surface of the Maine coastal waters twenty-four miles east of Portsmouth beyond the Isles of Shoals, where the United States Navy submarine 0-9 submerged in 402 feet of water at 10:36 this morning in a deep-diving test and failed to rise again, little pieces of painted cork insulation were picked up tonight.

The tentative schedules of individual and corporation income taxes announced by the House Ways and Means Committee indicate, as had been expected, that the forthcoming tax bill will be by far the heaviest this country has ever faced. The important question is how equitably the committee has succeeded in distributing the burden.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 20 -- Declaring the people of the United States must become united in purpose and Effort to meet successfully their common responsibilities for national defense, Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Deputy Director of Selective Service, told the members of the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce today that the men of their age group must bear the brunt of achieving that unity.

NEAR MERDJAYOUN, Syria, June 19 (Delayed) -- Vichy French troops this afternoon are sharing the possession of Merdjayoun with a company of an Australian battalion, which crept up under the cover of darkness early this morning and occupied a number of houses on the northern edge of the town.

WITH BRITISH FORCES IN NORTH AFRICA, June 19 (UP) (delayed) -- The entire area of Solum, Halfaya Pass and Fort Capuzzo appears to be in German hands after a four-day battle waged in the blistering desert under indescribable conditions.

The conflict between right and left-wing factions in the New York Newspaper Guild, C.I.O., continued yesterday in the wake of a general meeting Thursday night at which the members voted 365 to 362 to disavow interference by Guild officers in the North American Aviation Company strike at Inglewood, Calif., and to condemn the strike itself as a product of Communists, Nazis and Fascists.

Trading in cotton gray goods was virtually suspended yesterday as both buyers and sellers attempted to analyze the effects of the proposed ceilings which are expected to be established by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply shortly.

LONDON, June 20 -- Jacqueline Cochran, American flier, checked into the Savoy Hotel here this morning, causing something of a sensation when it became known that she is the first woman to fly a bomber across the North Atlantic.

A revolution has been quietly under way for some time in the galleries which house the paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The task is now more than half completed and even the most casual visitor will be impressed at the new effects.

The hot spell which began on Thursday dug in yesterday for what the Weather Bureau forecast might be a fairly long siege. The mercury went to 90 here at 4:30 P. M., and thermometer readings, reported by The Associated Press, showed that the heat was general throughout the nation east of the Rocky Mountains.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS OF THE SECOND ARMY, Manchester, Tenn., June 20 -- The "blitz buggies" of the armored force roared through clouds of Tennessee dust today as 77,000 troops of the Second Army, sweltering in 90-degree heat, ended another week of manoeuvres.

Competitive Sales The stage is set for the first demonstration on Monday of the operation of the compulsory competitive bidding rule for the sale of public-utility securities. At least three major syndicates are expected to compete for the $47,000,000 of New York State Electric and Gas securities, bids for which will be opened in the company's offices at noon.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 20 -- Finland ordered general mobilization tonight. Proclamations posted on street corners ordered all reservists up to he age of 44 to report at once for service in the army. The formal mobilization decree affects comparatively few men, since an intensive program of calling them to the colors in recent days already had been carried out by individual notification.

If no other records are broken in 1941, it is almost a certainty that Cupid is going to come through with an amazing performance. The statistics of the marriage license bureaus of New York City from the first of the year to June 16 indicate that 1941 will be the nation's busiest matrimonially.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., June 20 -- May net operating income of the Southern Pacific Company soared to $5,025,296, the largest for that month since 1917, the carrier reported today. This was an increase of $3,208,008 over last may's net operating income of $1,817,288. In May, 1917, the figure was $6,291,000.

Railroad-equipment-trust financing continued yesterday to be a feature of the new issue market, with the award of two additional issues aggregating $7,600,000. These, together with the $15,000,000 New York Central equipment issue on Thursday and the Nashville, Chattanooga St. Louis $4,290,000 loan on the previous day, kept the market well supplied this week with this type of security, which long has been a popular investment medium for banks and trust accounts.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The National Defense Mediation Board announced the settlement today of three labor disputes where stoppages would have materially affected national defense production.

The missing ballots of Referee Eddie Joseph and Judges Marty Monroe and Bill Healy finally came to light yesterday. Late Wednesday night, after Joe-Louis salvaged his heavyweight championship of the world by stopping Billy Conn in the thirteenth round, a searching party scoured the vicinity of the ringside, seeking to determine how the official vote on the first twelve rounds had gone.

The ten-day strike of longshoremen against the Morgan Line and the Maritime Commission will probably end today as a result of an agreement reached in Washington, it was announced yesterday by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association.

THESE three new books are about the great fortress in the Atlantic that must with our help stand against nihilism's grisly revolutionists on the European Continent -- unless this country wants to stay on a war footing forever.

Armstrong Sperry, author and illustrator of "Call It Courage," received yesterday the Newbery Medal for "the most distinguished contribution to American literature for children." He has written and illustrated many books of adventure, but "Call It Courage" is a story in the Robinson Crusoe tradition retold from a Polynesian legend.

These surveys are made by a system of highly selective samplings in each of the forty-eight States in proportion to voting populations; thereby, the American Institute of Public Opinion holds, is obtained a result which would not vary from that of a much larger canvass.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 20 -- Completion of the colony with the arrival of varsity and freshman crews from Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Washington's time trial and the weather shared the rowing conversation today as the final drive toward Wednesday's regatta got under way.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 20 (AP) -- The French Command issued this communique today:

DURHAM, N.H., June 20 -- America's relief problem is a "permanent one, subject to variation in degree as business conditions fluctuate," William. Hodson, New York City's Commissioner of Public Welfare, said today at the University of New Hampshire's seventy-fifth anniversary celebration.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 20 -- The Royal Air Force in Syria bombed Damascus for the first time today, the Beirut radio reported tonight, and British military sources in Ankara warned that Allied forces in Syria were preparing a total war to blast French artillery from the city and take Damascus by storm.
ROME, June 20 -- American consulates throughout Italy began preparing to close their offices at the end of the fiscal year on June 30. That will leave two weeks for liquidation.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The lowly Senators allowed the Indians to tie the score with a three-run drive in the ninth, but pushed over a run in their half of the inning to beat the American League leaders, 7 to 6, today.

A suite containing nine rooms in the building at 365 West End Avenue has been leased by the Kempner Realty Corporation, managing agents, to Jacob Nacht, president of the Union Card and Paper Company. Other units in the same building were taken by Mrs. Nathan Goldman and Ben Silverman.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., June 20 -- Four acres of selective service troops, ending their thirteen weeks of preliminary training in the field artillery replacement center, graduated the course this afternoon amid impressive ceremonies. One group, numbering 4,200, who came down from Camps Dix, Upton and Devens, cheered Brig. Gen. Gustave Franke to the echo when he told them that they would be leaving tomorrow or the next day for Indiantown Gap.

The appearance of two sizable issues of railway equipment trust certificates swelled the total of new bond offerings this week to $21,346,000. This compared with $25,311,403 in new bonds offered last week and with only $10,772,641 marketed during this week a year ago.

LONDON, Saturday, June 21 (UP) -- The Daily Mirror reported today that Janet Margesson, 23-year-old daughter of War Secretary Captain David Margesson, will represent the left-wing People's Convention at the American Youth Congress at Philadelphia in July.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress on the sinking of the Robin Moor follows:

The tide of applications for the new British Civilian Technical Corps swelled yesterday into a boom-time rush, and when recruiting closed at 6 P.M. in Room 1056 of the British Consulate General's offices at 25 Broadway more than 800 had been received.

Alexander Smallens conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for the first time this season last night at the second of the Summer's concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium. In addition to the HandelHarty "Water Music," Mozart's "Jupiter" symphony and Strauss's "Don Juan," the engrossing program contained two contemporary works.

The Most Rev. Francis J. Spellman, Archbishop of New York, will leave tomorrow to attend the ninth National Eucharistic Congress, to be held in St. Paul and Minneapolis Monday through Thursday. The congress will be attended by seventy-one Archbishops and Bishops, hundreds of priests and thousands of Catholic lay pilgrims.

If citizens of Westchester County find that the clasped time between deposits and credits on checks is lengthened, it will be because the Westchester Clearing House Association has given up its function of clearing checks. At the Federal Reserve Bank of New York it was said yesterday that the institution had begun to clear all checks among banks in Westchester County, with Wall Street correspondent banks of the Westchester institutions assisting.

Inspiration for any extension of the recovery movement in the securities markets was lacking yester and stocks backed away under lighter trading. The start of business on the Stock Exchange had revealed a firm tone, but this soon gave way to misgivings after word was flashed that President Roosevelt would send an important message to Congress.

The cotton futures market received renewed support from several sources yesterday and prices forged ahead. Closing quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange stowed gains of 5 to 8 points. At their highs for the day prices were up 12 to 16 points.

Warners "Underground" will open this morning at the Globe. The drama, which deals with illegal radio broadcasters in Nazi Germany, stars Jeffrey Lynn and features Philip Dorn, Kaaren Verne, Mona Maris, Frank Reicher and Martin Kosleck.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled adversely today on the question of the admissibility of expert opinion on the valuation of securities of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Two officers and at least thirty-one men were aboard the submarine 0-9 when it submerged yesterday in waters off Portsmouth, N.H., and failed to come up. According to records here it was possible that thirty-two men, besides the two officers, were aboard.

The United States Rubber Company announced here yesterday through Eric Burkman, secretary, that it will start production in the immediate future of barrage balloons, similar to those used for defense against invading warplanes in England.

Economy in the Borough of Manhattan, social reforms in the Borough of Queens, no more "bickering" in the City Council and vaguely defined but wide-spread benefits "for all in Greater New York," were modest now-that-I-am-elected promises made yesterday by the city's new junior officials.

Although he used a shingle for a rod and a pearl wobbler for a lure, extremely unorthodox tackle for the results obtained, an angler on Long Lake in Maine landed a 19-pound-11-ounce landlocked salmon, the heaviest of this species taken since 1907 and the second largest in history.

MTTCHUL FIELD, L.I., June 20 -- The Second Operation Company, which is entrusted with vital duties in defense against air raids, will leave this post at 4 A.M. Tuesday for MacDill Field, near Tampa, Fla.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Senate passed today and returned to the House for action on amendments and increases of about $50,000,000 the $936,390,000 relief bill for the fiscal year beginning July 1 after rejecting two amendments offered by Senator Murray of Montana.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 20 (AP) -- Paul Draper, the dancer, announced today he would marry Heidi Vosseler, also an American dancer, here on Monday.

Although open for business as usual, Italian Consulates here and in other sections of the country were making preparations yesterday to close their doors on expected orders of the United States Government in retaliation for similar action by the Italian Government on Thursday.

Demand for lamb yesterday showed some improvement over that of the first half of the week but other classes had a limited outlet. Veal supplies were about normal, lamb light. Steer beef hind and rib supplies were about normal but prices remained mostly unchanged. Lamb prices were around $1 higher, veal hindsaddles weak.

PITTSBURGH, June 20 (AP) -- The Phillies lost their fifth straight game today, but carried the Pirates to the very last ditch in the ninth inning before bowing, 7 to 6.

New Yorkers of high and low degree responded willingly and in numbers yesterday to the opportunity given to them to protect in wartime the lives and property of their families and neighbors. They flocked to the eighty-two police precincts in the city, even before the opening hour of 9 A. M., to enroll for duty as air-raid wardens, New York's first line of civilian defense in the event of war and air raids.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 18 -- The men of the 122d Coast Artillery, a National Guard unit from Northera New Jersey, have been kept busy at Fort du Pont this week. Several overnight hikes have broken the routine of garrison drills which have been in vogue for the past month.

Despite the fact that crude rubber prices have advanced 37 per cent since the start of the war and that the Office of Production Management has ordered a cut in rubber and tire usage, retail tire prices as reflected in pre-holiday promotions are practically unchanged from a year ago, a check-up yesterday revealed.

Jett Lauck, author, labor economist and chairman of the American Association for Economic Freedom.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Government buying of pork and extremely light fresh supplies drove the market for hogs upward again today. As had been the case for several days, prices set new four-year June peaks. Top loads rose 25 cents to $10.50 a hundredweight, compared with $5.35 on the corresponding day last year.
The submersion of the submarine 0-9 yesterday recalled the dramatic episode of the submarine Squalus in the same area a little more than two years ago.

The subways will continue to operate even if the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, calls a strike on the city's unified transit system on or about June 30, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday. The union indicated some time ago that such a strike would be called if the city persisted in its refusal to negotiate collective-bargaining agreements to replace contracts expiring June 30.

This tendency is familiar to psychiatrists.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Sehas made public a letter from its general counsel, Chester T. Lane, to Paul Bartholet, executive director of the National Committee of Investment Companies, explaining some aspects of Section 24 (b) of the Investment Company Act, which requires the filing with the SEC of three copies of certain advertising matter.

MONTREAL, June 20 (Canadian Press) -- The Newark Bears tightened their grip on first place in the International League standings and dropped Montreal down to fourth tonight with an 8-5 victory over the Royals.

Stassen at a meeting last night.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., June 21 -- Dr. William M. Lewis, president of Lafayette College and State Director of Selective Service, told the 138 graduating students at the Hill School today that they should not rush into uniforms upon completion of their schooling.

DAVID O. SELZNICK is going back to the work of making motion pictures, after more than a year of inactivity during which he kept quite busy doing other things -- for one, counting those $32,000,000 earned by "Gone With the Wind"; for another, liquidating the Selznick-International Company in which John Hay Whitney was interested.

THERE is no doubt that those who confine their dance-going to the obvious places and the established personalities miss a great deal of excitement and virtually all the pleasures of discovery. WASHINGTON -- The great American pastime of trying to make an automobile or truck beat a railroad train to a grade crossing persists throughout the country, despite countless gruesome driver defeats, but the peril is being eliminated at many points.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H. -- Trout fishing enthusiasts are enjoying fine sport within the White Mountain territory. New Hampshire stocks its streams and lakes well, and speckled, square-tailed and rainbow trout are augmented in some localities by brown and Loch Lomond.

LOS ANGELES, June 21 -- Water from the Colorado River, carried 292 miles across deserts and mountains and treated in a chemical softening plant, reached eight Southern California cities last Wednesday, thus marking the completion of the great $220,000,000 Colorado River Aqueduct.

WASHINGTON, June 21-- The United States finally came up this week with a modern definition of the word "invasion." After three historic years we conceded officially what every good Austrian, Czech, Dane, Rumanian and Bulgarian discovered long ago -- that a nation can be invaded not only by tanks, bombers and storm troopers but also by sausage salesmen, mimeographs, radios, ideas, economics and fake diplomats in striped pants.

At the commencement exercises held in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon, attended by 3,000 persons, 339 girls from Cathedral High School, Lexington Avenue and Fiftieth Street, were presented with diplomas by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman.

PALO ALTO, Calif., June 21 -- In a meet marked by thrills, spills, the inevitable loose dog and some stellar individual performances, the University of Southern California Trojans won the twentieth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field team championship today.

MEXICO CITY -- To most of the United States, Mexican food means chile and tamales, with vague impressions of peppers and chocolate. In the Southwest, to be sure, the term widens considerably, but even habitual patrons of Mexican restaurant there know nothing of the variety and savor of dishes prepared in homes below the border.

DETROIT, June 21 (AP) -- The Tigers bid high today in the major leagues' latest poker game, stacking a reported $45,000 in blue chips to acquire the services of 20-year-old Dick Wakefield, University of Michigan batting star.

According to the best estimate, a cubic mile of seawater contains $25,000,000 worth of gold. Undismayed by a cost of extraction which is about five times the value of the recovered gold, chemists for sixty years have looked upon the ocean as an aqueous El Dorado. Fascinated by the problem presented, the late Nobel Prize winner, Fritz Haber, devoted some six years to analyzing the sea, with the official support of a post-war bankrupt Germany.

SUMMER and vacation needs have taken up any slack that had developed in retail trade and sales increases are again marching ahead. In addition to these normal demands, the purchasing of articles which will grow scarce as defense requirements expand has become more feverish.

After a wave of selling at the opening had caused recessions of 3 to 6 points, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rallied sharply yesterday to register new high levels for four years. Final quotations, which were close to the day's best marks, were up 9 to 12 points.

NEWPORT, R.I. -- If the weather ever warms up sufficiently for any one to go in for a dip, Newport's Summer visitors are planning to divide themselves among five different beaches. All are now open and the demand for bathhouses, cabanas and even beach umbrellas has started.

THE pollock and the sea bass are biting, these days, and the fishing trains that leave Pennsylvania Station for Montauk on Thursday, Saturday and Sunday mornings are filled with high-spirited anglers out for a lively time with their rods and reels.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- A strong undertone developed in the wheat market today, with prices working slowly upward as the result of mill buying, strength in Minneapolis and reduced estimates on the Southwestern crop. Retail trade in the New York area continued active last week. A feature was the sustained demand for both women's and men's Summer apparel. Department store sales were estimated at 9 per cent over last year. Better than seasonal gains were reported for variety, shoe and drug chains.

The largest contingent of European refugee children to come here since the westward movement of British children ceased last December arrived yesterday on the little Portuguese liner Mouzinho, which brought packed in cabins and improvised dormitories in the holds a total of 721 men, women and children.

BERLIN, June 21 (AP) -- A deliberate silence was the only answer here today to President Roosevelt's message to Congress on the Robin Moor case and the ebbing of American-German relations to the lowest point in years.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 21 -- The annual Spring series of garden parties conducted by the Westchester County Children's Association to advance its welfare work will be concluded for this season next Thursday afternoon with a fete at Penwood, the home here of Mr. and Mrs. Carll Tucker.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 21 (AP) -- Those two torrid Texans, Jimmy Demaret and Ben Hogan, took a stranglehold on the $2,000 top prize in the $7,000 Inverness invitation four-ball golf tourney as they halved one match today and won, 6 up, in another to jump 6 points ahead of the field with two rounds to go.

Three golf tournaments to decide the district champions will be held this week in New Jersey, Long Island and Westcheater. Starting simultaneously tomorrow at the Montclair, Nassau and Apawamis Clubs the tourneys will continue through Friday in Long Island and Westchester and through Wednesday in New Jersey.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, announced yesterday that the membership of the union had accepted the terms of an agreement reached by him in Washington last week, and that the strike against the Maritime Commission and the Morgan Line had been called off.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Members of the National Guard and Reserve Officers Corps will be kept in active service beyond the single year planned when they were called, if a recommendation made today by the War Department is approved by President Roosevelt and Congress.

TRUJILLO, Peru -- Tourists cruising down the west coast of South America sometimes visit Chanchan, the seat of the Great Chimu empire, whose people preceded the Incas.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Motorists of 20 to 25 years had the highest proportion of fatal accidents among age groups in 1940, according to figures given by the National Safety Council. WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Control Administrator, today banned increases in the price of automobile hires, inner tubes and crude, reclaimed and scrap rubber and appealed to the public not to buy rubber products in advance of actual needs.

MANCHESTER, Tenn., June 21 -- The number of troops swarming across this fertile plateau of the Cumberland Mountains in the June exercises of the provisionally organized Second Army alone exceeds by many thousands the total strength of the Regular Army within the continental limits of the United States ten years ago.

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity moved into new high ground in the week ended June 14, when it advanced to 130.2. It stood at 128.0 in the previous week and at 108.6 in the week ended June 15, 1940.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Italian Embassy was directed by the State Department in a note published today to close all its consular offices and other agencies in this country having connections with the Italian Government by July 15.

TUCSON, Ariz. -- Deep in the hollow of a lime-crested mountain about sixty miles southeast of Tucson lies an age-old but newly discovered cave which has excited the scholarly interest of Southwest explorers.
