Jacob (Jake the Bum) Wellner, an ex-convict, whose election as business agent of a Brooklyn local of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers confronted the American Federation of Labor with the first test of its anti-racketeering powers, has been reelected by a vote of 295 to 92 in balloting supervised by the Honest Ballot Association, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UP) -- Commenting tonight on the German declaration of war against Russia, Senator Walter F. George, Democrat, of Georgia, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said:

VICHY, France, June 21 -- Damascus was evacuated by its French defenders today and the British-de Gaullist forces entered the city. No details have yet come to hand. In fact, the news arrived after publication of the daily communique, which spoke of continued resistance.

After a brief invasion of severs up-State cities, the kennel caravan will swing back into the metropolitan area for the annual Monmouth County and Staten Island all-breed shows slated for Saturday and next Sunday, respectively, at Rumson and Oakwood Heights.

DURING the years which form the theme of Mr. Shirer's diary, the world turned upside down. Yet in general the American correspondents whose business it was to observe the scene remained their normal shrewd selves, proving as indifferent to the blandishments of sundry dictators as they were appreciative of the virtues of "a good bottle of Margaux."

AMONG the buildings piously restored in recent years as reminders of great men and significant events in America are many churches. For the founders of our country were religious folk and built churches of a sort almost as soon as they built houses to live in.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A national campaign to collect aluminum for defense will be begun by the Office of Civilian Defense, with the approval of the Office of Production Management, it was made known today.

LAKE MAHOPAC, N.Y., June 21 -- Collective bargaining and the right to strike in government and defense industries were debated at the June conference of the League for Industrial Dmocracy at Forest House here today.

VICHY, France., June 21 -- In a new note delivered by Ambassador Gaston Henry Haye in Washington and through the French Embassy In Madrid to Sir Samuel Hoare, British Ambassador to Spain, the French Government protested tonight that the British were openly attempting to incite a revolt against the French Government in French Somaliland and that the British blockade of that colony was causing deaths from undernourishment among children.

WARWICK DEEPING still maintains his credo of love, courage and compassion, the trinity of virtues he has solemnly and repeatedly affirmed in each of his more serious novels. But he clings to them in this story of Victorian England rather as one might cling to a gallant and fading ideal, not as one clings to the rock of immutable truth.

NO doubt countless young ladies, during the Victorian era, rebelled in vehement phrases against the limitations of their sex and the conventions of their society and announced their determination to Live in some new, free, exciting fashion, no matter what the cost might be.

SUMMER group exhibitions continued to bulk largest on the calendar as the New York art world prepared for the hot season doldrums. A number of diverse and interesting shows opened last week, including oils and watercolors by French and American artists at Kraushaar's, the annual Summer show at Rehn's, a group retrospective at the No. 10 Gallery and two traveling exhibitions not previously seen in New York at the Museum of Modern Art.

THE annual tournament at Shawnee, Pa., will be played next Friday, Saturday and Sunday. A one-session contest for mixed pairs will begin at 9 o'clock Friday night. Open-pair play will be in two sessions on Saturday at 2 and 9 P.M.

IN the foreword to his recent juicy history of Belle Starr, the Bandit Queen, that fighting man of letters, Burton Rascoe, makes a very interesting point. He claims that most of the legends -- and most of the so-called facts, too -- about the glamorous desperadoes of our wild and woolly West had their origins in the lurid pages of the National Police Gazette.

VACATIONISTS who seek a complete change from their customary mode of life are welcoming the opportunity to take their holidays on horseback. Recently developed trails winding through Eastern States and totaling thousands of miles in length enable the modern adventurer to travel wilderness country almost as virgin as that which confronted his pioneer forefathers.

In a War of Nerves The United States and Germany last week were waging what seemed to be a war of nerves. In actions unparalleled since the critical days of 1917 each nation struck out against the other. Washington, following upon the freezing of Axis funds in the United States, ordered the closing of all German consulates and propaganda agencies.

Yesterday's order giving walking papers to Italian consular employes and other agents in the United States -- an expected sequel to the recent expulsion order against German representatives -- was the calmination of a series of increasingly bitter actions between the two governments involving consulates, ships, money and men.
Who Are the Nihilists? A number of trades and professions were singled out by President Conant in his baccalaureate sermon at Harvard as responsible for the chief malady of our times.

NATIONAL defense and priorities on materials necessary to the manufacture of receiving sets have become points of heated discussion among radio manufacturers. They maintain that their industry is an essential one and have indicated their resentment that it "has apparently been ranked midway between toothpaste and hair tonic" in the defense program.

Assuming that the war continues, there can be no question that industrial volume of business will far surpass either 1929 or 1937, Spencer Trask Co. declare in their June issue of Business Survey. The investment firm, commenting on general business, says:

The electrical "hound" has been developed by Dr. William Shoupp, Westinghouse research physicist, to track lost specks of radium and to discover stray X-rays in hospitals. With a nose made of wire-screening, a metal rod, and a head full of radio tubes and wires, the "radium hound" can point to as little as a tenth of a millionth of an ounce of radium by tuning in on the rays sent out.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 21 -- Miss Virginia Eldridge Thomas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Egbert Eldridge Thomas of this city, was presented to society today at two parties given by her parents at their home. In the afternoon a reception was given to introduce her to older friends of the family, and in the evening a dance was held for her and many of her young friends.

MEDFORD, Mass., June 21 -- With undergraduate and prospective students showing an intense interest in drama courses and numerous graduates seeking opportunity for further study in this field, the Tufts College faculty has voted to establish a major department in drama and speech next year, Dr. George S. Miller, dean of the arts and science faculties, announced today.

Full cooperation has been offered by the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York to the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply in its studies with regard to possible fixing of price ceilings for cotton textiles, it was announced yesterday by W. Ray Bell, president of the association.

While the Italian Consulate and other offices maintained an almost clam-like attitude yesterday regarding the United States order shutting up Italy's consulates and agencies in this country, the reaction of Italian anti-Fascist groups and spokesmen was, by contrast, one of jubilation and satisfaction.

CRETE, Ill., June 21 (AP) -- Lincoln Fields' thirty-day meeting closed today with Equifox, an 11-to-1 entry, owned by Howard Wells, winning the featured $5,010 added Lincoln Handicap as the even-money favorite. Mrs. Marie Evans's Shot Put finished fifth in a field of six.

Oil savings equivalent to the tonnage normally carried by ten of the fifty tankers diverted from East Coast runs to the British service can be effected by raising the efficiency of new installations and existing oil heating units, according to an estimate by the Oil Burner Industry Committee for National Defense.

SHELLFIRE is as important in the present war of mobility as it was in the war of position of 1914-18. Today's fast motorized units of an army carry their heavy guns in speedy motor trailers, for even though infantry, traditionally the "queen of battle," may be the basic arm of military forces, it is usually the shells that first crush the foe.

Wholesale markets were active this week, with large numbers of buyers in town to attend the earlier Fall openings, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The government, extending far-reaching control over all manufacturing use of rubber, today suspended private imports from the Far East and ordered civilian consumption cut 20 per cent in the next six months.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Six changes in the iron and steel price-ceiling orders were announced today by Leon Henderson, Federal Price Control Administrator, but the general price level was maintained. Mr. Henderson said the changes were the results of suggestions from a cross-section of the steel industry which said the minor amendments would facilitate operation of the schedule.
OTTAWA, June 21 -- Over three-quarters of a million people in Canada have subscribed to the "Victory Loan," the total of which today stood at just short of $668,000,000.
NEW YORK Mrs. George Barton French of 164 East Seventy-second Street will leave tomorrow for Southampton, where she has taken a residence in Meeting House Lane for the Summer.

For one reason or another many gardeners make little use of biennials, although this group of plants presents some of the most interesting and effective material for Summer borders. The drawback is that one must plan a year ahead for them.

If you haven't yet reached the point in your development (or should one say salary?) at which you can afford a place in the country, you're probably escaping into the open via other people's houses. It's polite, of course, to take along a present.
Ford and the C.I.O. We have decided to go the whole way.

The underwriting community is prepared for what is likely to be one of the most interesting periods in years in the field of new security distributions this week. During the next two days, three individual financing operations with an aggregate principal amount of approximately $122,000,000 will be thrown open to competitive bidding.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- While official Washington awaited further reports from the Nazi-Soviet war, unofficial observers here said that Reichsfuehrer Hitler's decision to invade his former collaborator may be the turning point in the war.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- The last of the 500 delegates from all parts of the United States and Canada who attended the convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers here this week are returning to their homes today carrying with them a new sense of their serious responsibility in the national emergency program during the coining months.

The general conclusion that city planning in connection with the rehabilitation of the Yorkville section of Manhattan should be in the direction of making the section more residential with less emphasis on business is made by the zoning committee of the Yorkville Chamber of Commerce in a report submitted to Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs.

Dr. E. George Payne, dean of the School of Education at New York University, announced yesterday that under a new plan established by the university candidates for the doctorate degrees would be permitted to publish their theses and final documents by microfilm.
MONTREAL, June 21 (AP) -- With Jock Graham driving in five runs on a homer, a double and a single, the Montreal Royals swamped the International League-leading Newark Bears today, 12 -- 5.

LONDON, June 21 -- It is no longer necessary to argue with the average intelligent English schoolmaster on the importance of teaching United States history in English schools; that battle is won. It is still -- and very naturally -- necessary to argue with intelligent Americans who ask, "If this be so, why, comparatively speaking, is so little American history taught?"

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The War Department has rejected Congressional demands for an independent air force and reorganized its own air arms into a unit to be known as "The Army Air Forces." The consolidation was effected under orders of Secretary Stimson.

Is Wall Street finally going to have a $4,000,000,000 commercial bank now or will that financial milestone be deferred until the third quarter of 1941? That will be one of the questions answered by the mid-year bank statements of condition which will soon be coming to hand.

SEEKONK, Mass., June 21 -- The first licensed obedience trials of the Obedience Training Club on the grounds of the Jacobs Hill Hunt Club today produced excellent work in all five classes. It was one of the few all-breed obedience trials ever held in America, apart from an all-breed bench exhibition.

AGAINST EAR "WINDOWS" -- Here and abroad attempts have been made to correct deafness by cutting away sections of the base of the skull, the canal of the ear and the bony capsule that protects part of the inner ear's semi-circular canal.

THAT most typically American of all foods -- corn -- is approaching the top of its season. Since no one is quite sure when the first golden harvest was reaped, there is no way of knowing for how many hundreds of Summers the gathering of the crop has set mouths to watering all over this continent. But it is well established that maize is very Early American.

HOLLYWOOD. TO the undoubted confusion of Metro's executive staff, Nature has refused to amend her laws. As a result, the studio has been forced to shelve its titanic production of "The Yearling," in which $500,000 was reported to have been invested when the cameras stopped turning.

MOSCOW, June 12 (By mail to Berlin) -- A Soviet country estate enclosed within a heavy picket fence like an old American stockade has been leased by United States Ambassador Laurence A. Steinhardt as a possible refuge for Americans in Moscow in event of hostilities.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 21 -- A community effort toward an understanding of the present conflict in preparation for civilian defense work was undertaken at St. John's College last week with a series of seminar discussions of important books on the subject of war.

A rose garden totaling 652 plants at last count is the especial pride of Edward Moyse in Manhasset, L.I. Whereas most suburban gardeners must content themselves with a rose bed or small rose garden, Mr. Moyse enjoys to the full his more spacious planting, which does not take up more than onefifth of his two-acre plot.

WASHINGTON. ONE cold, damp morning in 1930 a rookie White House policeman walking his beat behind the Executive Mansion was startled almost out of his boots when a trio of particularly husky-looking men suddenly appeared around a hedge.

OPERA given in a smaller theatre than the Metropolitan, with American singers trained to sing in the vernacular as well as in foreign languages; opera interpreted with special care for the stage as well as the score, and a thoroughly unified ensemble, has more than once been mentioned as a highly desirable if somewhat hypothetical feature of the musical life of New York City.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of June 16 a sermon by the Rev. Dr. John H. McComb was quoted, under the headline "Colleges Called Faith Destroyers."

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The mountain-laurel display reaches its peak this week in the Mount Everett State Reservation, in the town of Mount Washington. It grows in profusion for three miles along the Mount Everett Highway.

BERLIN, Sunday, June 22 -- As dawn broke over Europe today the legions of National Socialist Germany began their long-rumored invasion of Communist Soviet Russia. The non-aggression and amity pact between the two countries, signed in August, 1939, forgotten, the German attack began along a tremendous front, extending from the Arctic regions to the Black Sea.

BOSTON, June 21 (AP) -- Just as hot as the 94-degree heat, the Browns today hammered three Red Sox pitchers for sixteen hits -- including homers by George McQuinn, Wally Judnich and Chet Laabs -- to bang out a 13-to-9 victory and even the series.
That private capital has been quick to respond to the housing needs brought on by the defense program in New Jersey was revealed yesterday by Warren J. Lockwood, New Jersey State director of the FHA.

MR. BAGGER has done something decidedly interesting in the way of an autobiography. In style, his book is diffuse and rambling, very much like a one-sided conversation in which the talker again and again flies off at a tangent, only to return to use his digressions as threads for the weaving of his main theme.

HOBBY About 1,800 miles of railroad track-age in this country will be of no use at all in the defense program, except as it carries a load off people's minds. This is the trackage operated by miniature-railroad enthusiasts.

SPURRED on by Virgil Thomson, one of the liveliest newcomers to join their ranks in some time, the music critics have followed the example of their dramatic and motion-picture colleagues and formed a Circle. At first there was some talk of calling themselves a Round Table to distinguish them from those colleagues, but this was voted down.

IN addition to its membership concerts on six Monday nights and its annual Gabrilowitsch memorial series of five Saturday afternoon programs, the National Orchestral Association plans to give a "music play" series next season.

LONDON. TWENTY-ONE years ago a group of women keenly interested in public affairs embarked on the risky experiment of starting a weekly review which should be entirely the work of their own sex.

The statement of Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands that the people of Holland are being forced to manufacture airplane parts and other military supplies, including ships and even submarines, for the German war machine is not surprising. It confirms reports from Holland itself which are duplicated from other countries conquered by Germany in the last year and a half.

THE new Photographic Society of America exhibition, called "In the Image of America" and presenting pictures by United States Farm Security Administration photographers, is now on display at the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Radio City.

ASIDE from its sheer readability, David Loth's "Woodrow Wilson" is chiefly remarkable for what it is not. To John Maynard Keynes, Wilson was the Presbyterian moralist who could preach a lofty sermon for mankind but lacked utterly the power of organizing his vision into anything concrete.

City College faculty members and students who were enrolled Communists were ordered to indoctrinate as many of their associates as possible with Communist philosophy, according to testimony yesterday in the Court of General Sessions at the trial of Morris U. Schappes, suspended English tutor at the college.
Utility in the modern small home, acording to an official of the FHA, means simply "fitting the space to the functions."
BUFFALO, June 21 (AP) -- A medical development which is said to make unnecessary the typing of a patient's blood for transfusion was announced today by the Buffalo Research Associates, Inc.
LONDON, June 21 (AP) -- It was announced officially today that no change was contemplated in the organization of Britain's eight-man War Cabinet, under fire frequently in House of Commons debates.
SUMMER can be the good old time of song and story if you don't let its minor hazards deprive you of its pleasures.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- This resort will entertain some 2,500 youngsters during the annual Children's Week, which starts next Thursday.

NOWHERE can English children be seen to such advantage, Alice Duer Miller says, as in Hyde Park, when "with red cheeks, blue eyes, golden curls, soft voices, and an early understanding of horsemanship, they gallop their ponies of a morning in Rotten Row."

Walter A. Sullivan, builder and president of Graystone Homes, Inc., announced yesterday plans for a new suburban home community to be known as Country Club Homes in Garden City, L.I. He has arranged with Realty Associates, Inc., to take over and develop 200 home-sites extending from the Garden City Club to New Hyde Park Road.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- An election "as soon as possible within thirty days" among employes in the editorial and news departments of THE NEW YORK TIMES was ordered today by the National Labor Relations Board.

WOODSTOCK, Vt., June 21 -- Failure of fiduciaries to fulfill their functions and failure of other businessmen to "live up to plain old-fashioned standards of honesty and fair dealing," Robert E. Healy of the Securities and Exchange Commission told the Vermont Bankers Association tonight, "are as much a menace to our system of government and to the American way of living as anything that comes from Russia, Germany or Italy."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One of the most fallacious arguments used by the isolationists is the bugbear of dictatorship. We are being warned by an obstinate minority that, once sufficient powers are given to the Executive to insure swift mobilization and direction of our forces for the preservation of Britain, our liberties will be forever lost.

HOLLTWOOD. AFTER a twenty-one day absence, Bette Davis has returned to the set of Samuel Goldwyn's "The Little Foxes," made up with rose-bud mouth, the pompadour hair of the Nineteen Hundreds and the chalky, self-willed prettiness of Regina Giddens.

FEW contemporary composers have written as many fine songs as Sergei Rachmaninoff. Singers and concertgoers have known this for a long time, but to the general public this aspect of his achievement is virtually unknown.

THE people who make card-catalogues for libraries are going to have some trouble with this book; that is, they will have it if they attempt to classify it too minutely. There are in these absorbing and delightful pages large stretches of history, of sociology and of many other things.

MADRID, June 21 (UP) -- A new version of the Rudolf Hess affair was circulating in diplomatic gossip here tonight. It asserted that the arrival of Herr Hess in Britain had touched off a series of events that led France to adopt her policy of "collaboration" with Germany and produced the current Russo-German crisis.

Progressive Education Association. In the May issue of Progressive Education two statements are made which might be questioned. One is that this issue contains the first formal pronouncement of the philosophy of progressive education authorized by the association.

The existence of a "gyroscope of life," which stabilizes life as a physical gyroscope stabilizes a giant ocean liner, has just come to light as the result of researches by three cooperating scientific teams in three institutions of learning -- Cornell University Medical College (New York City), Western Reserve University School of Medicine (Cleveland, Ohio) and the University of Texas (Austin, Texas).

Shippers engaged in the African trades believe that the withdrawals of merchant ships from these routes for use as government auxiliaries have seriously injured American business relations in the foreign field, and that unless the Maritime Commission works out a solution to the problem the country will suffer incalculable harm.

"READING for Enjoyment -- How to Make Use of It" would have been a more accurate, if paradoxical, title for this book of elementary guidance to benefits in books. Not that the author admits a practical purpose; no, he is firm in his emphasis on pleasure as reading's aim -- "epicurean enjoyment," he calls it.
LONDON, June 21 (AP) -- A reliable foreign source reported tonight a secret clause in the German-Turkish friendship treaty.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- President Roosevelt's strong denunciation of the Nazi government, the closing of the Axis consulates in this country, and the Axis response in kind, brought official relations between the United States and Germany close to the breaking point this week.

Figures released at Police Headquarters last night showed that 15 per cent of the 62,000 air-raid wardens called for by Mayor La Guardia had volunteered in the first two days of the current enrollment.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., June 21 -- Long-hitting Billy Dear, the Essex County Country Club star, smashed the amateur course record with a four-under-par 34, 33 -- 67 in the first round of the ninth annual John Roche Memorial member-guest golf tourney at the Mapplewood Country Club today.

CIRO ALEGRIA, the young Peruvian whose novel, "Broad and Alien Is the World," won a $2,000 prize earlier this Spring in Farrar Rinehart's Latin-American Prize Novel Contest, is still in New York and means to stay here as long as his money and passport are good.

EVERY morning at 9:30 o'clock and every afternoon at 1, a lone seaplane takes off from the United States Coast Guard air station at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn for a three-hour patrol of nearby coastal waters.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. -- Outdoor recreation is near its Summer peak in this resort, with colonists enjoying surf sports, deep-sea fishing, golf and tennis, and hiking and horseback riding over forest and desert trails.

To the Drama Editor: WHO is going to clean the Augean stables of the actors' agency racket? The part of Hercules is impossible to cast. Why doesn't Equity investigate a few of the notorious malpractices which are everyday occurrences among actors' agents?

A large delegation of realty brokers, agents, builders and appraisers from New York City will attend the thirty-seventh annual convention of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York at the Hotel Sagamore, Lake George, N.Y., opening on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission denied today an application by the Colorado Southern Railway to lease the Fort Worth Denver City Railway and the Wichita Valley Railway, having 1,170 miles of railroad in Texas.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 21 -- The latest news from Finland is bad. The impression that most Finns do not want to take any part in the German-Russian conflict has been reinforced here by yesterday's manifesto of the Finnish Social Democratic party, trade unions and other organizations representing the Finnish working classes.

ELMIRA -- For the first time in the history of the annual national soaring contests here the eleventh yearly meet, opening next Saturday, will be practically under Federal auspices. United States Army officers, now in training here, will be observers for the government and aliens will be barred from Harris Hill, contest headquarters, unless they hold passes countersigned by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

PUERTO RICAN LAND: Under the defense program Puerto Rico, midway in the arch of islands stretching from the South American mainland to Florida, is slated to become "the Gibraltar of the South Atlantic." Washington has been spending some $65,000 a day to transform the island, an American possession since 1898, into a key link for Caribbean and Canal Zone defense.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 21 -- French troops evacuated the city of Damascus today after a persistent bombardment by British artillery and withdrew to new positions outside the Syrian capital, according to official advices from Beirut. Early in the afternoon it was learned that the Allied vanguard was already beginning to enter the city.

FORMED a year ago "to provide humanitarian air service at home and abroad to relieve physical suffering," Relief Wings, Inc., has now organized the whole Eastern section of this country. Volunteer pilots, flight surgeons and nurses and amateur radio operators from Maine to Florida have enlisted for this emergency service.

DARIEN, Conn., June 21 -- Achieving the rare feat of winning two hunter titles at the same exhibition, Martin Vogel Jr.'s imported Demas supplied the outstanding feature as the fifteenth annual Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show was concluded before a sweltering throng today.

In an effort to encourage creative expression among the 135,000 students in the junior high school division, New York City school officials have, for the first time in 100 years, compiled a comprehensive anthology of the actual work performed by children in the classroom.

Lake Sibelius of Finland, who gave the world the essence of his native music, Edvard Grieg, a generation earlier, was the first to mold the special qualities of the music of his people into classic music which is today a rich inheritance.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 21 -- The strange marriage of convenience between Soviet Russia and Nazi Germany, even if reaffirmed by some startling but now unforeseen development, seemed as close to the breaking point this week as at any time since it was cemented in August, 1939.

EVERYBODY, including even children and small babies, is going out to the beaches now and getting a first coat of tan. Adults, presumably, can take care of themselves when it comes to deciding how much sun they should have, but babies are a different problem.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 21 -- Howard C. Stocker and Young Doug Ford of Green Valley, the New York State junior champion, scored a best-ball 32, 35 -- 67 in the second section of the qualifying field in the first annual Ardsley Country Club member-guest handicap golf tournament this morning and tied for medal honors with Harry A. Arthur and Jess Sweetser of Siwanoy, who carded 34, 33 -- 67 in the first division yesterday.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., June 21 -- As hope faded rapidly for the crew of the Submarine O-9, which failed to rise after submerging yesterday morning twenty-four miles east of this city, it became known tonight that the Navy might be unable to complete its salvage operations, and might be compelled to leave the bodies entombed where they lie--440 feet below the surface of the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- President Roosevelt selected William H. Davis, New York patent attorney, today to succeed Clarence A. Dykstra as chairman of the National Defense Mediation Board when the latter returns to his post as president of the University of Wisconsin on July 1.

New safeguards intended to wipe out fraud in the use of Federal food stamps have been instituted in this city by the Surplus Marketing Administration and the Welfare Department, L.L. Horch, district supervisor of the SMA, disclosed yesterday.

LAST Sunday a small parcel of comment on current activities relating to Modern Art was delivered to the reader interrogatively wrapped. On the assumption that the twentieth century's specific, accredited an historically placed and documented art movement known as Modernism has about, as such, run its pioneering course, these questions were posed: What next?

Aggregate earnings of the automobile and aircraft industries in the first quarter of 1941 would have been well above the fourth and first quarters of 1940 had it not been for the substantially higher tax provisions and the setting aside of contingency reserves to provide against future tax laws affecting this year's results, a survey of these industries shows.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On April 11, after the British overpowered Italian forces in East Africa and cleared the Red Sea of the enemy, the President, by a proclamation issued in accordance with the so-called Neutrality Law of Nov. 4, 1939, reopened to American shipping the Red Sea, which was closed by him on June 11, 1940, after the start of Anglo-Italian hostilities.

Widespread simplification of merchandise is possible throughout the retail field, with benefits to the government in conservation of needed materials, to the manufacturer in savings of man and machine hours in concentrated production, to the retailer in eliminating slow sellers and markdowns and to the consumer in a greater degree of price stability, according to views in authoritative retail quarters.

LONDON, Sunday, June 22 -- Twenty-six Nazi fighter planes were destroyed in daylight yesterday by Royal Air Force fliers on their fifth straight day of raiding the Germans' invasion coast and air bases in Northern France.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee postponed action today on the nomination of Attorney General Robert H. Jackson as associate justice of the Supreme Court after hearing a charge that he "abused his official office" in 1940.

LONDON, June 21 -- King Peter of Yugoslavia arrived in London this morning with the intention of setting up his government here from which to give the British all possible aid and at the same time to become part of the third kingdom in exile to seek refuge in this monarchical democracy.
BERLIN, June 21 (UP) -- Neutral observers believed tonight that Germany would reject any United States demand for reparations in the sinking of the Robin Moor.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- An estimate that Great Britain, despite heavy losses at sea, had gained in relative naval strength over the Axis powers in the last four months came today from the Navy Department.

QUENTIN REYNOLDS, American newspaper man and commentator in the movie short, "London Can Take It," now strides to the British microphone to fling a few bass notes toward his one-time acquaintance, Dr. Goebbels.

Applicants for noncombatant paid jobs as radio technicians and other types of mechanics, to operate England's secret weapon for detecting invading aircraft, continued to storm the recruiting office of the British Civilian Technical Corps yesterday morning in Room 1056 of 25 Broadway, where the British Consulate General is located.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 21 -- Turkey is negotiating a new trade pact with Germany to succeed the last commercial accord signed between the two powers before the outbreak of war in August, 1939, Foreign Minister Shukru Saracoglu told American journalists during the course of an informal press conference today.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 21 -- There is unreserved approval for the "prospectus for Australia's total war effort," as Prime Minister R. G. Menzies described it. Newspapers hail his statement as a challenge to Australians cheerfully to put their services to whatever use the urgent demands of the war direct and applaud the courage and wisdom of Mr. Menzies.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark. -- Soon it will be fiesta time in this picturesque mountain and lake surrounded spa, already decorated in American and old imperial Spain's colors in anticipation of many visitors to tha de Soto Quarto-Centennial celebration.

JUST fourteen years ago a young New York radio engineer with a collection of good phonograph records -- he was prompted by a score or so of letters from widely scattered listeners-turned a television experiment into a new idea in broadcasting.
PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (AP) -- Clubbing fifteen hits to offset three Chicago home runs, the Athletics swamped the White Sox, 11 to 5, today to break a three-game losing streak.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 21 -- Two week-end golfers eliminated the favorites, Ray Billows, one of the metropolitan district's ranking stars, and F.B. Hamilton of the home club, in the second round of the Cherry Valley Club's annual best-ball tourney today.

KATE O'BRIEN'S latest work can but add distinction to an already distinguished literary reputation. To say that this story of an Irish convent before the first World War is flawless may convey the idea of a somewhat remote and possibly cold perfection.

ALTHOUGH many things have been changing in the last quarter of a century, Robert Edmond Jones, the scene designer, is not one of them. He retains the poetic idealism he brought into the theatre from New Hampshire, where he was reared, and Harvard, where he was educated.
"GLENCANNON AFLOAT" brings together eight more yarns about the "Auld Scots Engineer," with his walrus mustache and his bottle of "Duggan's Dew." Every one is a howler, and one not more than another.

ALTHOUGH the second of the three rooms of the Berg Collection at The New York Public Library will be ready for occupancy in a few weeks, it may be another year before the books and manuscripts can be made available to the public.

WHEN Vienna was a city of light and laughter and merry waltz tunes, Viennese hostesses used to serve supper on shady terraces in the warm Summer evenings. And after supper, with the good Viennese coffee came small, fastidious chocolates, icy cold from the refrigerator.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., June 21 -- The diving attempt to reach the sunken submarine 0-9 this afternoon was carefully supervised by the Navy's best technicians. Besides Rear Admiral Richard S. Edwards and others who proved themselves in the Squalus rescue, they were master divers who have won the Congressional Medal of Honor.

BOSTON -- Experts in the matter seem to think that of the people who spend their vacations in New England about half originated there and the other half wish they had. The one half -- either native or a generation or so removed -- knows pretty much all it wants to about the region and takes its pleasures with a minimum of moving around.

WITH military traffic becoming increasingly in evidence on New York's streets this Summer, civilian motorists' have been puzzled over what regulations, or even rules of etiquette, they should follow in dealing with it.

The calendar and the weather bureaus in the country finally got together yesterday, and the first day of Summer was also the hottest day of the year for most of the nation. From the Atlantic to the Dakotas the temperature was in the nineties, and in some places it topped 100.

THESE children are not bad, says Justice Jacob Panken of the boys and girls who are brought before him in the New York City Children's Court. And having made this general statement in his book's introduction, he expands it later on: "In the Children's Court we are confronted with all kinds of delinquencies by children.

TOKYO, June 21 -- With relations between the United States and Germany approaching the breaking point, Japan sees herself confronted with a fateful decision involving the peace of the Pacific and her very existence as an empire.

In announcing yesterday the registration for the Summer session of the civilian flying course at City College, it was stated that all those taking part in the civilian pilot training program, supervised by the CAA, will be deferred from selective service training as long as they are receiving instruction.

THE fifth annual series of "Sunset Symphonies," to be given by the National Symphony Orchestra at the Potomac Water Gate, Washington, will open next Sunday evening and continue until July 31. Except during the initial week, all the concerts are scheduled for Mondays and Thursdays at 8 P.M.

The completion of work on the northern section of Bronx Park for recreational purposes was announced yesterday by the Department of Parks, which disclosed that complete rehabilitation must await contemplated changes in the alignment of Bronx River Parkway.

The author of the "Ezekiel" books has moved back in time and up in latitude to tell, in this story of Patsy, of her own childhood on a Tennessee plantation. Patsy was 8, with a boundless affection for living creatures, but chiefly for animals, and so her escapades are mostly connected with the barnyard inhabitants which children consider the most important part of the farm.

EDITORS of school papers have been enlisted in the campaign against vandalism by Judge Stephen S. Jackson, director of the Bureau for Prevention of Juvenile Delinquency. Editorially, the boys and girls lay down the law.

THIS high-spirited -- not to say ingratiating -- title introduces the 1941 winner of the Mary Roberts Rinehart mystery novel contest. And the title has a vital relation to a story whose scene shifts in and out of a court room, whose theme has to do with the law of double jeopardy, and whose plot introduces an unidentified murderer muttering "Justice be damned!" in the first paragraph.
A FRAGILE, tea-colored book of forty small pages, by "a Bostonian," was given to the New York Public Library a few weeks ago. Its owner had paid $17,500 for it.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines today forecast the market demand in July for domestic crude oil at 119,260,000 barrels, or 3,847,100 barrels daily. This is 17,100 barrels more than the estimated daily demand this month and 6 per cent above the actual demand in July, 1940.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- An American who refused to turn over a transport plane to the government at its request was today cited as an example by President Roosevelt in a letter which he wrote to Senator Robert R. Reynolds, chairman of the Senate Military Affairs Committee, stating that the Administration believes the property requisitioning bill now being considered by that committee should be passed.

The record of shipping losses in May now given out by the British Admiralty shows a drop of 119,823 tons from the preceding month, but is nevertheless disturbing enough to call for redoubled effort to meet this serious menace. Total sinkings in May were ninety-eight snips, 461,328 tonnage.

PITTSBURGH, June 21 (AP) -- Pitcher Joe Bowman, who once toiled for the Phillies, pushed them deeper into the National League cellar today by hurling a 2-0 shutout for the Pirates. It was the sixth straight defeat for the Phils.

WHEN Rockefeller Plaza, running between Forty-eighth and Fifty-first Streets, was withdrawn from public use for twelve hours recently, its sudden exclusiveness was not due to any desire for the sheltered life.

The temperature was down to 10 centigrade [14 degrees Fahrenheit], but I didn't feel the cold for the moment. My hot-air pipe, a sinuous length of rubber, more like an elephant's trunk than anything outside a zoo, but far more useful in an airplane, was tucked securely inside my jacket and blew its comforting warmth all around me.

In preparation for a primary election fight in September, the rival factions of the American Labor party will meet this week to designate candidates for Mayor and possibly for other local offices. The right-wing group, which controls the State committee, will hold a conference Wednesday at the Hotel Capitol.

An ambulance unit of fifty American, British and Canadian volunteers will embark from Los Angeles on Monday for service along the Burma Road in China, James G. Blaine, national chairman of the United China Relief, announced here yesterday.

When the Reserve Board's index of industrial activity for May had risen to 148 per cent of the 1935-39 average, whereas the highest percentage even in 1929 was 114, it was natural that the transportation business should have risen with it. Railway cars loaded have increased over 1939 something like 30 per cent.

FOR any one interested in California's colorful history, the State's political and social development and the dynamic personalities that guided its destinies for good or ill during the latter half of the nineteenth century "Christopher Strange" win prove one of the season's most absorbing novels.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 21 -- Sentiment for a complete embargo on oil and metal shipments to Japan, often expressed here in recent years, appears to be at a new crest. The Great Pacific Northwest harbors of Puget Sound and the mouth of the Columbia River are much nearer by sea to the Orient than to Europe, and in this region the international crisis has always been appraised with a wary eye on Tokyo.
A novel predicted-log race for cruisers and two new rendezvous have been devised by near-by yachtsmen for the coming fortnight that includes, of course, an extra-long Fourth of July weekend.

THE Juilliard Summer School has added twelve members to its faculty. These include Leon Rothier, the Metropolitan bass, and Isidor Philipp, pianist and teacher. Also Mishel Piastro, violin; Lief Rosanoff, 'cello; Marcel Grandjany, harp; Vittorio Giannini, composition and orchestration; Fritz Rothschild, ensemble playing with records; Marion Bauer, musicology; Grace Leeds Darnell, junior choir; Ruth Shafer, public school music; Lamar Stringfield, American music, and Saul Goodman, tympani.
POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Announcement of two events of unusual interest in art and music circles is being made in the Poconos.

Plans were filed with the New York City Department of Housing and Buildings during the first five months of this year for work estimated to cost $80,049,561 on 10,985 buildings, according to Myron L. Matthews in the Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

Japanese Irises in the vicinity of New York City are at their height of bloom now and through the end of June. Notable collections of these showy flowers may be seen on the grounds of the State Institute of Applied Agriculture at Farmingdale, L.I., and at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1,000 Washington Avenue.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, June 21 -- Antioch College seniors will forego traditional processionals, orations and commencement ceremonies this year in favor of a Conference on Progressive Action and Post-War Reconstruction which will replace graduation exercises.

Although a record attendance and early buying have been predicted for the midsummer market which opens at the New York Furniture Exchange tomorrow, buyers believe that total business will be held down considerably by the sold-up position of many of the factories.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Vermont's hotels and inns are now nearly all open and guests are beginning to arrive. One of the first to open was the Dogteam Tavern of the Grenfell Labrador Industries, located three miles north of Middlebury on Route 7.

OMAHA, Neb., June 21 -- Notwithstanding that an upturn of general farm prices, especially for livestock and livestock products set in about the first of the year, Corn Belt farm income for the first quarter of 1941 was slightly under that of a year ago.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The combined total of recent events on the labor front has prompted the unions as well as the general public to take stock of the whole union labor situation.

There were eight people without alibis when the cowboy and general entertainer, Tex Logon, was killed at the new California mountain resort of Summit House. But while some of them might perhaps have wanted to murder each other, a mere employe seemed too insignificant to be in anybody's way.

A marked increase in residential construction in the central and southern parts of Westchester County, with the great majority of the new homes in the more moderate price range, was reported yesterday by Thomas G. Grace, State Director of the FHA.
BALTIMORE, June 21 -- A B-26 Martin medium bomber crashed and burned near the Gleen L. Martin Airport today, killing two men.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Discontinuance of cooperative advertising and merchandising by small groups of independent individual grocers banded together in informal organizations to meet chain competition and the revision of many plans for cooperative action seemed certain to occur shortly as the result of information gathered by retailers at the annual convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers in Chicago last week.

SOME one should write a handbook for the American home on the importance of puttering. Suggestions are made regularly of worth-while things to do in your spare time, but the trouble is very few people today have any spare time, and they are exhausted at the idea of unrelenting efficiency.

NEARLY a hundred stamps from France and five French colonies -- Cameroons, Dahomey, Indo-China, Madagascar and Togo -- are among last week's arrivals. A 5-francs red has been added to France's current postage-due series, and there are two overprinted provisionals: "1F" in black on the 1.25fr rose-carmine in the Peace design, and "1F" in red on the 1.75fr dark ultramarine in the Cerea type.

About this time of year it is usually evident just which are those areas where even the most optimistic cannot hope for a real stand of grass. If after a number of fair trials no healthy growth can be established, then it is time to look around for some good substitutes.

Despite the sinking of the Robin Moor by an undersea raider of the German Navy, and the Reich threat to sink all American ships transporting "contraband" for the benefit of Great Britain, there has been only a slight adjustment of hull insurance rates and no change in cargo rates, underwriters reported yesterday.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey national chairman of the United Service Organizations, announced here yesterday that the USO's $10,765,000 national campaign drive had passed its half-way mark with a total of $5,411,083 contributions reported to date.

MELBOURNE. WHILE the war has prevented the annual Australian Celebrity Concert season from starring overseas conductors and soloists, the Australian Broadcasting Commission has seized the opportunity to discover local talent.

Immediate steps will be undertaken to draft the proposed national code to forestall government regulation of installment selling, David D. Bolen, new president of the National Retail Credit Association, told THE NEW YORK TIMES last week.

DETROIT -- Regardless of what happens to the new-car end of the business, one thing is certain during the present emergency: New-car dealers at long last will give deserved attention to their servicing departments, after having tolerated this phase as a "necessary evil" for many years.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration announced today that 191 airport sites would be surveyed for possible construction or improvement worK under the $94,977,750 CAA appropriation for the year beginning July 1.

A FORMER flight sergeant of the Luftwaffe. Gottfried Leske, is the author of "I Was a Nazi Flier." which Dial Press will publish late in July. The main part of the book is in the form of a diary kept from May. 1940, when the Nazis overran the Low Countries, until January, 1941, when the author bailed out of his bomber over England and was taken prisoner.

WITH a threat of "gasless Sundays" for the Eastern seaboard before the end of the Summer, the Keystone Automobile Club has delved into history for a comparison of present-day conditions with those existing at the time of other "gasless Sundays" during World War I, in 1918.

AMONG this year's recipients of honorary degrees of Doctor of Laws from Wayne University, Detroit, which is among the first twenty largest colleges in the country, were Charles E. Wilson, president of General Motors, and Henry T. Ewald, president of Campbell-Ewald Company.
LONDON. LKE the Free Trade Hall of Manchester, London's Queen's Hall has been reduced to a heap of ruins by enemy bombs and the two best concert halls in the country have ceased to exist.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- Members of the Summer colony here and in adjacent resorts throughout this end of Long Island are working actively in behalf of the current United Service Organizations drive. Mrs. Reginald Fincke of New York and Southampton, who is chairman for Suffolk County and vice chairman for Southeast Suffolk, reports that the campaign here is well under way, with considerable progress indicated and much cooperation by Suffolk citizens.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.

STANTON, Del., June 21 -- Exploding the myth that he belonged to the category of thoroughbreds that could run fast but couldn't run far, Arnold Hanger's brown gelding, Dit, raced to a convincing triumph at Delaware Park today in the fifth running of the $10,000 added Sussex Handicap.

WORKING in conjunction with Atfero Service of Montreal, an organization headed by W.G. Golien, chief pilot of Transcontinental and Western Air's western division, has been set up to recruit American pilots, co-pilots and navigators to fly American-built warplanes from this country to England.

Miss May Okon of the Eastern Women's A.C. upset Miss Jean Adelman, Jewish Community House of Bensonhurst, No. 3 seeded player, as competition began in the women's metropolitan A.A.U. one-wall handball championship at Manhattan Beach yesterday.

ONCE upon a time there was a country called Denmark, situated on a continent known as Europe. In this country lived a young man named Mielche, who had spent his childhood wandering about living on his wits as anything from artist to gigolo.

One of the newest of the light furniture wood finishes used in decorations in the contemporary manner is that given to walnut. Formerly associated chiefly with stately, dark-hued Queen Anne furniture, this handsome wood takes on through bleaching a lovely platinum gray effect, which has the double virtue of intrinsic beauty and close harmony with the soft colors of today's decorative fabrics.

THE "town" of Dr. Rufus M. Jones's memories was a Maine township. There one of the leaders among American Quakers spent his country boyhood against the background of the Friends' worship, the closely knit, yet highly individualized, family circle, the rural school, the town meeting, not least the country store.

THIS volume, like its predecessor. Edwin Corle's "Desert Country," is one of a series, through which, as Editor Erskine Caldwell says, "the colorful story of American life is being told for the first time through its own galvanic medium, the customs of the people."

Eugene Goossens, conductor of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, who makes his initial appearance at the Stadium Concerts on June 30, will have soloists on three of the ten programs he is scheduled to direct. Mischa Elman will be heard in the Tchaikovsky violin concerto at the first concert, when a suite by William Byrd and Beethoven's "Eroica" symphony will complete the offerings.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- Instead of a deficit of $22,233, as predicted in its budget prepared last year, the Philadelphia Orchestra Association has reported a final net deficit for the 1940-41 season of only $1,621.59.
The heat wave crackled at the Stadium yesterday but two pitchers, Dizzy Trout and Al Benton, put a chill on the Yankees as the Tigers won, 7 to 2, to the disappointment of a gathering of 20,067.

CHORUSES of the Schola Cantorum and the Eva Jessye Choir, with Paul Robeson, Louise Burge, Abner Dorsey and George Headley as soloists, will appear in the "gala evening" program at the Stadium tomorrow night.

Dresses and sports wear met best consumer response in the promotions of stores in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles last week, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

Comparisons between Napol on and Hitler have been made time and time again. Both dictators overran Western Europe; both were subjected to a British blockade; both invoked all the aid that contemporaneous science could lend; both cherished the illusion that they were destined to rule the Western world.

Joe DiMaggio exploded his fifteenth homer of the campaign at the Stadium yesterday to lift the Yankees into a major league record for consecutive-game, four-ply hitting, as he advanced a step nearer record distinction in his own batting streak.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Now that Russia has been attacked by Germany, officials here expect that she will be declared exempt from the President's general order freezing the funds of all Continental European countries.
The Mutual Life Insurance Company has sold the private house at 119 East Eightieth Street through Duff Conger, Inc., brokers, to a buyer who intends to alter and occupy it.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Senator Pepper of Florida proposed today that Congress implement President Roosevelt's demand for maintenance of the freedom of the seas by repealing the Neutrality Act which prevents Americans shipping from entering war zones.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 22 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:
The prospects for a good bluefish season are getting better and reports of several excellent catches have come in from waters where these fish have been scarce for the past three or four years.

HELSINKI, Finland, Monday, June 23 (UP) -- Finland still was technically at peace with Russia early today, and Soviet Ambassador Orloff stated he was convinced that neither Russia nor Finland wanted a new war with each other.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 22 -- Military operations between Russia and Germany are now going on along the longest continuous front in the history of modern warfare, extending in vast stretches from the southernmost limits of the Black Sea to the northern continental boundaries of Europe.

Three hundred persons gathered under a blistering sun in the Bronx yesterday -- foregoing trips to seashore and countryside -- to join the ninth annual pilgrimage to the grave of the Rev. Francis P. Duffy, wartime chaplain of the 165th Infantry (Old Sixty-ninth) and pastor of the Holy Cross Church, Forty-second Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.

LONDON, June 22 (AP) -- The most widely circulated speculation on Russian strategy in London today was offered by the British Press Association, which said it had learned on good authority that the Red Army would drive an armored column at the center of Germany while the Germans attacked the Ukraine and through Finland.

Ignoring the traditional Sunday "day of rest," hundreds of New Yorkers, anxious to volunteer as air-raid wardens in the civilian defense program started by Mayor La Guardia, flocked yesterday to police precinct stations throughout the five boroughs, and, by 10 P.M. 1,873 had been added to the fastgrowing corps.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- United States exports to British Empire destinations increased 55 per cent during the first quarter of this year, as compared with the 1940 period, according to an analysis of American foreign trade issued by the United States Chamber of Commerce. Exports to all other countries declined 45 per cent.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- High prices for competing oils and fats last week lifted quotations for lard last week to the highest levels in four years, but the market was called upon to absorb heavy profit-taking sales, and the best prices were not maintained, although closing trades yesterday on the Board of Trade showed gains of 30 to 32 1/2 cents a hundredweight for the week.

WOODMEBE, L.I., June 22 -- Badly outplayed at the start and punished by her opponent's drop shots, Mrs. Millicent Hirsh Lang had the courage to collect her forces and go on to victory over Miss Helen Germaine today in the final of the women's New York State tennis championship at the Woodmere Club.

The New York State Parole Board announced yesterday that of more than 5,000 persons with indeterminate sentences to State Prison and Elmira Reformatory who were on parole in the New York district during 1940, sixty-six were convicted of committing new felonies, eighty were convicted of misdemeanors and 221 others were found delinquent by the board and ordered to return to prison.

VICHY, France, June 22 -- Information furnished here from official circles estimates that the total number of Soviet forces in line ready to meet Germans, Finns, Rumanians and Hungarians number from ninety to 100 infantry divisions, twenty-two cavalry divisions and thirty-two armored brigades.

Declaring that our legislatures are "fast becoming pagan," the Rev. William Scully, director of religious education of the Archdiocese of New York, in his sermon yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral urged Catholic women to bind themselves together to prevent general acceptance of any laws that may be passed contrary to the doctrine of Jesus Christ.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- An increase of 35 per cent in internal revenue collections for the eleven months ended on May 31, compared with the same period the year before, is indicated by figures issued today by the Treasury. The increase is even more noticeable when the results for last month are compared with the data for May, 1940.

Due to control measures embracing all currencies of Continental Europe not hitherto banned and announced at the preceding week-end, business in the foreign exchange market last week dropped to its lowest point of inactivity in history, even when comparison is made with the post-War No. 1 period of a quarter century ago when some activity prevailed in the major European currencies.

BOSTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Browns blasted twenty-nine hits today, but the best they could get was an even break with the Red Sox, Landing on Jack Kramer for six runs in the first inning of the opener, the Sox withstood the sixteen-hit St. Louis attack and triumphed, 7 to 5.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., June 22 -- After the Navy Department officially abandoned all hope of rescuing the two officers and thirty-one men of the training submarine O-9 this afternoon, impressive funeral services were held aboard another submarine near the place where the O-9 went down Friday morning.

MOSCOW, Monday, June 23 (AP) -- German troops attacking Russia on the long front from the Baltic to the Black Sea at dawn yesterday succeeded in making small gains in former Lithuania and Poland, but at great cost, the Russian High Command announced early today.

THESE are strange days, stirring times. Babe Ruth and Ty Cobb, great rivals of other days on the diamond, are going to play again. And against one another. At what? Golf! And the fellow who egged them on is Bobby Strawbridge of the Long Island polo set.

There's a quiet corner of a great, bustling metropolitan grocery department that has been transformed overnight -- as though by magic -- into a tiny, tranquil country store, where the air is cool and damp and deliciously fragrant with the smell of spices.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Prices of corn held within a range of about 1 1/2 cents a bushel last week on the Board of Trade here, but dealings broadened out in the December, which sold at a new high level for the season.

Alexander Kerensky, former Russian Premier, whose government was overthrown by the Bolsheviki, yesterday appealed for assistance for Russia, predicting that a victory for the democracies would end in the collapse of the Nazi and Soviet regimes and the building of a free international order.

FORT DIX, N.J., June 22 -- "Reunion in Vienna" occurred in reverse here today when two recently drafted men, former friends in Vienna, Austria, met in War Department Theatre No. 3 this morning for the first time since they left Europe more than two years ago.

CLEVELAND, June 22 (AP) -- Almost half the current inquiries for steel include evidence of government-granted priorities, but even the possession of such preferential rating does not guarantee delivery of the order, the magazine Steel reports today in its weekly summary of the industry.
Five films will arrive this week in midtown theatres. The schedule follows:

BERLIN, June 22 -- Having since the beginning of this super-dimensional war on Sept. 1, 1939, militarily defeated or become allied with nearly every other continental European power, German armed striking power early today directed its energies toward the Reich's tacit ally in the early stages of the conflict, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 22 -- Having upset Ray Billows, Walker Cup star, and his partner F.B. Hamilton, the medalists, in the second round yesterday, Frank Simonson of the home club and Burton Braun of the Garden City Country Club went on to win the Cherry Valley best-ball invitation golf tournament today.

Captain James Roosevelt, eldest son of the President, who has been abroad as an official military observer since April 19, arrived at the marine terminal at La Guardia Field yesterday aboard the Yankee Clipper from Lisbon, bearing information that he said "should be reported as soon as possible."

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Legislation to tighten present regulations against the dissemination of foreign propaganda in the United States is being drafted, according to a letter sent by Secretary Hull to Senator Mead of New York, made public today by the Senator.
In New York, James A. Farley, former Postmaster General and former Democratic National Chairman, said:

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 22 -- Sumner Waters, former home club champion, and Charley Newman, current titleholder at the North Hempstead Club, justified the confidence their buyers in the pool placed in them by winning the Nassau Country Club's thirty-ninth annual invitation golf tournament today.

Coincident with the beginning of the long-awaited tearing down of the Fulton Street elevated structure in Brooklyn, the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement issued a report showing that the downtown section of the borough is overrun with dilapidated structures and fertile territory for general rehabilitation and sprucing up.
OTTAWA, June 22 -- Backing Prime Minister Winston Churchill's stand on the German-Russian issue, Prime Minister William Mackenzie King this evening declared his sympathy with the attacked nation.

VICHY, June 22 -- Reports submitted to their annual meetings by the large credit institutions in France give some details on the conduct of financial operations in 1940. They describe how the personnel and material of the different branches were transferred to the rear in the face of the most unexpected difficulties as the invasion of the country extended.

The Foster Parents Plan for War Children, 55 West Forty-second Street, through Mrs. Edna Blue, its executive secretary, announced yesterday the "adoption" of a 6-yearold British boy, Dennie Edward Mitchell, by Mrs. Stephen S. Wise, wife of Rabbi Wise.
MOSCOW, June 22 (AP) -- Russia proclaimed martial law tonight in border areas from the Arctic to the Black Sea, including the newly Sovietized Baltic States and the Leningrad area.
Several parcels of industrial realty in New Jersey passed to new control in deals reported over the week-end.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- Dr. Thomas Aloysius O'Brien, first Philadelphia surgeon to transplant successfully the cornea of a corpse to the eye of a living person, died yesterday at his summer home in Ship Bottom, N.J., after an illness of six months.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Bobby Feller reached the halfway mark of his 1941 goal of thirty victories today, hurling his fifteenth triumph by letting the Senators down with seven blows while the Indians were clubbing out a 6-0 decision.
Our Vacation City No matter how many New Yorkers leave the city to spend their vacations at mountain or seashore, as many people will come to spend their Summer holidays here.

MOSCOW, June 22 -- As Germany struck at Russia by land and air in a dawn invasion today the Soviet Government immediately accepted the challenge, hurling the might of its Red Army against the Nazis with orders to "repulse this predatory assault," which Moscow's spokesman said was started under a pretext that "is a sheer lie and provocation."

WESTBURY, L.I., June 22 -- The Meadow Brook Club's annual tourney for twenty-goal polo teams slipped into high gear today as Great Neck, Bostwick Field and Aknusti opened their schedules by scoring impressive victories.
