Local owners of machine tools, "capable of operating at close tolerances," were urged yesterday by W.O. Crabtree, regional District Manager of the Defense Contract Service of the Office of Production Management, to register the number of their tools and capacities with his office, 33 Liberty Street.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 22 -- William H. McGee of 22 Pondfield Parkway, chairman of the board of William H. McGee Co., Inc., 111 John Street, New York, marine underwriters, died today in the Mount Vernon Hospital after a long period of failing health.

Brooklyn College will award degrees to 1,389 men and women this morning at its sixteenth commencement exercises. The ceremony will be held on the college campus, Avenue H and Bedford Avenue, at 10 o'clock. Raymond Gram Swing, radio commentator, will be the principal speaker and President Harry D. Gideonse will address the graduates briefly.

LONDON, June 22 -- As this country rocked under the impact of this morning's announcement that Russia and Germany were at war, Prime Minister Winston Churchill went to the microphone tonight to tell his countrymen and the world that Germany was the enemy and that Britain was not going to take her eyes off the main target.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 22 -- Military and diplomatic quarters here tonight, basing their opinions on meager details that began filtering through the gradually settling fog of first-day military operations, declared the struggle at the end of the first eighteen hours of fighting between Russia and Germany virtually a draw.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The bill of Congressman Joseph J. Mansfield of Texas, to put through the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Deep Waterway to the Sea, as a vital defense measure, has received the approval of Secretaries Stimson, Knox, Hull and Jones of the President's Cabinet and of Messrs.

MANCHESTER, Tenn., June 22 -- The Russo-German campaign brings into action the largest armies of the world. The Germans can probably put from 5,000,000 to 6,000,000 men under arms -- from 250 to 300 divisions, most of them veterans of victorious campaigns.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Organization of the civilian fliers of the United States into a defense auxiliary in a score of fields is rapidly getting under way.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 22 -- Paramount has announced that Charles Laughton, Akim Tamiroff and Oscar Homolka will be asked next week to take screen tests for the role of Pablo in "For Whom the Bell Tolls." Also at Paramount, Jackie Searl joined the cast of "Glamour Boy," and "The Remarkable Andrew," acquired Rod Cameron, who will play the Ghost of Jesse James.

All at once H.L. Mencken has delivered to Knopf not only the manuscript to the second volume of his autobiographical reminiscenses, "Newspaper Days," but also the completed material on his "A New Dictionary of Quotations on Historical Principles."

RUTLAND, Vt., June 22 -- Benjamin Robbins Curtis Low, New York lawyer and poet, died this morning on his sixty-first birthday at his Summer home in Bridgewater. His New York residence was at 21 East Seventy-ninth Street. Mr. Low, his wife and their son and daughter arrived in Bridgewater yesterday to spend the Summer in the rebuilt farmhouse which they bought seven years ago.

LONDON, June 22 -- Last week's rise of u363,000 in the Bank of England's circulation to the new record of u637,500,000, was smaller than some recent increases, but the trend, nevertheless, will is strongly upward.

The 400 members of the joint executive committee of the Transport Workers Union, representing the union's membership on publicly and privately operated transportation lines, will meet at 8 o'clock tonight in Transport Hall, 153 West Sixtyfourth Street.
VICHY, France, June 22 -- After the fall of Damascus -- announced officially today -- interest in operations in Syria has turned suddenly to the Eastern Desert.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Walter Evans Edge and Miss Camilla Edge have left the Ambassador for Small Point Beach, Me., where they will spend the Summer.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A recent United States dispatch from Vichy mentions rumors allegedly originating in Ankara regarding British promises of "a larger Jewish national zone in parts of Syria, Trans-Jordan and Iraq as well as in Palestine."

As a direct result of the torpedoing of the American steamship Robin Moor, unlicensed seamen of the Seafarers International Union, A.F. of L. affiliate, will meet tonight in New York and thirteen other American ports to formulate demands for higher war bonuses for sailing vessels into "danger zones," it was revealed yesterday at the union's office at 2 Stone Street.
BERLIN, June 22 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 22 -- Despite Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's declaration that German and Finnish troops are marching together against Russia, it was officially declared from Helsinki at 5:30 this afternoon that Finland was not at war with Russia.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Senator Byron Patton Harrison of Mississippi, who was always known as Pat Harrison, died at 6:30 o'clock this morning in the Emergency Hospital, where he underwent an operation a week ago for removal of an intestinal obstruction.

Declaring that talk of an "honorable" peace among the warring nations of Europe does not constitute "treason to democracy or to any ideals of freedom," the Rev. Dr. Wesley Megaw in his sermon yesterday morning in the Fort Washington Presbyterian Church, Wadsworth Avenue at 174th Street, appealed to the United States Government to draw up the outline of such a peace and lay it before the conflicting powers.
The following is the text of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's address, broadcast yesterday from London, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 93.4 to 94.3 which brings it near the 94.7 high point for the 1936-41 period. Finished goods also advanced to their high point for that period, reaching 97.6. Among the subgroup indices, textile products, too, rose to a new 1936-41 high because of the higher prices for broadcloth, denims, sheetings and silk.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Conditions for the growing crop took a turn for the better last week and, with the rapid expansion of harvesting operations, wheat prices receded to their lowest levels since June 6, or just before official announcement of the government loan on the 1941 crop.

LONDON, June 22 -- Although there was the usual precautionary marking-down of prices in certain sections for the week-end the stock markets generally experienced an excellent five sessions beginning with last Monday from the viewpoint of business done and appreciation of listed values.

VICHY, France, June 22 -- Official circles here take the attitude that the opening of German-Soviet hostilities is outside the interests of a nation in France's position. Authorized quarters did not, however, conceal today that their interests are now with the German side, for two main reasons.

Cotton prices continued to move upward last week under an active trade and mill demand which met relatively light offerings. Net gains made by active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were, however, somewhat smaller than those of the previous week, and amounted to 40 to 46 points, compared with an advance of 53 to 62 in the previous period.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 (AP) -- Early settlement of the Bay area machinists' strike, without use of force, was held a possibility today by naval authorities.
PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP) -- The Athletics traded shut-outs with the White Sox in splitting a twin bill today before 25,563, the second largest crowd of the season at Shibe Park.

Department store earnings in 1940 averaged nearly 5 per cent of sales, the highest return in the last twelve years, while sales for the year averaged more than 6 per cent above the 1939 volume, according to the Report on Operating Results of Department and Specialty Stores, issued today by the Harvard Bureau of Business Research under the sponsorship of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

PITTSBURGH, June 22 (AP) -- The Phillies ended a seven-game losing streak by pounding five Pirate pitchers for seventeen hits to win the second game of a double-header, 7 -- 4, after dropping the first, 4 -- 1, today.

ROME, June 22 -- Italy declared war on Russia today. An official communique issued at noon stated that "the Italian Government had informed the Russian Ambassador that Italy considers herself in a state of war with the U.S.S.R. from 5:30 A.M., June 22."

MILLBROOK, N.Y., June 22 -- The Cardinal Hayes Memorial Home for Convalescent Children, a mansion adjoining the estate of Oakleigh Thorne near here, was blessed and dedicated this afternoon by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York at ceremonies attended by some 700 persons, including fifty-one children now resident there.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 22 -- Scoring points in all four championship classes, the Villanova junior, Frank J. Desmond of Short Hills, N.J., became intercollegiate outboard champion for the second consecutive year this afternoon on the Raritan River by piling up the impressive total of 3,825 markers.

The outbreak of war betweer Germany and Russia appeared yesterday to have made American isolationists more isolationist than ever and American interventionists more strongly convinced than ever that their views were right.

Defense contractors and sub-contractors are beginning to feel the pinch of the tight raw material supply as more and more commodities to under formal priorities, according to Philip M. McCullough, who last week was put in charge of the New York office of the priorities division of the Office of Production Management.

CARMEL, N.Y., June 22 -- Four persons died and two others are in critical condition in the Peekskill Hospital as the result of a four-car collision that occurred at 2 A.M. today on U.S. Route 6, two miles south of Lake Mahopac.

Financial markets had no opportunity to pass judgment upon Germany's declaration of war on Russia and invasion of that country; the news came in after midnight yesterday, when the Stock Exchange had been closed for hours. There had been rumors in Wall Street of such action throughout last week, but they had been hardly taken at face value.

The war proclamations delivered yesterday by Hitler and Molotoff as the mouthpiece of Stalin sound like a dialogue in hell, supposing hell to be some subcellar in the moral universe where evil is good and falsehood is truth. Each accuses the other of "unparalleled perfidy"; each charges the other with all the crimes he himself has committed; each calls the other a liar and a traitor.

SEEKONK, Mass., June 22 -- Three well-trained dogs obtained passing marks in the tracking tests today which marked the conclusion of the first licensed trials of the Obedience Training Club of Rhode Island at the Jacobs Hill Hunt Club.

MRS. GEORGE RUSSELL STRAUSS (Patricia O'Flynn), wife of the British M.P. and author of the newly published "Bevin and Co." was visiting New York last Fall and went to register as an alien at a postoffice on Lexington Avenue. Given a preliminary pink form to fill in, she filled it in in longhand and took it to a young man sitting at a typewriter.

Damascus, now fallen to the Allies, is one of the great prizes of the Arab world. Beirut may be of more strategic value, because of its fine harbor. But Damascus, "Eye of the East," is the political and cultural citadel of the Syrian states. Whoever holds it controls the nerve center of nationalism in the Near East.

BERLIN, June 22 -- The ban on wartime dividends exceeding the rate of 6 per cent, which was announced for the first time in the address by Dr. Walther Funk, president of the Reichsbank, on March 12, has at last been embodied in a decree, the main outlines of which were made public here today.

A transcription of Weber's "Perpetuum Mobile" by George Szell, the Czech conductor now resident in this country, received its first New York concert performance at last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Alexander Smallens.

BERLIN, June 22 -- The following is the text of Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop's statement on the German declaration of war against Russia. [An abbreviated version, which was the only one then available, appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday morning]:

Pat Harrison was only 59. He had been in Congress for thirty years. It was reasonable to hope that he might have ten or even fifteen years more of it. To the Senate and the country his death brings a sharp sense of frustration and loss. He was the overthrower of Vardaman.

LAKE MAHOPAC, N.Y., June 22 -- Post-war world organization, politically and economically, was urged with variations by speakers at the closing session of the June conference of the League for Industrial Democracy here today.

Impresarios so far have not been able to make a success of outdoor operatic productions at the Triboro Stadium on Randalls Island, but last night Maurice Frank and his 24-year-old assistant, Charles E. Rasher, undaunted by previous failures, launched a new operatic venture there with a performance of Verdi's "Aida," which was attended by 7,000 persons.

PITTSBURGH, June 22 -- The rush of steel buying which has raised weekly tonnages booked as much as 40 to 50 per cent above capacity and shipments, continued in the industry last week, although indications are becoming clearer that a large part of this volume will not reach consumers at anywhere near the time expected.

The American people must save themselves from the "spiritual casualties" of war and become more patient with both God and their fellow-men if they are to avoid a revival of "the medieval doctrine of man's total depravity," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday morning in his sermon in Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

With a sudden fury which seems in one dramatic moment to epitomize the whole long record of their own internal violence, the two great revolutionary regimes of modern times have now been thrown into mortal combat. This is the war which destiny has plotted, the long foreseen conflict between totalitarian and totalitarian.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Major attention in Washington today was centered upon the Far East rather than upon Europe as a result of Germany's attack on the Soviet Union. If Japan decides to play the part of an active Axis partner in the conference of leaders in Tokyo tomorrow, the United States, with most of its naval strength in the Pacific, might be forced to resist.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 22 -- Vast throngs of Roman Catholic clergy, religious and laity arrived today at the Twin Cities to attend the ninth National Eucharistic Congress, which will open Tuesday and will continue through Thursday.

LONDON, Monday, June 23 -- In another series of big daylight sweeps over the German-occupied territory of Northern France yesterday, the Royal Air Force shot down thirty German fighters, many of the new Messerschmitt t09-F type, with a loss of only two of their own planes.
The individual index numbers for May for the several groups of commodities, as compiled by the British Board of Trade, compare as follows with a month and a year ago:

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 22 -- Veteran skippers, with thousands of miles of cruising and many race victory to their credit, found today on the Hudson that a newcomer could bone up on the science of navigating and do a better job in laying a river course, sighting his polorus and calculating the tides and currents.
CINCINNATI, June 22 -- After twenty-five innings of battling in a sweltering heat of 95 degrees the Dodgers were able to leave here tonight only one game behind the first-place Cardinals.

BERLIN, June 22 -- With the advance into Russia by the Reich's armed forces at the sunrise hour today, the political, military and economic liaison between Berlin and Moscow came to a spectacular end.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 22 -- Five thousand members of Local 16, Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C.I.O. affiliate, voted here today to continue work pending negotiations with the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company of Kearny, which is engaged in building cruisers and destroyers for the United States Navy.

NEW ORLEANS, June 22 -- Cotton futures made new seasonal highs here for ten consecutive sessions before the upward move was halted temporarily on last Wednesday, but the reaction was attributed to a technical correction rather than to any bearish news.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 22 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies, commenting today on Germany's invasion of Russia, which aroused great excitement throughout Australia, said it was the most sensational news, representing what might be described as the high-water mark of Reichsfuehrer Hitler's cynicism.

The American people, although bewildered by the destruction of civilization in Europe, must not permit themselves to fear for the future of their own destiny, the Rev. Ralph S. Meadowcroft declared yesterday morning in his sermon in All Angels Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street.
FIELD HEADQUARTERS, SEC- OND ARMY, MANCHESTER, Tenn., June 22 -- They played "Tur- key in the Straw" and Uncle Char- ley did the calling.

Trade associations in the cottontextile industry, after learning that it is the intention of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply to reject all offers of industry committee control of prices, have issued advices to their members suggesting a cautious policy with respect to cooperation lest the industry run afoul of the anti-trust laws, it was learned at the weekend.

New York State's net funded debt on June 1, last, was $514,341,880, or about 2 per cent of the assessed value of the property in the State subject to taxation for State purposes, Controller Morris S. Tremaine revealed today in a statement of the State's financial condition in anticipation of tomorrow's sale of a $15,000,000 issue of State long-term bonds for institutionbuilding purposes.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Germany's attack on Russia is regarded by the State Department as convincing proof that Reichsfuehrer Hitler plans to dominate the world.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 22 -- Time trials by Wisconsin's varsity and freshman eights today provided the only excitement in the rowing camps pitched here for Wednesday's intercollegiate regatta.

Warning that the morale of America has already been invaded, the Rev. Dr. Frederick B. Harris declared yesterday that the inescapable function of the church today is to see that the walls of America are built of hearts and minds, and not just bombs and steel.

Nine thousand sons and daughters of the Gael, representing the thirty-two counties of Ireland, thronged the Fordham University campus in the Bronx yesterday afternoon to participate in and attend the ninth annual feis of the United Irish Counties.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 22 -- The main bulk of the army of General Henri Feroand Dentz, the French High Commissioner for the mandated territories in Syria and Lebanon, is now facing encirclement by the Allied forces as the British column that fought its way west from Iraq entered the important central tow of Tadmur this afternoon.

BUCHAREST, German-Occupied Rumania, June 22 (AP) -- General Ion Antonescu sent Rumania's Army against Soviet Russia today as a full-fledged ally of Germany, ordering his troops to recapture Rumanian soil.

MOSCOW, June 22 (UP) -- The government today ordered a blackout of all buildings, offices, factories and railroads and committees were instructed to inform the population regarding air raid precautio, measures. Air raid and gas attack shelters were ordered prepared.

For the third consecutive day the heat wave clung to the city yesterday, sending the temperature up to 94 degrees, a record for the date, and driving many thousands of New Yorkers along blistering roads to seek relief at seaside and mountain resorts.

Opening of Fall lines of fashion merchandise attracted not only large numbers of buyers but appreciably heavy ordering in the wholesale markets here last week. Browns and black were outstanding in dressy coats. Short untrimmed coats were ordered in costume-suit lines.
AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), June 22 -- The markets of the smaller Continental European countries last week displayed a quiet attitude pending further war developments, with price changes mostly narrow.

Finland is "ready by all her means to guard her freedom and independence" and "is not proanything except pro-Finnish," Herman Ramo, director of the Finnish Information Bureau, declared yesterday before 1,000 persons at the seventh annual Finnish Folk Festival on the Mall in Central Park.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- In an atmosphere complicated by the Russo-German war, Congress prepared tonight to clear up all remaining appropriation bills this week and act on legislation to curb Communist and other radical minorities in American labor.
LONDON, June 22 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

TOKYO, June 22 -- The outbreak of war between Germany and Russia despite the Russian-German nonaggression pact froze official Japan into icy silence. The only official comment was that there would be no comment.

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- The Braves today handed the Cubs their first double defeat of the year. Al Javery's six-hit pitching won the nightcap, 3 to 2, after Boston had come from behind with two runs each in the eighth and ninth innings to take the opener, 6 to 5.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 22 -- At midday yesterday Ethiopian patriot forces under British officers took Jimma, former headquarters of the Italians in Western Ethiopia and their largest remaining center of resistance in that area, the British Middle East Command reported here today.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 22 (AP) -- Ben Hogan and Jimmy Demaret, both Texans, lost one match and won another, 1 up, today to take the seventh annual $7,000 Inverness invitation four-ball golf tournament and split the $2,000 first prize.

The Communist party of the United States issued last night a statement that termed the German war on Russia "an unprovoked criminal attack upon the greatest champion of peace, freedom and national independence."

ST. LOUIS, June 22 -- Doing another of those amazing turnabouts which seem to be rapidly turning the entire National League topsy-turvy, the Giants today tripped the front-running Cardinals in both games of a torrid double-header.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The 1940 production of electric energy in the United States exceeded the previous high record, reached in 1939, by more than 14,600,000,000 kilowatt-hours, or 11.2 per cent, the Federal Power Commission reported today.

ST. LOUIS, June 22 -- Doing another of those amazing turnabouts which seem to be rapidly turning the entire National League topsy-turvy, the Giants today tripped the front-running Cardinals in both games of a torrid double-header.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The 1940 production of electric energy in the United States exceeded the previous high record, reached in 1939, by more than 14,600,000,000 kilowatt-hours, or 11.2 per cent, the Federal Power Commission reported today.

With an enrollment of 49 per cent of the nation's population in 1940, the 250 religious bodies in the United States maintained the increased memberships of the past decade and even added slightly to the percentage, it is revealed in the 1941 edition of the Yearbook of American Churches, announced for publication yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Armed with President Roosevelt's order freezing all American property of the Axis powers, and with a fund $900,000 larger than last year for its purposes, the Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice plans to expand considerably its drive to free American industry from restraints imposed by German patent licensing agreements, officials of the division stated today.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 22 -- The veteran team of Samuel Graham of the Greenwich Country Club and Ellis Knowles of Apawamis won the second annual member-guest best-ball golf tournament of the Greenwich Country Club today.

Tyrants and Caesars have never overcome the world; they have merely overrun the earth, and that only for a limited time, the Rev. Dr. William P. Merrill, pastor emeritus and moderator of the Presbytery of New York, said yesterday in his sermon at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street.

This first Monday of Summer finds Broadway with one more production than it had on the corresponding day last year, the score being thirteen to twelve in favor of 1941. Twelve months ago seven plays and five musicals held forth here; currently those categories number ten and three, respectively.
BERLIN, June 23 (UP) -- The D. N.B., official news agency, said tonight that eighteen British planes were shot down today in attempts to fly into German-occupied coastal territory.

Unexpected increases of 5 to 10 per cent in furniture prices were put into effect by manufacturers yesterday at the opening of the midsummer market at the New York Furniture Exchange. The announcement on Friday of a recommendation to set an industry-wide wage minimum at 40 cents an hour led to a last-minute change of mind by many manufacturers who had intended to defer raising their prices until the Chicago event in July.

An incorporated securities concern has been admitted to full membership in the Boston Stock Exchange for the first time in its 107 years, John E. Yerxa, president, announced yesterday. The firm of Perrin, West Winslow, Inc., has bought a seat on the Exchange, which thus becomes the first large securities market to extend full membership to a corporation.
The Park Avenue and other East Side areas accounted for the bulk of the residential leasing activity reported by brokers yesterday.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, June 24 -- Soviet troops colliding with, the mechanized fury of the German Army on a front extending from the Baltic to the Black Sea have destroyed 300 German tanks and captured 5,000 German troops, the Red Army High Command announced early today.

BERLIN, June 23 -- Since dawn yesterday the German legions have been constantly advancing along their routes of invasion into Russia. The German attack appears to have been so successful in its initial stages that deep inroads have already been made into Western Russia and devastating blows dealt the Red Air Force.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, its subsidiary, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, Inc., and the B.F. Goodrich Company, all of Akron, Ohio; Sears.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 23 -- Katharine Hepburn, who was labeled box office poison by exhibitors and then disproved the charge in last year's "The Philadelphia Story," was signed today for a second picture at Metro, temporarily titled "Woman of the Year."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 23 (AP) -- Earl Stewart of Louisiana State University who less than a week ago had a cast removed from a broken collarbone which had kept him off the links for seven weeks, ripped four strokes off par today to pace 169 starters through the first half of the qualifying round for the forty-fourth national intercollegiate golf championships.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- The outbreak of war between Russia and Germany sent prices of grains, soy beans and lard soaring today, with all deliveries of wheat, corn, oats, soy beans and lard selling at new seasonal high prices. Corn, soy beans and lard were at their best levels since 1937.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

ALBANY, June 23 (AP) -- Mounting defense production, already causing a scarcity of "all types of desirable labor," will create more than 65,000 new jobs in up-State New York within a few months, the State Labor Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 - Then were no signs in Washington today that, because of the character of the Soviet Government and the nature of its system, the United States will make Russia an exception to the basic lease-lend policy of giving all aid to any nation which is invaded by and resists the Nazis.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 23 -- Wallace Shaffer and Pat Cici of the Meadow Brook Club combined to clip eight strokes from par in winning the amateur-pro tourney of the Long Island P.G.A. with a 30, 34 -- 64 score at the North Hempstead Country Club today.
VICHY, France, June 23 (AP) -- The French issued the following communique tonight on operations in the Levant:

All the full-bodied, friendly fragrance of fat frankfurters and steaming sauerkraut-whose very name evokes a vision of frosty, foaming steins of beer and Schnitzelbank singing-has been incorporated into a compact jar that has just arrived in town.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 23 -- Fighting along the Russo-German front appeared today to be gradually concentrating along two lines -- in the north along a line stretching from Lyck, East Prussia, to Brest-Litovsk; in the south along a line roughly defined by the Pruth River, which the Germans have crossed at several points with no decisive results thus far.

RYE, N.Y., June 23 -- Miss Margaret Nichols, promising young player from Hudson River, fashioned an 86 in leading a field of eighty-eight for medal honors in the nineteenth annual women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association match-play championship today.

While most New Yorkers were pleased by the northeasterly winds that broke the three-day heat wave yesterday, the weather man was a little embarrassed that he had not predicted as much, although he'd seen it coming.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones told the House Rivers and Harbors Committee today that the $285,000.000 St. Lawrence seaway and power project could be built "without costing the taxpayers a dime" and would make available new sources of shipbuilding and power to bolster the national defense.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 23 (AP) -- The British Middle Bast Command issued this communique today:

Representatives of the Securities and Exchange Commission and public utility executives were among about twenty-five persons at he first test of the commission's ompulsory competitive bidding rule for utility securities yesterday when officials of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation attempted to sell approximately $47,000,000 of new securities.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), June 23 -- Heavy covering by the short interest caused a strong market here today especially in the Dutch here today especially in the Netherland Indies section. Amsterdam Rubber rose 14 1/4 points to 399 1/2, Amsterdam Rubber 9 to 246 5/8, Royal Dutch 81 1/8 to 230 1/8 and Unlever 2 1/4 to 113 3/4.
JERSEY CITY, June 23 (AP) -- Jersey City made it two in a row in its series with Newark tonight by defeating the Bears, 3 to 1, before a crowd of 4,862.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Representative Boggs Introduced a bill in the House today prohibiting members of the Communist and Fascist parties and the German-American Bund from membership in United States labor unions and from employment by the Federal Government or by persons holding government contracts.

WASHINGTON, June 23-Tentative approval was given today by the House Ways and Means Committee to increased rates for gift and inheritance taxes which are expected to increase the yield by $113,700,000 a year. The new rates were proposed for the Defense Tax Bill, designed to raise $3,500,000,000 to help finance the defense program.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended June 18 aggregated $11,494,000,000.

The board of governors of the Commodity Exchange, Inc., voted yesterday to prohibit the opening of new positions in rubber futures. The board further amended the rule governing price fluctuations in rubber by reducing the daily limit to 1/2 cent a pound from 2 cents.

Statements that a slush fund of $40,000 was raised in 1937 by a combination of Queens County contractors and was to have been paid to John J. Halleran, Commissioner of Public Works in Queens, have been made to John Murtagh, staff aide to Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen, who is investigating a city-wide paving racket.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 23 -- Complying with a request from Mayor La Guardia of New York, national head of civilian defense, that Westchester County proceed at once to establish a county airport for use as a military interceptor base, the County Board of Supervisors held a special meeting this afternoon and authorized a committee of five to recommend a site for the project.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today began at the reguest of Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, a check on unregulated commodity markets to detect possible speculative activity.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, June 24 (AP) -- The Red Army High Command issued this comnunique today:
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Nazi war machine must crush the Red Army in three months or face disastrous difficulties, according to well-informed opinion here.

BERLIN, June 23 (AP) -- Lithuanians here said the Kaunas radio had proclaimed an uprising against Soviet Russia and establishment of a new government today, but German authorities professed to know nothing about an insurgent anti-Russian regime in Lithuania.

Dissolution of the Equitable Trust Company of New York, which was formed in 1930 to assume certain trust business that conflicted with that of the Chase National Bank, when the Chase in that year absorbed the old Equitable Trust Company, whose history dated back to 1871, is to be voted formally today at a special meeting of Stockholders.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Representative August H. Andresen. Republican of Minnesota, submitted to the Committee for Reciprocity Information today a petition which, he said, was signed by nearly 100 Republican members of the House protesting the proposed negotiations of trade agreements with Argentina and Uruguay.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Arthur Bliss Lane, United States Minister to Yugoslavia; Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, and Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce. The White House announced the President had signed the bill to amend the Federal Crop Insurance Act and also several minor measures.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 18. An increase of $28,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, decreases of $54,000,000 in holdings of "other securities," $163,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks, and $199,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and an increase of $67,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

Heat in the City Summer is much kinder to the people of New York than the warm season used to be. The youngest generation knows only by hearsay the long list of heat prostrations, with fatalities occasionally rising to hundreds daily, which are so vivid a memory of city Summers before the World War.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board made public today the formula for settlement of all its outstanding cases against the Ford Motor Company after the signing of a unionshop contract by Ford and the C.I.O. United Auto Workers Union.

A $440,000 loan to the Haven Building Corporation on the sixstory apartment house under erection on an irregular plot between 173d and 176th Streets, from Haven Avenue to Riverside Drive, has been arranged with the Seamen's Bank for Savings.

Leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association. A.F. of L., voted yesterday afternoon against any support of striking longshoremen of the Cunard White Star Line at Piers 54 and 56, North River, who have demanded the dismissal by the steamship company of Captain John Barlow, assistant marine superintendent of the line's piers.

The first official statement of the position of the United States regarding Hitler's attack on Russia, a statement made yesterday by Under-Secretary Welles. is as sensible as it is straight-forward. We have not suddenly become friends of the Soviet regime because one dictatorship has quarreled with another.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 23 -- Cooperation with Great Britain to bring about as quickly as possible the defeat of Germany and, as well, the "coalescence" of the American and British navies to maintain peace in the world, are roles to be played by the United States as a world power, Major George Fielding Eliot declared tonight at the opening session of the annual Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.

Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, Director of Selective Service here, yesterday forwarded instructions to 280 local draft boards for registering upward of 70,000 young men in this city who will have reached their twenty-first birthday by next Tuesday.

DETROIT, Mich., June 23 -- While speakers at the American Newspaper Guild convention today united in condemning the use of troops in strikes, R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers. I.O., declared that the issue in the North American Aviation Company strike was "irresponsible leadership."
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Legislation designed to facilitate construction of petroleum pipe lines was opposed today before a Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee.

PITTSBURGH, June 23 -- Round Freddy Fitzsimmons's three-year mastery over the Pirates remained unbroken today as the Dodgers sank the Buccos under a 9-4 score in the opener of a three-game set and moved to a half game from the National League-leading Cardinals.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LONDON, June 23 -- The weather undoubtedly is Britain's biggest commodity news item last week. Following a long, wet but comparatively mild Winter, the country experienced a wet, cold Spring. Consequently the crops, after coming well through the Winter, responded poorly in the Spring.

BERLIN, June 23 (UP) -- German Panzer divisions, aided by flame throwers, artificial fog and blasting artillery, have broken through fortified Russian lines at "numerous points" and a clash between the two main forces is imminent, the German news agency D.N.B. reported tonight.

LONDON, June 23 -- Ambassador John G. Winant of the United States, newly arrived from a trip to Washington, today saw Ivan Maisky, the Soviet Ambassador, and Mr. Maisky saw Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden. These conferences were undoubtedly concerned with the adjustment in relations with Russia that will now have to take place as a result of her conflict with Germany.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 23 -- Tony Tiso of Hickory and Saul Lantzis of Femvay posted 33, 32 -- 65 in the Westchester P.G.A. oneday tournament at the Gedney Country Club today to win the bestball pro-amateur event for the second straight week and the third time in the last four county tourneys.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 23 -- Two of the leading contenders for the national intercollegiate tennis championship failed to survive the opening round today as the fifty-seventh annual tournament started on the clay courts of the Merion Cricket Club, with Joe Hunt of the United States Naval Academy as the man to beat for the title won last year by Donald McNeill of Kenyon.

A syndicate headed by the Bankers Trust Company won yesterday the award of $3,500,000 of airport bonds of Los Angeles, Calif., on a bid of 100.05 for $699,000 of the securities due from 1942 to 1944 as 3s, $1,163,000 due from 1945 to 1951 as 1 1/4s and $1,170,000 due from 1952 to 1956 as 1 1/2s, or a net interest cost of 1.4666 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Military experts here said today that Russia apparently had a numerical superiority on the Western Front, with an estimated total of 5,000,000 men, but disagreed over the fighting quality of the Red Army. Concern was felt over the lack of mature leadership as a result of the series of purges which "liquidated" much of the top command.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Condemning communism and nazism as "intolerable" to the people of the United States, but still viewing the defeat of Reichsfuehrer Hitler's attempt at conquest as the greatest task facing the world, the United States Government gave Soviet Russia ground for hope today for material assistance in her war against Germany.

Two more witnesses testified yesterday about Communist activity at City College at the trial in General Sessions of Morris U. Schappes, suspended English tutor, who is charged with perjury in connection with testimony he gave last Spring before the Rapp-Coudert legislative committee investigating subversive activities in schools.

DETROIT, June 23 (AP) -- A proposed contract between the Great Lakes Steel Corporation and the C.I.O.'s Steel Workers Organizing Committee, one described as the best offered in the steel industry, was rejected yesterday by a 2-to-1 vote of workers at a mass meeting.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 23 -- Acclaimed by great crowds of devout Catholics as the personal representative of Pope Pius XII, Dennis Cardinal Dougherty of Philadelphia arrived today to serve as Papal Legate at the ninth national Eucharistic Congress, which he will formally open tomorrow morning.

Declaring that every phase of business is being adjusted to current conditions, Reiss Advertising, in a booklet issued yesterday, declared that the advertising appropriation should be subject to "seizure and search" just as much as any other factor in business.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 23 -- A stiff battle between units of the Soviet Fleet, including light cruisers and destroyers, and the German Luftwaffe was reported to be going on today in the western limits of the Black Sea. These reports, it may be emphasized, entirely lacked confirmation.
WASHINGTON. June 23 -- Negotiations between Southern soft-coal operators and the C.I.O.'s United Mine Workers of America reached a crisis late today.

Picturing the organization of the British Royal Air Force as "at about 105 per cent," Juan T. Trippe, president of the Pan American Airways System, predicted yesterday that there would be no more daylight air raids over England and that while night raids were still expected they would prove very costly to the Germans.

The United Artists Distributing Corporation will inaugurate a new sales policy during the 1941-42 season and will not set any minimum or maximum on the number of pictures it will distribute, it was announced yesterday by Arthur W. Kelly, vice president and acting chief executive since the resignation last month of Murray Silverstone, general manager of world-wide operations!

Ty Cobb is worried. The Georgia Peach, who hung up his baseball spikes in 1928 with a lifetime batting average of 368 and who now fancies himself as a pretty good amateur golfer -- at least good enough to beat Babe Ruth -- arrived in New York yesterday.

For the second time within three days a large group of European refugees arrived in New York when the Portuguese liner Serpa Pinto docked yesterday at Pier 8, Stapleton, S.I., with 685 regular passengers and six Portuguese stowaways.

Lin Yutang will leave with his family this week-end for the peaceful Vermont woods to spend the Summer months. He plans to complete his new novel in the same camp where, in 1939, he wrote "Moment in Peking." The new book, as yet untitled, will begin where "Moment in Peking" ended, just after the outbreak of the war in China.

Department Store Sales Up 11% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 11 per cent for the week ended June 21, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
German troops moving against Russia will find themselves confronted by a veritable Chinese Wall nearly 1,300 miles long and at certain spots nearly 100 miles deep.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The British Embassy stated today that, beginning July 1, "mailcerts" will be issued to facilitate the passage of United States parcel post and package mail to neutral countries through the British censorship.

BOSTON, June 23 -- Characterizing the public library as "one of the finest manifestations of American democracy," Mrs. Hiram Cole Houghton, president of the Iowa Library Association, told trustees of the American Library Association at their annual convention today that books could be "the most powerful weapons in the defense of democracy" in the face of the present "mighty challenge."

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Arlington Park's rich Summer meeting, which will see the distribution to horsemen of more than $475,000 in purses through thirty-four days, opened today with the first of the track's thirteen stake events being won by Kings Blue, a 5-to-1 shot from the Huntley Sher Stable of Miami, Fla.

The sixty-two acre estate with a large residence, guest house and other buildings in the Union section of Morris Plains, N.J., has been purchased from the Russell Flagg VanDoorn estate by Joseph O. Senner of Brooklyn. The property was sold through Fred A. Barbanes, Morristown broker.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

A super-strong boxing ring was ordered by Mike Jacobs yesterday. The Twentieth Century Sporting Club president, ever the one to think ahead, placed his order for a durable fighting enclosure coincident with an announcement that he had signed Buddy Baer to meet Abe Simon in a fifteen-round bout at the Polo Grounnds on Aug. 14.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 23 -- Both the Finnish Foreign Minister, Dr. R.J. Witting, and the Soviet Minister to Helsinki, Pavel Orloff, have today declared that their countries are not at war with each other, thus leaving no doubt that for the time being, at least, Finland is neutral.

BERLIN, June 23 -- Soviet-German trade relations since the outbreak of the European war were presented today in Berlin in an entirely new light by well-informed German circles. It was asserted that Russian deliveries of foodstuffs and raw materials since September, 1939, served the purpose of "camouflaging the political intentions of the Soviet Union."

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 23 -- Two debutantes were presented to society tonight, second week of the North Shore "Little Season," which finds many of the country houses filled with young guests, classmates of the young men and women from school and college.

ROME, June 23 -- Those Italians who missed yesterday's radio messages learned today from their newspapers about what is called here "the Axis war against Russia." How the average Italian must feel about this huge expansion of the war in the Summer when he thought the conflict would end must be left to the imagination.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 24 -- The Japanese Government is expected to announce its stand in the new world situation resulting from the Russo-German conflict following a Cabinet session today. Pending the announcement, the people have been urged to maintain the utmost reserve and leave everything to the authorities.

Recent steps taken by Argentina in reducing restrictions on imports, although entirely independent of the reciprocal trade conversations with the United States, were in the true spirit of these negotiations, according to the Minister of Finance, Dr. Carlos A. Acevedo, in a recent address in Argentina before the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

SHANGHAI, June 23 -- The outbreak of German-Soviet hostilities, while having far-reaching consequences in the Far East, is regarded with mixed feelings in official and semi-official Japanese circles in China.

MOSCOW, June 23 -- Aroused workers and peasants all over Russia were reported today to be pledging themselves to multiply their output, shoulder arms and defend the country to the last man against the Germans.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Following criticism in and out of Congress of the Administration's property seizure bill because of its broad authority, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, today advanced a revised version sharply limiting this authority to military and naval defense needs.
With a heavy attendance of buy-...
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- A program of work projects that may involve $4,000,000,000 to $5,000,000,000 annually for six years after curtailment of national defense activities is now being surveyed by a new department of the Federal Works Agency, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Army probably will hold some selectees beyond the one-year training period for which they were called, but if possible it wishes to demobilize most of them at the expiration of a year of service, General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, said today.

Prince Ludovic Pignatelli's punishment for conspiring and using the mails in an effort to extort $500,000 was fixed at a year and a day in prison yesterday by Federal Judge Clarence G. Galston. His co-defendant, William M. Gibson, who wrote more letters than the Spanish nobleman and marksman, received sixteen months.

More difficulty than had been anticipated in the selection of the 152 zone wardens to act as brigadier-generals of the civilian defense army in New York City became apparent yesterday, when completion of the list was deferred for the third time.
HELSINKI, Finland, June 23 -- Actual or impending revolt in Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia was declared by anti-Soviet sources today to be threatening Russia along her northwestern frontier.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 23 -- With armies moving at high speed, a half-hour in a tank of today Is equal to a full day of marching and trench-digging in the first World War, Dr. Harold I. Magoun of Denver told the forty-fifth annual convention of the American Osteopathic Association at the municipal auditorium today.

Fresh contingents of buyers representing stores all over the country arrived in the wholesale markets here yesterday as many retail representatives who surveyed lines last week completed the placing of the earliest orders for Fall style merchandise in years.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Ways and Means Committee released today the following table comparing present gifts and estate tax yields with the amounts which the tentatively adopted new rates would bring in:

CHUNGKING, China, June 23 -- The German attack on Russia will not have any immediate decisive effect on China, authoritative observers here believe. It is thought that Russian supplies to China may be stopped, but it is pointed out that shipments on the basis of old contracts are practically finished and that Soviet cargoes would soon have ceased anyhow, pending possible conclusion of new contracts.

Counsel for the Board of Education demanded yesterday the dismissal from service of Dr. Louise F. Tucker, principal of Public School 67, the Bronx, and called upon school officials and the Corporation Counsel's office "to frustrate" any attempt of the principal to obtain retirement benefits.

TRENTON, N.J., June 23 -- Proceeding under the provisions of a new law patterned after New York's Moreland Act, Governor Charles Edison announced today that he would investigate the State Highway Department. Highway Commissioner E. Donald E. Sterner said he "welcomed" the inquiry, but would like a non-partisan one by the State Chamber of Commerce and Taxpayers' Associations.

Paul Robeson was the soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night at the Lewisohn Stadium and, despite the chilly weather, 14,000 persons turned out to hear him. Hugh Ross was the conductor and the program included two works which were given when the singer appeared at the stadium last year, William Grant Still's "And They Lynched Him on a Tree" and "Ballad for Americans."

LONDON, Tuesday, June 24 -- The record being made by the Royal Air Force in blasting the enemy's bases in France and shooting down Nazi planes on the way like so many clay pigeons was kept up by the R. A. F. yesterday. Twenty enemy fighters were destroyed at a cost of two British bombers and three escorting fighters.

Glenda Farrell, one of the three stars of "Separate Rooms," now in its second year on Broadway, has turned in her notice effective Saturday night, July 5, Miss Farrell said yesterday. She expects to leave for Hollywood immediately after her withdrawal.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Members of the Senate and House and the public paid respects to the late Senator Pat Harrison today as the body of the Senator, who died yesterday, lay in state from 2 to 6 P.M. in the flower-decked Senate chamber.

ORANGE, Texas, June 23 (AP) -- Representative Martin Dies predicted today that Hitler would be in control of Russia within thirty days, and said America must prepare for an emergency unprecedented in her history.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 21:

Harry J. Chapman of Hollis, Queens County chairman of the American Labor party, announced yesterday the slate of his party for borough offices in the Fall campaign. Mr. Chapman retained the leadership in a battle in the Supreme Court in Queens with certain members of his party whom he characterized as of the "left wing" or Communists.

Applications for special licenses to withdraw funds from "frozen" foreign accounts here continued yesterday to pour into the Foreign Property Control Department of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The department's staff, it further was made known, has been doubled since the assets in this country of the Axis powers, of Russia, Portugal and other nations were "frozen" by executive order ten days ago and that the directly involved personnel now numbers 200.

Three appraisers appointed in Supreme Court to value the stock of dissenting stockholders of the Metropolitan Opera and Real Estate Company, who objected to the price of $1,970,000 paid by the Metropolitan Opera Association, Inc., to the real estate company for the opera house and other tangible property, filed reports yesterday on their appraisal.

Air express shipments to and from New York in May totaled 48,043, an increase of 31.5 per cent over May, 1940, the air express division of Railway Express Agency reported yesterday. Gross revenue for the month was up 45.8 per cent in the city.
BERLIN, June 23 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:...

The problem of pricing finished cotton cloths and articles made from cotton goods in the light of the ceiling schedules expected to be issued by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply occupied the attention of most buyers of goods yesterday and this, together with the uncertainty over when the schedules would be issued, kept trading in goods down to virtually nothing again yesterday.

TRENTON, June 23 -- Action looking to settlement of the railroad tax problem was deferred tonight for another week by the Legislature while the controversy over the plan advocated by Governor Charles Edison became bitter.

A boom of major proportions struck the stock market at the opening of business yesterday, sky-rocketing prices 1 to 4 points, the additions were redduced by approximately half in the remainder of the session as trading lightened.

CERTAIN readers, I am sure, will be fascinated and delighted by Kate O'Brien's new novel, "The Land of Spices."* No doubt they will be few in number in relation to the American reading public at large, for this is pretty special and delicate fare, dealing as it does with life in an Irish convent school and having as a central character the austere figure of the convent's Reverend Mother.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture issued today a mid-month crop report forecasting production of Winter wheat in nine States -- Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Missouri, Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma, Texas and Colorado -- as indicated by conditions on June 16 at 476,310,000 bushels, compared with 488,770,000 that were predicted on the June 1 situation.

In units of electrical energy this country is literally the most powerful nation in the world. The report of the Federal Power Commission, published yesterday, cites figures for capacity and production that have already been discussed on this page: 41,638,956 kilowatts of generating capacity and a little under 150,000,000,000 kilowatt-hours actually turned out during 1940.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Verbal tilts between attorneys and long conferences at the bench today impeded progress in the Bookniga Corporation trial at which the company itself and the three officers -- Morris Liskin, Raphael Rush and Norman Weinberg -- are being tried under indictments charging failure to register as alien agents.

As the German military machine started rolling across the vast, inscrutable steppes of Russia it set in motion tremors and repercussions it is as yet far too early to follow to the end. It will take time to see the full effects on the rest of the world of this monstrous reversal of policy.

Sudden action by Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, barring from graduation 20-year-old Miss Roslyn Cohen following her testimony before the Rapp-Coudert legislative committee investigating subversive activities in the schools, caused a short-lived protest demonstration that was broken up by police during the college's commencement exercises on the campus yesterday morning.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 23 -- With only forty-eight hours remaining before the crews move to the starting line in Wednesday's intercollegiate regatta, training at the nine camps eased off today. Rain brought relief from the heat wave, but the usual pre-race tension was felt at all camps.

Registering gains of 33 to 40 points, prices of all active deliveries except the July on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced yesterday to the highest levels since June, 1930. The December position and other later months went above 15 cents a pound, while October touched a high of 14.99 cents.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Three Office of Production Management officials resigned today. They were Samuel R. Fuller Jr., of New York, head of the production division's materials branch; C. W. Kellogg of New York, power consultant, and R. C. Alien of Cleveland, consultant in the iron and steel unit.

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Hog prices continued their steady rise today, advancing 25 cents to new four-year highs. A moderate run of receipts, and better dressed quotations in the wholesale market acted as a stimulus to higher swine prices. Buyers paid a top of $10.75 for choice offerings. The average hog price has now advanced each day since June 6 in one of the longest uninterrupted upturns in stockyard history.
Mayor La Guardia established his Summer City Hall in the old Arrowbrook Club in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday and put in a full day on a long schedule of appointments.
Harlem yesterday was added to the city areas where loft properties recently have gone into new ownership. Operators were principals in several of the deals reported during the day.

Painstaking burglars with a thorough knowledge of skins used the week-end to loot the Alaska Fur Dye Works at 40 West Seventeenth Street of $30,000 to $40,000 worth of choice mink and sable. The police said it was one of the largest fur thefts here in recent years.

One of the largest industrial property sales made in Hoboken, N.J., for some time took place yesterday when the Elevator Supplies Company, Inc., sold the industrial building at 1516-32 Park Avenue to the Sweets Company of America. The building is four stories and occupies a site 240 by 165 feet.

The first broadbill swordfish of the season, arriving off the Long Island and New Jersey coasts just about on schedule, were brought in to Montauk and Brielle on Sunday, and excitement was high at both of these ports when the news of the catches spread.

Irving Schiller, who was charged as a member of Local Draft Board 182 with soliciting and receiving a $100 bribe for a promise of selective service deferment on March 5, unexpectedly pleaded guilty to two counts in the four-count indictment before Judge Robert A. Inch yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court.

There was little or no change in yesterday's wholesale dressed meat market. Demand for most classes continued slow. Steer hinds and ribs sold mostly steady with last Friday's quotations. Veal hindsaddles were steady, lamb prices uneven, mostly steady. Pork cuts steady. The market on kosher steer chucks and plates opened slow with prices weak to 50 cents lower.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Following their heroic efforts in St. Louis over the week-end the Giants experienced a let-down today. Giltedged pitching by Claude Passeau may have had something to do with it, for the score by which Jimmy Wilson's Cubs beat Colonel Bill Terry's troops in the opening clash of a three-game series was 1 to 0.
NEW YORK Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse, who had been at the Plaza for several weeks after returning from Palm Beach, has gone to The Fens, her Summer home in East Hampton.

Business firms and employe groups In Queens have contributed $172,823 to the Greater New York Fund for the support of its affiliated health and welfare agencies, according to announcement made yesterday by Walter S. Mack Jr., Queens camaign chairman, at the final report luncheon at the Howard Johnson restaurant. Elmhurst, Queens.

The Belair Stud had a perfect score at Aqueduct yesterday in the presence of owner William Woodward, when two homebred bearers of the white silk with red spots faced the starter and two came home in front. A crowd of 10,665 that included the chairman of the Jockey Club saw a successful return to competition of Foxbrough, bred here but raced in England until the war forced his return.

The details of the new Communist "party line," made necessary by the outbreak of war between Germany and Russia, doubtless will be laid down at a meeting of the Communist National Committee to be held Saturday. The meeting was announced yesterday.

Early release of $1,700,000 worth of machine tools and parts, oil field equipment and other machinery purchased here by Russia but immobilized in East and West Coast warehouses for months by export licensing restrictions, was forecast here yesterday by exporters, as a result of the German invasion of the Soviet.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce, and Leland Olds, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, warned today that this nation might face a "long pull" on defense preparations and urged the development of the St. Lawrence seaway and power project as a step in making the country safe from attack.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Springfield, Mo., with a gain of 49 per cent, and San Diego, Calif., with a rise of 48 per cent over last year, led in May retail sales increases by cities, according to the report issued by the Federal Reserve Board. Norfolk, Va., reporting an upswing of 48 per cent over 1940, made the best showing for the first five months of this year.

THEY must give a grand course in Business Administration at the University of Michigan. One of the students, who just finished his sophomore slice of that course, stepped out and made himself $40,000, $42,500, $45,000 or $50,000, depending upon who tells the tale. But it's still pretty good, even at the low figure of $40,000, part cash.
Higher prices were being asked for some grades of leather yesterday because of the effect of ceilings established by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply on all grades of hides.

KINGSTON, Ont., June 23 -- A permanent "partnership" between Canada and the United States as an outcome of the war, with Canada accepting its responsibilities toward Latin America and the United States linking itself closely with Britain, was predicted tonight by Dr. R.C. Wallace, principal and vice chancellor of Queen's University, at the opening of the fourth biennial conference on CanadianAmerican affairs.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 -- In a twofold effort to end a forty-five-day strike of machinists in shipyards with $500,000,000 in warships and other emergency contracts, the Navy tomorrow will begin signing machinists on civil service rolls and Bethlehem will sign a closed shop contract for the major struck plant.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Treasury and Justice Departments today banned the departure of Italian nationals from the United States pending further instructions.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS, SECOND ARMY, MANCHESTER, Tenn., June 23 -- Clouds of Tennessee dust mushroomed above the dirt roads of the drought-ridden hill country today as 77,000 men of the Second Army commenced the final exercises of a month of manoeuvres.

If it's any consolation to youngsters and to the countless adults who used to delight in touching off most of Junior's roman candles and skyrockets, Independence Day this year would be a "safe and sane" one even if legislation on the State's statute books did not prohibit the sale and use of fireworks.
LONDON, June 23 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

At a farewell dinner given by the American Friends of Irish Neutrality last night at the Murray Hill Hotel, Frank Aiken, Eire's Minister for Coordination of Defense, reiterated his belief that Ireland must maintain its neutrality in the present conflict.

MADRID, Spain, June 23 -- "Many thousands of Spaniards undoubtedly want to organize an expeditionary corps to join the fight on Russia," it was stated in official circles today. No answer was given to inquiries whether the Spanish Government had decided to send an expeditionary force.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 23M -- Miss Janet Douglas of Rumson led a field of seventy-nine contestants in the first round of the seventeenth annual women's New Jersey Golf Association medal play championship when she topped the favorites by two strokes with her card of 40, 40 -- 80 on the hilly third and fourth nines of the Montclair Club course today.

Despite the imperfections of democracies, when the "blueprints" offered by Utopians are worked out the apparent advantages of these plans will melt away, Raymond Gram Swing, radio commentator, told 1,389 men and women graduates of Brooklyn College in the principal address at the college's sixteenth commencement exercises yesterday morning on the campus.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 23 -- The Empire State Automobile Merchants Association opened its annual two-day convention today with words of pessimism on every side.

When the "Lou Gehrig Memorial" is unveiled at the Yankee Stadium on July 4, the fans will receive souvenir tickets of the event. The top half of the ticket of admission to the double-header between the Yankees and Senators will bear a head-and-shoulder photograph of the great Iron Man, who died recently.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 25 -- Hammering Germany's industrial centers in the northwest and her fighting aircraft over France, the British Royal Air Force yesterday kept up its prolonged campaign of attrition, bagging nine enemy fighters.

HAMPTON, Va., June 24 -- In a wind blown haze, the leaders in the Storm Trysail Club's ocean race from New London, Conn., swept into Chesapeake Bay today. After crossing the finish line off Old Point Comfort and berthing at the Hampton Yacht Club, the crews enthused over a fine sail, some after covering 422 miles and the others 347 miles.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 24 -- After straddling the Damascus - Beirut road west of Damascus, British troops in Syria yesterday pushed twelve miles southwest and occupied Qatana. Today they headed north again from Qatana toward the road, expecting to reach the highway at Tekkie, the source of Damascus's power and water supply.

VICHY, France, June 24 -- News reaches here that in Turkey the dispositions taken by the High Command have been modified in the last few days, and that bodies of troops have been moved south close to the Syrian border.

The Southern Kraft Corporation, which was a wholly owned subsidiary, has been merged into the International Paper Company as a sequel to the recent financing of the latter, it was announced yesterday by Richard J. Cullen, president. These measures are steps in a long-range program of recapitalization and reorganization which ultimately will result in elimination of the International Paper and Power Company, owner of almost all the shares of International Paper.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 24 -- Under a blazing sun that beat down upon 50,000 worshipers, Dennis Cardinal Dougherty of Philadelphia, the legate of Pope Pius XII, formally opened the eighth National Eucharistic Congress this morning with a solemn pontifical mass, celebrated with all the splendor and magnificence the church has handed down through the ages.

There seems to be no end to the list of delectable soups that may begin a meal in enticing, icy-cold fashion during stifling, sultry weather. The most recent addition to this lengthening roster is a pumpkin soup of tawny tint.

The defense opened its case in the perjury trial of Morris Schappes, suspended City College English tutor and former Communist, by calling to the witness stand in General Sessions yesterday a group of City College teachers who denied accusations made by State witnesses that they were or had been Communists.

News of smashing Nazi German attacks in the invasion of Soviet Russia brought about yesterday a general retreat in securities and commodities, with the losses in the principal staples of more serious proportions than those in the share list.

It was a special occasion yesterday for 20-year-old Paul Weber, a paralysis victim since early childhood. A full commencement program was held for him at the Jewish Sanitarium and Hospital for Chronic Diseases, Rutland Road and East Forty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, where Paul, in the presence of high officials of the Board of Education, received his high school diploma.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 23.

BOSTON, June 24 (AP) -- The third-place Red Sox pulled within three games of first place today by slaughtering three of the pace-setting Indians' pitchers for eighteen hits, including three homers, to gain a 13-2 triumph before a crowd of 8,000 that included Babe Ruth.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 24 -- When the campaigns of France and the Netherlands showed the absolute necessity of rapid-firing light and medium artillery to resist tank and dive-bomber attacks, the Russian industrial machine was set to work turning out these arms in large quantities, and today, only a year later, this major change has been in large measure completed, according to General Blagenravow, military commentator of the Pravda.
ST. LOUIS, June 24 (AP) -- The Cardinals were hotter than the weather today -- 90 degrees and a broiling sun -- as they smothered the Braves, 13 to 1.
NEW YORK Mrs. William Phillips, wife of the United States Ambassador to Italy, arrived yesterday on the steamship Exeter from Lisbon, and is at the St. Regis.

RYE, N.Y., June 24 -- Miss Jane Evans of Lakeview accounted for the only surprise of the day as match play for the nineteenth Women's Westchester - Fairfield Golf Association championship started at the Apawamis Club today.

Accepting the new Washington Heights crosstown bus service from its operators at noon yesterday, Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, predicted that Forty-second Street trolleys would give way to buses this Fall and those on Broadway a year from now.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 24 -- Joe Hunt of the United States Naval Academy drove up to the Merion Cricket Club early this afternoon, got out from behind the wheel which he had held from Chicago and played three matches in the national intercollegiate tennis singles to draw level with the field the quarter-finals.

THE debate is still raging as to which was the better ball player. Now they are going to show which is the better golfer, Babe Ruth and Ty Cobb. Two rounds to a decision. Or an extra round -- as in amateur bouts -- if it's a draw at the scheduled distance.

Held hitless for five innings by Danny O'Brien, Erasmus fast-ball hurler, Grover Cleveland High's baseball team broke out with power enough to score four runs within the last four frames and beat the Bull and Blue, 4 -- 1, in the city P.S.A.L. final round playoff at Erasmus Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : I am a taxi driver, aged 32, married and with one child. I'm a good, steady worker; I'm strong and in good health. I am very eager to improve my own economic position and also to be of real service to my country by becoming a skilled worker in one of the industries which are essential to the rearmament program.

JERUSALEM, June 23 (Delayed) -- English, Scottish and Australian troops all had their part in the battle for Syria's capital, as they had in the actions leading up to it. It is the role of the Free French that is most featured. The city's capture is regarded as their doing.
BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, June 25 -- It is becoming increasingly apparent that the main fighting

The spectacle of a racer of sprinting breed going a distance of ground in enduring fashion was afforded at Aqueduct, where G.A. Garrett's Happy Hunting fought things out at the end of a mile and a sixteenth to emerge a $39.10 for $2 winner yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., June 24 (AP) -- John Lindell pitched the Newark Bears to a three-hit 2-to-1 victory over the Jersey City Giants in the final of a three-game series tonight, giving the Bruins their only triumph of the set.
A Fifth Avenue transaction bringing about the merger of the leasehold and the fee of a large apartment house was closed yesterday after eighteen months of negotiation.

Complications Continue The Philadelphia Company yesterday awarded $60,000,000 of new securities to two underwriting groups, but the complications that surround this transaction, coupled with the failure on Monday of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation to dispose of its $47,000,000 of new securities in competitive bidding merely emphasized the problems that have arisen under the compulsory competitive bidding rule of the Securities and Exchange Commission for utility securities.

Bearing out earlier indications that fewer savings banks in this city would continue to pay dividends to depositors at an annual rate of 2 per cent for the quarter ended on June 30, it was disclosed yesterday that the Broadway Savings Bank and the Central Savings Bank, both of Manhattan, would pay at an annual rate of 1 1/2 per cent for this quarter, against 2 per cent formerly.
VICHY, France June 24 (AP) -- The French issued the following communique today on operations in Syria:

ORANGE, N.J., June 24 (AP) -- Frank Kovacs 2d of Oakland, Calif., third-ranking tennis player in the nation came within two points of defeat today in a first-round match in the men's New Jersey State tennis singles championship under the surprise assault of a comparative unknown, Edward Moylan of Trenton.

As six strokes of the school gong sounded the "alert," 770 boys and girls of Public School 229, Brooklyn, in strict silence, marched briskly two abreast out of their classrooms and into the street yesterday, marking the successful rehearsal of New York City's first supervised air raid drill.

Expansion of plant health programs in American industry is playing a vital part in the effort of the United States to build up the health of American workers and fortify them for the strenuous part they must play in the all-out drive for national defense, according to a survey completed by the National Association of Manufacturers.

Four persons, one of them a five-months' old girl, were burned when a taxicab took fire on the West Side Highway at Eighty-ninth Street while running north in the midst of heavy traffic at noon yesterday.
ROME, June 24 -- The Soviet Army would give battle to the Germans along the line of resistance built along the River Bug, the correspondent of Piccolo from the Moldavian front claimed today.

MOSCOW, June 24 (UP) -- Soviet newspapers said today that the Red Army was repulsing the German onslaught and that amid a nationwide upsurge of patriotic fervor the descendants of the Cossacks, famous for ferocity in combat, had vowed to drive "Hitler's unleashed dogs" from Russian soil.

Buyer Registrations Jump Visiting buyers registered in the market last week numbered 1,425 as against 867 In the preceding week and 872 in the like period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 805, which compared with 535 for a week ago.

CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- The persistent rise in hog prices, which had gone unchecked since June 6, encountered resistance today as comparatively heavy receipts entered the local livestock market. Opening steady to 10 cents off, swine prices weakened further in later dealings and closed on losses of 10 to 20 cents.

BERLIN, June 24 -- Adolf Hitler has joined his troops on the Eastern Front. At the same time, Berlin reports say, the German armies are advancing with great success in the sectors along which their invasion is concentrated. Herr Hitler's presence on the Eastern Front was indicated by the dateline of today's German High Command communique, which, contrary to those of the first two days of this campaign, "emanated from the Fuehrer's headquarters."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : It is with some hesitation that I address this letter to you, lest it be considered that it smacks of even a "tenth cousinship" of complaint. No words at my command can express the deep and abiding gratitude felt by my countrymen and women for the generous sympathy displayed in such a practical manner by our friends in the U.S.A.

E.F. McDonald Jr., president of the Zenith Radio Corporation, informed stockholder at the annual meeting yesterday in Chicago that unfilled orders are in larger volume than ever before for the season, and the company's problem this year will be production rather than sales.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The United Mine Workers Union policy committee today directed 150,000 miners in the Southern Appalachian bituminous coal fields to cease work as of July 8 unless the Harlan County (Kentucky) Coal Operators Association agrees before that date to accept the collective bargaining contract which the twelve other groups of Southern operators now are ready to sign.

Oliva Dionne, father of the quintuplets, informs THE NEW YORK TIMES that no French-English language controversy exists as far as the parents are concerned, in a letter in which he takes exception to various points set forth in an interview with Dr. Allen Roy Dafoe, the children's physician.

It is to America that the world "must look for the great artists and thinkers of the future," New-bold Morris, President of the City Council and Acting Mayor, declared yesterday at the graduation exercises of the High School of Music and Art, where diplomas were presented to 170 students by Dr. Benjamin M. Steigman, the principal.

LONDON, June 24 -- Ronald Ian Campbell, former British Minister to Belgrade, who had an exciting escape from that country and who played an important diplomatic part in Yugoslavia's decision to confront Reichsfuehrer Hitler rather than yield, is going to the United States as Minister to Washington, succeeding Sir Gerald Campbell, it was announced today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 24 (AP) -- Two new records went into the books today as sixty-four players advanced to the match-play rounds of the forty-fourth national inter-collegiate golf championship on the Ohio State University course.
