LONDON, June 24 -- Russia has accepted the British offer of aid and military and economic missions will leave shortly for Moscow, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden announced in the House of Commons today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: This week one hundred members of the Civilian Defense Institute were able to proffer their services to Mayor La Guardia as trained air-raid protection, workers and instructors. Many of these members have been in training for more than five months against the day when the need for their services might arise.

The stylish vacationer of the future will include an air-raid shelter suit in his wardrobe, it was predicted yesterday at a luncheon fashion show of men's and women's vacation clothes presented at the Promenade Cafe, Rockefeller Center.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- New regulations for complete control over the entry of aliens into the United States were issued by the State Department today in the program of setting up safeguards against the infiltration of fifth columnists.

The training of more than 60,000 men, in addition to the 62,000 air raid wardens now being recruited for civilian defense in case of air raids, will start either late this week or early next week, it became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- President Roosevelt is reported to be considering appointment of Joseph B. Eastman, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, as Emergency Coordinator of Transportation.

The management of the Lehigh Valley Railroad is giving serious consideration to Revella W. Brown, vice president of operation and maintenance of the Reading Company and the Central Railroad of New Jersey, as a successor to the presidency of their company, it was made known in competent quarters in Wall Street yesterday.
The stripers are definitely present in the New Jersey surf, and reports from several beaches indicate that this should be one of the best seasons in two or three years.

"Caught in the Draft," a Paramount comedy starring Bob Hope and Dorothy Lamour, is the screen newcomer opening this morning at the Paramount. Featured in the picture, which has an army camp background are Eddie Bracken, Lynne Overman, Clarence Kolb and Paul Hurst.

Tax reductions amounting to $3,300,000 for users of telephone, gas and electric service were approved by the City Council and the Board of Estimate yesterday as both bodies adopted an emergency relief tax program for next year designed to raise a total of $71,575,000.

Mrs. Dorothy Wayland Anderson has been named executive director of the recently formed New York Dress Institute, which over the next three years will conduct a $4,500,000 campaign on behalf of that industry, it was announced yesterday.

Declaring that his failure to obtain arms in this country for Eire's army of 60,000 regulars and 200,000 defensive volunteers meant he and his countrymen would probably have to "defend ourselves with whatever we have at the moment," General Frank Aiken, Irish Minister for the Coordination of Defensive Measures, left for home yesterday morning aboard the Lisbon-bound Yankee Clipper.

Two sets of twins and two brothers were among the winners of medals yesterday from the School Art League, which awarded scholarships and other honors to high school students in the city schools in the auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Two shabbily dressed men poked what appeared to be toy pistols at three girls yesterday afternoon and escaped with nearly $2,700 from a $3,300 payroll of Lips tern Brothers Haltman, Inc., 1359 Broadway, throwing the garment district into confusion as police cars raced to the scene.

The successful services and expanding needs of the American Eagle Club of London, which provides a "home away from home" for American and other nationals now serving in various units of the British forces, were described yesterday by Robert H. Hutchinson, its founder and active head.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 24 -- Alfred M. Morris of the Scarsdale Golf Club, the New York City stock broker who took time off to lead the field on opening day in the recent United States seniors' championship, three-putted himself out of a similar accomplishment at the Westchester Hills Golf Club today as sixty-three veterans turned out for the seventh annual title event of the Westchester Seniors Golf Association.

MOSCOW, June 24 (AP) -- the home front today Soviet citizens reacted emotionally to their country's rendezvous with destiny. Back again on old familiar anti-Fascist ground after an interlude of perplexing collaboration with the Nazis, they cheered troops departing for the front, sending them away with rousing Russian songs and pelting them with flowers.

TRENTON, June 24 -- Governor Charles Edison "cracked down" on the State Highway Department today by enjoining further expenditure of its funds until such time as Commissioner E. Donald Sterner complies with several specific orders.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Operators of American merchant ships told Senators today that they were carrying national defense supplies to the Red Sea, to Rangoon, Burma, and to new naval bases.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 24 -- The nation faces without fear an unlimited national emergency and is confident that righteousness and justice will not be obscured, Rabbi Emil W. Leipziger of New Orleans, president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis, said here tonight.
CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- The Milky Way Farm Stable's Gallahadion, 2-1 favorite, slipped through on the rail and drove to victory at Arlington Park today.

BERLIN, June 24 -- With the military campaign against Russia swinging into its fourth day, the foreign chronicler finds himself up against an uncompromising taboo so far as speculation over the dearth of news on military operations is concerned.

BOSTON, June 24 -- America cannot have a coordinated system of education while its colleges and universities continue to duplicate services and engage in rivalry and competition for students, Dr. Charles H. Brown, new president of the American Library Association, told the convention of the association tonight.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have noticed in your reports of the doings of Congress something that is without question and without exaggeration the wickedest piece of discriminatory legislation ever proposed to that body. I refer to the innocent-looking little proposal to require married people to file joint income tax returns, thus placing a very substantial financial premium on divorce and separation.

MADRID, Spain, June 24 -- "History and the future of Europe demand the extermination of Russia," Foreign Minister Ramon Serrano Suner declared this morning in a Falangista rally called to demand that Spain intervene to aid Germany in the fight against the "Red hordes."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 24 -- Tonight, as one of the most famous four miles of river water in the world stretched slate blue under a dying Summer sun, the oarsmen of nine American universities had ended their months of preparation for their one big day.

"Fit to Fly: A Medical Handbook for Fliers," by Lieut. Col Malcolm C. Grow, M.D., and Captain Harry G. Armstrong, M.D., will be published Friday by Appleton-Century. The book contains medical information for potential, fledgling and veteran fliers.

ROME, June 24 -- The Italian Government immediately replied to the United States measure forbidding Italians to leave the United States without authorization by adopting this morning similar measures toward American citizens.

Crude oil production in the United States last week was at an average of 3,857,600 barrels daily, or an increase of 34,850 over the 3,822,750 in the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 27,600 barrels more than the calculation of 3,830,000 daily by the Bureau of Mines for June.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- President Roosevelt pledged today that the United States would give all possible aid to Soviet Russia in its defense against Nazi Germany. The Treasury, acting upon his orders, released $40,000,000 in Soviet credits, frozen June 14.

The opening of a program to turn out every four weeks 100 specially trained pilots, qualified to ferry multi-engined airplanes to Great Britain, was announced yesterday by Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc.

A fire caused by a short circuit in a subway junction box on the signal system of the I.R.T. West Side and Bronx-Seventh Avenue line between Ninety-first and Ninety-sixth Streets on Broadway brought on a complete shutdown of power on the line between Seventy-second Street and Ninety-sixth Street shortly after 8:30 o'clock last night.

Kansas City Southern Net income of the Kansas City Southern Railway in May was about $143,000, G.P. Couch, president, estimated yesterday. This would compare with $51,000 in May, 1940, and would bring the net income for the first five months of the year to about $708,000, against $388,000 in the same period last year.

A public hearing to consider modification of the existing anchorage areas in the Hudson River on the New York and New Jersey sides and for provision of a naval anchor-age area, forty feet deep at lowest low water and 2,100 feet wide, to extend from West Seventy-second Street to the George Washington Bridge, was held yesterday in the Federal Office Building, 90 Church Street, by the Army Engineers Office.

KINGSTON, Ont., June 24 -- Saying the Axis powers were attempting to pass off an outworn system of economic imperialism as a "new order," Adolf Berle, assistant Secretary of State of the United States, told the conference on CanadianAmerican affairs tonight that in reality it is the New World which, through a silent revolution, is building up a new economic hemisphere.

It is gratifying that the War Department has decided not to insist on the passage of its property-seizure bill in the sweeping form in which it was originally submitted, but has brought forward a proposed compromise measure. under the revised bill the President would have power to seize "any military or naval equipment or munitions, or component parts thereof, or machinery, tools or materials necessary to manufacture of such equipment or munitions."

The first definite booking announced for the season of 1941-42 is "The Great Whitewash," which will come to the Cort Theatre the week of Sept. 8. Before its New York debut the Frank Gabrielson-Irvin Pincus farce will have a week of preparatory showings at the Maryland Theatre, Baltimore, with a cast including Teddy Hart, Frank Albertson, Keenan Wynn and J.C. Nugent.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 24 -- New incidents between Russia and Finland were reported today. Tomorrow Sweden will probably announce her official attitude toward the Germano-Russian conflict.

Two sharp warnings to city transit employes to "beware of reckless agitators" and that sabotage of railroad property is a felony punishable by maximum sentences of as much as twenty years in prison were posted by the Board of Transportation last night throughout the city's transit system.

Among the plans filed with the Department of Buildings yesterday was one for a six-story apartment house to accommodate 108 families in Brooklyn, whose cost is estimated at $425.000. The details of this and other projects follow:

LONDON, June 24 (AP) -- Britain officially declared tonight that the "Hun" has lost more than five fighters to every British pilot in the continuing grand-scale operations over France and the English Channel.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Considerably refreshed after a full night's sleep, the Giants came up with another of their spectacular rebounds today and behind Cliff Melton's highly commendable left-handed pitching flattened the Cubs, 3 to 1, in the second contest of a three-game series.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Washington climbed out of the American League cellar by defeating the White Sox today as Stout Dutch Leonard limited Chicago to eight hits in capturing a 6-3 decision. Washington nailed Thornton Lee for ten hits and was aided by four White Sox errors.
LONDON, Wednesday, June 25 (UP) -- Royal Air Force bombers loosed one of the greatest attacks of their current offensive against the French "invasion" coast early today.

CINCINNATI, June 24 (AP) -- Two ninth-inning errors robbed Bucky Walters of a shut-out today as, with five-hit hurling, he pitched and batted the Reds to a 5-to-1 victory over their "jinx" opponents, Philadelphia.

A report that the price ceiling on print cloths to be announced by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply would be 39 cents a pound for print cloths, swept through the gray goods market yesterday. This was about in line with the cost figures published in THE NEW YORK TIMES last week and applied to current raw cotton values.

The Committee for Guild Democracy, an organization of members of the Newspaper Guild of New York, headed by Gilbert Cant, chairman of The New York Post unit, announced last night that it had forwarded to the Guild's national convention in Detroit a petition signed by more than 1,000 Guild members, urging election of an entire new slate of national officers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 24 -- The battle between Orson Welles and RKO which has raged since the controversy over "Citizen Kane" began in January was settled today and a new contract is being negotiated under which Welles will make three pictures a year for the studio.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The House leadership paved the way today for consideration by the House later this week of legislation to halt defense strikes by declaring guilty of a criminal offense workers or industrialists who attempt by violence or threats to prevent any one from working on defense orders.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- The American public is showing increasing knowledge of nutrition, yet thousands of families are victims of malnutrition because they do not know what constitutes an adequate diet, delegates to the American Home Economics Association were told today.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), June 24 -- After a firm opening on the Bourse today a reaction set in and the close was irregular. Shippings were strong, especially the Dutch Indian Lines, which were as much as 3 higher. Tobaccos also were better.
CAIRO, June 24 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply sent requests today to forty-seven of the largest manufacturers of furniture and to sixteen producers of household refrigerators to halt price rises and cease other activities leading to inflation and economic "demoralization."

PITTSBURGH, June 24 -- Making his first start in six weeks, lanky Curt Davis tonight made it a good one by shutting out the Pirates with five widely scattered singles as the Dodgers won, 8 -- 0, for their fourth straight triumph.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 24 -- Taking issue with those who argue that now is the accepted time for the United States to engage in all-out warfare against Nazi Germany, Representative John M. Vorys of Ohio, told the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs tonight that this is the time for the United States to move in the direction of achieving "a just and satisfactory peace as soon as possible."

General Motors Corporation was the largest buyer of national advertising in the country last year and was followed by Procter Gamble Company, Chrysler Corporation, R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company and General Foods Corporation, according to the second annual edition of "Expenditures of National Advertisers in Newspapers, Magazines, Farm Journals and Chain Radio," issued yesterday by the research and promotion department of the bureau of advertising, A.N.P.A.

TOKYO, June 24 -- Meeting in a tense atmosphere with all members present, the Cabinet today debated the political, military and economic issues created for Japan by the Russian - German hostilities but failed to produce the anticipated statement clarifying Japan's policy.

The new Criminal Courts Building and city prison, to the east of the old Tombs at Franklin and Center Streets, will be dedicated next Monday, about one year after its cornerstone was placed, it was announced yesterday.
Full aid under the lease-lend act to the Soviets in their attempt to stem the Nazi invasion was urged yesterday by The Daily Worker, Communist newspaper, in a front-page editorial.
Women's wear shops figured prominently in the commercial leasing activity reported by Manhattan brokers yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 24 (UP) -- Dispatches and broadcasts from insurgent radio stations in the three Baltic States -- Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia -- pictured an immense military and political struggle in which the inhabitants were laboring to obstruct the Red Army's defense efforts as the German Army drove northeastward from East Prussia today.

Robert T. Stevens has been appointed district coordinator of the Defense Contract Service of the Office of Production Management for the New York area, according to an announcement yesterday by Robert L. Mehornay, director of the service, through the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The third day of the German assault upon Russia -- an assault that may decide the war -- ended last night with reports of actual operations sparse, and, as is to be expected, conflicting and unilluminating.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- In an effort to save on time and personnel the Office of Production Management has adopted a plan to set up about thirty industry committees, each matched by an OPM commodity section, William S. Knudsen, director general, annonced today.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 24 -- Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. Seggerman of Eltham, East Norwich, and 375 Park Avenue, New York, gave a large dinner dance tonight at the Piping Rock Club for their debutante daughter, Miss Anne Bonsal Seggerman.

Houlder Hudgins, president of Sloane-Blabor Corporation, yesterday advised members of the Sales Executive Club of New York to begin now to work out long-term sales policies which are not based upon post-war depressions or defense booms.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 24 -- Russian aircraft raided the Rumanian ports of Constanta and Galati, dropping a large number of heavy bombs and causing severe damage, according to radio reports received here today.

The American Export liner Exeter arrived at Pier F, Jersey City, yesterday with 224 passengers, the largest number she or her sister ships, the Excalibur and Excambion, have brought from Lisbon since they entered service between the United States and Portugal last Summer.

With the expiration of its contracts with the city only a few days off, the Transport Workers Union is doing all in its power to make a new agreement impossible. Their statement -- or perhaps one should say the statement of International President Michael J. Quill -- issued on Monday evening is a misinterpretation of plain facts.
LONDON, June 24 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique today said:

BERLIN, June 24 (UP) -- Nazi dispatches from the Eastern Front said tonight that the Red Army was resisting vigorously, but that so far the Russians had failed to halt the German Blitzkrieg offensive.

MONTCLAIR. N.J., June 24 -- Miss Gail Wild of Baltusrol, Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, and Mrs. Charles Whitehead of Plainfleld, the defending champion, each posted a card of 79 in the second round of the seventeenth annual New Jersey Women's Golf Association medal play championship at the Montclair Golf Club today.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I shall be pleased if I may, on behalf of the "Merchant Navy," thank the people of America for the very kind gifts of clothing they have sent us.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- From a reporter's notebook, on the third day after Germany decided that the best way to persuade Soviet Russia of the benefits of membership in the Axis was to dispel ignorance with Blitz:

HARTFORD, Conn., June 24 -- A committee of the House of Representatives of the United States heard evidence today about the trouble Mrs. Frank Robbins has had keeping the children quiet so that Mr. Robbins could sleep.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 24 (AP) -- Governor Lehman urged today a renewal of public vigilance against epidemics which might disrupt essential defense industries.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, June 25 (AP) -- This Red Army communique was issued early today:

More than 2,400,000 loans aggregating $7,247,000,000 were made by 60 per cent of the banks in New York State to business concerns and Individuals during the second half of 1940, the Research Council of the American Bankers Association disclosed yesterday in its semi-annual survey of bank-lending activity.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Admitting the receipt of large sum of money from a subsidiary of the Soviet Commissariat for Foreign Trade, defense witnesses in the trial of the Bookniga Corporation for failing to register as a propaganda agent, introduced documents and contracts today tending to show that these payments were all of a business nature, instead of subsidies which government witnesses had indicated.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 24 -- A special mission of six representatives of the Vichy government, headed by Jacques Benoist-Mechin, is expected to arrive in Turkey soon from Franca to discuss the possibility of evacuating through this country the armies now fighting under General Henri Fernand Dentz against the Allies in the French-mandated territories of the Levant.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 24 -- Talinn was reported in flames tonight, and German troops were said to be in Kaunas.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Diplomats pondered the probable effect on Japan of the President's decision to help Russia.

Alexander Smallens opened and closed his program with novelties last night at his fourth appearance of the season as conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium. The first novelty was a ballet suite by Benjamin Britten based on piano pieces by Rossini.

DETROIT, June 24 -- Soon after the anti-administration forces in the American Newspaper Guild convention announced their slate of officers and platform today an initial test of strength indicated that the administration and its opponents were fairly evenly divided in voting strength.

A banking syndicate headed by the Chase National Bank was the successful bidder yesterday for an issue of $15,000,000 of New York State institutions building bonds, receiving the award on a 1.1946 per cent interest cost basis. The winning tender, which was one of five submitted for the issue, was 100.7199 for the bonds bearing interest at the rate of 1 1/4% per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (AP) -- Singles by Rudy York and Bruce Campbell, followed by Pinky Higgins's long fly that scored York, gave Detroit a run in the ninth inning tonight and a 2-to-1 victory over the Athletics. Philadelphia tied the score in the eighth on Wally Moses's single and a three-bagger by Bob Johnson.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 24 -- While confusion continues among the extreme Leftists in the Chilean political field as a result of the German-Russian War, two important Leftist parties, Radical and Socialist, revealed this afternoon details of a pact signed today that deliberately leaves the Communists out of the picture.

The long-drawn-out diplomatic duel between Adolf Hitler and Joseph Stalin, in which the latter scored no fewer points than his opponent, has ended at a time when the Russian steppes are firm and dry for tanks to pass, and the Russian skies are clear for planes to fly.

Senator Bennett C. Clark, Democrat of Missouri, declared he was opposed to aiding Russia and was convinced more than ever by the latest war developments that America should keep out of Europe's conflicts in a talk last night before 2,500 members of the Brooklyn Chapter of the America First Committee.
WASHINGTON, Juno 24 -- Contracts awarded today by the War Department totaled $11,452.697.47. Among these were the following, not previously published, which went to concerns In the New York area:

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Carrying forward the policy of favoring Russia against Germany, President Roosevelt promised all possible American help for the Soviets today and released frozen Russian assets to permit the purchase of needed materials in the United States.
The United States Maritime Commission has relaxed requirements in its merchant marine officer training program to draw officer students from a wider field, it was disclosed here yesterday.

Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, estimates that at least 80 per cent of the new housing needed for workers in the defense centers of the nation must be supplied by government funds.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals today assailed a ruling of the National Labor Relations Board ordering reinstatement of employes guilty of strike violence. The court held that employes commiting unlawful acts during a strike automatically lose their rights under the Labor Relations Law.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 24 -- Mrs. Charles Armstrong of Meadow Brook, a former Texas star, gained the principal honors of the first round in the annual Women's Long Island Golf Association championship, over the Nassau Country Club's course today, when she upset Mrs. Harry McNaughton of Plandome, defending titleholder and medalist, 2 up.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, June 25 -- Russia, meeting the German onslaught with "stiff resistance," announced officially early today that her armies had annihilated a Nazi mechanized regiment and that her bombers had started great fires in Warsaw, Constanta and other German-occupied cities.

As the result of a sharp break in the afternoon trading, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday lost about half of the gains made on Monday. Opening prices were unchanged to 2 points off, but the market soon began to give ground under pressure from several quarters, and final quotations reflected net losses of 17 to 21 points for the day.

The Browns arrived at the Stadium yesterday for a first-hand look at the daily Yankee fireworks display. They did not enjoy it but they could not help being impressed as the Bombers blasted away for a 9-to-1 victory that lifted them within a single game of the league-leading Indians.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 24 -- Lawrenceville took an impressive lead in the Eastern interscholastic team championship today as the annual competition of the young prep school golfers got under way at its old stamping grounds, the Greenwich Country Club.

The American Windowglass Company has called a special meeting of stockholders on Aug. 25 to vote on a plan of recapitalization which is designed to absorb the company's wholly owned subsidiary, the American Photo Glass and Export Company.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- President Roosevelt implemented his policy of aiding Russia in the war with Germany by authorizing the announcement today that he would not apply the neutrality statute against the Soviet Union. It already is in force against Germany.

Lehigh Valley Net income of the Lehigh Valley Railroad in May was about $423,000, against $49,458 in May, 1940, Albert N. Williams, president, estimated yesterday. This would make net income for the first five months of the year $1,243,000, against a net loss of $738,730 in the same period last year.
BERLIN, June 25 (AP) -- The German Sigh Command communique, issued "from the Fuehrer's headquarters," said today:

It will make for greater clarity in the thinking of the American people and for greater speed in the action of their Government if, from the very start of this new discussion of our policy toward the German-Russian war, we drop the false and misleading slogan of "Help Russia" and concentrate our attention on the real aim: "Stop Hitler."

William Solomon, Tammany leader of the Seventeenth Assembly District, North, and Charles H. Mullens, a Republican, former Assistant State Controller, who retired in 1939, were found guilty in General Sessions late yesterday afternoon after four hours' deliberation by the blue-ribbon jury on all six counts of the bribery indictment on which they had been on trial seven and a half weeks.

BERLIN, Thursday, June 26 (AP) -- Swarms of Stuka dive-bombers were reported today to have smashed Soviet troop and munition trains moving up to the Balkan front as Nazi tanks sliced eastward in their attempts to encircle great masses of Red Army soldiers.

Various entertainments have been planned in connection with the eighteenth annual Fairfield County Hunt Club Horse Show which opens today in Westport, Conn., and will continue there tomorrow and Saturday. This afternoon the exhibitors in the show will be the guests of honor at a cocktail party to be given by Mr. and Mrs. Willard I. Emerson in Southport.

CHATTANOOGA, Term., June 25 -- In view of the failure of recent rains in the Southeast to make a substantial contribution to rapidly dwindling water reserves that have been stored for power production, the Tennessee Valley Authority must soon decide whether it will be necessary to ration electric energy in the Tennessee Valley to meet the pressing demands of war industries.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 25 -- Roman Catholics are offering prayers today to the Sacred Heart "that God will yet save men and nations from the livid juggernaut of war's lava of cruelty and carnage," the Most Rev. Francis J. Spellman, Archbishop of New York, declared this morning in the sermon at the pontifical mass for children at the ninth National Eucharistic Congress.

Stockholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday voted approval of the largest single financing program in the history of the Bell System. Under the terms of the program A. T. and T. will issue $234,000,000 of "new money" convertible debentures, the proceeds of which will be used for expansion to meet increasing demands of national defense on the Bell System's facilities.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Exports from the United States to the United Kingdom established a new twenty-year record in April as America's lease-lend aid program gained speed, the Department of Commerce reported today.

TICONDEROGA, N. Y., June 25 -- Ticonderoga firemen and police early today rescued two daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Harold F. Pitcairn of Bryn Athyn, Pa., summer residents of Diamond Point, from the side of Rogers Rock on Lake George, where they became entrapped while attempting to scale the 600-foot incline.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 25 -- British and Free French forces, continuing to clean out nests of opposition in the Damascus area of Syria, have advanced northwestward ten miles to the Damascus-Beirut road.

Arriving buyers may register in this column by telephoning LAckawanna 4-1000 RETAIL CLASSIFIED BY OFFICE Arliwright, Inc.; 138 W. SUt BINGHAMTON -- Hills. McLean ft Hasklns; D. D. Biewer, furniture, lamps. BOSTON-Gllchrist Co.; A. Long, basement coats.

Wall Street bade Emil Schram welcome last night. More than 1,650 persons jammed the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore for a dinner by the New York Stock Exchange and the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, at which the chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced that he would take over his new duties as president of the Stock Exchange on July 1.

Why New Zealand decided to give full aid to Great Britain's war effort was explained yesterday by Frank Langstone, New Zealand Minister for Lands, Industry and Native Affairs, at a reception in his honor held by the Anzac War Relief Fund at the Grosvenor Hotel, 35 Fifth Avenue.

The rate of gain in electric refrigerator sales by manufacturers in May over the previous year was reduced sharply from an average of nearly 50 per cent to 12.4 per cent, according to the monthly report yesterday of the National Electric Manufacturers Association.

BERLIW, June 25 -- According to the only information made available here tonight, the initial successes of the seasoned National Socialist armed forces in a military "crusade" against Communist Russia, have been so tremendous that they exceed even the most optimistic German expectations.

The right wing of the American Labor party, at a city-wide conference in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Capitol adopted last night a resolution drafting Mayor La Guardia as its candidate for a third term. The action was taken with the Mayor's consent.

To hasten the preparation of unemployed youths for jobs in defense industries, working hours on National Youth Administration defense projects will be lengthened from 60 a month to 160, effective next Tuesday, the NYA announced yesterday. Total pay for the 7,000 workers in defense trades will rise from $22 monthly to $25.

With sales for the first five months of this year equal to the volume for all of 1940, the Kelvinator Division of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation will continue its advertising campaign through July and August, instead of curtailing it as usual at the end of June, forty Eastern distributors, zone managers and sales managers were told yesterday at a meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

MADRID, June 25 (AP) -- The Spanish Government announced today it was studying "very carefully" the situation created by the German-Russian war, but maintained silence on the possibility of allowing Spanish volunteers to take up arms against the Soviet.

BERLIN, June 25 (UP) -- P. G. Wodehouse, British writer, who received the freedom of all Germany six days ago after a year in an internment camp, said tonight, "I wouldn't have missed my present experiences for the world."

The new Rumanian motorship Mangalia, which has been lying at a Brooklyn pier for more than a year, was taken over by the government yesterday when an agent of the Maritime Commission walked on board and posted a notice stating that the vessel had become the property of the United States.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 25 -- Another upset almost took place in the quarter-final round of the women's Long Island Golf Association championship tournament at the Nassau Country Club today when Mrs. Ruth M. Torgerson of Lakeville, winner of the event here six years ago, just lasted to grain a 1-up victory over Mrs. J. Barney Balding of Cedar Creek.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 25 -- A bit of drama that went unnoticed by most of the crowd of 25,000 who gathered here today for one of sport's great classics marked the close of the varsity race.

An attempt to link the American Peace Mobilization to the Communist party was made yesterday at the perjury trial of Morris U. Schappes, suspended City College teacher, as the prosecution sought In General Sessions to discredit the testimony of Dr. Walter Scott Neff, one of its founders and another suspended teacher of City College.

Measures to protect the health of the nation's 17,000,000 industrial workers pay dividends to employer and employe alike, according to the survey of industrial health programs completed by the National Association of Manufacturers.

New York State Electric Apparently leading Wall Street underwriters, interested regulatory bodies and officials of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation are still up in the air over the failure of the utility to sell $47,000,000 of its securities at competitive bidding.

HAMPTON, Va., June 25 -- After lying off a drowsy shore with not even a caress of stirring air at times, the trailers in the Storm Trysail Club's ocean race from New London, Conn., crept up Chesapeake Bay today to the finish off Old Point Comfort.

Creditors of Clarke Brothers, the private banking house at 154 Nassau Street that failed on June 29, 1929, owing $5,500,000, will meet today to launch a new effort to collect further funds from the remaining assets of the firm. About 2,800 depositors were affected by the failure, mostly small business men, newspaper men and New York City employes.

The administration of the Civil Service Law in this city has never been "at so low an ebb as it is today," former General Sessions Judge Alfred J. Talley, told members of the Kiwanis Club yesterday at the regular weekly luncheon of that organization held in the Hotel McAlpin.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The United States is winning its war against venereal disease, Public Health Service officials reported today. Surgeon General Thomas Parran said that 63,000 of the first million men examined for the new United States Army were infected, but that preliminary figures indicated there was only one-seventh as much serious clincila syphilis and about one-third as much gonorrhea in the nation as in 1917.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: America must go to war now. We must do so because fighting is the only means left for us to preserve our independence.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- In another effort to prevent a shortage of petroleum products on the Atlantic seaboard. Harold L. Ickes, petroleum coordinator for national defense, today asked the oil industry to utilize fully the nation's tankcar facilities, even though rail transportation "will in many ways be more expensive than movement by other means."

MOSCOW, June 25 (UP) -- The press and radio gave prominence today to President Roosevelt's announcement of "all possible help to Russia" and to the freeing of frozen Soviet funds in the United States.

Price advances due solely to Increased demand in a sellers market will not be tolerated and clamping down on such rises is a cardinal principle of the policy of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, Herbert F. Taggart, assistant administrator in charge of accounting of the OPACS, said yesterday in an address at the cost conference of the National Association of Cost Accountants at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
PARIS, June 22 (Delayed, via Berlin) -- The news of the German troops' crossing of the Russian frontier at dawn today thrilled the White Russians here.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The National Defense Mediation Board today asked 1,500 members of the C. I. O.'s International Woodworkers of America to end the walkout they continued in the Puget Sound Douglas fir belt after 10,000 other union members had gone back to work in accordance with a temporary settlement formula suggested by the board.

ORANGE, N.J., June 25 (AP) -- Larry Krieger of Orange, former Yale tennis captain, chased all over the court unavailingly today after the drop shots of Bobby Riggs of Clinton, S. C., and the top-seeded Southerner swept into the quarter-finals of the New Jersey State singles championship, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.

A recent State Department ruling officially explained as "directing the withholding of visas from aliens having close relatives still residing in certain countries and in territories controlled by these countries" seems to have been widely misunderstood. The Department was not so explicit as it might have been.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 25 -- Sweden has granted the right of transit "to a force of [German] troops not exceeding one division" going from Norway to Finland.

SOMEWHERE IN NORTHERN IRELAND, June 25 -- With Germans admittedly within earshot, and possibly even with German agents looking on, British military authorities are staging here big-scale manoeuvres designed to test tactical plans for combatting any invasion of Britain by way of any part of Ireland.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Information received here is accepted as proving conclusively that France gave Germany assistance in establishing airdromes in Syria that went far beyond the terms of the armistice between the two countries.

Seven tenants in the Irving Trust Company's building at 1 Wall Street have enlarged their quarters there in transactions arranged by the Cruikshank Company. The leases call for additional space ranging from 500 to 10,000 square feet for Davies, Auerbach, Cornell Hardy and Eugene D. Powers, attorneys;

After rallying from an opening decline to register gains of 8 to 11 points, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday sold off sharply in the afternoon trading, and closed with net losses of 5 to 10 points on the day. The general tendency to hesitancy and irregularity which marked the dealings was attributed largely to uncertainty over price "ceilings" on cotton cloths and to the appearance of liquidation.
LONDON, June 25 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

BETHEL, Conn., June 25 -- Mrs. Florence Muller was ironing in the kitchen of her farmhouse on the outskirts of town at about 2 o'clock yesterday when over the quiet hiss of the iron came sounds of a rumpus in the back yard.

Plans for a new home in the insurance district for the Fidelity and Deposit Company of Maryland, large bonding company with more offices in Baltimore, were revealed yesterday with the announcement that the concern had bought 138 and 140 William Street, southeast corner of Fulton Street, and would erect a building.

MOSCOW, Thursday, June 26--German infantrymen driving toward Vilna, in old Lithuania, have been cut off from their tank forces by counter-attacking Russian, soldiers, the Russian High Command reported today.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 25 -- Jasper McLevy, Mayor of the important munitions city of Bridgeport, told a Congressional investigating committee today that he hated to think of what would happen if an epidemic started in one of the defense industry centers which were now struggling with the twin problems of overcrowding and insufficient sewer facilities.

HAPPINESS is always breaking in. Things were dull when along came a sheet from the mimeograph mill maintained by Uncle Mike Jacobs to inspirit the press and the public when he has a fight afoot. This light literature had to do with the approaching bout between Fritzie Zivic of Pittsburgh and Private Al Davis of the United States Army. In part the document ran:

Trading continued slow on virtually all classes of fresh meats yesterday. Prices of steer hinds and ribs and other major cuts were weak. The lamb market was steady to strong. Veal hindsaddies were unchanged. Fresh pork cuts were mostly steady. Kosher steer chucks and plates sold at unevenly steady to weak prices.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP) -- The Athletics won their second victory of the season from the Tigers today, sewing up a 5-to-4 decision by scoring three runs in the fourth inning. The Tigers had won eight of their nine earlier games with the Philadelphians.

Extensive highway, park, beach and playground facilities, either completed recently or under construction, were surveyed yesterday by 350 representatives of a score of civic organizations on the second annual water tour of the Park Association of New York City.

Dr. Alfred Bilmanis, Latvian Minister in Washington, last night delivered to the State Department a declaration formally repudiating German as well as Soviet Russian rule over the Baltic nation, and asserting Latvia's intention to continue the struggle for her "complete and unconditional independence."

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Asserting that "malnourished people make poor farmers, poor workers and poor soldiers," Mordecai Ezekiel, economic adviser to the United States Department of Agriculture, warned today that this country "must strengthen the home front on the positive side of democracy."
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- More than half of the work of modernizing defenses of the fleet against air attack has been completed, Secretary Knox said at a press conference today.

LONDON, Thursday, June 26 -- Twice yesterday Royal Air Force bomber squadrons made daylight sweeps into German - occupied France, accompanied by their "umbrellas" of fighter planes. They penetrated as far as the railway yards at Hazebrouck, where bombs were rained on freight yards and two railroad bridges were reported hit.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday assured Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, director of Selective Service here, that all city departments again would cooperate with local draft boards next Tuesday, when about 70,000 young men in this city who have become 21 years old since Oct. 16 must register.

Reports that Gabriel Pascal, the film producer and director, was making persistent attempts to launch Katharine Cornell on a film career, gained credence yesterday when Mr. Pascal, Miss Cornell and her husband, Guthrie McClintic, discussed the subject over the luncheon table at Sardi's.
VICHY, France, June 25 (AP) -- The French Command issued this communique today:
HELSINKI, Finland, June 25 (AP) -- The Finnish Government issued the following communique today:

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 25 -- It was reported in diplomatic circles here today that the Red Army bad begun a fierce counter-attack in Bessarabia, driving back Rumanian divisions and their German armored support in the direction of the Pruth River, and that the Wehrmacht was rushing reinforcements to its smaller ally.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- Hogs rose 10 to 15 cents in active trading today, canceling yesterday's loss and establishing a new top price of the past four years at $10.80. Early dealings were only slightly higher, but buyers bid more actively later. The $10.80 price was paid late in the day for a short load averaging 210 pounds.

The old pots, pans and other worn-out or unneeded aluminum utensils that Mayor La Guardia has asked housewives to turn in for national defense are not likely to find their way directly into the fuselages of bombing planes. But they will help, indirectly, the production of more planes.
The Yankees drove a couple of blazing singles right past the desperate clutch of Johnny Allen at the Stadium yesterday and moved into the American League lead.

Robert Searle Chafee, non-flying cadet of the Army Air Corps, stationed at Mitchel Field, L. I., since last June 6, was reported as missing yesterday when he failed to return to his post after coming to New York late Monday night. Army authorities and the police issued a warning that the 26-year-old Harvard University graduate might attempt suicide.
TOKYO, June 25 -- Foreshadowing important decisions, the Cabinet and army and navy authorities sat in almost continuous conferences today.

DURHAM, N. H., June 25 -- Two tiny groups of cells in the kidneys may be responsible for a large part of the high blood pressure which in recent years has become a chief cause of death in America. This hitherto unknown mechanism was reported today to a meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science by Dr. F. W. Dunihue of the University of Vermont.

With its sails spanking in an easterly breeze and fourteen Girl Scout Mariners from Maplewood, N. J., taking over the sailors' duties, the ninety-foot schooner Yankee slipped from its City Island dock yesterday afternoon for a week's cruise in Long Island and Connecticut waters.

HELSINKI, Finland, Thursday, June 26 (AP) -- Beset devastatingly by Russian bombers all day and night, Finland announced early today her determination to defend herself with all her power against this latest "aggression" by an old enemy.

RYE, N.Y., June 25 -- Miss Margaret Nichols of the Hudson River Country Club, Mrs. Edward Stevens of Round Hill, Mrs. John. F. Degener of Apawamis and Mrs. James M. Robbins of the Mount Kisco Country Club won quarter-final matches in the nineteenth annual Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association championship tournament at the Apawamis Club today and will meet in that order in the semi-final round tomorrow.

Priority rulings and shortages of raw materials have made it necessary for an increasing number of manufacturers, particularly those making durable goods, to curtail non-defense production, according to a survey by the National Industrial Conference Board.

PITTSBURGH, June 25 -- In a game that blazed with acrimony among umpires and players and which brought on the banishment of both Managers Leo Durocher and Krankie Frisch, as well as Pirate Coach Mike Kelly, the Dodgers finally nosed out the Pirates, 5 -- 4, today for a series sweep and their fifth straight triumph.

The first offering to the public of public utility securities issued under the new competitive bidding regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission will be made today as a result of the award on Tuesday of $48,000,000 of 4 1/4 per cent collateral trust sinking fund bonds and $12,000,000 of one-to-ten year 2 5/8 per cent collateral trust serial notes of the Philadelphia Company to two banking syndicates.

The stock market put up yesterday a stubborn resistance to weakening tendencies, and strength which first appeared in the aircraft group and later spread to the coal and rail issues was consolidated in the final hour to give the list an irregularly higher close.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- British sources reported today that an American contracting firm, Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation of New York, would undertake construction in the British Isles at an early date.
BOSTON, June 25 (AP) -- The Red Sox knocked Cleveland out of first place today behind the seven-hit pitching of Lefty Grove, who beat the Indians, 7 -- 2, for the 298th victory of his career.
MOSCOW, Thursday, June 26 (AP) -- The Russian Army communique, issued early today, follows:

Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said yesterday that Leon Henderson's action with regard to furniture prices had "the utmost significance to all American business."

James W. Hubbell, who joined the New York Telephone Company in 1902 as a clerk in its traffic department in Brooklyn, was elevated yesterday to the presidency of the company. He succeeds James L. Kilpatrick, who will retire on July 31 in accordance with the company's retirement plan.

Two new films will open in local theatres today. Metro's Technicolor "Blossoms in the Dust." starring Greer Garson and Walter Pidgeon will have its world premiere this morning at the Radio City Music Hall. Featured in the drama, based on the life of Mrs. Edna Gladney, founder of the Texas Children's Home and Aid Society, are Felix Bressart.

The last bit of New York Central track -- a forty-foot section of rust-covered rail -- was lifted out of eleventh Avenue yesterday, between Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Streets, symbolizing the final passage of old "Death Avenue" and the completion of the gigantic West Side improvement project for which the city and civic organizations have striven for almost forty years.
WASHINGTON. June 25 -- The Army accepted 786 aviation cadets last week, a record number. They increased to more than 9,000 the number in training at forty-five civilian and Army air schools.

Leon Henderson, head of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, met a major rebuff in his effort to control prices yesterday when several furniture manufacturers announced further increases of about 5 per cent despite his request on Tuesday that plans to raise prices be submitted to him for approval before they were put into effect.

The appellate term of Special Sessions reversed yesterday the conviction of Joseph E. McWilliams on Oct. 1 by Magistrate Edgar Bromberger on a charge of disorderly conduct. The seventy-five-day sentence to the Workhouse imposed on Me Williams as the result of a speech he made three months earlier denouncing Jews was nullified.

Pacific Coast crews easily defeated their Eastern rivals in the two major races at the Poughkeepsie regatta yesterday as Washington repeated its 1940 victory in the four-mile varsity event. The Huskies scored by two and a half lengths over California.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The House approved and sent to the Senate today the second deficiency bill of the session, containing in all $894,221,310.80 for nearly twenty agencies, but of which 97 per cent was for national defense purposes.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- In a cross-examination backed by official and unofficial documents the government revealed the complicated past of Raphael Rush today in the trial of the Bookniga Corporation and its officers, under indictment for failing to register as alien agents.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The attack by Nazi Germany upon Soviet Russia raises difficult problems of foreign policy. Subversive groups will be quick to exploit the new situation, with the object of destroying American unity and perhaps of affecting the disposition of American military supplies.

Harley D. Hutchins, investment broker, of 535 Fifth Avenue, who died in Los Angeles last Thursday, at the age of 68, bequeathed to Chauncey Ford Warner of 63 Midchester Avenue, White Plains, N. Y., his secretary and friend of more than twenty-five years, $500,000 and conferred upon him unusual powers as executor and trustee of his estate.

Desperate conditions of hunger and privation among French war prisoners in German concentration camps were cited yesterday by Miss Anne Morgan as the inspiration for the packing and shipping of food from New York from headquarters of the Coordinating Council for French Relief Societies at 4 West Fifty-eighth Street.

Now that the broadbill swordfish have made an appearance offshore, several anglers seem interested in learning more about their "rights" in connection with the taking of these fish aboard a boat chartered by them. Also whether such fish, taken by harpoon or rod and reel, are the property of the charter party or the captain.

BERLIN, June 25 -- The German-Russian war, which was launched with the avowed objective of overthrowing Moscow's "Jewish Bolshevist" regime, has naturally offered a pretext for all kinds of conjectures as to eventual successors to that regime.

ANKARA. Turkey, June 25 -- It can now be revealed that a German proposal clearly hinting at the desirability, from Berlin's point of view, of an Anglo-German combination against the Soviet Union was submitted to the British Ambassador here by the German Ambassador, Franz von Papen. The suggestion was categorically refused.

As wholesalers the members of the National Leather and Shoe Finders Association are faced with a peculiarly important responsibility in the defense program, since they must meet an increasing demand from retailers while their supplies are being rationed, they were told at their annual convention at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- On the Fourth of July 130,000,000 Americans will have an opoprtunity to renew their oath of allegiance after a radio address by President Roosevelt.

ERSKINE CALDWBLL and Margaret BourkeWhite (Mrs. Caldwell) have again put their heads together and brought out one of those mixtures of letterpress and illustration for which, suppose, famous is the word. This time they didn't go to Europe for subject-matter, as in "North of the Danube" (1939), or simply to a certain few American States, as in "You Have Seen Their Faces" (1937).

Upward price trends in the chemical industry were continued yesterday when third-quarter contract quotations were named on several important materials. Sulphuric acid, which has been quoted at $16.50 a ton at Eastern seaboard plants for the 66-degree grade in bulk, but which has been sold below that level by as much as $2 a ton, moved up to a firm basis and sales for the third quarter were being made at the quoted basis.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is considering a loan to the British Government, secured by the remaining British investments in this country, Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, announced today.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 25 -- Minus the metropolitan amateur champion, who was barred on a technicality, the New Jersey State amateur golf championship started today, and when 115 players had completed the eighteen-hole qualifying round, John E. Parker Jr. and William Y. Dear Jr. of Essex Country Club were tied for the medal with scores of 74, two over par for the Baltusrol club's lower course.

The unusual tone of German war communiques was continued yesterday -- fourth day of Russo-German fighting -- as Berlin predicted great and incredible successes and Moscow declared the Germans had been hurled back from the Baltic to the Black Sea.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Buying of wheat futures by mills at Minneapolis, accompanied by reports that the government might purchase 600,000 barrels of flour later this week gave the wheat market a rather firm undertone in the early trading today.

In a noisy meeting that ended on a discordant note, the Board of Education, acting at the request of the Rapp-Coudert committee, withdrew yesterday sabbatical leaves of absence for twelve New York City school teachers. These leaves had been granted by the board on May 20.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 25 -- In the closest finish in the history of the tournament Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches won the seventeenth annual New Jersey Women's Golf Association medal play tournament today as she added a 78 to 83 and 79 for a fifty-four-hole total of 240 at the Montclair Golf Club.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 25 -- The Scarsdale Golf Club, which monopolized honors in the Westchester Seniors Golf Association championship for the first four years, recaptured lost glory in the seventh staging of the event today as Alfred M. Morris won the title with 74, 75 -- 149 and Henry Hering finished as the runner-up.

Popular Price Goods Dominate Early reports confirm previous indications that popular to medium price merchandise is being most heavily bought by retailers in line with the increase in purchasing power of family units having an annual income of $2,000 or less.

A claim by the Oliver Mining Company, an iron-ore subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, for assessment of its 1940 occupational taxes on its own selling prices for iron ore rather than on the Lake Erie base-price quotations was disallowed early this month by G. H. Spaeth, Minnesota Tax Commissioner, according to a report on the proceedings.

WASHINGTON, June 25--When Congress recently amended the RFC Act to permit that agency to make loans to foreign governments on the security of the American investments of their nationals, Administrator Jones said definitely that Great Britain was to be a beneficiary.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : At long last Adolf Hitler has been forced into the position of fighting a two-front war.

The Office of Production Management has announced plan of reorganization intended to centralize the activities of that agency and eliminate some of the overlapping that now exists. Under the new arrangement committees will be established for about thirty industries corresponding to a like number of commodity sections in the OPM.

Reporting to stockholders in the forty-second annual statement, Charles J. Hardy, president of the American Car and Foundry Company, stated that net earnings for the fiscal year ended with April amounted to $5,161,130 after all charges, including interest, depreciation, amortization, repairs and provision for estimated income and excess profits taxes.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 25--A clash of hundreds of armed vehicles that, according to reports received here today, surpasses the horrors, noise and pounding of the French-German clash at Rethel last May, has been in progress between the Germans and Russians for more than twenty-four hours.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), June 25 -- The Bourse was quiet but generally firm. Amsterdam Trading rose 4 1/2 to 404 1/2; Amsterdam Rubber 3 1/4 to 249; A. K. U. 3 to 138 and Philips 2 to 205 3/8, but Unilever was 1 1/8 lower at 112 and Royal Dutch was easier at 229 3/4.

SHANGHAI, June 25 -- The first sign of direct partisanship in the European war has occurred in Shanghai, when at the German controlled and maintained Kaiser Wilhelm School gateway and walls were placarded with red painted signs reading, "Down with Hitler" and bearing the Soviet hammer and sickle.

Geysers of water snot up spectacularly off New York Harbor yesterday morning when small test charges of TNT, connected to newly laid "mines," were detonated by the Army as part of the most intensive raining practices to be held here by harbor defense forces since the World War.

VICHY, France, June 25 -- Developments may be expected soon in Syria, as reports reach here of important reinforcements received in all sectors by the British and de Gaullist forces and of signs pointing to a determined effort on their part.

Finding John K. Ackley, Registrar of City College, gruilty of violation of duty and conduct unbecoming a member of the staff, a trial committee of the Board of Higher Education announced yesterday that it had recommended his dismissal. It held that under the Education Law he had forfeited his tenure of office because of Communist activity and interference with the work of the Rapp-Coudert joint legislative committee investigating subversion in the public schools.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia of New York City disclosed in hearings of the House Appropriations Committee made public today that an air raid precaution program for New York City would need 175,000 wardens and would cost about $2,000,000 for eacn 1,000,000 of population.

LONDON, Thursday, June 26 -- Finland announced last midnight, in a statement issued by her legation here, that she was now prepared to defend herself against the Soviet Union. The British, who had hoped the Finns would maintain their neutrality, see in the virtual declaration of war a final surrender of Helsinki to the German plans. The statement said:
CHICAGO, June 25 -- The Giants closed their second Western jaunt of the year with a triumphant flourish today by polishing off Jimmy Wilson's Cubs in the series final, 4-1.

Securely wrapped parcels are leaving New York these days, simply but surprisingly addressed to Her Majesty, Queen Elizabeth, Buckingham Palace, London. And in acknowledgment, thank you notes, on heavily crested stationery -- and uncensored, as is all royal mail -- are being stuffed into American mail boxes, along with the gas bill and a notice from the neighborhood movie.

Air Reduction Air Reduction, Inc., yesterday declared an extra dividend of 25 cents together with the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents to holders of the common stock. On April 15, last, a similar extra was distributed.

Heavy war taxation in England is converting the country into a "socialism of democracy," but while her pre-war economic system will be gone when peace comes, British leaders "will take good care of us and what we come out with will work," Miss Gordon Holmes, one of Great Britain's leading women bankers, declared yesterday morning on arriving here from Lisbon on the Atlantic Clipper.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- President Roosevelt took action today to prevent discrimination of defense jobs because of race, creed, color or national origin, asserting that "the democratic way of life within the nation can be defended successfully only with the help and support of all groups."

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- Union composing room employes of The Daily Times, The Daily News and The Herald-American, afternoon newspapers, ceased work today. They continued to publish editions, but the news matter and headlines in each were virtually the same as in the one preceding.

Germany's invasion, of Russia, far from providing a breathing spell for American armament production, will actually require a speeding up of output, Robert L. Mehornay, chief of the defense contract service of the Office of Production Management in Washington, warned members of Mayor La Guardia's business advisory committee yesterday in a meeting at City Hall.

The first Camp Fire Girls group in the country to report 100 per cent subscription to the purchase of defense stamps was congratulated yesterday by Albert Goldman, Postmaster of New York, in the nation's largest postoffice at Thirty-first Street and Eighth Avenue.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 25 -- The white-tipped oar blades of Washington's crew wrote a new chapter with old words into the history of the Poughkeepsie regatta today. By a margin of 2 1/2 lengths the Huskies took the varsity race from California and the Westerners had the Hudson to themselves after the first mile.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 25 -- An indication that British troops in the Near East soon will be able to confront the Germans in American tanks, which are the arms they most need here, is seen in the arrival in Cairo tonight of officers and enlisted men of the United States Army Tank Corps.

HOLLYWOOD. Calif., June 25 -- Anne Burr, who is playing the role of Mary Dolphin in "Native Son" on Broadway, will make her screen debut in RKO's "Gwangi," the fantastic spectacle picture of life discovered on a lost mesa by a band of cowboys, the studio announced today.

DETROIT, Mich., June 25 -- Administration supporters at the American Newspaper Guild convention today stole a march on their foes by adopting a major plank in the latter's program -- the election of officers by referendum instead of by convention.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.

NEWTON, Mass., June 25 -- Par slightly more than held its own today, but old Father Time took an awful lacing as two of the greatest figures in sports history met on the links of the Commonwealth Country Club. On this brilliant afternoon Babe Ruth and Ty Cobb turned back the leaves of the calendar and, for a charitable cause, renewed their "feud" of yesteryear.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The War Department announced that supply contracts totaling $38,400,207.77 were awarded today. Included among these were the following, not previously published, which were granted to firms in the New York area:

The first drill of city employes for fire auxiliary purposes, in connection with civilian defense, will take place tomorrow afternoon at the headquarters of Engine Company 324, Horace Harding Boulevard and 108th Street, Queens. The site is near the Summer City Hall, and it is hoped that Mayor La Guardia will attend.
ROME, N.Y., June 25 (AP) -- Establishment of a $14,000,000 Army Air Corps Depot on the flat farmlands near here is expected to cause one of the biggest booms in the history of the Mohawk Valley.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 25 -- Favored Lawrenceville, which led the rest of the field yesterday by a wide margin, made a runaway of the team competition in the Eastern interscholastic golf championship at the Greenwich Country Club today.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 25 -- Without the loss of a set among them, Joe Hunt of Navy, Ted Olewine of Southern California, William Canning of California and Joe Davis of Vanderbilt won their quarter-final matches today in the national intercollegiate tennis championship at the Merion Cricket Club.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Robert Low Pierrepont will leave soon for the Seigniory Club, Quebec Province, to spend the Summer.
Houses along the borders of and near Central Park drew a number of the new apartment tenancies listed by brokers yesterday.

The danger of a strike on the city's unified transit lines increased yesterday, so far as surface indications were concerned, when the Board of Transportation, after a brief conference with a delegation representing the Transport Workers Union and the national leadership of the C. I. O., rejected all requests that it negotiate with the group for a new contract covering wages, hours and working conditions of the 27,500 operating employes of the unified system.

STORRS, Conn., June 25 (AP) -- Miss Ree Dillinger, Summit, N.J., grade school teacher, outshot National Champion Ann Weber today in the opening rounds of the four-day sixty-third annual tournament of the Eastern Archery Association on the University of Connecticut campus.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 25 -- Adolf Hitler's decision to invade Russia may make or break him, but whatever the outcome of his present engagement with the Soviet Union, the effect upon the rest of the world will be portentous, according to guest speakers, each an authority in his field, who joined in today's discussions at the Virginia University's Institute of Foreign Affairs.
Brokers yesterday reported sales involving several rows of small apartment houses in various sections of Brooklyn.

GREENSBORO, N. C., June 25 (AP) -- A suit for 41,000 shares of stock of the Vick Chemical Company, valued at $1,600,000, was filed in Federal District Court here today by representatives of various Southern Presbyterian Church agencies named as beneficiaries under a charitable trust established by the late L. Richardson Sr., founder of the company.

Lippincott will publish in August "The Men Around Churchill," by Rene Kraus. The book, a companion piece to Mr. Kraus's best-seller biography, "Winston Churchill," will contain a gallery of portraits of England's present leaden, with King George the central figure.

Even, before their diplomas were in their hands, the graduating class of seventy-one boys and girls of the Food Trades Vocational High School marching into the auditorium of the annex at 250 West Houston Street last night, held an almost 100 per cent employment record.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Control Administrator, stated today that the Chrysler Corporation had refused to rescind price increases on new cars and the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply would be forced "to take the pricing of automobiles out of the hands of the industry."

NEWARK, N. J., June 25 -- Colonel Josiah C. Wedgwood collapsed of a heart attack tonight as he was entering the auditorium of Fuld Hall to address a meeting of the United Jewish Appeal of Essex County. The 69-year-old British Laborite was revived in an anteroom by Dr. Ralph Schwartz, who had been called from the audience.

Pale and thin but cheerful and smiling after almost fourt months of hospitaltzation as a result of injuries suffered in an airline crash near Atlanta, Ga., last Feb. 27, Captain E. V. (Eddie) Rickenbacker, president and general manager of Eastern Air Lines, arrived in New York yesterday aboard a special plane.

Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission declined to state whether he believed that the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., had a right to strike against the city when he was asked the question yesterday during an all-day interrogation before the City Council committee investigating civil service.
WASHINGTON. June 25 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 24:
CAIRO, Egypt, June 25 (AP) -- The Middle East Command issued this communique today:

The first of the city's tenement children to start country holidays at the Children's Aid Society's Summer camps left Grand Central Terminal yesterday with a few extra whoops because they were spared their final three days at school.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., June 2 -- Rising bell, equivalent of soldiers reveille, awakened draft-age concientious objectors in the old Waldo Johnston Mansion at 5:45 A. M. today in this idyllic village on Lake Otsego in the Adirondack foothills.

The perennial issue of illegal price-fixing under the cloak of FeldCrawford price maintenance contracts in the liquor industry arose to plague distillers here again yesterday. Challenging the right of Calvert Distillers Corporation to obtain an injunction against him for alleged price-cutting on the company's advertised brands, Joseph Varon, downtown retailer, charged horizontal price-fixing by Calvert in agreement with Seagram Distillers Corporation and Browne-Vintners Company, Inc., in violation of the Donnelly act.

Long Awaited Blow Hitler's invasion of Russia has at last brought the Soviet State face to face with the test which its leaders have been expecting from the very beginning and for which they have been feverishly preparing over a period of more than a dozen years.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of $4,000,000 of short-term notes of Boston, Mass., at 0.32 per cent plus a premium of $52. The notes, dated June 27 and payable on Dec. 31, 1941, were reoffered on a basis to yield 0.25 per cent.

Mrs. Payne Whitney's Tangled further confirmed her claim on the 3-year-old filly championship when she led from end to end of the $6,700 Gazelle Stakes, feature yesterday at Aqueduct, where 10,979 were in attendance and wagered $675,341 on the day.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- President Roosevelt signed bills authorizing $50,000,000 for construction of bases for small naval craft, extending jurisdiction of American prize courts to cover captured aircraft; authorizing the Navy to use vessels stricken from its register as targets, and clarifying the rights of the Navy to require fewer than four years of training for aviation cadets.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Youthful Sid Hudson walked one run home in the thirteenth inning and was the victim of a triple steal today as the White Sox defeated Washington, 2 -- 0. Hudson allowed only five hits, while Johnny Rigney yielded six.

The membership of the Independent Theatre Owners Association, representing approximately 250 theatres in the metropolitan area, voted unanimously to abandon the showing of double-features and revert to single feature programs, at a meeting yesterday in the organization's headquarters at the Astor Hotel.

Italians in Russia There can no longer be any doubt that Hitler has crushed the Soviet armies. Mussolini is sending an expeditionary force to the Russian front. By now Il Duce easily holds the world's record for ex post facto invasions and expeditionary forces.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 26 -- The Bostwick Field and Texas combinations recorded victories today as play continued in the Meadow Brook Club's annual twenty-goal championship. Bostwick Field had an easy time with Broad Hollow, winning, 12 to 6, on Waterbury Field, while Texas turned back Los Tamaraos, 16 to 10, on Whitney Field.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 26 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

The Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., voted last night, at the first of four divisional meetings, to strike on the city's unified transit lines next Tuesday unless the Board of Transportation agreed before that date to enter into negotiations with the union for a collective bargaining agreement covering all but a few hundred of the 32,000 civil service employes of the city-operated system.

Operations in one of the greatest campaigns in military history were still veiled in the obscure phrases of official communiques last night as the world's largest armies were locked in struggle on the Eastern Front.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The attention directed by President Roosevelt to discrimination against the Negro in industry, and particularly in national defense work, reopens a problem which has long baffled those of us who are engaged in Negro welfare work.

LONDON, June 26 -- Shifting allegiances within the last week have brought forward a new Communist party line which may have some effect on the production of war goods in this country and the United States. Enunciated for the British Communists through the press today, a hastily reformed Communist leadership in Britain calls for "cooperation with the Soviet and a big drive in the factories," according to William Gallacher, Britain's only Communist Member of Parliament.
BERLIN, June 26 (AP) -- The German High Command communique, issued from "The Fuehrer's Headquarters," today:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 26 -- Tonight's broadcast to the Finnish people by President Risto Ryti leaves no doubt that Finland considers herself irremediably in a state of defensive war against Russia and also seems to indicate that the Finnish Government does not intend to declare war, officially at least, for the time being.

The local drive of the United Service Organizations for funds to operate recreational facilities for men in the armed forces and defense industries has reached a total of $1,375,495, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon in the Bankers Club.

The largest sales in the history of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company were recorded in the fiscal year ended on Feb. 28, according to the annual report of John A. Hartford, president, to be mailed today to stockholders. The $1,115,774,058 volume for the year compared with sales of $990,358,339 for the preceding twelve months and with the previous high of $1,065,806,885 for the year ended on Feb. 28, 1931.

TOKYO, June 26 (AP) -- The Japanese Cabinet, seeking to determine this country's policy in view of the German-Russian war, will be urged tomorrow by a powerful group of retired military leaders and politicians to take a strong nationalistic stand in the Pacific area.

The Board of Estimate refused yesterday to approve the retirement of Queens Public Works Commissioner John J. Halleran on pension pending the completion of an investigation by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen into payments made by a contracting concern to a man he identified only as "Halleran."

UTICA, June 26 -- Unanimous action in favor of a milk holiday starting Tuesday unless dealers pay producers $3 per hundredweight (47 quarts) for all 3.5 per cent butterfat milk delivered between July 1, 1941 and May 1, 1942, was taken today by the 28 county chairmen of the Dairy Farmers Union.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 26 -- A feud that involves many of 10,000 Summer residents of the Lake Peekskill region of Putnam County was brought into Supreme Court here today before Justice Lee Parsons Davis when attorneys made charges of blackmail, contended there had been tamperings with nature's flow of water into the depleted lake and promised to eat two snapshots in court if the pictures misrepresented evidence.

CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- Hog prices hit the $11 mark for the first time since Oct. 18, 1937, in active trading on the livestock market today. Opening about 10 cents higher, prices were soon forced upward as buyers bid eagerly for comparatively moderate offerings. Most gains at the close were about 25 cents and the $11 top was paid freely.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: That there still exists a log-jam in America's defense effort, both officially and privately, as pointed out in your editorial of June 16, should cause thoughtful citizens deep anxiety.

Retroactive provisions in the pending price ceilings for cotton gray goods would not only work injustice throughout the industry but also create grave instability, W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, declared in a statement issued yesterday.

TOKYO, June 26 -- One of the most conspicuous effects of the war upon Japan is that the country has changed from a land of tourists to a land of refugees. Japan has everything the tourist wants, but, because of the world conflagration, there are no tourists.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES IN SYRIA, June 25 (delayed) -- With recapture from the Vichy forces of the village of Merdjayoun and its fortress, the British forces in the central sector have succeeded in clearing up a troublesome situation.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The general level of wholesale prices, largely as a result of further increases in prices of farm products, continued to rise in the week ended on Saturday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 87.2 last week, compared with 86.7 on June 14, 85.9 on June 7 and 77.1 on June 22, 1940.

Morris U. Schappes, suspended City College English teacher, swore before a General Sessions jury of men and women yesterday that he told the truth last Spring when he testified before the Rapp-Coudert legislative committee that he knew of only three other Communists at City College.
