A residential landmark on Park Avenue will make way for a modern apartment house project representing an investment of $1,500,000 as the result of the sale yesterday of the home of the late Robert S. Brewster and adjoining property at the southeast corner of Park Avenue and East Seventieth Street.

An Increase of more than 27 per cent in the number of retail liquor package stores in this city was approved yesterday by the State Liquor Authority, which last night sent letters to 237 applicants advising them that their requests for licenses had been granted.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 26 -- It is reported here that the Rumanian Government has transferred its seat from Bucharest, following a series of air-raid alerts over that capital. At the same time there are many indications here that the Axis drive against Russia is not going any too well in the southern sector, despite Rumanian contentions that an entire Soviet division has been scattered.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- A total national income of at least $85,000,000,000 for 1941 was forecast today by economists of the Department of Agriculture, a minimum increase of $11,000,000,000 over last year.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The War Department has invited the twenty Latin-American governments to designate a total of seventy-five junior Army officers to serve with this country's Army as guests of the United States.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 26 -- Sol Lesser, independent member of the United Artists organization, today obtained his release from that firm to join RKO-Radio as executive producer of the studio's A product. Lesser will report at RKO next week.
LONDON, June 26 (AP) -- The authoritative magazine Aeroplane said today the recent Royal Air Force initiative was a "valuable element" in lowering morale in the Luftwaffe.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 26 -- The besieged British garrison at Tobruk made its third successful attack on the German salient in the city's perimeter defenses yesterday and "considerably strengthened" its positions, it was announced today by the British Middle East Headquarters here.

Much to the surprise of the Sam H. Harris office, Danny Kaye, one of the mainstays of "Lady in the Dark," has been signed as the star of the Vinton Freedley musical, "Let's Face It!" due here in October. The announcement concerning Mr. Kaye's new assignment was made yesterday by Mr. Freedley's spokesman and confirmed by W. Horace Schmidlapp, Mr. Freedley's partner.

FORT DIX, N.J., June 26 -- After nine months of "dry firing," trench mortar squads of the Forty-fourth Division began using "live" ammunition today for the first time since the 81 mm. mortars were issued last Fall.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- After reading a paper in Federal court calling for "widespread civil disobedience" and "peaceful revolution" Merritt Eugene Garst Jr., aged 22, was sentenced today to serve five years in a Federal penitentiary for refusing to register under the Selective Service Act.

Regulations governing the new personal loan law, which cuts interest rates and imposes other curbs on licensed lenders in New York State beginning on next Tuesday, were issued yesterday by William R. White, State Superintendent of Banking.

Government purchases combined with speculative buying are continuing to push up the cost of dairy products, the New York Department of Markets reports. Tub butter, now averaging 42 cents a pound, has increased 2 cents since last week.

Brown, hard, twelve pounds lighter and looking fitter than at any time in five years, William McC. Martin Jr., most publicized private in the United States Army, came back to Wall Street this week to wish his successor as New York Stock Exchange president the best of luck.

TRENTON, June 26 -- Reversing a decision by the State Supreme Court, the Court of Errors and Appeals declared constitutional today two laws enacted by the Legislature in 1940 with the object of validating State Tax Commissioner J.H. Thayer Martin's revised formula for the allocation of public utility gross receipts and franchise taxes for 1938 and 1939.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 26 -- Two victories in full-count working hunter classes by the Chestnut mare, Candolette, under the guidance of her owner, Miss Eleanor Moffett of Asheville, N.C., ranked among the high spots as the curtain went up today on the eighteenth annual Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 26 -- Playing spectacular golf, Miss Grace Amory of Cedar Creek advanced to the final round of the women's Long Island championship today by defeating a former titleholder, Mrs. R.M. Torgerson of Lakeville, 5 and 3, at the Nassau Country Club.

Kermit Roosevelt, son of the late President Theodore Roosevelt, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon, ending for the time being almost two years of adventurous assignments for Great Britain and her Allies, and declared as he stepped off a plane: "Really, there isn't anything I can say."

Dabney Harrison's chestnut colt, Counterglow, recently shipped here from Suffolk Downs, scored at Aqueduct yesterday in the mile-and-a-sixteenth claiming race for 3-year-olds and upward in the $4,500-$5,500 class.

An attempt by three jittery young Negroes to hold up Harry Arnold, a diamond dealer, in his office at 562 Fifth Avenue backfired yesterday when in smashing the victim over the head with the butt of a pistol the weapon went off and wounded one robber.
ROME, June 26 (AP) -- An Italian communique:

Joshua B. Powers, Inc., international Publishers' representatives, yesterday sent letters to 100 industrial plants and Class A railroads, urging that they institute advertising campaigns in Latin-American newspapers to get across the story of the industrial power of the United States.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 26 -- New showers of Soviet bombs thundered down in the environs of this capital tonight soon after the Finns were told by their President that they were at war again with Russia, but defensively, and this time not alone as they were in their 1939-40 defeat.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., June 26 -- Although the national defense program is uppermost in the minds of the American people, city planning experts and realty men should cooperate with government officials in working out at once a comprehensive plan for reconstruction of the outmoded and unsightly slum areas of our cities, Philip W. Kniskern, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, told the Real Estate Association of the State.

For 1,100,000 children and 38,000 teachers the long-awaited ten-week Summer vacation begins today. When the gongs clang at 3 o'clock this afternoon all educational lesson-plans, problems and discussions will go into temporary retirement. School buildings will be darkened and doors locked, marking the close of the academic year.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Congress was asked today by the Navy Department to approve legislation empowering the Navy to hold in service all enlisted men, regardless of the expiration of their six-year enlistment periods, so long as Congress finds that a national emergency exists.

ROME, June 26 -- Italian troop are going to the Russian front to take part in the campaign, it was disclosed this morning when Premier Mussolini reviewed a motorized division about to leave for the theatre of operations. The division will be part of an expeditionary corps that will help the Germans along with the Rumanians and Slovaks, although not necessarily on the same part of the front.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Jimmy Bloodworth's single to right with two out in the sixteenth inning scored Buddy Lewis from second base to give the Senators a 3-2 victory over the White Sox today in their second straight extra-inning game.

LONDON, June 26 (AP) -- The 9,000-ton German merchant vessel Elbe, reported sunk by a British plane in the Atlantic, undoubtedly was a supply ship for the sunken German battleship Bismarck, an authoritative source said today. Seven Bismarck auxiliary vessels previously had been accounted for since the battleship was sunk May 27.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The Marlin-Rockwell Corporation of Plainville, Conn., which manufactures ball bearings for military airplanes, became the first employer to reject a recommendation of the National Defense Mediation Board for settling a dispute with its 1,225 employes who are represented by the United Automobile Workers Union (C.I.O.).

The report of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries, exclusive of its major European units, for the first quarter of this year, issued yesterday by Sosthenes Behn, president, showed a consolidated net income of $178,192, after all expenses and charges, compared with $406,500 in the March quarter of 1940.

DETROIT, June 26 -- Replying to a charge by Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, that the Chrysler Corporation had refused to cooperate with his office and withdraw this month's retail price increases on its automobiles, the corporation issued a statement today defending the price rises and setting forth its participation in the defense program.

Failure to reflect in both budgets and current financial statements the probability of higher Federal taxes on 1941 income was condemned yesterday by Paul D. Seghers, partner in Barrow, Wade, Guthrie Co., in an address at the closing session of the annual cost conference of the National Association of Cost Accountants at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
LONDON, June 26 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

CAMP TAMIMENT, Pa., June 26 -- American aid to Soviet Russia should be made conditional upon democratization of the Soviet regime, release of political prisoners and restoration of civil liberties in that country, speakers at the Tamiment Economic and Social Conference declared tonight at the opening session.

An English version of Offenbach's "La Vie Parisienne" will be the second work to be produced here this Fall by the New Opera Company, Mrs. Lytle Hull, the company's sponsor, announced yesterday at a luncheon in her honor given by Howard S. Cullman at the Waldorf-Astoria.

ABOARD ROOSEVELT TRAIN, En Route to Hyde Park, N.Y., June 26 -- President Roosevelt today went to his Hudson River retreat at Hyde Park for a long week-end. Further steps in the government's policy of extending aid to Russia against the Nazis thus appeared to be postponed at least until next week.

William Bayard Cutting Traveling Fellowships, among the most prized awards bestowed by Columbia University, have been granted for 1941-42 to three Ph.D. candidates who will pursue original research in history, philosophy and English and comparative literature, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

BOSTON, June 26 (AP) -- After Bob Feller spotted the Red Sox a 5-1 lead in the third inning, the Indians rallied to give their great right-hander his sixteenth victory of the season, 11 -- 8, today before 24,000 at Fenway Park.

MOSCOW, Friday, June 27 (AP) -- Soviet troops again repulsed German efforts to force the Pruth River on the southern end of the long battle front in Eastern Europe and successfully engaged German tank units filtering through Soviet defenses "in the direction of Minsk," the Soviet Information Bureau announced today.

In 1917 young men drafted for military service were examined only superficially for clinical evidence of venereal disease. Today chemical, blood and bacteriological tests are made, with the result that the afflicted are far more surely detected. Because of this new thoroughness it might be expected that more cases of syphilis and gonorrhea would be brought to light in 1941 than were revealed in 1917.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A special Senate committee investigating the defense program reported today that an aluminum shortage of a least 300,000,000 pounds a year was threatening to curtail aircraft production by 25 per cent in 1942.

LONDON, June 26 (UP) -- Responsible British and Russian sources tonight denied rumors of Anglo-Soviet negotiations looking to a commitment to refrain from a separate peace with Germany, which would formalize an alliance between the countries.

BERLIN, June 26 (AP) -- The German Army's drive to the east against Russia was claimed by military leaders to be progressing to their utmost satisfaction today. The High Command itself was reticent about Russia, however, and in

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The prospect of being interned "for the duration" has been opened to many of the war refugees by Katherine Hill, in a letter to the editor published in THE TIMES. Written as it is in a friendly and understanding mood, it will be regretted by many of those to whom it intends to be helpful and sympathetic.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 26 -- In an address here tonight Secretary Ickes practically called on the United States to make war on Germany while she is occupied with the Russian campaign. He assailed Charles A. Lindbergh as "a Hitler stooge" and his supporters as "Nazi wolves in Pacifists' clothing."

First shipments of men's wool and part wool hose, stamped according to the requirements of the Wool Products Labeling Act, which becomes effective July 15, have startled retail store executives because goods previously "assumed' to be 50 per cent wool now turn out to have a content of only 18 per cent, and the 25 per cent wool content of some numbers has dwindled to a mere 6 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Department store sales again rose during the week ended June 21, increasing 17 per cent over the corresponding week of 1940, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Last week there was a gain of 13 per cent. Gains of 14 per cent were reported for both the four-week period ended June 21 and for the year up to that date, compared with the similar periods a year ago.

Net income of the United States Industrial Alcohol Company for the fiscal year ended on March 31 amounted to $1,067,768, or $2.72 a share on 391,238 shares of common stock outstanding, according to the annual report of the company signed by Charles E. Adams, chairman, and Charles S. Munson, president.

"Caught in the Draft," the new Bob Hope comedy, set a record for the first two days of its run, ending yesterday at the Paramount by grossing $9,875 for its first day and $9,650 for its second day, it was reported by the management last night.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 26 -- The Finnish Government has presented to the Swedish Government a fairly comprehensive list of supplies, particularly foodstuffs, which the impoverished Finns would like to receive from this country for their civilian population, and army.

A new office to coordinate the growing ship repair and alteration problems under the defense program has been established here by the Navy Department and the United States Maritime Commission, it was learned yesterday. It has been jointly created by the two Federal departments and will be administered jointly.

Manufacturers made appreciable progress during May in their efforts to increase their ratio of shipments to orders, but their backlogs continued to rise, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. The value of manufacturers' shipments rose from an index number of 178 in April to 185 in May, which was 59 per cent ahead of May, 1940.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night joined the long list of distinguished dance companies which have appeared at the Lewisohn Stadium over the years, and managed to score the largest attendance of any dance event in recent seasons.

The first of a series of boat rides through the waters of New York Harbor, which are planned for the season by the Department of Welfare and the Board of Education for aged welfare recipients, took place yesterday on the steamboat Colonel Clayton, supplied by the Department of Docks.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Consideration is being given here by government economic experts to the problem of protecting British investment in Latin America from falling into Nazi hands in the event of a British defeat.

Aside from the fact that polo's two ten-goal stars, Cecil Smith and Stewart Iglehart, will ride against each other, the All-Star benefit contest between Texas and Meadow Brook on the Meadow Brook Club's famed International Field one week from today, Independence Day, probably will give fans their only chance this year to witness teams of thirty goals or better in action.

Residential quarters comprising an entire floor in the building at 891 Park Avenue have been leased by Mrs. L. DeJan in a transaction arranged by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc. A suite in 168 East Seventy-fourth Street was taken by Dr. Edward H. Rogers, and in 455 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The first commencement exercises of the Bronx High School of Science were held last night in the school auditoruim, 184th Street and Creston Avenue, the Bronx. Dr. Morris Meister, the principal, presented diplomas to 130 graduates before an audience of more than 1,000 parents, prominent scientists and educators.

LONDON, Friday, June 27 -- British bombers, raiding Northwest Germany before dawn yesterday on their fifteenth successive night attack over the Reich, blasted Kiel and Bremen and reported setting many "large" fires.

Denouncing the American Newspaper Guild's strike against The Jewish Day as a "Communist-inspired" move to undermine the Jewish Writers Union, the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C.I.O., and the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A.F.L., replied yesterday to a resolution adopted by the Guild convention in Detroit censuring earlier criticisms of the strike by officers of the two clothing unions.

VICHY, June 26 -- There is an impression in military circles here that in Syria the British-de Gaullist command, after having pushed forward several columns, is now assuring its lines of communication, extending its positions and generally preparing for the next move.

Ernest Mondorf, 17-year-old painter, who was born in Cologne, Germany and came to this country at the age of 6, won first place with his painting, "The Boy With the Shell," yesterday afternoon at the close of the public exhibition of art at the High School of Music and Art in the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue.

The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, in a final effort to receive bids for its securities, will accept sealed proposals for 120,000 shares of new preferred stock on next Tuesday, R.D. Jennison, president of the utility, disclosed last night.

Demand continued slow for most classes of fresh meats in yesterday's trading. This condition has shown little change throughout the current week. Steer hinds and ribs were held for steady prices, with some houses asking 50 cents stronger prices for 600-700 pound weights. The cow and bull beef markets were steady.

Mary Jane Cassidy, 24-year-old model, identified yesterday from the witness stand in General Sessions one of three men on trial for shooting of Harry Vance Maxwell, advertising executive, as a youth who had accosted her and Mr. Maxwell in the latter's automobile at Eighty-first Street and Lexington Avenue just before her escort was killed early in the morning of May 4.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Mullaney, Ross Co. will offer today to the public $1,000,000 City of Chicago, Ill., 2 per cent water works system certificates of indebtedness. The certificates, due $400,000 on May 1, 1959, and $600,000 on May 1, 1960, will be offered at prices to yield 1.90 for both maturities.
The following text of the Moscow broadcast attacking Finland was recorded here yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System:

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Strength in the commodity markets and unfavorable weather in parts of the Southwest lifted the price of wheat futures more than 2 cents a bushel at one time today with the July and September selling at new seasonal high levels.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Mitchell of 1 Sutton Place South left yesterday to spend the Summer at Overdune, their place in Southampton.

TOKYO, June 26 -- Government, military and naval authorities continued today to study the effects of the Russo-German war upon Japan from all sides, including the military, the economic and the ideological. The government and the High Command met in another liaison conference, and the Emperor granted audiences to Yosuke Matsuoka, Minister for Foreign Affairs, and Masatsune Ogura, Minister for Coordination of War Economy, who in some respects stand at opposite poles of Japanese policy.

With cities outside of New York displaying the widest year-to-year gain for many years, the amount of checks passing through the banks of the country continued to show a vigorous rise over the corresponding week of last year.

The cotton futures market moved upward easily yesterday as a steady influx of mill-buying orders found a virtual scarcity of contracts. Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange opened around Wednesday's closing levels and advanced almost uninterruptedly to end with net gains of 21 to 23 points on the day.

The Brewster Aeronautical Corporation announced yesterday consolidated net earnings of $1,500,909 before Federal taxes for the first four months of 1941 and the declaration of a 30-cent dividend, payable on July 15. The last payment, 25 cents last December, was the only dividend disbursement in 1940.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -- Despite sharp disagreement among their leaders, striking San Francisco machinists have voted to return to work Monday in shipyards and drydocks on this side of the bay.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 26 -- Maintaining a par clip, Charley Whitehead of Plainfield, defending champion, today won a pair of matches to gain the quarter-finals of the New Jersey State amateur golf championship over the lower course of the Baltusrol Golf Club.

George D. Cronin has sold for cash above a first mortgage of $12,400 to Marie Berenson the one-family residence, 75 by 100 feet, at 4 Strathmore Road, Great Neck, Nassau County. According to the City Title Insurance Company, insurer of the title, the parcel is assessed for 515,750, of which $3,250 is on the land.

Evidence that the Nazi invasion forces were meeting stiff resistance from the Soviet defenders, and in some cases being trapped, encouraged yesterday further consolidation of the creeping recovery movement in the stock market. While gains were somewhat limited in the share list, the revival of interest in the bond section, particularly in the second-grade railroad issues, gathered momentum.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Eight American steamship companies engaged in foreign trade under operating-differential agreements with the Maritime Commission have voluntarily agreed to a reduction in their subsidy rates to "a comparatively nominal figure," the commission announced today.

RYE, N.Y., June 26 -- Mrs. James M. Robbing of the Mount Kisco Country Club moved to within one step of her second Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association championship in the nineteenth staging of the event by defeating Mrs. John F. Degener of the host club in the semi-final round at the Apawamis Club today.

Further declines in the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City and in the excess reserves of member banks of the Reserve System as a whole occurred in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Arthur Frederick Goodrich, author and playwright, died early yesterday morning from a heart attack while asleep in his rooms at The National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park. He was 63 years old.
VATICAN CITY, June 26 -- The text of the Pope's broadcast today to the Eucharistic Congress in St. Paul was as follows:
RETAIL ALBANY -- Ulian's; Mr. Ulian, ready-to-wear; 101 W. 31st (Wm. Loweth Co.).

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that world supplies of wheat for the marketing year beginning on July 1 were expected to surpass the record of 5,508,000,000 bushels made in 1939. This year's crop was forecast at about the same as last year's production of 4,042,000,000 bushels, but reserves of old grain were said to be at record levels, due principally to the war's destruction of export trade.

Twenty Years Indoors Today the New York Curb Exchange will celebrate quietly the twentieth anniversary of its moving indoors. George P. Rea, president, will entertain former presidents at luncheon. Nobody seems to know when the Curb market really began.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP) -- Indian Bob Johnson gave the Detroit Tigers a lesson in hitting today as he drove in six runs to help the Athletics take an 8-4 decision over the American League champions.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 21 amounted to 885,558 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 22,583 cars, or 2.6 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 157,065 cars, or 21.6 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 247,024 cars, or 38.7 per cent, more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

In recognition of their scholarship, initiative and outstanding talent, seven New York City public school children received a total of $1,500 in cash prizes yesterday at special ceremonies conducted by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, in his office at Board of Education headquarters.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, June 27 -- Smashing through the Russian defenses on the Niemen River above its junction with the Neris [Wilja] River, German forces have succeeded in pushing a wide salient in Russian-held Poland within fifty miles of Minsk in the last forty-eight hours, it was revealed in Russian official reports today.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 25:

Enrollment of air-raid wardens reached approximately one-third of the desired total during the first week, it was indicated by figures tabulated yesterday. The enrollment has proceeded at a steady rate since the rush the first day and will continue indefinitely.

David W. Frankel, operator, made his tenth investment of the year in loft properties yesterday when he bought the twelve-story building at 39-47 West Nineteenth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $207,000 for ten years at 3 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Defense officials indicated today that President Roosevelt might send a special message to Congress within two weeks requesting specific price control authority for the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply and proposing legal punishment for price violators and profiteers.

The Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply is running into increasing difficulties in its program of voluntary price control. On the same day Chrysler Corporation refused to rescind recent price increases and a number of furniture manufacturers raised prices, both in defiance of the demands of Price Administrator Henderson.

Mrs. Walter Sands Marvin of Montclair, N.J., has been appointed director of the Metropolitan Opera Guild to succeed Homer E. Wickenden, who is returning to the hospital field, Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the Guild, announced yesterday at a meeting of the guild's board of directors at Hampshire House.

Arthur Cutler, who recently purchased twenty-five parcels of realty from the Bowery Savings Bank, has now resold eight of the properties, all in Westchester County, to a syndicate headed by Max N. Koven in, a cash deal.
BALTIMORE, June 26 (AP) -- Paced by Kelleher and Stirnweiss, who contributed two homers apiece and nine runs batted in, the Newark Bears defeated Baltimore, 10 to 7, tonight.

Stanley M. Isaacs announced yesterday that he would seek renomination for Borough President of Manhattan by the American Labor party as a "rank and file" candidate and that he expected to receive the Republican nomination.

DETROIT, Friday, June 27 -- Two New York Newspaper Guild officials and one officer of the American Newspaper Guild, the national organization, were charged early this morning with having been members of the Communist party.

The varied talents of the Yankees were exerted in another direction yesterday as Marius Russo spun a gorgeous one-hitter. Unfortunately, the only hit cost him a shut-out, since it was a homer by George McQuinn. But the Bombers managed to hold fast to first place as they beat the Browns at the Stadium, 4 to 1.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- During the week ended June 25 member bank reserve balances decreased $146,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $57,000,000 in money in circulation, $57,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 26 (AP) -- Two youths who no longer are in college, the tourney medalist and the Pacific Coast champion romped into the semi-finals of the forty-fourth national intercollegiate golf championship today as the defending titleholder dropped by the wayside.

STANTON, Del., June 26 -- The riding wizardry of Eddie Arcaro prevailed again at Delaware Park today when he brought the Greentree Stable's Swing and Sway off a back-breaking pace to score a convincing triumph in the fourth running of the $6,500 added Diamond State Stakes.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- An increase in the registration of security issues from $102,761,000 in May, 1940, to $272,521,000 in May last was reported today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Securities proposed for sale by the issuers amounted to $164,480,000 last month, compared with $99,739,000 the year before.

LONDON, June 26 (AP) -- The Bank of England's note circulation continued this week to rise to record levels. For the week ended yesterday the weekly statement recorded this figure at u638,984,000, which is well above the total fiduciary issue before its last expansion in the latter part of April.
Arkansas Power and Light Company -Twelve months to May 31: Net income, after charges, $1,344,857, against $1,167,439 for the preceding twelve months.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 26 -- The members of the Newport Garden Club were entertained at a tea today at the home of Mrs. Charles Howland Russell, one of the directors. Mrs. Francis L.V. Hoppin was re-elected president, Mrs. Kenneth Shaw Safe, Mrs. Bradford Norman and Mrs. Louis B. McCagg were re-elected first, second and third vice presidents respectively, Miss Helen M. Weaver, secretary, and Mrs. Hamilton Fish Webster, treasurer.

BERLIN, June 26 (UP) -- German armored forces were said tonight to be advancing against stubborn Russian resistance, while in the air the Nazi planes carried out "extraordinarily heavy" attacks on Leningrad.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 26 -- The evacuation of 20,000 French troops now fighting in Syria, across this country and eventually back to France, is on the point of being arranged, according to reliable information here.

BERLIN, June 26 -- Although correspondents had been given to understand that the German High Command would become more voluble today and give some intimation of the advances the German armed forces have made since Sunday against Soviet Russia, no such information has yet been revealed here.

IT isn't a matter of life or death, to be sure, but G. Herman Ruth, the erstwhile Colossus of Clout, is going to bring grief to a flock of his still faithful rooters if he allows Ty Cobb to double him up in this two-lap golf match. The Georgia Peach took the first round over the Commonwealth course in the Boston area. The battleground for today is the Fresh Meadow links on Long Island.

A huge six-year school building program, calling for the construction of 225 schools at a cost of $268,919,800 from 1942 to 1947, was recommended yesterday by the Board of Education, in presenting its annual capital outlay budget. These buildings would relieve overcrowding and replace many obsolete and outmoded structures.

STORRS, Conn., June 26 (AP) -- Miss Ree Dillinger, Chatham Township (N.J.) school teacher, wrested the national and Columbia round championships from Miss Ann Weber of Bloomfield, N.J., today in the sixty-third annual Eastern Archery Association tournament.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 26 -- The first definite plan for division of Westchester County into new districts, under the charter amendment that would set up a new, compact Board of Supervisors, was submitted this afternoon to the Supervisors' special committee on redistricting.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), June 26 -- Stocks here showed gains under the lead of Dutch Indians, which were strong on the improved outlook in the Far East. Amsterdam trading rose 6 1/2 to 311; Amsterdam Rubber, 6 1/2 to 255 1/2; Royal Dutch, 3 to 232 7/8, and shippings, tobaccos and tins were strong.
HITLER, at long last, has decided to try to eat that red herring he has been dragging around all these years -- and we hope it chokes him.
Babe Ruth and Ty Cobb will write the second chapter of their battle of the links at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Flushing this afternoon beginning at 3 o'clock.
VICHY, France, June 26 (AP) -- The French High Command issued this communique today:

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 26 -- A current of black paganism stronger than that of the Mississippi River is undermining the foundations of Christian culture, Pope Pius XII warned today in an address broadcast by short wave from Vatican City to the closing session of the ninth National Eucharistic Congress here.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 26 -- Having obtained passage of a bill increasing the number of Ministers from twelve to nineteen and their total remuneration from u18,600 to u21,250 (Australian), Prime Minister R.G. Menzies has announced the enlargement and reconstruction of his Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The United States will give immediate attention and as favorable consideration as is possible to any request from the Soviet Union for material assistance. Constantine A. Oumansky, the Russian Ambassador, was thus informed by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, during a half hour's conference late today.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 26 -- Don Kling of Peddle, medalist in the thirtieth annual Eastern inter-scholastic golf championship, paid the qualifying leader's toll today when he was eliminated in the first round of the tourney being staged at the Greenwich Country Club.
The Dodgers rushed into a tie for first place with the Cardinals in most emphatic fashion by swamping the Braves beneath an 11-2 score at Ebbets Field last night.

The Board of Education's trial committee, headed by former United States Attorney Charles H. Tuttle, has recommended that the board dismiss City College Registrar John Kenneth Ackley on five itemized charges of disloyalty to the college, the board and to his legal and moral obligations as a public employe.

To nullify the effect of non-American propaganda spread by subversive groups, Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, former United States Minister to Norway, urged yesterday that a national festival to encourage artistic and creative talent to express "the spirit that means America" be staged every five or ten years.

War in Russia has swung attention away from the battle line along the Mediterranean. But the fighting there has been resumed, with the besieged garrison at Tobruk making a new assault on the German unit within the British defenses. This drive, "considerably strengthening" the British position, according to the announcement yesterday from Cairo, is the third successful thrust against that Axis sector.
Electric Products Corporation -- For 1940: Net income, $123,479, equal to $1.62 a share on 76,071 capital shares compared with $49,789, or 64 cents on 78,077 shares for 1939.
MOSCOW, June 26 (UP) -- The official communique covering Thursday's war operations:

An amendment to the golf rules placing a limitation on the speed of the ball has been adopted by the executive committee of the United States Golf Association and will become effective Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday.

With the temperature rising and all reserve supplies of bottled Coca-Cola exhausted, the State Mediation Board succeeded last night in settling the ten-day strike of 800 employes of the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York. Daily delivery of 1,000,000 bottles of the beverage will be resumed today.

Retail Collections Up 1.76% Retail credit collections showed an increase of 1.76 per cent during May over the same month last year, according to the twenty-store index issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc. The rise compared with a gain of 0.17 per cent in April and a decrease of 0.89 per cent in May, 1940.

The surfcasting prospects for this week-end are very good, according to reports received from several New Jersey beaches, and, as the striped bass have arrived, both the bait fisherman and the squidder stand a chance of taking fish.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 26 -- In an unevenly played match that provided tennis of the first class in spots, Ted Olewine of the University of Southern California defeated William Canning of the University of California today in the national intercollegiate championships at the Merion Cricket Club.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The War Department announced today that supply contracts totaling $97,308,177.52 had been awarded, among which were two, for airplane and spare parts, in the amounts of $80,418.170 and $10,587,192, awarded respectively to the Glenn L. Martin Company of Baltimore and to the Douglas Aircraft Company of Santa Monica.

Retailers should assume leadership in supporting the national defense effort, Donald M. Nelson, Director of Purchases of the Office of Production Management and honorary chairman of the 1941 National Retail Demonstration, said yesterday at a luncheon at the Union League Club, tendered in his honor by Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, yesterday resisted for the second successive day attempts by the City Council committee investigating civil service to pin the label of Communist on him. He was equally successful in avoiding a direct uncomplimentary reference to Joseph Stalin, the Soviet form of government or communism itself.

JERUSALEM, June 27 -- Strong British offensive patrols have pushed out beside the coastal road leading to Beirut and have captured two Vichy garrisons east of Wadi Zeini and northeast of Ras Nabi Yunis, British headquarters here announced today.

WILMINGTON, June 27 -- The vote of the stockholders of the plan to dissolve the North American Light and Power Company will be postponed from next Monday until July 21 to permit Federal Judge John P. Neilds to study the arguments presented today.

BERLIN, June 27 (UP) -- Authorized Nazi spokesmen tonight greeted Hungary's declaration of war against Russia jubilantly and declared that six nations now were participating officially in the "European crusade against Bolshevism."

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 27 -- Playing invincible golf, Charley Whitehead of Plainfield today reached the final round of the New Jersey State championship for the sixth time in the last six years and thus is in a position to set a new record in the forty-year-old event.
CAMP TAMIMENT, Pa., June 27 -- Immediate entry of the United States into the war as an active belligerent was urged by speakers at today's session of the Tamiment economic and social institute.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins revealed today substantial concessions by the C.I.O.'s Tranport Workers Union and expressed belief that a threatened strike at midnight Monday on New York's city-owned transit lines would be settled "without any interruption of work."

Moving to the highest levels in eleven years, prices of all active deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday went above 15 cents a pound. Maximum gains of 30 to 36 points were established before a sell-off in the last thirty minutes of trading pared the net gains for the day to 27 to 29 points.

MOSCOW, Saturday, June 28 (AP) -- The Soviet Command acknowledged today that fierce Nazi tank thrusts had forced its army back toward the old Russian-Northern Poland frontier, but said that elsewhere Red troops had held fast and even counter-attacked across the Danube into Rumania to seize 500 prisoners.

LONDON, June 27 -- The stock markets made a fine finish today to show gains on the week for the first time in a long time. The market was influenced by Russia's resistance to Germany's attack and the continuance of R.A.F. attacks on industrial targets in Germany.

LONDON, June 27 -- The arrival of Sir Stafford Cripps, British Ambassador to Russia, accompanied by an extremely strong military mission, in Moscow was confirmed here today. In addition to the returning Ambassador, who was home only a little over two weeks, there were Lieut. Gen. F.N. Mason Macfarlane, Acting Colonel K.G. Exham, Rear Admiral G.J.A. Miles and Air Vice Marshal A.C. Collier.

BERLIN, Saturday, June 28 -- Reports early today from the eastern front, where the Nazis claim the mammoth Soviet war machine is falling apart under the blows of the air force and German armored divisions, said the Germans had driven deep salients into the Russian lines.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The United States is welding Latin America into an economic unit within itself by pouring millions of dollars into the southerly nations to underwrite peak production of strategic materials for several years ahead, it was learned today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 27 (UP) -- A game little Texan from Louisiana State University and a 21-year-old Stanford sophomore won two of the longest semi-final matches in the forty-four-year history of the National Collegiate A.A. golf championship today to advance to the thirty-six-hole final.

VICHY, France, June 27 -- In government quarters it was stated today that there was no question of French troops being sent officially to fight against the Soviet troops. It was said, however, to be within the bounds of possibility that members of private organizations in the occupied zone might be able to raise a volunteer corps to join the "European" crusade against communism.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times : In THE TIMES of June 20 James P. Dawson's follow-up story on the Louis-Conn fight mentioned that Johnny Ray, manager of the challenger, "was critical of Referee Joseph for ordering Conn to 'come on and fight, mix it up.' "

The perjury case against Morris U. Schappes, City College English teacher who was suspended after the Rapp-Coudert legislative committee inquiry into subversive activities in the schools, will be given to a jury in General Sessions today.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES IN SYRIA, June 27 -- The British forces are officially stated to have made little headway northwest of Damascus. A slight advance in this territory, however, means a great deal, for nowhere else in this war theatre does the terrain so lend itself to defensive warfare.

BERLIN, June 27 -- According to official German opinion, an all-European anti-Soviet political coalition -- excepting neutral Switzerland -- is backing the German military advance into Russia and the war on bolshevism has now become "Europe's crusade."

A total of $91,980,000 in new bonds was placed on the market this week, marking the largest weekly total in more than five months, or since the period ended Jan. 17, when issues aggregated $110,375,000. This compares with only $21,346,000 in bonds marketed last week, and with $45,875,000 during this week last year.

CLEVELAND, June 27 (AP) -- Back in first place after the Yankees' setback in the afternoon, the Indians took a full game lead in the American League by defeating the White Sox, 3 to 1, under the lights tonight. Southpaw Al Milnar yielded seven hits as he pitched his seventh victory before a crowd of 42,039.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter of Harry Kavash in THE NEW YORK TIMES, contending that the Communist party "is not a legal political party in the State of New York" because it failed to attain 50,000 votes in the last Gubernatorial election, expresses a misconception of the State Election Law.

Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, yesterday defended the propriety of allowing the use of his name and official title in connection with the activities of organizations that have been labeled as "left-wing" and "Communist-front" groups by various investigatory agencies and individuals.

A reversal of the war outlook on the Russian front as the Soviet armies were forced to fall back deeply brought out fresh timidity in stock trading yesterday and prices moved irregularly lower. The continued spurt in commodities, however, stole the limelight from the securities markets as some important staples shot forward to the highest levels in fifteen or more years.

When the Nazi war machine rolled into Russian territory a week ago the house of cards that Stalin's diplomacy had so laboriously built up over several years collapsed. Most people denounced that policy, while it was revealing itself, for its double-dealing, its mendacity and treachery.
A number of business properties in the Chelsea and downtown areas, as well as several residential parcels on the East Side were reported yesterday as figuring in late realty deals in Manhattan.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 27 -- James B. Baldwin of Piping Rock and Robert L. Gerry Jr. of Meadow Brook showed a sizable field how it should be done today when they posted a 67, four under par, to take the qualifying medal in the annual Piping Rock invitation best-ball tournament.

After listening to complaints against the condition of schools yesterday by forty-eight speakers, representing sixty-five civic, educational and parent groups, James G. McDonald, Brooklyn member of the Board of Education, observed that the disclosures were "shocking."
Time and the Prophets Prophets cannot be reminded too often that time is of the essence of the contract. Any number of people foresaw and foretold long, long ago that Hitler would attack Stalin.

Fifty-six children of superior intelligence, carefully culled for their special abilities from among 272 who scored 130 and above in I.Q. tests, will start a two-day educational program next September at the Hunter College Elementary School, 695 Park Avenue.

Employment of a new defense technique against German Incendiary bombs, under which all men not already in the armed forces are required to register for compulsory fire-watching duty, has reduced property damage and loss of life by fire in London, Oliver Simmonds, Member of the British Parliament and chairman of the Air Raid Precautions Committee of Parliament, reported yesterday upon his arrival here aboard the Yankee Clipper.

Beyond the accounts of bombings and air battles over sea and land, the vital importance of air power is being brought home to the average civilian in many ways. Civilian fliers, now numbering about 100,000, are of course aware of the increasing role of the airplane.

SARANAC LAKE, June 27 -- "Our great Presidents have never hesitated to do whatever was necessary for the preservation of the union," Edward H. Foley Jr., general counsel for the Treasury Department, told the New York State Bar Association in a talk on the Constitutional powers of the President.

With whoops of joy and care left behind, between 4,000 and 5,000 boys and girls set off for Summer camps yesterday, departing from the city by bus, automobile and train. This is the first contingent of many thousand more who will make the exodus during the next ten days.

TRENTON, June 27 -- William Walker, who travels 640 miles a week back and forth from work, and spends almost one-third of his income on train fares, was presented before a Congressional investigating committee today as one of the champion commuters of the New York area.
THE review of reviews begun here yesterday continues this morning with notes and afterthoughts on books that have appeared since the snow-deep beginning of March:
There is only one issue in the subway crisis in this city. It is not the issue of collective bargaining. It is the issue of what kind of collective bargaining.
VICHY, France, June 27 -- The prefectures of unoccupied France have begun to receive the declarations that Jews must make before July 16 to comply with the new laws.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Further curtailment of passenger car and truck production will be necessary because of the shortage of critical materials and the increasing need of the industry's men and machines for national defense purposes, the Office of Production Management announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Senate passed unanimously in 80 minutes today the $10,384,821,624 Army Appropriation Bill, the largest single money bill in the history of Congress. Only twenty-four Senators were on the floor when the voice vote was taken.

Alexander Kerensky, who was Premier in the short-lived democratic government of Russia, declared last night in a radio talk over Station WEVD that the governments and public opinion of Britain and the United States must insist, in the common interest, that the Kremlin, while waging implacable war against the Nazi foe, "make a just and lasting peace with its own peopls."
CAIRO, Egypt, June 27 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command today issued this communique:

Kathleen Romoli, author of "Gateway to South America," received the "Cross of the Boyaca," one of the highest honors of the Colombian Republic, at a party held in her honor at Essex House yesterday afternoon. Mrs. Romoli is the first American woman to receive the award.

The United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company has purchased for cash through the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., for its Brooklyn headquarters the nine-story fireproof business building at 164-66 Montague Street, in the heart of the borough's financial and insurance section.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., June 27 -- Members of the Real Estate Association of the State were urged tonight by Michael F. Walsh, Secretary of State, to resist the "growing menace" of subversive influences such as communism, nazism and fascism in order to protect Americanism and to preserve the "basic" right of private property ownership.
Thirteen college students, members of the Experiment in International Living Organization, sailed yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Paula for Medellin, Colombia, where they will spend the Summer.

The action in Russia is smothered in dust -- the dust thrown in the eyes of the onlookers by the clash of the two supreme propaganda machines, and the actual dust of the Russian plain in a dry Summer. Russia has the quality of a careless mammoth performing its elemental functions in public, and its dust is like the earth itself shaking off its skin.

DETROIT, June 27 (AP) -- Four-hit pitching by Bob Harris ended today the most depressing jinx of the Browns, who defeated Detroit, 9 to 0. It was the first St. Louis victory here in fifteen starts since April 16, 1940.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin) June 27 -- A good demand developed again today for Dutch Indian shares. Amsterdam rubber rose 6 to 261 1/2, Amsterdam Trading 4 to 415, and Royal Dutch 2 3/4 to 235 5/8. Shippings were firm. Otherwise a firm undertone was maintained, but with few changes.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation to readvertise for competitive bids on its 120,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock, $100 par value, which it was unable to sell on Monday at the first trial of the competitive-bidding rule of the commission.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Reporting an employment gain of 300,000 in May, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins said today that non-agricultural employment in that month reached a high record of 38,278,000, approximately 800,000 in excess of 1929's high.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 27 -- Jitney Jingle, the chestnut gelding from Mrs. Sallie Jones-Sexton's Bryn Du Farm of Granville, Ohio, captured the young hunter championship at the Fairfield County Club Horse Show today.

RYE, N.Y., June 27 -- More than 1,000 persons representing communities throughout Westchester attended the county dinner and ball given at the Westchester Country Club here tonight, under the sponsorship of the Westchester Opera Association, which shared in the proceeds with Bundles for Britain.
Back from their impressive tour of the West, the Giants celebrated their homecoming by flattening Doc Prothro's Phillies, 7 to 4, at the Polo Grounds last night.

State banks engaged in commercial business showed moderately increased earnings in 1940, according to a survey covering 8,236 banks in 45 States reported yesterday by the State Bank Division of the American Bankers Association. These banks reported total gross earnings for the year of $706,627,000, with operating, expenses amounting to $501,703,000, resulting in net current earnings of $204,924,000 before recoveries and charge-offs.

"Borrowing" Defense Industry has been borrowing brokerage-house workers from the branch offices of firms having membership in the New York Stock Exchange, and according to some of the larger houses in Wall Street, the Federal Government has been making things a little difficult here in New York.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- The hallowed cinders at Franklin Field felt the crunch of spiked shoes today as America's finest athletes held their final tune-ups for the fifty-third annual national A.A.U. track and field championships, which will start tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- About thirty-five representatives of the oil industry, conferring today with Ralph K. Davies, deputy petroleum coordinator for national defense, reached a general but not a detailed agreement on proposals for pipeline and new tanker construction to alleviate the threatened petroleum products shortage on the Atlantic Coast due to the defense program.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 27 -- Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, who is also treasurer of R.H. Macy Co., told delegates to the Institute of Public Affairs of the University of Virginia here today, in discussing "National Fiscal Policy and the Two Super-Budgets," that much of the controversy with respect to fiscal policy centers around a comparatively limited objective; namely, that of balancing the budget.

RYE, N.Y., June 27 -- Miss Margaret Nichols of the Hudson River Club, medalist in the nineteenth annual Westchester-Fairfield Women's Golf Association match play championship, was beaten today by Mrs. James M. Robbins of the Mount Kisco Country Club, 3 and 2, in the thirty-six-hole final at the Apawamis Club.
PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- Joe DiMaggio today stretched his hitting streak to thirty-nine consecutive games, two from George Sisler's modern record.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., June 27 -- With woeful tales about mosquitoes, chiggers and rain-soaked bedding in Louisiana lowlands, troops that have been engaged in the "June manoeuvres" near Camp Beauregard are trickling back into Camp Shelby.

ST. LOUIS, June 27 (AP) -- The Cardinals broke their first place tie with the idle Dodgers and went a half game out in front in the hot National League race by defeating the Reds, 5 to 3 tonight on Don Padgett's eighth inning homer with a mate on base.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- On the heels of criticism by the Senate Defense Committee of the Office of Production Management as failing to estimate the amount of aluminum needed for defense and make preparations to get it, that agency today disclosed a plan to add 600,000,000 pounds to the national production capacity, nearly doubling that now built and building.

Tonight's departure of "Native Son" will reduce the number of Broadway shows to a dozen next week; the corresponding week last year had one less. With fewer attractions on the boards the list of available Sunday offerings, consequently, is dwindling.

HAIFA, Palestine, June 27 -- General Charles de Gaulle, the Free French leader, visited Damascus yesterday morning with General Georges Catroux and General Jean le Gentilhomme and inspected the damage from Wednesday's bombing.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- "A very considerable amount of inflation" and "a deficit of $10,000,000,000 in 1942" were predicted for the United States today by Senator Taft of Ohio.

MARCH FIELD, Calif., June 27 -- The world's largest bombing plane, the Army's four-motored Douglas B-19, made its first test flight today, a fifty-six-minute cruise from Santa Monica, over the ocean to the air field here, a distance of seventy-five miles.

"Soviet Frontiers on the Danube," the first Russian film to open at a Broadway theatre since January, 1940, will have its first local showing this morning at the Central. The seven-reel feature deals with the "economic and political reorganization of Bessarabia and Bukovina by Soviet forces.

Domestic American airlines, already stripped of most of their spare equipment to aid Britain, have been asked by President Roosevelt to surrender twenty-four more transport planes, it was learned yesterday. Twelve are to be delivered before Tuesday and twelve more before Aug. 1.

ROME, June 27 -- The interview of President Getulio Vargas with the Bueno Aires newpaper Nacion, in which he was reported as saying that this war was outside the interests of the Western Hemisphere has received the utmost prominence in the Italian press today.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The Cubs had to contend with a "tenth man" on the field for the Pirates today, but even removal of the playful fan by police failed to help the Bruins cause and they lost, 4 to 2, for the sixth time in their last seven starts.

TOKYO, June 27 -- With Vladivostok and the Russian Maritime Provinces in the center of public interest the Cabinet met today and there was an extraordinary liaison conference between the government and the High Command.

Although the leadership of the Transport Workers Union obtained yesterday at membership meetings additional authority for a strike on the city's unified subway lines next Tuesday, powerful forces, including Mayor La Guardia and Philip Murray, chairman of the C.I.O., were at work in efforts to iron out the controversy between the union and the city over the issue of a collective bargaining agreement on hours, wages and working conditions.

HYDE PARK, June 27 -- President Roosevelt disclosed today that he was considering the shipment of American rifles to Eire, provided that the Irish would give assurances that they would defend themselves against German attack.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Senate confirmed today President Roosevelt's nomination of Harlan Fiske Stone as Chief Justice of the United States, but confirmation of Attorney General Jackson's appointment as associate justice was held up when two witnesses before a Judiciary subcommittee opposed his appointment.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- Hog prices declined today, as salable receipts were larger than expected and wholesale pork quotations were marked down. A few choice offerings, however, brought $11, equal to the four-year high established yesterday.
BALTIMORE, June 27 (AP) -- A big eighth inning netting Newark seven runs turned the tide against Baltimore tonight, with the Bears scoring a 12-to-7 victory for two straight in the series.

Marked interest was shown here yesterday by merchants and the public in the announcement published by John Wanamaker, New York and Philadelphia, that employes of these stores will be put on a five-day week with pay for six days and that a campaign to lower distribution costs by cutting merchandise returns will be put into effect next Tuesday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, June 28 -- A further withdrawal of Soviet troops in the north central sector amid fierce fighting in which successful counter-attacks were launched was reported from Moscow early today.
CAMP UPTON, L.I., June 27 -- A group of workmen are rushing the remodeling project to give this camp a bigger and better "opry house.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The records show that either Washingon or California has won the Poughkeepsie regatta twelve times in the past eighteen years. Last Wednesday's Washington victory was an outstanding example of watermanship and a tribute to Al Ulbrickson, the Husky coach, but it did much to prove what many fervent rowing enthusiasts have been contending for a long time.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 27 -- Twenty-seven hours after it had begun its deliberations a jury in Westchester County Court returned a verdict at 4 o'clock this afternoon finding Charles McGale, Joseph Riordan, William Wade and Edward Kiernan guilty of first-degree murder for the slaying of a guard during the Sing Sing Prison break of April 14.

The American Meat Institute has appropriated another $2,000,000 for a national campaign to follow the current one, it was announced yesterday. This time, however, there will be an increase of 15 per cent in the budget for daily newspapers. Officials of the institute said they were highly pleased with the selling job newspapers had done for them.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 27 (AP) -- Lieut. Comdr. Robert M. Peacher, commander of Submarine Division 11, testified today that it was conceivable an explosion "might have taken place" on the 0-9 before the submarine plunged to the bottom of the ocean off Portsmouth, N.H., carrying thirtythree men to death.

RACING and baseball go rolling along. It's big business. The Dodgers pack 'em in, night and day. There's a double-header between the Yanks and Red Sox up ahead that, weather permitting, will draw considerably more than two men and a boy through the turnstiles. Suffolk Downs, Aqueduct, Delaware Park, Arlington and other horse tracks are putting a heavy strain on their mutuel machines.

As the result of three national denominations having sought membership in the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America within the last nine months, the council now has twenty-four national denominations officially federated with it, bringing the total membership to 25,964,082 persons.

A direct hit by British bombing planes wrecked the 26,000-ton German battleship Gneisenau in dry dock at Brest and killed 128 members of her crew, according to uncensored advices received yesterday by The United Press from responsible sources in continental Europe.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 27 -- Allied forces in Syria are carrying out a successful encircling action about Tadmur despite stubborn French resistance, according to British military sources in Ankara this evening. British sources reported Royal Air Force bombing south of this strategic city, as well as raids on the Rayak Airdrome and other airfields to the north.

Minsk, on the Napoleonic route to Moscow, rail center and key point in the Russian defense system, is already threatened by a three-pronged German drive that has punched its way more than 120 miles through the Russian lines in the first six days of fighting.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 27 -- The duty of Americans to safeguard their essential freedoms at home while joining in the defense effort to protect them against attack from without was urged at today's sessions of the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs by representatives of labor, management, finance, industry and business and other "friends of democracy.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Leon Henderson, price administrator, announced today that a ceiling would be put on some West Coast lumber and that the price of cotton-seed oil was being studied and "ceiling action is planned."

NEW YORK Prince and Princess Adolphe de Schwarzenberg, who have been at the Carlyle for the Spring, will leave today for Islesboro, Me., to visit William Astor Chanler. They will be joined there by the Grand Duchess of Luxembourg, sister of the Princess.

NEWARK, N.J., June 27 (AP) -- A strike threatens to disrupt delivery of baked foods next week to homes, hotels and restaurants in Northern New Jersey, Staten Island and parts of Long Island and Connecticut.

VICHY, France, June 27 -- At the end of the sixth day of the war in Eastern Europe neutral military opinion here recalls that in Septemher, 1939, the fate of Poland had been sealed within that period. However, with such vast expanses as are to be found in Russia and with such a wide front, "Blitzkrieg" cannot be all "Blitz."

The importance of building morale in the country's armed forces, not only as an essential element in successful combat but as a guard against unrest when the soldier returns to civilian life, was impressed upon the women's division of the United Service Organizations yesterday at a campaign meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria.

A new record for Greater New York Fund campaigns was announced yesterday at the organization's third report luncheon in the Hotel Biltmore, when the amount raised to date in cash and pledges was given as $4,036,915, or $837,000 more than was raised in the first fifty-five days of the 1940 campaign.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The National Labor Relations Board, giving judgment on the most protracted and one of the most bitterly-fought cases in its history, decided today that the Weirton Steel Company violated the Wagner Act by discouraging membership in the C.I.O.'s Steel Workers Organizing Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- Notables from Washington, New York, Boston and Baltimore were among the 1,000 persons who attended the dance given tonight by William C. Bullitt, former United States Ambassador to France, to present to society his daughter, Miss Anne Bullitt.

Six, including Your Chance and Fenelon, are named for the historic Brooklyn Handicap, which may exceed $28,000 in value if all go to the post today at Aqueduct. It will be the high point of the Queens County Jockey Club meeting and once more the record attendance mark of 33,240 will be threatened.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on June 14 amounted to 3,162,510 shares, compared with 2,311,230 in the preceding- week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Harry Packer, garage operator in Jackson Heights, Queens has just arranged to enlarge his storage and service facilities there through the purchase of an additional 13,000 square feet of land for one new wing, and the lease of another building to be erected for him on a 21,500-foot plot.

The House Ways and Means Committee, having decided upon the general outlines of the tax schedules for individual and corporation incomes, excess profits, gifts and estates, has now reached the final main division of its tax program, the question of excise taxes.
The witching hour carried terror for the occupants of a four-story building at 968 Lexington Avenue, but only a small dog on the third floor knew it.

Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey yesterday extended formal recognition to the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes, an affiliate of the A.F. of L., as bargaining agent for the 10,000 sanitation employes of the Department of Sanitation.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Selection of Senator Carter Glass as president pro tempore of the Senate to succeed Senator Harrison of Mississippi was predicted tonight by Democratic leaders. The only thing needed to make it a certainty was the consent of the Virginian to serve

The outstanding news photograph of this week was a perfect example of the diabolical cleverness and the ultimate dumb-bunnyness of Nazi propaganda. Taken by German Army camera men, it showed a giant Russian captive, disarmed, helpless, befuddled -- the perfect image, one might say, of the vast hulk of a nation into which Hitler has been attempting to thrust the rapiers of his panzer divisions.

A sweltering beat retained its hold on the city for the second successive day yesterday as the mercury climbed to a high of 90 degrees at 4:30 P.M., coming within two degrees of the record high for the date -- the 92-degree record set in 1901.

The enrollment and training of an auxiliary fire force of city employes, to number over 60,000, began yesterday with dash and fervor on the part of the volunteers that overreached the carefully laid plans of Fire Department officials.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 26:

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The announcement that Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, had placed a ceiling on cottonseed oil as a result of recent sharp advances in prices threw the grain trade into confusion late today. Brokers said that with the cottonseed oil market in New York closed tomorrow holders of futures in that commodity might attempt to hedge here by sales of lard and possibly grain and soy beans.
MOSCOW, Saturday, June 28 (UP) -- The Russian communique covering Friday's military operations follows:

PRINCETON, N. J., June 27 -- Rumors of peace between Germany and England are almost certain to be revived if Hitler's invasion of the Soviet Union is successfully finished in the next few weeks or months. Indeed, a number of isolationist leaders in the United States, notably Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh have already urged that Britain try to arrange a negotiated peace.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Pacific Gas and Electric Company filed late yesterday in the San Francisco office of the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed offering of 400,000 shares of its 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $25 par value.
PANAMA, June 27 -- The United States must adopt very soon a definite policy to combat Axis propaganda in Latin America, according to the recommendations of Douglas Fairbanks Jr.

With the black bass season opening in most of New York State on Tuesday, the trout waters will receive even less pressure than during the past few weeks, but many anglers will continue to employ fly rods and surface lures for bass and pickerel.
BERLIN, June 27 (AP) -- The German High Command communique, issued "from the Fuehrer's Headquarters," said today:

FORT DIX, N.J., June 27 -- New York City's Seventy-first Infantry Regiment, commanded by Colonel Grant Layng, this afternoon played host to officers of the Seventeenth Infantry Regiment, which succeeded them as a guard unit in New York when the Seventy-first was inducted into the Federal service last September.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 27 -- Mrs. Sylva A. Leichner of Fresh Meadow won her second championship in three weeks when she triumphed, 4 and 3, over Miss Grace Amory of Cedar Creek in the thirty-six-hole final of the women's Long Island match play golf title tournament at the Nassau Country Club today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: All of the weak points of contemporary automobile design emphasized by Albert A. Volk are glaringly apparent. From the standpoint of appearance and ease of operation, present-day cars are reminiscent of the false second-story fronts of frame buildings in Western frontier settlements.

DETROIT, June 27 -- After four hours of turbulent debate, the convention of the American Newspaper Guild, by a roll-call of 90 2-3 to 80 1-3, adopted a vote of confidence today in Milton Kaufman of New York, executive vice president who had been charged with membership in the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) -- Sharply higher taxes on automobiles and other durable goods virtually were assured today as the House Ways and Means Committee neared completion of the $3.600,000,000 defense tax bill.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- American policy toward Finland, in view of her involvement in the Russo-German war, and Sweden, in view of the permission she has given for German troops to pass through her territory, will be determined in the light of further information and future developments.

JONES BEACH, L.I., June 27 -- Lieutenant Don D. Dudley suffered severe burns and Lieutenant Charlie Falletta also was injured this morning when an Army plane from Mitchel Field, apparently forced down by engine trouble, crashed and burst into flame in the marshland off the Meadowbrook State Parkway near here.

Scoring a pair of par 72s on the South Shore course in Huguenot, S.I., Charles Amandoles of Dongan Hills led a field of twenty-nine today in the metropolitan district qualifying round for the United States Golf Association's twentieth amateur public links championship.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Sidney Hillman, associate director general of the Office of Production Management, disclosed today government plans to standardize wages and working conditions in the aircraft industry by means of a two-year regional agreement, under which employers and employes would agree to uninterrupted production of planes vitally needed by the United States and Great Britain.
MOSCOW, June 27 (AP) -- The following communique was issued today by the Soviet Information Bureau:

HAVERFORD, PA., June 27 -- Departing from the usual pattern of his attack to circumvent a stone-wall defense, Joe Hunt of the United States Naval Academy defeated Joe Davis of Vanderbilt today to gain the final round of the national intercollegiate tennis championship at the Merion Cricket Club.

A definite scarcity of desirable merchandise in the costume jewelry field by Oct. 1, due to conditions which exist in the market on both metals and stones, was predicted yesterday by Urie F. Mandle of the Nat Levy-Urie Mandle Corporation of this city.

The Madison Club, regular Democratic organization of the Eighteenth Assembly District in Brooklyn, was exonerated yesterday by the Kings County May grand jury of all charges of alleged larceny from the club's funds.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The arrest yesterday in New York of Louis Presto and Margaret Lovejoy by Federal narcotic agents was described by Treasury narcotic officials today as part of a three-city smash of a ring of illicit narcotic importers and distributors that had evaded the law for many years.

The June list of 100 books recommended by the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee for reading by members of the Roman Catholic Church was issued yesterday at St. Joseph's Seminary, Dunwoodie, N.Y. The committee publishes its book survey quarterly.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 27 -- "There is a state of war between Hungary and the Soviet Union because of the aerial attacks," the Hungarian Premier and Foreign Minister, Dr. Ladislaus de Bardossy, declared in the House of Deputies today amid cheers.

NEW ROCHELLE, June 27 -- Trainees from Fort Slocum went on their first camping trip this week, traveling by truck to the Camp Smith Reservation near Peekskill and spending the night in the open. The Fort Slocum command said the men had been drawn from New York City draft rolls and were "more accustomed to the canyons of midway than to rugged hill-sides.

Three vessels of the Maritime Commission's long-range construction program will be launched today at points on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts. Another ship was launched on the West Coast on Thursday, bringing the total to 119 vessels of the 500-ship program that have been sent down the ways.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The Senators bunched their eight blows effectively to defeat the Red Sox, 5 to 3, before 18,500 spectators tonight as Steve Sundra scattered eight safeties.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 27 -- One hour a week for religious training will not solve the problem of character building, Dr. Emanuel Gamoran of Cincinnati said today as the Central Conference of American Rabbis adopted a report opposing religious education in the schools.

LONDON, Saturday, June 28 -- Early today British bombers were still pounding the Nazi invasion coast and inland bases in Northern France, after almost continuous Royal Air Force attacks through yesterday and last evening.

A generally slow trade featured the market on all classes of fresh meats yesterday. Supplies of steer hinds and ribs were about normal, veal hindsaddles moderate to normal and lamb mostly normal. Kosher steer chucks and plates, lamb foresaddle and veal foresaddle supplies were about normal Prices of kosher meats were unchanged.
VICHY, France, June 27 -- Admiral William D. Leahy, the United States Ambassador, today had his first personal conference with Marshal Henri Philippe Petain in some time.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- A proposal by the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, United States Steel subsidiary, to expand its production of armor plate, special-treatment steel and heavy forgings needed for the Navy, at a cost of $85,000,000 to be met by the government, was approved today by William S. Knudsen.

Babe Ruth and Ty Cobb, representing a million dollars -- give or take a few -- of baseball talent of a bygone era, yesterday clashed for the second time in three days on the golf links. Three and a half hours of none too impressive golf resulted in a nineteen-hole 1-up victory for the Babe.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- As special agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation raided headquarters of the Socialist Workers party in Minneapolis and St. Paul, seizing records and other material, today, Acting Attorney General Francis Biddle authorized the placing before a Federal grand jury in St. Paul on Tuesday of criminal charges of seditious conspiracy against leaders of the party, alleged Trotskyite branch of the Communist movement.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 27 -- Full-scale resumption of work in Bay region shipyards next week was promised today following the action late last night of striking C.I.O. machinists of Oakland in voting, 267 to 35, to return to work Monday in shipyards in the East Bay area.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 27 -- Not until President Risto Ryti of Finland went on the air and declared "Finland is again going to defend herself" did the citizens of Finland realize that they were again at war.

Cotton-textile production this year is running at the record-breaking rate of 11,000,000,000 square yards annually, and more than 20 per cent of this is going either directly or indirectly into the defense program, it was estimated yesterday by the industry committee of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York.

DALLAS, Texas, June 27 -- President Roosevelt, who personally endorsed Representative Lyndon Johnson as his man in the United States Senate race for a successor to the late Morris Sheppard, tonight denounced as "preposterous" Governor W. Lee O'Daniel's plan for a Texas army, navy and air force.

Trade Here Up 20% in Week Retail trade here made sharp gains this week. Department store volume was estimated as running around 20 per cent ahead of the corresponding week last year. Some individual stores here had increases on several days of the week of 30 per cent or better, it was reported.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Norman Weinberg, secretary-treasurer of Bookniga Corporation of New York and one of the three officers of the company on trial here under indictments charging refusal to register with the Secretary of State as propaganda agents of a foreign principal, this afternoon decided to change his sworn testimony when asked if he had not had a copy of the Communist manifesto sent to a a girl, a student at Radcliffe College.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal Tor savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

GREENWICH, Conn., June 27 -- Bobby Edwards of Brunswick School and Bill Campbell of Exeter will meet tomorrow in the 36-hole final for the Eastern interscholastic golf championship at the Greenwich Country Club.
