HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 27 -- Richard Dix, star of Western films, was engaged today by Universal for the role of Wild Bill Hickock in "Bad Lands of Dakota," which will go before the cameras on Monday with Alfred E. Green directing. The deal is apart from Dix's agreement with Paramount for two pictures a year.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Supply contracts awarded today by the War Department totaled $17,310,990.58. Companies in the New York area receiving awards, not previously published, were announced as follows:

When Winter winds blow, cucumbers come to us from far away, romantic islands -- Puerto Rico, Cuba and the Isle of Pines -- and come at prices that only those with long purses can reach. Michigan's hothouses supply cucumber connoisseurs with their out-of-season treat, too, but again prices are luxurious.

The signing of contracts with the city for two public low-rent housing projects to accommodate 3,492 families and to cost $20,920,000 was announced yesterday by Edward Weinfeld, State Housing Commissioner.

JERSEY CITY, June 27 (AP) -- Jersey City registered its eighth victory over Syracuse in eight games tonight and climbed into fifth place in the International League standings by taking both games of a double-header from the Chiefs, 2-1 and 5-2, before a crowd of 4,201.

Pre-Independence Day sermons will be preached tomorrow in many of the city's pulpits. The discourses will include references to the new war between Germany and Russia and pastors will praise President Roosevelt for calling upon every American citizen on the nation's "birthday" to renew the oath to flag and country.

While showing no undue alarm over the prospects of a strike of subway employes, business houses of the city began yesterday to make or consider plans for getting their employes to work in the event of a rapid transit shutdown.

Many members of C.I.O., A.F. of L. and independent unions would refuse to use the subways to get to work if the city maintained operations in the face of a transport workers' strike, a survey among union officials indicated yesterday.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Many sports fans appreciated the comment James P. Dawson made in his follow-up story on the Louis-Conn fight when he wrote: "Criticism was heard from spectators in the level ringside rows over inability to see what happened in the ring because those in the front rows stood up impulsively in the excitement.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, by utilizing substitute materials, has saved enough aluminum in the last six months to build 130 Army bombing planes, A.W. Robertson, chairman of the company, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) -- The War Department asked Congress today to authorize a purge of unfit officers the retention of whom, Acting Secretary of War Patterson warned, would be "a real danger to national security.''

A strike of A.F. of L. construction workers and truck drivers in Queens spread to other boroughs yesterday, halting all delivery of building materials throughout the city, tying up bricklaying activities and producing the threat of a city-wide walkout of 10,000 building craftsmen early next week.
BOSTON, June 28 -- If there are subversive elements among the Braves, as is persistently reported in several local papers, they must have taken a day off today.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Congress worked busily today to dispose of legislation needed before the end of the fiscal year and cleared its calendars of some of the most important measures, while laying the groundwork for disposal of the others when it reconvenes Monday.

The Spicer Manufacturing Corporation and its subsidiaries, builders of transmissions, shafts and forgings, issued yesterday a report for the nine months to May 31 showing a net profit of $2,279,516 after depreciation, normal Federal taxes and other charges, and allowance for excess-profit taxes.
The United States Army today -- after a year of expansion and preparation -- is still months away from adequate combat efficiency.

This is a first booK that promises well. The author's style is pleasant and easy and he combines an interesting, swiftly moving tale with enough practical information about boat building and sailing to encourage any boy who lives near a pond to follow Davey's example and build a boat of his own.

A candidate pledged to end "Communist domination" of District Council 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, A.F. of L., was elected yesterday to the office of secretary-treasurer, principal position in the council, which has 11,000 members in Manhattan and the Bronx.

Plans have been completed for polo's big Fourth of July celebration on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club, where, on Friday, the two highest handicapped teams of the year will meet in a match for the benefit of the United Service Organizations.

TUXEDO PAKK, N.Y., June 28 -- This colony is enjoying its most active season in recent years. The club is filled to capacity and has had more visitors than in any period since the new club was opened. There will be a square dance here tonight.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 28 -- There were two records set on Long Island Sound today. The fleet of 119 boats in the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club's sixth annual regatta was the season's high for a championship event. Moreover, the oldest skipper in these waters could not remember another occasion when all boats finished before 5 P.M.

Long drought and a burning sun are just as real enemies to garder hardihood as are snow and ice. Even when the garden is not in a region much subjected to blistering weather there are frequently hot, dry spots where it is a real problem to obtain even living green, let alone bright color.

COLONEL, REMINGTON is evidently a dual, if not a multiple, personality. One part of him is sensitive, artistic, receptive to emotional impulse and quick to see human values. The other part is cool, analytical and restrained.

FOR decades the Mexicans have made much of Saltillo as a Summer health resort, and now Americans, in increasing numbers, are finding the place much to their liking. This season, for the first time, Summer courses will be offered.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 28 -- Earl Stewart, Louisiana State's redhaired 150-pound junior, climbed to the national intercollegiate golf throne today, firmly grasping as a scepter the magic putter with which he won the right to rule.
OUT of lullabies from sixteen different countries Dorothy Commins has made a gracious and appealing book, one that will please young and old and one that children and parents can enjoy together.

EYE - WITNESS accounts of Germany's first thrust against the Red Army are already flashing from the short waves of the Reich. Departing from the practice of shutting news of military moves from the air lanes, Berlin last Monday night gave a detailed story of the pounding by artillery of Soviet concrete defenses and the follow-up of "wave upon wave of attacking infantrymen."

The wide differences in the effects of the defense program on the economic life of the various sections of the country are reflected in the ratios of defense contracts awarded in the various States to their total manufacturing activity and their total income.

The war has not affected the New York art market adversely and has even helped it, according to figures for the past season just issued by the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc. The gross sales of this firm for its 1940-41 season were $3,606,381, an increase of 54 per cent over its previous season's total, and, according to the announcement, the largest total for any art and book auction house in the United States since 1929.

Mrs. Huntington's "Let's Go Out of Doors," an excellent first book for little children about insects and other outdoor creatures, illustrated by Preston Duncan's beautiful photographs and published two years ago, was planned by the author to answer the questions of her own boys.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., June 28 -- President Roosevelt decided today that, in view of the national emergency, government employes should not have an extended week-end holiday following July 4. The orders affects 1,478,407 employes.

With many of the new arrivals active on work in connection with the defense program, seventy-six new manufacturing establishments moved to the Bronx from Jan. 1 to May 31 of this year. A study by the Bronx Board of Trade of the records of the factory inspection bureau of the State Labor Department shows that nineteen new concerns located in the borough last month for manufacturing purposes.

A MAJOR competition which offers to both amateur and professional photographers an opportunity not only to win cash prizes, but also to have their work added to the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art has just been announced by that institution.

An appeal to join the new Fire Department Auxiliary Corps, an emergency defense project, was handed yesterday to each of 25,000 candidates for the job of fireman as he left a city high school building where he had taken the first civil service examination for fireman in four years.

IF a Newgate Calendar for Central New York were ever compiled no doubt many pages of it would be filled with biographical records of the Loomis family of Oneida County. In the middle decades of the last century these counterfeiters, horse-thieves and arsonists terrorized the countryside in the region of Waterville, Sangerfield and Clinton, and spread their depredations through the surrounding counties.

Germany's invasion of Russia a week ago today brought to a sudden climax the struggle that is now twenty-two months old. The new campaign -- measured by area and number of troops engaged, the greatest campaign of this or probably any other war-may shape Europe for generations to come.

OTTAWA, June 28 -- The weight of Germany's one-week-old attack on Russia has brought to this country just one year after the fall of France a second realization of the immensity and danger of the Nazi strength.

And now it is Dr. Victor G. Heiser, author of the admirable "American Doctor's Odyssey," who tells us that we are getting soft. "It is high time," says Dr. Heiser, in fact, "for Americans to develop some of the brawn of their pioneer ancestors and quit being dainty, steam-heated, rubber-tired, beauty-rested, effeminized pampered sissies softened by a thousand and one civilized gadgets and contraptions."

How Radiolocator Works Now that the British have appealed to us for technically trained men who can maintain and repair their radiolocators of aircraft, we have dug into the patent literature to discover what has been done by inventors to create artificial sense which will enable us to see through fogs and the inky blackness of moonless nights.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- An electric power emergency was declared today to exist in the Southeast by the Federal Power Commission. It was the first time the commission had invoked its emergency powers under the Federal Power Act.

QUEBEC -- A tour available to motorists this Summer describes an extensive loop through a little more than 500 miles of Quebec's beautiful rural countryside and vacation lands. Four distinct regions are embraced by this route.

DALLAS, Texas, June 28 (AP) -- Governor W. Lee O'Daniel cut sharply into the lead of Representative Lyndon Johnson in the special Texas senatorial election tonight as late rural returns were tabulated by the Texas Election Bureau.

BY Christmas the Army will have 273,812 motor vehicles, one for each five of the present 1,418,000 men, according to a report from the Washington correspondent of American Machinist. About one-third of these men, between 400,000 and 500,000, serving as drivers, mechanics and service men, are engaged in the transportation of the other two thirds.

The National Association of Manufacturers, in a public statement last week, asked the Federal Government, for the sake of maximum defense production, to "urge employers specifically not to discriminate against either union or nonunion workers," and to "protect the right of every man who wants to work to do so, free from coercion or intimidation from any source."

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Most of the people of this Central States area are hoping that Nazi Germany and Communist Russia destroy each other. To them that would be the ideal solution of the war now raging in Europe.
BERLIN, June 28 (AP) -- A communique from Adolf Hitler's Field Headquarters today said:
NEW YORK Lady Thornton has arrived at the Waldorf-Astoria from Chicago.

To the Music Editor: Is it not time for the Met to give a Mozart Cycle? With the revival of the "Magic Flute" this coming season there will be three of his operas in the repertory. Why not also give "Die Entfuehring" and "Cosi fan Tutte" and present them in a matinee and in an evening cycle?

If they were lazy this Spring or forgot to correct their government charts, some yacht skippers probably have been having some frightening moments lately, especially after dark. There is hardly a waterway used by metropolitan cruisers that hasn't been visited by the Coast Guard during recent weeks.

Criticism of American education is having its innings. It is reported that the Army examinations are turning up too high a percentage of illiteracy. It is set forth that Federal aid to education is the only remedy for the fact that some of the States are unable to find funds with which to keep large numbers of children of school age in school.

A new brightness has come into the dining room through the use of payer and more delicate color schemes. Everything -- pastel table linen, clear white, dull red or patterned china, blond furniture -- adds to the distinction that this all-important interior is beginning to take on.

TOYOHIKO KAGAWA is to Japan what Count Tolstoy was to Russia. A convert to Christianity, he has courted the displeasure of the Imperialists who are having things very much their own way in his country. His philosophy of non-violence has again and again landed him in prison.

To modernize and bring the New York City school curriculum up to date, extensive changes, sweeping in nature, are now being planned by a special committee consisting of the associate superintendents and experts in the field. Nearly every subject from elementary through high school is to be evaluated and studied.

MANCHESTER, Tenn., June 28 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Ben Lear, commander of the Second Army, said tonight in a report that the war manoeuvres, just ended, involving 77,000 men, showed the need of improvement in performance of commanding officers or "disastrous embarrassments and failures will be encountered during battle."
FRESNEAU was the name until after the death of Philip's father, and the family lived on Oleron, that small island in the Bay of Biscay just a few miles from the ancient city of La Rochelle in France.
June, 29 (AP) -- Field Marshal Baron Carl Gustaf Emil Mannerheim declared today in his first order of the day that the soldiers of Finland must follow him in a holy war against the Russians.

VICHY, France. IN order to stimulate French film production the government has just authorized loans to motion picture producing companies, with a limit of 50,000,000 francs for each concern. The loans will be made at 5 per cent over a three-year term.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: GELETT BURGESS, the writer interviewed in THE TIMES for June 8, held Robert Louis Stevenson up as the height of dudism in letters. By this he means, I suppose, that whereas contemporary writers use a bare, almost skeletal style, those of the nineteenth century -- with Stevenson at their head -- produced a musical flow of words that was intriguing, perhaps, but somewhat consciously "pretty."

NAMES of members of the jury of admission and award for the exhibition. Directions in American Painting, which will be held at Carnegie Institute in the Fall, have just been announced. They are Charles E. Burchfield of Buffalo, Charles Hopkinson of Boston, Kenneth Hayes Miller of New York and Millard Sheets of Los Angeles.

Concerning Mixed Company Because the democratic nations and Soviet Russia now have a common enemy in Hitler, some of our isolationists are forced to conclude that the democracies must not defend themselves against Hitler.

Under the combined effects of the threatened "ceiling" on cottonseed oil, and the placings of maximum prices on six cotton-cloth constructions, prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday broke $2.35 to $2.70 a bale, or 47 to 54 points, in unusually heavy liquidation for a two-hour session.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 28 (AP) -- The Rumanian High Command issued this communique today:

The organization of Men's Garden Clubs has spread until twenty-one States are now represented in the "more pants in the garden" movement that was started nine years ago in Chicago as the result of a $1,000 prize award, in a city-wide garden contest, to a male gardener.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- A new cowling control for air-cooled fighting planes which would prevent overheating of the engine in case of puncture by shell fire has been developed by the Bureau of Aeronautics of the Navy Department. The device has been patented (No. 2,246,498) by its inventor, Clarence F. Blanding of Arlington, Va.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Vermont's observance of the 150th anniversary of its admission to the Union as the fourteenth State gets into full swing this week, with no less than thirty-five separate celebrations planned in various parts of the State for the next ten weeks.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 28 -- The national intercollegiate championship tennis trophy was presented to Joe Hunt of the United States Naval Academy today by Dwight Davis, donor of the Davis Cup, marking the first victory for the East since 1928 and the first ever for Navy.

Another group of foreign investors has entered the home building field on Long Island, Thomas G. Grace, State Director of the FHA, revealed yesterday. The latest foreign firm to start construction there consists of a number of Dutch bankers headed by David van Dam, long a successful real estate operator in Amsterdam, the Netherlands.

THERE is something strange and fascinating in the relationship of Hitler and Stalin. They were until recently at opposite poles of policy. Then the two extremes met and people began to discover that there was much similarity between the Nazi and Bolshevist regimes if not between the personalities of the two dictators.

The great seaport of Beirut, cradled in a fertile plain about halfway along the Mediterranean's eastern coast, has been a prize of empire since the days of the seafaring Phoenicians. It has been held by Roman, Crusader, Druse, Turk, Russian, Egyptian, Briton. Since 1920 it has been the capital of Frenchmandated Lebanon.

BERLIN, June 28 -- In his New Year's proclamation to the German people Reichsfuehrer Hitler categorically asserted that "the year 1941 will bring the culmination of the greatest victory in our history." From the context of the proclamation and the circumstances under which it was issued, this assertion was interpreted not only throughout the world but also within the Third Reich to mean Germany's war with Britain would be concluded this year.

MOSCOW, June 28 -- Russia's hero for today was young Uladim Shchevchenko, fighter pilot of the Red air fleet, who was credited with shooting down twenty-two German bombers yesterday during a series of intense air battles on the Lwow front.

Deposits aggregating $102,402,000 were received by the savings, building and loan associations and cooperative banks throughout the country during the month of April, reports the United States Savings and Loan League. It was the third month of the present year in which the receipts exceeded more than $100,000,000.

A HUNDRED years ago today, balletomanes of Paris were all agog over the production the night before at the Academie Royale de Musique of the most successful ballet since the revolutionary "La Sylphide" nine years earlier.

OMAHA, Neb., June 28 -- If the blitzkrieg in Russia has had any marked effect on the Middle West's attitude toward the war it is not perceptible to the naked eye. Nor is much, if any, shift in public opinion anticipated.

PREVENTING CIRRHOSIS -- Professor E.V. McCollum and Dr. Harold Blumberg of the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene announce in Science that cirrhosis of the liver in rats can be prevented by choline, a chemical generally considered part of the vitamin B complex.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated June 27:

Yachtsmen of the New York Athletic Club, who have formed Flotilla No. 604 of the Coast Guard Auxiliary, will meet Tuesday night at the Travers Island Yacht House to learn more about small boat service in time of war. Commander W.K. Denton has arranged to have Walter Footer tell of his experiences in wartime England and especially of the evacuation of Dunkerque.

with practically an the available cottages now occupied in the numerous lake resort areas within the metropolitan territory, the Fourth of July holiday period this week is expected to show a greater degree of activity than has been seen for several years.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The Fourth of July holiday is expected to bring to the resort one of the largest crowds in its history, and an appropriate program of entertainment has been arranged by hotels, piers and night clubs.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Bill Zuber, heretofore a relief hurler, pitched the Senators to a 3-to-1 victory over the Red Sox today with the able support of the Washington infield, credited with five double plays.

Production cuts in consumers' durable goods, such as autos, appliances, radios, tires, etc., resulting either from government requests or from material shortages, will definitely stimulate the service industries as dealers attempt to offset Bales losses on new products by other means, executives in the various fields predicted last week.

Reich Against Russia The two contracting parties [Germany and Russia] obligate themselves to refrain from every act of force, every aggressive action and every action against one another * * * -- Russo-Gennan pact, Aug. 24, 1939.

LONDON, June 28 (AP) -- Agitation grew in Britain tonight for daring attacks by British Army and Navy raiders on the German-held Continental coasts, now that the Nazis' backs are turned. One military expert suggested that amphibian tanks join in a general offensive teamed up with the great, continuing R.A.F. assaults.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Legislation to confer upon Federal district courts jurisdiction over all threatened labor stoppages was proposed today by Representative Walter of Pennsylvania, who said he would introduce in the House Monday a measure providing for such action.

Fritzie Zivie, the Pittsburgh warrior who holds the welterweight championship of the world, will clash with Al Davis, Brownsville athlete who is now a private in the United States Army, at the Polo Grounds on Tuesday night. Zivic's title will not be at stake, since the battle is listed for twelve rounds, but this circumstance will hardly serve as a deterrent to the success of the bout.

Prevailing temperatures not-withstanding, the earth will be in Aphelion, or farthest from the sun, at 7 P.M. (E.S.T.) on Wednesday, July 2. At that time it will be 94,450,000 miles distant from our daytime star. This is approximately 4,000,000 miles farther from the sun than we were on Jan. 3.

MOUNTING applications to engage in non-commercial educational broadcast service are held by radio men to be indicative of the Value of FM in developing the five high-frequency channels reserved by the Federal Communications Commission for non-profit educational use.

TEL AVIV. FOLLOWING the Palestine Orchestra's first performance, earlier in the season, of Ben-Chaim Frankenburger's symphony, the orchestra played for the first time another work of a Palestinian composer in the course of its Spring season.

Fenelon, the big Belair Stud colt, ran so fast and pulled so strongly at Aqueduct yesterday that he changed Jockey Jimmy Stout's tactics on the way to victory in the $28,000 Brooklyn Handicap, richest event ever run by the Queens County Jockey Club.

A distinctive new type of hardy garden lily, with large blooms opening flat and outward, has been produced by F.L. Skinner, Canadian hybridist who has been experimenting for many years in Northern Manitoba. These new flat-opening hybrids bloomed for the first time last Summer, and are among a number of promising new seedlings in the test plots.
MOSCOW, June 28 (AP) -- A new Soviet spokesman said at a special press conference today that "we have no claims on the Dardanelles."

Figures for May released last week by the United States Customs Service show that traffic in this port reached a new high level for the third successive month, a marked increase being evident in the movement of vessels in foreign trade.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Although the exact status of British payments on account of pre-lease-lend commitments in this country is a diplomatic secret, rough statistical approximations indicate to some experts in the government that Great Britain may be able to pay off these obligations by the end of the calendar year with the aid of a Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan now under negotiation.

WATERVILLE, Me., June 28 -- The Colby College library, possessor of the world's finest collection of the works of Thomas Hardy, will open on Tuesday an exhibition of fifty editions of Hardy's novel, "Tess of the D'Urbervilles," to mark the fiftieth anniversary of its publication on July 4, 1891.
Conversion of the Park Slope neighborhood of Brooklyn from an area of fine old mansions into one of high-class apartment houses is continuing unabated, a check-up of that section reveals.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 28 -- Only through the enlightened and generous interest of American Catholics can the church keep a foothold on "the frontiers of faith" in foreign mission work, the Most Rev. Edward Mooney, Archbishop of Detroit, declared today.

The U.S.S.R.'s resistance to the Nazi assault will depend to a large extent upon the power and efficiency of the Soviet industrial machine. The output of the steel mills and factories, the productivity of the grain fields, and the efficiency of railroads and canals will be important factors in the struggle of the Red Army against the armed might of Germany.

THERE is a disarming affability about the Chileans that frequently causes the visitor to overlook their tenacious intellectual vitality and national consciousness. But it is precisely these qualities that give hemispheric significance to the present political movement in Chile.
LONDON. June 28 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

Divergent views on the granting of American aid to Soviet Russia in its war against Nazi Germany were expressed here yesterday by two Catholic groups.

Between 56,000 and 70,000 New Yorkers who have reached the age of 21 since Oct. 16, 1940, will be listed here on Tuesday in the second national registration for Selective Service, it was estimated yesterday by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, Director of Selective Service for New York City.

RUMSON, N.J., June 28 -- For her third best-in-show victory of the year, the excellent-moving, heavily black-marked German shepherd bitch Ch. Giralda's Ulla won chief honors today in the thirteenth annual Monmouth County Kennel Club all-breed exhibition on the Harding estate.

HAGERSTOWN, Md. -- Chugging up and over the Blue Ridge Mountains and then gliding down to this thriving third city of the Old Line State, Western Maryland Train No. 3 from Baltimore brings the traveler some of the most picturesque scenery in the East.

"DON QUIXOTE" is one of the few books that can claim the distinction of being universal and cosmopolitan, equally at home in all the languages into which it has been translated. For a long time it was looked upon as a burlesque, a farcical satire on the romances of chivalry, just as Shylock was for so long considered a character of low comedy.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 28 -- Press reports from both Berlin and Helsinki indicated tonight that German troops were driving through Northern Finland toward the Russian port of Murmansk and along the Karelian Isthmus in the south toward Leningrad.

The national defense program which, for some time has been causing extensive real estate activity in outlying districts around New York, is now bringing about considerable action in the downtown office section, according to J. Clydesdale Cushman, head of the firm bearing his name.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Mayor La Guardia's first big gun as Civilian Defense Coordinator was fired last week at all the surplus aluminumware in the country. He called for old pots and pans, golf sticks, anything made of aluminum, in the hope of acquiring donations aggregating 20,000,000 pounds, enough to make some 2,000 fighters.

MADRID, Spain, June 28 -- Argentina and Spain have begun negotiations for a new commercial agreement under which Spain would receive large quantities of foodstuffs, it was stated today, and it was expected the agreement would be concluded soon.

HOLLYWOOD. MICKEY MOUSE and Donald Duck have screeched "Unfair" from placards at the gates of Walt Disney's pastel-shaded studio for four weeks and a picket line has yelled "scab" and "fink" at the artists who continue to cross the line and bring Mickey and Donald to life inside.

More buyers were in the market last week than in the corresponding week of previous years and placed a satisfactory volume of business in fashion merchandise of all types, according to the market report prepared especially or THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

NEXT Thursday afternoon a great trek will begin. Friday, the Fourth of July, Saturday and Sunday -- the longest week-end of the Summer -- will see millions of people at beaches and mountain resorts. Already railroads, airlines and bus companies have received heavy booking's; automobile traffic promises to be exceedingly heavy.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Owen Lattimore, widely known American author of several books dealing with affairs of the Far East, has been appointed as a special political adviser to the Chinese Government, and will go to Chungking immediately.

The fifty-five-game championship schedule of the National Football League will get under way on Sunday, Sept. 7, and will continue with two or more contests each week through Sunday, Dec. 7, Elmer Layden, newly appointed Commissioner of Professional Football, announced yesterday from his Chicago office.

QUEBEC -- A dual celebration, symbolic of the friendly relations existing between Canada and the United States, will be held in Quebec during the next few days. On Tuesday visitors from the United States will help Canadians celebrate Dominion Day, marking the sixty-fourth anniversary of the founding of the Dominion of Canada.

What once was Idlehour, the magnificent estate of the late William K. Vanderbilt at Oakdale, L.I., and more recently was known as Peace Haven, a sort of laboratory wherein immortality was to be proved to mortal satisfaction by the Royal Fraternity of Master Metaphysicians, has been ordered sold "at the front door of the Suffolk County Court House," it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Senator George, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, led a surprise Democratic attack on the Administration's "totalitarian methods" today and asked for assurance that "when we are called upon to move into the actual range of fire" the American people, through Congress, would have the ultimate decision.

FRAISSES, Loire. JACQUES SAHEL in his new novel, Echec aux Hommes (Plon). makes a successful effort to renew the material of fiction. For the theme of love or adventure he substitutes a subject solely borrowed from the life of big business.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Control Administrator, ordered a reduction today of about 15 per cent in the prices of six leading types of cotton cloth and announced that he was considering action to lower the prices of rayon fabrics.

TRAVEL LINES: Scranton, Pa., celebrates its centennial July 23-30, and as the center of the world's richest anthracite deposits it will give visitors an opportunity to see the "workings" far underground, miles of under-surface roads, and that vanishing American, the faithful mine mule who is rapidly being replaced by the electric motor. . .

The stories of the savage raids on London on May 10 and 11 -- the raids that saw Westminster Abbey hit, the Commons Chamber in the Houses of Parliament unroofed, the British Museum struck -- did not get around to the details of a little nursery center which disappeared under a bomb that fell on a slum in Hoxton.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- Ordinarily the 10,000-meter run is a drab event, but it teemed with drama today as the fifty-third annual national A.A.U. track and field championships opened on sunbaked Franklin Field in 100-degree weather.

CANYON CITY, Col. -- This Summer the tremendous areas of the Rockies -- many hundreds of square miles of which are still unexplored -- are being discovered by fresh thousands of Eastern sportsmen. For news of the variety, quantity and quality of fishing and hunting to be had in these parts has been spread about and, what is more to the point, at last is being believed.

THE broadening of the European conflict to include Russia suggests possible philatelic changes and the three Baltic States of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia are those most immediately concerned. They were incorporated into the U.S.S.R. less than a year ago, ending the national independence which the World War of 1914-18 gave to each.

Officers of the new Public Health Research Institute of New York City. Inc., which was authorized by the Board of Estimate last Thursday, have been elected, and a council of medical scientists to supervise the technical work has been named, it was announced yesterday by Health Commissioner John L. Rice.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 28 -- The medalists, James B. Baldwin of Piping Rock and Robert L, Gerry Jr. of Meadow Brook, were still in the running tonight as play in the annual Piping Rock invitation best-ball golf tournament moved into the semi-finals.

CARE of the thousands of children -- also of some adults -- who stray away from relatives while visiting New York City beaches during the Summer presents a real problem.

WHEN Germany's Luftwaffe was blitzing England last Summer with just about everything it had, the heroic little Spitfires and Hurricanes that finally fought the Nazis off were running anywhere from 2.500 to 4,000 feet before getting off the ground.

According to the annual report of the committee on technical services of the American Institute of Architects, of which Professor Charles W. Killam of Harvard University is chairman, governmental agencies, including the United States Housing Authority, the Public Buildings Administration, the War and Navy Departments and the National Bureau of Standards, are failing to make available to the building industry their findings on building materials and methods.

WASHINGTON. TWO Junes ago some residents of Washington looked uneasily at the gray granite building, massive under its green dome, which stands a few hundred yards east of the Capitol. Outside the fact that some people considered it rather ugly, there was nothing the matter with the building itself.

THE fifth annual Mozart festival will be held Aug. 28-31 in Asheville, N.C., under the musical direction of Thor Johnson. Five concerts will be given, sponsored by the Asheville Mozart Festival Guild, Inc. One of the purposes of these festivals is to give American artists, especially those of North Carolina, an opportunity to take part in a musical undertaking of the sort.

Old Dr. Priestley is as astute and sharp-spoken as ever, but a good deal has happened before he steps into the solution of the mystery of Furnace Wood. In Furnace Wood a troop of soldier-scientists has completely hidden its laboratory camp while engaged in extremely important research work.

With the muskalonge season scheduled to open in New York on Tuesday, the State Conservation Department announces that all anglers planning to fish in any waters of Chautauqua of Cattaraugus Counties, with the exception of Lake Erie, must first obtain a special muskalonge license.

Wendell L. Willkie, in a speech based upon President Roosevelt's announcement that the United States has fallen behind in the manufacture of ammunition, asked yesterday for the coordination of defense production and for the appointment of an individual responsible to the President to administer that coordination.

About 130 boys and girls, ranging in age from 5 to 12, will return to school tomorrow, somewhat in the role of "teachers," in the Summer demonstration school sponsored jointly by the New York University School of Education, the Summer Play Schools Association and the Associated Experimental Schools in the building of the Little Bed School House at 136 Bleecker Street.

THE prospect of a new radio law has been clearly indicated in the barrage of words laid down at the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee hearing, now in recess, on the White resolution calling for Congressional investigation of the broadcasting industry and the Federal Communications Commission.

Wall Street met its first competitive-bidding test for public-utility securities head-on last week, and, strange as it may seem, almost the exact opposite of competitive bidding resulted. The explanations for the failure of the competitive-bidding test to go off smoothly were many and varied, depending, of course, on the points of view taken by the parties involved.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 28 -- Many members of the Summer colony are already established at their estates here and a large contingent is expected early next week for the full program planned for July 4.

Clapham has become painfully aware of this in his peparation of "The Cambridge Economic History of Europe From the Decline of the Roman Empire," of which the first volume, covering the agrarian life of the Middle Ages, has just appeared.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- In a critical report on defense progress, the House Military Committee asserted today that a series of major "failures" and "delays" had led to a serious lack of strategic materials.

Garden "spreaders" are plants which increase either by expanding their clumps by offshoots, or, more often, by throwing out long underground roots from which new plants arise. In the garden such spreaders may become serious pests, but properly handled many of them have very definite uses.

If the stock market is really the barometer of business, somebody should tap it. The first half of 1941 is ending with business activity at the highest level in history, with national income for the year estimated at $85,000,000,000, with most important business indices approaching or crossing the highs of 1929 -- and with the New York Stock Exchange expecting the worst volume since 1914, when trading was shut down from Aug. 1 to mid-December.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- An official warning yesterday that a ceiling would be imposed on prices for cottonseed oil was responsible today for a wide-open break in the soybean and lard markets on the Board of Trade here. Soy beans dropped 8 cents a bushel and lard $1 a 100 pounds, the permissible limit for one day's trading under the Exchange's regulations, and the close was at the bottom.

However different the conditions of the two wars may be, and whatever the outcome in the present case, in at least one respect this clash hears a close resemblance to that between Napoleon and old Russia.

JERUSALEM, June 28 -- British Imperial air forces extended their "they-shall-not-pass" campaign this week against German supplies from Italy to Tripoli harbor, but did not cease their regular attacks upon the Cyrenaican seaport of Bengazi, which has been bombed almost nightly for more than a month.

Russia's entrance into the war against Germany must not result in slackening of American aid to England, because, despite American opposition to communism, Hitlerism must be destroyed if democracy is to survive, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: What we need today is an American labor program free from foreign isms and underworld exploitation.

TORONTO -- New areas for tourist exploration beckon in Canada's Near and Far North. Gold and silver, radium and copper, the white coal that is water power, fur and oil -- these are a few of the reasons that the trail northward is becoming more traveled as each year rolls by.

The end of the second heat wave in less than a week was predicted yesterday by the local Weather Bureau after the temperature had risen to 88 degrees. Although the mean temperature yesterday was not quite as high as that of Friday the humidity was greater.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina. June 28 (UP) -- Indication that Brazil would accept the non-belligerency formula proposed by the Uruguayan Government to the other American republics was given today by the Brazilian Foreign Minister. Dr. Oswaldo Aranha.

Law schools are urged to extend to all students the type of training in independent research now confined to student editors of the law reviews, in a survey of methods and objectives in the placement of law graduates made by Professor James P. Gifford of the Columbia University Law School.

LOS ANGELES -- With a "box office" that would please a New York producer, the W.K. Kellogg Institute of Animal Husbandry at Pomona has presented Sunday shows to nearly 1,500,000 people in the past ten years and has proved to be one of California's outstanding tourist attractions.

NUMEROUS biographies and novels have been written in recent years about Paul Jones, but there has not been a life of Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, whom Rear Admiral Caspar F. Goodrich called "our Navy's greatest man," in over thirty-five years.

The Giants looked to have the Phils all wrapped up for a swift and early embalming at the Polo Grounds yesterday when, to the consternation of 4,682 astounded onlookers, Manager Doc Prothro, by a series of fiery gestures on the coaching lines, managed to inject some of his dashing spirit into that of his supposedly jaded helpers.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 28 -- The Vassar College Summer Institute of Euthenics, which began its sixteenth, annual session this week, has eighty college men and women enrolled from twenty-one States and Canada. The six weeks' program will be carried on under the leadership of thirty-four experts from various fields.

IN two articles, originally published in The Saturday Evening Post, Harry Scherman discusses the prospects of inflation and "The Real Danger in Our Gold." His answer to the title question is the only safe one to make, namely: "It Depends."

Whether the railroads can replace the fifty tank steamships transferred to British service in the transport of petroleum is a question on which opinions differ as between the railroads and the oil companies. The railroads believe that with soma restrictions on consumption they are in a position to provide an adequate supply of fuel to the Atlantic seaboard, whereas the oil companies say the building of more pipe lines and tankers is necessary.

DOCUMENTARY photography is assuming an increasingly important role, and the current exhibition of Farm Security Administration photographs at the Museum of Science and Industry at Rockefeller Center is an outstanding example of documentation in the United States.

WHAT costs, charges and profits make up the price of a new car? Mr. and Mrs. Buyer wonder about this and perhaps find some of the answers. The question is answered fully, from the consumer-motorist point of view, in the 1941 edition of Ward's Automotive Year Book, just out.

DALLAS, Texas, June 28 -- There is no real sympathy in the South-west for Russia in its war with Germany, but the people of this section agree almost unanimously that the United States should help Russia as a means of halting Hitler.

IT may come as a surprise to some people to learn that the public has no rights in a library of rare books, that a primary concern of the curator of such an institution is to protect the books against the public. Harsh as this dictum may sound, it is one whose validity is generally recognized by responsible librarians, collectors, bibliophiles and scholars.

R.A.F. raids on Hamburg in May had a "devastating effect" in spite of elaborate anti-aircraft defense and camouflage precautions, according to a German-Jewish citizen who has just arrived in this country via Lisbon and whose name is withheld because members of his family are still in Germany.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 28 -- From now on it might be a good plan to concede the New Jersey State golf championship to Charley Whitehead and let the other Garden State amateurs battle it out for runner-up honors.

EIGHTEEN years ago, on arriving here to conduct the opening concerts of the new Rochester Orchestra, a well-informed New York reporter at Pier 56 asked me, during the course of his routine questionnaire, what I thought of American composers.

TRENTON, N.J., June 28 -- Colonel Cassius M. Dowell, commanding officer at Fort Dix, told a Congressional investigating committee today that he had recommended to the War Department that no additional Army units be sent to the camp until sanitation facilities had been increased.

Bringing the total number of accredited schools to 102, ten colleges and universities have been added to the list of educational institutions whose work in chemistry has been approved by the committee on the professional training of chemists of the American Chemical Society, It was announced yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, June 29 -- The Russian High Command, in a communique received here early this morning, reported that 4,000 German and Russian tanks had been engaged for the last forty-eight hours in a seesaw battle in the Luck sector of the Russian-held area of Poland.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 28 -- Possibly because the Pacific Coast region has been one of the principal scenes of Communist agitation in the labor movement, advocates here of all-out aid to Hitler's enemies are attempting to distinguish between opposition to communism locally and encouragement for the Soviet Union internationally.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 28 (AP) -- By shattering twenty-five straight targets in a shoot-off, W.D. Chappell of Buffalo won the handicap championship of the New York State trapshooting tournament today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 -- San Francisco and the bay area have long been pro-British with opinion on American entry probably 70 per cent in favor-an estimate based on the virtually unanimous belief that involvement is inevitable. The effect of Germany's "crusade" against Bolshevism is making little if any difference.

The Transport Workers Union called off yesterday the strike scheduled for Tuesday on the city's unified transit lines. The C.I.O. affiliate announced that its joint executive committee would act tonight on a peace formula worked out by Mayor La Guardia and Philip Murray, chairman of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, in an exchange of telegrams.

The cost of foreclosing mortgages in New York State is described as "excessive" by State Senator Thomas C. Desmond in an attack on the system of appointing receivers, realty agents and auctioneers. The expense of repossessing real estate here is greater than in any other State except Illinois, according to Senator Desmond, who attributes the high charges in the main to "political patronage."

THE new Criminal Courts Building, on Centre Street just off Foley Square, will officially open tomorrow. This is a handsome building and architecturally rather an important one. Its importance may be gauged by looking at its neighbors across, the street.

Bundles for Britain, Inc., 745 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday that the steadily increasing' volume of apparel and supplies it is shipping to the war-stricken people of the British Isles had reached an over-all total of nearly 3,000,000 items on June 1.

TOKYO, June 28 -- Following the recent recognition of the Roman Catholic Church as a legal religious organization under the Religious Bodies Law, which became effective April 1, 1940, all Protestant denominations in Japan, except the Episcopalians, and Seventh-Day Adventists, united in one organization, the Church of Christ in Japan.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The President's difficulties in fixing upon and executing an aid-to-Russia program arise in part from politics, both domestic and international, using the term in its highest sense; and in part from strategic, geographical and economic perplexities.

Few people, young or old, know very much about libraries and what they can get from them. "Millions of Books" in a well-written, interesting and dignified text, with many photographs, tells what kinds of libraries there are, what they will do for those who use them, and makes excellent suggestions to library users for getting the most out of these libraries.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., June 28 -- "America, more than any other country in the world, has conferred upon lawyers a most prominent role in the political life of the nation," said Speaker Heck of the New York Assembly in an address before members of the New York State Bar Association at the closing banquet of the two-day convention tonight.

DETROIT, June 28 (AP) -- George McQuinn belted a tremendous two-run homer in the tenth inning today to give the Browns a 3-to-1 victory over the Tigers after Buck Newsom had wild-pitched the tying run home in the ninth. It was Newsom's eleventh setback against five victories.

WHAT is so comic about bad play? Strictly speaking, it should be boring One should be overcome by the sheer dullness of the stuff that is coming across the footlights Certainly that is the effect pool plays have on an audience.

WOODS HOLE, Mass. -- It would be difficult to find along the coast of Southwestern Cape Cod a household that does not possess a boat. Lively sailboats of various sizes and trim cruisers of all descriptions dot the region's waters like so many gulls.

FOUR weeks ago we were noting in our usual dutiful way that the motion picture business was then suffering from a dearth of patronage. Box-office grosses were lagging from here to Los Angeles, and theatre men were plucking their brows in openly bewildered despair.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Latvia, according to Dr. Alfred Bilmanis, her Minister here, will "continue to struggle for her complete and unconditional independence."

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Work on 312 emergency cargo ships on the ways in nine shipyards on the Atlantic, Gulf and West Coasts is sixty to ninety days ahead of schedule, the Maritime Commission reported today.

A new school to train stagecraft instructors for college drama departments, combining classroom, studio and workshop instruction during the Winter at a plant in Edgewater, N.J., with production experience during the Summer at the Ogunquit Playhouse in Maine, will be opened in the Fall by Alexander Wyckoff and a nucleus of associates with whom he has worked for the last fifteen or twenty years.

With a truce reached in the transit labor row, the C.I.O. threw all its resources yesterday into a fight with the city over recognition of an A.F. of L. affiliate as bargaining representative for 10,000 Sanitation Department employes.

SOMEWHERE IN VERMONT. LIKE many other city people, we longed for a home in the country: "a little place with a view and a brook and an old apple orchard," where one could raise chickens, strawberries or potatoes; a place where one could retire when the city job gave out.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 28 -- Fifteen awards for reporting and service to newspapers, radio, news-reals, magazines and news photography were presented here tonight at the annual dinner of the National Headliners Club at the Hotel Traymore, attended by 125 leaders in these allied fields.

Unless all groups in a community are willing to sacrifice some of the ease and comfort of their daily existence to benefit children in need, American principles of democracy may vanish from the earth. William Church Osborn says in a foreword to the annual report of the Children's Aid Society, of which he is president.

Bewildered by the ramifications of the Presidential order of June 14, requiring Federal licenses for transactions with the nationals of Continental European countries, a number of companies hare last week suspended the balk of their export businesses until the regulations are clarified.

MOSCOW, Sunday, June 29 (UP) -- The Russian High Command announced today that Russian forces were fighting off a German tank assault toward Minsk and reported that one of the greatest tank battles in history, with 4,000 machines engaged, was being fought in the Luck sector.

One of Washington's youngest and busiest agencies is the OPACS -- the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply. Created by President Roosevelt on April 11 and put under the New Deal economist, Leon Henderson, the OPACS seeks to prevent spiraling prices, inflation, profiteering and a soaring cost of living.

PHILADELPHIA. THE Liberty Bell, symbol of American independence, celebrates a double anniversary on July 8. On this day in 1776, 165 years ago, it pealed out the tidings of our republic's birth. On this day in 1835,106 years ago, it was made mute by the famous crack that runs upward like a jagged scar from its chipped and timeworn rim.

"A CLAMBAKE." said Henry, "ain't no lady party." Within the confines of the piscatory fraternity of the Fulton Fish Market, Henry enjoys universal respect as a clambake expert. Indeed his prowess is so well recognized that he eagerly envisages an un-interrupted series of week-ends spent on the beaches of Long Island and New England, breathing in the fine, familiar fragrance of salt air and seaweed and steaming soft-shell clams.

The Park Department, which is nothing if not versatile, has branched out into the unexpected field of puppeteering. Every day, until Aug. 19, in one of sixty-eight playgrounds, fifty or a hundred children will cluster around a green and giddily decorated trailer which, when doors in its sides are opened and a curtain rises, becomes a very acceptable puppet theatre with a stage 12 by 8 by 14 feet.
WASHINGTON. AMONG the men with the longest strings of headaches in Washington is 32-year-old Nelson Aldrich Rockefeller, who is "coordinating" our drive against Nazi influence in Latin America.

A TIME may be coming, it seems reasonable to hope, when the use of a European name for an American wine will be enough to relegate it to the cheap mass-production class, and all really good native wines will bear informative geographical appellations.

CODE A German submarine commander is able to signal intelligibly to a surface vessel of quite another nationality, a British patrol ship can hail a craft of any registry and personnel and exchange messages with her.

FOR a century and a half the character of a London brewer's wife has been a subject of fascinated controversy among people interested in eighteenth-century life and literature. "What a dear, delightful person she was!" Professor Sir Walter Raleigh exclaimed to A. Edward Newton, as those two savants discussed Dr. Johnson's friend, Hester Lynch Thrale, some years ago.

The Bronx is experiencing a slight slowing up process in the number of plans filed for new building construction but there is no definite indication that builders are deserting the field, according to James A. Houlihan, president of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx.

Stating that the administration of the registered home service has recently been transferred from the offices of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in Washington to the regional banks in each of the twelve Federal Home Loan Bank districts, the current issue of The Federal Home Loan Bank Review points out that the basic essentials remain unchanged.

THE longer this war runs the less formidable the German Luftwaffe becomes. There is little reason to doubt that it is the most powerful air force operating in the world today, but it is far from being the invincible machine the Nazis pictured it to be and most of the world thought it was.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 28 -- John M. Melville's Canadian-bred chestnut gelding Chiropodist captured the conformation hunter championship as the eighteenth annual Fairfield County Hunt Club Horse Show closed today.

TOKYO, June 28 -- Ever since the fateful flash from Berlin last Sunday, announcing that war had begun between Nazi Germany and Bolshevist Russia and that the two totalitarian world revolutions had at last met in a long-expected head-on collision, highest Japanese Government authorities have been sitting in continuous conferences with army and navy heads to formulate a policy for coping with the new situation.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sunday, June 29 (AP) -- The British Middle East Air Command issued the following communique today:

LEADING stars of the films and radio will perform "Double Duty" -- to the U.S. and the U.S.O. -- tonight, in a three-hour program of that name at the Hollywood Bowl in aid of the United Service Organizations drive for funds to provide recreational facilities for the American armed forces.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The full meaning of the outbreak of hostilities between Nazi Germany and Soviet Russia will not be clear for many years to come. The immediate danger to America is that this new crisis will confuse and retard action at a moment when speed and clarity of purpose are of paramount importance.

JOURNEYING from Cape Town to the Mediterranean, the young American journalist and travel writer James Saxon Guilders saw the "two Africas." And it is in a resolutely informative emphasis on that dual personality that he has written this book.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 28 -- A column of British troops, supported by bomber and fighter aircraft, pushed deep into Central Syria today along the main road leading out of Damascus toward Horns and is now only about thirty-five miles from that city.

WASHINGTON. June 28 -- The War Department's consolidation of the Army's air services into one coordinated unit and its opposition to the creation of a separate independent air force are described by Secretary Stimson as based on the necessity for unified command under the exigencies of modern warfare, and to the fact that the creation of an independent air force would require alteration of the country's entire military set-up at a time of emergency.

A preliminary report from a national survey of industrial plants and storage buildings being made by the Society of Industrial Realtors indicates an abundance of industrial plants in good condition, available for immediate use for defense industries and industrial expansion, according to Walter S. Schmidt, president of the society.

LONDON, June 28 -- The Alstertor, a fast oil-burning German ship of 3,000 tons, built three years ago and used lately as a supply vessel for commerce raiders and as a prison for captives, has been intercepted, the Admiralty announced tonight. Seventy-eight officers and men of the British merchant marine were rescued.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With reference to your recent article on rubber rationing, the writer, who has lived in Brazil, believes this would be unnecessary if rubber supplies were obtained at this time from the Amazon basin of that country.
Planning a small home so as to combine charm with pleasing variations from neighboring houses is said to be one of the fundamental problems facing the building industry today.

THERE is no better reading, surely, than a good collection of letters. Not all good writers are interesting in their correspondence, but the late T.E. Lawrence was assuredly one of that restricted circle.

David Ford, assistant governor of the Federal Home Loan Bank System, calling attention to the rising demand today for low-cost homes, pointed out that too often in the past such homes have been produced without adequate considerstion of proper design, llvability and utility, and without proper safe-guards on materials and workmanship.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Pittsfield is to have an old-fashioned Independence Day celebration, starting on Thursday night with a "rag-shag" parade for children. A patriotic parade is scheduled for Friday morning, with floats, drum corps and marching units in competition for prizes.
WHAT, demanded the blunt-bodied and rapierminded Dr. Gideon Fell, investigating a murder-or-suicide mystery in a haunted castle in the Scottish Highlands, "what could have been in that dog-carrier?"

HOLLYWOOD. THE first thing Joseph I. Breen, former Production Code Administrator of the Hays office, did when be assumed control of the RKO Radio studios on Monday was to open negotiations with Orson Welles for a new contract, thus restoring hope and happiness to the life of the producer of "Citizen Kane."

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Officials indicated tonight that the Federal Government might take over the smokeless powder plant of the Western Cartridge Company at East Alton. Ill., if company officials persisted in their refusal to grant exclusive bargaining rights to the local of the Chemical Workers Union, A.F. of L., as recommended by the National Defense Mediation Board.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 28 -- Bill Campbell, just out of Exeter, made a runaway of the thirteenth annual Eastern interscholastic golf championship today. Playing at the Greenwich Country Club, home course of his opponent, Campbell ended the test on the thirteenth hole of the afternoon round for a 7 and 5 triumph over 17-year-old Bobby Edwards of Brunswick School.

THERE will never be an exact count of the immense crowd that jammed the Lewisohn Stadium ten days ago at the opening night of the Philharmonio-Symphony Orchestra's twenty-fourth Summer season. The crowds that converged on the Convent Avenue entrance behind the shell broke the turnstile there and so they had to be admitted without being counted.

THERE are men and women living today who can remember when horse cars angled leisurely through the principal streets of our large cities, and immense stables, with many grooms, took care of the multitudes of horses which furnished the motive power for an age which to us, accustomed to speeding along concrete highways with one eye open for a motor cycle cop, must seem "primitive."

VATICAN CITY, June 28 (AP) -- Pope Pius XII prayed at the tomb of St. Peter tonight on the eve of a radio address to the world in which he was expected to make known his views on the war the Axis is waging against Soviet Russia.

With the question of industrial costs directly involved in steps toward price control, cost accountants are now facing a variety of new problems. Of outstanding importance among them is the question of "excess" labor costs and overhead under conditions of increased production.

IT is a toss-up as to who does the most worrying, the week-end hostess or the week-end guest. The hostess is usually taut with anxious hospitality; the guest, on the other hand, may be very grateful to be there at all, but he feels as uneasy as a strange dog in a new home.

PARK COMMISSIONER ROBERT MOSES has again demonstrated his grasp of the fine art of How to Lose Friends and Influence People. Where to put New York's collection of fish is the cause of the current fracas. Mr. Moses wants a new Aquarium and wants it in one place; the extremely vocal opposition wants it in another.

LONDON, Sunday, June 28 -- Risking the consequences of attacking the strongly defended cities of Northwest Germany in the clear night skies, the Royal Air Force before dawn yesterday heavily bombed Bremen, Wilhelmshaven and Emden and half a dozen other places along the coasts of the Netherlands and France.

WHEN Sir Thomas Beecham gave his lecture on Mozart last month at Town Hall there were two things he hotly denied about his favorite composer. The first was that he was in any way artificial and the second was that he was written out at the time of his death.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 28 -- With a fleet of more than forty craft entered, the Riverside Yacht Club's eleventh annual race out around Stratford Shoal lighthouse, the mound out in Long Island Sound between Bridgeport and Port Jefferson, L.I., was started tonight.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 28 -- With almost the entire continent of Europe leveled before its military might and a chunk of Africa under its control, the German Reich finds itself in the paradoxical position of having to race against time in order to have any chance of winning this World War.

Wall Street in general and government securities dealers in particular are indulging in speculation over the proposed issuance by the Treasury of tax-anticipation securities which would be sold to taxpayers, presumably to individuals as well as corporations, to be turned in on tax days in lieu of cash.

MOSCOW, June 28 (UP) -- S.A. Lozovsky, Vice Commissar of Foreign Affairs, told newspaper correspondents today that the Soviet Government had realized that frequent frontier violations by the Luftwaffe indicated aggressive intentions by Germany and had protested to Berlin on April 18.

TRIP: Before last November's election Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens said that he would move to Canada if President Roosevelt were re-elected. Last week Mr. Harvey boarded a plane for Toronto. "I am now paying my debt," he declared.

Since the House Ways and Means Committee voted unanimously two weeks ago to stop issuing daily accounts of their deliberations on the forthcoming tax bill, no announcement has been made of the results of their further studies of the proposal to compel married couples to file joint returns.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 28 (UP) -- The German-Rumanian High Command announced tonight that Russian parachute troops had been dropped in Rumania and said that the majority of them had been captured.

THE principal contract bridge tournament of the year, always held at Asbury Park, N.J., the first week in August, will begin on Monday, Aug. 4, and last through Sunday, Aug. 10. Play will take place at the convention hall on the Boardwalk, as it has for the last fourteen years with only one exception.
THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity in the week ended June 21 advanced to 131.4. It stood at 130.7 (revised) the week before, and at 109.2 in the week ended June 22, 1940.
CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- The Pirates' inner defense approached two major league records for activity today, but cracked on two critical plays that allowed the Cubs a 3-to-2 victory.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Major General Johnson Hagood, retired veteran of the Coast Artillery, asserted today that the bomber had outmoded the railway gun and advocated that the War Department abandon the latter.

IT was on May 22, 1919, that Jesse L. Lasky was first seized by "the big inspiration" and when even his secretaries broke forth with spontaneous applause he knew it was good. He was standing, he remembers as one remembers any historic occasion, at a ninth-story window of the Famous Players - Lasky - Paramount offices across from the Public Library.

The Japanese beetles are here again, with the peak of the feeding period two weeks or more hence, and after that a very gradual diminution going on into September and possibly October. Home remedies remain about the same as in previous years.

DETROIT -- Aside from the probability that a decision on further car output curtailment will be delayed until after Aug. 1, a widely discussed subject in the automotive industry currently is the history-making Ford contract with the UAW-C.I.O. and its many potential effects on the industry's sales and production set-up.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., June 28 -- A resolution supporting the national defense program but urging "care and caution" in expenditures for other public improvements at this time and calling for restrictions on defense housing was adopted today by the Heal Estate Association of the State of New York at the closing session of its annual convention.

History will record the ironic fact that of the three most famous -- or infamous -- dictators of our time, two, who were utterly devoid of moral scruples, and prided themselves upon their cold-blooded Machiavellism, brought about their own undoing, possibly at the expense of the third, by failure to remember or apply one of the shrewdest maxims of Machiavelli himself.

GLENS FALLS -- Nestling in the IT foothills of the Adirondacks, midway between New York City and Montreal, this combined industrial and resort city, the hub of New York State's northeastern vacationlands, has arranged an extensive schedule of Summer activities.
BOSTON, June 28 -- No evidence has appeared in New England that the people have altered in the slightest degree their attitude toward the war as a result of the German onslaught on Russia.

The first revision of the Baltimore Catechism of the Roman Catholic Church was published yesterday, according to an announcement by the Episcopal Committee of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine. Most of the answers of the old catechism, which has been widely used in parochial schools, have been simplified and modernized in terminology and treatment of subject matter.

These surreys are mode by a system of highly selective samplings in each of the forty-eight States in proportion to voting populations; thereby, the American Institute of Public Opinion holds, is obtained a result which would not vary from that of a much larger canvass.

THE Pasadena (Calif.) Community Playhouse is having a "Festival" of George S. Kaufman plays, and once again Mr. K. is speaking a note about collaboration. In a letter printed in the festival's program, he observes:

TRAINING dogs to be good companions, welcome socially, is the main purpose of a movement spreading through the United States and Canada. This new phase of schooling is designed to make the canine race more acceptable as household pets and more agreeable to the public when they walk abroad, besides giving them a show-ring presence.

Morris U. Schappes, suspended as a tutor in English at City College for Communist proseletyzing, was convicted in General Sessions Court yesterday afternoon on four counts of perjury in the first degree for having testified falsely before the Rapp-Coudert legislative committee investigating subversive activities in the public schools.

Columbia University is conducting an Institute of Horticulture to be held at the Hamilton Arboretum and Gardens at Nevis. Irvingtonon-Hudson, from July 10 to 21 inclusive. Meetings of the institute will be held from 2 to 4 P.M. daily. Registration fee for all sessions is $10; for individual sessions $1.50.

IT is announced by the National Gallery of Art that twenty-two paintings by French nineteenth-century artists, from the Chester Dale Collection, New York, have arrived at the gallery and will be installed during the Summer and placed on exhibition early in the Autumn.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Development of a secret radio beam device for spotting enemy bombers long before they can reach American shores was revealed today by the War Department.
Three new merchant vessels of more than 28,000 gross tons were added yesterday to the fast-growing American merchant marine.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 28 (AP) -- Government observers, including representatives of the Army and Navy, agreed today at ceremonies which opened the 12th annual national soaring contest that motorless planes had a "vital place" in America's aviation training program.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has given $100,000 toward the $10,765,000 fund the United Service Organizations for National Defense is raising to finance 360 recreational clubhouses near Army and Navy bases for service men.
CLEVELAND, June 28 -- Two home runs from the bat of Don Kolloway plunged the Indians back into second place in the American League today behind the Yankees.

With $66,000 for horsemen to shoot at during the first three days of its meeting that opens on Thursday, officials of the Empire City race track are looking forward with confidence to a successful twenty-one-day session. Seven stakes, headed by the $25,000 added Butler Handicap, will be run during the Yonkers meeting, which ends July 26.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Shine O'Night, a 4-year-old filly bred in the hills of Tennessee, galloped to victory for the second consecutive year today in the $7,500 added Matron Handicap at Arlington Park before a crowd of 25,000.
MOSCOW, June 28 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau today issued this communique:

RADIO studios are a beehive of new activity. Performers come and go endlessly -- tap dancers, variety specialists, personable and photogenic musicians. "It looks as if the old vaudeville era is being born all over again," the head of one of Broadway's oldest talent agencies said the other day.

RETAIL trade improved on its recent gains in the week as the national holiday drew closer with its usual vacation preparations. The schools let out and apparently business expanded in all divisions. After a short lull, houseware buying resumed on a larger scale again.
LAKE PLACID -- The Independence Day week-end and the forty-fifth annual convention and tournament of the Northern New York Firemen's Association have jammed the calendar here with exciting events.
The Maritime Commission is planning to embark on a new phase of ship construction involving craft of a type entirely different from any ordered previously in its standard and emergency programs.

IN Lower New York Bay, about a quarter-mile off the south shore of Staten Island, tiny, wind-swept Hoffman Island is of much interest to seamen these days. On it the United States Maritime Commission is training new seamen and improving the fitness of experienced seamen for life in a merchant marine that is straining to meet the needs of a war-torn world.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Possibility of a coal shortage next Winter was foreseen today by the Bituminous Coal Administration.
BERLIN, June 28 -- The German High Command said today that "tremendous successes" in the invasion of Russia would be revealed tomorrow in a series of special announcements.

Calling attention to the higher wages being paid to thousands of workers throughout the country, John H. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board says that the future security and prosperity of the nation will be materially enhanced if a large proportion of these wage-earned funds is invested in well-built small homes.

MAYO, Yukon Territory -- An oil road is sought by this port of the Northland as a means of opening up a new channel of trade and commerce. Such a road has been proposed by Vilhjalmur Stefansson, Arctic explorer, to connect Mayo and Fort Norman, North West Territories.
