TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a recent editorial in THE TIMES, "The Two Japans," Japan was portrayed in two categories: "The Japan of the business men, professional men, workers and farmers," on one hand, and on the other, the Japan of "warlike statesmen, generals and admirals."

THE pretty, auburn-haired young soprano was negotiating some difficult passages when this interrogator finally rang the bell. There was no mistaking that the voice of enthralling lyric qualities belonged to Francia White of radio repute heard Monday nights over WEAF'S network.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- Independence Day, which traditionally marks the formal opening of the Summer season here, will have an added significance this year. The recently organized defense councils and local chapters of relief, and war enter prises have their work well under way in the major resorts at this end of Long Island, and community activities are planned by various Legion posts throughout Suffolk County for the celebration of the Fourth.

WRITING would provide the most pleasant existence imaginable, Alice Duer Miller said, if it weren't for the recurrent fear that you had had your last good idea. "The fear that you are through, that you have used up everything you had to say, and never will find anything new."

Indications that Federal price control may ultimately extend to retail mark-ups were seen last week as the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply widened its activities. This has been feared in retail quarters, but it was asserted that if such control does extend to mark-ups it will not be because of retail transgressions but because of short-sightedness in other business quarters.

FROM a height of five miles England took on the proportions of a village to John Llewelyn Rhys, who had been flying since 1934, in the Royal Air Force since 1935, and had come to feel he knew every inch of her.

THE Cincinnati Summer Opera Association opens its twentieth anniversary season tonight in Cincinnati, with Verdi's "Il Trovatore." The cast includes Rose Bampton, Elsa Zebranska, Giovanni Martinelli, Robert Weede and Virgil Lazzari.

DAYTON, Ohio, June 28 -- A civilian test-pilot's vertical dive at a record 661 miles an hour in an Army ship over Wright Field was disclosed today as evidence of the importance of the test-pilot in the task of developing America's efficiency in the air.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 28 -- Los Tamaraos, with a substitute riding in the post of the injured Earle Hopping, made a handicap and a last early start carry it through to its first victory in the Meadow Brook Club polo championship on Cochran Field today.

STORROWTON, Mass. -- Visitors to New England this Summer will find the latchstring out each day at the little white entrance gate leads to the colonial village of Storrowton on the grounds of the Eastern States Exposition at West Springfield, Mass.

WITH the entrance of women into the world of commerce and industry it was natural for the Cinderella theme in fiction to take a new slant. The climb from rags to riches now followed the pattern made by men; the office girl became a bank executive, the salesgirl a department head.

The Society of Tammany, or Columbia Order, will celebrate the 155th anniversary of the founding of the society and the 165th anniversary of American independence Wednesday evening, July 2, with patriotic ceremonies at the Great Wigwam in Union Square.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The American Army, now deployed over this country, and going in increasing numbers to outlying bases in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, has passed the 1,400,000 mark in its development into the greatest peacetime aggregation of armed forces ever supported by the United States.

More than 1,000 leaders in civilian defense activities, including ranking New York City police officers, police heads of cities and towns along the Atlantic seaboard and the 194 recently appointed air-raid zone wardens, have been invited to attend the first of a series of five lectures on civilian air-raid precautions at 4 P.M. tomorrow in the gymnasium in Police Headquarters.

THE AMERICAN BUILDER, a new freighter of the United States Lines, is tentatively scheduled to begin its maiden voyage late in July and the Seamen's Church Institute of New York will provide a cachet for covers. The proceeds will go to benefit torpedoed and shipwrecked crews of merchant vessels.

NEWPORT, R.I. -- Newport is getting ready to have a real old-fashioned Fourth of July celebration this week. This applies not only to the city proper but to all of the military stations hereabouts, where Independence Day has particular significance in this stage of the national emergency.
Cracks in plaster ceilings of new homes may be traced to one or several faults, according to FHA officials.

BALTIMORE, June 28 (AP) -- Newark swept a three-game series by defeating the Baltimore Orioles, 11 to 7, today. The Bears touched off an attack good for twenty base hits, Majeski leading the van with a homer, double and two singles. Newark garnered fifty hits in the three games.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Finland's efforts to stave off Soviet demands in the period before the Russo-German war began, and to preserve her independence, were set forth in a statement issued by the Finnish Legation here tonight.

J. Gilbert Hall, veteran tennis star of East Orange, N.J., moved into the second round as play in the Eastern States men's clay court tennis championship started at the Jackson Heights Tennis club yesterday. The 42-year-old Hall was the only seeded player to see action and he came through at the expense of Calvin Friedman, New York University freshman, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5.

"Famous American Flyers" has a wider scope, for this latest volume is a collection of biographical sketches which present the lives and personalities of outstanding airmen, beginning with the Wright brothers and ending with Douglas Corrigan.

Streit and his followers now face in the growing danger of the present world crisis.

BOLTON LANDING -- With the townspeople taking part in the church scene in "Our Town," the first of the plays to be presented by Frank C. Davidson's professional stock company will open on Tuesday evening in the Bolton Landing Central School.

An enlarged slate of judges, led by Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of Katonah, N.Y., has been named to make the awards at the Great Barrington, Mass., all-breed exhibition on Aug. 31, according to an announcement by D.A. Tassone, president of the Great Barrington Kennel Club.

AT intervals in the fashion cycle, or independently at certain moments in their lives, women turn to wearing black. Not the drab swathings of mourning, not the discreet black of conservatism, but a blazing, staccato negation of color that makes them stand out like exclamation marks in the crowd.

Contracts awarded during the first five months of this year for all types of construction in Northern New Jersey aggregated $63,448,000 in estimated costs, according to Dodge reports. This is a rise of $24,000,000 over last year's period.

Leon Henderson's announcement that his office would establish ceilings on cottonseed oil and six types of cotton goods at levels below those prevailing on Friday brought yesterday a wild day in the commodity markets, but stocks were not affected.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Reservations for the Independence Day week-end are heavy at all Pocono resorts. High-lights of the holiday program will be flag-raising ceremonies by the children at several places, notably Buck Hill Falls, Pocono Manor and Skytop, and a variety of sports contests.

The new twenty-one-story apartment building known as the Berkeley House at 120 Central Park South, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, will receive its first tenants in August, according to Irving Broff, president of Berkeley House, Inc.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: This is a plea for help to the English language. A dock is not a place for a Governor to sit while he watches a waterfront fire. It is not a place on which to deposit goods that are to be shipped to England. And it is not a place on which Germans would waste bombs.

LONDON (By Wireless). FOR their tigerish fighting and reckless bravery in combat the Poles flying in the Royal Air Force are becoming the legendary heroes of this war. Wherever airmen gather conversation is likely to shift around to some new exploits of a Polish flier. Invariably the story relates to a feat of flying skill or courage or vicious fighting and it is heard with relish.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Documentary evidence showing that Bookniga Corporation sold 12,000 copies of the Soviet Constitution in substantial booklet form at only a small fraction of one cent a copy was introduced this morning during the fifteenth day of the trial of the corporation and its three officers on charges of failing to register with the Secretary of State as propaganda agents of a foreign principal.

Retail trade continued active last week in the New York area. Department store gales were estimated at around 20 per cent above a year ago, with individual increases running up to 40 per cent on some days of the week. Sales of home furnishings departments, including refrigerators, washers, etc., showed particularly heavy gains, while ready-to-wear sales made smaller increases.

COMPARATIVELY few New Yorkers are familiar with Jamaica Bay. the large body of water nearly hemmed in by South Brooklyn and South Queens and the Rockaway Peninsula. Those who do know it think of a little-used sea arm which, for all its potentialities, is proscribed for fishing, boating and swimming -- a complete loss, so far as recreation is concerned.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on June 21 amounted to 259,142,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented a decrease of 1,322,000 barrels in the week, comprising a decrease of 1,350,000 barrels in domestic stocks and in increase of 28,000 barrels in foreign stocks.
LONDON. THERE have been no new plays in London during the last fortnight, unless you allow me to count "Cavalry Patrol," which was put on for two performances at Rudolf Steiner Hall.

To the Art Editor: MR. JEWELL'S article of Sunday, June 22, presented a very stimulating idea and it is inviting to follow him in prophesying as to the form Modernism in art will take in its next evolutionary cycle.

LONDON, June 28 (UP) -- British military experts said tonight that Russia may be able to twist Adolf Hitler's Slitzkrieg plans awry, provided that Red troops can stand off the pounding of Panzer forces toward Minsk.

Although unanimity of opinion developed last week at a series of conferences between oil executives and government officials in Washington with respect to a joint undertaking by the oil industry to build tankers to relieve the expected shortage of petroleum products on the Atlantic seaboard, a decided division existed as to the wisdom of constructing a pipe-line to move refined oil products from the Texas area to the New York-Philadelphia region.

The twenty-two-story building at the northwest corner of West End Avenue and Seventy-second Street will again be placed on the auction block shortly with an upset price of $250,000 as a result of an authorization received last week from the Board of Estimate, the Real Estate Board of New York pointed out yesterday.

OTHER events in the local art world last week were over-shadowed by the official announcement of changes which have been going on in the galleries of paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The changes reflect the ferment in museums during the last few years and emphasize the new-day methods of displaying art to the best advantage, with the interest of the public placed foremost.

Mendelssohn: Capriccio Brillant. Johanna Graudan, pianist, and the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Dimitri Mitropoulos. (Columbia, two twelve-inch records, $2.50.) Mme. Graudan is a Latvian pianist who is now living in Minneapolis, where her husband, Nikolai Graudan, is the first 'cellist in the orchestra.

HARTFORD, Conn. FROM the ridges one sees factory smoke on the New England skyline. Arms factories, factories straining every metal thew and sinew for defense of that America which lives beside this winding road. For this skyline is no distant, unwavering horizon: it advances and retreats as one, follows the macadam to the hilltops and back once more into the valleys.

Price advances at the Summer furniture market here last week, although important to the manufacturer and to Leon Henderson of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, seemed relatively unimportant to the buyer, who, as a rule, had been instructed to get orders on the books without too much regard for price.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Germany's military and diplomatic Blitzkrieg victories have at last opened the eyes of the world. Only now, awakening from eight years of stupor, the world has come to realize that German National Socialism is actually commanding the most powerful military organization.

The Nelson A. Rockefeller Committee, its proposed $600,000 advertising campaign in 350 Latin-American newspapers withdrawn at the insistence of the State Department, yesterday was seeking some new approach to the problem of spreading good-will among the publishers that would meet with the approval of official Washington.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- Joe DiMaggio's hitting streak in consecutive games soared today to within one contest of the modern record, established in 1922 by George Sisler. The Yankee record for home runs in successive games was improved and, to top it all, the McCarthymen downed the Athletics, 7 to 4, at Shibe Park in a game that raised the temperatures of 13,604 already sweltering fans.

FORT SLOCUM, N.Y., June 28 -- Alfred Zangrillo, 23 years old, who fought unwillingly for Mussolini in the Spanish Civil War, is a newly enlisted soldier in the United States Army and hopes to defend the American way of life as a pilot in the Army Air Corps, it was disclosed here today.

A serious menace is presented in the proposed Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Seaway and power project to New York's position as America's greatest port, declares Loring M. Hewen, vice president in charge of commercial properties of Wm. A. White Sons.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 28 -- The Loan Council yesterday rejected the Commonwealth Government's proposal that the States vacate the income-tax field for the duration of the war in favor of the Commonwealth and accept L30,000,000 (Australian) in compensation.

JERSEY CITY, June 28 (AP) -- The Jersey Giants swept their three-game series with the Syracuse Chiefs by winning the final contest, 6 to 1, today. It was the ninth consecutive time the Little Giants had defeated their International League rivals.

THE Ravinia Festival, which was launched last night with a program given by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, under Frederick Stock, continues tonight with another concert directed by the same leader. Sir Thomas Beecham takes the podium for two weeks, beginning Tuesday night.

TO WASHINGTON: When the Luftwaffe smashed Belgrade last April there began an adventurous odyssey for the British Minister to the Yugoslav capital, Ronald Ian Campbell. The envoy trailed the Yugoslav Government from place to place in the country's interior until capitulation after twelve days of Blitzkrieg.
BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., June 28 -- Builders in New York State are anticipating the issuance of orders from Federal authorities shortly which may seriously affect the private construction industry.
BERLIN, June 28 (UP) -- German sources reported tonight that Russia's armies had been thrown back on a long front and forced into a disintegrating retreat from which there could be no recovery.

THE Ravinia Festival, which was launched last night with a program given by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, under Frederick Stock, continues tonight with another concert directed by the same leader. Sir Thomas Beecham takes the podium for two weeks, beginning Tuesday night.

The envoy trailed the Yugoslav Government from place to place in the country's interior until capitulation after twelve days of Blitzkrieg.

EUGENE GOOSSENS, conductor of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, begins a week's engagement at the Lewisohn Stadium tomorrow night For the program, which marks his debut at the Stadium, Mr. Goossens will have Mischa Elman as so loist in the Tchaikovsky violin concerto.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va. -- The figurehead of the American bark Belle of Oregon, for many years displayed on the grounds of Webb Institute of Naval Architecture in New York City, has found a new home in the Mariners' Museum here.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am in urgent need of prompt advice on a matter which if prolonged bids fair to bring on nervous prostration.

Veronica Mimosa, 15-year-old pianist of this city, made an excellent impression as soloist in the Saint-Saens concerto in G minor at last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Alexander Smallens, at the Lewisohn Stadium.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am in urgent need of prompt advice on a matter which if prolonged bids fair to bring on nervous prostration.

Veronica Mimosa, 15-year-old pianist of this city, made an excellent impression as soloist in the Saint-Saens concerto in G minor at last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Alexander Smallens, at the Lewisohn Stadium.

LONDON, June 28 -- When the British turned on their radio sets early last Sunday and heard the announcement that Germany had finally turned eastward and was attacking Russia they were incredulous; then they became jubilant.

FORT DIX, N.J., June 28 -- Creation of a provisional anti-tank battalion for the Forty-fourth Division was announced today by Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell, commanding general, at the same time that a low bid of $208,934 was received for constructing housing facilities for the new unit.

A freak electrical storm that zigzagged through the metropolitan area yesterday killed a woman, critically injured a man and threw traffic in parts of Long Island, New Jersey and Rockland County into confusion. The storm, however, brought little relief from the sweltering temperatures of the last four days.
The names, addresses and occupations of the persons arrested in the spy round-up as given by J. Edgar Hoover, head of the FBI, follow:

John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, announced yesterday that the board would begin negotiations this afternoon with the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, on adjustment of wages, hours and working conditions of city transit employes represented by the union.

Twenty-five persons operating a rowboat, the two-way radio in La Guardia Field's control tower, a station wagon, a Pan American Airways launch, a small tractor generally used to haul planes, and a police radio car were stumped for almost an hour yesterday as they attempted to catch a runaway who apparently feared her first airplane trip.

Six Broadway theatres will present new films this week. Wednesday night the Warners' "Sergeant York," a biographical drama about the Tennessee World War hero, Sergeant Alvin York, will have its world premiere at the Astor Theatre, an event which the Sergeant himself will attend.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mayor La Guardia, in his address the other day as Federal Director of Civilian Defense, has informed us in very broad outline of the job ahead. While there are many details to be worked out, I suggest that consideration be given to the utilization of existing defense machinery in laying the groundwork for the civilian defense program.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- A sharp rise in traffic fatalities prompted a warning to American automobilists today to exert extra caution during the mass motor migration of the long Independence Day week-end.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 29 -- Two games were completed in the Meadow Brook Club polo tournament before rain interrupted the third at the close of the second period today. Stewart Iglehart's Great Neck team was going extremely well and had piled up six goals on Texas when the rain came.

CLEVELAND, June 29 (AP) -- The White Sok sent up thirteen batters to score eight runs in the sixth inning today to give Ted Lyons the 240th victory of his major league career and whip the Indians, 9 to 3. Ken Keltner hit his thirteenth homer in the Tribe's fourth inning.
The cards, it seems, were stacked against the Phillies from the beginning at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

It is good news that the Park Department expects the long-forbidden Jamaica Bay to be cleaned up and ready for recreational use some time in 1943. Because of its polluted waters, Jamaica Bay necessarily has been taboo for swimming, fishing and other recreational pursuits.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 29 -- Poor eyesight is one of America's major problems, and the rapid tempo of the defense program will aggravate the condition, Dr. John E. Corbett of Boston, president of the American Optometric Association, said here today.
VICHY, France, June 29 (AP) -- The French communique on operations in Syria said:

The Medical and Surgical Relief Committee of America, 420 Lexington Avenue, through its executive chairman, Mrs. Rogers Balcom, announced yesterday that $10,000 in medical supplies had been shipped to the Administrative Committee of the Free Norwegians in Iceland.
MOSCOW, Monday, June 30 -- The Soviet Information Bureau, in a communique issued today, emphatically disputed the German High Command's anouncement of gigantic Russian losses in men and equipment.
CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- The Pirates swept a double-header with the Cubs, 8 to 2 and 3 to 2, before 17,440 today and took fifth place in the National League from the Chicagoans.

TOKYO, June 29 -- Japan is extremely anxious to maintain friendly relations with the United States and the imperial government "sees no reason why the two countries cannot remain friendly," Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye said today in an interview.

It is interesting to speculate on the effect of the German invasion on the Russian people. It should be remembered that the armies smashing across the country are the first foreign visitors to come en masse to the Soviet Union since the revolution. During all these years Russia has been peculiarly and incredibly isolated from the rest of the world.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The sudden break-up of the German-Russian alliance, with the shifting position it involves for Japan, China, England and the United States, emphasizes once again the lack of any solid foundation on which we can build a long-time policy in the Far East.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), June 29 -- The securities markets of the small Continental European countries last week, except in Stockholm, displayed, on balance, a moderately firm trend with sometimes comparatively good selective demand, though on the whole trading was quiet.

This is no hour for apology for the Christian message because there has never been a time when more evidence has been piled up that Jesus was right, the Rev. Dr. Halford E. Luccock of the Yale Divinity School, New Haven, Conn., declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Broadway at Fifty-sixth Street.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 29 -- Ausralian pilots defeated the Vichy French in combat between American planes over Tadmur, Syria, yesterday, it was claimed today.

An appeal to Christians everywhere to join forces with God in the completion of His creative work was made yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John M. Pearson in his sermon at the Metropolitan-Duane Methodist Church, Seventh Avenue and Thirteenth Street.

The official "line" of the Communist party of the United States changed once again last night and the popular front policy of the days before Germany signed a non-aggression pact with Russia was taken out of the discard and restored under the name of "a united and people's front" against "Hitler fascism."

NEWARK, June 29 (AP) -- The league-leading Newark Bears stretched their latest winning streak to six straight while handing the Syracuse Chiefs their ninth and tenth consecutive setbacks, 8-3 and 6-1, in an International League double-header today.

Last Monday morning financial markets had to adjust themselves to Sunday's sudden and largely unexpected declaration of war by Germany on Russia. Politically and in a military way there was much perplexity. That the persistent Nazi breaking of faith and falsehood to international pledges had once more been exhibited to the world was evident enough, but of proof for that there was no need.
MOSCOW, June 29 (AP) -- The Russian Information Bureau issued the following communique today:
NEW YORK Dr. Alexander Loudon, the Netherlands Minister, has arrived from Washington and is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, June 29 (UP) -- Fragmentary reports indicated tonight that the German-Russian battle along the border of White Russia had achieved unprecedented fury and that mechanized units on both sides were gambling heavily in bold and hazardous manoeuvres.
BERLIN, June 29 (AP) -- The following communiques were issued today by the German High Command:

Warning that all individuals and groups must be prepared to submit to closer governmental restrictions on economic life, the Guaranty Trust Company, in the current issue of the Guaranty Survey, declares that considerations of present sacrifice and subsequent reaction must be dismissed for the duration of the emergency.

MOSCOW, June 29 Acting Patriarch Sergei, Primate of the All-Russian Orthodox Church and Metropolitan of Moscow, said tonight that the church had decided to forget the past and enlist its entire resources on behalf of the nation's war effort.

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, announced yesterday that the New York Committee to Aid Britain by Reciprocal Trade, of which he is honorary chairman, had been informed by British authorities that Britain was discontinuing the export of foodstuffs to the United States.

National advertisers have apparently regained their courage as far as the general economic outlook is concerned and are now beginning to make longer advertising commitments, according to agency executives. Whereas in the early part of this year few advertisers seemed willing to plan more than a month or two ahead, now some of them are making contracts for three, six and even eight months in advance, it was said.

IT turns out that Don Vernon Gomez, the lighthearted Lefty of the Yankees, has been playing Pagliaccio all these years. Laugh, clown, laugh! With a breaking heart. How come? It's a piteous story. The sad secret lying behind the light laughter of Don Vernon Gomez is herewith exposed to view.
Reynal Hitchcock report that the invasion of Russia has aroused unexpected interest in "Mein Kampf," causing a depletion of stock. The twentieth printing of 25,000 copies is now on the press.

After twenty-six years of service to widowed mothers and their children, the Board of Child Welfare will end its independent existence today. Tomorrow the functions of the board, the 800 members of its staff and the 24,000 families on its rolls will be taken over by the Department of Welfare, which now administers all other forms of city relief.

ROME, June 29 -- Pope Pius XII threw a cold shower today over all Axis hopes that he would come out in support of an "anti-bolshevist crusade." In a world-wide broadcast he made a long and important discourse on the ways of Providence without giving a single word of encouragement to the selfstyled crusaders.

CHUNGKING, China, June 29 (UP) -- The counselor of the British Embassy and three other British nationals, including a woman, were injured today when fifty-four Japanese bombing planes subjected this provisional Chinese capital to two savage air raids.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, completing a three-year program of modernizing the city's accounting methods, will start tomorrow the use of an elaborate set of machines that will displace the inherited hand bookkeeping practices of "counting house days."

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 29 -- Two persons were killed and eight wounded in a serious clash today between armed Italian Fascists and the enraged populace of Durazno, a small town about sixty miles from here. A regular battle raged in the streets for some time between the Fascists, who used revolvers, and the public, who retaliated with stones and other missiles.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 29 -- Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler gave a luncheon today at Lenny Cottage, their home in First Neck Lane. They will be joined at the week-end by the Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox, chaplain of Columbia University, who will conduct the service at St. Andrews Dune Church on Sunday.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 29 -- For the first time in it's eleven-year history, a Riverside Yacht Club craft won the annual Stratford Shoal race of that organization when John U. White's sloop Babe, which he recently bought, came back over the fifty-mile course today.

The Office of Production Management soon will have accumulated a vast amount of data from members of the steel industry on when, where and how much they can increase their facilities for producing specific products, together with all pertinent facts as to the expansion in output of steel ingot, pig iron, coke and coal and iron ore needed to fit into the specific program.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 29 -- Opposition to American aid to Soviet Russia was declared here today by the Rev. John Tracy Ellis, Professor of History in the Catholic University at Washington, in an address at the University of Virginia.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Serious shortages of qualified workers in aircraft, shipbuilding and machine-shop occupations were reported today by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator. A labor survey just completed showed that in sixteen aircraft, thirteen shipbuilding and twenty-six machine-shop occupations there were insufficient workers registered with State employment offices to meet employers' needs.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., June 29 -- President Roosevelt issued today an Executive order authorizing the induction of 900,000 men in the land forces during the year beginning July 1. This is the maximum number allowed by the Selective Service Act.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- The entrance of Soviet Russia into the European war has made a "gargantuan jest" of the arguments of interventionists that the United States should become involved in the war to preserve democratic principles and ideals, Herbert Hoover declared here tonight in a radio address to the nation.

The Board of Higher Education is to reconsider today the advisability of continuing or discontinuing the Townsend Harris Preparatory School -- the only city institution of its class that gives a four-year academic course in three years, with a staff of teachers of such high quality that they are often appointed to professorial chairs in the City College itself.
There will be 14.8 per cent more freight cars loaded in July, August and September than in the same period last year, according to estimates by the Shippers Advisory Boards.

BERLIN, June 29 -- Exactly one week after the mighty National Socialist armed forces began their "crusade" to eradicate the "bolshevist world enemy" and to free their rear of a potential threat while engaged in a death struggle with the archenemy Britain the German High Command today reported its successes.

The series of special communiques issued yesterday by the German High Command cover the first seven days of Hitler's war on Russia. They reveal a massive advance along the whole Polish-Soviet frontier and through Lithuania against the central sector of the Red armies.

Only one seeded player, the veteran J. Gilbert Hall of East Orange, N.J., went into action in the Eastern clay courts tennis championship at Jackson Heights yesterday. Hall, No. 7 on the list, scored a straight-set victory over Jim McGuire, St. John's University freshman, and joined Leonard Hartman, former Columbia captain, in the third round.

VICHY, France, June 29 -- Discussion continues in the press here concerning the role that gold should play in the new world economy. The thesis most often adopted is that currencies should be absolutely independent of gold and that, instead of being guaranteed by gold, a currency should represent the labor and production of the nation.
Suspension of all units of the American Student Union at Brooklyn College for an indefinite period beginning immediately was announced yesterday by Harry D. Gideonse, president.

The arrest of twenty-six men and three women, twenty-two of them German, on charges of conspiracy to undermine national defense by acting as spies, was announced here last night by J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Pistons From Pots Aluminum plays its many roles in kitchen, power plant and battlefield because it has so many different qualities that make it desirable. It conducts electricity -- hence its use in power lines.
CAIRO, June 29 (AP) -- This communique was issued today by the British Midde East Command:
After fifty years of library work, Dr. Victor Hugo Paltsits will retire today as keeper of manuscripts and chief of the American History Division of the New York Public Library.

LONDON, June 28 -- Thursday's statement by Arthur Greenwood in the House of Commons and the subsequent publication of White Papers regarding the policy on Australian and New Zealand produce surpluses were hailed here as an important step in the solution of the international commodity surplus problem.

ROME, June 29 (UP) -- Italian commentators and the press dwelt today on the prospects that the war with Russia will be a long one because the Soviet Union has spared no effort or expense to construct a "grand, fearful fighting machine."

SOMEWHERE IN NORTHERN IRELAND, June 29 -- Valuable lessons in military strategy have been learned by the British Army staff officers, junior officers and men in the ranks as a result of extensive military exercises covering more than 100 square miles in Northern Ireland.

There used to be a saying about soldiers of the old French Army that they were "100 per cent better than they looked." The same saying might be applied to the present American Army. From casual inspection, the men don't ''look" too well, though as a whole they have smartened up immeasurably since last Fall.

BERLIN, June 29 -- Paradoxically, promulgation of the long overdue decree introducing confiscatory taxation of dividends exceeding 6 per cent resulted in all-round price advances in the German stock markets last week. The stock index soared in the week from 197.42 to 201.33 on June 27 and some shares registered gains of more than 10 points.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Archbishop Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic delegate to the United States, in a sermon today called for reunion of the 160,000,000 Greek and other Eastern Orthodox Christians of the world with the world's 400,000,000 Catholics.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 94.3 to 95.1, thus reaching a new higfi for 1936-41. Most of this rise took place in commodities in the raw materials group, especially those of agricultural variety.

BOSTON, June 29 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio told the convention of the National Education Association today that "Federal control of education, eliminating local self-government, would abandon one of the real safeguards of freedom in the United States."

Plans for the construction of two new plants, employing 2,000 persons, for the manufacture of propulsion equipment for merchant ships, were announced yesterday by Charles B. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Joe DiMaggio scaled new heights today.

NEW ORLEANS, June 29 -- Further evidence of the depletion of loan stocks of cotton, the principal mainstay of the consumer division of the industry, found spot bidders pressing into the futures market here after the middle of the week along with speculators and trade interests.

In his first address since his return from his good-will preaching mission to Great Britain, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell told his congregation yesterday that while he was in the British Isles he delivered thirty addresses and sermons in churches in England and Scotland -- in halls, in air-raid shelters, to workmen in shipyards and to soldiers in their barracks.

CAMP TAMIMENT, Pa., June 29 -- Charles A. Lindbergh was assailed as "the leader of the Fascist youth of the United States" by Dr. Frank Bohn, chairman of the German-American Congress for Democracy, in an address before the conference of the Tamiment Economic and Social Institute here today.

Ignace Jan Paderewski, internationally famous pianist and states- man, died of pneumonia last night in his suite at the Buckingham Hotel, 101 West Fifty-seventh Street, after an illness of four days. He was 80 years old.

WITH July 1 at hand, the customary pause for breath and recapitulation. Of the books I read during the Spring season, these seem to stand out above the rest My Friday-and-Saturday collaborator, Mr. Poore, has already made a report of his own.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A sharp increase in buying has been caused by an expectation, that defense needs will bring about a curtailment of output of many civilian luxury and semi-luxury supplies, the Department of Commerce said today.

LONDON, Monday, June 30 -- The daily British sweep by powerful squadrons of bombers and fighters over Northern France was exceptional yesterday because no German planes were shot down -- for the simple reason, according to the Air Ministry, that none was seen in the air.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Congress will spend a long day tomorrow passing on all remaining appropriation bills before the end of the fiscal year at midnight and then turn its attention to fundamental criticism of the Administration's foreign policy and national defense program.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 (AP) -- The Athletics split with the Red Sox today, winning the second game, 3 to 2, after losing the opener, 13 to 1. The second largest crowd of the Philadelphia season, 28,483, saw the double-header.

The delayed German announcements of "spectacular successes" in the Russian campaign and the dramatic fanfare that accompanied them yesterday -- a fanfare ususual even to the process of Nazi government -- bore unmistakable evidences of ulterior purpose.

PITTSBURGH, June 29 -- Increasingly greater numbers of incoming steel orders last week were carrying preferential ratings and steel consumers with nondefense business were pondering the "pinch" which they soon will face to a much greater degree.
Realty activity in Manhattan over the week-end included purchases of loft buildings by investors.
ROME, June 29 -- The text of Pope Pius XII's radio broadcast today follows:

There are several reasons for gratification in the agreement to which Mayor La Guardia and Philip Murray have come assuring New York that it will not be tied up by a subway strike. The settlement of the question has been arrived at without the sacrifice of certain essential principles on the part of the city.
BERLIN, June 29 -- With the Reich's economic war machine working for months at top speed, the opening of the Eastern campaign had no outward and tangible effect on the Reich's financial situation.
HELSINKI, Finland, June 29 -- Artillery duels shook the Russian-Finnish border for more than 600 miles today as the northern front suddenly blazed into action.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Reduced by doctor's orders to the role of visitor and spectator, I may at least show gratitude. What has happened to me? I am a dyed-in-the-wool old radical, steeped in the tradition of John Bright and Henry George, and I find myself writing in profound admiration of all the six leading articles in today's NEW YORK TIMES -- the organ of the other side!

Persons who will become first voters in November were urged yesterday by the Evening School Division of the Board of Education to obtain their certificates of literacy in July or August and not to wait until the registration period in October.

There has not been a pianist like Paderewski in this period or any other. He will probably be ranked by history as the third in the succession of the supreme masters of his instrument, that succession being Liszt, Rubinstein and Paderewski.

SANDS POINT, L.I., June 29 -- Nearly 400 entries, the largest number ever to take part in an exhibition on the Edgar F. Luckenbach estate, competed in the eighth annual Sands Point horse show for the benefit of the Port Washington Welfare Society today.

BOSTON, June 29 -- Joe Medwick's towering three-run homer off Southpaw Art Johnson that gave the Dodgers and Curt Davis the first game, 5 to 2, was offset by a three-run, first-inning assault on Hugh Casey in the nightcap and an inside-the-park home run by Carvel Rowell in the fifth for a 6-to-2 victory by the Braves today.

Sibelius's Third symphony was the special feature of the concert conducted by Alexander Smallens last night at Lewisohn Stadium. Although this work was composed thirty-four years ago, it had enjoyed but five previous hearings in this city.

VICHY, France, June 29 -- Tonight's communique regarding operations in Syria, while stressing French resistance, indicated that British-de Gaullist pressure had not ceased although yesterday it was described as less marked.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 29. -- Ann Rutherford, who plays Polly Benedict in Metro's Hardy Family pictures, has been borrowed by Universal to replace Miriam Hopkins in "Bad-Lands of Dakota," the latter studio announced. It is understood that Metro lent Miss Rutherford as part payment for Bud Abbott and Lou Costello, whom M.G.M. borrowed June 1 for a projected remake of "Rio Rita."

FARMINGDALE, N.J., June 29 -- Fourteen persons were injured, none seriously so far as is known, and many others of the eighty passengers were severely shaken tonight when a Pennsylvania Railroad train of the Jamesburg-Freehold branch was derailed here.

VICHY, France, June 29 -- For two days this week-end Vichy has been the center of the first troop demonstration of the Labor Serv- ice for Youth, which since the armistice has replaced the old obligatory military training for those who are 20 years old.

LONDON, June 29 -- After a cautious initial reaction to the German invasion of Russia the stock markets have taken a decidedly strong line in estimating the new situation which has arisen from this great extension of the European conflict.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A continued serious lag in the production rate of industries manufacturing critical defense items has prompted a new type of government survey designed to learn why some industries are more efficient than others and to make a pool of ideas to assist the slow ones.
DETROIT, June 29 (AP) -- The Tigers snapped a four-game losing streak by taking the final of a three-game series with the Browns today, 3 to 1, behind the four-hit pitching of Hal Newhouser.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 29 -- Seventy-four yachts sailed in the special regatta of the New Rochelle Yacht Club today off Execution Light, with almost half finishing in a northwest squall.

LONDON, June 29 -- Perhaps one of the strangest repercussions of the German invasion of Russia was the sharp rise last week among the government bonds. Japan's position in the Axis set-up now becomes highly problematical according to the general feeling in City circles.

Recognized as one of the outstanding toy dogs, Mrs. James M. Austin's imported Pekingese Champion Che Le of Matson's Catawba, extended his long chain of major victories yesterday by annexing top honors in the sixth annual Staten Island Kennel Club all-breed exhibition at the Staten Island Elks Club, Oakwood Heights.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Charles B. Henderson, member of the board of directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, has been elected chairman of the corporation to succeed Emil Schram, who has resigned to take the presidency of the New York Stock Exchange.

With the granting of $6,529,816 for the support of educational projects last year, the General Education Board is now winding up its affairs and will close shop within the next few years, Raymond B. Fosdick, president, announced in his annual report made public yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, June 30 -- Russian mechanized forces counter-attacking in the Minsk-Baranovichi sector succeeded yesterday in cutting off advance German motorized columns driving at Slutsk and at Stolbtsy, on the Niemen River, forcing the Germans to withdraw after a fierce encounter between tank divisions, according to reports received here.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -- America's athletes were as hot as the weather today as the fifty-third annual National Senior A.A.U. track and field championships were unfolded before the awed gaze of 25,000 spectators at Franklin Field.

Fritzie Zivic, welterweight champion of the world, went through a three-round workout at his training camp at Greenwood Lake, N.Y., yesterday, while his rival, Al Davis, enjoyed a day of leisure at his headquarters in Summit, N.J. The welterweight king stepped one round apiece with Larry Anzalone, Henry Majcher and Felix Garcia.

The Summer theatre season gets under way in earnest this week. At least eighty playhouses, the largest number so far this year, will be operating along the Atlantic seaboard during the week, according to a survey made yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- The lard market declined $1 a hundredweight yesterday as the result of general selling induced by prospects that a ceiling would be placed on cottonseed oil. The decline, which carried prices off the permissible limit for one day, more than wiped out gains made earlier in the week which had carried prices into the highest ground since 1937.
ST. LOUIS, June 29 (AP) -- The Cardinals smothered the Reds, 14 to 4, in the second game of a twin bill today after the Reds had taken the first, 6 to 2.
LONDON, June 29 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill once again shook up his Cabinet tonight, and this time he sent Lord Beaverbrook to the job of Minister of Supply.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 -- C.I.O. and A.F.L. machinists will return to work tomorrow in eleven bay area shipyards and drydocks where vital warship and merchant marine construction has been crippled since they struck May 10.
VICHY, France, June 29 (AP) -- Indications were growing in Vichy today that Turkey might be asked for aid in some form in the French defense of Syria against the British attack.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Soy bean futures, after having advanced about 16 cents a bushel in less than two weeks and selling at the highest levels in four years, broke the permissible limit of 8 cents a bushel yesterday on the Board of Trade here when scattered longs and holders of cottonseed oil futures became aggressive sellers.

A property on Washington Heights that had been held in one ownership for forty-five years passed to new hands when builders purchased from Blanche M. Nolan a plot of ten lots on the west side of Cabrini Boulevard 450 feet north of West 187th Street.
Frederick Joubert Duquesne, then 52 years old, was arrested in New York in 1932 as a final episode in charges of espionage dating back to an earlier arrest and escape during the World War.

CAMP STEW ART, Ga., June 29 -- New York's 102d Coast Artillery Brigade, having more than 5,000 men. will begin a two-day command-post manoeuvre at this anti-aircraft training center tomorrow, the largest coordinated tactical operation for the three regiments since they were garrisoned here in February.

KILLINGWORTH, Conn., June 29 -- If you are willing to be patient and have a rifle that will enable you to take a chance on some long shots, this is the time to get in some woodchuck shooting, for the majority of the farmers have mowed and raked their fields and | the chucks are easy to find.

At least a week or ten days must elapse before Soviet commercial representatives here will be in a position to start shipments of supplies moving to help Russia repel the Nazi invasion, according to opinions expressed yesterday by sources close to the Amtorg Trading Corporation, buying and selling agency here for the Soviet.
MOSCOW, Monday, June 30 (AP) -- The Russian Information Bureau communique early today follows:

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Bullish sentiment ruled in the wheat pit for most of last week and all deliveries sold at new high levels for the season before the bulge was checked by profit-taking and liquidation induced by reports that a "ceiling" would be placed on cottonseed oil.
BALTIMORE, June 29 (AP) -- With a 30-hit attack leveled at seven hurlers, Jersey City took both ends of today's double-header from Baltimore, 11 to 5 and 11 to 2.

Russia in 1812 One of the things about Napoleon in Russia that Leo Tolstoy could not rationally explain was why the famous and disastrous retreat from Russia ever took place. It is Tolstoy's opinion, set down in "War and Peace," that after the burning of Moscow the French Emperor should have headed not for home but southwestward into the rich and warm Ukraine.

Among the ninety passengers who arrived yesterday aboard the American President liner President Hayes was Dr. John J. Umgeher, formerly of the research staff of the University of Belgrade, who was traveling on a German passport with an American visa and with the permission of the British Government.

Having played to 85,062 persons in its first four days, Thursday through Sunday, "Blossoms in the Dust" will be held over by the Radio City Music Hall for a second week, beginning Thursday. Greer Garson and Walter Pidgeon are starred in the drama, which is based on the life of Mrs. Edna Gladney, founder of the Texas Children's Home and Aid Society in Ft. Worth. . . .

New securities offered to the public here in June aggregated $210,052,000, composed of $194,501,000 in 55 bond issues and $15,551,000 in nine stock offerings. These compare with flotations amounting to $390,494,000 in May, when $281,765,000 represented 51 bond issues and $108,729,000 was for seven stock issues.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, has called for intensification of labor's war against the Communists, declaring that "whatever foreign policy the Administration may follow as a military expedient, there can be no reversal of our unrelenting opposition to Communists within our democracy."

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Congress completed action on all sup- | ply measures for the fiscal year 1941-42 tonight by passing six bills which brought the total appropria- tions to a record $33,310,870,190.63.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Men newly come of age, about 750,000 of them throughout the nation, will register for miltary service tomorrow with the chances increased that they will be called to the colors within the year.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., June 30 Playing alternate strokes from selected drives, Johnny Kinder, Plainfield professional, and Mrs. Charles Whitehead, also of Plainfield, today equaled par 72, to win the New Jersey State pro-women's golf tournament at the Spring Lake Golf and Country Club.

Competitive bidding for new seurities entered the industrial field yesterday when an underwriting syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co., Lazard Freres Co. and F.S. Moseley Co. won the ward of approximately $19,300,000 of new securities of McKesson fc Robbins, Inc., on a weighted average annual interest cost to the company of 3.805 per cent.

Two hundred and fifty persons attended yesterday a funeral service for George Blumenthal, retired banker, philanthropist, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and president emeritus of Mount Sinai Hospital, held privately in his home, 50 East Seventieth Street.

GREENPORT, L.I., June 30 -- A mother and her eight children had an experience similar to being dive-bombed at noon today when a light open biplane, in which a father and son were taking a pleasure trip to Maine, crashed upon their lawn, severely injuring the two occupants.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- American Red Cross nurses as well as United States Marines were on board a ship, en route from New York to Britain, that was torpedoed a few days ago, officials here said today. All were believed to have been rescued.

A departure from the usual opening ceremony was observed by the Modern Industrial Bank yesterday when, it turned over all the facilities of its new midtown branch at 225 West Thirty-fourth Street to the United Service Organizations for the collection of contributions toward the $10,765,000 fund being raised to operate recreational clubhouses for soldiers and sailors.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 30 -- Walter Beckjord of the Greenwich Country Club set a brilliant mark for future players when he won the qualifying medal in the twenty-first annual Westchester junior golf championship with a recordbreaking two-under-par 34, 35 -- 69 over the Century Country Club course today.

Seven men, two of them labor union leaders, were arrested yesterday as racketeers in alleged shakedowns of $2,500,000 in the last five years from independent wholesale milk dealers here and trucking concerns hauling milk to this city from New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Vermont and up-State.

Twelve officers and crew members of the Dutch tanker Pendrecht, which was torpedoed and sunk on June 8 while on her way from Wales to the United States, arrived here yesterday on the American Export liner Excalibur, which rescued them after they had drifted for fourteen days in an open lifeboat.

DURAZNO, Uruguay, June 30 (AP) -- The death of a 17-year-old boy today, the second fatality resulting from a street fight yesterday between anti-totalitarian students and guests at an Italian Red Cross benefit, set off a new series of out-breaks this afternoon.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- Hog prices were marked down 25 to 35 cents in slow dealings today. A top of $10.75 compared with the four year peak at $11 scored last week. Weighty butchers and packing sows showed the full decline. Although sheep arrivals continued small, prices sagged 25 to 50 cents.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 30 -- For the third successive day the Beirut radio station failed today to give its customary broadcast and there was increasing speculation here about the possibility that its transmissions had been cut either as a result of British bombardment or of internal disorders.

New York State's annual "legal list" of securities eligible for purchase by savings banks and trust funds in this State was announced yesterday by William R. White, New York State Superintendent of Banks. Issues of securities aggregating $875,007,402 have been added to the list, while at the same time issues amounting to $1,655,360,800 have been dropped from the list.

Announcement was made yesterday that Mrs. Edward C. Kalbfus, wife of Rear Admiral Kalbfus, president of the Naval War College, would address the wives of the officers at the new class of the college at the art association tomorrow.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 30 -- Finland's new war has put its mark on the country, but undoubtedly in quite another way from the war of defense that ended fifteen months ago. With resolution, but also with some sort of resignation, the Finnish people have again gone to war because this business with Russia has to be ended, and in reality no one had expected that the Moscow peace would be more than a breathing spell.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The nomination of Attorney General Jackson to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court was unanimously approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee today despite a protest by Senator Tydings of Maryland that Mr. Jackson was unfit for the office.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., June 30 -- President Roosevelt issued instructions today that Ignace Jan Paderewski be buried temporarily in Arlington National Cemetery if his family desired for him this honor, accorded only once to a foreigner. Later it was learned that the family had accepted.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 1 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique early today:
BOSTON, June 30 -- Secretary Knox declared tonight that "the time to use our Navy to clear the Atlantic of the German menace is at hand."

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : There is too much noise being made over the need of spending about $80,000,000 for new pipelines to carry crude oil and gasoline from the Southwestern oil fields to the Atlantic seaboard. Some folks say it is necessary, on account of shifting fifty American oil tankers to the British, which, at best, is a temporary condition.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 30 -- The Women's Westchester-Fair-field Golf Association team defeated a Connecticut squad, 11 to 4, in their annual match at the Brooklawn Country Club today. Among the winners for Westchester-Fairfield were Mrs. James Robbins, Miss Margaret Nichols and Mrs. Russell Holman.

The legality of a civil service examination for firemen taken last Saturday by 20,000 applicants was questioned yesterday before the City Council committee, and the committee voted to ask for an immediate opinion from the Corporation Counsel and the Attorney General.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 30 -- Implementation of the "good neighbor" policy by adoption of measures which would establish it on a firm foundation of mutual good-will and economic well-being was urged at today's sessions of the University of Virginia's Institute of Public Affairs.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 30 -- Three of the seven seeded players -- Seymour Greenberg of North-western, who was runner-up last year and is seeded second, Marvin D. Kent of Lehigh and Edward Moylan of Spring Hill, Ala. -- were a round ahead of the field at the conclusion of the first session of play in the Eastern intercollegiate varsity tennis championship today at the Montclair Athletic Club.

FORT DIX, N.J., June 30 -- Formation of the Forty-fourth Division's new anti-tank battalion, authorized Saturday by the War Department, got under way today under the direction of Lieut. Col. John A. Rodgers, newly appointed division anti-tank officer.

Negotiations between the Transport Workers Union and the Board of Transportation over hours, wages and working conditions on the city's unified transit lines began yesterday in an atmosphere described by both sides as "amicable."

Leading all the way, Charles Stern's Mary Schulz captured the $2,500 Ocean Bound Class C Handicap for fillies and mares over a mile and a sixteenth at Aqueduct yesterday. Eddie Arcaro had the bay mare off in front and Mary Schulz went on to win over the muddy track by half a length.

Exporters yesterday tried a variety of ways to cope with new regulations requiring Federal licenses on all business transacted with, nationals of some twenty-nine European countries, including Spain and Portugal. The licensing regulations, which provide heavy fines and prison sentences for violators, have hit trade with Latin America severely as exporters have hesitated to fill orders until certain of the buyers' nationality.

The trustees in reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation announced yesterday that arrangements had been made, subject to approval by the Federal Court and the Securities and Exchange Comismsion, for sale of the concern's interest in the Northeastern Water and Electric Corporation to John H. Ware Jr. for approximately $3,800,000.

While the July 4 holiday will curb wholesale market activities during the next few days, buying for Fall will resume its active pace next week, according to the consensus in merchandising and manufacturing quarters here yesterday.

LONDON, June 30 -- There was a certain amount of indignation here when it was announced today that the British Government had yielded to United States pressure and released the French tanker Sheherazade to proceed from Bermuda to Casablanca with 16,000 tons of oil.

BERLIN, Tuesday, July 1 (AP) -- The Nazi air force showered tons of bombs on hundreds of miles of struggling Russians retreating with all their machines on the Baltic front, and German and Rumanian troops reported making deep thrusts into the Ukraine, where they found deserted devastation, the official German news agency said early today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Enhanced plans for the rapid development of Alaskan defenses were confirmed in military quarters today as Secretary Knox announced that the new naval air station at Dutch Harbor, Aleutian Islands, would be commissioned Sept. 1.

BERLIN, June 30 -- Advancing eastward past both sides of the two Russian armies allegedly trapped in the Bialystok sector, rapidly moving German tank and motorized divisions were reported today to have caught another sizable contingent of Russian troops in a new pocket between Minsk and Smolensk, about three-fifths of the distance between the German border and the Russian capital of Moscow.

With rapidly changing conditions vitiating the value of old business indicators, one market research authority suggested yesterday that a group of technicians get together to establish a new, quick and accurate yardstick for the measurement of marKets.

Paul Block, newspaper publisher, who died on June 22, last, left his widow, Mrs. Dina W. Block of Greenwich, Conn., an outright bequest of $100,000, and a life interest in one-third of his residuary estate. The will was filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Officials of North American Aviation, Inc., Inglewood, Calif., whose plant has been under Army control since June 9 because of an unauthorized strike of U.A.W.-C.I.O. workers, have replied to the Mediation Board's recommendation on the union shop issue, but board officials, finding the reply not clear, have asked the company to revise it within twenty-four hours.

VICHY, France, June 30 -- While recognizing the seriousness of the German thrust toward Minsk, well-informed French circles hinted tonight that in the present phase of hostilities in Russia no objective observer would dare to speak of decisive developments.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 30 -- Painting truck bodies white and modification of the color scheme of automobiles were advocated today by Dr. Edwin H. Silver of Washington as a means of cutting down night accidents.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 30 -- Plans are going forward rapidly for the fourteenth annual dog show of the Southampton Kennel Club, to be held Saturday on the grounds of the new Southampton Elks club-house in aid of the Hampton chapter of the American Red Cross.

G.H. Walker Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that Thatcher M. Brown Jr., son of Thatcher M. Brown of Brown Brothers Harriman Co., will become a partner of that firm today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The release by British, naval authorities of the French tanker Sheherazade, which they captured at the end of May, is an initial step in the enforcement of a plan, long contemplated here, for sending supplies to North Africa.
Mrs. Charles S. Whitman of 455 East Fifty-seventh Street, and her daughter, Miss Louise Taft Grosvenor, will depart tomorrow for Mexico City, to be gone until September.

Ring in the New! When Emil Schram sounds the gong at the opening of trading on the New York Stock Exchange this morning, his first, official act as president of the Exchange, it will mark the beginning of a new forward-looking era in the history of the institution, it is hoped fervently by members.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 1 (AP) -- The Russians have fallen back to a new battle line in the Lwow sector because of a flanking threat from Hungary, but the Red Army is tenaciously resisting fierce attacks elsewhere, it was announced today.

IF it doesn't rain, this will be a big day along the historic Harlem River. On one side, two ball games for the price of one admission. And what ball games! The Yankees vs. the rich Red Sox. Joe DiMaggio and his hitting streak against Ted Williams, the high man of the big league batting order. Theodore Francis Williams, by the latest returns, is hitting a nonchalant 404 and enjoying it no little.
The names of three naturalized Germans were added yesterday to the list of twenty-six men and three women arrested by Federal agents over the week-end in a nation-wide spy hunt.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (U.P.) -- Senator Wheeler of Montana asked today for an investigation of printed reports that United States naval vessels had been "shooting or destroying" German naval craft.

Thirty-five hundred members of the Brotherhood of Scientific Instrument Makers of America, employed at four plants of the Sperry Gyroscope Company in Brooklyn making bombsights and other defense material, voted last night at a stormy meeting in Livingston Hall, 301 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, to rescind their strike vote, which would have been effective this morning, and to accept a compromise proposal from the company.
MOSCOW, June 30 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

HELSINKI, Finland, June 30 (U.P.) -- A mighty battle for Hangoe Peninsula and adjacent islands raged all day today and into the night, with heavy gunfire audible in Helsinki, seventy-five miles distant.

When Poland again is free, the body of Ignace Jan Paderewski, first pianist of the world, first Premier of the Republic of Poland, who died here late Sunday night at the age of 80, will be returned to Warsaw for burial. The heart will remain in his "second country," the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Twelve Senators and Representatives responded today to a call by Senator Smith or South Carolina to all who oppose "piecemeal and disastrous price fixing," and adopted unanimously a resolution asking Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, to cease performing the duties assigned to him in an executive order until Congress acts on the subject.
VICHY, France, June 30 (AP) -- The French, High Command issued today this communique on the fighting in the Levant:

In the largest declarations for the month since 1937, dividends voted in June aggregated $306,103,478 for 1,597 companies, including $49,245,174 for 358 banks and insurance institutions. The total compared with $521,381,031 for 1,156 corporations in the preceding month, of which $4,011,701 represented sixty-five bante and insurance companies.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Arguments by counsel for both prosecution and defense occupied the sixteenth day of the trial of the Bookniga Corporation and three of its officers for failure to register as alien propaganda agents.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- While liquidation caused a sharp decline in soy beans and lard at the opening of business today on the Board of Trade here, influenced by the break in cottonseed oil, the grain markets developed independent strength and at no time was there any material pressure on grains.

In line with developments pertaining to the break-up of the Northern group of properties in the Commonwealth, and Southern Corporation system in compliance with the "death sentence" provisions of the Holding Company Act, it was learned yesterday that Justin R. Whiting, president of the $1,000,000,000 holding company, had been elected president of the Consumers Power Company, main operating unit of the system and by far the largest single Northern property.
MOSCOW, June 30 (U.P.) -- The war will last as long as is necessary for Russia to destroy the might of Adolf Hitler, Vice Foreign Commissar S.A. Lozovsky said today.

Archduke Otto of Habsburg, and his brother, Archduke Felix, were guests of honor at a tea given yesterday in the Roof of the Pierre for the Austrian Unit, composed of former citizens of Austria-Hungary, which is now serving under the direction of Archduke Robert with the British forces in England.

OSTERVILLE, Mass., June 30 (AP) -- Paul Runyan, twice P.G.A. champion from White Plains, N.Y., topped the Massachusetts open golf field at the halfway mark of the seventy-two-hole competition by posting a pair of two-under-par 70s today at Oyster Harbors.

As the heat wave swung through its fifth day yesterday it gained in strength, while the populace wilted under the steam that was generated by a 90-degree temperature and plenty of humidity. The metropolitan area did not suffer alone, however, for the heat wave extended as far west as the Dakotas.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Administration's plant seizure bill was opposed today by Merwin K. Hart, president of the New York State Economic Council, on the ground that it would be used to help Soviet Russia. If it was to be passed he advocated that it carry an amendment preventing aid to Russia.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Senate completed action on pending appropriation bills and the bill extending the Commodity Credit Corporation and adjourned at 10:44 P. M., until noon Thursday. Received were the Johnson-Kilgore bill for consolidation of Army and Navy Departments and OPM into a Department of National Defense and the Wheeler resolution for an investigation of reports of firing on German ships.
Mr. and Mrs. Alan H. Beggs of Montclair and their children leave today for a stay on a Wyoming ranch.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Responding to a continued strong demand from the defense and consumers' goods industries, the daily average shipment index of the Department of Commerce rose 7 points to 179 for May, it was re-, ported today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended June 25 aggregated $9,997,000,000. Total debits during the thirteen weeks ended June 25 amounted to $131,357,000,000, or 19 per cent above the total reported for the corresponding period a year ago.
BALTIMORE, June 30 (AP) -- The Jersey City Giants took their third straight game from Baltimore tonight, 14 to 7, pounding four Oriole hurlers for 16 hits.

With the creation of the Public Health Institute the city embarks on a research enterprise which is unique in American municipal history and which promises much. Though it cannot be said that our city health authorities have ignored medical research, they have certainly never attempted to study disease and the methods of handling it as they are studied by the Rockefeller Institute, the great medical schools or some of the government bureaus.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts sold yesterday to a group of banks an issue of $3,500,000 of notes at 0.125 per cent, plus a premium of $17.50. The successful group was composed of the Bankers Trust Company of New York; Merchants National Bank; Boston Safe Deposit and Trust Company; National Shawmut Bank and the Day Trust Company.

Herbert P. Whitlock, who is retiring today at the age of 73 as curator of the Department of Geology and Mineralogy of the American Museum of Natural History, believes that a museum, although a storehouse for the preservation of the tradition and culture of kingdoms, symbolizes the practices of democracy.
The United States Army today is at a crossroads of development.

THERE was history as well as cigarette smoke in the air at a party in a downtown apartment one afternoon last week. I don't know how many of the guests there realized it. Most of the time every one milled around as at any ordinary Summer afternoon affair, laughing and talking, shaking hands with acquaintances, complaining how hot it was and keeping an eye cocked for the waitress with the tray of lemonade.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Representatives of six organizations have requested President Roosevelt to extend to the armed forces the recent Executive Order banning racial discrimination in defense industries.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Gross revenue from, nation-wide air express in April, 1941, increased 41.81 per cent over April, 1940, the Air Express Division of Railway Express Agency reported today. Shipments for the month totaled 108,697, an increase of 33 per cent over the corresponding month of last year.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 25: Increases of $33,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans and $174,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and decreases of $188,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and $95,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

CHUNGKING, China, June 30 -- "China's fate and destiny are inextricably linked to the fate of the countries fighting aggression," Dr. Quo Tai-chi, new Foreign Minister, said today in a statement to foreign correspondents. He spoke after he had been sworn in to his new position.

Dedicated to the hope that jurisprudence in the future will become as "streamlined" as the buildings themselves and that the structures will prove to be too large for actual needs in the years to come, the new $19,300,000 Criminal Courts Building and New York County Jail were formally opened yesterday afternoon at ceremonies in the main lobby of the courthouse, 100 Centre Street.
BOSTON, June 30 -- Governors Lehman of New York, van Wagoner of Michigan and Dixon of Alabama called on the Governors' Conference today to join in common action for defense.

Bound for Tokyo, where he said he would confer with Japanese Government officials before returning to his post in London early next Fall, Mamoru Shigemitsu, Japanese Ambassador to Great Britain, arrived here yesterday afternoon aboard the Atlantic Clipper.

Cotton mill men, selling agents and their customers yesterday were reconciled to the necessity of operating under ceiling orders from the office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply despite efforts of a group of Senators led by "Cotton Ed" Smith to halt Leon Henderson's program of price control.
LONDON, June 30 (AP) -- The Air and Home Security Ministries issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The House Committee on Military Affairs is more independent of New Deal controls than most of the Congressional groups, and this quality is traceable in part to its chairman, Mr. May of Kentucky. An immediate and valuable consequence was the critical analysis of the defense program which the committee, by a vote of 16 to 9 (it has 28 members in all, of which 17 are Democrats), issued last Saturday.

MOSCOW, June 30 (U.P.) -- All day yesterday, a war communique said today, German and Finnish forces hammered at the Soviet border on the Karelian Isthmus, scene of the decisive battles in the Russian-Finnish war, "but Invariably they were forced to withdraw with great losses owing to the fire and counter-attacks of our troops."

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- The White Sox knocked Schoolboy Rows out of the box in the ninth inning today and scored two runs to beat the Tigers, 7 to 6. Detroit had taken the lead with a run in the first half of the ninth.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., June 30 -- President Roosevelt dedicated today the $350,000 library which bears his name with a declaration of faith in the future of free America.

With the market for pivotal issues dormant, the share list ended yesterday the lightest trading volume for a June since 1920 and the smallest first six months in twenty-seven years. What little activity the session produced was centered on the lower-priced stocks, and after drifting narrowly throughout the business period, final quotations were irregularly lower.

CINCINNATI, June 30 (AP) -- The Reds pounded veteran Charlie Root from the box with five hits tonight to score five runs in the first inning and start Elmer Riddle to a 7-to-1 victory over the Cubs before 24,536 spectators. It was Riddle's eighth triumph of an unbeaten season.

Brenda Diana Duff Frazier, heiress and "glamour girl," was married to John Simms (Shipwreck) Kelly, insurance broker and former University of Kentucky football player, in the apartment of her mother, Mrs. Frederic N. Watriss, in Carlton House, 22 East Forty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon.

Johannes Kaiv. Estonian representative who had already declared the taking over of his country by Soviet Russia to be without legal grounds, stated last night that he would also refuse to recognize any German-dominated rule set up in Estonia.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Spring sowing in the Soviet Union seems to be from two to three weeks behind that of last year, which also was late, the Agricultural Department reported today. The delay is attributed largely to unfavorable weather.

The propeller division of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation dedicated yesterday its fourth factory, a newly acquired manufacturing plant of 400,000 square feet located at Indianapolis, Ind., in the presence of Governor Henry F. Schricker of Indiana, Mayor Reginald H. Sullivan of Indianapolis and various business and civic leaders.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 1 -- The Japanese Government's search, for a policy toward the Russo-German war was believed approaching a climax today as a result of new conferences by political and military leaders.

The Society of Restaurateurs, which announced recently that increased prices were inevitable because of rising costs of labor and foodstuffs, is canvassing patrons at tables in a survey to ascertain what solution the public has to offer.

A silversmith, a stationary fireman, a Spanish teacher, an elevator operator, a credit man and a sheet-metal worker joined with full-time workers in the radio industry yesterday in the first group examination for technicians to man the new radiolocators now being used in Britain to spot enemy planes.
When the National League squad checks into Detroit next Tuesday to battle the American Leaguers in the ninth annual All-Star game four players will be getting a new thrill.

VICHY, France, June 30 -- The breaking of diplomatic relations by France with Soviet Russia today was accompanied by a general round-up of Russians of all categories in both zones of France. All persons with Soviet or Nansen passports, whether Soviet citizens or White Russians, were held for questioning.

The cruise itinerary of the American Yacht Club of Rye was announced yesterday by Edward L. Richards, race chairman. This cruise, lengthened by the American Club because the New York Yacht Club is not to hold its squadron runs in August, will have six racing days.

The strike of building trades workers, which began in Queens about a week ago, continued to spread yesterday throughout the city. It was estimated that 30,000 A.F.L. building trades craftsmen, supported by teamsters, who have refused to move materials, were idle.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Treasury closed the books today on one of its biggest money years, thanks to the defense program, but tomorrow will start a new fiscal year slated to pale anything in the fiscal history of the nation.

Nervousness and irregularity characterized trading in cotton futures yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, with the market apparently endeavoring to adjust itself as the result of the heavy liquidation on Saturday. After recovering from early declines of 8 to 22 points, the list strengthened to register gains ranging from 6 to 12 points, but a reaction in the late afternoon left prices at net recessions of 3 to 10 points on the day.

The grief of official Washington at the death of Ignace Jan Paderewski was expressed yesterday by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State during the illness of Secretary Cordell Hull, who said he spoke for the President in expressing deep sorrow at the death of the great pianist and Polish patriot.
