LONDON, June 30 -- Treasury returns for the first quarter of the fiscal year, issued tonight, showed a net increase in total ordinary revenue of u130,988,538. The revenue for the first three months this year was u319,157,988, against u188,169,450 in the same period last year.

TRENTON, N. J., June 30 -- Admonished earlier in the day by the party's new State Chairman, H. Alexander Smith of Princeton, to "get down to brass tacks," the Republican majority in the Legislature forced passage of a bill setting up a new three-member milk control board which would be expected to name Senator Arthur Foran of Hunterdon County as administrator at $10,000 a year.
LACKAWANNA, N.Y., June 30 (AP) -- Six city officials, including the Mayor, were convicted today of conspiracy to defraud the city by padding WPA payrolls.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman approved yesterday stipulations filed with him withdrawing applications for appointment of a receiver for the interest of Clarence K. Reynolds in the brokerage firm of Granberry Co. and drawing Mr. Reynolds's objections to appointment of a receiver for other property held by him in this State.

The swift and tremendous sweep of the German armies into Russia ought to jar out of their complacency those Americans who have been cultivating for a week the pleasant theory that Hitler's turn to the east is taking the war a long way away from the United States.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month increased moderately over May, but sales of 10,450,563 shares, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, were the dullest for any June in twenty-one years, or since 1920. It was also the smallest six months' business in twenty-seven years, or since 1915, with sales amounting to 63,666,952 shares.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 30 -- Details of fighting on the eastern front, particularly in the region around Minsk, at the end of the first week of hostilities continued today to be confusing and in some instances contradictory.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.

BOSTON, Mass., June 30 -- A suggested attitude for Americans toward the Nazi-Soviet war was presented tonight to the convention of the National Education Association by Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University. Asserting that communism never had been the same kind of danger to the United States as nazism had become since the fall of France, Dr. Conant added:

David M. Wood of Thomson, Wood Hoffman was elected president of the Municipal Bond Club of New York yesterday at the annual meeting of the club held at the Bankers Club. Mr. Wood succeeds Delmont K. Pfeffer of the National City Bank.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Tentative agreements were reached today by the ways and Means Committee on a large number of excise duties to be written into the defense tax measure, calling for $3,500,000,000.

The outlines of civilian defense in time of war were defined in detail yesterday by Mayor La Guardia to the zone leaders of the city's air raid warden force, to police and city officials, religious leaders and heads of the protective forces of many cities along the Atlantic Coast.
For a change, Joe Louis and Billy Conn will sit back tonight and see how the other fellow does it.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 1 -- Yesterday, for the first time, Royal Air Force bombers made two blistering attacks in daylight on Germany, pounding Bremen and Kiel and other coastal bases and industrial centers of the Reich. The raids followed up long bombing attacks before dawn on Bremen and Hamburg.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 30 -- Warners today signed Monty Woolley to repeat his stage role, that of Sheridan Whiteside, in the screen version of "The Man Who Came to Dinner," with Bette Davis. Woolley will come to the Coast about Aug. 1, and the picture is scheduled to start a week after his arrival, with William Keighley directing.

"For fresh, green-and-yellow vegetable salads," reads the label on a lovely lemon-colored jar of dressing -- describing that invigorating Summer luncheon we begin to think of about 11:30 these torrid mornings. "Also for fruits," it continues -- naming the primary rival to our first vision.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday designated Mrs. Frances Lehrich, secretary of the Board of Estimate, to become the second woman member of the Magistrates' Court and gave her a full ten-year term at $10,000 a year.
BERLIN, June 30 (AP) -- Today's communique of the German High Command follows:
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 28:

Nearly a hundred of America's greatest writers will be represented in "The Democratic Spirit," a collection of American writings from Colonial times to the present day. It will be released by Knopf in the Fall. The 1,000-page volume will be edited by Bernard Smith.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Carl Anderson, editor and publisher of The Nebraska Monitor, a weekly newspaper at Litchfield, Neb., leaped to his death today from, the eighth floor of a Loop building shortly after he had undergone a four-four lie-detector test in connection with the suspected murder of his wife, Mrs. Evelyn O'Brien Anderson.

Rather than compete with the week-end weather at this time of the year the two Sunday performances of "Hellzapoppin" will be dropped during July and August. Therefore next week's schedule will be as follows: Evening shows from Monday through Saturday night; matinees on Wednesday and Saturday.

WHOLESALE COMMODITY PRICES U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (August, 1939=100) Im-Domes- Food-IndusIndex, port. tic. Farm.stuffs.trial. 1941. (28) (11) (17) (7) (12) (16) June 23. .148.2 152.0 145.8 147.8 157.7*141.4 June 24. *148.1*152.2 145.5 146.8 157.5*141.2

Thirty-six officers and crew members of two freighters that were torpedoed by German submarines without warning early in June off Cape Race, Nfld., arrived here yesterday morning by train from Norfolk, Va., where they were landed last Tuesday night by the Finnish freighter Hammarland.

ST. LOUIS, June 30 (AP) -- The last place Browns exploded right in Bobby Feller's face in the seventh inning today, the American League's ace pitcher was soon in the showers and St. Louis beat the Indians, 12 to 6. The defeat dropped Cleveland to a point two games behind the first place Yankees.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 30 -- Jack Sabol, Westchester Hills pro, and Neil White, last year's Southern amateur champion, now of the Gedney Country Club, won the pro-amateur event of the one-day tourney at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club today with a record best-ball card of 31, 31 -- 62.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The War Department awarded contracts today for airplanes, parts and equipment totaling $530,208,023.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 30 -- Add to the list of the combinations that have gained fame by winning the Father and Son Golf Association championship during the twenty-five years the event has been going on the names of J.R. Lowell and James R. Lowell Jr., members of the Piping Rock Club on Long Island.

Following a hot, humid week-end, trading in most classes of dressed meats yesterday was slow. A few miscellaneous cuts were fairly active However, Veal hindsaddies and most fresh pork cuts were higher. Other classes of traefer meats were weak to lower. Early kosher business was slow. Kosher beef and lamb opened weak, veal about steady.

A total of thirty-eight apartments were leased in the Fifth. Avenue Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Ninth Street, during the fourweek period from June 1 to 28. Thirteen were taken by new tenants and the remainder were renewals.

With defending champion Frankie Parker's first appearance deferred until today, Frank Kovacs, the nation's third ranking player, got a head start on his rival as he made his debut in the Eastern Clay Courts championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : I read with great interest your editorial "Honeymoon Price-Fixing." You stressed a number of good points although I cannot agree with your generalizing statement that "the OPACS has been attempting to control prices by asking for voluntary reduction in profits."

Ignace Jan Paderewski was a great internationalist who was also, literally, Polish to his fingertips. He was a magnificent pianist, ranking with Liszt and Rubinstein, as Mr. Olin Downes wrote yesterday in this newspaper, "in the succession of the supreme masters of his instrument."

A continuation of the recent imarked interest in Manhattan loft properties was shown yesterday by the purchase of two such buildings in the downtown produce market area by an operator. Other late deals involved properties in Brookilyn and Westchester.
The Hoboken Bank for Savings has sold the five-story building containing two stores and six apartments at 131, Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., to the Washington Development Company.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : May I add to Jefferson C. Bell's recent story in THE TIMES, headed "Supports Strike in Government Job -- New York City Education Official Asserts Worker Becomes Impotent If Losing Right."

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The volume of trading in cottonseed oil and lard in the 1941 fiscal year was at the highest level in records in the possession of the Commodity Exchange Administration, the Department of Agriculture made known today.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 30 (AP) -- California entries had the field virtually to themselves tonight and easily swept the three national A.A.U. relay championships in a twilight meet run in a steady downpour at the Asbury Park High School stadium.

BOSTON, June 30 -- A ball game that could and should have been wrapped up in the first inning went to the Giants in the twelfth today. A fluke double by Johnny Rucker finally broke up a scoreless pitching duel between Cliff Melton and Manny Salvo, and the Braves went down to a 3-0 defeat.

With a strike of 23,000 dairy farmers due to start this morning, the large milk distributors of New York City were agreed yesterday that there was little or nothing they could do to mitigate any milk shortage, but they differed as to the seriousness of the situation.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 30 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

BALDWIN, L.I., June 30 -- E.V. Smaje and George Ramsden of Oceanside made up the victorious combination today in the Long Island P.G.A. amateur-pro best-ball competition, at the Milburn Country Club. The second pair to tee off this morning, Smaje and his professional partner toured the 6,441-yard course, open to the public for the first time this season, in a sparkling 64, seven strokes under par.

By a unanimous vote, the Board of Higher Education last night dismissed John Kenneth Ackley, suspended registrar of City College who had been found guilty by a trial committee of conduct unbecoming a member of the college staff.

For the tenth time in their ten meetings, the Dodgers esterday beat the Phillies, 9 -- 2, but for the second time this year in a game between the teams a Brooklyn player had to be carried from the field on a stretcher because of a "bean ball."

The week-end brought several surprises to the big-game anglers, for the first giant bluefin tuna was taken in Ipswich Bay, Mass., and the first white marlin of the season was boated off Ocean City, Md.
PITTSBURGH, June 30 (AP) -- Maurice Van Robays's triple, scoring two mates in the third inning, proved the deciding blow in the Pirates' 4-to-3 triumph over the Cardinals tonight.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 1 -- The Moscow radio said today that full authority of the State had been vested in a defense committee with Joseph Stalin as chairman and Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff assistant chairman.

AMSTERDAM via Berlin, June 30 -- In a highly irregular market, A.K.U. met an increased demand and rose 5 1/4 to 14 1/8. Phillips was 6 3/4 higher at 213 3/4, but Dutch Indian securities were depressed. Amsterdam Trading was 9 lower at 406, Amsterdam Rubber 2 1\2 at 259, and Royal Dutch 1 at 234 1/2.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Sales by wholesalers at $303,634,000 were 32 per cent higher in May than a year ago, according to an announcement today by J.C. Capt, Director of the Census. This 32 per cent gain exceeds all previous year-to-year gains in the last five years.

TRENTON, N.J., July 1 (AP) -- The State Tax Department reported today the combined value of real and personal property in New Jersey for 1941 at $5,337,539,370, a drop of 542,756,933 under last year's $5,380,296,303.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 1 -- While unconfirmed but disquieting reports of new German victories and accelerated pushes of the German war machine into Russia continued to circulate here today, proSoviet sources maintained at least outward calm and spoke of "the coming Winter campaign."

TRENTON, July 1 -- New Jersey had no control over milk prices today for the first time in eight years, with producers, distributors and consumers wondering what the result would be. The Legislature is in recess until July 14 and nothing can be done before then.

At a turbulent meeting of Democratic county committee members of the Eighth Assembly District in the Stuyvesant Casino, 142 Second Avenue, Abraham Rosenthal was declared elected last night as district leader, succeeding the late Representative M. Michael Edelstein.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, and Mayor La Guardia devoted some time yesterday to the problem of producing practical uniforms for women defense workers at moderate cost, and decided that their objective could be reached without difficulty.

A heavy last-minute demand from manufacturers for the promotional labels to be sewn into dresses swamped the offices of the New York Dress Institute at 1,450 Broadway yesterday. All garments coming off the machines, effective as of yesterday, must carry the label as part of the $1,500,000 annual campaign to feature New York as the fashion center of the world.
BERLIN, July 1 (AP) -- The Fuehrer's Headquarters today issued this communique:

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Projects calling for the expenditure of almost 500,000,000 have been proposed for study under the new $150,000,000 Defense Public Works Program. Some of the suggestions may be passed upon within a week, John M. Carmody, Federal Works Administrator, said today.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Deferment of all men of 28 or over from selective service induction became a fact today for at least a short time.

TOOTED STArES The Civil Service Commission announced today that it would fill Important administrative positions In defense and other government agencies through the competitive examination procedure. Among the positions for which registers will be established are:
Torrid heat and stifling humidity oppressed New Yorkers for the sixth consecutive day yesterday, taking three lives before a short downpour brought slight relief in the late afternoon.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On May 3 last Governor Lehman signed a bill appropriating $50,000 for the use of a joint legislative committee which our State Legislature a few days before adjournment had authorized to deal with the subject of reapportionment of State Senate and Assembly districts as well as Congressional districts.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 1 -- The Estonian capital is still in Soviet hands. The Tallinn radio began its broadcast today as usual by playing the "Internationale" and Radio Moscow's war communique'.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 1 -- The British troops encircling Tadmur have thrust toward Beirut and cut all communications with Horms, according to British military sources here. They have now isolated Tadmur with repeated heavy bombings.

Armies by the Sea The idea would be a lost-children index for estimating the size of Coney Island crowds. The visitors at Coney Island last Sunday were a million. The number of small boys and girls who lost contact with parents to whom, they were ultimately restored was fifty-two.

The body of Ignace Jan Paderewski, in a bronze coffin borne by an Army caisson, will be taken to St. Patrick's Cathedral at 3 o'clock this afternoon to lie in state until the funeral mass tomorrow morning.
MOSCOW, July 1 (AP) -- The section of today's communique containing personal commendations and political matters follows:

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 1 -- By unanimous vote the Argentine Senate today approved the inter-American convention calling for temporary administration by the American republics of any European colony or possession in the Americas that might become a center of aggression against this continent.

COLORADO SPRINGS, July 1 (AP) -- Five Stanford University golfers, led by Ray Brownell, gained places in the top rank of scorers today in the first half of the 36hole qualifying test for the fortysecond Western amateur golf tournament.
NEW YORK Admiral Joseph Strauss, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Strauss have arrived at the St. Regis from Washington.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 2 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau said today that numerically superior German-Finnish invaders had been held back in the Murmansk area by fierce-fighting Russians.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 1 -- Several large ships, one about 20,000 tons, were damaged during a series of fierce bombing raids yesterday on Tripoli harbor, it was announced today. The superstructure of one ship blew up after a number of bombs hit the deck, and another was seen in a half sunken condition, it was added.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Morris Liskin, president; Raphael Rush, vice president, and Norman Weinberg, secretary-treasurer of the Bookniga Corporation of New York, were found guilty tonight by a jury in the District of Columbia Federal Court of conspiracy to prevent the corporation from registering with the Department of State as propaganda agents of a foreign government, as required by the McCormack act.

Loyal support of the national defense program and of President Roosevelt's labor policies, coupled with emphatic opposition to any "united front" with the Communists despite the fact that Soviet Russia is now at war with Nazi Germany was voiced at a conference of A.F. of L. and C.I.O. unions at the Hotel Edison last night.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 (AP) -- Twenty-eight skilled workers who, naval spokesmen said, could not be trusted to work around military secrets have been discharged from Mare Island Navy Yard.
As German spearheads drove deeper into Russia yesterday and Nazi troops tightened a ring of fire and steel around encircled Soviet forces the Red Armies apparently faced a major debacle.

Workable plans for simplification of merchandise involving the cooperation of manufacturers, retailers and wholesalers are being framed by the Office of Production Management, the consumer division of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply and tha Department, of Justice, the Retailers' Advisory Committee reported in a bulletin available here yesterday.

The United States has just completed the eleventh full fiscal year of unbalanced Federal budgets. In that period the National Government has taken in a total of $47,000,000,000 and spent over $82,000,000,000, leaving a deficit of more than $35,000,000,000. The national debt has trebled from $16,185,000,000 in June, 1930, to about $48,500,000,000.

VICHY, July 1 -- At a special press conference this morning on the operations in Syria, General Charles Huntziger, Minister of War, declared that, "now that masks have fallen," the struggle appeared in its true light and France would continue to fight with the utmost determination in token of national unity.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Creation of a huge seventeen-State power pool to make available 200,000 kilowatts of needed power in the Southeastern States for aluminum production and other defense purposes was brought near actuality today by a Federal Power Commission order directing immediate construction of seven new interconnections between power plants in six States.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Wheat made a firm start today and a tame finish. There was fair commission house and mill buying early but the latter was by no means aggressive and when cottonseed oil and soy beans started to decline wheat followed, with the downturn accompanied by selling which appeared to be hedging against purchases of cash grain in the Southwest and Northwest.

BERLIN, July 1 -- Although reticent about specific geographical gains won by its attacking forces on the Russian front, the German High Command today claimed continued success in all sectors in spite of the "fanatic" resistance of the Red Army.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 1 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

Returning to this country after the flight in which she became the first woman to ferry a warplane to Britain, Miss Jacqueline Cochran, American flier arrived at La Guardia Airport from Montreal via Canadian Colonial Airways at 4:10 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

FORT DIX, N.J., July 1 -- National Guard officers of the Forty-fourth Division, who in fifteen months have won promotions that require twenty to twenty-five years in the Regular Army, are apprehensive over the War Department's proposal to purge the Army of unfit officers.

LONDON, Wednesday, July 2 (U.P.) -- Morning newspapers were unable to agree whether the exchange of Generals Wavell and Auchinleck was due to a possible German threat to India, or to General Wavell's being "demoted," because he needed a rest.

BOSTON, July 1 -- Mayor La Guardia, national director of Civilian Defense, told the Governors' Conference today that tentative plans called for putting gas masks, at government expense, in the hands of everyone of the 50,000,000 persons living along the Atlantic, Gulf and Pacific coasts of the nation.

Buyers' June Total Up 51% The number of out-of-town buyers reported in the market last week was 1,056, against 1,425 in the preceding week and 615 in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the listings published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

W. Alton Jones, president of the Cities Service Company, announced yesterday that the directors had declared a dividend of $3 a share on the outstanding 6 per cent preferred stock, payable on Aug. 1 to holders of record of July 15.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 1 -- President Roosevelt reiterated today earlier expressions of hope that the United States could keep out of war, but he refrained from expressing confidence that this country would be able to avoid fighting.

The Federal Trade Commission's searching inquiry into advertising allowance practices of retail stores and the Department of Justice move against cooperative advertising by independent grocers indicate that this type of advertising may be in for some difficult times.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The first shipment of essential supplies to French colonies in North Africa, to be sent under agreement arranged by the State Department, was scheduled to leave tonight aboard the French freighter he de Noirmoutier, sailing from New York for Casablanca.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Ways and Means Committee virtually completed its preliminary survey of tax sources today and reported another list of excise taxes as having been tentatively approved. It appeared that the bill would be reported by July 10.

LONDON, Wednesday, July 2 (U.P.) -- One of the biggest air armadas of the war carried out a bold sweep of German-occupied France last evening, virtually without challange from the Luftwaffe, after three daylight bombing invasions of Germany and German-held territory by Royal Air Force squadrons.

WEST POINT, N.Y., July 1 -- An assertion that the United States "is in greater danger than at any period since the war of the Confederacy" was made today by Brig. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger, Superintendent of the United States Military Academy, in addressing some 500 young men who enrolled as the class of '45 today.

Long-distance telephone traffic has stepped up 25 to 35 per cent in the last year, largely in reflection of the increased business tempo resulting from the defense program, officials of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday.

A partial settlement of the strike of 50,000 building trades workers was achieved yesterday as the result of the intervention of Mrs. Ethel S. Epstein, Mayor La Guardia's adviser on labor affairs. Forty thousand strikers will return to work this morning in Manhattan and other boroughs, but the walkout in Queens, which marked the beginning of the city-wide strike movement more than a week ago, will continue.

Eugene Goossens, conductor of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, made his debut as a conductor at the Lewisohn Stadium last night after rain of the late afternoon had threatened for the second time to cause postponement of his appearance with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

T.M. Girdler, chairman, and R.J. Wysor, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, informed stockholders yesterday in a letter accompanying dividend checks that steel ingot capacity available for civilian uses at the end of 1941 will be greater than the industry's production, for all purposes in any previous year.

Of all the roles that Hitler has chosen to play, for the sole purpose of getting what he wants from a credulous world, none is more fantastic than this present role of White Knight leading the civilized people of Europe on a holy crusade against Bolshevism. The stage is being set for this spectacle by diligent Nazi propaganda.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 1 -- Mrs. Eleanor Young, prominent in society here and in New York, and Nicholas S. Embiricos, also of New York, were killed today when their plane crashed in thick fog into the surf at Matunuck Beach.
BALTIMORE, July 1 (AP) -- Jersey City, although, outhit 16 to 14 by the Baltimore Orioles, scored its fourth straight victory tonight, 8 to 6.

Preparations for the observance of Independence Day were in progress yesterday, with the Society of Tammany beating the gun by two days in plans for a celebration tonight at the clubhouse in Union Square.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- "Prices of all kinds have gone up faster in the recent months than ever before in history," Vice President Wallace said today at the dedication of a new capital information center for the national defense savings campaign.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- North American Aviation, Inc., accepted today a "maintenance of membership" clause recommended by the National Defense Mediation Board to end the labor dispute at its Inglewood plant, which led to government seizure of the factory on June 9 to end an unauthorized strike by the C. I. O. United Automobile Workers' Union of America.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Commenting on the report issued Saturday by a subcommittee of the House Military Affairs Committee concerning delinquencies in the defense effort, Representative Faddis of Pennsylvania, the subcommittee's chairman, said that Secretary Ickes was to blame in part for the threatened shortage of aluminum.
With a notable string of victories to his credit in the Middle West, Frank Parker arrived at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club in Queens yesterday for his first appearance of the season in the East.

MADISON, Wis., July 1 -- An indictment accusing six corporations and nine individuals of conspiracy to fix the price of foreign type cheeses in violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law was returned before Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone today.

OSTERVILLE, Mass., July 1 (AP) -- After a terrific struggle over the last nine holes, Harold (Jug) McSpaden of Winchester gained his fourth Massachusetts open golf title since 1936 today by posting a record-breaking 72-hole total of 280 at Oyster Harbors.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board said today that it had requested a special master of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals in New York to find that Remington Rand, Inc., and James H. Rand Jr. were in contempt of court.

The larger milk distributors, the Health Department and the Federal State Milk Marketing Administrator reported yesterday that the city's supply had not been reduced by the strike called by the Dairy Farmers Union among its 23,000 members, but at least one of these spokesmen warned that milk strikes usually gain momentum before "dying out."

As the details of Mayor La Guardia's plans emerge, the complexity of the task of protecting this city in the event of an air raid becomes apparent. Several times the number originally set for air-raid wardens -- namely, 62,000 -- will be needed. In addition, every considerable business plant will be expected to develop and train its own staff of wardens.

VICHY, France, July 1 -- "French volunteers, having manifested their intention of participating in the European struggle against communism," the government today announced that it could raise no objection since international law did not prevent such action and which, moreover, "is not contrary to French unity."

NEWARK, July 1 (AP) -- The Newark Bears extended their winning streak to seven games, their longest of the season, as they downed the Syracuse Chiefs, 5 -- 2 tonight, before a crowd of 3,500. The loss was the eleventh in a row for the Chiefs, who had previously won eleven straight.
LOS ANGELES, July 1 (AP) -- Richie Lemos, Los Angeles Mexican, knocked out Petey Scalzo, New York, in the fifth, round tonight to win the N.B.A. featherweight championship before a crowd of 9,500.
Even the Phillies now and then turn on their tormentors.

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, principal subsidiary of United States Steel Corporation, announced yesterday the acquisition of the tin-plate manufacturing facilities of Standard Tin Plate Company and the coal mining properties of Canonsburg Coal Company, both subsidiaries of the Continental Can Company.

VICHY, France, July 1 -- France's budget figures for 1941, published today, not only give the first perspective on the government expenditures for the whole year 1940, and the first half of 1941, but provide indications never before published on the effects of the war on French national finances.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., July 1 -- Hillsborough Township, where Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell maintains Duke Farm as her domicile, wants $13,834,924 from Mrs. Cromwell for taxes for 1940 and 1941 on intangible assets fixed by the township tax collector at $222,426,438.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Some members of Congress identified with the isolationist group criticized Secretary Knox today for suggesting that the Navy should intervene in the sea war. Their demands ranged from censure of the Secretary of the Navy by the President to impeachment.
DALLAS, Texas, July 1 (U.P.) -- Governor W. Lee O'Daniel has been elected to the United State Senate on the basis of complete unofficial returns of the State Election Bureau.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 1 -- Famine is now settling in all over Greece, according to authentic reports that have reached here, and the refuge Greek Government is understood to have appealed to Britain to create a loophole in the continental blockade to permit limited wheat shipments to her unhappy ally.

A group composed of J. S. Rippel Co., H. L. Alien Co. and Minsch, Monell Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of $461,000 of sewer, street and school bonds of Paterson, N.J., on a bid of 100.52 for 1 1/2s. The bonds, dated May 1, 1941, are to mature on May 1, 1942 to 1954.

After blocking for several years the efforts of the Fusion administration to accomplish reorganization of county offices, the Democratic majority in the City Council introduced yesterday two bills that accomplish the reorganization except for the petention of one city-wide elected Sheriff.

BOSTON, July 1 -- Unlucky Hal Schumacher, who hasn't come up with a victory in exactly a month, was the victim of two misplays by Babe Young as the Braves counted six times in the third inning today and handed the Giants a 6-4 set-back.

Apparently as impervious to heat as to bullets, Sergeant Alvin C. York of Centris County, Tenn., World War hero No. 1, lustily called for convoying yesterday as reporters steamed through an interview with, him in the compartment of the railroad car on which he arrived at Pennsylvania Station.
Without benefit of speeches, John Finley Walk, atop the East River Drive from Eighty-first to Eighty-ninth Street, was dedicated yesterday morning.

June was a quiet month in London During the whole of what is usually England's best month, a month of clear days and short nights, the alarm siren sounded only seven times. There were no air raids at all. Tired Londoners slept in their beds. In the long twilights they walked in the Green Park and rowed in the Serpentine as if life were normal again.

The scheduled ten-round bout at Dexter Park last night between Abe Simon, giant Richmond Hill heavyweight, and Joe O'Gatty of Newark was not held, the reason being that the gloves ordered for Simon were too small. It was announced by the management that tickets purchased for last night's show would be honored at Monday night's card. which will feature Simon and O'Gatty.

The New York City school system, has shown a net loss of 50,000 students in five years, and for the first time since 1927, is scheduled to drop below the 1,000,000 mark next year, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, disclosed yesterday in his annual statistical report.
Macmillan will release "In the Mill," by John Masefield, on August 5. The book is an account of Mr. Masefield's two years' experience in a carpet factory in Yonkers.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 1 -- Declaring that substantial evidence of a "State pardon racket" had been uncovered, the Fulton County (Atlanta) grand jury appealed to the Federal Government today to conduct an investigation into all sources of income of former Governor E. D. Rivers during his 1939-40 term of office.

The English clergy, irrespective of denomination, have become a militant group in behalf of civilians and military alike in the face of the sacrifices of war, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, minister of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, told his associates yesterday.

Quite a steady stream of people is to be seen these days flowing through the doorway of a certain Fifth Avenue shop -- to emerge aljmost immediatedly with small, square, white-and-gold boxes swinging from their fingers by a loop of ribbon.
The Todd Shipyards Corporation posted notices yesterday in its Atlantic Coast yards of pay increases of 8.73 per cent, retroactive to June 23, for all shipyard workers.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) -- Rookie right-hander Phil Marchildon pitched his best game of the season tonight as the Athletics walloped Washington, 10 to 1, before 13,840 at Shibe Park. He limited the Senators to four hits after hurling no-hit ball for 71-3 innings.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Walter J. Cummings of Chicago, national treasurer of the United Service Organizations, announced today that contributions totaling $7,276,000 had been received to provide recreational facilities for men in the nation's armed service.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Secretary of the Navy, Colonel Knox, told the Governors' Conference at Boston last night that the United States should clear the Atlantic with its fleet, which means war with Germany, declared or undeclared. The President at Hyde Park today had no comment except to say he still hopes the nation can keep out of war.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) -- Maurice B. Saul, counsel for the Lehigh Valley Railroad, told a special statutory court today that the railroad "expects" to collect $13,000,000 from the German Government for damages to its Black Tom terminal in Jersey City in the first World War.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 30: COLONELS Cousins, R.P., Air Corps, Boiling Field, D.C., relieved G.S.C., to Hqrs., Army Air Forces, Washington, June 30. Kunzig, L.A., Inf., to command Camp Blanding, Kia.

Ever on the alert to stimulate trade, William Saroyan has hit upon another exploitation idea for "The Beautiful People," which he wrote, directed and produced. Before the attraction opened he gave away free tickets to preview audiences.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Hogs held about steady in another slow market today as 11,000 salable arrivals proved sufficient to meet moderate demand. The top quotation remained unchanged at $10.75 but a few losses of 5 to 10 cents were noted on butchers and sows. During June hogs advanced approximately 13 per cent, the American Meat Institute reported today.

VICHY, France, July 1 (U.P.) -- Plans to mobilize two groups of volunteers were understood to have been in an advanced state when the government announced today that it "will not object" to the sending of French man power into the war against the Soviet Union.
MOSCOW, July 1 (AP) --The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

An underwriting' group of fortyone investment firms headed by Kidder, Peabody Co., Lazard Freres Co. and F. S. Moseley Co. will offer today to the public $13,700,000 of debentures and 56,000" shares of preferred stock of McKesson Robbins, Inc.

Mayor La Guardia revealed yesterday in response to specific questions that there were at presesnt no completed plans either for building bomb-shelters in New York City or for evacuating the civilian population in case of air raids.
ST. LOUIS, July 1 (AP) -- The Indians took a big early lead over the Browns tonight and held it, although, they were threatened late in the game, to win a 10-to-6 decision.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 2 (U.P.) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 1 -- Two programs, each designed to implement the country's defenses, were put tonight before the University of Virginia's Institute of Public Affairs.

Establishment of price ceilings on six types of cotton goods failed to halt the upward price trend in the men's shirt industry, contrary to buyers' expectations, and yesterday one of the leading popular-price houses increased prices 25 to 50 cents a dozen.

The greatest of the present-day ball players drew even with one of the legendary figures of the past yesterday when Joe DiMaggio equaled Wee Willie Keeler's all-time major league record of hitting safely in forty-four consecutive games.

LONDON, July 1-- King George presented colors to two Canadian regiments stationed in Southern England today -- this ceremony, being one of several in Britain marking Dominion Day, was the first time that a sovereign had handed over battle flags to a Canadian regiment in this country.

Gramps, one of the few sons of Equipoise not noted as a stayer, finally sustained his sire yesterday at Aqueduct when he stood a long, bitter drive to hammer out a victory at the end of the mile and a sixteenth of the Diablo Handicap before 9,479 fans, who bet a total of $610,640.

On the strength of a report that the Army, through the OPM's purchasing division, had asked the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply to "lay off" any cotton goods constructions used heavily by the Army, several cotton mills were reported yesterday to be preparing to switch looms from price-controlled numbers to the "Army" constructions.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial on the tax proposals you conclude that because so few people pay a direct tax it is easy for members of Congress to announce that further efforts to reduce nondefense expenditures have been abandoned.

Reflecting uncertainties with regard to price-fixing operations by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, futures quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday fluctuated nervously but trading was comparatively quiet.

TOKYO, July 1 (U.P.) -- The Premier, Prince Fumimaro Konoye, called upon the people of Japan today to "strongly unite" for any eventuality and asserted that Japan should depend on her own power to establish a "Greater East Asia co-prosperity sphere" regardless of what other nations might say.

Commenting on the further decline in June in the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in this district and for the system as a whole, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly review of credit and business conditions, to be distributed today, notes that this downward trend reflected the heavy payments into Treasury deposit accounts in Reserve Banks from Treasury bond sales and income tax collections.

The quotation on the Japanese yen, which has been "pegged" by the Japanese authorities at the New York equivalent of 23.48 cents since Oct. 21, 1940, was advanced unexpectedly yesterday to 23.62 cents. Agencies of Japanese banks here stated that they were not informed in the matter, save for cable messages from Tokyo directing the lifting of the rate.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 1-- Mothers and daughters, most of whom have left the old homestead for homesteads of their own, permitted nothing, not even intense heat, to keep them from their annual golfing get-together today, the mother-and-daughter championship conducted by the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 1 -- rene Dunne will be starred in a domestic comedy, with Gregory LaCava producing and directing, it was announced today by Universal. It will be the second time the two have been teamed. They recently completed "Unfinished Business," with Robert Montgomery as Miss Dunne's co-star.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 1 (AP) -- Eight co-eds from seven schools breezed into the quarter-finals of the first women's national intercollegiate golf tournament today as two of eight opening-round matches produced upsets.

In a setting reminiscent of their desert environment, a collection of 2,000 cactus plants of virtually every Mexican species was presented to New York City yesterday by the Mexican Government. The ceremony began in stifling heat that bore comparison with the atmosphere of any Sahara and ended abruptly when the Weather Man transformed the atmosphere from that of a desert to a tropical down-pour.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Army has twelve pilots officially trained as glider specialists. These officers have just completed special training courses which, were kept secret until completion.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Control Administrator, said today that the cost of living was bound to go up and that new and direct legal powers and penalties would be necessary to combat increasing pressures on the price level.

The report of the International Shoe Company issued for publication today by Frank C. Rand, chairman, and Byron A. Gray, president, reveals a net income for the six months ended on May 31, of $2,750,812, equal to 82 cents each on the 3,350,000 shares of capital stock outstanding.

The rain which, hit the steaming city last night forced postponement of the twelve-round non-title bout between Fritzie Zivic, world welterweight champion, and Al Davis, Brownsville battler, who is also being trained as a fighter in Uncle Sam's Army.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The scope of the coming investigation by the Federal Communications Commission into newspaper ownership of radio stations was defined in an order issued today. Ten main questions will form the basis of the inquiry, which is intended "to determine what statement of policy or rules" should be laid down regarding newspaper acquisition of any high frequency (FM) stations or future standard broadcast stations.

Two railroad equipment-trust issues, aggregating $4,825,000, were awarded officially yesterday, augmenting the supply of that type of security in the market, which was regarded there as already abundant.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 1 -- The first supper dance of the season at the Meadow Club will be held on Saturday. The opening tennis tournament in a series, a mixed doubles handicap tournament, will be held on the club's grass courts Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

BAILEY ISLAND, Me., July 1 -- The bodies of eleven women and two men, two unidentified, and one of them the captain of a cabin cruiser in which a party of thirty-five picnickers set out Sunday were picked up today and tonight and all the others are believed to have been lost in one of Maine's worst sea disasters in fifty years.

Although moved from the woods where they originally had to sleep because no provision had been made for housing them, laundresses working at Camp Blanding, near Jacksonville, Fla., still live in sub-standard quarters, lacking adequate facilities and recreation.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission modified today its order of Aug. 2, 1940, revoking the over-the-counter registration of Walston Co., and suspending Vernon C. Walston and William Sherman Hoelscher from membership in the New York and San Francisco Stock Exchanges for six months.

A contribution of $69,000 to build nonsectarian nursing homes for children in Great Britain was presented to the British War Relief Society last night by the Jewish Section of the Interfaith Committee for Aid to the Democracies at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria honoring Dr. Stephen S. Wise, president of the American Jewish Congress.

Without Fanfare The widespread interest in Emil Schram's taking over his duties as president of the New York Stock Exchange, beleaguered yesterday morning by many photographers and reporters, could have become something of a publicity stunt if the staff of the Exchange had wished.

Two new films will arrive at Broadway houses today: "Sergeant York." Warner's picturization of the life of the Tennessee World War hero and winner of the Congressional Medal of Honor, will have its world premiere tonight at the Astor Theatre before an invited audience including many civil and military personages.
The city's second peacetime registration, for military service counted off yesterday 40,253 young men who have become 21 years old since the draft enrollment of Oct. 16.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 30 (delayed) (AP) -- British overtures to Russia for a new agreement that would establish Russian and British zones of influence in Iran and under which Britain's Northwest Frontier Army eventually would be shifted from India to Iran were reported today in diplomatic circles here.

DETROIT, July 1 -- Plans for the production of aviation engines at a rate never before attained were announced today by two major units of the automobile industry to supplement the projected output of other car makers.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 1 -- Seymour Greenberg, Northwesterr University ace, runner-up for the title last year, and Edward Moylan of Spring Hill (Ala.) College led the field into the varsity singles quarter-finals of the annual Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship tournament today at the Montclair Athletic Club.

Trading was generally slow yesterday In all classes of fresh meats. The market on steer hinds and ribs was about steady at Monday's quotations, hut lamb was down about $1 a hundredweight. Veal hindsatidies and fresh pork cuts were about steady. Kosher steer chucks and plates and veal foresaddles sold at mostly steady prices, but kosher lamb foresaddles were off about $1.

BRIELLE, N.J., July 1 -- Despite a fresh wind and a falling barometer today, the offshore anglers fishing out of New Jersey ports from Water Witch to Beach Haven brought in fair catches of bonita and tuna. However, the surfcasters along the same stretch of coast found their sport rather unexciting.
LONDON, July 1 (AP) -- The Air Ministry said in a communique today:

BERNE, Switzerland, July 1 -- Russian troops fighting a fierce rear-guard action throughout last night and early today gradually fell back to the Berezina River as heavy German motorized forces drove forward along two salientsone northeast and the other southeast of Minsk, capital of White Russia.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,847,250 barrels daily, or 10,350 fewer than the 3,857,600 barrels of the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 17,250 barrels more than the calculation of 3,830,000 daily by the Bureau of Mines for June.
Paperboard production advanced less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index fell to 155.2 from 156.7. It stood at 128.4 for the week ended June 29, 1940.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 1 -- Lacking the urgency and haste which characterized the commissioning of the United States naval operating base earlier this year, the formal establishment of the United States Naval Air Station here; the first to be commissioned among the new Atlantic defense bases, took place this morning on Tucker's Island, one of two islands in the Great Sound which will ultimately form the site of the base.

Morris Mardavich, 23-year-old ex-convict on. trial for murder, admitted from, the witness stand in General Sessions yesterday that he shot and killed Harry Vance Maxwell, advertising company executive, last May 4.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The first Russian request for material aid under President Roosevelt's policy of assistance was announced today by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- A line-up in which a brilliant, youthful pitching staff will be backed up by a crew of distance sluggers will represent the American League in the ninth annual all-star battle with the National Leaguers next Tuesday in Briggs Stadium, Detroit.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 1 -- Gunfire was heard again today in the neighborhood of Helsinki. A few pursuit planes -- Finnish and German -- hurried to the scene of action, but no air-raid alarm has been given here for the last thirtysix hours.

In its second effort to sell in competitive bidding 120,000 shares of its preferred stock, the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation yesterday received two bids from syndicates and awarded the issue to a group headed by the First Boston Corporation and Glore, Forgan Co. on a moneycost basis of 5.057 per cent. The successful tender was 100.85 for shares carrying a dividend of 5 1-10 per cent.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, acting di-

BOSTON, July 1 -- A proposal was presented to the National Education Association today by the executive committee for the establishment of a national commission of sixty educators which would investigate organizations attacking education and teachers accused of subversive activities.

Many Wall Street banks made public yesterday their mid-year statements of condition, showing, in. the aggregate, fairly substanial gains in loans and discounts, reflecting the financing of defense industries and the improvement in business generally.

No deaths were caused directly by the heat in New York City last week but the general death rate was raised virtually two full points, largely, if indirectly, because of the heat wave, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, was informed, yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records in the Health Department.

LONDON, July 1, -- General Sir Archibald Percival Wavell, architect of the British victories over the Italians in Cyrenaica and director of five battles at once, has been replaced by General Sir Claude John Eyre Auchinleck, it was announced at 10 Downing Street today.

CHICAGO, July I (AP) -- Paul Trout pitched a brilliant three-hit game today to give the Tigers a 5-to-l victory over the White Sox and even the series at one game each. It was Trout's sixth triumph, just twice as many as he gained all last year.
PURCHASE, N.Y., July 1 -- Two upsets occurred in the twentyfirst annual Westchester junior golf championship as the first and second rounds were completed on the Century Country Club course today.

PITTSBURGH, July 1 (AP) -- A pair of "Johns" -- Johnny Mize and Johnnny Hopp -- gave the Cardinals a hand today which won undisputed possession of first place in the National League stakes with an 11-7 victory over the Pirates.

The presentation of evidence against the alleged espionage ring broken up by the Federal Bureau of Investigation Sunday began yesterday before the Federal grand jury in Brooklyn. United States Attorney Harold M. Kennedy disclosed that the June term of the grand jury had been extended through July so that it might hear the case.

Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler yesterday upheld Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, in permitting candidates less than 21 years old to file for the Fire Department examination. The City Council investigating committee had challenged the legality of the step.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 (AP) -- Charles A. Lindbergh told an anti-war mass meeting tonight "I would a hundred times rather see my country ally herself with England, or even with Germany with all her faults, than with the cruelty, the Godlessness, and the barbarism that exist in Soviet Russia."

MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 2 (AP) -- Red Army troops supported by a tremendous artillery barrage have checked the German invaders of Russia on the Minsk front and inflicted heavy losses, the Soviet Information Bureau stated today in announcing a series of defense successes against a numerically superior enemy.

Almost 150 executives of investment trusts from all parts of the United States attended a testimonial dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria last night given by the National Committee of Investment Companies for David Schenker, who has retired as director of the investment company division of the Securities and Exchange Commission to engage in the practice of law in this city.

FORT DIX, N.J., July 2 -- Chinese trainees in the Forty-fourth Division were urged today by Dr. Tsune-chi Yu, consul general of the Chinese Republic, to be prepared to defend democracy "anywhere in the world."

The American Peace Mobilization, an organization that picketed Congress in February in opposition to the Lease-Lend Bill and recently picketed the White House for forty days in protest against President's Roosevelt's foreign policies and aid to the democracies, announced yesterday that it now was in favor of aid to the Soviet Union, Great Britain and other nations fighting Nazi Germany.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 2 -- President Roosevelt returned control of the North American Aviation Company plant at Inglewood, Calif., to the owners today. At the same time be warned that if efforts again were made "to interfere with this essential production, I will not hesitate to take whatever steps may hereafter be necessary to assure its continuance."

Voting on a plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific Railroad certified by the Interstate Commerce Commission should be completed by early Fall, a committee for the company's first and refunding 5 per cent bonds, headed by John W. Stedman of the Prudential Insurance Company, announced yesterday.

Bearing aluminum utensils that clanged like the brass cymbals of their ancestors, a group of Chinese Girl Scouts, members of Troop 174, marched into Girl Scout headquarters yesterday and became the first group to respond to the appeal made by Mayor La Guardia to the people to contribute old aluminum ware to the government for defense purposes.
BERLIN, July 2 (AP) -- A special German High Command communique, issued "from the Fuehrer's Headquarters," said today:

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 2 -- Many guests will arrive here tomorrow to spend Independence Day and the week-end at estates throughout the colony. Mr. and Mrs. Ernest C. Wagner and their daughter, Miss Margaret Van Horn Wagner, will have as their guests at Red Top Farm, Mr. and Mrs. George Pettengill 3d and Miss Cecilia Von Rath.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 2 (U.P.) -- The Germans are reported to be increasing the pressure on the Red Army's extreme right wing in an apparent effort to isolate Murmansk and cut off communications with Leningrad.

A kitchen on wheels, the shadow of St. Patrick's Cathedral and a microphone carrying speakers' voices from coast to coast provided the setting yesterday for graduating exercises of the class in mobile kitchen feeding, first of its kind, sponsored by the American Women's Voluntary Services.

If you live on a Western prairie and see a grass fire coming it is a good plan to light a little grass fire of your own before the big one arrives. You may save your house. The Democrats in City Council seem to have heard of this method. The imminent filing of a county reform petition backed by 80,000 signatures led them on Tuesday to light a county reform backfire of their own.

A. Kentish Barnes, chairman of the Royal Insurance Company, Ltd., issued the results of operations for the year 1940 at the ninety-sixth annual general meeting held in the company's head office in Liverpool on June 4.

The two-family residence at 1271 Fiftieth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Commodore Realty Corporation to Nettie Keismand, who paid part of the consideration in cash and gave to the Hamilton Federal Savings and Loan Association of Brooklyn a purchase money mortgage of $8,000.

Because the national barber shop quartet organization banned four New York Negroes, who last Thursday won the city championship, from competing in the country-wide finals at St. Louis beginning today, Park Commissioner Robert Moses and former Governor Alfred E. Smith have resigned as vice presidents.

The eleven-room residence with two baths and a two-car garage at 237 South Grand Avenue, Baldwin, L.I., has been sold by the Home Owners Loan Corporation through Fred'k Fox Co., Inc., to a client for occupancy. The house is on a plot 69.38 by 238.4 feet.

TO the best of deponent's knowledge and belief nobody in organized baseball has called the attention of Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis to an incident of the diamond that fairly shrieks for investigation. Possibly everybody interested in baseball was so wrapped up in following Joe DiMaggio's hitting streak that this other hitting streak -- under cover of darkness and lasting only one night -- didn't receive the suspicious attention it merited.

Although the weather kept attendance to below 1,000, a Stop Hitler First Rally was held at Manhattan Center last night by the Union for Democratic Action, with the cooperation of the Fight for Freedom Committee and the New York Chapter of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies.

BOSTON, Mass., July 2 -- Strong opposition in the National Education Association appeared to be developing late today to the proposal of the executive committee to create "a commission on the defense of democracy through education" and there was a promise of sharp discussion on the floor tomorrow when it comes before the annual meeting of the association at which about 10,000 delegates are registered.

Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, told the City Council committee investigating civil service yesterday that he believed Communists should be permitted to teach in city schools, provided they did not indoctrinate their students with their own political views.
MOSCOW, Thursday, July 3 (AP) -- The communique issued early today included the following:

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 3 -- Premier Joseph Stalin warned his people in a broadcast today that Nazi troops were inside White Russia and the Ukraine, but promised that "Hitler's army will be beaten like those of Napoleon and Kaiser Wilhelm."

The "holdout" of unlicensed seamen of the Robin Line has spread to two other lines, and threatens to extend still further to affect a number of vessels in the Red Sea route and other important American trades, it was disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- Buck Newsom pitched a brilliant three-hit game tonight to give the Tigers a 1-to-0 victory over the White Sox and the rubber game of the three-game series. Detroit made only five hits off Bill Dietrich.
Germany's two-pronged offensive against Leningrad threatens the entire Russian Baltic Fleet with destruction or capture.

A housing project for New Rochelle, to clear nine acres of slums and put 265 Negro families in modern, low-rent apartments, was announced yesterday by Edward Weinfeld, State Housing Commissioner. The cost is put at $1,400,000 for construction, to be lent by the State, in addition to annual subsidies from the State and municipality.

The Yankee Clipper, carrying nine passengers to Lisbon and twenty-seven to Bermuda, left the Pan American Airways marine terminal at La Guardia Field a few minutes after 1 P.M. yesterday, and within two hours the Dixie Clipper, returning from Lisbon with twenty-one transatlantic travelers and fifteen Bermuda passengers, took its place at the dock.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 2 -- Allied aerial and ground reinforcements now arriving in Syria, intensifed British bombing operations, and the change in the British Middle East Command all point to an immediate all-out offensive to smash Vichy's resistance or force an armistice so as to end the Syrian campaign quickly, according to usually well-informed foreign military sources here tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Russia should have little trouble in raising dollars needed to pay for whatever material aid the United States can provide, according to government experts consulted today regarding the statement of Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, that the Soviet Government would pay.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for a health center on West 136th Street, near Fifth Avenue and opposite Harlem Hospital.
PASSAIC, N.J., July 2 (AP) -- Cornelius Warmerdam, the world's greatest pole vaulter, proved again tonight that he doesn't need fancy settings to do his best leaping.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Secretary Knox denied categorically today that naval vessels had been engaged in encounters with German craft while carrying out patrol missions in the Atlantic Ocean.

Criticizing the county reorganization bills introduced Tuesday in the City Council as designed to perpetuate political patronage contrary to the interests of the city in efficiency and economy of administration, the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee met yesterday in the rooms of the Merchants Association and decided to file today its petition for a rererendum on county reform at the November election.

LONDON, July 2 -- Pilots of the American Eagle Squadron, in their first full-fledged attack over German-occupied territory, today shot down three Messerschmitt fighters and severely damaged two others.

Additional statements of condition of banks as of June 30, which came to hand yesterday, were in line with the general trend toward increased earning assets. Few of the statements failed to show increased loans and discounts, as well as larger holdings of United States Government securities.

Despite the efforts of the Defense Contract Service to find defense work for small plants in this city, many concerns with antiquated machinery and dependent on vital materials not forthcoming will be forced out of business, Phillip M. McCullough, district manager of the Division of Priorities, Office of Production Management, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Merchants Association of New York at the Downtown Athletic Club, attended by 250 leading business executives.
PITTSBURGH, July 2 (AP) -- Paul Derringer sustained his tenth defeat today as big Max Butcher hurled Pittsburgh to an 8-to-3 verdict, his third success over the Reds.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Under orders issued today by Major Gen. H.H. Arnold, chief of the Army Air Corps, requirements for pilots to command the Army's four-engined heavy bombers are revised in order to assure sufficient pilots for the expanded air fleet.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The United States welcomes and wholeheartedly supports the proposal made by Uruguay on June 21 for the American republics to adopt a policy of not treating as a belligerent any American country, which, in defense of its own rights, should find itself in a state of war with nations of other continents.

Repeated efforts to evade the draft that culminated in the payment of a $1,000 bribe were attributed in a Federal indictment yesterday to Francis M. O'Connell, his father, James J. O'Connell, Bronx contractor, and Daniel J. Houlihan, an insurance man and former member of a draft board.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2 -- James Cagney's next film at Warners will be "Captains of the Clouds," a story of the Royal Canadian Air Force, in which George Brent and Dennis Morgan will also play leading roles, the studio announced today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Is not the headline on Mr. Crider's dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 28 -- "U.S. Trade is Giving Latin Americans Economic Freedom" -- somewhat over-optimistic? The greater part of United States purchases from Latin America at this time is for government account, for use in the defense program.

LONDON, July 2 -- Reduction of the basic ration of gasoline for private cars by one-sixth, in the next ration period, from August to October, was announced in the House of Commons yesterday by Geoffrey Lloyd, Secretary for Petroleum. The reduction will be brought about by halving the gasoline value of the basic ration for October.

LONDON, July 2 -- Anxiety over the release of the oil tanker Sheherazade by the British Navy in compliance with the desire of the State Department in Washington was expressed in the House of Commons today, and Prime Minister Winston Churchill, who did his best, failed to dispel doubt about the wisdom of this policy or even to define the policy itself.

These sultry days we find our thoughts returning inevitably, with a sort of fatal fascination, to the ice-box, where our fond reflections center about the chilly, beaded containers that await us on the upper shelf. And a very nice thing to find there are small, individual cans of unsweetened grapefruit juice.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 2 (AP) -- On the theory that it isn't Coach Ed Leader's fault that his Yale crews have lost seventeen consecutive races to arch-rival Harvard, the Elis' athletic department tonight announced he would be given one more chance.

The Securities and Exchange Commission will send a questionnaire to member firms of the New York Stock Exchange within the next few days in an effort to establish the income of the firms on the basis of present commission rates, it was learned yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 2 -- As the German forces that arrived yesterday on the Berezina River at Borisov and Bobruisk drove toward each other in an effort to close their pincers isolating Minsk, indications were received here tonight of intensive Russian preparations behind the line of the Berezina for what might well turn out to be the beginning of the "Battle of Russia."

Sixteen men, three of whom were officers or former officers of two teamsters' local unions, were named yesterday by the New York County grand jury in a forty-five-count extortion indictment. They were accused of a conspiracy in which $157,800 was extorted in the last five years from fourteen independent wholesale milk corporation and ten trucking concerns throughout the State.

COLORADO SPRINGS, July 2 (AP) -- Harry Todd of Dallas won the medal in the annual Western amateur golf tournament at Broadmoor today with 71, 70 -- 141. Todd, who annexed the title at Oklahoma City two years ago, was the low amateur in the national open this year at Fort Worth.

Eyelash Victories The razor-edge plurality of 1,095 votes by which a United States Senator from Texas has been elected in a poll of approximately half a million ballots is startlingly close to another American hairbreadth election of far greater importance.

LONDON, July 2 (U.P.) -- For almost the first time an authoritative British source today took a cautiously confident view of the Russo-German war as Red Army chieftains were reported convinced that they can beat the German Blitzkrieg.

BOSTON, July 2 -- Shelving political differences twenty-eight governors at the closing session of their annual conference, today adopted unanimously a resolution pledging full support of President Roosevelt's efforts to preserve free institutions in the world.

The heat wave continued yesterday to affect consumer demand and fresh meats were hard to move. Steer beef was weak to lower. Pork loins Were sharply lower, but hams were higher. Cow beef was exceptionally hard to move and some bids were down a full $1 a hundredweight. Kosher business continued slow and most prices were down.
NEW YORK Mrs. Burke Roche of 1020 Fifth Avenue, formerly of Paris, is at the Mansion House, Poland Springs, Me., to stay through July.

Better buying entered the stock market yesterday, and although trading on the New York Stock Exchange proceeded at a slower pace than on Tuesday, gains of fractions to a point were frequent in the share list at the close. Since the previous sessions, during which a downward spiral had been followed, had revealed no evidence of necessary selling, the reaction upward came more as a technical readjustment.

Price advances averaging 30 to 40 cents a quart on bonded liquor brands are provided in new price lists sent to retailers here yesterday by National Distillers Products Corporation. In letters to package store owners of the rive boroughs and in Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties the company announced that its new fair-trade contracts and price list will go into effect July 14.

The Aircraft Manufacturing School has leased from the Bowery Savings Bank through Gordon S. Braislin, Inc., brokers, the second floor in the building at 235 East Forty-second Street for an aviation trade school to prepare workers for the aircraft industry.

While Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, and the milk distributors said that today's supply of milk would be adequate for this city and others in the metropolitan area, the strike in the New York milkshed made itself felt here last night as the New York Metropolitan Milk Distributors Bargaining Agency found it necessary to allocate 160,000 quarts of milk to eleven small dealers whose own sources had failed them.

ANOTHER report on London under the strain of war, this time Negley Farson's "Bomber's Moon."* Mr. Farson is not consecutive, but he is genuinely encouraging, even though he makes an obvious attempt to tell the truth, pretty or not, so far as the censors will let it be told.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Ways and Means Committee put the finishing touches today on the largest revenue bill in United States history, adding an estimated yield of $3,503,400,000 to present Federal taxation. The committee then sent the bill to the legislative drafting service to be translated into legal phraseology.

LONDON, July 2 (AP) -- The War Office disclosed tonight that the Vice Chief of the Imperial General Staff, Lieut. Gen. Sir Robert Hadden Haining, had been sent to the Middle East on military administrative duty -- another step, presumably, in a far-reaching overhaul of Great Britain's Middle East Command.

Accepting William Saroyan's public offer to return the admission price to those who did not like his play, "The Beautiful People," nine persons received a total of $21 after last night's performance. Mr. Saroyan's stunt went into effect for the first time last evening at the Lyceum Theatre, where his play, which he wrote, directed and produced, is running.

Blyth Co., Inc., and C.F. Childs Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of an issue of $500,000 of highway bonds of the State of Maine on their bid of 100.29 for seven-eighths of 1 per cent obligations. Dated July 1, 1941, the securities will mature on July 1, 1942 to 1951.

Passengers scheduled to depart today for the West Indies, Venezuela and Colombia on the Grace liner Santa Rosa include Miss Natalie Henry, Mr. and Mrs. William Hall, Carlos Salazar, Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Dunn, Miss Cecilia Quijano, Dr. and Mrs. Edward L. Curran, Mrs. Marion F. Eberly, Miss Esther R. Barnes, Miss Kathryn Barnes, Miss Esther Carlson, Mr. and Mrs. John B. Hyde and Dr. and Mrs. Glenn I. Jones.

If you should be walking through Rockefeller Plaza and run across a couple of young sea lions strolling down the street, don't think its the heat, because it probably will be some of the four that were placed in the Prometheus Fountain of the lower Rockefeller Plaza yesterday afternoon.

Replying to criticism that present Army leaders were "too old" for service, Major Gen. Irving J. Phillipson, Commanding Officer of the Second Corps Area, declared yesterday that younger officers would be in command in actual combat.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 2 -- Six players gained quarter-final brackets today in the annual Eastern intercollegiate varsity singles tennis championship at the Montclair Athletic Club.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 2 -- Joseph Riordan and Charles McGale were sentenced today by County Judge Frank H. Coyne of Westchester to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison during the week of Aug. 10 for their part in the murder of a guard during their escape April 14 from Sing Sing, where they were serving terms for robbery.

After deliberating for almost fifty-six hours, a Federal Court jury last night found two former officers of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company and of the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company not guilty of using the mail to defraud purchasers of guaranteed mortgage participation certificates and reported to Judge William Bondy that it was "hopelessly deadlocked" with respect to two other former officers.

Racing will begin today at Empire City following the conclusion of the Queens County Jockey Club's most successful meeting at Aqueduct. The Yonkers racing will start at 2:15 P.M., just as did that which ended yesterday at Aqueduct with the victory of the Paragon Stable's Great Albert in the Phosphor Class C Handicap.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 1:
MOSCOW, Thursday, July 3 (U.P.) -- Today's communique included the following:

NEWARK, N.J., July 2 (AP) -- George Wasbburn, a Yankee castoff, limited the Chiefs to two hits today, after holding them, hitless until the seventh and the Bears galloped to an 8-to-1 victory, their eighth straight. The defeat was the twelfth in a row for Syracuse, which previously had won eleven in succession.

Under the influence of an improvement in the securities and commodity markets, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange developed moderate strength yesterday and closed with net gains of 8 to 10 points.

The evidence mounts that all is not well with the national defense program. Our military reporter, Hanson W. Baldwin, finds that after a year of expansion and preparation the United States Army is still months away from adequate combat efficiency. In the opinion of most high-ranking officers not a single division is yet ready for war.

The Textile Fabrics Association, representing cotton goods converters, advised its members yesterday to oppose efforts of mills to bill goods on existing contracts at prices above the ceilings named last Saturday by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- A stronger tone was apparent today in both the hog and cattle pens. Hogs sold at steady to 10 cents higher prices, and steers and yearlings up to 25 cents higher. A steady tone prevailed in the sheep market. Imparting strength to the hog market was a reduction in receipts made in the face of an adverse price trend prevailing the past two days.

An intimation that the government may alter its policy and publish what exporters have termed, its "blacklist" of Latin-American companies guilty of subversive activities, was given yesterday by exporters who returned from conferences this week with officials in Washington.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- William S. Knudsen told the House Rivers and Harbors Committee today that there was no such thing as "too much power" in advocating legislation to authorize the development of the St. Lawrence seaway and power project.

BERLIN, July 2 -- Having already thrashed the Red Army in a ten-day "battle of annihilation" along the entire Russian-German frontier and occupied virtually all the territories that Moscow had annexed since this war began, according to Berlin reports, the Nazi legions were said here this evening to be in "uninterrupted" advance along the entire Eastern Front.

Another unit in the chain of Grant department stores will be opened in Waterbury, Conn., where the W.T. Grant Realty Corporation, the real estate holding company for the organization, has purchased for an indicated consideration of $250,000 from the Immaculate Conception Church the site of the old church edifice in East Main Street.

PAWLING, N.Y., July 2 -- It takes more than the mere opening of a season to put bass in a creel, as a number of New York anglers who visited Westchester and Putnam counties discovered yesterday and today.

A syndicate headed by The First Boston Corporation and Glore, Forgan Co. offered formally to the public yesterday a new issue of 120,000 shares of 5.10 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation.

DETROIT, July 2 (U.P.) -- Government defense orders to Henry Ford went up to $737,000,000 today and made his concern the greatest potential producer of airplane engines and bombers in the automobile industry.

The problem of maintaining price stability has now reached a critical stage. While living costs have gone up only 4.4 per cent since the outbreak of war, the general index of wholesale prices is up 17 per cent and a group of basic commodities is up nearly 50 per cent.

TOKYO, July 2 -- The long struggle behind the scenes between rival views and rival forces, which became acute with the outbreak of the Russian-German war, was brought to a dramatic conclusion when the imperial conference, in the presence of Emperor Hirohito, decided today, in the words of the official announcement, "on important national policies to meet the current situation."
Several apartment houses, two taxpayers and a number of small residential properties figured in the Bronx realty trading yesterday.

MOSCOW, July 2 (AP) -- Soviet Russia officially thanked the United States today for its stand on the Russo-German war and once again defied Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler with a firm declaration that he "can never win the war."
MOSCOW, July 2 (AP) -- The Sovied Information Bureau Issued this communique today:

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 3 (U.P.) -- German armored columns attempting a major break-through to Moscow are meeting fierce Russian resistance Borisov, fifty miles northeast of Minsk on the old Napoleonic route to the Russian capital, a Soviet war communique said early today.

Although "growing intolerance of minorities out of step with the national effort" is in evidence, the national emergency and the defense program so far have produced "remarkably few casualties" in the field of civil liberties, the American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday in its twenty-first annual report.

Charges of communism and subversive activities were brought against two suspended New York City school teachers yesterday afternoon as the first departmental trials held by the Board of Education as a diract outgrowth of the Rapp-Coudert committee investigation opened at board headquarters, 110 Lavingston Street, Brooklyn.
PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP) -- Indian Bob Johnson's home run in the tenth inning -- his seventeenth of the season -- gave the Athletics a 7-to-6 victory over the Senators today.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Queen Victoria complained of Gladstone that he addressed her as if she were a public meeting. The President's government colleagues do that very thing. But Mr. Roosevelt does not seem to mind; in fact, the belief in Washington is that he encourages it.
