MOSCOW, July 2 (AP) -- The section of today's communique containing personal commendations and political matters follows:

VICHY, France, July 2 -- Although Syria remains a minor theatre of operations, a new development there may increase its importance in the near future. The British have sent a strong motorized force from Iraq along the caravan trail that follows the course of the Euphrates in the general direction of Aleppo.

In one of the apartment leases reported yesterday, Johnny Green, the orchestra leader and composer, took a large suite in the building at 45 East Eighty-fifth Street through Robert E. Simon Jr., agent, and Warren Marks Associates, brokers.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 2 -- The transfer of General Sir Archibald Percival Wavell's command from the Middle East to India is believed here to result from a combination of political and strategical necessities.

Obviously the heat had affected the Phillies. They started against the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday as though they actually were going to beat the Brooks for the second day in a row. But then they settled down to their normal stride and bowed, 9 to 3.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Trading in wheat futures today was on a somewhat reduced scale and prices held within narrow limits. Scattered buying attributed to mills gave the market a firm start, but prices eased later on selling on the December by houses with Southwestern connections, which was regarded as hedging.
MOSCOW, Thursday, July 3 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The automobile industry may be called upon to carry three times its present $2,000,000,000 load of defense contracts next year, William S. Knudsen, OPM director general, told leaders of the industry today. This would make it necessary that automobile production be cut further than the 20 per cent already decided upon for next year, he asserted.

The Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group, Inc., has requested Price Administrator Leon Henderson to make an investigation of higher costs of materials which, if found justified, would lead to advances in the wholesale prices of dresses selling from $4.75 to $1.37 1/2.

The proposed change to a wholesale cost basis for tax purposes recommended by the House Ways and Means Committee has aroused considerable misgiving in the toilet-goods industry, particularly on the score of penalizing branded goods and of possible increased litigation, according to comment in authoritative quarters yesterday:

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Asserting that the German attack on Russia did not justify the feeling of some Americans that "danger was averted," but holding, rather, that the direct contrary was the truth, William S. Knudsen, Director General of the OPM, in a Fourth of July message, called on every American to do all he could to push the defense program faster and faster, whether directly engaged in the program or not.

The greatest successes in land warfare achieved thus far by a British commander have been the work of General Sir Archibald Wavell. So the news that he has been relieved of his command at Cairo and sent to India comes as a surprise. Different interpretations have followed the order, and it is not yet clear precisely what it means.

Bank of America The Bank of America, N.T. S.A., of California, reported as of June 30 total deposits of $1.685,488,418 and total assets of $1,877,738,675, compared, respectively, with $1,606,435,057 and $1,781,996,172 on April 4.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 2 -- A report from the Berlin correspondent of the Aftonbladet, who has been reporting the occupation of Russian towns from twenty-four to forty-eight hours in advance of the event, states that Murmansk fell into German hands yesterday.

A resolution pledging "full and unstinting support to the Soviet Union in its struggle to defend its land, its people and its freedom" was adopted last night at a mass meeting at Madison Square Garden sponsored by the American Council on Soviet Relations.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Like many others, I am wondering if our Congressional committee realizes the consequences of unifying the incomes of husband and wife in order to tax married life higher than the same individuals unmarried.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 2 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:

Two new films will arrive in local houses this morning. Metro's "They Met in Bombay," starring Clark Gable and Rosalind Russell, will be the newcomer at the Capitol. Directed by Clarence Brown, the romantic adventure features Peter Lorre, Jessie Ralph, Reginald Owen and Luis Alberni....

Details of the break-up of the northern group of properties of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation's system, in compliance with the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, were submitted yesterday to the Securities and Exchange Commission by Justin R. Whiting, president of the $1,000,000,000 holding company.

TRENTON, July 2 -- Governor Edison's investigation of the Republican-controlled State Highway Department moved forward today with selection of Henri Schwob of New York and Sidney Goldmann of Trenton as assistants to Roger Hinds of South Orange, who will direct the inquiry.

The war in Russia is a campaign of vague and immense movements on a field of such fantastic size that it dwarfs all previous battles in this conflict. It is a war of isolated operations, hundreds of miles apart, and although enormous forces are engaged, they are somehow lost in space, thin lines criss-crossing a terrain which absorbs and erases everything.
LONDON, July 2 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique today said:

Despite declines in national and automotive copy, total advertising in eight New York newspapers rose 2.1 per cent in June, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. Increases were registered by six newspapers with one morning and one evening daily showing small losses.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Expenditures of $12,710,000,000, or $3,712,000,000 more than during the preceding year, were shown today by the Treasury in official figures for the fiscal year 1941 ending June 30. Receipts of $7,607,000,000 were $2,220,000,000 more than in the fiscal year 1940.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Metals Reserve Company has contracted for 616,882,800 pounds of aluminum from the Aluminum Company of Canada, Ltd., a quantity almost equivalent to the annual production of the Aluminum Company of America, which is currently estimated to be at the rate of 635,000,000 pounds, Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, announced today.

The German attack on Russia clearly indicates that the Reich was not obtaining all the supplies it thought it could get, or was obtaining as complete Russian collaboration in economic and foreign policy as it thought it could win by military victory, the National City Bank asserts in its monthly bank letter released yesterday.

If there was any question of the mastery of Fritzie Zivic, world welterweight champion, over Al Davis, Brownsville fighter who is now Private Albert Davidow of Battery D, Sixty-ninth Coast Artillery, it was dissipated last night on the Polo Grounds to the complete satisfaction of even the most rdent Davis rooter.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The National Defense Mediation Board today set a 5 P.M. Thursday deadline for an answer from the Western Cartridge Company of East Alton, Ill., to the board's recommendation that it grant exclusive bargaining rights for 550 smokeless powder division employes to the American Federation of Labor's Chemical Workers Union, which won an NLRB election.

VICHY, France, July 2 -- More prisoners of war are about to be released by the German authority, according to a government announcement tonight. They include four categories -- all captives of white race still in French territory; all reserve officers who fought in the World War; all born prior to Jan. 1, 1900, except career officers and long-service men, and about 1,000 postal employes.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company has sold to Crawford Properties, Inc., represented by Jesse H. Barkin, attorney, the twelve-story store and office building at 16-18 East Fortieth Street and 13 East Thirty-ninth Street, four floors of which are occupied by Arnold Constable Co.

Eugene Goossens made his second appearance of the season as the guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. His program included three works by Spanish composers and two by French composers who were inspired by Spain, Debussy and Ravel.
PURCHASE, N.Y., July 2 -- Shooting well-nigh perfect golf, Douglas Ford of Green Valley won the twenty-first annual Westchester junior championship tournament on the Century Country Club today.

Unable to find a suitable replacement for Monty Woolley, around whom all the action of "The Man Who Came to Dinner" revolves, the Gearge S. Kaufman-Moss Hart comedy will terminate its successful engagement at the Music Box on Saturday night of next week.

Steel Capacity It is now certain that the American Iron and Steel Institute will make a mid-year revision, in its calculation of the theoretical production capacity of the steel industry, as it did for the only previous time in 1937.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 2 (AP) -- Earl's Moody Guy, a bay gelding driven by the veteran Vic Fleming, tonight equalled the world trot record for a mile and one-sixteenth at the Fort Miami fair grounds by covering the distance in 2 minutes 11 seconds.
Sweeping majestically onward with a thunderous smash that soared deep into the left-field stands, Joe DiMaggio yesterday rocketed his current hitting streak beyond the all-time major league record.

ALBANY, July 2 -- Governor Lehman, reporting this afternoon on the condition of the State's finances, stated that not only has the $30,000,000 deficit as of July 1, 1940, been wiped out, but that the State now has a working surplus of $7,000,000.

A strong plea that the United States use its naval forces to protect the freedom of the seas was made last night by Bear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, Commandant of the Third Naval District, in an address to the Society of Tammany at Tammany Hall.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 2 -- A long-range policy of British and American collaboration in the Pacific to assure the political and economic stability of that area, free of domination by the Axis powers, especially Japan, was advocated at today's sessions of the University of Virginia's Institute of Public Affairs by representatives of Australia, Netherlands Indies and the United States.

Frank Kovacs led at 40 -- 0 in the final game of his match yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, Queens. He then proceeded to lose the next five points while the gallery watched in stunned silence, and so ended the prospect of a final-round meeting between Kovacs and Frank Parker in the Eastern clay court championship.

BALTIMORE, July 2 (AP) -- The Glenn L. Martin Company, announcing formation of a subsidiary to manufacture bombing planes at Omaha, disclosed today that its backlog of unfilled orders for combat aircraft for the United States and Britain is $646,000,000.

The Sterling National Bank and Trust Company has been appointed trustee for an issue of $2,525,000 of 42 Broadway Building twenty-year income bonds, due on July 1, 1961, of the Broadway-New Street Corporation, and also agent of the voting trustees with respect to 25,250 shares of the corporation's capital stock of $1 par value.

As the climax of a full week of blistering heat, the temperature in New York climbed yesterday to 94.4 degrees at 4:45 P.M. to set by a scant margin a new high for the year. The previous high was a flat 94 degrees on June 22.

August Lull Seen Possible Producers of women's apparel and other merchandise are trying to appraise what the results of heavy initial ordering in June will have on late July and August activity in the wholesale markets. There are some who fear that a lull in what ordinarily is a very active period may develop, affecting the later season.

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 3 -- The text of the broadcast address by Joseph Stalin, Premier and chairman of the State Committee of Defense, as translated by Tass, the official Russian news agency, follows:

A former Storm Trooper of the German-American Bund was arrested yesterday by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as a member of the alleged espionage ring uncovered over the week-end. His arrest brought to thirty-three the number of men and women who have been taken into custody in the case.

BOSTON, July 2 -- Where Johnny Wittig failed, Bill Lohrman met with success today. Lohrman blanked the Braves, 6 -- 0, after the home team had gained a 5-4 decision in the first game of the double-header.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Led by especially sharp price increases for agricultural commodities and fats and oils, the general level of wholesale prices again advanced in the week ended on June 28, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said today.

In a mock funeral procession, headed by seven suspended City College instructors garbed in cap and gown, the Committee for Defense of Public Education symbolically buried "academic freedom" yesterday and then placed a wreath over the "body" in front of the Supreme Court Building in Foley.

Officials of the city government and leading retail stores joined in a program at noon yesterday in Franklin Simon's store, on Fifth Avenue at Thirty-eighth Street, in support of civilian defense. Window displays, illustrating several phases of defense activities, were unveiled by Newbold Morris, President of the City Council.
LONDON, July 3 (U.P.) -- There are indications that the battle being fought from the Baltic to the Ukraine is beginning to go in favor of the Russians, military experts here said tonight.

During the course of the trout season this Spring a number of anglers seem to have stumbled upon good woodchuck areas, and with the decline in trout fishing many of them have decided to try 'chuck shooting rather than turn to other forms of fresh and salt water angling.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Representatives of the Southern soft coal operators and the United Mine Workers of America resumed negotiations in a surprise move today and the indications were that an agreement would be reached tomorrow, averting a second strike in Southern coal fields.

Controversy over utilization of the "package" bidding method 'in the sale of public utility securities continued yesterday as an aftermath of completion of a $47,393,000 financing program by the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation.

After ten weeks' labor the House Ways and Means Committee has completed its proposals for the 1941 revenue act. The program is far from, perfect; but the committee has put in a great deal of hard work; it has not been content to. take ready-made solutions either from the Treasury or its own experts without careful examination, and its members have shown a high degree of knowledge and understanding in working out technical problems.
THE fiery particles of a rocket spangled the darkness. Gunpowder smell charred the air. On the grass there was a tangle of shadowy bent wires where the tall sparklers had blazed in the early evening.

Holiday All banks and financial markets will be closed today in observance of Independance Day. They will be reopened tomorrow with the exception of those commodity markets that normally are closed on Summer Saturdays.

BRIDGETON, N.J., July 3 (AP) -- Long John Borican started a new chapter of the local-boy-makes-good story when he won three of five events today to lead the race for the National A.A.U. decathlon championship.

In its new phase of existence as a temporary museum, the Vanderbilt mansion at 640 Fifth Avenue did well for national defense yesterday, the cash register in the foyer having checked in $650 on its first day of public inspection. The stream of callers -- each of whom contributed $1 to the United Service Organization drive for the privilege of exploring this former haunt of the very rich -- was steady.

LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- Note circulation of the Bank of England continued on its skyrocketing course to reach another high record of u643,365,000 for the week ended on July 2. Reserves lost u4,411,000, the fifth, drop in as many weeks.

From the name of the Society for the Preservation and Encouragement of Barber Shop Quartet Singing in America breathes an air, we had thought, of democratic sociability and bonhomie. It seems, however, that the word White should have been included in it.

HELSINKI, Finland, Friday, July 4 (U.P.) -- The Finnish High Command announced in its first communique of the war early today that German and Finnish troops had occupied important points on the Russian side of the 600-mile Russian-Finnish frontier.
CHICAGO, July 3 -- The Cardinals' defense cracked today and the Cubs scored two unearned runs behind Claude Passeau's five-hit pitching to win, 2-1.

STANTON, Del., July 3 (AP) -- Miss Janet Brodsky's consistent gelding Brave Sir scored his third triumph in five starts at the Delaware Park meeting when he was first home in the featured five-and-one-half furlong Bridgeville Claiming Purse today.
LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- The Air Ministry said in a communique today:

Tampa, Fla., will enter the market on July 14 with $2,000,000 of water revenue bonds for which bidders are to specify a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent. The bonds, dated July 1, 1941, are to mature on July 1, 1945 to 1971.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Finnish Legation made public today a message sent by the Social Democratic party of Finland and the Central Organization of the Finnish Trade Unions to the Labor party and the General Council of the Trade Union Congress in Britain.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Secretary Morgenthau announced today a new tax-payment plan permitting taxpayers to meet the heavy 1942 payments through systematic savings over a period of months. The plan, designed to cover personal and corporation taxes, which will be required under the national defense program, calls for the purchase by the taxpayer of tax-anticipation notes, which will be put on sale August 1.

MOSCOW, July 3 (U.P.) -- Joseph Stalin's appeal for unlimited war was reported tonight to have touched off a nation-wide surge of enthusiastic effort against "the German hordes -- the savage, treacherous and brutal enemies of our fatherland and of all humanity."

The Kingdom of Sweden brought suit in Federal court here yesterday against Vultee Aircraft, Inc., demanding $7,039,188 damages for the failure of the airplane makers to deliver 144 pursuit planes ordered in February of last year. According to the complaint, Vultee failed to deliver the planes even after Sweden had offered to accept them in this country, despite the refusal of the government to grant licenses for their export to Sweden.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Control Administrator, deferred today "for some months" plans to establish ceiling prices on automobile tires and tubes as rubber industry representatives assured him they could work out current price problems on a voluntary basis.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 3 -- The real impact of the war is getting nearer day by day and the atmoshpere in this strange city is electrified by the feeling that something is going to happen -- events about which the Finns are not yet informed.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Plans for far-reaching experiments in the field of mechanized war, including organization of twenty-two anti-tank battalions and creation of a more formidable motorized division than any heretofore attempted by the United States Army, were told today by Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., July 3 (AP) -- Defending champions in nine of the eleven scheduled events have sent in entries for the women's national A.A.U. track and field championship meet at the Recreation Center here Saturday.

BUFFALO, July 3 -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend, leader of the pension movement bearing his name, proposed today a "Townsend National City" where a central educational institution would be devoted to "the general welfare" of all the people.

BERLIN, July 3 (AP) -- In phrases edited by Reichsfuehrer Hitler himself, the High Command reported today that German, Finnish, Hungarian and Rumanian forces were engaged in one move along the entire 2,000-mile front, with the likely objectives Russia's three most important cities:

For the fifth time this year the volume of weekly tank clearings exceeded $7,000,000,000. While the gain over the corresponding week of last year was not as large as that of a week ago, check exchanges for the week remained at a high level.

BERLIN, July 3 (U.P.) -- Britain | lost 768,950 tons of shipping in June and 109 planes in the week ended yesterday to a German offensive being maintained relentlessly by air and sea, the Nazi High Command asserted today.

MOSCOW, July 3 -- The fighting speech delivered today by Premier Joseph Stalin, in which he denounced Germany's aims against the Soviet Union and announced a "scorched earth" policy, has endeared him with the Russian people.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- An urgent recommendation for repeal of laws restricting service of National Guardsmen and trainees to the Western Hemisphere or United States possessions was made today by General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, in a semi-annual report to the Secretary of War.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Jacques Benoist-Mechih, French Secretary of State, has failed in the niissior that took him to Ankara last week He tried in vain to persuade. the President of the Turkish Republic and his Ministers to sell back to Vichy the war material received from France in 1939-40 and to allow arms and ammunition to pass freely across Turkish territory to Syria.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman denied yesterday an application by John G. Lonsdale and James M. Kurn as trustees of the St. Louis San Francisco Railway Company to take depositions from Edward N. Brown, chairman of the board of the railway, and from James Speyer and other partners in Speyer Co., bankers.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- General Marshall's request for the removal of restrictions on the time of service and the field of operations of the trainee army of the United States was sharply criticized today by non-interventionist Senators.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Conservation, substitution, and simplification of design must be applied on an unprecedented scale to practically every commodity to free vital supplies for the defense program, according to Robert E. McConnell, chief of the conservation section of the Office of Production Management.

Miss Mary C. Tinney, long a social worker and formerly Director of the Division of Professional and Service Projects of the Work Projects Administration here, died yesterday in her home, 1 Tennis Court, Brooklyn, after a long illness. Her age was 52.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

Although some of Premier Joseph Stalin's remarks in his broadcast to the Soviet people Wednesday seemed like whistling in the dark, his flat assertion that "history shows that there are no invincible armies and never have been" was something that needed to be said.

While most advertising media registered gains for the first half of this year over 1940, the increases in general were disappointing, considering the record rate of both industrial production and retail sales. Advertising expenditures as a whole probably did not run more than 4 to 5 per cent ahead of the first half of last year.

From Maine to California and from the Great Lakes to the Rio Grande, citizens throughout the country will pause for a few minutes today, on the 165th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence, to join with President Roosevelt and Chief Justice Stone in a simple and solemn Independence Day observance unprecedented in the nation's history.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Harold L. Ickes, speaking as the Petroleum Coordinator, said today that within a day or two he would ask State and city highway patrolmen to make "a few judicious arrests" of drivers of automobiles which waste gasoline and oil.

The long-standing feud between Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, and the City Council committee investigating civil service broke out afresh yesterday as Mr. Kern accused the committee of engaging in "crooked work" in the concealment of the commission's documents and the committee countered with a virtual threat to jail the commission's head for contempt.
BOSTON, July 3 (AP) -- Hurling five-hit ball, Al Javery registered his fifth victory of the season today as the Boston Braves defeated the Phillies, 4 to 1, in the series opener.
HELSINKI, Finland, Friday, July 4 (AP) -- Finland's first communique in her new conflict with Russia was issued early today as follows:

Eager to divert conversation from the pugilistic and financial failure that he promoted at the Polo Grounds the night before, when Fritzie Zivic handed an artistic pasting to AI Davis, the erstwhile "Bad Boy of Brownsville," Mike Jacobs spent most of yesterday afternoon talking about the forthcoming bout between Joe Louis and Lou Nova.
BERLIN, July 3 (AP) -- The German High Command communique from "the Fuehrer's headquarters" said today:

Although, not a wheel turned yesterday among the greater city's three major league ball clubs, heavy firing is in prospect today in the holiday twin bills which will be staged in New York and Brooklyn.

The Penn-Mex Fuel Company has reached a settlement with Mexico and has received $300,000 in cash as full compensation for its properties in Mexico, according to a statement issued yesterday by Harry F. Sinclair, president of the Consolidated Oil Corporation, which owns about 85 per cent of the 394,391 shares of Penn-Mex Fuel.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 3 -- The nation's golfing co-eds crowned their first champion today -- Miss Eleanor Dudley of Chicago, who was 'graduated only a few days ago by the University of Alabama.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 3 -- The mysterious sector of the Soviet-German front is undoubtedly Finland, where except for vague indications given by the German and Russian communique's, mystery reigns over the operations, particularly on the Karelian Isthmus.

More banks reported yesterday their statements of condition, as of June 30. Most of them showed increases in their earning assets. In general, the reports followed the trend whereby the smaller institutions showed further gains in deposits, reaching new records in some instances.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 3 -- Claims and counter claims filled the customarily befuddled atmosphere at the baseball writers' outing today at the Crescent-Huntington Club grounds.

Stalin's broadcast yesterday was not the appeal of the Communist leader to the embattled proletariat. In a desperate crisis of his power, when for the first time since the revolution an invader had crashed through the gates of the Soviet Union, he spoke as the head of a Government under the necessity of explaining why he adopted a policy which led to disaster.
Apartment properties were most in demand in the realty trading reported yesterday in the Bronx. Several houses in the northern section of the borough went into new ownership.

The-seventeen-story factory and office building at 323-25 West Thirty-seventh Street has been sold by the Empire City Savings Bank to the Joram Holding Corporation, subject to a purchase-money mortgage of $100,000.

Polo, in the interests of the United Service Organizations, offers today what is in many respects the most interesting show ever to be Held at historic International Field, Westbury, L.I. In cooperation with Mitchel Field, the great flying base of the Army, whose property adjoins that of the Meadow Brook Club, an all-star polo game and a flying exhibition, with some military trimmings on the side, have been scheduled.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Excess reserves of thirty-six member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City declined $5,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $2,160,000,000, the lowest since March 20, 1939. These figures, made public yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, contrasted with an expansion of $120,000,000 in the week in the excess reserves of all member banks of the Federal Reserve System to $5,270,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Western Cartridge Company of East Alton, III., has agreed to meet Saturday with the A.F. of L. Chemical Workers Union "for the purpose of entering" into negotiations as to wages, hours and conditions of employment of all the employes in the bargaining unit found appropriate by the National Labor Relations Board."

The denial by the Interstate Commerce Commission of the application of the Colorado Southern Railway to lease the Fort Worth Denver City and the Wichita Valley Railways is a step backward from a solution of the nation's railway problem. The leasing, which would have been tantamount, for practical purposes, to consolidation, was to have saved upward of $235,000 a year, principally by a reduction in labor costs.

HYDE PARK, July 3 -- President Roosevelt signed the $1,030,000,000 second deficiency bill today but issued a statement noting that under the terms of the measure, employes of the Farm Security Administration, Department of Agriculture, could not be brought under the Civil Service as war made possible for other employes by the Ramspeck Act.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 3 -- The celebration of the Fourth in the Summer colony really began this evening when many of its members attended the annual radium ball, given for the benefit of the fund being raised to purchase radium for use in cancer cases in Newport County.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today several large gifts of stocks in May by officers, directors and principal owners of corporations.
VICHY, France, July 3 (AP) -- The French High Command issued the following communique tonight on operations in Syria:

ANKARA, Turkey, July .3 -- The Allied campaign in Syria is believed rapidly nearing a successful conclusion, despite the surface impression of continuing stiff French resistance and actual Allied preparations for new major offensives. It is expected the struggle will end with an armistice within a week, according to high foreign military sources here tonight.

LONDON, July 3 (U.P.) -- London pubs echoed tonight with preliminary toasts to the independence of the United States as the British prepared to celebrate the Fourth of July wholeheartedly for the first time.

Dr. E. George Payne, dean of the School of Education of New York University, yesterday outlined a four-point plan for education in the effort to "conserve democracy." It included specific educational planning in recognition of the emergence of a "new order," vocation training camps for youth under an "interneship" plan, adequate adult education, and the organization of youth.

In commemoration of today's holiday, eight of the dozen current Broadway shows will offer matinees. Alphabetically listed they are "Arsenic and Old Lace," "Hellzapoppin," "My Sister Eileen," "Pal Joey," "Panama Hattie,' "Separate Rooms," "The Beautiful People" and "The Man Who Came to Dinner."

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- A bill giving the Maritime Commission new and sweeping powers over the merchant marine moved close to final passage today, when a conference committee report on it was put before Congress.
NEW YORK Mrs. Charles Page Perin is spending the Summer with Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip at her country home, Beechwood, in Scarborough.

BOSTON, July 3 (AP) -- The silks of Hal Price Headley, Kentucky owner and breeder, which have dominated Suffolk Downs's long meeting, went to the masthead today for the thirteenth time when Walter Lee Taylor scored with Alaking, a home-bred, in the Waban, a $1,500 mile race for 3-year-olds in Grade C.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 2:

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- General Marshall's recommendation for the removal of restrictions on the time of service for selectees, National Guardsmen and reserves would enable the United States to expand the Army. If all present personnel were retained, together with the increment of 900,000 trainees for the year started July 1, the Army would reach a strength of 2,300,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 3 -- "They Lived Alone," a comedy by Sonya Levien, will be used as Deanna Durbin's next vehicle, with production scheduled for late Summer, Universal announced today. Miss Levien is writing the scenario and Miss Durbin's role will be that of a girl reporter in New York.

Ruth Benson Blinn, widow of Holbrook Blinn, the actor, has sold to Julia L. Voska of New York her residence in Blinn Road, in the Town of Yorktown, Westchester, with a plot of more than four acres of land. The house contains seven rooms.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, appointed a seven-man national defense committee today and called upon the members "to make voluntary cooperation of labor with the government so effective as to destroy all pressure for compulsory service."

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- During the week ended June 28, the department-store sales continued to gain, rising 23 per cent over the corresponding week a year ago Last week there was an improvement of 17 per cent. The sales showed a gain of 14 per cent both for the four-week period ended June 28 and for the year up to that date in comparison with the similar periods of 1940.

MOSCOW, Friday, July 4 (U.P.) -- Russia's armed forces, unleashing "crushing blows," are inflicting great losses on the Germans in the fierce battle of the Berezina River 360 miles west of Moscow, where Napoleon's army met disaster 129 years ago, today's Soviet war communique reported.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- An indictment accusing three Chicago meat packing companies, seven officials and two trade associations of conspiring to fix prices for hogs slaughtered in Chicago was returned today by a Federal grand jury before Judge Michael L. Igoe.

A 5-year-old boy who had been beaten and then bound with sashrope by the hands and reet to a bed in an apartment on the second floor of a three-family house at 490 Dean Street, Brooklyn, was taken to the Children's Shelter at 105 Schermerhorn Street yesterday afternoon as a neglected child, while a man who said he was in charge of the boy was arrested on a charge of felonious assault.

The Japanese merchant marine, which has in the past carried an important volume of commerce in and out of the Atlantic ports of the United States, is being steadily withdrawn at a rate indicating that within a few weeks only a few vessels in indirect trades will continue coming into the Atlantic, it was disclosed here yesterday.

LONDON, July 3 -- A question concerning German agents and their activities in Eire was raised today in the House of Commons when Sir William Henry Davison, Conservative, asked whether the government was aware of the ease with which they could cross ,and recross the frontier between Eire and Northern Ireland to obtain full particulars about the British forces now stationed in Ulster.

BERLIN, July 3 -- Having reported the elite Russian divisions thrashed in a ferociously fought "battle of annihilation" on the Russian-German border, the German High Command today asserted that the "power of resistance" of the Soviet forces had been broken.
MOSCOW, July 3 (AP) -- The section of today's communique containing personal commendations and political matters follows:

DETROIT, July 3 -- The Wayne County (Detroit) prosecutor's office began an investigation today into charges that terrorists run out of New York City by Thomas E. Dewey were "cutting themselves in" on some Detroit unions.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP).-- Although supplies at the stockyards were abridged in view of the three-day suspension of market activities over the holidays, buyers obtained hogs, steers and yearlings today at generally steady prices, while steady to strong values prevailed in the sheep pen.

BOSTON, Mass., July 3 -- The National Education Association adopted a resolution today opposing "the employment, in any school, college or university, of any person who advocates or who is a member of any organization that advocates changing the form of government of the United States by any means not provided for under the Federal Constitution."

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the amount of money borrowed by member firms from banks, trust companies and other lenders in the United States, excluding borrowings from other members of national securities exchanges, amounted to $416,194,020 at the close of business on June 30.
MOSCOW, July 3 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique said today:

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The House Committee on Ways and Means has made a sour Fourth of July present to those American married couples of which the wife has an income of her own. Whether she has inherited, earned or had it as a gift from her husband, she must file with him a joint return.
Gloria Swanson, the film star, has leased from the Carpenter Realty Company residential quarters in the building at 920 Fifth Avenue, through Hickernell-Ro-meyn, Inc., brokers.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- Colonel Kolb was a banker and philanthropist who Inherited a modest baking plant from his father, developed it into one of the biggest in the city and eventually became one of the largest holders of central Philadelphia real estate.

Insisting that he is no warmonger for World War No. 2, America's World War hero No. 1, Sergeant Alvin C. York, declared yesterday that "no one can possibly hate war as much as a soldier who has tried to catch his breath with the mud of trenches caked on his face.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Despite hostilities in Europe, Asia and Africa, and on the whole because of them, imports into the United States during the fiscal year which has just ended increased by an amount which produced customs receipts for the 1941 fiscal year of $392,000,000 as compared with $349,000,000 for 1940, a gain of 12.5 per cent.

POLO, tennis, golf, swimming, yaching, horse racing -- the program for today is filled in all directions. But the big dish is the baseball lineup. Two games all around, weather permitting. This could be crucial in a way. It might cut the "logical contenders" to two clubs in each big league.

CHARLOTTESVELLE, Va., July 3 -- The underground resistance of the "free peoples" of Europe to the dictatorships imposed on their "occupied but unconquered" countries was reported today to the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs by representatives of Norway, Czechoslovakia and Poland.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 3 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:
Three weeks before publication a fourth printing of A.J. Cronin's novel, "The Keys of the Kingdom," has been ordered by Little Brown. A quarter of a million copies have now been printed.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), July 3 -- The Bourse was very firm today under the lead of domestic industrials and trading companies with important increases in numerous issuer. Only A.K.U. was 1 1/4% lower at 140 1/4. Dutch Indians also were firm.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the conclusion of a series of informal conferences between its staff and representatives of the Cities Service Company of New York for the working out of a cooperative program for the solution of the company's problems under the "death sentence" clause and Section 12 of the Holding Company Act.

Paderewski and Versailles It may serve to clarify people's ideas about the Treaty of Versailles if one thinks of Ignace Paderewski. He was one of the chief builders of the Poland that arose out of the World War and one of Poland's representatives at the Peace Conference.

Mrs. Florence C. Whitney of Stowe, Vt., widow of Caspar Whitney and a leader in women's political, civic, welfare and educational activities, was killed instantly in an automobile accident at White River Junction, Vt., about 5 o'clock Wednesday afternoon, according to word received here yesterday.

Prisoners in the Women's House of Detention at 10 Greenwich Avenue have been heckling the three women arrested last Sunday as members of an alleged espionage ring so severely that the authorities have transferred the alleged spies to other parts of the prison and have had their meals served in their cells instead of the regular dining hall, it became known yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 3 -- The first stages of the "Battle of Russia" along the Berezina River line east of Minsk have ended slightly in favor of the Russian forces in the first twenty-four hours, according to reports received here tonight.

Anti-fascist spokesmen representing Italy, Norway, France, China, Latin America and the United States broadcast messages of confidence and warnings against appeasement policies to both, the free and suppressed peoples of three continents at a meeting yesterday afternoon of the newly organized International Free World Association.
Dr. Lester Carson Spier, a surgeon, has purchased for his residence and office the five-story dwelling at 15 East Eightieth Street.

Cotton prices fluctuated narrowly yesterday in quiet trading. After opening generally firm, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 1 to 6 points above Wednesday's close but subsequently eased to close at net losses of 1 to 4 points for the day.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

According to figures assembled by the New York Department of Markets, prices have settled into a quiet normality for the holidays -- no average change of more than one cent being recorded in either meat or dairy products since last week-end.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- While most of today's trading in wheat futures consisted of pre-holiday evening-up, sufficient buying by mills developed to about offset hedging pressure and closing trades on the Board of Trade here were unchanged to 1/4 cent a bushel lower than yesterday.

JERUSALEM, July 3 -- British and Free French forces who had laid siege to Tadmur in central Syria, for thirteen days entered the town at 1 o'clock this afternoon after the Vichy garrison had signified its capitulation.
LONDON, Friday, July 4 -- British bombers and fighter planes were back over France again yesterday in two daylight offensive sweeps.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 3 -- With the exception of one match, play was postponed in the first round of the twenty-seventh annual Nassau Country Club invitation turf-court tennis singles tourney today because of rain.

Empire City opened its Summer meeting yesterday with, many of the best known men and women in racing in the grandstand, with a new green lawn, and with longshots hammering home in the races, including the featured Irvington Purse.

LONDON, July 3 -- A great row over the present,and future of the Ministry of Information flared up in Parliament today, ending with government concessions to the Ministry which did not satisfy the House of Commons, the press or officials, who contend that they are being hamstrung by 'the military services and by other departments of the government.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 3 (AP) -- Florida's racing commission adjourned a three-day meeting today without fixing dates for horse races next season and without acting on a request for an investigation of Tropical Park at Miami.

Wholesale trading remained brisk this week as retailers continued to order Fall merchandise freely, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Many buyers who had already covered a large share of their requirements for Fall were back in the markets again to check on deliveries and study new developments in styles and prices.

BUTLER, N.J., July 3 -- Machine age and horse-and-buggy met on Route 23 here in an extraordinary incident at one o'clock this morning. Before it ended State Troopers had to save two horse-and-buggy drivers from machine-age motorists who took the horse's side.
MOSCOW, Friday, July 4 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau today issued the following communique:

An organized group of almost half the milk producers in the New York milkshed announced last night its intention of joining 23,000 members of the Dairy Farmers Union, in the three-day-old strike that has continued to cut down the city's milk supply, provided the groups can reach a joint agreement.

The cool air mass which the weather man had been promising for the last few days, but which perspiring news writers had been wearily placing in quotes, reached the Eastern seaboard yesterday, albeit not in perfect condition.

Unusual calm was exhibited yesterday by the stock market in the face of the Independence Day holiday which will be stretched by most of the financial community into a week-end affair. Except for a slight interruption after the noon hour, the share list on the Stock Exchange made fairly steady improvement during the session.

Supporters of Abraham Rosenthal, claimant to the Tammany leadership of the Eighth Assembly District, took no chances of having the Manhattan Democratic Club at 136 Second Avenue invaded by Nathan Weiss and his supporters last night.

Cooler weather yesterday had the effect of improving the demand for most classes of fresh meats. Some salesmen were asking higher prices for steer hinds and ribs and also lamb. Supplies were rather heavy preceding the holiday and some fair sized lots will probably be carried over until tomorrow.

Baseball Game Members of the department, and their families, are invited to attend the baseball game between the teams of the Department of Sanitation and the Fire Department, on Tuesday, July 8, at 2 P. M., at Parade Grounds, Parkside Ave., Parade Place and Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn.

The doctrine that all governments derive "their just powers from the consent of the governed" was officially set up in this country 165 years ago today. It was not new, but we were the first nation to take it for a motto. It was not called democracy, for the word democracy in 1776 was not yet respectable.

LONDON, July 3 -- A great row over the present,and future of the Ministry of Information flared up in Parliament today, ending with government concessions to the Ministry which did not satisfy the House of Commons, the press or officials, who contend that they are being hamstrung by 'the military services and by other departments of the government.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 3 (AP) -- Florida's racing commission adjourned a three-day meeting today without fixing dates for horse races next season and without acting on a request for an investigation of Tropical Park at Miami.

Wholesale trading remained brisk this week as retailers continued to order Fall merchandise freely, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Many buyers who had already covered a large share of their requirements for Fall were back in the markets again to check on deliveries and study new developments in styles and prices.

St. Patrick's Cathedral was crowded with, more than 4,500 persons, who filled every seat and stood in every available space, yesterday morning at the solemn pontifical mass of requiem for Ignace Jan Pederewski.
HUTCHINSON, Kan., July 3 (AP) -- Miss Auriol Lee, stage director and actress, was killed yesterday when the automobile she was driving skidded and left a highway.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 3 -- Despite a final business day before the holiday week-end, and a fading wind and rain, fifty-six craft turned out today for the New York Yacht Club's ninetieth annual regatta and the special races held with it.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES :

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 3 -- With varsity competition postponed, today's play in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships at the Montclair Athletic Club was confined to freshman singles and doubles. Tomorrow's holiday program will feature quarter-final matches in varsity singles and semi-finals in freshman singles.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- During the week ended July 2 member bank reserve balances increased $140,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of 5244,000,000 in Treasury deposits with. Federal Reserve banks and $77,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, and increases of $24,000,000 in Reserve bank credit, $7,000,000 in gold stock and $2,000,000 in Treasury currency, offset in part by an increase of $214,000,000 in money in circulation.

Settlement of the dispute between unlicensed seamen in the Seafarers International Union and three ship lines appeared remote yesterday after union members had voted unanimously against submitting to arbitration.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Governor Stassen of Minnesota and Governor Moses of North Dakota concurred today in President Roosevelt's contention that a St Lawrence seaway and power development was vital to defense and the economic welfare of the nation.

It is gratifying that, as soon as the National Defense Mediation Board had secured assent to its decision in the North American Aviation strike, the President turned back the plant to its private owners. This should strengthen the hope that there is to be no wholesale seizure of plants and government operation of them in the name of national defense.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- The seventh annual American Youth Congress opened its sessions here tonight with a sharp debate over the nation's foreign policy in the offing, but with no signs of the presence of what its officers described as "professional opposition."

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board will move to New York at an unannounced date in the near future to make room for defense activities in the national capital, Chairman John H. Fahey announced today.

Leon Henderson, Price Control Administrator, has been asked by the National Dress Manufacturers Association to investigate increases of "approximately 100 per cent" in the cost of corrugated paper boxes, used by the ready-to-wear industries, it was learned here yesterday.

MANILA, July 3 (AP) -- The Customs Bureau announced tonight that henceforth all departing Japanese vessels would be inspected to prevent any evasion of the export control system, a move interpreted in shipping circles as apparently intended to counteract the possible effects of Japan's requisitioning such ships.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Sales by departments in 249 reporting department stores continued to show appreciable increases during May, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

COLORADO SPRINGS, July 3 (AP) -- Rallying courageously in the face of what seemed sure defeat the 1940 champion, Marvin (Bud) Ward of Spokane, Wash., swept the last four holes to beat Rodney Bliss of Omaha, 1 up, in the Western amateur golf tournament's first round today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 (AP) -- Robert Moses Grove scored his 299th pitching victory today in defeating the Athletics for the Red Sox, 5 to 2. One more triumph for Old Mose and he will be the twelfth pitcher in major league history to hit the coveted 300 mark.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman announced yesterday that he had created the office of Secretary of Education for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, to which he had appointed the Rev. William A. Scully, former pastor of the Church of the Sacred Heart of Jesus, 451 West Fifty-first Street.

The about-face of American Peace Mobilization, which had condemned all aid to Britain but now is urging aid to Soviet Russia, was cited yesterday by Miss Mary W. Hillyer, executive director of the Keep America Out of War Congress, as proving conclusively the Communist domination of the group.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The National Labor Relations Board voted today not to require two New York steamship companies to reinstate twenty former employes with back pay since 1937.
HAVANA, July 4 -- The Fourth of July was enthusiastically celebrated by the Cuban people today as a demonstration of friendship for and solidarity with the United States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The press reported on July 2 that officials of the Department of State revealed that the American Government would make no exceptions to the order that all aliens associated with the German and Italian consulates and propaganda agencies must leave the United States this month.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Assurances that officers and men of the National Guard now with the Army's field forces are ready and willing to remain in the service as long as the present emergency continues was given in a statement by Major Gen. John F. Williams, Chief of the National Guard Bureau, made public today by the War Department.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, July 5 -- German forces succeeded yesterday afternoon in thrusting around the headwaters of the Berezina River at Lepel, near the Berezina-Dvinsk Canal. The latest Russian communique said that "after strong air preparation the enemy succeeded in making our troops fall back several miles to the east."

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- When this country adopted its Declaration of Independence, it set up ideals which will always be a threat to dictators everywhere, because these ideals will always be a standing incitement to suppressed peoples everywhere to overthrow their masters, Robert H. Jackson, Attorney General, declared in an Independence Day address here today.

VICHY, France, July 4 -- A new flag outside the Embassy and an informal reception by the Ambassador, Admiral William D. Leahy, for the few Americans in Vichy were all that marked the Fourth of July. The observance was quiet also in Marseille, Lyon and Nice, the only other places in the unoccupied zone where the United States has diplomatic or consular representation.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- General George C. Marshall reported today that American overseas garrisons had been more than doubled as a part of an urgent effort to keep defenses in a state of readiness.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 4 -- The skirl of bagpipes relieved the rainy-day gloom in the Round Hill district here this afternoon as the Scottish games of the Round Hill Scottish Games Association were renewed after a year's lapse on the estate of Colonel Charles A. Moore.

Few facts have leaked out about Soviet Russia's Stalin Line, which the German advance is approaching, and there is no reliable basis on which to judge its strength. Here is the best available picture:

As the nation stood at the crossroads in a world aflame with war and conquest, Americans paused yesterday to celebrate the Fourth of July in the most solemn mood with which they had observed the day in many years.

The plan to issue tax-anticipation notes as an incentive to taxpayers to save up for next year's heavy income taxes is an excellent idea. Under the plan the Treasury will sell throughout the year interest-bearing notes which can be remitted in payment of taxes the following year.
VICHY, France, July 4 (AP) -- Today's communique of the Vichy Government follows:

The New York center of the National Catholic Community Service, which is cooperating with Jewish and Protestant agencies in the effort of the United Service Organizations to provide recreational facilities for soldiers and sailors, was opened yesterday in a three-story former residence building at 17 East Fifty-first Street.

NEWPORT, July 4 -- The Newport Clambake Club celebrated the Fourth with its first bake of the season and later with a trap shoot for a trophy offered by Secretary-Treasurer Daniel W. Jones, which was won by Bradford Norman Jr. There was a gathering of more than 100 members and guests at the bake.

The next two weeks should find the big game fishing season well under way. A dispatch from Nova Scotia indicates that the giant bluefin tuna are now in Lobster Bay near Wedgeport, and local offshore anglers daily report having sighted school tuna and broadbill swordfish.

THIS morning's book is particularly commended to Charles Lindbergh in the hope that it may relieve him of some of the notions behind that increasingly fallacious martyr complex he has been carting about the country. It is called "You Can't Do Business With Hitler,''* and it is an" authoritative and unblinking study of the felonious and piratical ways of Nazi trading.

TRENTON, N.J., July 4 (AP) -- Norman Frey, veteran driver from Lancaster, Pa., piloted Tommy Glennon's Wild Goose to a repeat victory in the Trenton Yacht Club's feature ten-mile free-for-all race for the Governor's Trophy today. Five thousand persons braved a steady downpour to watch the performance on the Delaware River.

TOKYO, July 4 (AP) -- Japan is considering an extension of the limits of her territorial waters which, in effect, would cut off Vladivostok, Russia's big Pacific port, from normal contact with the rest of the world and hamper shipments of United States material to the Soviet Union.

A bouquet of red, white and blue carnations was laid at the base of the Eternal Light flagstaff in Madison Square yesterday, as the climax of an hour-long noon observance of Independence Day, during which speakers touched upon the menace to democratic institutions in Nazi aggression and advocated aid to Great Britain.

LONDON, Saturday, July 5 -- Large forces of British bombers returned to Bremen in daylight yesterday for an attack that was delivered with hardly a pause from a blasting of that German port and industrial center by the Royal Air Force over Thursday night.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Douglas Fairbanks Jr., special envoy for President Roosevelt on a recent South American tour, assured radio listeners in this country tonight that the democratic ideal was strong in the countries he visited, but insisted that those who minimize the danger of Nazi invasion of the southern continent are living in a "false paradise."

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- R.G. Casey, Australian Minister to the United States, predicted today that the issue of the war would be "silently and fatefully decided in 1941," and urged the British and American peoples to attain "a workable, measure of cooperation" not only in the war but also in establishing the peace.

Post-Independence Day sermons will be preached tomorrow. The Russian situation will be discussed. Prayers of thanksgiving will be offered that here we still have the privilege of "life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness." Many religious organizations will use for conventions, retreats and conferences the long "holiday week-end."

WASHTNGTON, July 4 -- The explosive quality of new types of ammunition can be observed with safety at the Jefferson proving ground at Madison, Ind., through the use of bomb-proof shelters of special construction.

TOKYO, July 4 -- Emperor Hirohito received Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka and the War Minister, Lieut. Gen. Eiki Tojo, today. Later, Mr. Matsuoka conferred with Marquis Koichi Kido, Lord Keeper of the Privy Seal, who is consulted only on most important affairs of state.

CAMP UPTON, N.Y., July 4 -- The proposed opening during the coming week of the former Cliffton Hotel beach in Patchogue for the use of Camp Upton men, their families and friends is the latest act of hospitality shown by Suffolk County villages toward men stationed at the Yaphank Reservation since it was restored to use last Fall.

OGUNQUIT, Me., July 4 -- Dedication of a new $38,000 ship basin was a feature of Ogunquit's Fourth of July celebration today. Summer residents joined with natives in the opening of the new harbor, which will prove a boon to fishing and pleasure craft as well as providing a safe anchorage for coastal defense.

LONDON, July 4 (U.P.) -- Russian circles claimed tonight that the invading Germans had not yet met the main Soviet Army forces and asserted that in the first thirteen days of war Russian artillery and armored divisions had maintained an edge of two-to-one in losses and casualties inflicted on the enemy.

Most Americans will agree that our three principal objectives, in these critical days, should be:

MOSCOW, Saturday, July 5 -- The Red Army reported today the smashing of a great German effort to cross the Berezina River, strategic barrier on the road to Moscow where Napoleon lost thousands of soldiers in his retreat from the Russian capital 129 years ago.

Activities involving foreign ships seized under the Federal requisitioning order and also vessels commandeered by the government from private operators are increasing in the Port of New York, pointing to an early date for actual operation of this tonnage, it was disclosed yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The prevalent popular notion that in "keeping him guessing" the United States is outsmarting Hitler is a dangerous assumption on our part in these critical days. More probably we are keeping ourselves guessing, with confusion piled upon confusion, while the Nazi evil genius goes about his business.

"Ees" and Ease Time was bound to show up this business of the "ees" as really a habit-forming practice. After the trainees and the draftees and the selectees we now have looming on the horizon the beautiful word "detenees."
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 4 -- There was a round of entertaining throughout the day for holiday guests at various estates in the colony.

BRIDGETON, N.J., July 4 (AP) -- Winning first places in five of the ten events, John Borican, Negro star representing the Asbury Park (N.J.) A.C., captured the National A.A.U. decathlon championship with a total of 5,892 points today.

Contracts awarded in the first half of this year for engineering construction projects amounted to $2,841,403,000, the largest volume for a period of six months on record and 9 per cent greater than in the last half of last year and 104 per cent above the total for the first half of last year.

THE sprinkling system that operates on this globe is irksome at times. Too often it happens that when rain is needed, it doesn't come, and when rain isn't wanted, down it pours. Scientists have done wonderful things, but here is a simple matter that seems to be beyond their control.
SHANGHAI, July 4 (AP) -- Shanghai heard today that Japan, presumably in a deal with Germany, was preparing to move southward within two weeks against Southern French Indo-China and perhaps Thailand.

Ignace Paderewski was perhaps the most striking symbol of the New Order that came out of the last war. At a memorable meeting in the Metropolitan Opera House, a few years after the Peace Conference, he was acclaimed by Clemenceau as one of the chief architects of the Versailles system.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Negotiators of the United Mine Workers of America and the Southern Coal Operators Association stated today that "progress" had been made toward a final agreement, aiming to avert a strike of 150,000 miners called for Tuesday in the Southern Appalachian soft coal field.

Independence Day messages from the Chief Executives of Cuba, Argentina and Brazil were broadcast to the United States yesterday over a three-way short-wave hookup with the Columbia Broadcasting System here.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 4 -- Bermuda saw busy Americans knock off work today on defense bases to celebrate the Fourth. Only the most urgent work was continued as American civilians and service men under a broiling sun gave the day its due with baseball matches, picnics and ceremonies.

TORONTO, July 4 (Canadian Press) -- The market holiday in the United States had no effect on the Toronto Stock Exchange. The turnover of 118,000 shares was up to the average for recent weeks and prices held firm to strong. Base metals had narrow gains and other groups finished virtually unchanged.

FORT LEWIS, Wash., July 4 -- Picturesque cavalry charges, with horsemen brandishing sabers, may figure in communiques from the Russian front, but have no part in American Army tactics, it was said here today by officers of the 115th Cavalry (mechanized).

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority will go ahead with the development of the Fontana (N.C.) hydroelectric project on the Little Tennessee River under an agreement with the Aluminum Company of America, William S. Knudsen, Director General of the Office of Production Management, stated in a letter to Senator Truman made public today by Senator Truman.

BOSTON, July 4 -- Kept well off the pace until the final quarter mile, the Woodvale Farm's Our Boots came with, a rush in the stretch today to score a length decision before 35,000 at Suffolk Downs in the seventh running of the $25,000 added Yankee Handicap.
It was an indoor Fourth of July yesterday throughout most of the North Atlantic States, from Massachusetts to the Virginia Capes, and westward to the Ohio Valley.
ROME, July 4 -- A series of decrees for final solution of the Jewish question is expected to be approved by the Council of Ministers tomorrow or the first week in August at the latest.

"Cherry ripe, ripe, ripe, I cry. Full and fair ones -- come and buy!" sang Robert Herrick back in the merrie, old England of the seventeenth century. And some 300 years later, early each May, on the wide avenues and narrow lanes of Manhattan his cry is echoed by vendors whose pushcarts, laden with large, dark red cherries, bear vivid witness to the arrival of Spring.

BOSTON, July 4 (AP) -- Manuel Salvo cracked his ten-game losing string by defeating the Phillies, 4 -- 3, today, then Jim Tobin's two-hitter in the nightcap gave the Braves a 2-0 decision for a clean sweep of the twin bill and current series with the tail-enders.

For the eleventh consecutive year the Woodlawn Memorial Post 1024 of the American Legion conducted a patriotic rally at its headquarters, 305 East 235th Street, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon. The rally was scheduled to take place at the Woodlawn Memorial Monument at 238th Street and Van Cortlandt Park East, but the rain caused a change in plans.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 4 (U.P.) -- According to the newspaper Aftonbladet, the Russian radio announced that German troops had entered Tallinn, capital of Estonia, early today.

Two men who between them received all but a handful of the votes cast in last November's Presidential election spoke to the American people yesterday. On the one issue that overshadows all other issues they are, save for one detail, in complete agreement.

COLORADO SPRINGS, July 4 -- The defending champion, Bud Ward, put on a one-man fireworks show in the forty-second annual Western amateur golf tournament today, rocketing into tomorrow's semi-finals with two subpar victories.
DENVER, July 4 (U.P.) -- The nation's best golfers agreed tonight that spectacular golf should be the rule next week in the twenty-fourth P.G.A. tournament.

BERLIN, July 4 -- Claiming that major parts of the Russian armies had been trapped, beaten and destroyed in the first ten days of the invasion, German military quarters declared tonight that to all practical purposes -- Stalin Line or no Stalin Line -- the Soviet armies had already been defeated and that all that remained was to annihilate them as a military force.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 4 -- Hewing straight to the line and letting the chips and putts fall, W. Neal Fulkerson of the Garden City Golf Club gave golf a Fourth of July surprise by setting the pace for the field in the Lincoln memorial tournament at the Ekwanok Country Club.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 4 -- General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, soon to relinquish his post as Commander in Chief in the Middle East, in which he has won the greatest distinction of any British soldier in this war, discussed the war today in an informal interview that may be considered as his valedictory to the command he is leaving.

WEIRTON, W. Va., July 4 -- (AP) -- The Weirton Steel Company announced tonight that it would comply with all but two sections of a National Labor Relations Board order directing disestablishment of two employe representative organizations.

VICHY, France, July 4 -- After the capture of Tadmur, reported yesterday, another British motorized column that had been held in check for several days has succeeded through superior numbers in investing the desert center of Deir-ez Zor, according to the communique from the French Command in Syria tonight.

CLEVELAND, July 4 -- The Indians won two games today by the skin of the Tribal teeth, beating the Browns in the final innings of tooth contests, 9 to 8 and 3 to 2, and gained one game on the idle Yankees, whose lead over Cleveland now is two games.

CINCINNATI, July 4 (AP) -- Vince DiMaggio converted one fat fourth-inning pitch by Monte Pearson into a home-run skyrocket today to give Pittsburgh a 6-4 victory after Cincinnati had taken the opener, 6 to 0, behind Bucky Walters's six-hit hurling.
TOLEDO, Ohio, July 4 (AP) -- Peter Astra, winner of the 1939 Hambletonian Stakes, swept to a straight-heat triumph tonight in the evening program of the Grand Circuit meeting at Fort Miami.

VICHY, France, July 4 -- On the eve of the first anniversary of the assumption by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain of plenary power in France -- July 11 -- party strife seems to be reawakening. From the outset, Marshal Petain urged the French people to forget party politics and to think only of the country.

STANTON, Del., July 4 (AP) -- The seventh largest daily double pay-off in the United States returned a total of $5,507.70 to each of seven persons at Delaware Park today when two long shots, Forest Do and Sun Monia, won the first and second races on a sloppy track.

BERLIN, July 4 (U.P.) -- Destruction of thirty-seven British, bombers and fighters during R.A.F. attacks on Germany and occupied territory in the past twenty-four hours was reported officially tonight.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 4 -- Clever down-wind work in a dying wind enabled the distinguished yachtsman and designer Frank C. Paine to capture the Puritan Cup for the second time when his Gypsy went from a poor position to within a boat length of the first finisher in the Eastern Yacht Club's annual regatta.

WINNIPEG, July 4 (Canadian Press) -- Closing of the markets in Chicago owing to the holiday in the United States resulted in dull trade today on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange, and values of wheat features closed unchanged at 72 1/2 cents a bushel for the July, 74 7/8 for October.

FORT DIX, N.J., July 4 -- All leaves and furloughs for members of the Forty-fourth Division were canceled today by Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell, commanding general, effective July 16 and until further notice, to enable the division to leave here for two weeks of manoeuvres in Caroline County, Va.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 4 (AP) -- Except for the besieged Italian garrison at Gondar, Northern Ethiopia, and a small Italian force dispersed in the wilderness southwest of Assab, Eritrea, all Italian East Africa has been cleaned up by British Imperial forces and their native comrades-in-arms, the Middle East Command announced today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 4 -- While rain washed out many other Independence Day sports, the Larchmont Yacht Club's sixtieth annual regatta was carried on this afternoon with eighty-five craft competing out on Long Island Sound.
LOS ANGELES, July 4 (AP) -- Seven craft started in the biennial yacht race to Honolulu at noon today, with the Escapade, a sloop owned by Walter Elliott of Long Beach, taking the lead.

Pig Tails, at $21.40 for $2, captured the $7,600 Demoiselle Stakes at Empire City yesterday through mud and rain as 23,710 looked on. Handled by Jack Skelly, the lad who gained such popularity at Aqueduct, Hal Price Headley's home-bred daughter of Hollyrood and Mammy's Girl scored by half a length in a hard drive.
LONDON, July 4 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

ASUNCION, Paraguay, July 4 -- The military garrison of Pilar attempted to revolt against the government today but the seditious movement was promptly quelled, its leaders having either been arrested or obliged to flee.

BUFFALO, July 4 (U.P.) -- Senators Pepper of Florida and Wheeler of Montana, respective champions of intervention and non-intervention, debated America's foreign policy today at the closing session of the Townsend Clubs here.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), July 4 -- After a firm opening today the stock market fluctuated and had a tendency toward weakness, owing to profit-taking operations and a lessening of demand. Before the close, however, there was a sharp rally in domestic issues and industrials were firmer.

MANILA, July 4 -- The United States neutrality patrol has withheld temporarily the clearance of the freighter Noshima Maru with a cargo of 6,000 tons of Philippine chrome ore destined for the United States via Japanese ports, pending developments in Japan's sudden move recalling vessels carrying cargo bound for the United States.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of last Saturday John E. Lancaster commented on Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page's score of 67 made at the Sedgefield C.C. in Greensboro, N.C., last June 10. He also referred to Mrs. Opal Hill's score of 66 made in the Missouri women's championship on Sept. 1, 1937.

Count Ciano's newspaper II Telegrafo of Leghorn finds one likeness between Communist Russia and the "Anglo-Saxon plutocracy." In the United States and Britain, as in Russia, women wear pants. Some good American hearts may momentarily throb in sympathy with the Fascists on this score.

For the benefit of the thousands of students attending Summer sessions at Columbia and other universities, which open Monday morning, the churches on Morningside Heights will hold special services with widely known clergymen in charge.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 4 -- Rioting and looting have broken out among native troops and civilians in Beirut and disorders are spreading through the native quarters of the city, it was reported by high neutral foreign diplomatic sources here tonight.

DETROIT, July 4 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox prevented the champion Detroit Tigers from getting into the American League's first division at the traditional holiday milestone by dividing a double bill today before 40,068 spectators.

Following is the text of a fifteen-minute address on "The Significance of Independence Day" that was recorded by Wendell Willkie Thursday night in the studios of the National Broadcasting Company, translated by its international division into six languages and broadcast to the world yesterday:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 4 -- An increase of 36 per cent in the number of patrolmen guarding New York City's watersheds, which extend through eight counties and into the foothills of the Catskills, was announced today by Lawrence H. Tierney, assistant secretary of the New York Board of Water Supply and superintendent of watershed police.

State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by seventy-three divisions aggregates $9,629,865, compared with $7,650,026 this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date stands at $34,842,482.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 4 (AP) -- British General Headquarter for the Middle East issued this communique today:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 4 -- Preston Sturges has been assigned by Paramount to direct "Take a Letter, Darling," a comedy by George Beck which will feature Fred MacMurray and Frank Macdonald, late of "Lady in the Dark." Shooting will start as soon as Sturges completes editing "Sullivan's Travels," which is now before the cameras.

LENOX, Mass., July 4 -- Members and guests of the Lenox Club, 200 altogether, attended the sixty-seventh annual Independence Day luncheon. Among those who had guests were Giraud Foster, president of the club, who is in his ninety-first year; Mrs. David T. Dana, Mrs. Anson Phelps Stokes, Mrs. Owen Johnson, Miss M. Symphorosa Bristed, Mrs. Ramsay Hoguet, Mrs. Newbold Morris and Victor Elting.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: It appears that the Western crews are making things look rather one-sided at Poughkeepsie, and the effect on Eastern morale and interest is not softened any by the glowing accounts in the sports columns of the so-called invincible crews from the West.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: People are entitled to personal opinions, but Arthur Daley ceased being a reporter and became a critic -- and a most unjust and ignorant one, in my humble opinion -- when he judged walking to be a "dreary travesty on competition" in his mention of the 3,000-meter walk at the National A.A.U. championships.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- The Cubs took both ends of a doubleheader with the Cardinals today, 6 to 5, and 5 to 2, to drop the St. Louis team one game behind the Dodgers, who were idle because of rain. The Cards and Brooklyn had been tied for first place in the National League standing.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The dedication on July 1 of "John Finley Walk" on the upper East River Drive, recalls an incident in Dr. Finley's life illustrative of his love of walking. It was in 1900, the year he was called to Princeton to become the first incumbent of the new chair of politics in the university.

As of yesterday, there were sixty-three Summer theatres registered with Actors Equity, plus ten rotating stock offerings. At the height of the season a year ago the total was seventy-eight. This doesn't mean, however, that there are fewer Summer places this year; at least three have non-Equity performers and three others have special dispensations from the actors' union.

On the very day that Hitler invaded Soviet Russia, this suddenly ceased, in the opinion of the American communists, to be an "imperialist war" and became a life-and-death struggle between fascism and democracy. The communists and fellow-travelers are now using many of the same phrases as those who believe in American democracy and liberalism, and for the moment are working for some of the same ends.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 4 -- Drafting a number of private indoor courts in the surrounding countryside to circumvent a second day of rain, the tennis committee of the Nassau Country Club succeeded in completing the first round of competition today in the annual invitation tournament.

The Germans declare they have crossed the Berezina River, which a century ago ran red with the blood of Napoleon's men, and have passed another milestone on the long road to Moscow. The Russians, however, contend that all attempted crossings have been smashed.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 4 -- The democracies which won the last World War and lost the peace were called upon today by speakers at the University of Virginia Institute, to decide in the light o that experience and make known the kind of post-war world they wanted.

MOSCOW, July 4 (AP) -- First reports of guerrilla activity since Premier Joseph Stalin called for nation-wide warfare of this type said today that in one German-occupied section of the Soviet Union a guerrilla party had blown up a train loaded with munitions for German artillery as it moved toward the front.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 4 -- From the scant news reaching here today about land operations in Finland, it becomes more and more evident that Finnish-German troops are delaying their expected attack against Russia on the Karelian Isthmus until the German Armies from the Baltic States are nearer Leningrad and they can join in a pincers operation.
