BERLIN, July 7 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of June 30 shows the following changes compared with that of June 14, in thousands of marks:

ROME, July 7 -- Americans learned this morning that from now on they would receive only 18 lire per dollar, instead of the previous "misto lire" rate of 25, which was available for personal expenditures. The new rate is even worse than the official internal ate, which is 19.
Mrs. Henrietta S. Allison of Elizabeth is visiting friends in Elmira, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended July 2 aggregated $12,565,000,000.

Three members of the City College staff who have admitted they formerly were Communists identified Arthur R. Brauhlich Jr., tutor in English at the college, yesterday as having been an active member of the Communist unit on the campus.

The Chase National Bank, as trustee for the estate of William P. Aldrich, sold the four-story apartment house at 56-58 Newkirk Street, Jersey City, N.J., to the Ridgefield Realty Corporation of New York. The building is on a plot 50 by 105 feet, contains twenty apartments and brings in a monthly rental of $869.

The first of a series of examinations conducted by the New York City Civil Service Commission to test the qualifications of a growing army of civilian technical and mechanical workers who have volunteered to serve in Britain was held yesterday at the commission's offices, 299 Broadway.
WASHINGTON. July 7 -- The War Department released the following orders, today, dated July 5:

The combination of intermittent rains and a large holiday population swelled attendances at most of the major first-run motion-picture houses on Broadway to record proportions over the week-end, it was reported by theatre managements yesterday.
William Church Osborn was elected as the eighth president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday afternoon at a special meeting of the board of trustees. He succeeds the late George Blumenthal.

DETROIT, July 7 -- For the second time in nine months this industrial metropolis of the Midwest tonight found itself playing host to baseball's outstanding figures. Sox shortstop, went out of action with a damaged knee yesterday and was taken off the list. As the American Leaguers had named three other shortstops in their original selections, Baker decided to fill the vacancy with another pitcher, naming Dutch Leonard, knuckleball specialist of the Senators.

Compasses went wild and transatlantic radio reception was impossible for hours during the last week-end, and all because spots appeared on the sun, 93,000,000 miles away. No doubt mariners must have noted the occasional strange behavior or their compass needles long before Galileo discovered spots on the sun; but it was not until the telegraph, the transatlantic cable and radio were introduced that sunspots began to interfere with the lives of business men.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- A comprehensive program to prevent interruption of international radio and cable communications between this country and other nations has been completed, James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Defense Communications Board, announced today.

Influenced largely by the strength in securities and commodity markets generally, prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced yesterday 30 to 34 points, or $1.50 to $l.70 a bale, on heavy buying by the trade and speculative interests.

Tax-Anticipation Notes Though the sale of tax-anticipation notes by the Treasury to taxpayers is not scheduled to begin until Aug. 1, many banks in this city and in the State are preparing to handle these new securities as they now handle Defense Savings Bonds, namely, as a public service, without reimbursement for expenses incurred.

Consideration of "our post-war purposes" is urged in a letter received yesterday by the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, 8 West Fortieth Street, from thirty prominent Britons, who suggest that there should be an early exchange of views between the American and British peoples.

Officials of eleven local housing authorities will be in the market this month with a total of $30,094,000 of short-term obligations, it was announced yesterday. Ten of the issues, aggregating $29,474,000, will be offered for sale on July 15, while the eleventh, consisting of $620,000 of Denver, Col., Housing Authority notes, due Feb. 10, 1942, will be sold on July 22.
George Aubrey Hastings received the Republican nomination last night for Representative from the Fourteenth Congressional District. This is the post left vacant by the death of M. Michael Edelstein.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 7 -- Today, for the second time within a week, a British general broke the silence hitherto maintained by British leaders as to how far the United States must go if Germany is to be defeated by giving his personal opinion that the war could not be really and permanently won without United States man power on the European battlefield.
BERLIN, July 8 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today, dated "The Fuehrer's Headquarters":
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Sabin have arrived from Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., and are at the Ritz-Carlton.

The war has reached two major crises. As the greatest campaign in military history approaches its climax in Western Russia, a small force of United States sailors and marines landed in Iceland, 600 statute miles from German-occupied Norway.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), July 8 -- The Bourse was steady today owing to profit-taking and a smaller turnover. Domestic industrial shares were generally irregular. A.K.U. rose 1 1/4 points to 141 1/4. Philips Lamps and Unilever were almost unchanged.

BERLIN, July 8 (U.P.) -- D.N.B., the official news agency, said tonight that eight British Spitfire fighter planes were shot down in afternoon air battles along the Channel coast, boosting to twenty-six the number of British planes destroyed since last midnight.

The report of American Export Lines, Inc., covering the March quarter, shows a net profit of 52,654,188, including excess profits subject to possible recapture, but after depreciation, interest and Federal income taxes, compared with $1,200,037 in the first quarter of 1940.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 8 -- The Eastern clay court tennis championship final, scheduled for this afternoon at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, was chased all the way to the Piping Rock Club today by a rainstorm that fell just as Frankie Parker and Gene Mako made ready to start play.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 8 -- Weary and footsore soldiers of the Thirty-fifth Division's "doghouse" battalion, paying the penalty for whistling and calling to girls wearing shorts on a Memphis golf course, alternately hiked and rode through Arkansas today on their way back to Camp Robinson.

ALBANY, July 8 -- The sixteenth Army induction call for 1,249 registrants to report between July 28 and Aug. 8 was issued today by Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State director of the selective service. It calls upon up-State boards to furnish 645 white and 30 Negro registrants for induction at Buffalo, and 550 white and 24 Negro selectees to be delivered at Fort Jay, New York City.

LONDON, Wednesday, July 9 -- The Royal Air Force gave the Germans another impressive display of its rapidly growing might during the past twenty-four hours. Continuing what have now become unremitting day and night attacks, large forces of British planes clawed at numerous enemy points all Monday night and during daylight yesterday, spreading havoc wherever they went.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 8 -- With 1,800 educators here from this and foreign countries, particularly Canada and the Latin-American republics, today was set aside for the United States at the international conference of the New Education Fellowship.

British troops in Iceland were amazed at the quality and quantity of American equipment landed in Iceland by United States Marines, a National Broadcasting Company observer in Reykjavik, the capital, said over the NBC blue network last night in the first broadcast to come from Iceland since President Roosevelt announced occupation of the island by American forces.

"Time Out for Rhythm," a Columbia musical featuring Rudy Vallee, Ann Miller, Rosemary Lane, Allen Jenkins, Joan Merrill, the Three Stooges, Brenda and Cobina and Glen Gray and his orchestra, which will arrive at the Rialto, is this morning's sole film newcomer.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 8 (AP) -- Finnish Military Headquarters issued the following communique tonight:

Production of crude oil in the United States last week averaged 3,658,200 barrels daily, a decrease of 189,050 below the 3,847,250 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 188,900 barrels below the estimated requirements of 3,847,100 daily for July as calculated by the Bureau of Mines.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 8 -- Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, runnerup to Frank Parker here a year ago, advanced to the third round of the ninth annual Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament today as play started on the clay courts of the Bathing and Tennis Club.

QUITO, Ecuador, July 8 -- A tense Ecuadorian-Peruvian border situation hung fire today while this government awaited mediation action by the United States, Argentina and Brazil. Officials said no direct negotiations were going on with Peru.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Secretary Ickes said today that he had sent a letter to Congress denying that his refusal to grant additional hydro-electric power to the Aluminum Company of America had slowed up aluminum production.
John D. Rockefeller Jr. revealed in a radio address last night the ten "fundamental and eternal principles" by which "my wife and I have tried to bring up our family."

Conferences among Democratic leaders on the Mayoralty campaign started yesterday with an informal talk between Frank Kelly, Kings County leader, and Edward J. Flynn, leader of the Bronx and Democratic National Chairman. Today the Tammany leader, Christopher D. Sullivan, is to have a similar talk with Mr. Flynn.

LOS ANGELES, July 8 -- The National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs adopted a recommendation today to continue support of the equal rights amendment. One of the practical forms of that support, Dr. Minnie L. Maffet, president of the group, said, lies in vigorous efforts to persuade Congress to disinter the amendment from committee, where it was buried after its introduction some seventeen years ago.

SMITHTOWN BRANCH, L.I., July 8 -- Charles William (Bill) Brenner, son of Assistant District Attorney Harry C. Brenner of Suffolk County, did not get a ticket today although he drove nearly 400 feet across and against traffic along the Jericho Turnpike here, hit five parked cars, sent one up on the curb and caused a 9-year-old girl to bruise her left side.

A compact package containing the tempting possibility of a golden brown crumb cake is the stream-lined device of an ingenius New Jersey woman. This neat box holds a white powder with hidden but almost magical potentialities. Add two-thirds to one cup of cold water to the contents, beat briskly, pour into an eight-inch pan, sprinkle lightly with crumbs and bake the mixture for a brief twenty minutes.

A call to the New York State Legislature to enact a statute that would protect dress manufacturers from design piracy, and suggestions for a general form of the law, were contained in an opinion yesterday by Federal Judge Robert A. Inch.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Colonel Robert Olds, chief of the new Army Air Corps Ferrying Command, received today the bronze trophy and medal of the International League of Aviators for his contribution to aviation.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Use of tank cars and ocean tankers to bring crude oil and petroleum products to the Eastern Seaboard States is showing its effect already in the fight to cope with the shortage of the products, Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator for National Defense, stated today.

Boys' apparel manufacturers face a difficult problem at present in attempting to reconcile the demands of their customers with the regulations issued by the Federal Trade Commission under the new Wool Labeling Act which goes into effect July 14, manufacturers said yesterday at the opening of the twelfth annual convention of the Boys' Apparel Manufacturers' Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, July 8 -- The British Government, which has been plagued by many of the same production problems that have harassed the United States, today announced through Minister of Labor Ernest Bevin in the House of Commons a new scheme of joint labor-employer boards.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Senator James F. Byrnes was sworn in at the White House today as an associate justice of the Supreme Court in the presence of President Roosevelt and high officials of the several branches of the government.

Emphasizing that American occupation of Iceland resulted from "free and friendly agreement," Thor Thora, Icelandic Consul General in New York, said yesterday that the action of the United States would be welcomed by the people of his nation.

CINCINNATI, July 8 (AP) -- United States District Judge Robert R. Nevin awarded today a judgment of $526,645 to the Henry L. Doherty estate of New York against the Fifth Third Union Trust Company and the defunct Cosmopolitan Bank and Trust Company, which closed in June, 1930.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Unimpressed by reports that the Axis powers consider American occupation of Iceland as this country's entrance into the operations area of the European war, President Roosevelt reiterated today the intention of this government to act outside of the strictly defined Western Hemisphere if and when necessary in the interest of defense.
LIMA, Peru, July 8 (U.P.) -- The Peruvian Government, in a note to Ecuador, today disaffirmed responsibility for the border fighting.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Army Air Corps has established a transport service to carry officials directly between this country and British landing fields.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Pressure by the government to keep furniture prices down evoked assurances of cooperation from officers of the National Retail Furniture Association at the annual president's breakfast here today in the American Furniture Mart and a survey on behalf of Merchandise Mart tenants showing that advances had been far less than the increase in manufacturing costs.

Payments by life insurance companies to policyholders and beneficiaries for the year to date passed the billion-dollar mark, according to the monthly report of the Institute of Life Insurance to be made public today.

Only a few days passed after Hungary had declared war on Russia when there were reports of explosions in a munitions dump at Nagy-Teteny and fire in the Almasfuzito petroleum refinery. Simultaneously came a dispatch from Rumania saying that all Rumanians had evacuated all Jews from Moldavia and Southern Bukovina as a precautionary measure against sabotage.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 7:
MOSCOW, July 8 (AP) -- The following is the section of the Russian communique dealing with individual exploits and with subjects not strictly military:

ANKARA, Turkey, July 8 -- German sources here report that a large British army is being concentrated in Iraq along the Iranian border, and it is clear that the Nazis are preparing to accuse the British of aggressive intentions against that Middle Eastern land.

FORT DIX, N.J., July 8 -- Offering a more formidable appearance than the dummy wooden tanks of the Nazis are sixty dummy 37-mm. anti-tank guns being constructed here by the 119th Ordnance Company to overcome shortages in training weapons for the Forty-Fourth Division's use during manoeuvres in Virginia late this month.

Dillon, Read Co. headed a small group of investment firms which yesterday offered a block of 40,290 shares of capital stock of the National City Bank of New York at $28.50 each. This offering represented one of the largest transactions in bank stocks consummated in this market in some time.

For a hundred years neither Peru nor Ecuador has known exactly how large they were. The territorial controversy between the two nations, the only one on the South American continent still unsettled, is more than a boundary dispute, for the sparsely populated area involved includes the greater part of Ecuador.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 8 (AP) -- The Rochester Red Wings beat the Newark Bears tonight, 4 -- 1, as Hank Gornicki scattered eight hits for his seventh victory. The Wings gathered five off Johnny Johnson and added the rest against Relief Pitcher Fred Frankhouse.

The Pierpont Morgan Library at Madison Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street is a public library and as such is exempt from New York City real estate taxes, Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin ruled yesterday. His decision invalidated the attempt of the La Guardia administration to deny exemption to the library as not truly a public institution, in line with the Mayor's policy of holding tax exemptions to a minimum.

UPPER DARBY, Pa., July 8 (AP) -- The Farm Security Administration of the United States Department of Agriculture today adopted a four-point plan to aid immediately milk producers whose hay and grain crops were cut to critical levels by the drought.

Horace W. Stokes, formerly president of the publishing house of Frederick A. Stokes and since it was taken over by J.B. Lippincott on May 16 its treasurer and director, has resigned from the concern, it was made known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (U.P.) -- Plans for the defense of Hawaii's civilian population in the event of an attack have been perfected, Hawaiian officials said tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- President Roosevelt today read to his press conference a letter with "an appealing human interest viewpoint received June 29 from an unnamed resident of Missouri. The letter told the writer's pride in being an American.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 7 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

The production of manufactured goods in Australia for England's war effort has been "far beyond all expectations," Francis W. Leake, a member of the British Purchasing Commission who has been working there and in India under the direction of the British Ministry of Supply since last August, said yesterday before leaving this city for England aboard the Yankee Clipper.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A new plan to assure delivery of machine tools where they are most needed was announced today by E.R. Stettinius Jr., director of priorities. Its purpose was stated as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- A new warning against communism, prepared by Representative J. Parnell Thomas of Allendale, N.J., before he was stricken ill, was put in The Congressional Record today by Representative Gordon Canfield of Paterson.

Formation of a committee for holders of bonds of the Dallas Levee Improvement District was announced yesterday. The committee is composed of C.K. Baxter, John G. Getz Jr. and Kenneth M. Keefe, chairman. W.D. Bradford is secretary.

Nazi defenses against the nightly and daily forays of the R.A.F. upon cities in Germany and the occupied countries of Western Europe appear to be growing stronger, and the Luftwaffe was able on Monday night to deliver a heavy counter-stroke against Southampton, after a lull which lasted nearly a month.

Completely out of our flesh-and-blood world were the "Ersatz" models that displayed fashions yesterday in a suite at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Usually inhabitants of the static cosmos of store windows where they quietly assume fashionable poses for days on end, a few of the tribe of plaster and plastic manikins created by Cora Scovil, in gowns designed by Helen Cookman, greeted guests who attended the opening of the temporary showrooms for Scovil manikins.

BERLIN, July 8 -- The occupation of Iceland by United States troops provoked no surprise in official German quarters, as such an eventuality was apparently anticipated over the week-end as a result of predictions reported back from Washington.

LONDON, July 8 -- In a radio appeal by Maxim Litvinoff, Russia tonight urged Great Britain to hurl her full weight against Germany in the West while the Red Army withstood the shock of the Nazi war machine in the East and thus force Adolf Hitler to wage war on two fronts.
DETROIT, July 8 -- The play-by-play description of the ninth annual All-Star game in Briggs Stadium today follows:
MOSCOW, July 8 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 8 -- Eleven residents of the Ryan Park area of Rye appealed to Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis today for an injunction to stop the operation late at night of two large roller coasters and the "octopus" at Playland, Westchester County's amusement center, just east of Ryan Park.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 8 (U.P.) -- Military representatives of American nations at ceremonies here tomorrow in connection with the celebration of Argentina's independence anniversary are planning to hold conferences on hemispheric defense, General Pedro Aurelio de Goes Monteiro, Chief of Staff of the Brazilian Army, revealed tonight.

BATON ROUGE, La., July 8 (AP) -- Louisiana is again torn by political strife nearly as bitter as that which broke the power of the Huey P. Long machine eighteen months ago, and with the participants and issues virtually the same.

DETROIT, July 8 -- No scene that could be conjured up in Hollywood could match the affectionate display for Ted Williams in the American League clubhouse today after the Red Sox outfielder's home-run blast in the ninth inning had brought victory to his league in the ninth annual All-Star game at Briggs Stadium.

After establishing gains of 30 to 35 points in the afternoon, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange in the late dealings reacted yesterday, and final quotations reflected net gains of no more than 11 to 19 points for the day. At their test level for the session, however, prices were the highest since 1930, and all months from the December forward were above the 15 1/2-cent mark.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 9 (AP) -- A Russian communique issued today said that Russian forces in the Novograd Volynsk area were repulsing a German tank offensive in hard fighting.

The possibility that Japan may have called in her ships from the Atlantic side of the Panama Canal to have them on the way home before the Ship Control Bill now before Congress becomes law, was advanced here yesterday by importers and exporters who have speculated about the cause of the Japanese action since the recall became generally known last week.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., July 8 -- Albert S. Pinkus, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, who is leading the field in the masters tournament on the Municipal Pier here, was paired tonight with Ariel Mengarini of Washington in the fifth round.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- President Roosevelt was reported tonight to have told legislative leaders that he is opposed to compulsory arbitration of labor disputes and to the May bill authorizing the use of the armed forces to break strikes in defense industries.

Richard Whitney, formerly a millionaire, sportsman and president of the New York Stock Exchange, will be released Aug. 11 on parole from Sing Sing Prison where he has served three years and three months for grand larceny, the State Board of Pardons decided yesterday.
LONDON, July 8 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique today said:
Record June sales capped the greatest sales volume of General Motors cars and trucks for any first half in the corporation's history, according to the monthly report issued yesterday.

Sidetracked Two of the three issues facing the New York Stock Exchange have been sidetracked. The matter of a changed commission schedule now awaits a special study which is being made by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Temporary Assignments DEPUTY CHIEF INSPECTOR Michael A. Wall, Brooklyn East Headquarters, assigned in command of Brooklyn West and Richmond Headquarters, in addition to his other duties, for 9 days, from 8 A.M., July 10, during the absence of Deputy Chief Inspector on vacation.

An underwriting group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., was the successful bidder yesterday for 590,527 shares of common stock of the San Diego Gas and Electric Company, owned by the Standard Gas and Electric Company. The group's winning tender was $13.427 a share.

BERLIN, July 8 -- It is not possible to judge from Berlin tonight whether or not the drive of the National Socialist legions to the east met a check along the Stalin Line. Interestingly, however, today's German High Command communique devotes a mere eight German words to the Russian, theatre, when it declares:

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Congressional sources disclosed today that they expected President Roosevelt within the next few days to ask for additional defense funds, possibly as much as $5,000,000,000 or $6,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Stephen Early, President Roosevelt's secretary, charged today that Senator Wheeler of Montana, endangered the lives of American bluejackets and marines by telling the world of the impending occupation of Iceland at a time when the forces were actually on the seas.

DETROIT, July 8 -- Coming up with a last-minute electrifying charge that floored a foe at the very moment he appeared to have a signal triumph within his grasp, the American League snatched victory from defeat today. Scoring four runs in the last half of the ninth inning, the Harridge forces overcame the National League, 7 to 5, in the ninth annual All-Star game.

GARRISON, N.Y., July 8 -- Lisburne Grange, the country home of Mrs. Samuel Sloan here, will be the setting Saturday afternoon for a large garden party for the benefit of United China Relief. Dr. Hu-Shih, the Chinese Ambassador, is expected to speak.

The enrollment of volunteer airraid wardens continued at a brisk pace yesterday with 3,674 persons, including 3,318 men and 356 women, registering at the city's police stations. The total for the nineteen days of the drive reached 43,005, of which 36,125 are men and 6,880 are women.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 9 (AP) -- The Soviet communique early today follows:

Despite the fact that next Monday is the deadline set by the Treasury Department for all banks of the nation to return filled-out questionnaires, Form TFR-300, giving detailed information on all foreign accounts handled by them, no bank in this district, where most of the foreign business is done, has received a copy of the questionnaire.
Several leases for space in buildings in Fifth and Park Avenues were among the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday.

More discipline in American education and the abandonment of the emphasis on individuals in favor of a program that would teach cooperation and the following of strong, youthful leaders was advocated yesterday by Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, as a means of combating the totalitarian threat to the American way of life.

A volume market for a hundred British products in nine major categories has been discovered in the United States in a study by committees of American retail experts which was forwarded yesterday to the Industrial and Export Council of the British Board of Trade.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 9 (AP) -- A Russian communique contained the following section on Red Army exploits:
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Ill-assorted effects following in the train of certain governmental domestic policies have been exemplified in the milk strike on the local agricultural front.

Gregor Piatigorsky, Russian 'cellist, was the soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. Eugene Goossens conducted and the program was the one originally scheduled for Monday night.

Mrs. Isabella Greenway King, formerly Representative at Large from Arizona, was announced yesterday as the new chairman of the board of the American Women's Voluntary Services, with headquarters at 1 East Fifty-seventh Street. The organization, which was founded by Mrs. Alice T. McLean, is one of the largest women's units active in defense work.

Chick Meehan's venture into the field of pugilistic promotion suffered a setback when rain caused the postponement of the all-star card the former New York University football coach had scheduled for Ebbets Field last night. The card, headed by a ten-round contest between Tami Mauriello, Bronx light heavyweight, and Steve Mamakos of Washington, will be presented tonight.

The "dream horse," Sky Raider, won for C.V. Whitney through mud and rain at Empire City yesterday and sustained those who feel that the cross of Man o' War and Top Flight is one of the greatest possible in breeding and racing. With Alfred Robertson in the saddle, the black colt dashed past the finish line a length to the good at the end of the short six furlongs.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- The Calumet Farm Stable entry of Sun Again and Some Chance passed their final test for Saturday's $50,000 Arlington Futurity by running one-three in the Brookfield Purse at Arlington Park today.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Defense officials held the first of a series of conferences today with representatives of consumers' durable goods industries in an effort to determine where priorities are pinching, whether there will be any labor displacement owing to shortages of materials, and to obtain information necessary to provide the base for an over-all system of rationing of materials.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, July 9 -- After the Germans had shown great reserve in their communique yesterday, the Russians reported early today that the Red Army had met with success at several points on the long Eastern European front.
Three requisitioned Italian freighters in Southern ports have been ordered sent to drydock for repair and will fee assigned to service on the North Atlantic, it was reported here yesterday.

PURCHASE, N.Y., July 8 -- T. George Tracy of Gedney and his son, T. George Jr., tall, well built and 20, showed the way today in Westchester County's father-and-son golf championship, sixteenth in the series.

MADRID, Spain, July 8 -- The next few days may clear up some outstanding problems between Spain and the United States, in particular the question of Spanish credits frozen in the United States, it was learned today. Most of the discussions concerning the impounded credits have taken place in Washington, but there have been informed contacts here -- thus far without results -- in an effort to establish a common ground.

The failure of the Administration to demand or of Congress to provide any net economies in nondefense expenditures for the current fiscal year is the greatest single weakness in the nation's effort to maintain economic stability in the rearmament period. Employment is increasing, prices are rising; we are planning this year to spend the record total of $22,269,000,000.

James V. Mangano, Sheriff of Kings County, was elected a member of the State Democratic Committee last night by county committee members in the Eighth Assembly District, Brooklyn. The vote, taken at a special meeting in the United Democratic Club, 359 Union Street, presided over by John J. Dorman, chairman of the Kings County Democratic Committee, makes Sheriff Mangano Democratic leader of the district.

TOKYO, July 8 -- The stationing of American naval forces in Iceland to replace the British is regarded in Japanese political and military circles as a decisive step through which the United States entered hostilities so a clash between Germany and the United States is expected soon, Domei, the semi-official Japanese news agency, reported today.

MONTREAL, July 8 (AP) --The Montreal Royals and the Jersey City Giants divided a double-header tonight, with the Giants making sixteen hits to win the nightcap, 13 -- 4, after dropping the opener, 5 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The total authorized defense program from June 11, 1940, to June 30, 1941, was $46,914,000,000, of which, up to June 15, $20,960,000,000 had been contracted for, and $6,556,000,000 had been expended, the Office for Emergency Management said today.
A vote to call a "recess" in the eight-day-old milk strike up-State promised last night that deliveries to New York City would return to normal soon.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 8 (U.P.) -- Russian troops tonight were reported to be stubbornly resisting attempts of German and Finnish forces to drive across the Arctic forests to Kandalaska at the top of the White Sea along the important Leningrad-Murmansk railroad.

Drexel Co. head an underwriting group that will offer today to the public at $13.75 a share 225,000 shares of Indianapolis Water Company Class A common stock of a par value of $10.50 a share. This will be the first time that the public has had an opportunity to participate on any large scale in the ownership of the company.

VICHY, France, July 8 -- The new French State, directed by a positive authority, should be based on "true liberty" and not on "theoretical liberty," Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, the Chief of State, declared today in opening the session of the National Council's Commission that is to recommend a new French construction.
The First National Bank of Pittsburgh yesterday won the award of an issue of $1,000,000 of temporary loan notes of Allegheny County, Pa. The bank purchased the notes at 0.333 per cent.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 8 -- Resuming weekly one-day tournaments, which had been discontinued for a month because of sectional and district championships, the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association began its Summer schedule with a competition that drew a large field of 112 contestants to the North Hempstead Country Club today.

SHANGHAI, July 8 (AP) -- Major Kunio Akiyama, Japanese Army spokesman, said "the United States Navy did not send its forces to Iceland for a Summer outing; the occupation is a long stride toward war by Roosevelt."

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Fairly general buying of wheat futures, led by houses with Eastern connections, carried prices today to new high levels for the season. Reports that sales of flour exceeded 250,000 barrels and strength in other commodities had considerable influence on sentiment.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 8 -- Australian troops in the coastal sector of Syria have now occupied all Vichy defense positions south of the town of Damour and north of the Wadi el Kadi without undertaking more than long-range fighting.

DETROIT, July 8 -- Stanley Hack, the fair-haired boy of the Chicago Cubs, collaborated with Rapid Robert Feller of Cleveland in getting the All-Star ball game under way. Feller pitched. Hack struck out. Apparently Stanley never saw the ball; he just got wind of it.

A proposal for a $1,000,000,000 freight-car building pool is to be presented tday to Ralph Budd, transportation commissioner of the advisory commission to the Council of National Defense, and to J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads.

The Colgate-Larsen Aircraft Company announced yesterday that it was making a major revision in production so as to permit it to double the volume of its defense work. Gilbert Colgate, president, said the company would revise its sheet-metal and welding operations for volume production of wing tips, engine mounts, pontoons and other items.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 8 -- Foreign Minister Enrique Ruiz Guinazu again displayed great activity today in his efforts to bring about effective diplomatic intervention in Lima and Quito before the clash between Peru and Ecuador develops into a fullfledged war.

MARK down on your pending reading list Helen MacInnes's thriller called "Above Suspicion."* Put * * after it, for that matter, if you can abide thrillers at all. I can't, as a rule, but this one seems to be A-1 and fairly wonderful, even unto some terrific business about a big, black, stolen, swastika-hung Mercedes, a series of forged passports and a fierce and ultimately spitted dog.

The Guaranty Trust Company announced yesterday that Robert H. Craft, second vice president, has been transferred to the bank's government bond department. The department will be under the joint supervision of Arthur H. Kiendl, second vice president, and Mr. Craft.
LONDON, July 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of former Soviet Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff's broadcast from Moscow tonight to the British and American people, as transcribed in London:

The Guaranty Trust Company announced yesterday that Robert H. Craft, second vice president, has been transferred to the bank's government bond department. The department will be under the joint supervision of Arthur H. Kiendl, second vice president, and Mr. Craft.

ROME, July 8 -- The United States' occupation of Iceland was called this morning "a genuine intervention in European waters to create a vast zone where supplies can safely navigate." This comment came from the customary political circles and hence it was not strictly official.

CLEVELAND, July 8 -- In a resolution intended to give support to John L. Lewis, former president of the C.I.O., in his attack on Sidney Hillman, associate director of the Office of Production Management, the National Maritime Union charged today that "reactionary labor leaders" were "selling out the American workers as part of the defense program."

VICHY, France, July 8 -- Government circles today disclaimed any knowledge of reports published in the Paris newspapers of offers of armistice terms to High Commissioner Dentz in Syria. It was stated that in any case they have not been considered, as General Dentz has made no report of them to the government here.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- This year' cotton crop may be one of the smallest in twenty years, production, authorities said today in commenting on a report of the Department of Agriculture that the 1941 harvested acreage might be the smallest since 1895.

Members of the City Council committee investigating civil service threatened yesterday to restrict Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, to private hearings if his conduct at public sessions did not improve.

Arthur G. Klein, an attorney for the Securities and Exchange Commission, was nominated last night as the Democratic candidate for the seat of the late M. Michael Edelstein as Representative in Congress from, the Fourteenth New York District.
VICHY, July 8 (AP) -- The French High Command issued this communique:

No one looking over the reports from the various Long Island and New Jersey fishing ports can doubt that the school tuna are as plentiful as they were last year, and in many areas the totals are much better than during the 1940 season.

BERLIN, July 8 (AP) -- Some observers felt that behind the High Command's silence today was an indication that the second phase of the smash against Russia was developing, with fresh troops preparing a new surprise for the Red Army. One propaganda company reporter spoke of several Nazi armies being moved for a secret task.

In occupying Iceland with its armed forces, the United States has taken a crucial step. That step is not a mere gesture, and nothing could be more dangerous than for us to treat it as a mere gesture. We cannot occupy the island, for example, merely with a token force, trusting that Hitler will not dare to attack it for fear of becoming involved in war with us.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- Steady to 10 cent higher prices prevailed today in a moderately active hog market, pushing top values to $11.10, the highest since October, 1937. Lamb prices were strong to higher, but values in the cattle section were mixed with medium and heavy-weight steers weakening under large supplies.

Another event in the successful career of "Life With Father" will be noted tonight at the Empire Theatre when the comedy reaches its 700th performance, thereby moving into fourteenth position on Broadway's select list of long runs. On a carefully worked out stagger system, Oscar Berlin, the producer, is giving each member of the company a vacation, following a custom established last Summer.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The executive board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America made plans today to extend throughout the men's clothing industry, which has 100,000 employes, a plan for health and life insurance to be financed by a 3 per cent tax on employers' payrolls.

AMBLER, Pa., July 8 -- A detachment of marines moved early this evening into the asbestos plant of the Keasbey Mattison Co., closed by a labor dispute, and obtained delivery of asbestos boards needed in the construction of the temporary Navy building in Washington.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 8 -- The first nation-wide survey completed since the outbreak of the Russo-German war indicates that American public sentiment in favor of convoys has remained virtually stable with a slight increase, but that the number of voters for entering a shooting war now has declined.

LONDON, July 8 -- Soviet Ambassador Ivan Maisky was the center of another enthusiastic popular demonstration today when a crowd, singing and cheering, joined him on a railroad station platform to greet a strong mission representing the Russian fighting services, headed by Lieut. Gen. R. Golikoff, deputy chief of the Soviet General Staff.

PANAMA, July 8 -- A pitched battle yesterday between twenty armed members of the German-Swiss colony and Panamanian police in the isolated Panamanian town of Cotito in the Province of Chiriqui, approximately twenty miles from the Costa Rican border, was revealed here today in a formal report to the Ministry of Government and Justice.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 8 -- Bert Lahr, the Cowardly Lion in Metro's "Wizard of Oz," will return to the screen under the auspices of RKO, the studio announced today. With Buddy Ebsen, Lahr will be featured in "I'm Dying to Live," a farce by Charles Belden and Charles E. Roberts; Roberts will collaborate with George Jeske on the scenario.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES IN SYRIA, July 7 -- The battle for Beirut, which many believe will mean the end of the Syrian campaign, is expected to continue for at least a few days more. Some hard fighting must be put in it before an Allied victory is achieved.

Two of the principal Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday brought all-cash considerations. The properties involved were a six-story apartment house and a private dwelling on the East Side close to Fifth Avenue. In another transaction, a ten-story loft was acquired by a syndicate headed by an operator.

A hold-out for greatly increased war-risk payments begun on June 20 by the Seafarers International Union, which had tied up four ships due to sail to Red Sea and African ports, ended yesterday when the union, responding to a government ultimatum, ordered the vessels released.

Samuel Levine, 48 years old, business agent and former president of Local 240, Clothing Drivers and Helpers Union, A.F. of L., was held in $75,000 bail yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Algeron I. Nova in Brooklyn after District Attorney William O'Dwyer had charged that he was a material witness in a murder case against Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, who formerly ruled a $1,000,000 industrial rackets empire in the city.

The effort of the government to improve national health by a 25 per cent increase in the consumption of naturally-fortified foods, such as fresh fruits, vegetables and dairy products, is being supported by increased advertising campaigns by the various groups.

Junior League members and volunteers associated with the Welfare Council of New York decided at a first meeting yesterday that they should learn how and where to direct civilians to the city's various health and welfare services, as well as acquire complete knowledge of all points of interest here, so they can inform visiting soldiers and sailors on what to include in their sightseeing tours.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Trustees of the Erie Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to purchase the Chicago Erie and merge it with the Erie for operation and ownership. The Erie now operates the other road as a subsidiary.

Home of the Sagas American occupation of Iceland might be called something of a homecoming. From Iceland, roughly about a thousand years ago, went forth Eric the Red -- the reference is to the color of his hair and not to his ideology -- to discover Greenland and to beget a son.

Trading in locally dressed meats was fair to good yesterday. Prices in general were strong to higher, with fresh pork cuts up most. The hog kill was light and other classes normal to moderate. The kosher markets opened steady to slightly stronger.

Trading in locally dressed meats was fair to good yesterday. Prices in general were strong to higher, with fresh pork cuts up most. The hog kill was light and other classes normal to moderate. The kosher markets opened steady to slightly stronger.

A balanced investment program for savings banks, with suggestions as to securities to buy and not to buy, was offered recently by August Ihlefeld Jr., president of the Savings Banks Trust Company of New York, at the Massachusetts Bank Management Conference.
Midtown leasing to concerns in the various branches of the apparel industry featured the business rentals activity yesterday. Several expansion moves were reported.

A printing concern recently organized to take over interests formerly operating in Paris and which plans soon to publish a new magazine in New York, was listed yesterday among the lessees of business quarters.

The United Service Organization for National Defense, Inc., in collaboration with the Canadian War Services Fund, the agency serving the same purpose in Canada, will start functioning immediately to provide leisure-time activities and facilities for the 80,000 American troops to be stationed in Iceland, Richard W. Lawrence, New York USO chairman, announced yesterday.

George F. Baker, son of the late president of the First National Bank, has purchased from the estate of Herbert L. Smith the seventeen-acre waterfront property on Center Island, Oyster Bay, L.I., through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc,. brokers.

LONDON, July 9 (AP) -- Britain has completed arrangements for supplying large quantities of war materials to Russia and some military equipment already is in transit, the Ministry of Economic Warfare announced today.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., July 9 -- Edward Amark, courageous San Francisco youth who plays his best tennis when he is under pressure, chalked up the first upset of the Atlantic Coast tennis championship today.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), July 9 -- After a firm opening the Boerse was quiet today and domestic industrials were in demand. A. K. U. Y., stimulated by official listing of its shares on the Berlin Boerse, rose 3 points to 147 1/4, Philips Lamps advanced 1 1/2 to 230 1/4 and Unilever 2 to 126 3/8.

With so many vital materials in short supply as a result of the defense program, merchandise premiums offered by national advertisers are undergoing a steady change, with a strong trend toward plastics, agency men remarked yesterday.

DENVER, July 9 -- Dark horses roamed the range and upsets tumbled over each other today as the field in the National Professional Golfers Association tournament was whittled down to sixteen survivors in two blistering rounds of match play.

Current prices of garment boxes, based on 20 cents for No. 9s, have been advanced only to the extent justified by increases in board prices, according to M.E. Hyman, executive officer of the Corrugated Box Institute of the Apparel Industry, Inc., a purchasing agency for garment manufacturers.

BUENOS AIRES. July 9 -- The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for June 30, issued today, shows that the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation increased from 113.23 per cent on June 15 to 114.96 per cent on June 30.

BOSTON, July 9 (AP) -- The 5-year-old Manamaid stepped up into allowance company today, but it looked the same to her as she captured the $1,500 Massasoit, feature at Suffolk Downs, for her fourth straight victory.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 9 (AP) -- The Finnish High Command tonight issued the following communique:

Much Misunderstood Sphere One of the little thing's which, people have not really learned is that the earth is round. Everybody thinks he knows. We are always citing the roundness of the earth to prove how much better educated we are than Plato or Leonardo da Vinci, who thought that the earth is flat.

The big naval transport West Point, which was the liner America until the government ordered her-withdrawn from commercial service a month ago, will arrive in New York Harbor on Saturday to prepare for a voyage to Europe with the ousted Axis consuls and their staffs.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 9 -- American troops were busy unloading equipment today after disembarking from the largest convoy that ever reached the shores of Iceland.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 9 (AP) -- The Rochester Red Wings gained an even break by winning the nightcap, thirteen-inning game of a twin bill tonight, 2-1, after dropping the abbreviated twilight encounter, 5-1, to the leading Newark Bears of the International League.
BELFORD, N.J., July 9 -- A young woman and a girl were drowned and another young woman and girl were rescued this afternoon after a rowboat overturned in Sandy Hook Bay about a half mile off here.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- From a reporter's notebook, two days after the first occupation of Old World territory by United States troops at a time when this nation was not technically a belligerent:

Some manufacturers of dresses in popular prices will shortly introduce a new price range at $3.37 1/2, abandoning their $2.87 1/2 lines, according to market reports yesterday, because of higher fabric and other costs. Other houses will continue to make dresses at $2.87 1/2, but will make savings on labor costs by reducing stitches and other details and will reduce quality to some extent by switches in quality.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 9 -- Members of the Wednesday Night Bridge Club held their first meeting of the season tonight at the Meadow Club, with a dinner earlier at the clubhouse. Among those who attended were Mrs. Charles Tracy Barney, Mrs. William Adams Kissam, Mme.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Construction of the St. Lawrence seaway and hydroelectric power project would not hurt the commerce of the Port of New York and certainly would produce lower electric rates for its inhabitants, Mayor F.H. La Guardia told the House Rivers and Harbors Committee today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Sidney Hillman, Associate Director General of the Office of Production Management, announced today reorganization of the Labor Division of that organization to speed up the training, placement and transfer of workers needed for defense production and to give labor better representation in the policy-making phases of production management.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 9 -- A subscription dance at Bailey's Beach, on Saturday evening of next week will be the first dance at the beach this season, as the one scheduled for July 4 was canceled. It will follow the Paine-Leidy wedding of the afternoon and is being arranged by the dance committee of the Beach Association.

FORT DIX, N.J., July 9 -- Eighteen soldiers of the Forty-fourth Division were chosen today to attend officers' training schools at Fort Benning, Ga., and Fort Sill, Okla. Those completing the three-month course satisfactorily will receive second lieutenant commissions.

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 10 -- Large German tank and mechanized forces are smashing anew at the Russian lines in three main areas, the Red Army announced today, and the Russian defenders are holding off offensives directed at Leningrad, Moscow and the Ukraine.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Rear Admiral S.M. Robinson, chief of the Navy Bureau of Ships, said today that the United States would be producing destroyers at the rate of 100 a year by the end of 1943.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 9 -- The economic importance of defeating Germany was urged upon the general session of the international conference of the New Education Fellowship tonight by Dr. Maurice J. Bonn of London.
LONDON, July 9 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique today said:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 9 -- Bud Abbott and Lou Costello will be featured by Universal in "Flying Cadets," a comedy of the air service, upon completion of 'Ride 'Em, Cowboy," which is now before the cameras, the studio announced today. The picture will precede the comedy team's assignment at Metro in "Rio Rita" and is scheduled to start next month.

Japan's "new policy," being hastily improvised after the shock of the Nazi invasion of Russia, has not yet been officially revealed. When it is, one must hope that it will prove wiser than the policy Japan has been pursuing for the last four years. For on net balance, what Japan has mainly to show for its wanton attack on China is its own gradual impoverishment and upward of 1,500,000 of its sons killed or wounded.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 8:

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Representative Hoffman of Michigan called on the President today to approve a national referendum on the question whether "we should send an American expeditionary force to fight outside the continental United States."

Defense of democracy requires not only repelling an invader from our shores, but the assurance that every boy and girl in the United States be allowed an equal educational opportunity to build himself into a healthy, productive member of society, Professor George D. Strayer of Teachers College, Columbia University, told 750 educators yesterday at the second day meeting of the interdivisional conference at Teachers College.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Reports that the Federal Trade Commission has men on the way or actually on the ground in several furniture factories reached the National Home Furnishings Market today as buyer registrations ran about 40 per cent ahead of the third day of last Summer's market.

The Council Against Intolerance in America makes the ominous statement that it possesses "evidence that divisive propaganda is being used by the Nazis to disrupt morale in the camps." To help counter these efforts it has just issued a program, handbook, "Calling All Americans," for use by group leaders working with the troops.

LONDON, July 9 -- The question of supply, which means Britain's effort to keep her far-flung armies going while reserving quantities to repulse an attack on Britain, was taken up in the House of Commons today in statements made by a number of its members.

LOS ANGELES, July 9 -- The respective merits of New York and California as arbiters of fashion was one of the topics discussed today at the convention of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs. Women were also advised to explore public housing as a field for their activities.

The defense and prosecution rested yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Morris Mardavich, 23 years old, an ex-convict; Vincent Morgano, 23, and Frank Alascia, 22, on a first-degree murder indictment in the hold-up shooting of Harry Vance Maxwell, 41, an advertising executive, in a parked car opposite 151 East Eighty-first Street on May 4.

CLEVELAND, July 9 -- The National Maritime Union joined with the Oil Workers International Union today in a drive to bring 65,000 workers in oil fields, refineries and tanker fleets of the Standard Oil Company under C.I.O. closed shop agreements.

The new cargo carrier Santa Rita, the fourth of a series of freighters for South American trade ordered by the Grace Line, will be launched at noon tomorrow at the yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, Kearny, N.J.
The world's two largest armies were still locked in titanic and bloody struggle from the Arctic to the Black Sea yesterday as an inglorious military sideshow drew toward an end in Syria.

Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, delivered a sharp personal attack yesterday on Emil K. Ellis, counsel to the City Council committee investigating civil service after the attorney had questioned his statement that he had never served as a member of the county committee of the American Labor Party.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies in June showed a smaller gain over a year ago than in the month previous, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The June gain amounted to 16.9 per cent, compared with 23.1 for May and 26.2 for April, when this year's sales were inflated by a late Easter.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Hitler lies -- and with him his Gauleiter Mussolini -- when they speak of a "new order" and of a "new Europe." The two fellows lack imagination; when they are not better advised from Paris by some French traitors, they draw their "ideas" from the arsenal of the most stuffy past:

The Board of Education reinstated yesterday Miss Mary B.C. Byrne, a teacher suspended twenty-one months ago for alleged insubordination in refusing to submit to a physical examination. The action, at a regular board meeting, was taken "with the understanding that she is retiring."
Directors of the F.W. Woolworth Comany yesterday authorized the declaration of a 40 cent dividend, payable on Sept. 2. Previously stockholders received 60 cents quarterly.
ANKARA, Turkey, July 9 -- A generous set of armistice conditions has been offered the French in Syria by the British, and therefore it is thought these will eventually be accepted.
CEDARHURST, L.I., July 9 -- Mrs. Harry McNaughton of Plandome captured the low gross prize in the one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.

Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan heard argument yesterday on applications in behalf of William Solomon, Tammany leader of the Seventeenth Assembly District, north, and Charles H. Mullens, former assistant State Controller, for certificates of reasonable doubt that would permit their release on bail pending appeal from their recent convictions in General Sessions for accepting $28,000 in bribes from, the now defunct Burland Printing Company.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, July 10 -- One of the key German spearhead thrusts against the Stalin Line has been broken at Lepel, according to yesterday's Russian communique. Today's Russian bulletin announced that Soviet troops had unleashed counter-attacks against the Germans there.

Fifth Avenue strollers took one look yesterday at the Coty, Inc., premiere, and realized at once that the spectacle in the sunken plaza of Radio City, staged at the opening of the company's super-deluxe salon on the promenade above, had achieved something which ambitious mercantile rivals may envy for months to come.

A request that the government give limited publication to the list of undesirable business houses in Latin America, to clear up the confusion existing among exporters who desire to comply with the President's proclamation of June 14 freezing foreign funds, was made yesterday by the Merchants Association of New York.

Word precedes the arrival from Hollywood today of Vinton Freedley and Richard W. Krakeur (two-thirds of the F-S-K Corporation) that Eve Arden and Benny Baker have heen signed for the firm's musical, "Let's Face It!" in which Danny Kaye will be starred.

The health, morale and well-being of 3,000,000 prisoners of war in Europe are "much better than during the last war," according to Tracy Strong, general secretary of the Y.M.C.A. World Committee for War Prisoners' Aid, who arrived yesterday on the Dixie Clipper.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Argentina, Brazil and the United States have made a proposal to Ecuador and Peru calculated to stop hostilities in their border warfare and to point the way to a permanent settlement of their boundary dispute.
MONTREAL, July 9 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals took a 6-3 decision from the Jersey City Giants and climbed to within a half game of third place in the International League standing tonight.

It may well be that your country week-end hostess presents a puzzling problem. She is a happy, wholesome person -- as rural women are likely to be -- engrossed in her home and her garden and is impervious to the charms of imported perfumes or frivolous furbelows.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Governors of sixteen Eastern States were called on today by Secretary Ickes to lead "a voluntary effort having as its aim a reduction in the consumption of petroleum products by at least twenty per cent."

ST. LOUIS, July 9 -- Nothing, they say, is ever quite so old as yesterday's newspaper. However, news that is twenty-four hours old scarcely seems to move any quicker into the limbo of a forgotten past than an All-Star game.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- A movement, backed by Administration forces, to modify or delete from the May bill some drastic provisions aimed at defense strikes appeared tonight to have gained force, as the House prepared to take up amendments to the measure tomorrow.

First Boston Corporation Directors of the First Boston Corporation have voted a dividend of $300,000, equivalent to 60 cents a share, payable on July 29. The previous payment was $1.60 in January, this year. In 1940 the corporation paid $1 in January, and 50 cents in July.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Eleven members of a committee for the automobile industry which will consult with the Office of Production Management on important questions were named tonight by the Bureau of Defense Industry Committee of OPM.
PHILADELPHIA, July 9 (AP) -- Top-favored Miss Helen Jacobs swept into the third round of the women's Middle States tennis tournament today as play began after a two-day postponement because of rain.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Use of $14,000,000 of Work Projects Administration funds in a program to educate perhaps 1,000,000 aliens in a nation-wide, citizenship program has been approved by President Roosevelt; Acting Attorney General Francis Biddle said today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Good will and hemispheric solidarity were emphasized by President Roosevelt in a message read on his behalf tonight on radio programs of the Columbia Broadcasting System to Argentina on the occasion of Argentine independence day.

Manfred Read, an American citizen who has been serving as acting manager of a British bank in Pau, France, since November, 1939, said yesterday upon his arrival at La Guardia Field on the Dixie Clipper that he had been held by the French police for ten hours because he befriended four Frenchmen who told him they were being mustered out of the French Army.

A leading West Side transaction yesterday involved the twelvestory apartment building at 210 Riverside Drive, northeast corner of Ninety-third Street, which was purchased by Louis Schlechter for investment from Yhto, Inc. It has three elevators and occupies a plot 114.5 by 97.10 by 100.8 by 152 feet.

LONDON, July 9 -- General Henri Fernand Dentz, Vichy's High Commissioner and commander in Syria, has asked the British for discussion of armistice terms, Prime Minister Winston Churchill announced in the House of Commons today.
MOSCOW, Thursday, July 10 (AP) -- Today's Russian communique contained the following part on individuals' exploits:
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 9 (AP) -- Argentina celebrated today 125 years of independence, marking the day with, one of the biggest military shows in the nation's history.

LONDON, July 9 -- United States and British, forces will cooperate in defending Iceland against any attempt by the Germans to capture that important island, Prime Minister Winston Churchill announced in the House of Commons today.

A suggestion that manufacturers of boys' and students' apparel take stock now of their production and supply resources and be prepared in advance to shift output or use substitute materials if the defense program makes it necessary, was made by Robert A. Brady of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply at a round-table session of the industry yesterday at the annual convention of the Boys' Apparel Buyers' Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Secretary Knox implied today his belief that President Roosevelt's new orders for the Navy to guard sea lanes serving strategic defense outposts authorized the Navy to use its guns as well as its eyes in patrolling the ocean.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Colonel William J. Donovan, who traveled widely through Europe as special observer for President Roosevelt before Germany over-ran the Balkan countries, will soon be named to a post as Coordinator of Intelligence Information gathered by government agencies.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Wendell L. Willkie called on president Roosevelt at the White House today and asserted later that he had assured Mr. Roosevelt of the fullest support from himself and the "overwhelming" number of the Republican rank and file in the occupation of Iceland and any other steps the Administration might deem necessary to deliver the most effective material aid to Great Britain and her allies.

BERLIN, July 9 -- After a silence of twenty-four hours, the German press opened today an attack on the United States military occupation of Iceland and President Roosevelt's defense of what was designated here as the first military step of the United States into the war zone.
NEW YORK Mrs. Leland Harrison, wife of the United States Minister to Switzerland, is at the Plaza.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Reports that "when-issued" trading in the forthcoming offering of $233,584,900 of debentures of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was to be carried on have brought a warning from the Securities and Exchange Commission that such trading would be illegal until the registration statement has become effective under the Securities Act.

Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh announced yesterday that civilian volunteers who wish to join the emergency auxiliary corps of the Fire Department would be welcomed at all firehouses tomorrow when training classes begin for the 30,000 city employes who are members of the corps.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 9 -- Favored by idyllic weather and with all hands signing in for action, the ninth annual Spring Lake Invitation tennis tournament moved ahead in high today at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

A special meeting of stockholders of the St. Regis Paper Company will be held in Watertown, N.Y., on July 31 to consider action taken by the board of directors at a meeting on June 26 authorizing restatement of the value of certain investments retroactive to Jan. 1.

AMBLER, Pa., July 9 -- For the second time, within twenty-four hours marines entered the plant of the Keasbey Mattison Company here today to remove asbestos boards needed in Navy construction work. The big factory, with about 80 per cent of its orders at least indirectly for defense purposes, was closed by a labor dispute two weeks ago.

The flush of enthusiasm In the stock market was more tempered yesterday, and although the volume on the New York Stock Exchange held above the million-share mark, the rapid advance of the previous day was slowed down by spasmodic profit-taking.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Representatives of four of the world's major surplus wheat-producing countries -- Argentina, Canada, Australia and the United States -- will convene here tomorrow to discuss an international "ever-normal granary" program for dealing with the surplus problem.

The city of Cleveland, Ohio, awarded yesterday an issue of $4,000,000 of refunding bonds on an interest cost basis of 1.736 per cent to a syndicate consisting of the First National Bank of Chicago, the National City Bank of New York, the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, Graham, Parsons Co., the City National Bank and Trust Company, Kansas City, Mo., and the Milwaukee Company.

LONDON, July 9 (U.P.) -- Two to three million well-equipped Russian troops are being thrown into the central sector of the Russian front against German forces that thus far have been able to gain less than half of their objectives, a competent British military commentator reported tonight.

Smiles For the third successive day Wall Street has had a good market, and already there are indications that the financial community has forgotten its woes. In no other place can minds be changed more rapidly. Last week all was gloom.

Blyth Co., Inc., as head of an underwriting group that entered the successful bid on Tuesday for 590,527 shares of common stock of the San Diego Gas and Electric Company, announced last night that about 75 per cent of the shares had been sold on the first day of the offering.

MOSCOW, July 9 (AP) -- German has failed in an effort to crush Soviet defenses, even though she sent 10,000 tanks against the Russian lines in an ultra-secret opening attack, Vice Foreign Commissar S.A. Lozovsky, declared tonight.
ATLANTA, July 9 -- An Atlanta speech by Senator Wheeler of Montana was postponed indefinitely today pending a show-down with city officials on the use of the Municipal Auditorium.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Congressional investigation of Lieut. Gen. Ben Lear for his "mass discipline" of some of his soldiers who whistled at girls in shorts on a Memphis golf course was threatened by a House member today.

VICHY, France, July 9 -- General Henri Fernand Dentz, French High Commissioner and commander of the forces in Syria, was authorized tonight by the government here to ask an armistice and an immediate suspension of arms.

Marshal Petain's discourse to the commission that is to compose a new Constitution for the New France which he wishes to establish is curious in its conceptions and its language. He orders "an authoritative hierarchical social state," a fine rolling phrase. "Authoritative" seems to be an alias of "totalitarian."

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange on June 30 was 478,859 shares, against 496,892 on May 29, the Exchange announced yesterday. Neither figure included short positions in odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers.
MOSCOW, July 9 (AP) -- The following is the part of the Russian communique dealing with individual exploits:

CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- Increased supplies failed to halt a rising price trend in the hog market today and top values pushed to a new four-year peak of $11.25. In the cattle pens, however, continued burdensome supplies sent most prices lower with only light yearlings holding steady. All classes of sheep were steady.

Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday fluctuated irregularly in a sensitive market. Strength was apparent at the opening and continued through most of the morning trading, but a decline late in the afternoon reduced quotations from gains of 11 to 25 points to around the levels of Tuesday's close before a recovery in the last fifteen minutes of the session established net gains of 7 to 10 points for the day.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 9 -- The United States Army Air Corps has approved a tract of farmland in North Purchase on the Westchester-Connecticut boundary as a site "satisfactory from a military standpoint" for a Westchester County airport, according to a telegram received today from Washington by Ralph A. Carretta, chairman of the Westchester Board of Supervisors.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 9 -- Mrs. Clara Traver, said by her attorney and officials at the Nassau District Attorney's office to be the wife of the secretary to the German Consul General in New York, was charged here today with grand larceny for allegedly keeping $13,475 worth of jewelry entrusted to her by a friend for safe keeping.
VENTNOR CITY, N.J., July 9 -- Decisions reached in adjourned games, played off today, resulted in a general shuffling of leaders in the invitation chess masters tournament on the Municipal Pier.

In another close handicap Paul B. Codd's Gino Rex emerged as the winner of the feature at Empire City yesterday. The Paul B. Codd racer was in a full drive, with Jockey Nick Wall flailing away for all he was worth as he drove past the finish line first by a half length at the end of a mile and a sixteenth.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A nation like the United States, not economically self-sufficient an relying on ocean trade for essentials to its national defense, can be weakened, strangled and defeated by being denied access to the seas. It cannot maintain, let alone increase, its existing state of defensive power while its strength is being sapped by gradual contraction of the ocean areas its vessels can safely navigate.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- President Roosevelt announced today he had accepted the resignation of Leon Henderson as Securities and Exchange Commissioner to allow him to devote all his time to his duties as Administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply.

The idea men, the gadgeteers, are in town. Dedicated to the proposition that Professor Rube Goldberg is right and with "It works like this . . ." for a password, the Inventors of America opened their Eastern States meeting and exhibit yesterday in the Hotel Edison.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 9 -- American coffee exporters here are watching keenly the reaction of the New York Coffee Exchange to measures put in force by the National Coffee Department regulating coffee exports and setting minimum prices.

Although Arthur R. Braunlich Jr., a suspended City College English tutor, denied yesterday before a trial committee of the Board of Higher Education that he was ever a Communist, City College students wrote published verse on his discoveries of "leftist propaganda" even in Shakespeare.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 9 (AP) -- The International Christian Endeavor Society's 2,000,000 members in the United States and Canada were urged tonight by their president, Dr. Daniel A. Poling of Philadelphia, to campaign vigorously for a seven-point world peace program.

The need for "gasless Sundays" throughout the nation because of the defense emergency can he greatly decreased by intelligent control of isolated traffic lights in metropolitan areas, Queens County Sheriff Maurice A. Fitzgerald declared yesterday in calling for the combined cooperation of police, motorists and garage operators in a general effort to reduce the "high amount of gasoline wasted annually."

FORT HANCOCK, N.J., July 9 -- A simulated raid from the sea on the military reservation here -- one of the important defense posts for New York harbor -- was repulsed today in an hour's "fighting," but only after considerable quantities of military stores and equipment theoretically had been destroyed and several of the camp's buildings "set on fire."

CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- Idle Sun, a 5-year-old gelding owned by Mrs. Emil Denemark of Chicago, came from far back to win the $2,500 added Grassland Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth over the turf course at Arlington Park today. A crowd of 12,000 saw the race, one of the few stakes run over the grass in America.

DETROIT, July 9 -- Next year's All-Star show is slated for Brooklyn, although the National League, whose turn it is to play host, won't make an announcement until the Winter meeting. . . . The American League wanted to give the vote for players back to the fans, but this suggestion was received coolly in the senior circuit. . . . Yesterday's game, the most thrilling of all, grossed more than $70,000.

The All-Star game out of the way for another year and the defeat of the National League thoroughly second-guessed, clubs in both major leagues today will resume operations on the championship trail where they were interrupted following last Sunday's contests.

Production of coke pig iron in June, according to The Iron Age, reached 4,553,165 net tons. This compares with 4,599,966 tons in May, and the operating rate for the industry's blast furnaces was 95.9 per cent, against 93.8 per cent in May.

Trading on the Stock Exchange has now risen above 1,000,000 shares on two successive days, and prices have reached the best levels in six months. It appears that the market is breaking out of the strange deep lethargy that has gripped it for so long and which resulted in a volume of trading last month lower than for the corresponding month in twenty-one years.

The wholesale meat business showed little change yesterday. Trading was fair to good, and prices were steady to strong. The pork loin market showed some unevenness, some points reporting a steady market and others higher. The hog kill continued light, and the slaughter of other classes was normal to moderate.

VICHY, France, July 9 -- Conformably with custom, little or nothing is being said here of the visit that Admiral Frangois Darlan, Vice Premier, is making to Paris and other points in the occupied zone, but it is understood that he may return soon.

Kurt Amrein, president of the Amrein, Freudenberg Company, an importing firm, has leased an apartment at 50 Park Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., broker. The Elliman firm also rented to Don Herold, writer and cartoonist and president of the Don Herold Company, Inc., advertising agency, a suite in 103 East Eighty-sixth Street, and an office in 40 East Sixty-second Street to Dr. Loren Guy, eye specialist.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 9 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:
BERLIN, July 9 (AP) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

A parking lot on the East Side changed hands yesterday, with a possibility that it will be improved with an apartment house. The property consists of 23,350 square feet, with a frontage of 220 feet, at 404 to 420 East Fifty-third Street and was sold by Webb Knapp, Inc., to a syndicate headed by Louis W. Abrons.
MOSCOW, Thursday, July 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following early today:

FRANK LUTHER MOTT, director of the School of Journalism at the University of Iowa for fifteen years and Pulitzer Prize winner a few years back for his "History of American Magazines," has now prepared in one large volume the nearest thing yet to a full-dress history of the newspaper in the United States: "American Journalism, 1690-1940."*

ROME, July 9 -- A strongly worded note asking that the Italian Government take measures to permit United States nationals to leave Italy in the same way that Italians are allowed to leave the United States was presented to the Foreign Ministry this morning by George Wadsworth, Counselor of the United States Embassy.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 9 (AP) -- Virtually all Syria was under the military control of British and Free French forces tonight as the French defenders requested an armistice.

Two planes that approached the American Export liner Excambion at sea on July 1 caused apprehension among her passengers until they were identified as United States Navy seaplanes, it was disclosed yesterday when the ship arrived at Pier F, Jersey City, from Lisbon.

Tami Mauriello, hard-hitting light heavyweight from the Bronx, helped usher in the Chick Meehan boxing regime at Ebbets Field last night by scoring a knockout triumph over Steve Mamakos, gallant Washington, D.C., battler.
The monthly meeting of the Savings Banks insurance Forum of Group Five will be held on Tuesday at the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn at 4 P.M.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 9 -- The Finnish press today published the first real military information about the war in the north on the Murmansk coast, where united Finnish-German forces are advancing from Petsamo, according to this evening's official High Command communique.
