The Building Trades and Construction Council voted unanimously yesterday to throw the full support of its 250,000 members behind the strike that Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A.F. of L., has voted to call against the Consolidated Edison Company.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A government sponsored, mandatory savings system for defense workers was advocated today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, to cushion the effects of a letdown in employment when the defense program is completed, and to prevent inflation.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Hogs topped at $11.65 today, the highest top since October, 1937, on a moderately active trade. Cattle ruled strong to 15 cents higher and sheep were mostly 10-15 cents lower. A good clearance of hogs on sale was reported, with the bulk of good butchers selling readily at $11 to $11.60.
Nine sales of residential property in Brooklyn for the Home Owners Loan Corporation were reported yesterday by the John J. Mattia Realty Corporation, as contract management broker.

Stoppage of a large part of the present beef supplies for Army and Navy bases in this area, the Panama Canal Zone, Bermuda, Newfoundland and elsewhere was threatened yesterday by a strike called against the New York Butchers Dressed Meat Company, Eleventh Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street.
Posters designed to spur national defense won $2,000 in a competition yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 15 -- The New Jersey State father-and-son golf championship at the Rock Spring Club today ended in a deadlock between two teams that finished the thirty-six-hole journey with totals of 153.

Seeded players continued their advance in the Eastern junior and boys' singles championships at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday. Play in the boys' group reached the semi-finals, while the juniors got to the quarter-finals.

Because 25 to 30 per cent of this year's sales of motor cars was "borrowed" from 1942, the prospective curtailment in automobile production may be a "blessing in disguise," offsetting the bad dip in business which would have resulted from so much anticipatory buying, D.U. Bathrick, vice president and general sales manager of the Pontiac Division of General Motors Corporation, declared here yesterday.

In accordance with a practice initiated a year ago, the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey yesterday estimated that its net earnings for the first six months of this year were $79,000,000 after all charges and reserves, and after allowing for income taxes based on the Revenue Act of 1940.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Although the British offer to negotiate with the Chinese Government on the surrender of extraterritoriality is gratifying to Chinese circles, the move on the part of London occasioned no surprise in either Chinese Embassy or American State Department circles today.

"Before Hitler invaded Soviet Russia the war was not properly the business of the United States. * * * Now, however, * * * America must withhold nothing in the way of possible aid to Russia and to Britain." For this candid statement Robert Minor, acting general secretary of the Communist party in the United States, deserves the gratitude of the American people.

County reform bills sponsored by the Democratic majority in the City Council to counter reorganizations proposed by the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee were adopted yesterday by the Council by a vote of 15 to 3. Mrs. Genevieve B. Earle, minority leader and advocate of county reform for years; Salvatore Ninfo and Robert K. Straus voted against them.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (U.P.) -- An economic federation of the islands of the Caribbean has been proposed to President Roosevelt as part of a broad program to help the Caribbean peoples meet the effects of the war, it was disclosed tonight.

BERLIN, Wednesday, July 16 -- The German Air Force was reported yesterday to have blasted a path of blazing destruction ahead of advancing German Armies, declared to be close to Novgorod, just 100 miles southeast of Leningrad, and in possession of the easternmost bunkers of the Stalin line on the road to Moscow.
A conflict between coat and suit manufacturers and wool goods mills over the refusal of many of the latter to issue guarantees of fiber content in their fabrics developed yesterday.
LONDON, July 15 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique today said:

Births in New York City last week totaled 2,810, the high record for the year and the highest for any week since the Summer of 1928, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner. He predicted that births this year would exceed 110,000 and be the highest annual total since 1931.

A program, described by municipal officials and medical men as "a long step forward" in the treatment and prevention of cancer in New York took shape yesterday when the city filed plans for the Florence Nightingale Hospital, to be erected on a large plot in West 163d Street.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Legislation creating a Glider Division within the National Youth Administration for the purpose of carrying out a program of training in the construction, handling and maintenance of gliders and sailplanes, was introduced in both houses of Congress today.

Two grandsons of Charles Evans Hughes, life-long Republican, have left the Republican party, it was declared last night. Samuel Joseph, chairman of the law committee of the Bronx County Republican Committee, charged at a meeting that H. Stuart Hughes had enrolled as a Democrat in 1937, 1938, 1939 and 1940, while Charles Evans Hughes 3d had voted for Democratic and American Labor party candidates on an absentee ballot on at least one occasion.

Business throughout the Bell System in the first six months of this year reached new high record levels, with installations of telephones showing an increase of nearly 50 per cent over the same period the year before, according to a report sent yesterday to stockholders by Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, parent concern of the Bell System.

SUDBURY, Vt., July 15 -- Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth F.H. Underwood of Hayseeds, this place, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Denise Hull Underwood, to John Hildebrant Martin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Benjamin Martin of Plainfield, N.J., and Spur Tree Farm, Romulus, N.Y.
SHANGHAI, July 15 -- Japan and Japanese-occupied China are marking time, awaiting the outcome of European hostilities. Japan wants to join the winning side.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Rounding out two months of the most sustained hitting major league baseball has ever seen, Joe DiMaggio today plastered Edgar Smith, White Sox left-hander, for a single and a double to send his astounding streak to fifty-five consecutive games in which he has connected safely.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), July 15 -- The Bourse was firm today with a larger turnover of domestic industrials. Unilever rose 6 1/4 to 131 1/4; Philips 6 to 233 and only A.K.U., which lost 1 3/4 at 149 3/8, was lower. Dutch Indians were firm especially the tobaccos. Amsterdam Trading gained 9 to 433 1/2; Amsterdam Rubber 8 1/2 to 281 1/4 and Royal Dutch 5 1/8 to 251 1/8.

The Seaman's Bank for Savings has sold the eleven-story store and loft building at 73 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Fifteenth Street, to Shelton Properties, Inc., Benjamin Rich, president, an importer of straw goods. It was bought for investment.

Salomon Brothers Hutzler and associates were the successful bidders yesterday for $9,387,000 of Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad 1 1/2 per cent equipment trust certificates at an interest cost of about 1.32 per cent. The winning bid was 100.679.

BERLIN, July 15 -- Whatever advances the German armed forces may be enjoying in the Eastern theatre of war are not being revealed either to the German public or foreign correspondents in Berlin. Today the official communique again disposes of the Russian front in eight crisp German words.

A syndicate headed by Smith, Burris Co. will offer to the public today a new issue of 40,000 shares of $2 cumulative preference stock of the Domestic Finance Corporation. The stock will be priced at $29.75 a share.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 15 -- Gene Tierney, Twentieth Century-Fox's import of last year from Broadway, has been borrowed by Arnold Pressburger, United Artists producer, to play Poppy in "Shanghai Gesture," which will go before the cameras Aug. 11 with Victor Mature in the male lead.

LONDON, July 15 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill announced unexpectedly in the House of Commons today that there would be another day's debate in the House on war production so that he himself could make a statement publicly in reply to criticisms made in last week's discussions.
SPOKANE, Wash., July 15 (U.P.) -- In the qualifying round of the national public links golf championship today, Jim Molinari, San Francisco's golfing policeman, shot 70, 73 -- 143.

Spurred by buying activity in the railroad section, the stock market broke through yesterday to its highest levels in the current recovery movement. Although the best call was for lower-priced issues, some of the better-type investment shares were not completely ignored.

One incident of the past week has a curious bearing on our agricultural situation. The railway president in charge of transportation in the defense program has officially warned shippers of grain that they must not use railway cars for storing grain. This was a very definite hint that the huge and constantly increasing surplus of unsold wheat may create a problem of stor-age-room such as has not arisen in many years.

Trading in locally dressed meats yesterday was good to slow. Slaughterers had too many commercial and utility grade lamb carcasses and some sales were S1 lower. Better grades of lamb were mostly steady. Cow beef was strong to 50 cents higher, steer beef and veal hindsaddles strong. Fresh pork cuts were mostly steady under a slow trade.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,870,750 barrels daily, an increase of 212,550 over the 3,658,200 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 23,650 barrels more than the calculation of 3,847,100 daily for July by the Bureau of Mines.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads reported today that eighty-seven Class I railroads had estimated operating revenues of $367,080,657 in June, compared with $281,935,333 in June, 1940. The reporting carriers, the association said, provide 81.8 per cent of total railroad operating revenues.

"The Get-Away," a Metro melodrama, will open today at the Rialto. The picture features Robert Sterling, Charles Winninger and Donna Reed. Dan Dailey Jr., Henry O'Neill and Don Douglas are among its supporting players. . . . "In the Navy" begins its sixth and final week today at Loew's Criterion, and "Caught in the Draft" start its fourth week today at the Paramount.

While a Coast Guard plane hovered watchfully overhead, the Navy transport West Point pulled out of her berth at Pier 61, North River, at 5:32 P.M. yesterday on the first stage of her voyage to Lisbon with a passenger list made up of 450 Germans and Italians leaving this country in compliance with orders of the State Department.

From an economic -- though not from a political -- standpoint the economic defense policies of the United States become increasingly difficult to understand. Here is Leon Henderson, the Price Control Administrator, declaring that higher prices and shortages of all kinds are at hand.

MOSCOW, July 15 (U.P.) -- The Soviet Government announced tonight in answer to Italian-German radio reports that it has "not the slightest intention" of evacuating Moscow and withdrawing to a new temporary capital farther eastward.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Senator Wheeler accused THE NEW YORK TIMES today of "suppressing" an article from Harold Denny at Cairo who expressed the opionion that if the United States decided to enter the war "she must prepare at once to wage war on the continent of Europe in a manner compared with which the American Expeditionary Force of 1917-18 was a picnic."
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Roosevelt expressed the view today that there would be need of a tax bill each year during the defense emergency to adjust revenues to expenditures.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 15 -- A Federal grand jury today indicted twenty-nine persons, charged with advocating the overthrow of the United States Government through armed intervention.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 15 -- The governments, painting Enoch L. (Nucky) Johnson as a graft-collecting overlord of crime and politics in Atlantic City, set out today to prove that in one venture alone he collected $28,000 which was not included in his income tax report.

A new form of Savings Bank Life Insurance policy, designed to protect families against the loss of their homes in case of the premature death of the mortgagor is being offered by twenty-nine mutual savings banks in New York State, it was announced yesterday by Judge Edward A. Richards, president of the Savings Banks Life Insurance Fund.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 15 -- Miss Betty Baldwin Young, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Sloan Young of this community, was married here this afternoon to Lieutenant Geza Robert Tinay, U.S.N.R., of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Aladar Tinay de Ilosvay of New York.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The plan of reorganization for the St. Louis Southwestern Railway (Cotton Belt), which sharply reduces capitalization and fixed charges and eliminates the holdings of present stockholders, was issued today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
NEWARK, N.J., July 15 (AP) -- The Newark Bears registered their sixth straight victory, and fourth straight over Baltimore, by trimming the Orioles in a wild contest tonight, 17 to 8.

Directors of National Ice Advertising, Inc., meeting in Chicago yesterday, approved a new three-year program for the promotion of the use of natural ice, calling for an increase of 33 1-3 per cent in the assessments of the participating ice companies, levied on a percentage basis.
MOSCOW, July 15 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Revision of the old age assistance and survivors insurance provisions of the Social Security Law to provide more adequately for those in need by readjustments in the interest alike of the beneficiaries and of the Federal Government was predicted today by Senator Downey of California, at today's special committee hearing on pensions.

LONDON, July 15 -- Lord Vansittart, retired permanent Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, today declared that the only thing possibly to be gained from the German attack on Russia is time -- time wherein Great Britain and the United States can continue preparations -- and he asserted that American help to Britain will be most effective when another American Expeditionary Force lands in France.

Reginald Stewart, Canadian conductor, who retired in favor of Benny Goodman on Monday night, came into his own last night at his second concert as conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewi-sohn Stadium.

Charles A. Gill, general manager of the Reading Company, was elected vice president in charge of operation and maintenance at a special board meeting in Philadelphia yesterday. He succeeds R.W. Brown, who has been elected president of the Lehigh Valley Railroad.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Acting under Instructions from the board of directors of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, Elisha Hanson, general counsel, told the Federal Communications Commission today that it was legally powerless to inquire into newspaper ownership of radio broadcasting stations and asked the commission to scrap its investigation scheduled July 23.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 15 (AP) -- Today's war communique included the following:

LONDON, July 15 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill brushed away all weasel words and all talk of "association" and bluntly announced to the House of Commons today that the recent agreement between Britain and Russia "is, of course, an alliance and the Russian people are now our allies."

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Mayor La Guardia's warning to peace organizations to beware of peace proposals that are being planted by a representative of Reichfuehrer Hitler in this country received the seal of official approval at the White House today.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 14:

POINT LOOKOUT, L.I., July 15 -- The full board of engineers of the War Department's Division of Rivers and Harbors, highest water-ways authority in the nation, sat in session at the Short Beach Coast Guard Station near here today to consider the proposal to tame Jones Inlet, the treacherous gut between Long Beach and Jones Beach that was the scene last year of 237 boat accidents and 840 Coast Guard rescues.
MOSCOW, July 15 (AP) -- Today's Russian communique included the following:

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, July 15 -- The growth of the British Empire's military power is to be seen in the fact that the New Zealand Expeditionary Force, which lost a third of the men sent to Greece and Crete, according to official disclosures, is now at full strength again.

Five prisoners on their way to Sing Sing Prison and ten other persons were injured yesterday when the police patrol wagon taking the convicts to Grand Central Station overturned at Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street after a collision with a private car.
BERLIN, July 15 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today, dating it "The Fuehrer's Headquarters":
BERLIN, July 15 -- Taking advantage of the relative lull in war news from the Eastern Front the German press is again denying "the legend of the high blockade vulnerability of Continental Europe."

Sorry, indeed, were the Dodgers yesterday, when the time came for them to hid adieu to their Chicago cousins. If Leo Durocher, the loquacious one, muttered a friendly "come hack soon," in keeping with his good neighbor policy, it was pardonable, for twice yesterday Brooklyn manhandled the Cubs, 7 -- 0 and 8 -- 4, and made it four out of five for the series.

A syndicate composed of the Bankers Trust Company, Kidder, Peabody Co. and Estabrook Co. won yesterday the award of $744,000 sewer district and park district bonds of North Hempstead, L.I., on a bid of 100.309 for 1 1/2s.

In a buying movement stimulated by inflationary fears and unfavorable crop reports from the South, futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday sold above 16 cents a pound for the first time since May, 1930. After advancing 13 to 19 points at the opening, the market continued to move ahead until the late afternoon when there was a temporary set-back.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Representatives of the American Federation of Labor Building Trades Unions and government officials are reported to have reached a tentative agreement on a stabilization pact banning strikes, lockouts or jurisdictional stoppages on government construction for the duration of the emergency.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, July 16 -- The Russian High Command announced today that the Red Army forces opposing the German advance toward Leningrad had counter-attacked, destroying German motorized and mechanized forces "section by section" or driving them back to the west.
Active renting of apartments in houses on the East and West Sides was reported yesterday, with, the former area in the lead.
VICHY, Unoccupied France, July 15 -- The text of the British-French convention ending the war in Syria, follows:

Although "Tobacco Road" will not return to the Broadway boards next month -- as indicated last May when the attraction closed its record-breaking engagement here -- the saga of life in the Georgia red clay country will be resuscitated in a fortnight for touring purposes, it was announced yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Testifying at a House committee hearing on the proposed St. Lawrence seaway project, Mayor La Guardia in Washington the other day despite the opposition of an able "advisory committee appointed by him," doubted that the project would harm business at the New York port, and he even expressed the belief that "lower power costs" would "quickly wipe out" any losses the city might suffer.

TOKYO, July 15 -- The Cabinet today decided upon a drastic economy program for the next fiscal year in line with the basic financial policies recently adopted. A communique issued following the Cabinet session said:

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, told his reasons in detail for asking for extended service for Selective Service trainees, Guardsmen and reserves when he spoke before the Senate Military Affairs Committee last Wednesday.

DETROIT, July 15 (AP) -- The Tigers climbed within striking distance of fourth place today by defeating the Athletics, 3 to 2, on Barney McCosky's first home run of the season. Rookie Luman Harris of the Athletics was charged with his first defeat against two victories.

Thirty-three persons were Indicted in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of cooperating with the German Government to violate the espionage laws of this country. One defendant pleaded guilty yesterday. The others will be arraigned in Federal Court on Friday and the trial has been tentatively set for September.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Future industrial defense problems may "dwarf" those now facing the United States, according to Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, who appeared today as a witness before the Special Defense Investigating Committee, headed by Senator Truman of Missouri.

Active leasing of commercial space in the midtown district along Broadway and Fifth Avenue below Thirty-fourth Street was reported yesterday. Tenants were obtained also for a number of stores and brokers noted a number of renewals and contracts for additional space for expansion purposes.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We read in THE TIMES of July 14 that the Regional Plan Association says the cessation of population growth may bring stagnation and blight with consequent economic and social losses to cities.

Another C.V. Whitney homebred dashed to victory at Empire City yesterday when Kingfisher, named after August Belmont's famous horse of post-Civil War days, ran over his opposition in the stretch to score by a length. This was in the Dalmatian Handicap, feature of a program witnessed by 12,232, who wagered $684,706.

Vintage sherry from sunny California pervades the new, translucent amber dessert that comes in cunning little six-ounce jars with gay orange tassels tied about their necks. Tucked under the cords are tiny folded notes -- these to describe the uses of the bottles' tawny contents.

What We Defend One way not to contribute to democratic defense is to insist that three-fifths of all Americans over the age of 65 are "dependent upon charity or relatives." So one witness declared before the Senate Pension Committee the other day.

About 40,500 New Yorkers who became 21 years old after the registration date for the original selective service lottery last October, will be among the 750,000 throughout the nation involved in another goldfish bowl drawing in Washington at 8 o'clock tomorrow night.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel Hofstadter decided yesterday to appoint an official referee to take testimony on the validity of the claims of Arthur G. Klein and Philip Cooper to the Democratic nomination in the Fourteenth Congressional District.

Cotton Crosses 16 Cents Inflationary fears seem to have taken hold of the cotton market, where prices yesterday crossed the 16-cent mark for the first time since May, 1930. In the last five months, cotton futures have advanced an average of about 1 cent a pound a month and recently have been registering new eleven-year high records almost daily.

OSSINING, N.Y., July 15 -- Work halted early this afternoon in the offices, factories and shops of Sing Sing Prison here while nearly 2,400 inmates crowded into the prison chapel to hear the "valedictory address" of Warden Lewis E. Lawes, who ended formally today twenty-one and a half years of service as head of the most famous penal institution in the nation.

Two experts from the Labor and Treasury Departments who have been assigned to the United States Embassy in London at the request of Ambassador John G. Winant left here yesterday morning for Lisbon aboard the Yankee Clipper.
According to a report just received from Maine, bluefin tuna are now plentiful from Kittery to Monhegan, and the chances are excellent for a successful tournament next week.
CLEVELAND, July 15 (AP) -- Pitcher Joe Dobson, who couldn't quite make the grade as a regular with the Indians, proved today they made a mistake in trading him last Winter.

BERLIN, July 15 -- German press discussions of President Roosevelt's "Atlantic policies," among which a multitude of alleged projects involving the acquisition by the United States of air and naval bases in the Eastern Atlantic are included, are assuming more acrimonious accents, and the conclusions reached uniformly imply an avowed determination to force official United States policy to the point of undisguised provocation of Germany.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 15 (AP) -- Roy Henshaw blanked the Syracuse Chiefs for six innings tonight and pitched Jersey City to a 5-to-3 victory to even the series at two games each.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 15 -- Despite ideal weather conditions and a well groomed course, ninety-three starters found the going difficult in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association on the Briar Hills course today.

ROME, July 15 -- The staffs of all United States consulates in Italy left this evening for Lisbon aboard a special train paid for by the United States Government. Thus today, for the first time since 1798, the United States has no consular representation in this country.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Roosevelt signed the Ship Warrants Act authorizing shipping priorities; promoted Daniel W. Tracy to be Assistant Secretary of Labor; promoted Alfred T. Nester of New York to the rank of Consul General; asked Congress for national or regional daylight saving and conferred with Treasury, budget and House leaders on the new tax bill.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today for legislation to provide daylight saving time "upon such a regional or national basis, and for such part, or all, of the year, as he might deem necessary in the interest of our national defense."

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP) -- The second-place Cardinals and the last-place Phillies battled tooth-and-nail for sixteen innings today before the Redbirds eked out a 3-to-2 victory on Jimmy Brown's long fly with the bases full in the sixteenth.

FORT DIX, N.J., July 15 -- The Forty-fourth Division's second trip to Virginia for manoeuvres will be made over different routes from those used last month to avoid paying bridge tolls on the Tacony-Palmyra Bridge, crossing the Delavare River, and other spans over the Potomac and Rappahannock Rivers in the South.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- From a reporter's note-book, a day after Administrator Henderson sent word to American housewives that a long period of domestic shortages and higher prices is at hand:

MAURICE GARLAND FULTON, editor and chief finder of the "Diary and Letters of Josiah Gregg,"* either has led a particularly upright life or was born under a particularly lucky star. The material he found and has now edited as the first of two Gregg volumes is the kind of material that most research workers dream about as they nod in their stalls over old manuscripts and newspaper files.
The Giants were stricken with an acute case of butter-fingers at the Polo Grounds yesterday as four errors gave the Pirates the four runs they needed for a 5-to-1 victory.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 16 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information issued the following communique today:

ALBANY, July 15 -- Representatives of twenty-two major defense contractors, holding more than $1,000,000,000 of defense orders, met here today with executives from about 200 small plants and arranged for the sub-contracting of millions of dollars worth of the work so as to help what Governor Lehman called "the battle of our generation for the rights of free men."

BOSTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Belair Stud's already heavily burdened Fenelon and Foxbrough appear assured of being overloaded with public support tomorrow when, against nine rivals, they will go postward as an entry for the seventh running of the $50,000-added Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

LOS ANGELES, July 15 -- A decision of far-reaching significance in the field of distribution and release schedules of films under the motion-picture consent decree was made today. Arbitrator Herbert S. Cameron sustained with one exception, prevailing zone - release practices of the major distributors.

OTTAWA, July 15 -- Canada adopted an Ickes oil conservation measure today in an order banning the sale, delivery and distribution of gasoline and lubricants to motorists from 7 P.M. to 7 A.M. weekdays and throughout Sunday for all Canada.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- Judge John S. McClelland of the Criminal Courts of Atlanta was elected Grand Exalted Ruler of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, succeeding Joseph G. Buch of Trenton, N.J.

Large companies should be prevented from erecting new plant facilities to do defense work wherever existing plant facilities could be used satisfactorily, George J. Seedman, president of the American Business Congress, declared last night at a meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
SPOKANE, July 15 (AP) -- Jimmy Clark, a stockroom, employe in an aircraft factory, won medal honors of the 1941 national public links championship today with a thirty-six-hole total of 135.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 15 -- Miss Katharine Patten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard B. Patten of Fairview Avenue, this place, was married here this evening to John Albert Lapointe, son of Arthur L. Lapointe of Montreal and the late Mrs. Lapointe.

The New York millinery field can never be static as long as there is a John-Frederics to keep it stirred up. John's mind -- it is he who always puts over the novelties -- is like a veritable Pandora's box. Out of it pop innumerable ideas, some prankish, the majority eminently sound.

LONDON, July 15 -- Bremen and Hanover received heavy blastings last night by bombers of the Royal Air Force, when many tons of high explosives and thousands of incendiaries were dropped on both cities. Extensive fires were started and considerable damage was done to the Bremen docks and among industrial buildings in Hanover.

Export licenses permitting the shipment of more than $1,700,000 worth of machine tools, machine tool parts, oil field equipment and related products from United States ports, where they have been in storage for two to more than six months, have been granted to Amtorg Trading Corporation, American buying and selling agency of the Soviet Union, by the Office of Export Control, according to information reaching exporters here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Tietjen Lang Drydock Company of New York City offered the Maritime Commission today $31,500 annual rent for Pier 6 of the Hoboken, N.J., terminal. It was the only bid.

Formal announcement that the Democratic county leaders in New York City would meet this morning to select the Democratic organization ticket for the mayoralty campaign was made yesterday by Edward J. Flynn, Democratic National Chairman and also leader of Bronx County.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Possibility of a further cut in automobile production beyond the 20 per cent reduction ordered by the government, effective Aug. 1, was intimated today as prominent figures in the automotive world conferred with Leon Henderson, administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply.

IN the wake of the football storm that swirled around the academic area of Urbana, the home of the University of Illinois, Bob Zuppke bobbed up with the ball again. Perhaps "still" instead of "again" would be the right word except that "still' doesn't fit Zuppke, even if he has held possession of the ball at Urbana for twenty-eight years.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 15 -- Mrs. Theron Roundell Strong gave a luncheon today at Casa Basso, on the Montauk Highway, for her cousin, Mrs. George Edward Wood of New York, who arrived yesterday to spend several weeks with Mrs. Strong at Asher Lodge.

A good part of the coast of France, on the English Channel and the Bay of Biscay, is almost made to order for the Summer vacationer. He has been going there for as long as there have been Summer vacations. The Spanish, the English, in recent years the Americans, have known and loved sections of that coast.
ALBANY, July 15 -- The adjutant general released the following orders today:

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Roosevelt indicated today the need for control of rents in areas subject to housing shortages and stated that the problem might be dealt with in a bill separate from the one designed to control prices generally.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 15 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission and the North American Company disclosed jointly today that they were hopeful of reaching soon a compromise in their dispute over the utility's right to dissolve a subsidiary, the North American Light and Power Company.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Howard Bruce have come to the Ambassador from Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The House Rivers and Harbors Committee was told today that while the principal demand for the St. Lawrence seaway came from the Middle West, at least half the cost of the $285,000,000 project would fall on four Eastern States which had no need for the development.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 16 (U.P.) -- The Russian High Command reported today that German mechanized forces 150 miles from Leningrad had been "hurled back to the west" or destroyed in a fierce battle.

LONDON, July 15 -- Dr. F.J. van de Meulebroeck, Burgomaster of Brussels, has been, arrested by the German military authorities, Belgian Premier Hubert Pierlot announced here today. He was dismissed from office last month for failure to cooperate with the occupation authorities.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Government officials here took under "serious consideration" today action by the New Jersey Legislature which would have the effect of hampering, if not of nullifying, a defense housing project in "Union County now in process of construction for workers in the Federal shipyard at Kearny.

Officials of ten local housing authorities awarded yesterday a total of $29,474,000 of short-term note obligations, dated July 29, 1941. Of the total, a syndicate headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company purchased $22,380,000 at various interest rates.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Warren Wright's Whirlaway, king of the 3-year-olds, turned in an exciting workout for the $65,000 Arlington Classic by romping to victory in a $5,000 special mile and a furlong race before 20,000 at Arlington Park today.

What is perhaps the greatest battle in military history -- the second phase of the invasion of Russia -- is now five to seven days old. Judging from the communiques of both sides, the Germans are still driving deeper into Russia, though they have not yet approximated that definitive success, annihilation of the Red Army, that is their primary goal.

ROME, July 15 (U.P.) -- The Turin newspaper Stampa claimed today that the Germans were preparing to spring a huge "death trap" on the Russian Army defending Moscow and seal the doom of the Soviet capital in one mighty blow.

Wendell L. Willkie predicted in a radio speech last night that the peace to follow the present world conflict would be "written in understanding of the aspirations of all men for freedom and opportunity."

Joseph. J. Doyle, delegate from the Panama Railroad liner Ancon to the National Maritime Union's convention at Cleveland, who resigned from the union when faced with expulsion proceedings on Sunday, and was barred from the ship on his return here, declared yesterday that he would appeal to authorities in Washington for re-assignment to his former job.

VICHY, France, July 15 -- In signing the military accord with Great Britain for the cessation of hostilities in Syria, France renounces none or her rights to her mandate in the Levant. This is the principal point stressed here on publication of the text today.
RENO, Nev., July 15 -- Katharine Ingham Brush Winans, who writes fiction under the name Katharine Brush, filed a divorce suit today against Charles Hubert Winans, charging cruelty.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Defeat of a resolution permitting the President to use the armed forces outside this hemisphere probably would not interfere with his power to use the forces as might become necessary. The following excerpt from Vol. 129, American Law Reports, is pertinent:

Miss Rose Anne Mooney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Mooney of 29 Washington Square, this city, and Far Rockaway, Queens, was married yesterday morning to Lieutenant Robert Emmet Curry, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Curry of 1010 Fifth Avenue, in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary, Star of the Sea, at Far Rockaway.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's communication to Congress today on daylight-saving time was as follows:

With Donald McNeill all but helpless to resist him in the center of the court, Joe Fishbach had an easy forehand passing shot to make for a 5-3 lead after winning the first set from the national titleholder yesterday in the New York State tennis championships at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The War Department released the following orderi today, dated July 15:

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers was the successful bidder yesterday for $5,680,000 city of Boston funding and relief bonds on their bid of 100.77 for 1 1/2s. The bonds, dated Aug. 1, 1941, $568,000 of which will mature annually on Aug. 1, 1942 to 1951, were reoffered at prices to yield 0.25 to 1.50 per cent for varying maturities through 1950, at a dollar price of 99 3/4 for the 1951 maturity.

Almost twenty-four hours after her scheduled sailing time, the Navy transport West Point lifted her anchor at 3:10 o'clock yesterday afternoon and steamed over the horizon, bound for Lisbon with 464 German and Italian Consular officials, employes of agencies of those governments and members of their families, all leaving at the insistence of the United States Government.

VICHY, France, July 16 -- By a decree that will be published tomorrow General Maxime Weygand, in addition to his position of Delegate General for Africa, will become Governor General of Algeria. He replaces Admiral Jean Abrial by decision of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, the Chief of State, with whom General Weygand and Admiral Abrial conferred in the past few days.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Taking issue with. Mayor La Guardia, James W. Danahy, vice president and managing director of the West Side Association of Commerce, predicted today that the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway would do irreparable damage to the Port of New York.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. William Amory Parker have come to the St. Regis from North Easton, Mass.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 (AP) -- The Cubs dropped the Phillies deeper in last place tonight with a 9-to-5 victory. The veteran pitcher, Charley Root, who started for Chicago, helped with a homer as did Catcher Clyde McCullough, who connected with two on in the third inning.

LONDON, July 16 -- Lacking direct news from Tokyo, the British are awaiting diplomatic dispatches and developments to explain the meaning of Japan's change in cabinet. It is not now known here whether the fall of Prince Fumimaro Konoye's government presages an increase in belligerency or is an expression of Japanese war fatigue.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Thirty-three child victims of the Blitzkrieg on Great Britain have been "adopted" by James C. McReynolds, retired associate justice of the Supreme Court, who has offered further to be one of a thousand donors of 510,000 each to the Save the Children Fund.

BERLIN, July 16 -- British-American speculation over the effects on German economy of the Anglo-Soviet pact are dismissed here as wishful thinking. As such speculation endeavors to construe an "encirclement of Germany similar to that existing during the World War," such calculations, it is asserted, proceed from wholly false premises.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- A strong to 20cent higher market today carried average cost of hogs above $11 and top grades to a new four-year peak of $11.80. while strong prices prevailed in the cattle market and steady to 15-cent higher values in the sheep market.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- An opportunity for exchanging views on the Far Eastern situation in the light of the resignation of the Japanese Cabinet was offered at separate conferences held today by Stunner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, with Dr. A. Loudon, Minister of the Netherlands, and Nevile Butler, Minister-Counselor of the British Embassy, who called in the absence from the capital of Viscount Halifax, the Ambassador.

Contributions totaling $1,387,595 have been obtained in the United Service Organizations drive through the National Corporations Committee, it was announced last night by John W. Hanes, committee chairman.

George Scalise, former president of the International Building Service Employes Union, recently sentenced to ten to twenty years in Sing Sing for looting the funds of the union, yesterday obtained a writ of habeas corpus in an attempt to have himself returned to Sing Sing from the old Bronx County Jail.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered the International Utilities Corporation to answer charges by the staff of the commission that the company's Class B stock, although it has an asset value of considerably less than zero, has 89 per cent of the total voting power.

BOSTON, July 16 -- Samuel D. Riddle's comparatively inexperienced War Relic, a 3-year-old son of Man o' War, surprised his aged owner and most of the 25,000 spectators today by not only winning the 567,100 Massachusetts Handicap but also clipping a fifth of a second from the Suffolk Downs track record for the mile and a furlong.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- A request from President Roosevelt that the House Ways and Means Committee revise its $3,500,000,000 tax bill to conform to the Treasury Department's invested capital plan of computing corporation excess profits taxes is expected to be laid before the committee tomorrow.

The annual statistical report of the American Iron and Steel Institute for 1940, out today, includes for the first time a table of shipments of steel products to principal consuming industries in addition to other data not given in previous vears.

PORT MONMOUTH, N.J., July 16 -- Miss Eleanore Maldoaado, 20 years old, of 118 Tomkins Avenue, Brooklyn, was believed to have been drowned this afternoon at Cedar Beach on Raritan Bay. The girl, the daughter of the Rev. Louis Maldonado, pastor of the Pentacostal Church, Brooklyn, was last seen at 4 P. M. floating on an inner tube 100 yards from shore.

New attractions at the Zoological Park and the Botanical Garden in Bronx Park were viewed yesterday by members of the Park Association of New York City. Eighty-four members of the association were guests of the New York Zoological Society and the New York Botanical Garden on the inspection tour.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 16 (AP) -- A German bid for the right to send troops across Turkey into the Soviet Caucasus was reported today as a large item in military, diplomatic and economic stresses pulling this country into a new tug-of-war between Germany and Great Britain.

Among the thousands of inventions and ideas submitted for national defense the government has found "one or two of very great importance," which may revolutionize even the Blitzkrieg type of warfare, Karl Penning, former assistant commissioner of patents, revealed yesterday.

Experiences of foreign traders in obtaining United States Treasury Department licenses for transactions with foreign customers will be made available to its membership by the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau of the National Association of Credit Men under a plan announced here yesterday.
VICHY, July 16 -- General Henri Fernant Dentz, Vichy's High Commissioner for Syria, and his staff are understood to have sailed for France before today's occupation of Beirut by the British.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- The Calumet Farm Stable sent out another stake winner today, Proud One galloping to victory in the $2,500 added Cinderella Handicap for fillies and mares before a crowd of 10,000 at Arlington Park.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Specialty Accounting Supply Manufacturers Association of Chicago was charged in a Federal Trade Commission complaint today with being a combination to restrain and eliminate competition by such methods" as price fixing, use of "espionage, coercion and cooperation" to enforce adherence to fixed prices, and the operation of "bogus independents" to destroy competition.

James Reeves, president of Daniel Reeves, Inc., announced yesterday that the boards of directors of this company and of Safeway Stores, Inc., met separately on Tuesday to authorize the calling of special meetings of stockholders to approve a merger of the two companies.

LONDON, July 16 -- The hair-breadth escape of two young Belgian Army flyers from their country in a borrowed training plane was told by them in a press conference at the Ministry of Information today.

Bob Falkenburg, the Hollywood high school boy who holds the national crown, was extended by Alan Watson of Elizabeth, N.J., before reaching the final of the Eastern boys' tennis championship at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Two members of the House Military Affairs Committee replied in a minority report today to a majority of their colleagues who recently criticized the failure of various defense agencies to procure an adequate supply of strategic materials and absolved the Aluminum Company of America of blame for the alleged shortage of aluminum.

LONDON, Thursday, July 17 -- British bombers have continued their bold attacks on Germany and German-occupied territory in fulfillment of the prediction made several months ago by Prime Minister Winston Churchill that Britain's air offensive against the Nazis would increase in intensity.
London, July 16 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

MOSCOW, July 16 (U.P.) -- The Moscow Soviet, preparing for a long struggle against Germany, today ordered the immediate rationing of foodstuffs and manufactured goods for the 4,200,000 residents of the Russian capital, effective tomorrow.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 16 -- The position of the German Army in Cyrenaica, which only two months ago was a menace to Egypt, is regarded as becoming daily more precarious as the Royal Air Force goes farther afield in the heaviest air offensive in the Middle East since the days preceding the first British attack.

With planes roaring over La Guardia Field to lend emphasis to his words, Mayor La Guardia described yesterday the city's plans for collecting used aluminum to release more of the metal for airplanes for defense.

The threat of a general A.F. of L. building strike to enforce the demand of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers for control over Consolidated Edison construction jobs ran into opposition from two quarters yesterday.

George F. Baker, chairman of the board of the First National Bank of New York, left a gross estate of $40,620,079, which was reduced by debts and expenses to a net of $25,689,668, it was shown in the estate tax appraisal filed here yesterday.

Stockholders of the North American Car Company are to meet on Aug. 5 to vote an authorization of a merger with the Palace Poultry Car Company, a wholly owned subsidiary, and a recapitalization to meet arrears on the parent company's first preferred stock, which will amount to S46.50 a share after payment of a dividend of $1.50 tomorrow.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 16 -- The opening of the Studio Players' season in the John Drew Memorial Theatre at Guild Hall on Friday, with Francis Swann's "Out of the Frying Pan," will be the occasion for much entertaining. Miss Fanny M. Cottenet and Rawlins Cottenet will have Miss Lucrezia Bori as their guest at the opening, and Mrs. Dudley Roberts will have her house guest, Mrs. F. Luis Mora, with her.

Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge, who owns the house at 800 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Sixty-first Street, extended her property yesterday when she took title to the five-story residence adjoining at 5 East Sixty-first Street, opposite j the Hotel Pierre.

Members of the New York Curb Exchange were asked yesterday by the board of governors to approve constitutional changes permitting purchase and retirement of not more than fifty of the 550 seats on the Exchange at prices not to exceed $1,000 each.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Pricefixing legislation designed to control the cost of the defense program and prevent a possibly ruinous spiral of inflation was placed on the agenda for this session of Congress today.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The House defeated today, by a vote of 198 to 94, a bill which would empower the Secretary of War to fill vacancies at the Military Academy from a list of eligibles furnished by the academy's academic board if there were vacancies thirty days prior to the beginning of the academic year.

Two doctors and four women employed at what the police described as a "wholesale abortion mill" operating ina private home at 241 East Eighteenth Street were arrested in a raid yesterday by ten detectives in command of Acting Captain Vincent J. Kiernan of the Fourth Detective District.

The adoption of a monthly contributory retirement plan for its employes was announced yesterday by the Tide Water Associated Oil Company. The plan provides for a normal retirement allowance to employes reaching' the age of 65 and having twenty or more years of service.

Freedom of the Seas One group of New York residents faces in very direct form the problem of reconciling freedom and security or choosing between the two. They are the tenants of the Aquarium in Battery Park. Removal of the Aquarium to other quarters has been decided on, and this may involve, according to Park Commissioner Moses, dumping some of the fish back into the sea.
The Franklin Society for Home Building and Savings announces the sale of six dwellings in New Jersey in separate transactions.

A proposal that skirt manufacturers refuse to take in fabrics already ordered from wool goods producers who do not provide either continuing or separate guarantees of fiber content will be presented to the board of directors of the National Skirt Manufacturers Association, B. H. Lerner, executive director of the association, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Office of Production Management reported today that it faced "an Urgent problem" in supplying enough fabricated aluminum parts on time for defense production in the next six months.
TOKYO, Thursday, July 17 -- To end the policy deadlock between Japanese leaders in view of the world situation the second Cabinet of Prince Fumimaro Konoye resigned last night after a year's tenure.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, July 16 (AP) -- Admiral Jean Decoux, Governor General of French Indo-China, says his government "has not received any request or demands from the Japanese for further concessions."

Demand for fresh pork cuts yesterday was slow. Other classes moved fair to good. Fresh pork cuts were barely steady. Other classes were steady to strong with some sales of lamb and cow beef higher, With one of the large slaughter houses closed, kosher meats opened strong to sharply higher.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 16 -- Members of the Garden Club of Southampton met this morning at Driftwood, the oceanfront home of Mrs. John Crerar. Mrs. John H. Morice, president of the organization, presided. A feature of the event was a talk on table arrangements by Miss Hazel Heissenbuttel of New York.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 16 -- Mrs. V.D. Crisp of Cedar Creek won low gross honors with 43, 41 -- 84 in a field of twenty-seven contestants in the one-day golf tournament of the Long Island Women's Golf Association over the picturesque Huntington Country Club course today.

For administering with consummate artistry a classic snub to the Kaiser's Imperial Array, Adolphe Max, late Burgomaster of Brussels, was imprisoned. It WSLS the only method the Germans could contrive for dealing with, the effrontery of the bearded little man who insisted upon treating them not as conquerors but as usurpers.

VICHY, France, July 16 (U.P.) -- Admiral Jean Abrial is said by the German-controlled Paris press to be in line for a "preponderant situation" in the occupied capital. Following the French capitulation in Syria, the Paris newspapers demanded that Marshal Petain shake up his Cabinet and do away with "a regime of inexperience, instability and costly rivalries."
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : In his column printed in your issue of July 1 Arthur Krock summarized a Congressional committee report as follows:

Reginald Stewart conducted his third and final concert of the season with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. His program included Brahms's First symphony and two works which had not been previously played there-his own transcription of Mendelssohn's piano fugue in E minor, and "Benedictus," by the late Sir Alexander Mackenzie.

A $20,000,000 Stake The plan of reorganization for the St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railroad approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission would wipe out the $20,000,000 investment made by the Southern Pacific Company in the Cotton Belt's stocks.

MANILA, Thursday, July 17 -- The United States Navy, on orders from Washington, began at dawn today to mine the entrances to Manila Bay and neighboring Subic Bay, both vital areas for the defense of Manila and the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The United States imported 65,093 long tons of crude rubber during June at an average declared price of 18.2 cents a pound, nearly a half cent over the May average and the highest in the past eighteen months, the Department of Commerce reported today.
ST. LOUIS, July 16 (AP) -- Chet Laabs had a perfect day at bat today, hitting two home runs, a triple and a double in four times up to lead the Browns to an 11-to-2 conquest of the Athletics.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Secretary Knox issued an order today that the 37,647 enlisted naval reservists now on active duty be held in service for the duration of the national emergency. His order also prohibits reservists now on duty from resigning even though their four-year enlistments expire.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Twenty of the highest-ranking officers of the Army, one lieutenant general and nineteen major generals, figured today in a drastic shake-up of commands, part of the program whereby General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, is seeking to revitalize the military services.

A COOL chap, this Willis N. (Jersey) Jones. Drops by in July to talk ice hockey. He's the defense man of the Rangers-with the typewriter. And by word of mouth. But he talks and writes fluently of other clubs, too. Of hockey in general, for that matter. He can speak with deep feeling of a minor league club or an Allan Cup player.
CHICAGO, July 16 -- William D. Sahm sat in police headquarters tonight and calmly told how he had stolen about $300,000 from a Lancaster, Pa., hank where he had been employed fifteen years.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 16 -- Mrs. W.A. Winant of Seawane and her 17-year-old son, John, captured the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association mother-and-son championship on the Nassau Country Club course today.

Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union and California director of the C. I. O., voiced his views on national and International issues yesterday afternoon at a combination press interview and reception that turned into a. sort of town meeting without moderator.

Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and the State and local officials who cooperate with them, in the police work of the national defense were warned yesterday against stirring up fears and excitement in their efforts to avert sabotage and espionage.

LONDON, Thursday, July 17 (U.P.) -- A great army of oppressed peoples who may some day rise in revolt against Hitlerism has been mobilized in the Nazi-subjected nations by Great Britain's "V for victory" crusade, the American people were told early today in a broadcast by J.B. Priestley, English author.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 16 -- Ernst Lubitsch signed Ginger Rogers today to star in his first production at Twentieth Century-Fox, "A Self Made Cinderella," which, according to the studio, is a story of "an American working girl who seeks romance."

During the past ten days nearly every one in the country has expressed an opinion about the lamentable episode of the Thirty-fifth Division boys who yoo-hooed at some ladies in shorts at the Memphis Country Club. But there is still another side of this incident to examine.

FORT BLISS, Texas, July 16 -- "Grasshopper" planes, the kind a person can learn to fly in ten hours, won high praise today here as a valuable aid to cavalry. Major Gen. Innis P. Swift assigned to them a definite job in the First Cavalry Division's ten-day desert manoeuvres which will begin tomorrow.

Al Jolson. the actor, was listee yesterday among the lessees of nev residential quarters, together with a number of other professional people and business executives. One broker reported leasing several large suites.

LONDON, July 16 -- The British Broadcasting Corporation will not play any more national anthems on its 9 P.M. Sunday programs, Minister of Information Alfred Duff Cooper announced in the Commons today. National airs of different nations would be played each week instead, he added, and on occasion the music of two or three might be combined.

Investors were reported yesterday as the purchasers of a number of Manhattan properties, including a large apartment in the Inwood section. Among other parcels sold was a loft building in Bleeker Street, just south of the Astor Place section.

BAST HARTFORD, Conn., July 16 -- Wage increases averaging five cents an hour were announced here today for 25,000 employes of the three manufacturing divisions of United Aircraft Corporation, adding $4,200,000 to the annual payroll. The wage increase is the third in seven months.

Despite the Nazi armies' victories in the field, the German people showed a marked apathy toward the war, Stephen Laird, Berlin correspondent for Time, Inc., and his wife, Lael, reported yesterday upon arriving here aboard the Dixie Clipper.

SPOKANE, July 16 (AP) -- Two young par blasters, still under voting age led the parade in first and second round matches of the 1941 national public links golf championship today that saw the defending titleholder and two former crown-wearers knocked out of the running.

Big Pete, the 4,500-pound hippo, had a belated birthday party yesterday afternoon at the Bronx Zoo and promptly suffered an attack of temperament. He took one sniff of the fifty-pound cake, nipped a couple of carrots and then refused to have anything more to do with it.

At the request of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, the Securities and Exchange Commission is aiding in the surveillance of unregulated commodity markets. The SEC has asked the New York Stock Exchange "to insist in this endeavor by requesting all members who are not subject to the regulations of the commodities exchanges to require of their customers the same initial margins as those prescribed by such exchanges."

The widest break in cotton futures in almost three weeks resulted yesterday in erasing virtually all of the grains of the two preceding days. After an early advance of 9 to 15 points, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yielded sharply to close with net losses of 20 to 34 points, or $1 to $1.70 a bale.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (U.P.)-- A prediction that American-made warplanes within the next few months will give Royal Air Force supremacy over the Nazi Luftwaffe for the balance of the war is made in the new issue of the authoritative Aircraft Year Book for 1941 that was issued today.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : I have just read Bishop Manning's letter to THE TIMES on the proposal to compel the filing of a joint income tax return by man and wife. He calls this proposal "retrogressive, inequitable and indefensible."

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- Cecil (Tex) Hughson, turning in his third straight victory since the Red Sox recalled him from Louisville recently, held the White Sox to four hits today to shade Buck Ross, 2 to 1, in a hurlers' duel settled in the ninth inning.

Charges of communism were brought against Dr. Walter Scott Neff, suspended City College psychology instructor, at the opening of his departmental trial yesterday, before a Board of Higher Education committee of three, meeting at downtown City College, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

United States Marshal Arthur Jaeger of Brooklyn yesterday started libel actions in the Brooklyn. Federal Court against the Italian freighters. San Leonardo, at Brewer's Drydock. Staten Island, and Viilar Perosa, tied up at Pier 46, Brooklyn.
Two large apartment properties, one in the Wodlawn area and the other opposite Crotona Park, figured in Bronx realty trades yesterday.

The 3,500 bug drivers, conductors, garage workers, mechanics and maintenance men employed by the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation and its affiliates will receive improved working conditions and wage rises ranging from 2 to 8 cents an hour under an arbitration award made public yesterday by William H. Davis, chairman of the National Defense Mediation Board.

To THE EDITOR op THE NEW YORK TIMES : If an American Senator visiting England were misquoted by a British journalist and made to say rude things about Parliament, he would, I think, write a letter to The Times to dissociate himself from the statement.

Industrial buying policies are beginning to show conflicting trends, with purchasing agents in the Detroit district curtailing advance buying and those on the West Coast extending it, according to reports from associations in those centers.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Participants in the credit executives conference of the National Retail Furniture Association here today were told by Rolf Nugent, consultant on consumer credit for OP ACS and director of the department of consumer studies, Russell Sage Foundation, that consumer credit outstanding as of June 30, 1941, had risen to $8,800,000,000, the highest on record.

Electric power output last week more than recovered its losses in the holiday week ended July 5. The adjusted index rose to 119.5 from 116.5 (revised) for the holiday week, tout was still slightly under that for the week ended June 28, when it stood at 119.6. A year ago it was 102.9.

NEWARK, N.J., July 16 (AP) -- Hank Borowy, Newark right-hander, delivered a single in the eleventh inning with one out to score George Stirnweiss from second base and win a pitching battle from Orlin Collier of the Baltimore Orioles, 3 to 2, tonight.

The pompadour was the conversation piece of Sally Victor's millinery showing yesterday afternoon. Sally is prophetic when it comes to pompadours. She believes that they are now on their way to the Styx in their original bloated form and that instead the stylish East will flatten its pompadours at the front, sweeping their hair back from the temples.

Pumpkin seeds-from pumpkins as impressive and proud as the golden sphere that furnished a coach for Cinderella -- are creating quite a flurry in the Manhattan specialty shop where they are making their debut. The crisp, delicate, little nuts with their palegreen skin and rich, mysterious flavor are toasted, salted and can be served at cocktail time to the inexpressible delight of venture-some investigators.
BOSTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Pirates found five Boston pitchers for fifteen hits today to win the second game of a double-header, 13 to 5, after dropping the opener, 4 to 1.

The Giants felt the Reds breathing hot on their necks yesterday in a grim effort to overhaul them in the race for third place and the New Yorkers seemed so startled by the proximity of the champions that they bolted from the barrier in a hurry.

Jerome Schoenthal has leased the store adjoining the Fifty-ninth Street entrance to the Hotel Delmonico at the Park Avenue intersection with that thoroughfare, for a retail shoe establishment to be known as Jaybar. Bentley Gardiner was the broker.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 16 -- A former Atlantic City judge, who admitted lying to save Enoch. L. (Nucky) Johnson, only to be "lost and left all alone" when authorities and left all alone" when he became involved with the authorities, testified today that the Republican leader of Atlantic County made more than the contractor for the construction of the. $1,000,000 Union Station of the Pennsylvania-Reading' Sea Shore Lines.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Despite the nation's defense production program, 5,000,000 persons will remain unemployed this year, Corrington Gill, assistant commissioner of the Works Progress Administration, said today.
WICHITA, Kan., July 16 (AP) -- Lenore Long Bales Bowman, 18 years old, departed for her home in Kansas City today, leaving in jail a bridegroom whom she accused of bringing her here against her will.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A movement developed in the Senate Military Affairs Committee today to have Congress extend the service of selectees by passing a simple resolution declaring that the national interest would be imperiled if they left the Army at the end of their year's training.

Cloud Wampler, president of Stern, Wampler Co., Inc., and a member of the investment banking fraternity for twenty-five years, will turn from finance to industry when on Sept. 1 he assumes his new duties as executive vice president of the Carrier Corporation, largest manufacturer of air-conditioning equipment in the world.

CHUNGKING, China, July 16 -- Movements of Japanese troops in China Tuesday increased the belief in Chinese Government circles that Japan would soon take new aggressive military or political action in some part or parts of the Far East. Opinion is divided over where the Japanese will strike.
Last night at Ebbets Field the Cardinals became the old Gas-house Gang for one devastating 5-run inning and thus sliced oat game from the league lead still held by the Dodgers.

A charge that New York City high schools have "coddled" their students to the point where graduates are unwilling to accept uninviting Jobs, often preferring government-made work, was made yesterday in the Board of Education's annual report on its cooperative education program.
Festive carnival lights over East 115th Street, near First Avenue, last night illuminated a colorful scene of Old World gayety in New York's uptown Little Italy.
MOSCOW, July 16 (AP) -- Today's communique included the following:

The Democratic leaders in New York City announced yesterday their agreement on the Mayoralty slate for the coming campaign, with William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn as the candidate for Mayor, David H. Knott of Manhattan for Controller and M. Maldwin Fertig of the Bronx for President of the City Council.

80% Delivery on Men's Wear One reason for the extensive forward buying on furnishings by men's wear retailers for Fall and Winter is their expectation that 20 per cent of their purchases will never be delivered, a store executive remarked yesterday.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), July 16 -- The price movements on the Bourse were irregular most of the day but the close was firm, especially the domestic industrials. A.K.U. rose 1 to 150 1/4, Philips was unchanged and Unilever was 2 3/8 higher at 133 5/8.

BERLIN, July 16 (U.P.) -- The Nazi press continued an anti-Roosevelt tirade today, charging the President with seeking to drag America into the war and asserting that the "United States had aggressive intentions toward the Azores and Ireland.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 16 -- Arthur Williams of the Yale golf team, playing in the event for the first time, tied John Handwerg Jr. of Rivervale today for the qualifying medal in the annual New Jersey State junior championship.

Cars of export freight other than grain unloaded at North Atlantic ports in the first six months of 1941 numbered 184,231, up 13.6 per cent from the total in the same period last year, according to the Association of American Railroads. The total for Atlantic, Gulf and Pacific ports was 283,537 cars, up 2.5 per cent.

BEIRUT, July 15 (Delayed) -- British soldiers were encamped tonight in the race track enclosure on Beirut's outskirts. They were busy polishing" up buttons preparatory to their ceremonial entry into the city, where they expect a popular ovation welcoming them.

Elizabeth Daly, a Farrar Rinehart author known for her mystery novels, will have her first non-mystery novel ready for September publication under the title "The Street Has Changed." Another author on the same publisher's list, Cecile Matschat, who wrote "Suwannee River" and "Preacher on Horseback," will try her hand at a mystery novel.

BERLIN, July 16 -- Although the Germans revealed virtually nothing today in regard to the course of their invasion of Russia, whose former borders have been pierced after more than three weeks of ferocious fighting, authoritative quarters implied this evening that important military information could be expected at the end of the week.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The War Department today awarded contracts totaling $9,387,417. The awards to concerns in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, not previously published, were as follows :

FOR DIX, N. J., July 16 -- Training for the Forty-fourth. Division followed schedules today with little indication that the entire division, except its new anti-tank battalion, would leave here tomorrow evening: for two weeks of war games in Caroline County, Va.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- President Roosevelt met with Leland Olds, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, Secretary Ickes, Ben Cohen and Senators Norris and Stewart in a conference 'which was followed by an announcement of an immediate defense power facilities construction program.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission filed today with the commission a brief asking for prompt reduction of the capital structure of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation to a single class of common stock.

CLEVELAND, July 16 -- There again was no stopping the Yankees today as, with Joe DiMaggio still the spearhead of their spectacular drive, they ripped through the Indians with such combined speed and force that the Tribe scarcely had time to figure what was coming off.

For nearly two years Hitler has been sitting like a black spider in the middle of Europe, casting out lines and tentacles in every direction in order to keep death and destruction as far as possible from his own country, and especially from the great forge of war he has built at the center of the web.
The British air offensive against Western Germany and German-occupied territory commenced to pay increasing dividends yesterday, according to London.
BERLIN, July 16 (AP) -- A German High Commatid communique, issued on the Eastern Front today, said:

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Commodity shortages, contractions of living standards, personal war penalties ranging from the high sacrifice of life and career to the petty one of daily ease, some degree of inflation and the loss of individual liberties-all these are the possible consequences to Americans of Hitler's ambition and its overwhelming support by the German people.

Total Eclipse scored his fourth victory in his last five starts yesterday at Empire City and thus became another of the large number of selling platers trainer Hirsch Jacobs has converted into something approaching stake horses. In the Ordinance Handicap, named for the great racer of years ago, Total Eclipse faced only three others, but each was a horse of some pretension.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, July 17 -- With German armies poised for coups de grace against the Russian lines in three main sectors -- Pskov, Vitebsk and Novograd Volynsk -- the main test of the Russian defensive organization appears about to commence after five days of fierce and stubborn resistance against the invading forces, with both sides losing heavily in attacks and counter-attacks.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 16 -- The day, one of the most perfect golfing days of the year, and the course, Quaker Ridge, one of the country's finest, attracted a record throng for the Metropolitan Golf Association's third 18-hole handicap event today.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 16 (AP) -- The British Royal Air Force Middle East communique said today:

Opposition to the proposal of the City Planning Commission to place thirty blocks in the "Cord Meyer section" of Forest Hills, Queens in a "G" zone restricted to single-family houses will be presented by George C. Meyer, president of the Cord Meyer Development Company, and other property owners when a hearing on the plan comes before the Board of Estimate today.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, aided by 100 detectives and uniformed patrolmen and fifty attache's of his office, early yesterday morning brought into the open a "long-range" investigation of general racketeering that he charged was hampering national defense efforts in this port.

ROME, July 16 -- The train bearing the United States consular agents and their families to Lisbon was held up early this morning at San Remo, a few miles from the French border. As soon as the United States Embassy was informed of this Ambassador William Phillips called on Count Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, for an explanation.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 16 (AP) -- Professor Carle C. Zimmerman of Harvard called upon patriotic Americans today to have more children.

BERNE, Switzerland. July 16 -- In every sector of the Eastern front the Russians are continuing to resist so stubbornly that between the Drut and Berezina Rivers they have virtually regained some of their lost ground. This stands out from an analysis of the communiques on both sides.

Using as his inspiration the memories of boyhood fishing days on the Potomac River, Raymond G. Barger, 34-year-old sculptor, designed an interesting group of bronze figures which have just Keen set in place to complete the center park and pool of Parkchester, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's housing project in the East Bronx.

Beyond yesterday's announcement that "The Beautiful People" is not to close on Saturday, after all, lies another of the bizarre touches William Saroyan is bringing to show business. A week or so ago, when trade at the Lyceum wasn't very heavy, the cast of the play wandered over to Equity and volunteered to take a salary cut.

Changes in New York Stock Exchange rules covering margins in accounts where a trader is long on convertible security and short that into which it may be converted were announced yesterday by Edward C. Gray, director of the department of member firms.

WASHINGTON. July 16 -- John M. Carmody, Administrator of the Federal Works Agency, has requested Governor Edison to veto the bill passed this week by the New Jersey Legislature which would make a separate municipal corporation of the defense housing now under construction at Clark. Township in Union County.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Libera hedging' sales, largely in the De cember, imparted a heavy under tone to the wheat market today but the market rallied later on mil buying and short covering, only to weaken toward the close, when cotton commenced to react and the finish was near the bottom witt losses of 1/2 to 3/4 cent a bushel.

BRIELLE, N.J., July 16 -- With poor prospects for surf casting, because of recent adverse winds which, brought the waves pounding on the beach, we decided to run off-shore and see what the deep sea had to offer.

Case histories of seventy campaigns in twenty major advertising classifications, all conducted in 1940, are outlined in the third annual Blue Book issued yesterday toy the research and promotion department of the Bureau of Advertising.

HAVANA, July 16 -- President Fulgencio Batista's Cabinet resigned today as a result of friction between the Ministers and Congress that threatened to block passage of measures requested by the President.

With the delivery of two new merchant ships to their operators yesterday and today, a total of ninety-seven of the 500 ships in the Maritime Commission's long-range shipbuilding' program will have been completed, it was announced by the commission yesterday.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., July 16 (AP) -- Dr. Hugh M. Parshall, a winner of two Hambletonian stakes, today piloted his own brown trotting colt Perpetual to a two-out-of-three heat victory in the $10,000 National Stake, regarded as a test for the rich Hambletonian at Goshen.

The question of good faith has been raised in connection with the President's recommendation that the period of training for selective service men be extended. Some members of Congress argue that a contract, strictly limited to twelve months of training, was made a year ago with the young men then called into the Army under the Selective Service Act.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- Two high-ranking officers of the Army and Navy alternately cheered and sobered the seventy-seventh annual national convention of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks today by assertions that the nation's naval forces were ready to operate in any theatre of war and that the defense program would fail unless the public was awakened, to the urgency of the world crisis.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Eight hundred carefully guarded capsules were tossed about on a canvas today to insure a thorough mixing of the numbers for tomorrow night's second draft drawing which will determine the order in which 750,000 young men are called up to qualify for military training.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A defense power expansion program involving the expenditure to up to $470,000,000 annually for the duration of the emergency will be started immediately, Leland Olds, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, said today after conferring with President Roosevelt on the power situation.

LONDON, July 16 (AP) -- A pledge that, even if disaster befell in the west, the Red armies would retire behind the Ural Mountains and fight on from the vast, remote spaces of Asiatic Russia was made today by Russian Ambassador Ivan Maisky.
PITTSBURGH, July 16 (AP) -- Samuel H. Isenberg, at 35 the father of twelve children, was disappointed today over receiving quick deferment from Army service because of his long list of dependents.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 16 -- Rosecliff, the elaborate villa which was formerly the Summer residence of Mr. and Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs of New York, was sold at auction today for $21,000.
