Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 3940 have been made against earnings in many reports.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company announced yesterday that it is building a $22,000,000 plant for the manufacture of steam turbines and gears for use in merchant ships of the United States Maritime Commission.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Representatives of industry and organized labor met jointly today for the first time in the history of the Office of Production Management to plan conversion of a peace-time industry to defense.

Operations of the United States Plywood Corporation in the fiscal year ended on April 30 resulted in a net profit of $781,774 after depreciation, all taxes and preferred dividends, equal to S3.2S a share on the company's outstanding common stock.

ALBANY, July 16 -- More than 300 Albany dogs, aristocrats as well as mutts, yapped, sniffed and barked on the lawn of the State Capitol today, giving a noisy send-off to the New York State "Barkers for Britain" campaign, a canine auxiliary of Bundles for Britain.

The Church Peace Union, an organization founded and endowed by Andrew Carnegie in 1914, is circulating a pamphlet entitled "Peace Aims," which expresses the belief that in the present war neutrality is impossible.

Bundles for Britain. Inc., announced yesterday that the "V for Victory" campaign, used in the occupied countries of Europe as a weapon in the war of nerves against the Nazi invaders, will be adopted here as part of the organization's relief program.

Deaths Announced Retired Engineer of Steamer Joseph F. Dowling, formerly a member of Engine Co. SO. residing at 90-16 215th St.. Queens Village, died July 14. Funeral will take place from his late residence, at 9 A. M., Thursday. July 37. Interment at St. Mary's Cemetery.

RKO's "Tom, Dick and Harry," starring Ginger Rogers, will be this morning's new film attraction at the Radio City Music Hall. George Murphy, Alan Marshal and Burgess Meredith play the respective title roles in the comedy romance, which was directed by Garson Kanin.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Walter Gordon Merritt, who are spending the season at Great Hollow, their place in Patterson, N.Y., will reside at the Carlyle on their return to New York.
Reactions among foreign traders here to the publication of this country's "blacklist" of Latin-American companies or persons deemed to be unfriendly to United States interests were mixed last night.

Hardly a change was made in the portfolio of the United States and Foreign Securities Corporation in the quarter just ended. The books reflected the five-for-one split-up of the common stock of the Detroit Edison Company and the sale of 475 participating units for the common stock of the Washington Railway and Electric Company.

Charles A. Lindbergh made public a letter to President Roosevelt yesterday disavowing any connection with any foreign government, asserting he had had no communication with any one in Germany or Italy since the Spring of 1939, before the war, and asking for an apology from Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, who repeatedly has denounced him for accepting a decoration from the Nazi Government in 1938.
LONDON, July 17 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique today:

A total of 55,999 shares of United States Steel Corporation common stock was transferred from brokers' names to investors in the second quarter of this year, increasing to 259,329 shares the common stock transferred to investors in five consecutive quarters, according to the company's quarterly report on stock ownership.
MOSCOW, July 17 (AP) -- Today's communique of the Soviet Information Bureau included the following:

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Exports of United States goods in May at $385,000,000 were almost exactly the same as in April, each of those months being about 20 per cent above the average either of the preceding twelve months or the corresponding period of 1940, the Department of Commerce reported today.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- While buying by mills and covering by shorts tended to steady the wheat market at times today, the demand was not sufficient to offset the hedge selling and prices dipped sharply, with the close on the Board of Trade here at the bottom with losses of 1 5/8 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel.

Twentieth Century-Fox will release fifty-two feature pictures during the 1941-42 season, it was announced Wednesday at the opening session of the company's four-day sales convention at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles. In addition, the company will release fifty-two one-reel pictures and 104 issues of Movietone News.

Young New York took the new draft in its stride last night. Among about 750,000 throughout the nation, 38,717 New Yorkers who became 21 years old since the original draft last October, and who registered on July 1, accepted the second great national lottery for selective service without a sign of opposition.

The Garden City Publishing Company will issue on Monday popular editions of twenty-two books. They include a Christopher Morley omnibus entitled "Four Favorite Books," "A Conquest of Tibet," by Sven Hedin; "Not Peace But a Sword," by Vincent Sheean; "Mr. Skeffington," by Elizabeth, and "Thirteen Plays," by Noel Coward.

Where Civic Virtue once reared his pretty head in City Hall Park another sort of statue is soon to rise. It will be made of aluminum, in the form of pots and pans, and will be put together by the rude hands of gents who do not rate as sculptors. Yet they will labor well, and perhaps not unlovingly.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Although the Treasury continues to deny any present intention of adopting a plan of "forced savings" such as is now in effect in Grreat Britain, it is expected that before the year is out an increase in social security taxes will be announced.
VICHY, France, July 17 -- With more and more insistence, social problems are being brought to the fore on both sides of the line of demarcation.

An amendment to the inferior courts law that went into effect last September and authorizes magistrates to dispose of some classes of misdemeanors formerly tried in Special Sessions was partly responsible for a drop of 6,124 cases disposed of in the latter court last year as compared with 1939.
PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP) -- Rain halted the game between the Cubs and Phillies today in the seventh inning with the score tied at 2 -- 2.

Though the resignation of the former Konoye Cabinet is an obvious prelude to a new shift in Japanese foreign policy, only those behind the scenes know precisely what this shift will be or even the sort of considerations that will guide it. The military clique that has ruled Japan in recent years has given no evidence of intelligent diplomacy from the standpoint of that country's larger and longer welfare.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 12 amounted to 876,165 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 135,672 cars, or 18.3 per cent more than for the preceding week, 139,382 cars, or 18.9 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 206,277 cars, or 30.8 per cent, more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

"THEY staggered and crawled back to a point on the edge of the bush opposite the boat. The tide had left it stranded. They lay there for a long time; then they heard Voices again. The voices spoke English, and English such as they had never heard before, but, indubitably, English. A moment later a colored man, a woman and several more colored men emerged from the bush and stood over them.
MOSCOW, July 17 -- A Soviet communique Tuesday morning reported the sinking in the Baltic of two German destroyers and thirteen troop transports.

By mutual consent of Teacher College and the Lincoln School Parent-Teacher Association, the scheduled merger of Horace Mann High School and Lincoln School will not take place during the 1941-42 school year, it was announced yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, July 17 -- Sixteen experts representing distant parts of the United States and Canada, were paired in two sections of eight each for tonight's opening round of the annual open championship tournament under the auspices of the St. Louis Chess League and the Missouri State Chess Association.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- If Charles A. Lindbergh was "an upstanding American" he would have returned the decoration he received from the German Government, "long ago, regardless of when, where or how, he got it," Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, declared today.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Unless the manufacture of goods for civilian consumption is soon sharply restricted, said Secretary Morgenthau today, it will be impossible for the United States to spend on defense during the present fiscal year more than half of what Congress has appropriated.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 17 (AP) -- William S. Knudsen, director-general of the Office of Production Management, urged 16,000 Consolidated Aircraft employes today to "cut two pieces of metal where you have one before."

The Army Air Corps has announced that Elmira will be used as a training center for glider pilots in connection with the national defense program. This is good news. But it suggests that once more we are making tentative use of a new weapon only after its value has been exploited in actual warfare by Nazi Germany.

Another new business building is planned in the shopping area of White Plains, Westchester, by Arthur Cutler, who has purchased a vacant plot known as 190 East Post Road from a client of Peck Heller, attorneys. The property is 61 by 260 feet, near Mamaroneck Avenue.
ITHACA, July 17 (AP) -- A Cornell University expedition started west today to measure the life-time of the mesotron, the peculiar particle of matter that lives longer the faster it travels.
BRIELLE, N.J., July 17 -- The school tuna were more plentiful and closer inshore today. And the anglers who put out of here in spite of the rain were rewarded by good catches.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks disclosed no important change in the various items reported.
The "V for Victory" movement among peoples of the occupied lands of Europe was officially recognized in Germany last night and immediately adopted as a campaign for German victory.

The Arab question, while for the moment overshadowed by the titanic Battle of Russia, has actually assumed a new significance because of Hitler's drive east. If this drive penetrates deep into Soviet territory and reaches one of its main objectives, the oil wells of the Caucasus, the German armies will be at the back door of Iraq and Iran.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 17 -- Not one of the three scheduled races in the International 14-foot dinghies between Great Lakes sailors and those of Long Island Sound could be sailed today. Lack of wind was the reason.

CLEVELAND, July 17 -- In a brilliant setting of lights and before 67,468 fans, the largest crowd ever to see a game of night baseball in the major leagues, the Yankees tonight vanquished the Indians, 4 to 3, but the famous hitting streak of Joe DiMaggio finally came to an end.

TRENTON, July 17 -- The authority of the municipal courts of Hudson County to try cases under the State's Disorderly Persons Act was upheld today by the State Supreme Court when it sustained the convictions of De Witt Lanning of Jersey City and Henry Glavocich of Hoboken on disorderly persons complaints.

In announcing an increase in the advertising appropriation of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation for the 1941-42 season, Charles E. McCarthy, director of publicity and advertising, stated yesterday that never before has the promotion of pictures been as important as it will be next season under the consent decree operation.
Because of the rain, only a handful of golfers turned out for yesterday's best-ball tourney sponsored by the Long Island Golf Association and held on the St. Albans course in Queens.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Count Carlo Sforza, the eminent Italian liberal and exile, was prompt in protesting against the Yugoslav Premier Simovich's claim on the city of Trieste after this war. It is unfortunate that Count Sforza neglected to mention, what, in case of Mussolini's defeat, should be done with the nearly two million Yugoslavs now under the Italian cudgel in Dalmatia and parts of Istria and Goriza.

There is no reason to doubt the "wisdom, sagacity and fairness" of the local, State and Federal law enforcement officers to whom Judge Learned Hand spoke at a special meeting here on Wednesday. But Judge Hand was timely in reminding them that these qualities are as important as courage just now.

An amendment to the registration statement was filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the proposed issue of $15,000,000 of Remington Rand, Inc., fifteen-year 3 1/4 per cent debentures due on July 1, 1956.

FORT DIX, N.J., July 17 -- High ranking officers here expressed surprise today at a report from Washington that Companies I and L of the 174th Infantry, a Western New York regiment, had sent telegrams to Senator Burton K. Wheeler protesting the proposed extension of the National Guard's year of service.

Three three-story buildings at 241-45 East Eighty-sixth Street, in Yorkville, occupied largely by Maxl's Restaurant, have been purchased by the Times Square Realty Corporation, Samuel Kaufman, president, from the Guaranty Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Ways and Means Committee decided today to delay until Saturday a vote whether to accept President Roosevelt's recommendation that the invested capital method of computing corporation excess profits be eliminated, and retain only the method of computing by the average period income.

Agreement by rayon weavers upon a schedule of prices acceptable to the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply was reported here yesterday and is expected to be officially announced by the OPACS within the next two or three days.

Further indications of greater restrictions on civilian production in favor of defense-materials output, growing concern and uncertainty over price-fixing policies and the inability or financial circles to gain a clear-cut picture of the Russo-German struggle brought yesterday a return to dull movements in the share list with resultant easing of prices.
BERLIN, July 17 (AP) -- The German High Command communique issued from the Fuehrer's Eastern Front Headquarters today:

Plans for an eighteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 1109-13 Fifth Avenue to cost $725,000 were filed yesterday by Emery Roth Sons, architects, for the Eleven-Eleven Fifth Avenue, Inc., of 18 East Forty-eighth Street. The site is 100.8 by 92.2 feet.

Housewives throughout the State will be asked to contribute their old aluminum ware for national defense in two house-to-house canvasses next week, Governor Lehman was informed yesterday by Dr. James E. West, chief executive of the Boy Scouts of America.

Reserving decision on whether George Scalise, former president of the Building Service Employes Union, should be sent back to Sing Sing Prison from the old Bronx jail, Justice Morris Eder yesterday ordered the office of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey to produce more evidence to substantiate its right to hold Scalise in the jail.

Commodity Margins In an effort to stem further speculative activity in commodities the Commodity Exchange Administration has suggested that all commodity exchanges registered under the Commodity Exchange Act adopt uniform margin requirements of at least 15 per cent of the value of futures transactions.

Step by Step Young men working for Adolf Hitler are made to feel that their services will not go unrewarded. A paternal eye, supplemented by a marvelous accounting system in the true German tradition of 100 per cent efficiency, watches over their every step.

LONDON, July 17-- The retirement of Geoffrey Dawson, 67 years old, from the editorship of The Times, London, after twenty-five years of service was announced today. He had reached the age limit set by The Times and would have retired last year but for the war.

Over the opposition of Borough Presidents James J. Lyons of the Bronx and John Cashmore of Brooklyn, the Board of Estimate delayed acting on the county reorganization bills yesterday and laid them over on the understanding that action would be taken before the next regular meeting on Aug. 14.

Owing to the pressure of business and other commitments, Walter Hoving announced yesterday that he was resigning as president of the United Service Organizations for National Defense, Inc., but that he would continue to serve the agency in the capacity of chairman of the board of directors.

Lists of new tenancies in several buildings still under construction were given out yesterday by several renting agents. Two such apartment structures on the borders of Central Park and a third on the East Side had their rosters enlarged.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 17 -- Arthur Williams of Springdale, 19-year-old Yale junior, today advanced to the semi-finals of the New Jersey State junior golf championship at the Rock Spring Club when he won a pair of hair-raising matches.

David S. Meister. operator, has sold to a group of investors for cash above a first mortgage of $260,000 the six-story apartment house at 43-06 Forty-fifth Street, on the southeast corner of Forty-third Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens. There are seventy-two suites of two to five rooms in the building, and the rental yield is $50,000 annually.

Reflecting chiefly substantial disbursements by the Treasury Department, excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in this city and for the system as a whole rose sharply in the week ended on Wednesday. This reversed the downward trend which had prevailed with only occasional interruption since the first of the year.

MOSCOW, July 17 (U.P.) -- Russia favors "in principle" the restoration of full independence and freedom to Poland as well as to Czecho-Slovakia and other German-occupied nations, it was stated late today by the official Soviet spokesman.

"The Beautiful People" cut loose from its commercial idealism yesterday and rejoined the Broadway legitimate theatre. After another of those telegraphic conferences with William Saroyan, who is on the Coast, his local managers announced that the satisfaction-or-money-back policy no longer would prevail at the Lyceum.
The number one registrant of Draft Board No. 1, which is on the lower East Side, was Wong Yee Choy, a Chinese baker, who came to this country from England last January and was 21 years old on May 6.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- As part of the government drive to conserve gasoline and keep down prices, Leon Henderson, administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, today asked all petroleum refiners in the Gulf Coast area to maintain a base price of 6 cents per gallon for Gulf Coast gasoline.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 17 -- Enoch L. (Nucky) Johnson was named and pointed out today in United States District Court as the man who received $825 a week in 1935 to make things "all right" for the numbers racket in Atlantic City.

FORT DIX, N.J., July 17 -- Twenty-two hundred trucks of the Forty-fourth Division, en route to Virginia, passed through Philadelphia tonight over two routes at the same time police were busy handling a parade of 10,000 Elks.

Probing German armored divisions thrust through the Stalin defensive system deep into Russia yesterday as the climax of the world's greatest battle was closely paralleled by a new crisis in the Far East.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Stories of acute labor shortages in some localities, of more widespread shortages expected, and of "sky-rocketing" rents in areas adjacent to large rearmament industries, were told to the Tolan Committee investigating the migratory labor situation today by Donald M. Nelson, Director of the Division of Purchases of the Office of Production Management, and Leon Henderson, Price Control Administrator.

NEWARK, N.J., July 17 -- The two young men of Newark affected by the drawing of S 196, making them honorary members of the "First Man Club," will seek deferment from the draft on the basis of having dependents. Gilbert Dixon of 70 Nineteenth Avenue, who became 21 on May 18, will have a second cause for deferment in that he is employed as a draftsman by an aviation concern.
Following are the numbers drawn from the goldfish bowl in Washington last night in the second national selective service lottery, listed by the numerical sequence of serial numbers.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 17 -- Tonight's Thursday buffet dinner, followed by backgammon and bingo at the Maidstone Club, was the occasion for several large parties. Mrs. Clifford H. McCall, Mrs. Walter B. Duryea, Mrs. Samuel M. Greer and Mrs. Benjamin Chapman Jr. entertained guests.

BERLIN, July 17 (U.P.) -- Thirty-three persons were killed and fifty-four injured when British planes dropped bombs in the Netherlands during a series of day and night attacks yesterday on the Netherland and Channel coasts and Northwest Germany, Nazi reports said today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, July 18 -- Although there was fierce fighting all along the Eastern Front throughout yesterday, the chief German activity seemed to have been concentrated in the Vitebsk-Smolensk area and in the north on the approaches to Leningrad.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 17 -- Richard Trimble, a stockbroker employed by Shearson Hammill Co., 14 Wall Street, New York, was found dead on the floor of the bathroom of his home here at 4 o'clock this afternoon. Although death was believed due to natural causes, an autopsy will be performed tomorrow in Meadowbrook Hospital.

Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O., has sent a letter to Mayor La Guardia accusing the city administration of "an extreme anti-C.I.O. attitude" and urging that exclusive collective bargaining rights be extended to the majority union in each civil service department, it was learned yesterday.

DUBLIN, July 17 -- In a debate in the Dail Eireann tonight on the war situation and the relations between Eire and the United States, James Dillon, deputy leader of the Fine Gael party, urged Ireland to provide bases for the United States and Britain if they wanted them to fight German aggression.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The story of a garden in Topics of The Times falls short of giving full value to the habits of the woodchuck. The woodchuck can dig under a fence but it can also climb over. In fact, the groundhog belies its name by climbing trees.

Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated nervously yesterday. Opening prices were 6 points lower to 4 points higher and during the day gains of 10 points and losses of 17 points were seen. The market steadied in the late trading and final quotations were 3 points lower to 6 points higher.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Price increases in recent weeks were fairly normal and need not be considered alarming, but the movement should be held on a line between 10 and 15 per cent above the low point of 1939, according to a report issued today by the Retailers' Advisory Committee.

PITTSBURGH, July 17 (AP) -- Federal Judge F.P. Schoonmaker refused today to grant an injunction restraining stockholders of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation from meeting on Tuesday next to vote on a plan for revision of the capital structure and merger of two subsidiaries into the parent organization.

BERLIN, July 17 -- Prices on the Boerse broke sharply along the entire front at the opening this morning, with the average losses in excess of 2 per cent. The selling continued to the close, when a slight recovery set in, but most listings lost 3 per cent or more for the day.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The House passed with little debate and no record vote today a bill authorizing the Navy to undertake expansion of ship building, repair and ordnance manufacturing facilities at government and private yards.

Apparently satisfied with the comedy's tryout last month at the Ridgeway Theatre, White Plains, N.Y., the new producing firm of Dorothy and Julian Olney and Felix Jacoves now announce the date and place for the Broadway production of "Village Green."

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Department store sales, according to the Federal Reserve Board, are continuing to show sizeable improvement over last year. During the week ended July 12 they rose 19 per cent over the corresponding period of 1940 while in the previous week there was an increase of 28 per cent.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 17 (AP) -- Ken Burkhart pitched three-hit ball to blank Newark tonight and end a seven-game winning streak for the league leaders as Syracuse gained a 4-to-0 triumph in the series opener.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- General Marshall presented to the Senate Military Affairs Committee today this table showing the distribution of selectees among the Regular Army and National Guard divisions and the dates when, under the present law, they would have to be returned to civil life:

RUMSON, N.J., July 17 -- With high-caliber campaigners entered in all divisions, the annual three-day Monmouth County horse show opened today at Thornton Farm. Soldiers from near-by forts, Hamcock and Monmouth, supplied a military aspect by staging diversified exhibitions.

The news that will greet shoppers when they go into their butcher stores this week-end will not be cheerful. That pork and veal show a marked advance in price, and that beef and lamb are also somewhat more expensive, is the discouraging word we receive from the Consumer's Service Bureau of the Department of Markets.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 17 -- Lupe Velez was assigned by RKO today to the leading feminine role in "The Marines Are Ready," which will start Aug. 1 with Victor McLaglen and Edmund Lowe as two tough leathernecks. Anne Shirley had been announced for the part but the studio was desirous of following the pattern of "What Price Glory," in which McLaglen and Lowe played Captain Flagg and Sergeant Quirk, and Miss Velez was substituted.

Life insurance in force reported by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States rose to a new high of $7,327,364,314 on June 30, Thomas I. Parkinson, president, announced yesterday following the semi-annual meeting of directors.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- The Woolford Farm's Technician was a handy winner of the Hindoo Purse before 10,000 at Arlington Park today. The 7-5 favorite, the Milky Way Farm's Gallahadion, nosed out Mrs. L.B. Muschal's Cherry Trifle for second.
OTTAWA, July 17 (Canadian Press) -- Dominion Government deposits increased $17,141,000 to $39,487,000 in the week ended yesterday, the Bank of Canada disclosed today.

DETROIT, July 17 (AP) -- Ignoring a 30-day "cooling off" period imposed a week ago by the State Labor Mediation Board, members of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee (C.I.O.) went on strike at the Great Lakes Engineering Works in River Rouge today.

IT'S the official duty of Mr. William Brandt, who runs the National League Service Bureau, to speak well and write often about all the ball clubs of the Ford Frick loop. Mr. Brandt is an honorable and industrious gent. He speaks and writes fluently of all teams and players in the National League, always in the favorable vein of an earnest propagandist.

HAWORTH, N.J., July 17 -- In a pro-amateur best-ball golf competition preliminary to the New Jersey P.G.A. championship, which gets under way tomorrow, two teams tied for first place today with scores of 65. The competition was held on the White Beeches Golf and Country Club course.

DETROIT, July 17 (AP) -- Young Bid Hudson, hit hard by the National League All-Stars in his last appearance at Briggs Stadium, had little more success today as the Tigers belted fourteen hits to defeat the Senators, 7 to 1.

The controversy over whether wool goods mills should provide continuing guarantees of fiber content was reduced yesterday to an exchange of statements by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers and the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board, in which neither yielded from its earlier position.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 17 -- Mrs. Patrick A. Valentine gave a dinner tonight at Valmay Cottage, her place in First Neck Lane, for her niece, Mrs. Livingston Platt of Rye, N.Y., and Mrs. Platt's daughter, Miss Priscilla Platt, who have joined Mrs. Valentine for a visit.

RUMSON, N.J., July 17 -- Rufus C. Finch, president of the Monmouth County Horse Show, which opened today at Thornton Farm and will continue through Saturday, and Mrs. Finch were dinner hosts tonight at their home to their house guests and the judges of the show.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The White House statement in explanation of President Roosevelt's proclamation blacklisting 1,800 firms and persons in Latin America deemed to have been acting for the benefit of Germany or Italy was as follows:

Bank clearings for the principal cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday were $6,530,921,000, exceeding the $5,454,598,000 volume for the corresponding week last year by 19.7 per cent, according to the report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
HAVANA, July 17 -- Ministers of the new Cabinet appointed by President Fulgencio Batista early this morning were sworn in at the Presidential Palace late this afternoon.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Dominic DiMaggio, driving in three runs with a homer and triple, led the Red Sox to a 7-to-4 victory over the White Sox tonight before 27,437 spectators. Thornton Lee, big Chicago southpaw, failed to go nine innings for the first time in seventeen starts this season.

TOKYO, Friday, July 18 -- On the recommendation of a meeting of elder statesmen, attended by all former Premiers except Prince Fuminaro Konoye and Baron Kiichiro Hiranuma, Emperor Hirohito today again commanded Prince Konoye to form a new Cabinet to replace the second Konoye Cabinet, which resigned Wednesday night.

VICHY, France, July 17 -- The task of feeding France is now in one man's hands. Jean Achard, Secretary for Supplies, has resigned and his department has been transferred to the Ministry of Agriculture, where Pierre Caziot, who has held that portfolio for a year, henceforth will be in a position to control all supplies from producer to consumer.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Led by sharply higher prices for farm products, particularly grains, livestock and cotton, and for lumber and furniture, the general level of wholesale prices resumed its advance in the week ended on July 12, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 17 -- Dr. Alexander Loudon, Netherlands Minister to the United States, was the guest of honor at a dinner given tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. McPherson, with whom he is staying at Court Hill, Pittsfield.

SPOKANE, July 17 (AP) -- Defeat of the tournament, medalist and red-hot favorite, Jimmy Clark, provided a climax today to third-round and quarter-final matches of the national public links championship.

Cornell players dominate the allleague team for the second year in a row, even though they were dethroned as the Eastern intercollegiate baseball champions during the 1941 season, according to the selections announced yesterday by A.sa S. Bushnell, secretary-treasurer of the circuit.

A. C. Blumenthal's six Mexican doctors, who found six different sets of ailments in the diminutive real estate and theatrical man, have failed to convince Federal Judge John Bright that Blumenthal was too ill to obey a court order to return here from Mexico City last Spring.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), July 17 -- The Bourse opened heavy today on profit-taking but rallied later. Among the losses in the domestic industrials were A.K.U. 1 3/4 down at 148 3/4, Philips 4 at 229 1/2 and Unilever 4 1/4 at 129 1/4.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Here is the administrative order which was issued in connection with publication of the "blacklist of Latin-American individuals and firms:

In a transaction recorded yesterday a fine residential property in Jersey City, N.J., was sold for less than one-eighth of the assessed valuation, according to the revenue stamps affixed to the deed of transfer.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 17 -- An Australian patrol penetrated 6,000 yards into German positions around Tobruk, Libya, on Tuesday and battered Axis forces severely before withdrawing, the British announced today.

Jerome Kern has received and accepted an invitation from Artur Rodzinski, conductor of the Cleveland Symphony Orchestra, to compose a symphonic version of the Kern musical play. "Show Boat," for first performance under Rodzinski's baton at the symphony concerts in the " Autumn.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.

Refrigerator Sales Curbed Because of the power shortage in the Southeast, sales of major appliances, such as refrigerators, in some districts have been restricted to replacements only, in order to prevent any increase in the power load, reports here yesterday indicated.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The text of the President's trade blacklist proclamation was as follows:

Because of a substantial drop in enrollment and a shift in New York City population, the Board of Education has authorized the demolition of three old school buildings and has assigned two others for non-educational purposes, it was announced yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 17 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

Trading in fresh pork cuts was only fair yesterday and other classes fair to good. Fresh pork prices were mostly unchanged. Other classes were strong to higher. Supplies were generally below normal. All kosher markets opened strong to higher.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Louis J. Taber, master of the National Grange, advocated the St. Lawrence seaway-power program today as needed for the national welfare. Governor Phillips of Oklahoma, however, labeled it "a boondoggling experiment."
MOSCOW, Friday, July 18 (AP) -- Today's communique of the Soviet Information Bureau, included the following:

The Germans are fighting for every mile of ground they take in Russia. Even in the Ukraine, where disaffection was supposed to be ready to explode at the first opportunity, the invaders have met fierce resistance. It is in this uncertain region, indeed, that the policy of the "scorched earth" seems to be pursued in the most vigorous fashion.

BELFAST, North Ireland, July 17 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister J.M. Andrews today urged American participation in the war "the sooner the better" and promised that the United States might do anything it desired in Northern Ireland.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 -- Dr. William Yandell Elliott, industrial consultant in the Office of Production Management, told the national convention of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks today that the government, and not the Aluminum Company of America, was responsible for a shortage of aluminum.

Two millinery houses presented hats for Fall yesterday. Mme. Pauline showed "dressmaker" fashions that accented femininity and rich color, while Gladys and Belle, in a new shop at 20 West Fifty-seventh Street, favored "easy-to-wear" models.

Former Representative Bruce Barton, who was the Republican candidate for United States Senator last Fall, conferred yesterday on the Mayoralty situation with Thomas J. Curran, New York County leader, at Mr. Curran's request.

Wendell L. Willkie appealed last night to labor and management to suspend their grievances for the duration of the national emergency and to join the common task of "outproducing the forces of totalitarian dictatorships."

PRINCETON, N.J., July 17 -- The Roosevelt Administration's action in taking over the defense of Iceland is approved by a substantial majority of American voters in the first returns of a nationwide poll conducted by the American Institute of Public Opinion.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- President Roosevelt issued a proclamation today making official a list of 1,800 Latin-American firms and individuals believed to be acting in the interest of Germany or Italy. The list, containing the names of many internationally known firms, was made public.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- New York dairymen received today assurances of prompt government consideration of their plea for aid in meeting an acute drought situation in the milkshed.

Fourteen thousand A.F. of L. butchers in the metropolitan area were ordered yesterday to stop handling Armour Co. meat products as a means of enforcing their union's strike against the New York Butchers Dressed Meat Company, an Armour subsidiary.

LONDON, Friday, July 18 -- Hammering away steadily with ever-increasing boldness, the Royal Air Force through Wednesday and yesterday bombed and wrecked eighteen Nazi ships totaling more than 100,000 tons and damaged five others totaling 40,000 to 45,000 tons, according to the Air Ministry.

SHANGHAI, July 17 (U.P.) -- Japan is mobilizing possibly 1,000,000 additional men, presumably for an attack upon Siberia and the Soviet Maritime Provinces, advices from Japan reported today. Tokyo plans "to move 1,000,000 men to the north," the advices said.

BENDIX, N.J., July 17 -- At least six persons were injured as C.I.O. pickets and the police clashed here today following an at tempt to prevent 350 workers o the day shift from entering the plant of Air Associates, Inc., makers of aviation accesories and engaged on national defense order.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A trainee inducted into the Army under the first lottery which, started selective service in October drew from the "goldfish bowl" tonight the first number in the second lottery held to determine the order in which 750,000 21-year-old men will be subject to conscription.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- President Roosevelt issued a proclamation making official a blacklist of 1,800 Latin American firms believed to have connections with Axis powers and extended his order of June 14 freezing the assets in this country of all European countries and their nationals to cover those named on the blacklist.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 17 -- Miss Mary Truxtun Homans of Englewood, N.J., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheppard Homans of New York and Newport, was married here at noon today to Trevor Charles Howell, son of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Howell of Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The concern felt here over the implications of future Japanese policy arising out of the Cabinet crisis in Tokyo was manifested today in a conference that President Roosevelt held with Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, to discuss the situation and study latest reports from Joseph C. Grew, the United States Ambassador to Tokyo.

A court battle over the so-called retroactive feature of the cotton-goods ceiling order was threatened yesterday when reports from Washington indicated that conferences between the Cotton Textile Advisory Committee and the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply were making no progress toward elimination of that provision.
ST. LOUIS, July 17 (AP) -- Harlond Clift's single with the bases full and one out in the ninth inning gave the Brown; a 4-to-3 victory over the Athletics tonight.

The directors of the Lehigh Valley Coal Company voted yesterday to redeem on Aug. 20 its $1,269,000 of five-year secured 6 per cent notes, Class A, extended to Jan. 1, 1943, and on the same date to pay the deferred portion of the interest due on Feb. 1 and Aug. 1, 1939, on its first and refunding mortgage 5 per cent bonds of 1924.

After she had floated for sixteen hours, drifting twenty-five miles from the Jersey coast into lower New York Bay in an old inner tube, Miss Eleanore Maldonado of 18 Tompkins Avenue, Brooklyn, was rescued early yesterday by the crew of the commuting steamer Sandy Hook.

Clarence (Red) Burman and Melio Bettina will complete heavy training this week-end for the feature ten-rounder of Chick Meehan's heavyweight boxing show at Ebbets Field on Tuesday. They will work out today, tomorrow and Sunday and taper off Monday.

BERLIN, July 17 -- The mightiest and not the least bloody battle in the world's history was reported by the Supreme German Command today. Nine million men oppose each other along the entire Eastern Front, the Germans assert.

LOS ANGELES, July 17 (AP) -- The 1,000th Lockheed bomber for Britain took off for England today with 30,000 aircraft workers cheering it on and Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, and his wife bidding it godspeed.

LONDON, July 17 -- Another British Cabinet shake-up, this time apparently involving the departure of Alfred Duff Cooper as Minister of Information, is being rumored around London. Nothing is yet confirmed, but there seems reason to believe that the present Minister will leave for some other government job and may be replaced by Brendan Bracken, Prime Minister Winston Churchill's Parliamentary private secretary and one of the most important members of the Prime Minister's personal staff.
BOSTON, July 17 (AP) -- Daniel J. Donovan's Graustark captured the Sharon Purse, $1,200 feature of a mile for $2,500 platers that topped the card at Suffolk Downs today.

BERLIN, July 17 (AP) -- United States consular officials and employes now rounded up for ejection from Germany and Europe will not be set free until German consular officials on the United States Navy transport West Point are set down on European soil, an authorized spokesman declared tonight.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : In a letter from Guy Irving Burch of Washington appearing in THE TIMES of July 16 statements recently released by the Regional Plan Association on its studies of population trends are interpreted to imply that a cessation of population growth is to be deplored as likely to bring stagnation and blight.

LONDON, July 12 (AP) -- The Bank of England's statement for the week ended on July 16 showed an increase of u2,890,000 in note circulation, raising the total outstanding to a new high record of u650,920,000. The undiminishing currency demand necessary to Britain's war effort rapidly is lifting note circulation to the current fiduciary issue ceiling of u680,000,000.

ROME, July 17 -- The United States Embassy was informed today that, following the German request to the Italian Foreign Office to "coordinate" the exchange of consular groups between the Axis and the United States, the Italian Government would release seventy-five Americans forming the consular group now in San Remo only when the United States Navy transport West Point reached Lisbon.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 17 -- Guests for the wedding of Miss Joan Widener Leidy and George Eustis Paine Jr. on Saturday began to arrive in earnest today, and entertaining in honor of the couple got under way. Miss Vivian Stokes, daughter of Mrs. Henry Drummond-Wolff, who will be one of the bridesmaids, entertained with a cocktail party at Oak Haven, home of her mother, in honor of Miss Leidy.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 17 -- Duesseldorf is little more than a charred ruin; the ports of Hamburg and Bremen have been blasted until the harbor installations are useless, and Hanover has been subjected to the heaviest bombing of military objectives since the European war began, according to information received here today from diplomats who have just arrived from Germany.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- In a compromise move precipitated by predictions that wholesale seizure of property by the government would bring about "a revolution in this country," the Administration accepted and the Senate Military Affairs Committee approved unanimously today a modified "draft property" bill which restricts the type of defense property to be requisitioned and puts a time limit on the President's powers.

MADRID, Spain, July 17 -- Denouncing the United States for, so he said, "refusing aid to Spain in her hour of need," Generalissimo Francisco Franco warned America today to keep out of the European war.

One out of every six shoppers at the department stores of Manhattan arrive by automobile, according to an estimate disclosed yesterday and based on more than 8,000 interviews obtained in eleven stores in the course of the general study being made by the Regional Plan Association of traffic and parking facilities in the central congested areas of the city.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the Army, called upon Congress today to proclaim by its own vote a state of national emergency and thus bring into force the authority for President Roosevelt to extend the military service of selectees, National Guardsmen and Reserve officers beyond the statutory period of one year.

Although subpoenaed by tha Rapp-Coudert committee investigating subversive activities, the American Student Union, a leftwing organization with an asserted membership of 20,000, announced yesterday that it would refuse to give up its records and membership lists.

MADRID, Spain, July 17 -- Denouncing the United States for, so he said, "refusing aid to Spain in her hour of need," Generalissimo Francisco Franco warned America today to keep out of the European war.

One out of every six shoppers at the department stores of Manhattan arrive by automobile, according to an estimate disclosed yesterday and based on more than 8,000 interviews obtained in eleven stores in the course of the general study being made by the Regional Plan Association of traffic and parking facilities in the central congested areas of the city.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the Army, called upon Congress today to proclaim by its own vote a state of national emergency and thus bring into force the authority for President Roosevelt to extend the military service of selectees, National Guardsmen and Reserve officers beyond the statutory period of one year.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 16:

What appeared to be an easy double-play ball in the first inning became the rock on which the Giants perished last night in their nocturnal strife with the champion Reds before a gathering of 20,289 at the Polo Grounds.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: New regulations for the issuance of visas for aliens went into effect on July 1. The essence of them is that henceforth applicants are required to submit their cases to the Department of State in Washington for preliminary examination before they are given final consideration by the consuls in foreign countries.
The revised list of next week's rural tryouts -- thirteen of them, by the way -- appears as follows:

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 18 -- Arthur Williams of the Springdale Country Club and Yale University won the New Jersey State junior golf championship today by defeating Fred Calder of Montclair, 2 and 1, at the Rock Spring Country Club.

In his letter to the shareholders of the Tri-Continental Corporation and associated investment companies, Francis F. Randolph, chairman of the boards, said that in and after the first World War "a condition of expanding demand coincidental with curtailment of supplies resulted in an inflationary rise in prices of goods and services."
The campaign for the re-election of Mayor La Guardia will begin Monday, it was disclosed yesterday, with activity first on the part of his supporters and then on the part of the Mayor himself.
HARRISBURG, Pa., July 18 -- The longest session of the Legislature in ninety-nine "years ended early this morning without passage of a Congressional reapportionment law.

Asserting that the proposed St. Lawrence Waterway would attract bulk cargo and thus disrupt commerce on the Atlantic seaboard that depends on such cargo for ship ballast, the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce filed a statement yesterday with the House Committee on Rivers and Harbors, opposing the waterway and power project.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered toy dealers:

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- President Roosevelt stated emphatically today that the United States would keep the sea lanes open between this continent and Iceland, as well as to other points, such as Bermuda and Newfoundland, where garrisons were maintained.

A net profit of $415,854 for the fiscal year ended on May 31 was reported yesterday by Lane Bryant, Inc., Fifth Avenue specialty shop. Charges against the net included depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and a $50,000 provision for excess profits taxes.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 18 -- Mr. and Mrs. Newell W. Tilton gave a dinner tonight at The Galley, the new restaurant in Main Street. The guests were seated at small tables decorated with garden flowers. Rose and amber lights illuminated the patio where aperitifs were served before dinner, and an accordionist entertained.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- Bob (Lefty) Grove, 41-year-old Red Sox southpaw, was thwarted again, today in his quest for his 300th American League mound victory. The White Sox beat Grove and his team-mates, 4 to 3, in ten innings.

Smolensk administrative center of the Province of Smolensk, is one of the oldest towns in Russia and was a place of great importance during the Middle Ages. Situated on the Dnieper River at a point where the plateau is deeply entrenched, the town is approximately 230 miles west-southwest of Moscow.

Four men and three women of an alleged world-wide Nazi spy ring yesterday pleaded guilty to violating the espionage laws of the country when arraigned before Judge Clarence G. Galston in Brooklyn. When the indictment was handed up Tuesday charging thirty-three persons with failing to register as agents of a foreign country and conspiring to transmit information about national defense to a foreign country, the "Government the German Reich" was specifically mentioned as a co-conspirator.

The Cardinal Hayes Memorial High School, nearing completion at Grand Concourse and 153d Street, the Bronx, will be opened and dedicated on Sept. 8, by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, it was announced yesterday at the Chancery Office.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Association of American Railroads, comprising 236 systems and its officers and directors, has consented to a Federal court decree under which practices violating the antitrust laws will be abandoned, the Department of Justice announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Japan's new Cabinet, formed today under the premiership of Prince Fumimaro Konoye, is so little changed in essential make-up and political coloring from, the preceding Konoye Cabinet that the ostensible shift in government is believed here to have been made only to clear Japan from responsibilities toward Russia and toward Germany and Italy.

FORT HANCOCK, N.J., July 18 -- West Point cadets, divided into two units, will spend the next two weeks at Fort Hancock to undergo a rigorous routine of training in the many phases of coast artillery. The cadets will take their places in gun crews and fire the variety of armament at Fort Hancock, from 30-caliber machine guns to the large 12-inch coast rifles.
MOSCOW, July 18 (AP) -- Today's, communique contained the following:

LONDON, July 18 (U.P) -- Adolf Hitler was reported today to have appealed urgently to Japan to attack Russia immediately, but some British quarters contended that the Japanese, instead of lining: up with Germany, were veering away from Nazi influence.

New York City will continue its progressive education experiment in seventy elementary schools this Fall, pending the results of a survey conducted by the State Department of Education, Dr. John J. Loftus, assistant superintendent in charge of the program, disclosed yesterday.

Eighteen men and eleven women, a few of them Negroes, who were picketing in front of the home of Mayor La Guardia, 1274 Fifth Avenue, at 109th Street, protesting against curtailment of the WPA, were arrested yesterday afternoon when they caused crowds of several hundred persons to gather in front of the apartment house.
JOHN KIERAN leaves nature no privacy whatever. He goes beagling about among the rocks and rills, the woods, reference books and templed hills, turning up amazing conglomerates of lore.
BERLIN, July 18 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique from the Fuehrer's Headquarters today:

ATLANTA, Ga., July 18 -- Dr. Harmon W. Caldwell, president of the University of Georgia, said today that the General Education Board had cut off financial relations with the University of Georgia system as the result of Governor Talmadge's seizing personal control of the university and its branches.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 (U.P.) -- Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States said today that while he saw no reason why there should be a clash between Japan and the western democracies, no one should think that Britain, preoccupied with war in Europe, will allow her rights in other parts of the world to be set aside.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- With a blazing five-under-par 66 that left such recent title winners as Craig Wood and Vie Ghezzi far in his wake, Ben Hogan, slender Hershey, Pa., golf professional, captured first-round honors in the $5,000 Chicago open championship at the Elmhurst Country Club today with a brilliance which made him an odds-on favorite to finish in the money in his fifty-first straight tournament.

Through the Federal Power Commission the Government has announced an electric power expansion program involving the expenditure of perhaps $470,000,000 annually for the uration of the defense emergency. This is to be paid for in part out of Federal funds supplied by the RFC, though it is expected that the steam plants in the main will be financed by private interests, while the Government will supply the funds directly for the hydroelectric expansion.

LONDON, July 18 (AP) -- Germany's armies and air force are threatened with a severe oil and fuel shortage if the Russian campaign continues through September, a Ministry of Economic Warfare source declared today.

BERLIN, Saturday, July 19 (U.P) -- German armored forces are "pushing rapidly eastward" toward Moscow over a newly completed modern highway after capturing the communications center of Smolensk, with heavy losses to the enemy, military reports from, the front said today.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 17:

Rapid progress in the construction of the section of the East River Drive from Thirtieth to Forty-ninth Streets, the next part of the drive to be completed, was disclosed yesterday during a tour of inspection of the area led by Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan.

James Speyer, retired banker and philanthropist and honorary president of University Settlement Society, who will be 80 years old Tuesday, will share his birthday cake and ice cream today with 250 city children at the settlement's vacation camp at Beacon, N.Y.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: In a recent column, John Kieran asks for additional light on my charge that boxing today is controlled by a monopoly.

Schick, Inc., formerly Schick Dry Shaver, Inc., will run the biggest advertising campaign in its history this Fall, Kenneth C. Gifford, vice president in charge of sales and advertising, announced yesterday. Mr. Gifford reported that sales for the first six months were 48 per cent ahead of 1940.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on July 5 was 1,746,750 shares, compared with 2,870,460 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Trading by members for their own accounts was 14.99 per cent of the total, compared with 17.62 per cent the week before.

NUTLEY, N.J., July 18 -- A keen putting touch that resulted in eleven one-putt greens enabled Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches to carry off the low-gross honors with 42, 40 -- 82 in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association on the Yountakah Country Club course today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 18 -- Universal has closed a deal with Elisabeth Bergner for the release of her first American picture, "Paris Calling," written by John Szekeley and Benjamin Glazer, the studio announced today. The photoplay, which deals with life in German-occupied France, will go before the cameras July 29 at Universal, and Edwin L. Marin, who left Metro this week after seven years with the company, has been engaged to direct.

CLEVELAND, July 18 -- His spectacular hitting streak finally ended in last night's thriller after he had set a, major league record of fifty-six games, Joe DiMaggio greeted a new day with a smile, a carefree shrug of his shoulders and soon started what may develop into another string.

Replacement of uniformed policemen by detectives as payroll guards was under consideration yesterday after robbers using a new technique obtained $1,487 from the office of Jacob Youngerman, manufacturer of coat fronts, at 18 East Sixteenth Street.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by fifty-two municipalities and local housing authorities aggregates $155,068,851, compared with $45,359,155 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $34,435,725.

In the first test of the Devaney law barring subversive persons from the public payroll in this State, Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller dismissed last Saturday an employe of her department for alleged membership in the Communist party, it was disclosed yesterday.

There was still little evidence last week of the slackening in business activity that usually sets in at this time, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Wholesale trade was brisk and climbed steadily. Sellers frequently reported that they could have booked more orders if the merchandise had been available.

The stock market righted itself yesterday, and the resumption of the advance, though mild, came in even a smaller volume than on Thursday. The session was one oi those rare Fridays when week-end profit-taking is noticeably absent in volume, and apparently a better demand was encouraged to enter the share list in the final hour.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The blacklist against 1,800 Latin-American firms and individuals believed to be acting in the interest of Germany and Italy will be extended in a few weeks or months to entities of the same character in countries outside the Western Hemisphere, except in the British Commonwealth of Nations, under a procedure announced today by Dean Acheson, Assistant Secretary of State.

This week-end should see the broadbill swordfish "hopefuls" cruising between Montauk and Block Island, for according to reports received yesterday that stretch of water now has one of the largest concentrations of these fish in some years.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- President Roosevelt revealed today that he intended to send a special message to Congress next week supporting the Army's urgent appeal for legislation to retain selectees, National Guardsmen and reserve officers in military service for the duration of the emergency.

The greater experience of Bob Falkenburg, Hollywood, who holds the boys' national crown, carried him to victory at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday in the final of the boys' Eastern tennis championships. The Californian took the measure of Henry Osten of Garden City, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 2, thus retaining the laurels he had won a year ago.

NEWARK, N.J., July 18 -- In bringing criminal proceedings against three former WPA workers, Federal authorities in New Jersey have invoked for the first time a law adopted by Congress in 1940, which prohibits distribution of WPA funds to Communists, Bundists and members of other subversive organizations, it was learned here today.

HAWORTH, N.J., July 18 -- By virtue of a 67 on his second round, Tommy Harmon, the Montclair Golf Club instructor, assumed the lead at the end of the initial thirty-six holes in the New Jersey P.G.A. championship on the White Beeches Golf and Country Club course today.

Trading In locally dressed meats yesterday was fair to good. Steer beef was higher and other classes of traefer meats generally steady to strong. Kosher steer beef opened sharply higher, and other kosher meats strong to higher.

In his greatest victory since he came to this country from Prague in 1939, Ladislav Hecht, formerly of the Czechoslovakian Davis Cup team, defeated Donald McNeill of Oklahoma City, the national champion, yesterday in the quarter-final round of the New York State tournament at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.

AUBURN, July 18 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared today that democracy was not only "worth dying for" but also "worth living for." She was here for the dedication and official opening of the National Youth Administration's resident centers, one for boys and another for girls, two of the most important in the NYA setup.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 18 -- Two former numbers bankers of Atlantic City, testifying in United States District Court today at the trial of Enoch L. (Nucky) Johnson, named different men as the recipients of $1,200 a week in protection money paid by a syndicate of racketeers.
Cotton-mill activity was higher last week but the daily average declined contraseasonally and the adjusted index dropped to 174.1 from 193.7 (revised). It was 116.5 for the week ended July 13, 1940.

Though Congressional leaders admit that there has been much opposition to the proposal to require joint returns of married persons "living together," it' is by no means certain that this provision will be removed from the final bill. The more the proposal is examined, however, the more unjust and anti-social its effects are seen to be.
FORT DIX, N.J., July 18 -- All furloughs were ordered canceled today for the personnel of the new anti-tank battalion at Fort Dix by its commanding officer, Lieut. Col. John Lemp of Trenton.

MOSCOW, Saturday, July 19 (U.P.) -- Bloody fighting with huge losses on both sides raged all day yesterday as the Russians struggled to blunt German spearheads near Smolensk, the gateway to Moscow, and in the sector protecting Leningrad, the Soviet Information Bureau reported today.

F.D.R.'s Place Secure In the shakedown of time President Roosevelt Place may take rank, as his admirers expect, with Washington, Jefferson, Jackson and Lincoln, or he may be listed, as the opposition hopes, with the numerous forgotten men who have come and gone in the Presidential office.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A request to be heard at the coming investigation of newspaper ownership of radio broadcasting stations was filed with the Federal Communications Commission today by the Newspaper Radio Committee, through Harold Hough, 371 Lexington Avenue, New York City.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., July 18 -- Two trainloads of fledgling soldiers, fourteen, hours out of Camp Upton, debarking in the Field Artillery Replacement Center this morning, looked with no little awe upon the tallest colonel in the Army.

The State School Employees Retirement Board of Pennsylvania will offer for sale on next Tuesday $24,159,000 of Pennsylvania municipal bonds. The various issues, with various interest rates and various maturities, are to be sold in competitive bidding.
The German invasion of Russia, four weeks old tomorrow, has given new significance to our own military preparations.

LONDON, July 18 -- The Czechoslovak Government today signed an agreement in London with Soviet Russia whereby diplomatic relations between the two governments would be resumed and a Czech legion created in Russia to serve under the Soviet High Command.

Representatives of automobile dealers from the twelve States of the Northeastern region were told yesterday by L.C. Cargile, president of the National Automobile Dealers Association, that they face the most serious crisis their business has ever known.

IT'S no trick to get Secretary Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick of the Giants started on Brooklyn. In fact, he is equipped with an automatic self-starter that, at regular hours, sends him off in that direction at full tilt It's the old Giant-Dodger feud, with modern embroidery due to diligent needlework on both sides of the Brooklyn Bridge.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- As a result of conferences with representatives of the cotton textile and rayon industries, Leon Henderson, administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, today announced a "comprehensive program" for price stabilization in the industry involving upward adjustment in present ceiling prices on cotton gray goods.

After a delay of twenty-four hours because of bad weather, the American Clipper left here yesterday morning at 10:43 o'clock for Lisbon with fifteen transatlantic passengers. Less than two hours later the Yankee Clipper, carrying twenty-seven transatlantic passengers, landed at the marine terminal of La Guardia Field after a flight from Lisbon.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Economists of the Office of Production Management estimate that by April the United States will be out-producing Germany in airplanes and tanks, Senator Downey of California told the Senate Military Affairs Committee in secret session this week.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, July 19 -- Overwhelmed by the weight of German reserves thrown in to assure the taking of Smolensk, Russian forces along the northern side of the Vitebsk-Smolensk-Orsha triangle were carrying out an orderly withdrawal yesterday in a general northeasterly direction, fighting fierce rear-guard actions all the way.

St. LOUIS, July 18 -- Reuben Fine, open champion of the United States Chess Federation, took the lead in the annual tournament here today when he defeated Joseph Rauch of Montreal in the second round after fifty-two moves. It was the second success for the young internationalist, who had the white pieces and had to deal with a Sicilian defense.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: A note of commendation is in order for the management of the Roosevelt Raceway harness races. A friend and I were present last Saturday night, when the meeting ended. There was a fine crowd and prospects for an entertaining, if not profitable, evening were bright.

The body of Dr. Willis N. Huggins, prominent Negro educator and the only man of his race to hold the degree of Doctor of Philosophy from Fordham University, who was reported missing last Dec. 24, was identified by a relative at the city morgue yesterday following its discovery in the Hudson River at Seventy-second Street last Tuesday.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: There seems to be a lot of criticism in Brooklyn of those persons who have suggested that, if the Yankees and the Dodgers are opponents in this year's world series, all the games should be played at the Yankee Stadium.
LONDON, Saturday, July 19 -- The Royal Air Force offensive over Germany, German-occupied territory and German-controlled waters continued with unabated vigor over Thursday night and yesterday.

The contest for the Democratic nomination for the seat in the Fourteenth Congressional District left vacant by the death of Representative M. Michael Edelstein ended yesterday with the signing of a stipulation, to be presented today to Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter, withdrawing the claim of Philip Cooper to the nomination and ratifying the issuance by the Board of Elections of a certificate of nomination for Arthur G. Klein.

Without waiting for the official lists of numbers drawn in the Washington lottery, which may not be received until Monday or Tuesday, local draft boards began yesterday to integrate the names of the new potential trainees with their old lists of last October's registrants who have not been called up for examination.

RUMSON, N.J., July 18 -- Victories by Mr. and Mrs. Martin Vogel's imported chestnut gelding, Demas, in two full-count conformation hunter classes, and the annexation of the polo mount champion-shop by R.V. Clark's chestnut gelding, Little Prince, drew the spotlight as the Monmouth County horse show continued today.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Charges of racial discrimination by private employers and by the nation's armed services were put before Congressional committees today by separate sources.
Full fields, of eleven and fourteen, respectively, have been named for the East View Stakes and Fleetwing Handicap, features today at Empire City.

LONDON, Saturday, July 19 (U.P.) -- Colonel V. Britton, Britain's mysterious radio "Voice of Doom," called on the peoples of German-occupied countries today to begin mobilizing a "V for Victory" army within forty-eight hours to strike at the Germans in any possible way.

Two revivals will make their appearance today on Broadway screens. At the Globe, Metro's "Navy Blue and Gold," a comedy-drama featuring Robert Young, James Stewart, Lionel Barrymore, Florence Rice and Billie Burke, which was first released in 1937, will be the new tenant.

PLYMOUTH, Wis., July 18 -- Twenty carloads of American Cheddar cheese, amounting to 500,000 pounds was bought today by the United States Government, bidding on the floor of the Plymouth Cheese Exchange for the first time in its history.

BERLIN, July 18 -- Announcement of the publication of "blacklists" of Latin-American firms by the United States Government and the alleged plan for an economic union of the Caribbean Islands offered today the principal targets for new and scathing attacks by the German press against what it calls President Roosevelt's "hemisphere imperialism."

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. John M. Barrett of 1158 Fifth Avenue and Mrs. Barrett's son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick P. Palen of 129 East Seventy-fourth Street, are at The Lodge, Smuggler's Notch, Vt.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 18 -- A third raid by troops of the Tobruk garrison into Axis lines in five days was completed early yesterday, and not only accomplished its mission of capturing prisoners but "revealed, the British said, that Axis forces were sufficiently unnerved so as to use searchlights for ground observation. The raiders again inflicted casualties.
LONDON, July 18 -- The posthumous award of the George Cross for conspicuous bravery to the Earl of Suffolk and Berkshire was announced in The London Gazette tonight.

Asked to identify a vegetable the shape of a globe and the color of sunshine, the reply of an Englishman might be pumpkin and that of an American, squash. Both would be right, but to both a botanist might issue the command: "Please be specific."

SEATTLE, July 18 (AP) -- Hundreds of new fires started by lightning in sun-scorched forests of the Northwestern States and British Columbia brought urgent official appeals tonight for additional fire-fighters.
LONDON, July 18 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said early today:
ST. LOUIS, July 18 (AP) -- Bob Johnson's ninth-inning home run today gave the Athletics a 6-to-5 victory over the Browns.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Competitive airline traffic across the Atlantic Ocean is justified, in the opinion of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals, which handed down a decision, read today by Justice Augustus Hand, upholding the right of the Civil Aeronautics Board to issue a certificate to American Export Airlines to engage in this traffic.

FORT MEADE, Md., July 18 -- The Forty-fourth Division's movement during the night from Fort Dix, N.J., to this reservation, on the way to Virginia for two weeks of manoeuvres, showed marked improvement over a previous trip six weeks ago, Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell, division commander, said this afternoon.

RUMSON, N.J., July 18 -- Many dinner parties were given tonight before the evening session of the Monmouth County Horse Show which is being held for the benefit of the Defense Council of the River Boroughs.

These surveys are made by a system, of Highly selective samplings in each of the forty-sight States in proportion to voting populations; thereby, the American Institute of Public Opinion holds, is obtained a result which would not vary from that of a much larger canvass.

Clergymen from many parts of the country will preach tomorrow in the pulpits here. They will substitute for the pastors who are away on Summer vacations. Several will be from Canada, one from Hawaii and one from Liberia. In some churches the discourses will be delivered by the associate or assistant pastors.

CAMP SHELBY, Miss., July 18 -- Among the 52,000 soldiers here in the largest tent encampment in the country the proposal to keep selectees and National Guardsmen in service longer than a year has been the week's principal topic of conversation.

ROME, July 18 -- The hopes of those Italians who still believed that the war would end within a year were definitely dashed today when it was announced that the gasoline allotted for civilian automobiles would be suppressed beginning Oct. 1.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, July 18 -- The government faces a test by-election tomorrow in the Waitemata seat, made vacant by the death of Government Representative Captain W.J. Lyon, who was killed in Greece.

Three fifteen-car trains left the Pennsylvania Station last night returning troops on leave to camps in Alabama. The cars in one train were provided by the Pennsylvania Railroad, but in the others they were owned respectively by bhe Norfolk Western and the New York Central.

New bond financing this week was again restricted to the railroad and the tax-exempt field, but the total volume of new flotations rose to $20,424,000 compared with $12,195,000 in new issues marketed last week. In this week last year, offerings of new bonds amounted to $86,923,000.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: This is just another letter from the "sticks" in support of the letter from F.L. Martin of Arlington, Va., published in THE TIMES of July 5. However, I think your editorial note on the same clearly shows that you back the reporting of Arthur Daley on walking of which the letter complains.
CAMP WHEELER, Ga., July 18 -- About 3,000 new trainees arrived at this infantry replacement center this week in one of the largest series of transfers since the camp opend in March.

Even with the most hopeful view that can be taken of the future, some dark days lie ahead for the American people. The totalitarian Powers still have the initiative in this war. With every gain they bring us closer to outright participation. In the weeks and months that lie ahead we shall have to make decisions which involve the very life and death of this Republic.

BENDIX, N.J., July 18 -- In contrast to the violence Thursday, when police had to use tear-gas bombs and revolvers to disperse strikers, 300 employes of Air Associates, Inc., passed peacefully a C.I.O. picket line as they returned to their work today on defense orders for the Army and Navy.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 18 -- The Maidstone Club's annual invitation men's double tennis tournament is the occasion for a number of house parties. Mr. and Mrs. Julian S. Myrick are entertaining at their home on Apaquogue Road Watson Washburn, William J. Clother, Lawrence A. Baker, Arthur McPherson, Gilbert Hunt, Alrick Mann Jr., Ernest Jonklaas and J. Gilbert Hall.

Making known its plans for the rest of the Summer and for Fall, Lippincott lists twenty-five books. Prominently mentioned is one by Osa Johnson, "Four Years in Paradise," the story of how Martin Johnson photographed the life span of the elephant.
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.
Deflation of the Dodgers continued at an alarming rate at Ebbets Field yesterday.

INWOOD, L.I., July 18 -- Back at the scene of his recent triumph in the Long Island amateur championship, little Frankie Strafaci, Fort Hamilton private, and his partner, Stanley Harte, could not quite do the trick in the Inwood Club's member-guest best-ball golf tourney today.

VICHY, France, July 18 -- Another Cabinet change was announced this evening. Pierre Pucheu, Secretary for Industrial Production, became Minister of the Interior and was replaced in his former post by Francois Lehideux, Delegate General for National Equipment, who retains his old duties.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 18 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

First "Extra Load" Tanker As a result of the recent revision by Congress of the load line law, the first of the "extra load" tankers will arrive in New York Harbor today. It is the Mobilgas, owned by the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., and it is bringing 125,000 barrels of gasoline from Texas, against a former limit of 122,000.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.

The Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company, maker of automobile bodies and stainless steel trains, reported yesterday for the second quarter of 1941 "a net profit of $957,466 after all charges, including provision for income and excess profits taxes of $1,199,000.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 18 (AP) -- Backed by a sixteen-hit attack, Johnny Lindell tonight scored his fourth straight victory over the Chiefs, 8 to 0, as Newark swapped shut-outs with its hosts in their two-game series.
DETROIT, July 18 (AP) -- Emil (Dutch) Leonard limited the Tigers to six hits today as the Senators won, 8 to 1. Rain halted the game at the end of the eighth inning.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The War Department announced today that it had awarded contract for supplies totaling $58,794,402. Among these were the following, not prevoiusly published, which went to concerns in New York State:

BERLIN, Saturday, July 19 -- In a special communique issued late last night, the German High Command announced that Smolensk, Russian town 230 miles southwest of Moscow, had been taken on Wednesday and that all Russian attempts to retake the town had failed.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The present time is bound to create difficulties for the press willing to give correct information about events in different parts of the world.
To THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES : May I offer a criticism of your editorial of July 16 which, under the interesting title "Communist Candor," delivered a broadside against me and my party.

The steadily increasing employment of women as policy slip collectors by the bankers of this particular racket had a sharp repercussion yesterday in the Bronx Magistrate Court where Magistrate Rothenberg, finding a 43-year-old mother of two children guilty of collecting slips, fined her $100 and sentenced her to a thirty-day work-house term.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 18 (AP) -- Baltimore snapped a six-game losing streak tonight by taking the the second game of a double-header from Jersey City, 4 to 1, after the Little Giants had captured the opener, 2 to 1.
BOSTON, July 18 (AP) -- Frank Frisch's strategy went awry today and enabled the Braves to rally for a 4-3 triumph over the Pirates after they had dropped the first contest of a double-header, 5-1.

ALBANY, July, 18 -- The State Banking Department Bulletin revealed today that the Nunda Dupuy State Bank of Nunda had filed its organization certificate with the department.
