OTTAWA, July 19 -- The success of the two-month campaign for recruits for Canada's overseas army has temporarily stilled the demand for conscription and most significantly so because the Province of Quebec made as good a showing as any of the others.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Strength in cotton, soy beans and lard was largely responsible for a moderate upturn in wheat futures on the Board of Trade today, but the rally was feeble. Prices held within a range of about 1 cent a bushel and closed at the top with gains of 5/8 to 7/8 cent over yesterday's final quotations.
Midsummer work in the Long Island home-building field is being carried forward at an active pace, with new tracts being opened for development and established communities showing expansion.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 19 -- Varied entertainments were held throughout the day for week-end guests at estates in the colony. Mr. and Mrs. William Adams Kissam gave a dinner tonight at The Shallows, their home in Halsey Neck Lane, for the right Rev. Ernest M. Stires, Bishop of Long Island, who will conduct the service tomorrow at St. Andrew's Dune Church, and Mrs. Stires.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Manufacturers Trust Company proposes to make an offering to the public of the common stock of the Marion-Reserve Power Company, which it will acquire from its subsidiary, the Utility Service Company, according to a declaration filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LIMA, Peru, July 15 -- Peruvian leaders are giving a round of receptions for the North Americans attending the Catholic Seminar on South America at the University of San Marcos here to introduce the visitors, professors and students from more than a score of colleges in the United States, to the centuries-old cultural life of the country.

Blair Hawley of this city, Exeter captain this year, stroked his way into the final round of the junior Eastern tennis singles championship by beating the fourth-seeded entrant, Dick Cooley of Rye, N.T., 6 -- 4, 9 -- 7, on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 19 -- Kenarden Lodge, the Summer estate of Mrs. John T. Dorrance, will be the scene of a concert on Tuesday to be given for the benefit of the British War Relief Society, under the auspices of the Mount Desert Island branch, of which John DeWitt Peltz of New York is chairman.

CHUNGKING, China, July 19 -- The threat of a new crisis in the relations between the Communists and the Kuomintang [Nationalist party] was seen today in the National Military Council's charges that Communist Eighth Route Army units had attacked Central Government troops at two places in Southeast Shansi Province and at three places in Shantung.

A Summer series of lectures, sponsored by the Second District of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, will be held at the New York State Institute of Applied Agriculture at Farmingdale, L.I., on three Mondays -- July 28, Aug. 25 and Sept. 22 -- at 1:30 P.M.
ST. LOUIS, July 19 (AP) -- They may not be going anywhere, but the Browns swept a double-header today from the Red Sox and looked like a team that might make a loud noise the remainder of the season.

RYE, N.Y., July 19 -- Strange things happen in member-guest handicap invitation golf tournaments. Ray Billows of Dutchess shot a par -- equaling 72 in the qualifying round of the annual Apawamis event today, and his combined score with his partner John W. Hubbell, was an eyecatching 69, yet that was not good enough to make the championship flight.

HERE in these pages, says William Allen White in his admirable introduction to this big volume, "is Theodore Roosevelt in his miraculous abundance." It is an excellent phrase, to which Mr. White adds another of more specifically descriptive summary: "Here is his teaching from A to Izzard."

IF Batty, who often lived up to his name, and who was the youngest and most unpredictable of the Pippits, hadn't insisted on wearing his gum boots to the cattle fair, these three children of an absent-minded English rector would never have embarked on the most exciting night of their young lives.

With industrial defense production swinging into high speed, the conservation of materials vital to the war effort is assuming added importance. One phase of this conservation program is best illustrated by the campaign now under way for the gathering of worn-out aluminum pots and kettles as an aid to our pursuit plane and bomber production program.

Because new developments in the defense program are constantly taking place, "often without the knowledge of the individual citizen," and because "in this time of national emergency it is perhaps not unnatural for the historic colleges of the country to feel a sense of special responsibility," Dartmouth is sending to all of its students and their parents a series of bulletins interesting because of their emphasis as much as for their information.

HOLLYWOOD. THE first major production dealing with the actual fighting between England and the Axis is before the cameras at Twentieth Century-Fox, where Tyrone Power is tracing the career of an American flier who participates in the evacuation of Dunkerque.
VICHY, France, July 19 -- Negotiations either for entry of supplies or for evacuation of women and children from French Somaliland are understood to be under way here today.

SKINNERS CORNER, Va., July 19 -- The Forty-fourth Division's 2,350 trucks, carrying more than 16,000 men, arrived at the A.P. Hill Military Reservation this morning only a few minutes behind schedule.

A campaign to raise $3,000,000 for relief of 100,000 British children will be opened by the British Child Aid Committee after the return in September of Henry J. Allen, American national chairman, from a survey trip to England, he said yesterday on departing from La Guardia Field aboard the Dixie Clipper to Lisbon.

To the Art Editor: HAVING read your "Artists in the National Emergency" and Forbes Watson's splendid review of the American artist's problems, I must express my appreciation of these constructive efforts in behalf of the American artist.

AN exhibition sponsored by the British Government, entitled "The Great Fire of London, 1940," is current at the National Gallery of Art and will continue through Aug. 11. The paintings and drawings by artists serving in the London auxiliary fire service were selected by Sir Kenneth Clark, director of the National Gallery, London; Sir W.W. Russell, keeper of the Royal Academy, and J.B. Manson, former curator of the Tate Gallery, London.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The term "war zone" is frequently used in current news items and comment, but the intended meaning is often vague, and the rights of belligerents and neutrals respectively in such area are not clearly indicated.

LONDON, July 19 -- The Russian news and the news from Japan have somewhat overlaid the phase of the war in which Britain is chiefly interested because, no matter what happens elsewhere, the British think that Germany can not win the war unless Hitler conquers these islands.

BEACON, N.Y., July 19 -- Many years ago James Speyer, the banker, who founded the Provident Loan Society, with the unique side purpose of making loans available to persons of limited means without the prohibitive interest rates charged by loan sharks, visited a Settlement Society, a new kind of charity in England.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of alterations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.

RUSSIAN atrocity tales were the order of the day on Reich waves all last week, with each German propagandist trying to outdo his colleagues in the presentation of gruesome pictures. Lord Haw Haw has been going strong.

John Kramer and Ted Schroeder of California, the national doubles champions, defeated Ted Olewine and Charles Mattmann of the University of Southern California, national intercollegiate titleholders, yesterday to reach the final round of the New York State tournament.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- The destinies of 104-year-old Rush Medical College, which, was started before Chicago was incorporated as a city, of its 68-year-old central free dispensary, and of 58-year-old Presbyterian Hospital have been united with those of the University of Illinois.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- Tennis enthusiasts at this resort will have a number of events for their entertainment during the coming weeks. Today on the grass courts of the Meadow Club there will be played a men's team match, Meadow Club players competing against a team from the River Club of New York.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 19 -- The Undine Barge Club of Philadelphia won the national amateur rowing championship today, but an unheralded schoolboy crew stole the show with a photo-finish race decided by a scant foot.

The closing of the rift between the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply and the cotton-textile industry, which was achieved late Friday, will release orders for at least 150,000,000 yards of gray goods, according to traders.

Not a few of the pretty business girls who spend most of the hot months in the city agree that a New York Summer broken by country week-ends and a two or three week holiday (with pay) is not half bad. One problem which they all face, however, is that of appearing neat and fresh from 9 to 5, and perhaps on into the evening.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 19 -- Another research bureau took its place beside the Princeton Listening Center and the American Institute of Public Opinion at Princeton this week with the establishment of the Bureau of Urban Research by Princeton University, it was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.

A STATISTICAL review of the first half of 1941 in philately shows that at least 925 major and minor varieties of stamps were issued by ninetyfive different governments. Other postal items are reported to have appeared but have not yet reached New York, and collectors believe that censorship has prevented news regarding still others from seeping through.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 19 -- There was no evidence of a world turmoil out on Long Island Sound today when the Larchmont Yacht Club's Forty-third Race Week started. Despite a thunder squall that undoubtedly kept some of the small craft in harbor, there were 266 starters, and from the Westchester shore across to Long Island the water was clouded with canvas.

OTTAWA. NO names, no routes, no airports and no times may be mentioned when one writes of the growing business of ferrying American-built planes across the Atlantic to England. This was made very plain by the slight young man in a blue serge suit who directs operations.

If we peer into the cloudy background of today's terrible events we see a people -- no, not a people, but an undetermined fraction of a people -- which has, first, proclaimed its superiority to all other peoples, and, second, has set out to impose its will upon them.

KEENE, N.H., July 19 -- Colonel Walter R. Porter, oldest banking official of this city, who served for fifty-four years as a director of the Cheshire National Bank without missing a single annual meeting, died at his home here today at the age of 81.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 (AP) -- Lord Halifax told 700 men producing marine-type engines today that the Nazis have turned from the plane to the submarine in an attempt to conquer England.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Ways and Means Committee began final consideration today of the defense tax bill designed to raise $3,504,000,000 in new revenue to help meet the rearmament costs.

The following statement issued by Almerindo Portfolio, city treasurer, shows receipts and payments by the city for June, 1941 and 1940, together with receipts and payments from July 1, 1940, to June 30, 1941, and for the similar period of 1939-1940.
LONDON, July 20 (AP) -- The following Air Ministry communique was issued today:

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Canada's method for stabilizing wages and outlawing "illegal" strikes, consisting of a combination of compulsory mediation with provision for periodic increases in wages, which were "frozen" as a counter-inflationary measure, has aroused considerable interest among some defense planners in Washington.

PASSAIC, N.J., July 20 -- President Roosevelt was urged today to Invoke the provisions of the Russell-Overton amendment to the Selective Service Act and take over the strike-bound plant of Air Associates, Inc., in Bendix, N.J., in order that "the interests of national defense will be furthered."

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 20 -- Following the state of siege decree signed last night by President Enrique Penaranda de Castillo, the morning newspapers Calle and Inti and the weekly Busch have been notified by the police to discontinue publication for a fortnight.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 20 -- Repeated German thrusts along the entire Eastern Front failed today to bring about any important change in the Russian line as the Russian-German conflict entered its fifth week.

PITTSBURGH, July 20 -- Steel companies last week continued to rush production on all material carrying preference ratings and were clamping down further on acceptances of fresh bookings for nonessential consumption. Despite these conditions, however, informed sources indicated that total order volume last week still exceeded both production and shipments of steel products.
MOSCOW, July 20 -- Before me stands an old but still strong man with a long gray mustache. He is little pale but very calm. His right arm is bandaged.
NEW ORLEANS, La., July 20 -- Cotton futures paid little heed to defeatists in its ranks the first half of last week here and rose another $2 a bale or so to new high levels for the season.

On the whole, financial markets acted last week as they usually do after a week of "million-share days." Monday and Tuesday, which in the previous week had run well beyond the million mark, decreased in the same days of last week to 762,000 and 644,000 respectively, and fell to 423,000 on Friday.

Louis Fischer, foreign correspondent and author, who departed by clipper on Saturday for England, will get to work immediately in England making some inserts in the British edition of his book "Men and Politics." The British edition has not yet been published.
Five Broadway houses will present new films this week. The schedule is as follows:

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- Little Ben Hogan, in a furious final-round battle that saw him out-shooting the national open titleholder, Craig Wood, captured the $5,000 Chicago open golf championship today with a seventy-two-hole total of 274, ten strokes under par for the Elmhurst Country Club course.

DETROIT, July 20 -- The Yankees' majestic sweep through the West finished on a long but triumphant note today when, to the dismay of 28,099 feverish onlookers the Bronx Bombers crushed the Tigers, 12 to 6, in a bizarre struggle that went seventeen innings.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- There was an increase of 11.3 per cent in the electric power transmitted across State lines and across international boundaries to Canada and Mexico in 1940, according to an official summary published here today by the Federal Power Commission.

The hopes for a good bluefish season are increasing with reports of fairly large catches of these fish by sportsmen along the lower New Jersey coast, and as the menhaden and other bait fish are quite plentiful the outlook is better than it has been in several years.

The clearance sale on Palm Beach suits which starts today and Will continue until Sept. 1 will give a much-needed lift to newspaper advertising on men's Summer clothing, which is running behind, last year. Advertising volume on men's wear has been lagging because of shortages and incomplete stocks on regular lines and even sales copy has been curtailed because of the lack of desirable offprice goods.

The four "V's for victory" in the war against evil are virility, valor, vision and vicariousness, declared the Rev. Dr. Samuel Henry Prince of the faculty of King's College, Halifax, N.S., in the morning sermon yesterday at St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, 128 West Sixty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- President Roosevelt asked all radio broadcasting companies today to send representatives to the White House at 11 A.M. tomorrow to make a recording of his message to Congress in which he will ask authority to extend the service of selectees, National Guardsmen and Reserve officers beyond the year set by law and keep the Army intact during the emergency.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The march of the defense program across the face of industrial America has progressed to the point where ordnance must be listed as a "big business." As it stands today, it is a two-billion dollar industry.

LONDON, July 20 -- Alfred Duff Cooper leaves the Ministry of Information, of which he has been head since Prime Minister Winston Churchill formed his government, under changes in the Cabinet announced today. He will be succeeded by Brendan Bracken, who has been one of Mr. Churchill's closest personal assistants for years and his Parliamentary Private Secretary since he entered the government as First Lord of the Admiralty on the outbreak of this war.

Frank Parker brought his most successful season on clay to a close at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills yesterday by adding the New York State tennis championship to his long string of conquests, interrupted by a lone defeat at the hands of Robert Riggs in Kansas City.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20 -- Frank Campbell made certain that he would be the Western Long Island Sound representative in the Star Class world championship regatta in San Diego next month by winning the sixth and last elimination race in the Larchmont Yacht Club's regatta today.
CLEVELAND, July 20 (AP) -- The Senators made it look easy in beating the Indians, 8 to 4, today, then lost the second game, 5 to 1, on errors that broke a seventh-inning tie.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 20 -- "Cheyenne," a story of the vicissitudes of a rodeo champion's life, by William Rankin and Winston Miller, will be John Wayne's next picture for Walter Wanger, it was learned today. Wanger is expected to close a deal tomorrow for screen rights to the story, now owned by Howard Hawks, a director.

BERLIN, July 20 -- In spite of the spectacular successes achieved by the Reich's armed forces in the first four weeks of the Russian campaign, and in spite of the losses which the Germans say they have inflicted on the Russian Air Force and Tank Corps, official German communiques continue to stress the fierce fighting and stubborn resistance of the Red Army.

One doubts that even Adolf Hitler, communing with what he takes to be his soul in lofty Berchtesgaden, can grasp the full extent of land, of peoples and of history which he has troubled by his invasion of Russia. His deepest penetrations, after nearly a month of war, were pin-pricks in Russia's skin, however costly to her armies.

The forthcoming effort of the Real Estate Board of New York to "sell" Manhattan to families that may be contemplating joining the trek to the suburbs, and to bring some of the way-ward ones back to town, will be watched with interest by large cities throughout the nation, because their problem is one with ours.

LONDON, July 20 -- In reaching a new high record at u650,920,000 the Bank of England's note circulation is now running against the normal trend, although in the light of present conditions any comparison with the old averages cannot really be made on a useful basis.
PHILADELPHIA, July 20, (AP) -- The Phillies made only three runs on twenty-one hits today, while Cincinnati got ten runs on fifteen safeties to down the celler dwellers, 7 -- 1 and 3 -- 2.
BERLIN, Monday, July 21 (U.P) -- Germany heralded her own "V for Viktoria" campaign today, the press depicting it as the symbol of a united Europe's support of the war against Russia.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There are two serious financial problems which confront the American people today. One is the problem of properly financing our defense program. The other is the problem of preventing a runaway inflation.
MOSCOW, July 20 (AP) -- Today's communique of the Soviet Information Bureau included the following:

VATICAN CITY, July 20 (U.P.) -- Informed Vatican circles tonight expressed anxiety over the health of Pope Plus XII, who for a week has been under the constant care of his personal physician, Dr. Galeazzi Lisi, for "nervous exhaustion."

MOSCOW, July 20 (U.P.) -- Joseph Stalin and the Supreme Soviet tonight announced the merging of the Commissariats of Home Affairs and National Security "because of wartime necessities." This was the fourth major government reorganization within a week.
FREDERICKSBURG, Va., July 20 -- Soldiers of the Forty-fourth Division have made their second public complaint on continuation of their Federal service, it was learned here today.

In its fourth, expansion since it took the store at 667 Fifth Avenue in 1935, Georg Jensen, Inc., silversmiths, have leased the corner store at 671 Fifth Avenue, at Fifty-third Street, through Albert B. Ashworth, Inc. Leases for expansion in 667 were made in 1937 and 1938 with the acquisition of second floor space, and in 1939 the concern took the adjoining store at 669.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 20 (AP) -- The motion picture screen has no room for propaganda, but the films have a definite service to perform in the present emergency, Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, said in a statement today.

Sparkling performances by Miss Helene Rains of the Women's Swimming Association, Miss Anne Ross of the St. George Dragon Club and Michael Priano of the Flatbush Boys Club highlighted the aquatic meet yesterday at Broad Channel Bathing Park, Queens.
LONDON, Monday, July 21 -- The Royal Air Force pressed without a halt yesterday its attacks on German shipping and sweeps into occupied France.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 20 (AP) -- British and Free French forces hastened today to convert conquered Syria and Lebanon into a great Near East defensive bulwark lest they become another Crete.

TOKYO, Monday, July 21 -- Having reported his assumption of the Premiership for the third time to the Imperial Ancestors at the grand shrines of Ise, Prince Fumimaro Konoye returned to Tokyo last night. He is now scheduled to clarify the policies of his new Cabinet in an interview and a radio speech tomorrow.

BOSTON, July 20 (AP) -- Although outhit in both games, the Cardinals swept a double-header today with the Braves. The scores were 4-2 in the twelve-inning opener and 7-3 in the afterpiece, halted after eight innings by the Sunday law.

THE funny thing is that it was a left-hander who stopped Joe DiMaggio's record-breaking hitting streak. Of course, it was a right-hander, Jim Bagby Jr., who put the crusher on Jolting Joe in his final turn at bat that night before the largest crowd of the season. But it was Lefty Al Smith who baffled the Yankee Clipper through the earlier part of the evening in Cleveland.

LONDON, July 20 -- The stock markets here were somewhat subdued last week, the change being, in part, a natural reaction after the preceding week's exuberance, and also the result of outside events, although the military and political developments have not really been unfavorable.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 20 -- Edward V. Ketcham Jr. of Babylon today took an indisputed lead in the Great South Bay Star class elimination series to select a representative for the fleet in the Atlantic Coast championships.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 20 -- President Eduardo Santos formally convened Congress today to begin its legislative labors for 1941. In his message to Congress he reported the economic condition of the country fundamentally sound and stressed the importance of the country's international relations.

With the aid of a favoring wind, Johnny Rucker coaxed his first home run of the campaign into the upper right-field stand to give the Giants their first brush with the Cubs in the twin bill at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The score was 7 to 5.

LONDON, July 20 -- The British Board of Trade's index for wholesale commodity prices in June, based on the 1930 level as 100, was 152.4, compared with 151.3 in May and 134.4 in June, 1940. In August, 1939, just before the war began, the index was 98.1.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- When the Army, in September concentrates half a million men in Louisiana for the nation's greatest peacetime war game, newspaper and radio reporters and photographers will be subject to "capture" by the side opposing the one to which they are attached.

ALGIERS, Algeria, July 20 (U.P.) -- The United States was warned today by the newspaper Depeche Algerienne that France, with her empire defenses newly strengthened, would fight against any American encroachment involving Dakar in West Africa or Morocco.

The Free French marching into Syria promised liberty to the Arabs. But in a wider sense they promised liberty even to disheartened Frenchmen in France, and to French nationals in all the colonies of the old Republic. Now that General Catroux is established victoriously in Syria it will be interesting to watch the development of Free French sentiment in other fragments of the French Empire.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 20 -- Former Finance Minister Victor Paz Estenssoro was arrested today at Tarija, in the heart of the Bolivian oil fields. The police said he was there "in connection with a Nazi Putsch" which has thrown this country into a state of siege and resulted in an expulsion order against the German Minister.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 20 -- Alfred M. Landon, asserting that "the President has the country out on a limb now and we have got to strengthen the tree at the base," announced reluctant support today of proposals to keep selectees and National Guardsmen under arms beyond a year.

On the principle that Manhattan's traffic problem is essentially one of parking, a plan calling for the creation of a municipal Traffic and Parking Authority and for a pick-up and delivery service appiled to automobiles is being announced today by the traffic and parking subcommittee of the civic and public affairs committee of the Advertising Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A charge that Representative John E. Rankin of Mississippi "slipped past the House of Representatives" a military pension bill giving $40 a month to every 65-year-old veteran of the World War who served at least ninety days and needs the money was made today by Robert B. Luchars, national commander of the American Veterans Association.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 20 -- Turkish official sources denied categorically today that Germany had introduced the subject of troop or munitions transport across Turkey to any future Asiatic front. They also denied rumors that Germany's Ambassador, Franz von Papen, had made such overtures in conversations during this week with Turkish Foreign Minister Sukru Saracoglu.

TUMBES, Peru, July 20 -- The writer arrived at Tumbes, headquarters for Peru's northern military district, after having crossed the disputed Zarumilla River, on the Ecuadorean-Peruvian frontier, in the Huaquillas district.

NORTHEAST, Md., July 20 -- Crack-ups yesterday at Havre de Grace levied a toll on today's regatta, and the fleet of speed boat entrants was lowered further in midafternoon when another of the northern Chesapeake Bay squalls darkened the skies, puffed the wind into a half gale and churned the Northeast River almost into surf breakers.

A patrolman who holds two departmental medals of honor was attacked in Staten Island early yesterday morning by five young hoodlums he was trying to quiet. In the fight, one youth was wounded fatally by a shot from the patrolman's revolver.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 20 -- American Red Cross officials said here today that Egypt's Red Crescent Society, aided by the American and British Red Cross, was caring for approximately 100,000 destitute and semi-destitute Egyptians who fled from Alexandria as a result of recent bombings that have taken a high toll of life and property.

The state of siege proclaimed in Bolivia underlines the peril to which our Good Neighbor policy and American solidarity are exposed as long as German intrigue is permitted to propagate anywhere on the soil of the Western Hemisphere. The measure is frankly described as taken to forestall a Nazi "Putsch" directed from Berlin.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Liquidation by holders of wheat futures as the result of a glut of cash grain at terminal and subterminal markets and a severe scarcity of storage room in the interior kept wheat prices on the downgrade the past week, with the volume of sales at the lowest level in about a month.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 20 -- The Aknusti poloists assured themselves of at least a tie in the Brook League of the Meadow Brook Club's annual twenty-goal championship today by turning back the Broad Hollow riders, 6 to 3, on the Phipps estate.

Renewed warning that failure by the Consolidated Edison Company to allocate the installation of electrical equipment in its Waterside plant, at Thirty-ninth Street and First Avenue, to Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A.F.L., would result in an immediate strike of 6,500 electrical workers in the city, and a consequent sympathetic walkout of 250,000 A.F.L. building trades-workers, was served yesterday by Harry Van Arsdale Jr., business manager of Local 3.

Warning that not every young man who is physically fit is emotionally qualified for the rigors of army life, the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, in its thirty-first annual report, urged yesterday that more adequate medical examinations should be provided to weed out the mentally and nervously unfit among the selectees.

A new kind of war started in the early hours of yesterday morning when the "V" campaign was launched over the air of the darkened Continent of Europe. V stands for Victory and also for the number five; it is the sign of the biggest. Fifth Column ever organized to carry on an invisible fight.

A group of sixteen German, Austrian, Russian and American Socialists, who have been conducting discussions under the auspices of the Rand School of Social Science, published yesterday a declaration on war aims and peace terms in which the statement is made that the survival of a Bolshevist regime in Russia after the war would be "a source of danger."

RYE, N.Y., July 20 -- Marvin Pierce of the host club and Hertie Barres of Round Hill teamed effectively down the homestretch of their final-round match with Robert Merrill and George Elliott of Concord and won top honors in the annual Apawamis Club member-guest invitation golf tourney today.

Single bliss is likely to lead to double trouble, if the study of the social background and criminal history of 2,158 indeterminate-sentence prisoners who were released to its supervision in 1940 by the State Parole Board means anything.

The Grenlite Realty Company, an investing syndicate headed by Henry Lichtig, bought from the Empire City Savings Bank the sixteen-story store and loft building at 257-61 West Thirty-eighth Street, the third property of its kind in the garment district sold by the bank in the last few weeks.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Nineteen large oil companies operating on the East Coast were asked today by Secretary Ickes, the Petroleum Coordinator, to give him a weekly report on their retail sales so that he may know the extent of compliance with recent requests for a voluntary reduction in the consumption of petroleum products.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's acceptance of an invitation to broadcast a weekly fifteen-minute commentary on current events, beginning in September, was announced yesterday by the Pan-American Coffee Bureau, which will sponsor the programs.

The recent report of the iron and Steel Institute, on the completed half-year's output of steel in this country, makes possible some unusual comparisons. The Institute remarks that this year's six-month production was within 20 per cent of the twelve-month output in 1917.
BERLIN, July 20 (AP) -- German bombers pounded British barracks

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 95.1 to 95.4. Moderate price rises occurred in all groups except chemicals, which declined slightly. The major finished goods group continued up into new 1936-41 high ground of 98.8. Similarly, a rise in the price of cotton yarn lifted the textile products subgroup up to 100.0, also a new 1936-41 high point.

ST. LOUIS, July 20 (AP) -- The Browns blended hitting and pitching today to capture a twin bill from the third-place Red Sox and stretch a winning streak to four games, their longest of the season. St. Louis swept the series, also having won a double-header yesterday.

MOSCOW, July 20 (AP) -- By again listing Smolensk among the battle zones the Soviet military leadership implied that the Red Army center had halted the mechanized Nazi advance units that clattered last week into that area 230 miles west of Moscow in a threat to the capital.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Lard prices tended downward last week, partly because of scattered liquidation induced by price-selling talk in some commodities, a Commodity Exchange recommendation that increased margins be asked on speculative trades and a relatively slow domestic shipping demand.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The United Federal Workers told affiliated C.I.O. unions today that government employes were confronted with a "virtual reign of terror in which Gestapo methods are being used by high government officials."

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- The White Sox defeated Connie Mack's Athletics today, 2 to 1, in the first half of a double-header, but the visitors gained an even break with a 4-to-1 decision in the 13-inning nightcap.

FORT DIX, N.J., July 20 -- The drive at Fort Dix to get recruits to serve as flying cadets in the Army Air Corps is meeting with enthusiastic response from the trainees of the Forty-fourth Division and other units stationed here, it was revealed today.

Continuing their upward movement, cotton prices again reached new high levels since 1930 last week. An early advance which carried all new-crop futures above 16 cents was followed by a sizable reaction, but the market gradually recovered.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Chairman Reynolds has declined to join with other members of the Senate Military Committee in recommending speedy passage of defense property seizure legislation, a revised version of a bill which Mr. Reynolds himself had introduced at the request of the War Department.

ARCHIBALD JOSEPH CRONIN'S sixth novel, "The Keys of the Kingdom," is published this morning, with the formal endorsement of the Book of the Month Club. A staggering number of pre-publication copies -- 250,000, more or less -- have already come from the press. By this day next week the figure will be still more staggering, and we shall have a newcomer high on the best-selling fiction list.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Bituminous Coal Division announced today that a trial examiner had recommended the denial of a request by Detroit, for revision of marketing regulations which would permit producers to make "premium and penalty" contracts for sale of coal to political subdivisions of Michigan.

BERLIN, July 20 -- After a firm opening last week when stock prices continued their advance of the last few weeks, the German stock market suffered a serious setback on Thursday, when leading shares lost 3 to 5 points. Nevertheless, on balance, the stock price index showed a slight net advance over the week, reaching 207.90 on July 18.

Confident that Mayor La Guardia will announce tonight, in a radio speech, to be broadcast from City Hall at 8:45 o'clock, his intention to run for a third term, Fusion, Republican and Democratic leaders stood ready yesterday to draw their battle lines for the September primaries and the November election.
JERSEY CITY, July 20 (AP) -- Jersey City captured both ends of a double-header from Buffalo before a crowd of 5,113 today, 3 to 2 and 7 to 6.

NEWARK, July 20 (AP) -- A home run by Center Fielder Tommy Holmes in the overtime eighth gave league-leading Newark a 2-to-1 victory over Toronto in the second game of a double-header before 5,000 today. The Bears were blanked in the opener, 1 to 0.

The Department of Parks has completed construction of park and playground areas in the vicinity of the Queensbridge housing project, Long Island City, Queens, to meet the recreational needs of the section and to avoid wear and tear on the landscaped areas around the housing development, it was announced yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, July 20 -- Ten of the original sixteen players entered in the preliminaries of the annual open championship of the United States Chess Federation had qualified when the games of the fifth round and those adjourned from earlier sessions were concluded today.

TOKYO, Monday, July 21 (U.P.) -- There were increasing indications today that the new Japanese Government headed by Prince Fumimaro Konoye would follow an extremely cautious foreign policy and that Japan's ties with Germany and Italy were weakening.
At least seven new dramas will be tested at the rustic outposts next week. The list, as of the moment, appears as follows:

The "racial-national" philosophy epitomized by the Nazis and the Fascists must be replaced by a new internationalism "if human life is to have any decent hopes," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of Riverside Church, said yesterday in his sermon.

VICHY, France, July 20 -- The Paris press confirms rumors, current here for some days, that leaders of the former regime now "administratively interned" at Valsles-Bains, in Ardeche Department, may be transferred soon to Porquerolles Island, off the Mediterranean coast.

SALEM, Mass., July 20 -- The mutilated body of Miss Frances M. Cochran, 19, of 54 Webster Street, Lynn, was found by police early this afternoon in underbrush fifteen feet from a woodland road near the Swampscott line. She had been missing since Thursday night.

Contending that the requisitioning of the two remaining vessels of the Seatrain fleet by the United States Government would be "highly detrimental to commerce," the Merchants Association of New York has written to the United States Maritime Commission urging that the ships be kept in service, it was announced yesterday.

Margaret F. Watson, James and Elizabeth Ruby and J.H. Brunning, former shareholders in the Claremont Building and Loan Association of Jersey City, bought from the trustees, who are dissolving the association, the three-story flat with two stores at 402 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J.

That blue and white Brooklyn pennant still was flying in the favored spot atop the center-field stands at Ebbets Field last night, but it didn't seem to flutter quite so arrogantly. For the Dodgers now are only a game and a half ahead of the second-place Cardinals.

INWOOD, L.I., July 20 -- After playing twenty-eight holes today In order to reach the final round, Harry Ogden and his guest-partner, Jimmy Oleska of the Bayside Golf Club, a headquarters detective in Brooklyn, emerged victorious in the annual member-guest tourney of the Inwood Country Club.

LONDON, Monday, July 21 -- Britain's newly launched "V for Victory" war of nerves against Germany -- formally declared at the zero hour of midnight, Saturday -- proved a tremendous success on the German-occupied Continent in the first day of the propaganda offensive, according to London officials.

BERLIN, July 20 -- All information available in Berlin tonight suggests that the German Army forces are still engaged in a smashing advance along most of the long Eastern Front. Leningrad, Moscow, Kiev and Odessa still are directly before the advancing Germans.

Commitments were made for an unusually large volume of merchandise by a great number of fashion goods buyers in the market last week. Many buyers were in town for their second Fall trip. There was a tendency in the market to hold prices in check as much as possible.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 20 -- Major and Mrs. John A. Warner gave a luncheon today at their home in Toylsome Lane for Mr. and Mrs. Duncan S. Ellsworth, who are spending the week-end with them.

The recent American occupation of Iceland may lead eventually to occupation of other outlying sites or strategic points dominating the sea approaches to this hemisphere and to the continents of Europe and Africa.

It is becoming more and more difficult to determine from the course of our foreign trade exactly the extent to which our financial position in relation to it is developing. On the face of things, the Commerce Department's much-belated May statement shows the largest export trade, except for the preceding month, since January of 1930.

Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York Methodist area, preaching yesterday at a union service in the Frist Presbyterian Church, 124 Henry Street, Brooklyn, said that one task of the church was to help reverse the downward pull of the worship of force and worldly success in the world.

Wholesale prices, the cost of living and wages in Great Britain have risen substantially since the beginning of the war in spite of the far-reaching wartime powers for the control of prices and production given to government officials by Parliament, according to John T. Madden, director of the Institute of International Finance of New York University.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 20 -- An answer to international skepticism was given here today by Dr. A.C. Fagginer Auer, a Netherland Professor of Religion, in opening the Harvard conference on "Religion and the World Today." Dr. Auer said that the statement that men could not cooperate in seeking the solution of a problem because they interpreted the truth in different ways was contrary to the principles of religion.

AMSTERDAM, July 20 -- The securities markets of the small Continental European countries recently have been showing an increasingly divergent aspect. Neither the influence of military developments nor all-around monetary abundance has been able to induce a general trend except in the bond market.

The advance of 4 cents a pound in cotton gray goods ceilings announced at the week-end by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply will result in a rise of 4 cents a yard, or 16 cents a pound, in branded percales at retail, it was predicted last night by the head of the percale division of one of the largest houses serving the retail trade.

A crowd of 18,000 last night attended the final performance of the season of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Lewisohn Stadium. The program was the one originally scheduled for last Thursday, but which was called off because of rain after the first number.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The speech of Leon Henderson at Atlantic City should be very welcome to Americans. He spoke frankly and let us know just what we are in for In the defense effort. He told us that we must expect to have our standard of living drastically lowered.

BERLIN, Monday, July 21 (U.P.) -- The division and encirclement of Russian armies in retreat "along the entire front," with the Russians suffering tremendous losses, were said by German quarters today to be "proceeding irresistibly."
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Henry Coster Emmet will leave the Plaza today for Bangor, Me.

Colonel Milton S. Bowman, commanding officer of the Seventh Regiment, New York State Guard, declared yesterday that State Guard regiments offered invaluable pre-draft training to young men. Some of his men who were drafted have been made corporals three days after induction, he pointed out.

VICHY, France, July 20 -- The promulgation of social measures continues to appear as one of the principal points of the government's program. Already much has been done to improve conditions for the wage-earner and to abate the evils of unemployment.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 20 -- After four weeks of war in Russia the Germans have won the battle of the frontiers and seem to be on the point of winning the battle of the Stalin Line. Their progress is certain and cannot be minimized, but the fact remains that the Blitzkrieg has been braked by the Russians. Such is the appraisal of the situation by competent observers here tonight.

With the aid of chorus girls, Boy Scouts, American Legionnaires and members of various civic and patriotic organizations, the nationwide campaign to collect old aluminum gets under way today. William S. Knudsen, director of the Office of Production Management, and Mayor La Guardia, director of the Office of Civilian Defense, hope for a "whole-hearted popular response" on the ground that such a result "cannot fail to impress the enemies of democracy."

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Corn, oats and other grains were affected last week by the same influences as wheat, and prices declined steadily. With the exception of corn, major grain crops were so near maturity that the outlook for the yield had little or no influence as a price-making factor.

LONDON, July 20 (U.P.) -- Britain's improved fighting planes, which now can fight at seven and a half miles altitude, should give the Royal Air Force a marked advantage over the most recent German fighter craft, according to Oliver Stewart, British aviation expert.
On the Daylight Standard If President Roosevelt has his way, it may become slightly silly to ask whether a given appointment or train departure is set for daylight-saving or standard time.

As pert and pretty as a freshly painted toy is the tiny new sweets shop that decorates a somnolent city avenue with its saucy scalloped awning of brightest blue. One immediately imagines round-hatted boys tugging their well-starched nurses through the narrow doorway to a point peremptorily at the barley-sugar lollipop rabbits.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 -- Ray Robinson, New York Negro who has yet to meet defeat as a professional, scored the most important victory of his career when he defeated Sammy Angott of Washington, Pa., tonight in a ten-round bout at Shibe Park.

Freetown, Sierra Leone, which is under British rule, rather than Dakar, world be the more desirable site for a United States air and naval base if the American occupation of Iceland should lead to similar occupation of other strategic Atlantic points.

As an initial step in a general reorganization of the affairs of the International Utilities Corporation, P.M. Chandler, president and chairman of the board of the utility holding company, resigned from both the positions yesterday and was succeeded in the presidency by William B. Yeager, a former official of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Except for a very few of their number -- Harry Hopkins, Secretary Ickes, Sidney Hillman and Justice Frankfurter -- the New Dealers have little important connection with the active defense establishment. That they have resented and worried over this is well known in Washington.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 21 -- The German trade commission to be headed by Dr. Karl Clodius and sent to Turkey to complete present commercial negotiations and sign the projected 25,000,000-Turkish-pound trade pact will arrive in Ankara during the first week in September, according to information today from usually well-informed diplomatic sources in Ankara.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 21 -- Speaking today of the Harvard Summer School conference on religion in relation to current problems, Dr. Kirtley F. Mather, director of the school, said that there was a rising tide of movements of the spirit all over the country, the significance of which, as exemplified in Harvard, "cannot be overstated."

Holders of approximately $7,000,000 Republic of Colombia 6 per cent bonds due on Jan. 1, 1961, and Oct. 1, 1961, have to date tendered their bonds in exchange for the republic's new 3 per cent external dollar bonds, according to an announcement made here yesterday by Dr. Gabriel Turbay, Colombia's Ambassador to the United States.

VICHY, France, July 21 (U.P.) -- An urn containing the ashes of Czar Nicholas II and his entire family lies in the vaults of the Bank of England in London awaiting ultimate return to the Kremlin, it was asserted today by General Pierre Janin, French World War leader.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Commerce Department announced today receipt of information that Paul von Bauer, Germany's "Director of Aviation Expansion for Spanish America," had abandoned his activities in Colombia because of "the recent restricting regulations of the United States Government and the hearty cooperation of the President of Colombia."

Hundreds of New York's fashion followers feasted their eyes yesterday afternoon on a diversified assortment of costumes presented in the I.J. Fox annual fur revue. Several innovations in fur styling were brought out for every kind of occasion, from spectator sport to formal evening wear.

Flaunting a seven-game lead over the Indians, the Yankees will launch a home stand at the Stadium today against the second-place Clevelanders. For the curtain-raiser in this series, which could make a runaway of the race if the McCarthymen swept all three contests, the Yanks will be called upon to face the redoubtable Bobby Feller.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 22 -- The heavy bombers, fighter bombers and fighters of the Royal Air Force continued to lash the enemy yesterday and through last night in a seemingly continuous series of attacks.

VICHY, France, July 21 -- When 578 officers and soldiers released from captivity in Germany arrived in the Roanne station this morning, Marshal Henri Philippe PStain was there to greet them and speak words of cheer. This was his second personal contact with prisoners.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Appraising the war danger to the United States and the Western Hemisphere as "infinitely greater" than a year ago, President Roosevelt called upon Congress in a special message today for the quickest possible enactment of legislation permitting him to hold selectees, national guardsmen and reservists in the Army longer than the statutory period of one year.

There is but one candidate for Mayor of New York City who stands a good chance of defeating the lean and hungry forces of Tammany Co. It is therefore good news that Mr. La Guardia is willing to run again. He is the most successful tiger-tamer we have had since Tammany was a kitten.

Private advices received last night by THE NEW YORK TIMES from a European capital reported that General Erwin Rommel, Commander of the German African Corps, had been recalled from Libya to collaborate with General Field Marshal Siegmund List in mapping the German campaign in Russia.

Dr. Gregory Mason, author, anthropologist and former war correspondent, has been appointed head of the Department of Journalism in the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced yesterday.

SKINNERS CORNER, Va., July 21 -- The Fourty-fourth Division's noncommissioned officers, particularly sergeants, will be subjected to observation just as thorough as that for commissioned officers during the manoeuvres of the next two weeks on the A.P. Hill Military Reservation.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- The wheat market was a tame affair today. There was a fair advance in sympathy with cotton at one time but the storage situation continued to overshadow all other factors as a market influence. The fear of a scarcity of warehouse space was increased late in the afternoon by a Department of Agriculture report showing an increase of 22,000,000 bushels in the indicated yield of wheat in the four Northwestern States.

Somewhat vexed about Hollywood's interference with the road tour of "Pal Joey," the George Abbott office yesterday decided to cancel the bookings and close the show here on Sept. 27. This double-barreled decision was made, according to the Abbott office, when Gene Kelly, who has the title role in the show, was engaged for the next Alfred Hitchcock picture, which David O. Selznick will produce.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: So much nonsense is being printed and broadcast about Iceland these days that one would think the place had just fallen off the back of the moon and was still too hot, from its dash through space, to bear close examination.

ROME, July 21 -- Premier Bogdan Philoff and Foreign Minister Ivan Popoff of Bulgaria arrived here this morning in what is understood to be an effort to obtain Premier Mussolini's recognition of Bulgaria's aspirations on Salonika.
WASHINGTON, Tuesday, July 22 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced this morning that it had authorized a loan of $425,000,000 to Great Britain.

When Harry Miller Lydenberg became director of the New York Public Library a little less than seven years ago a TIMES writer quoted some characterizations of him from friends who knew him best: "One of the most beloved and respected of American librarians; a man who carries modesty to a fine art; one who is tireless in the service of every good project; one who handles enormous administrative work, yet never seems hurried."
NEW YORK Mrs. E. du Pont Weir of Wilmington, Del., is at the St. Regis.

Operations of the Blaw-Knox Company and its subsidiaries, manufacturers of machinery and steel products, in the first six months of 1941, resulted in a net profit of $1,220,496. After allowances for depreciation, interest and $1,196,413 provision for Federal income and excess-profits taxes, the earnings are equal to 91 cents each on the company's 1,334,458 shares of capital stock outstanding.

"Murder by Invitation," the Monogram mystery co-starring Wallace Ford and Marian Marsh, which was scheduled to open at the Rialto tomorrow, will instead arrive at that theatre today.... "King of the Zombies," a Monogram melodrama with Dick Purcell and Joan Woodbury, and a Republic Western, "Desert Bandit," starring Don (Red) Barry, comprise the double-feature program, beginning today, at the New York Theatre....

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, July 22 -- Advices received from Moscow late yesterday said that severe fighting was continuing in the immediate vicinity of Smolensk, whose fall was announced last week by the Germans. Unofficial Russian reports declared that the city was still in Russian hands.

Following is the text of the communication addressed to Mayor La Guardia yesterday afternoon by the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee, headed by Samuel Seabury, asking him again to be a candidate for Mayor:

Merrill Lynch, E.A. Pierce Cassatt, brokerage and investment house, obtained 19,572 new customers during its first full year of advertising, according to an Advertising Facts folder issued yesterday by the research and promotion department of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, 370 Lexington Avenue.

LONDON, July 21 (AP) -- The British Army's plan for defending air fields probably will be reviewed as a sequel to manoeuvres in which a score of middle-aged American business men "captured" the heavily manned general headquarters of a brigade defending an important airdrome.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 21 -- Miss Kathleen Byrne of Rye and Mrs. Archie McLave of Westchester Hills tied for the lead with identical scores of 42, 42 -- 84 as the first round of the twelfth annual women's Westchester and Fairfield open golf championship was completed today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, announced today that the United States had assured Bolivia of full assistance if her ousting of Ernst Wendler, the German Minister, resulted in an international incident, and had informed the La Paz Government that the Minister would not be permitted to come to this country.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Mrs. Joan Kaufman Biddle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Kaufman of New York, was married today to William F. Ladd Jr. of New York. The ceremony was performed by Judge Henry J. Pendl in the Kaufman suite at the Blackstone Hotel.

FORT MEADE, Md., July 21 -- More than a score of Fort Meade selectees who sent a telegram to Senators Wheeler and Taft protesting against the proposed extension of service, will not be disciplined, commanding officers announced today, following an investigation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I, as one of those "Italian liberals" whom the son of the great Yugoslav leader, Svetozar Pribichevich, mentions in his letter to THE TIMES, express my fullest appreciation regarding the basic idea of Italo-Yugoslav cooperation. This has been, since the days of Mazzini, the substance of the slogan, "Action and Thought."

The two-story taxpayer at 113-18 Jamaica Avenue, corner of 114th Street, Richmond Hill, L.I., has been sold by the Chase National Bank to a client of Isaac Putterman, attorney, who paid cash above a $39,000 mortgage for seven years.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The United States Government has information that Germany plans other aggressions in Europe after she has completed her attack on Russia, it was announced by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, at his press conference today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Before a demonstrative audience which repeatedly had to be warned to keep quiet or get out of the galleries, the Senate today greeted President Roosevelt's message with a stormy debate which produced three alternative plans for extending the service of men in the armed forces.

TRENTON, N.J., July 21 -- The Legislature reconvened tonight with not enough votes in sight in either the Senate or Assembly for passage of the four bills designed to settle the controversial railroad tax problem.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 21 -- Phil Turnesa, veteran pro of the Elmsford Country Club, teamed with Bobby Bermant, recently graduated from Scarsdale High School, to win the Westchester P.G.A. one-day tournament at the Briar Hills Club today.

A firm of builders active recently in the construction of apartment buildings has acquired as the site for another such project the property at 223-33 East Sixty-first Street, where the church edifice formerly occupied by the East Sixty-first Street Methodist Church has stood for nearly three-quarters of a century.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 97.9 per cent of capacity, a gain of 0.7 per cent over last week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. A month ago operations were at the record high level of 99.9 per cent. The current rate is the best since then, the nationwide output having fallen to 93.7 per cent in the week that included the July 4 holiday.

Demand for most classes of locally dressed meats was fair to good yesterday. The market on steer hinds and ribs was strong to 50 cents higher. Fresh pork cuts were moderately active, with 8-12-pound loins up $1. Other major cuts were steady. Veal hind-saddles were steady to strong. Lamb about steady with Friday's quotations.

CAMDEN, N.J. July 21 -- Enoch L. (Nucky) Johnson, admitting through counsel that the numbers racket paid him $158,800 in 1935, 1936 and 1937, contended today that he spent half that amount in "oiling" his Atlantic City political machine and paid an income tax on the money he kept.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Efforts of "prominent individuals, commenting on the state of our defense program," to classify "electric ranges with luxuries which, are displacing defense" drew a strongly worded protest from the Electric Range Section of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association here today.

Cotton mills and their selling agents, besieged yesterday with orders for gray goods, moved cautiously and most of them sold nothing. Although they generally acknowledged that the new ceiling prices named last Saturday by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply reflected current values with reasonable accuracy, there was a disposition to avoid any hasty action.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- After a vigorous plea by George Roberts, counsel for the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, in the course of which he appealed to the press to prove his case, the Securities and Exchange Commission today took under advisement the question whether the corporate structure of the company should be reduced to one class of stock, a common issue only.

The large group exhibition called "Dealers Show American Art" opened yesterday afternoon with a preview at the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. Beginning today the assembled work, which is in several mediums, may be enjoyed by the public.

JERSEY CITY, July 21 (AP) -- Fred Hutchinson, Buffalo's 22-year-old right-hander, scored his eleventh straight victory and his nineteenth of the season tonight when he outpitched 41-year-old Bill Harris to win, 5 to 3, before 4,688 fans.

It was getaway day at Ebbets Field yesterday and it probably was just as well. The loyal Flat bush fans couldn't take much more of the brand of ball their favorites played as they lost to Lefty Ken Heintzelman and the Pirates, 8 -- 3.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 21 (U.P.) -- The German Government, in reprisal for the Bolivian Government declaring German Minister Ernst Wendler persona non grata because of alleged subversive activity, has given the Bolivian charge d'affaires in Berlin seventy-two hours to leave Germany, it was announced officially tonight.

Lew was long and Joe Weber was short. They grew up together as if by agreement and for comic effect. The East Side is a perpetual theatre. In their youth the variety show was in its prime. Life in much of New York seemed to be dancing a clog to the hiss of the sand-shaker.
LONDON, July 21 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique issued today:
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Office of Production Management predicted today a shortage of most types of paper as a result of the war and the defense program.

CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Lighter weight hogs commanded steady to strong prices today, but heavier hogs and sows brought steady to 10 cent lower values in an active market in which the top was unchanged at $11.85 a hundred pounds. Beef cattle and all classes of sheep were up as much as 25 cents.

Recommendations for a national program of voluntary rehabilitation of draft registrants rejected for military service because of physical defects are contained in a report just made public by the Commission on Physical Rehabilitation.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Thomas M. Wilson of Tennessee, veteran, Foreign Service officer and at present Consul General at Calcutta, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be United States Commissioner to India, with the rank of Minister.

Three thousand miles of ocean has ceased to mean protection for this country, Mayor La Guardia yesterday cautioned fifty heads of women's organizations at the Hotel Pierre roof, during a session on defense. An American-built bomber can be set down in England only six and a half hours after hopping off from our coast, and it is no farther one way than it is the other, he pointed out.

While seriously concerned by Leon Henderson's announcement of a program designed to cut refrigerator production 50 per cent and washer output 30 per cent, electric appliance manufacturers yesterday pointed out that the statement was a "forecast and not an order" and therefore subject to revision.

Charges that the Municipal Civil Service Commission delayed giving an examination in order to help provisional appointees already employed in the city service were heard yesterday by the City Council committee investigating civil service, as the committee entered what is expected to be its final week of public hearings.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Senate passed unanimously today the modified Draft Property Bill which authorizes President Roosevelt to requisition until June 30, 1943, any military or naval equipment or any supplies, machines, tools or materials necessary to the defense of the United States.

BAILEY ISLAND, Me., July 21 -- The wide, deep stage that is known as Casco Bay has been set for the first annual Maine tuna tournament, but tonight, on the eve of the first day's performance, the bac of lowering clouds does not active opening.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- American bakers were asked by Leon Henderson, administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, today to offset the higher costs of ingredients by reducing operating expenses instead of raising the cost of bread to the consumer.

BERLIN, July 21 -- The Germans claimed today that their invasion of Russia was making excellent headway on all fronts and that tremendous Russian forces were trapped east of Smolensk in a pocket from which they never would be able to escape.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Office of Production Management created a special power unit today to handle all defense power problems, called on private and public power interests to forget past conflicts and fears of the future and announced plans for three big power pools in the Southeast, Arkansas and the New England-New York areas to provide energy for new aluminum plants.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A description of relatively heavy competition for American shipping in Pacific waters, despite the war, was given to an examiner for the Maritime Commission today in the course of a hearing called to consider refusal of the American President Lines to agree to virtual cessation of subsidy payments.

As 25,000 parents and neighbors of service men began a block-to-block canvass of the city last night on behalf of the drive to raise New York's quota of $3,500,000 for the United Service Organizations for National Defense, Inc., former Governor Alfred E. Smith predicted that this campaign would do more than anything in a long time to "bring back the real neighborly spirit here in New York."

Lamp departments are planning on increases in dollar volume ranging from 15 to 30 per cent in the Fall, department store buyers said yesterday at the opening of the nineteenth semi-annual New York Lamp Show in the Hotel New Yorker.

LONDON, July 21 -- Slim, 33-year-old Mrs. Jean Knox took over control of the Women's Auxiliary Territorial Service branch of the army today and promised its 50,000 members she would give them a snappier uniform.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The authors and sponsors of the Burke-Wadsworth Selective Service Bill appeared before the Senate Military Affairs Committee today to ask the amendment of the law in consonance with the recommendations of President Roosevelt and General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff.
Following is Mayor La Guardia's statement announcing his candidacy for a third term:

A syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation submitted yesterday the high bid for an issue of $3,243,000 city of Kansas City, Mo., water revenue bonds, naming an interest cost basis of 1.8376 per cent. The successful tender was for $505,000 of the bonds as 2 1-3s and $2,738,000 as 1 3/4 s; the bonds will be dated Aug. 1, 1941, and are to mature serially on Aug. 1, 1943 to 1961.

ONE of the most vivid accounts we have had of life in wartime England is John Strachey's little history of his experiences as a London airraid warden, "Digging for Mrs. Miller."* Yes, this is the same John Strachey who used to write pontifical political tracts and expound the Truth (on at least one occasion he actually called it that) on lecture platforms.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 19:

ROME, July 21 (U.P.) -- Forecasting an armed clash between the United States and Portugal over the Azores, the Italian weekly review, Relazioni Internazionali, asserted today that the Axis planned to isolate first Russia, then Great Britain and then "any other power which opposes our advance."

Extensive camouflaging is being carried out in Berlin, with trees planted atop conspicuous buildings to shield them from the view of British bombers, Lincoln MacVeagh, United States Minister to Greece, reported on his return here yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 21 -- Italian units outside Tobruk lay in wait for British patrols, finally caught Indian troops between the lines early yesterday and attacked them "in force," the British Middle East Command said today. The Indian patrol counter-attacked with bayonets and drove the Italians back to their own lines with heavy losses.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Excerpts from the brief submitted today by Grenville Clark, chairman of the National Emergency Committee of the Military Training Camps Association, to the Senate Military Affairs Committee were as follows:

THE ex-footballer John Francis (Chick) Meehan is plunging ahead in the boxing business and has scheduled an all-heavyweight show for Ebbets Field tonight. Though new in the boxing business, Chick couldn't have picked a better spot for his activities. Ebbets Field is fighting territory. That's where the dauntless Dodgers play.

The Shell Union Oil Corporation reported yesterday for the quarter ended on June 30 a net profit of $4,208,151 after all charges, taxes and reserves, equal to 32 cents a share on 13,070,625 common shares. This compares with $4,135,788, or 28 cents a common share, after dividends on the preferred outstanding in the second quarter of 1940.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Seventeen brigadier generals were assigned today to new posts as part of the War Department's program to revitalize the Army by assigning field commands to its most active officers on the basis of selection according to efficiency.

The four-story building at 133 Newark Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., was sold by Richill Equities, Inc., Samuel Schack, president, to the Jackson Equities, Inc. The parcel is assessed for $43,400 and was sold subject to a $35,000 mortgage.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 21 -- Police harbor patrols along the Westchester shore and the North shore of Long Island joined today in search of a six-foot blond-haired "pirate" who, traveling in a sixteen-foot boat painted white and equipped with a powerful outboard motor, is believed to have broken into a dozen or more yachts in Long Island Sound harbors during the last five weeks.

First studies for the development of a program for moving hundreds of thousands of persons out of New York City in an emergency are being made under the guidance of Edward Weinfeld, State Commissioner of Housing, and Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti of the State Council of Defense, it became known yesterday.

The advance in prices of cotton, which was resumed late last week following the announcement of an upward revision in the "ceiling" on cotton cloth, continued yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The list again moved into new high ground since 1930.

More than 10,000 families of steelworkers, small shopkeepers and other residents of Homestead and Duquesne, Pa., learned yesterday that they would have to find new homes as a result of the signing on Friday of a contract between the Defense Plant Corporation and the Carnegie Illinois Steel Corporation for the erection of new steel plants in these mill areas.

A woman's day will be divided into two distinct parts, come Fall, predicts Lilly Dache. In the daytime defense tasks will occupy her time; after 6 o'clock, the cocktail hour providing the break, she will devote herself to pleasure. For her serious hours the woman will want common-sense hats; for playtime she will require glamour, declares this millinery oracle.

Creation of the V Clubs of America as a national auxiliary of the British American Ambulance Corps was announced yesterday by the organization's president, W.C. Ruxton, from his headquarters at 420 Lexington Avenue.

Jeremy Ingalls of Gloucester, Mass., is the winner of the 1941 Yale Series of Younger Poets Competition, it was announced yesterday by Stephen Vincent Benet, editor of the contest. Miss Ingalls's winning entry is a collection of poems entitled "The Metaphysical Sword."

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The House Ways and Means Committee voted today, after an all-day fight, to retain in the defense tax bill the mandatory joint income tax return for husbands and wives. The vote was reported to be 15 to 10, the same margin by which the joint return was originally voted.

Stars of the entertainment world joined hands yesterday noon with representatives of the Army and Navy in staging a United Service Organization rally on the steps of the former Subtreasury, at Wall and Broad Streets. From a platform beneath the statue of George Washington, amateur and professional alike sought the aid of 2,500 spectators.
BERLIN, July 21 -- The Boerse was irregular and narrow throughout today's session, with most issues fluctuating slightly. Schantung lost 3 and Bergen 3. The close was soft and dull.

The five-story loft building at 2338 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold by the City Savings Bank to a client of Kalmon Dolgin, Inc., brokers, and will be used for the manufacture of furniture. The structure is on a plot 50 by 100 feet and contains about 25,000 square feet of space.

Almost an essential element in the American way of life is the tried and true tradition of Sunday night supper. Then it is that families rally round in the old, familiar, informal fashion; the children proudly and meticulously placing napkins and silverware on the table, their apron-swathed mother happily carrying bowls of salad and crisp buttered toast in from the kitchen.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 21 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

Yehudi Menuhin made his first appearance as a soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium last night and 23,000 persons turned out to hear him. The immense crowd was only slightly smaller than the record breaking ones that jammed the Stadium at the opening night at the Gershwin concert eleven days ago.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Chicago's mail order houses are facing their most perplexing merchandising problems since the last war in contracting for materials for their 1942 Spring and Summer catalogues. The outcome probably will be increasing emphasis on the sale of soft goods lines to make up for the inability to acquire from the manufacturers such items as washing machines, electric refrigerators, ironers, power tools, in anything like normal quantities.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 -- Death cut short the major work of the career of Dr. Fisher, former chief archaeologist and Egyptologist of the Museum of the University of Pennsylvania, who left Philadelphia in 1926 to go to Jerusalem as Professor of Archaeology at the American School.
The first of two series of exhibitions of city gardens and penthouse terraces will be held today and tomorrow afternoon for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 21 -- Mrs. Reginald de Koven of New York entertained at dinner at Steepways tonight. Her guests included Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Magruder, Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Hale, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Ellsberg, Mrs. Pierson Price, Dr. James Murphy and Samuel L.M. Barlow.

The consolidation movement of last week gave way yesterday in the stock market to a fresh upswing and the rails broke through to new high levels since May of last year. In general strength, the share list had one of the best sessions of this year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 21 -- Pare Lorentz, producer of the Government-sponsored documentary films, "The River" and "The Plow That Broke the Plains" and of Paul de Kruif's "The Fight for Life," which Columbia released, is expected to sign with RKO as a producer, it was learned today.

Encouraged by the reception given its initial venture two weeks ago, Chick Meehan's Brooklyn Boxing Association will present its second program at Ebbets Field tonight. Melio Bettina, former light-heavyweight champion, and Clarence (Red) Burman, protege of Jack Dempsey, are to be the principals in the feature ten-round bout.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 21 -- Germany's long-awaited peace offensive will not be postponed until the end of the Russo-German war but already has been started in the remaining neutral capitals of Europe and is being intensified daily, according to information from neutral foreign observers arriving in Turkey.

After serving the New York Public Library forty-five years, Dr. Harry Miller Lydenberg, director, and one of the leading librarians of the country, will retire. He will be succeeded as director by Franklin Ferguson Hopper, Chief of the Circulation Department of the Library since Jan. 1, 1919.

MOSCOW, July 21 (U.P.) -- Vice Foreign Commissar S.A. Lozovsky announced today that Premier Joseph Stalin, having assumed the post of Defense Commissar and undisputed master of Russia's resistance, was "now officially the Commander in Chief of the Red Army."

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., July 21 (AP) -- Colby Hanover, black colt owned by D. Eugene Fay of York, Pa., and driven by Fred Egan, won the $4,500 National Stake for 2-year-old trotters at the Grand Circuit meet today to become an outstanding possibility for the 1942 Hambletonian.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 21 -- Opening day in the fifty-fourth annual invitation tennis tournament of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club was about to pass into history this evening without providing the customary reversal when Arthur Marx of the Hollywood House of Groucho came striding into the picture to strike the saving blow for tradition.

Store Sales Here Up 16% Department-store sales in New York and Brooklyn last week ran 16 per cent ahead of a year ago, according to the flash report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank. One store had one more selling day than last year.

LONDON, July 21 -- Britain's V -- "V for victory" -- war of nerves against Germany appeared today to have taken, by storm the imagination of many people in the German-occupied countries, as well as in Britain.

In response to the call for aluminum scrap, pots and pans and percolators poured forth in such quantities from the kitchens of America yesterday that Washington officials in charge of the campaign predicted the 20,000,000-pound quota would be topped.
Brokers yesterday reported many rentals of East Side apartments, including a number of large units, a penthouse and others with terraces.
MOSCOW, July 21 (AP) -- Today's communique of the Soviet Information Bureau included the following:
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress on extending military service for selectees, National Guardsmen and reservists was as follows:

A possible general strike of electrical construction workers in this city, which would in turn affect some 250,000 building trades employes, may be voted today as a consequence of a deadlock in the conflict between Local 3 of the Electrical Workers Union and the Consolidated Edison Company.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 21 -- Brilliant putting by Al Brosch and Roy Ward of Bethpage enabled them to clip six strokes from par and win the pro-amateur feature preceding the Long Island open tourney, with a 33, 33 -- 66 score at the Lido Golf Club today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 21 -- Mrs. Albert F. Jaeckel gave a dinner tonight at D.A.R. Cottage, her home in Main Street, for Mrs. T. Charles Farrelly, who is visiting Mrs. Charles Tracy Barney at the Meadow Club. The party later attended the bridge tournament held at the same club.

The renovation of Washington Market, formally completed yesterday, was cited by Mayor La Guardia as an example of the many public improvements in the Borough of Manhattan achieved through the cooperation of Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs with the city administration.
