Change at Tokyo Late in the Summer of 1947 there was a Cabinet crisis at Tokyo. The Ministry headed by Prince Konoye resigned, as a result of profound changes in the international situation.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 22 -- Reassuring Germany and Italy, who are perturbed by the recent Cabinet changes, Foreign Minister Teijiro Toyoda has told the German and Italian Ambassadors that Japan continues to uphold the spirit and the aim of the Axis alliance as the basis of her foreign policy and that there will be no change in the principles of that policy.

Mayor La Guardia announced last night, in a radio address to the people of the city, his willingness to serve a third term as Mayor of New York. He indicated that he would continue in his post as Civilian Defense Administrator, disposing of the dual-job problem in the second paragraph of his speech with a comment that "everybody is working harder now, why shouldn't I?"

James Speyer James Speyer, who for forty years was senior partner of the international banking house of Speyer Co. until its dissolution in 1939, reaches today another milestone in his brilliant career. He was born eighty years ago in this city.

ST. LOUIS, July 21 -- Reuben Fine of New York, the defending titleholder, Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, Bruno Schmidt of Detroit, Erich W. Marchand of Clayton, Mo., and Fred Anderson of St. Louis were the victors today in the first round of the finals for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 21 -- Vice Chancellor James F. Fielder refused today to restrain Sussex County authorities from proscribing use of land at Camp Nordland at Andover, formerly operated by the German-American Bund, on the ground that activities at the camp have constituted "a source of danger" to the national defense effort.

VICHY, France, July 21 -- Pierre Pucheu, the new Minister of the Interior, has left for Paris, it was learned today. He will review the general situation with the German authority and probably also with leaders -- or would-be leaders -- of French public opinion in the occupied zone.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 21 -- Everything was arranged today for the resumption of the Larchmont Yacht Club's forty-third annual Race Week, except the wind. There was practically nothing in the way of breeze until late in the afternoon.

ATLANTA, July 21 (AP) -- Governor Eugene Talmadge announced today he would withhold executive news from two Atlanta dallies unless "they correct their attitude" in regard to the recent hearings for two educators on charges of advocating racial co-education.

TOKYO, July 22 (U.P.) -- Japanese newspapers today warned that the storm lashing several islands of the empire was of exceptional intensity and said results of the prolonged rain and high winds would be "epoch-making." The weather bureau predicted the rains would reach their peak tomorrow night.

Dividends on stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange were 8.2 per cent higher in the first half of 1941 than in the first half of 1940, according to an article in The Exchange, organ of the institution. Aviation made the greatest gain, 104.6 per cent, followed by shipbuilding and operating, 94.2 per cent.

Captain William A. McHale, veteran master of ships of the Moore-McCormack Lines, has been called to duty with the Navy and will join the former American President liner President Adams, now in government service, late this month, it was announced yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 22 -- Need for a new world organization capable of enforcing its decisions was emphasized at the conference on Religion and the World Today at Harvard Summer School.

So modest is the appearance of a small butcher shop that one might casually pass it by without suspecting that a repertoire of delicacies awaits within. The black letters of a neat window sign -- inconspicuous clue to the specialties of the store -- read: "Kalv Sylta, Guthenburg Medurst, Flesk Korv."

When a publisher advertises a book or an author hints that something he has written is very good, indeed, no one thinks it odd. When seven private citizens who don't know the author and have no connection with the publisher spend their own private money to advertise a book, people may wonder why.

The Williams Oil-O-Matic Heating Corporation yesterday announced a sharply increased news-paper campaign and a novel method of reimbursing customers who suggest names of prospects that are actually converted into buyers. The plans were outlined at a sales meeting of the Eastern division at the Hotel Astor.

Three men, two of them convicts, were indicted yesterday on a first-degree murder charge in the shooting of Patrolman Michael J. Moroso nearly nine years ago at Second Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street by five hired Negro assassins who mistook Moroso for another patrolman who had been harassing a vice and gambling ring in that vicinity.
CINCINNATI, July 22 -- Unless the Dodgers are completely shockproof, they must have been stunned shortly after 5 o'clock today.

TALARA, Peru, July 21 (Delayed) -- The general impression gained after crossing the disputed frontier of Ecuador and Peru in Tumbes Province is that the military situation is static and probably will remain so during the informal conversations in Washington.

Fewer gray goods were sold yesterday than on Monday, but the market, nevertheless, appeared to be moving toward an adjustment to the new ceiling levels established at the week-end by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply.

Buyers' Registrations Off Visiting buyers recorded in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,031, as against 1,405 in the previous week and 1,280 in the same period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Willie Sing, 49 years old, of 9 Pell Street, operator of a laundry at 447 College Avenue, the Bronx, ran into a heap of trouble recently, but it was nothing compared to the anguish suffered yesterday by Lieutenant Robert McAllister of the Alexander Avenue station when he tried to unravel the Chinese puzzle caused by Willie's woes.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The War Department announced that approximately $62,467,112 worth of contracts had been awarded today, of which nearly 553,000,000 went for the purchase of 1,500,000 blankets and for almost 20,000,000 yards of cloth to be converted into Army clothing.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 22 -- Herewith is the complete text of the statement issued here today by Governor Charles Edison in reply to Mayor Frank Hague's charges that he brought pressure to bear to bring about passage of the railroad tax compromise bills by the New Jersey Legislature early this morning:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: How long will it take some people to see our actual danger? We don't need scaremongers' or Halloween hobgoblins to work on our emotions. We just need to open our eyes. It is natural for us with three thousand miles between us and the foe of civilization to hug our comfort till we hear the crash of bombs on churches and libraries and pleasant city parks.
BERLIN, July 22 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today from "the Fuehrer's headquarters":

Trading in the wholesale meat markets yesterday was slow on some classes and good on others. Steer beef hinds and ribs were strong to higher. Veal hindsaddles steady to strong, lamb mostly steady. Pork cuts steady to lower. The kosher markets opened with trading slow with little change in prices.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 22 (AP) -- Reports of a pro-totalitarian revolt among a group of Bolivian Indians reached the capital today as German Minister Ernst Wendler, expelled for alleged participation in a purported Nazi conspiracy to overthrow President Enrique Penarande de Castillo, left by train for Antofagasta, Chile.
Music publishers, musicians and theatrical firms figured in many of the commercial rentals reported by realty brokers and owners yesterday.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 22 -- Guerrilla warfare by Serbian irregular Chetniks continues in Serbia, Bosnia and parts of Macedonia despite countless executions, imprisonments and German warnings that 100 Serbs will be killed for every German or Croat shot by Chetniks, according to information reaching foreign military circles here this evening.

OGALLALA, Neb., July 22 (AP)-- President Roosevelt envisioned in Kingsley Dam today "an epochal triumph" for the veteran Senator Norris and a symbol of accomplishment for communities "where there is a strong and clear demand from the people that power be publicly owned and publicly distributed."

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- In a move which Senator Norris called the first step toward "establishing a gestapo in this country," the Senate today passed, 41-14, a bill authorizing the Secretary of the Navy to establish a secret detective force to investigate any existing or threatened espionage or sabotage in United States naval establishments.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,676,050 barrels daily, a decrease of 194,700 from the 3,870,750 reported a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 171,050 barrels below the calculation of 3,847,100 daily by the Bureau of Mines for July.

ST. LOUIS, July 22 -- Hurry Danning became confused during a Cardinal exhibition, of base-running that out-Dodgered the Dodgers at Sportsman's Park today. Billy Jurges dropped a throw in an important coverage of third base. The bespectacled Bob Carpenter's pitching victories were ended after four straight.

The season at the Lewisohn Stadium is virtually turning into a festival of Russian music, for it opened with an all-Tchaikovsky program, there have been Russian works on many programs, the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo gave an entire evening of Russian ballets, and last night Efrem Kurtz, a Russian conductor, conducted the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in the second program devoted entirely to various Russian composers.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 22 -- Mrs. Goodhue Livingston gave a luncheon today at Old Trees, her home in First Neck Lane, for Mrs. Henry R. Rea of Sewickley, Pa., who is visiting Mrs. J. Denniston Lyon at the latter's home on the ocean.

City gardens at the top of their midsummer bloom were put on view yesterday for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association. Visitors to eight private places opened to the public for the afternoon found a double pleasure in the wealth of healthy verdure and the ingenious features developed by the owners.

ALEPPO, Syria, July 21 (delayed) -- British and Imperial forces have wasted no time in occupying strategic positions along the 500-mile North Syrian border from the Mediterranean to the junction of the Turkish-Iraqi Iranian frontiers.

A committee of the National Republican Club, appointed by William M. Chadbourne, the president, to attend the funeral of Philip Elting, a member, who formerly was Collector of the Port of New York, was announced yesterday. The service will be held today at 3:30 P.M. in Mr. Elting's home, 106 Maiden Lane, Kingston, N.Y.

SEABRIGHT, N. J., July 22 -- After the lull of opening day the velvet turf of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club was alive with fast and exciting competition from morning to evening today as the ranking men and women tennis players of the country went into action in the fifty-fourth annual invitation tournament.

TOKYO, July 22 -- At the urgent request of Vice Admiral Teijiro Toyoda, Foreign Minister and Minister of Overseas Affairs, Kumataro Honda, ranking Japanese diplomat, who resigned as Ambassador to Nanking when Yosuke Matsuoka left the Foreign Ministry, has withdrawn his resignation and will return to his post around Aug. 10.
Reports that Dutch workers staged a widespread strike two months ago in protest against the regulations imposed by the German authorities in occupation of the country were received here yesterday.

Selling above 17 cents a pound for the first time since early in 1930, the prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday at net gains of 14 to 16 points. Buying by the trade and speculative sources which absorbed realizing kept the market moving upward.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The problem created by "leaks" of secret information througrh Congressional channels is worth thinking about, President Roosevelt said at his press conference this afternoon.

PITTSBURGH, July 22 (AP) -- The Pirates opened a home stand today by nosing out the Phillies, 4 -- 3, in a game which developed into a tight pitchers' battle after starting out as a free-swinging contest.

Working overtime under floodlights at night as well as at full speed during the day, building mechanics are speeding construction of the city's first defense housing project within a stone's throw of the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

Frank A. Erickson, the wealthy bookmaker whom Mayor La Guardia has been trying: to run out of New York City for several years, was accused of atrocious assault and battery with intent to kill in a complaint signed yesterday by Milton F. Untermeyer, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, who also named two women as accessories to the alleged attack.

After escaping injury in a spectacular spill in the previous race, Don Meade came on to complete a double by riding Mrs. G.C. Winfrey's Hard Jester home to capture the featured $2,500 Fordham Purse at Empire City yesterday.

Gene McCann, who has answered to the title of "Boy Wonder of Wall Street," although he is now 47 years old, was convicted of mail fraud yesterday and quickly sentenced to six years in prison, with fines totaling $600.

BERLIN, July 22 -- The Germans asserted officially today that the Russians no longer had a continuous line of defense against invasion. German and allied forces were said by the Supreme Command to have split the Soviet defensive front and separated the Russian Armies into disconnected groups that no longer appeared to operate under a unified central command.

Members of the public utility staff of the Securities and Ex-change Commission have been conducting at the regional office of the commission here for several days an inquiry into the operation of the compulsory competitive bidding rule for public utility securities which the SEC put into effect early in May.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- An international mechanism that will serve as an "adequate instrumentality" for restoring law and order and assuring enduring peace after the close of the present war was proposed by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, in an address today at the dedication of the new wing of the Norwegian Legation.

Representatives Doughton and Cooper give a lame reason for retention by the House Ways and Means Committee of the proposed provision compelling married couples to file a single joint income tax return. They say, in effect, that if this provision were not adopted the committee would either have to raise surtax rates or broaden the income tax base to make up the difference in revenue.

All that 1,600 hat buyers of the nation had to remember last night was "backward, turn backward," as they drifted out of the Hotel Astor's grand ballroom and the style promenade of the Millinery Stabilization Commission. For the phrase aptly incorporates a major motif of feminine headgear for Fall and Winter -- a season destined for sharp departures in this phase of fashion.
Dakar, on the shoulder of West Africa, has assumed increased importance in recent months in light of reports of increasing German influence there.
PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (AP) -- Exploding five hits for all of their runs in the second inning, the Athletics opened their home stand today with a 4-to-l victory over the Browns.
Moscow, July 22 (AP) -- Today's communique contained the following:

Melio Bettina, Beacon (N.Y.) boxer who once held the world light heavyweight championship, defeated Clarence (Red) Burman of Baltimore in the main bout of ten rounds at Ebbets Field last night. Performing before 10,647 spectators, who paid $20,409, Bettina scored a surprisingly easy triumph over the Maryland fighter, and the decision in his favor was unanimous.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The United States was believed ready tonight to impose stern economic restrictions upon Japan as word reached high government authorities that Japan would move into Indo-China, if she had not already done so.
TOKYO, July 22 (AP) -- Thousands in Japan were temporarily homeless and thirty-five were dead from a typhoon that lashed portions of the islands today in the wake of week-long rains.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Two of the most frequent statements made to the American people by their public men are: United States representatives are invariably out-traded in international conferences or negotiations; even the public propaganda of the authoritarian states is always deadly in its effect here and requires persistent countering.

The Actors Equity Council yesterday sanctioned the appearance of Ingrid Bergman, foreign actress, in "Anna Christie" the week of Sept. 1 at the Maplewood (N.J.) Theatre. Margaret Webster will stage the Eugene O'Neill revival. Although the council generally frowns upon stock engagements of alien performers, it took into consideration the fact that Miss Bergman is a star, and that the employment of Equity members depended on her getting the necessary permission.

LONG BEACH, L.I, July 22 -- Long and straight-hitting Ernie Catropa of the well-known Idle-wild twin-brother professionals set a blistering pace for the field of eighty-seven golfers who started in quest of the Long Island open championship today.

Officials of commercial airlines in this country revealed last night that they would not be required to turn over to the British Government the last half of the twenty-four transport planes due for transfer to England on Aug. 1. Twelve commercial transports were turned over to the United States Government for British use by the airlines on July 1.
Active renting continues at the John Murray House, the fourteen-story and penthouse building under erection at 220 Madison Avenue, one of the reports covering residental leasing disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The War Department honored the memories today of seven Air Corps fliers by giving their names to new fields leased as part of the air expansion program.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Applications for approval of issuance of $28,000,000 of bonds and $8,500,000 of debentures by the Virginia Public Service Company, for a capital contribution of more than $4,000,000 to the concern by its parent, the Southeastern Electric and Gas Company, and for dissolution of three of the subsidiaries of Virginia Public Service, were denied today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

PITTSBURGH, July 22 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation approved today a plan to revise its capital structure and merge its two principal subsidiaries into the parent corporation. The vote was announced as 975,480 for and 42,625 against.

Reporting to stockholders for the half year ended on June 28, R.S. Reynolds, president of the Reynolds Metals Company announced consolidated earnings of $3,367,057 before provision for income and excess profits taxes. This compares with $2,061,770 for the corresponding period a year ago.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 22 -- Miss Grace Amory of the host j club carded a one-over-par 38, 37-75, to gain a four-stroke lead in the first round of the annual women's Long Island fifty-four-hole medal play championship at the Cedar Creek Club today.
MOSCOW, July 22 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique today said:

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 22 -- The four-day-old American black-list of Nazi and Fascist companies has brought confusion to American industries and merchants established in Brazil and they are suffering headaches in trying to find solution to a puzzle with which they were suddenly confronted.

LONDON, July 22 -- Harry Hopkins, United States Administrator of the lease-lend program, and Prime Minister Winston Churchill had an audience with King George today on the heels of the latest Cabinet change, which, left many here dissatisfied because nothing was done about unifying production.
LONDON, July 23 -- Great Britain's "V for Victory" war against Germany grew in momentum today.

Profit-taking peppered the stock market yesterday in the afternoon session and brought on an irregularly lower closing, but only after prices had extended the recovery movement, in the morning, to new high levels for the current up swing.

BAILEY ISLAND, Me., July 22 -- For the first time in the history of an open tuna tournament, the wind, weather, sea and tuna today conspired to make for a perfect opening for the first annual State of Maine tuna tournament. And although only four tuna have been officially weighed in thus far, two more are on their way and several were hooked and lost.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 22 -- Mrs. John Laurence Hutton gave a dinner and bridge at her Apaquogue Road residence tonight for Mrs. Clifford H. McCall. Other guests were Mrs. Delos Walker, Mrs. A. Wallace Chauncey, Mrs. Ruxton Heppenheimer, Mrs. Benjamin G. Chapman Jr., Mrs. Irving H. Taylor, Mrs. Conrado Traverso, Miss Edna Nash and Mrs. Howard Morris.
Doubleday, Doran considers a biography of Clarence Darrow by Irving Stone one of the most important titles on its large Fall list. "Clarence Darrow for the Defense," will be published Sept. 19.

New York began hitting its stride yesterday in the matter of yielding up aluminum pots, hair driers and other scrap items, but even so there were indications that the drive for the metal would have to be extended to make possible a really imposing collection.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 22 -- Enoch L. (Nucky) Johnson, testifying in his own defense, entered a categorical denial today that he had defrauded the government of $39,800 in income taxes in 1935, 1936 and 1937.
LOS ANGELES, July 22 -- Wendell L. Willkie said today that war was like a smallpox epidemic which could not be cured by slamming the windows and locking the doors of a house.

No capital in the world offers a target to the bomber as conspicuous as the Kremlin. This is a city within a city, the secret fortress of a Government which the Commissars of the People took over from the oldest and most absolute Czars. The high walls are broken by towers and turrets that jut sharply into the sky.

The late William Guggenheim, industrialist and amateur poet, left to four former showgirls his entire estate, said to be "upward of $1,000,000," it was disclosed yesterday through The United Press, and cut off his widow and son without a cent.

Georg Szell, Hungarian conductor, who has taken out first citizenship papers in this country, has been engaged as guest conductor of the New Friends of Music Orchestra for next season, I.A. Hirschmann, founder of the organization, announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 (AP) -- A coast-wide strike vote of its 6,000 members was ordered today by the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. of L., in protest against alleged, signing of foreign crews at low wages to operate Danish ships recently taken over by the government.

BERLIN, July 22 -- For the Germans, the most exciting military information of the day today was the official announcement of the "retaliatory" air raid by Reich bombing planes on Moscow. Last night's raid on the Russian capital, which began at 10 P.M. and continued until dawn, was the first since the beginning of the invasion, and thousands of explosive and incendiary bombs were dropped upon "military appointments" as well as "communications and armament centers."

NORFOLK, Va., July 22 (AP) -- Four American Red Cross nurses and a Marine corporal, rescued from an open boat in the North Atlantic by a U.S. destroyer after their ship had been torpedoed, arrived at the Norfolk Navy Yard tonight aboard a Navy transport.

NEWARK, N.J., July 22 (AP) -- Newark and Toronto split a double-header tonight. The Bears won the second contest, 7-4, after Dick Fowler had spaced four hits in the seven-inning twilight game for a 3-2 Maple Leaf triumph.

Exceedingly close bidding marked the sale yesterday of $1,720,000 of Carolina, Clinchfield Ohio Railway equipment trust certificates due in one to ten years. In a field of seven competitors Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates emerged as the successful bidders with an interest cost basis to the road of about 1.73 per cent.
Clash of Metal Citizens are reminded that the government wants only their time-worn and battle-scarred aluminum pots, and it turns out that all was for the best.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: My first reaction to the request of the President to extend the period of service for selectees was one of chagrin and then disappointment. That response, I admit, was purely emotional. After applying logic to a situation which requires it, I have been compelled to conclude that President Roosevelt faced no other course,

CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- Diminishing demand in the dressed pork market was reflected today in a weak hog market where steady to 10-cent lower values prevailed. Cattle and Spring lambs, however, were strong to higher.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Ways and Means Committee voted decisively today against the administration's request to eliminate one of the alternative methods for computing corporation excess profits taxes and added a new exemption for corporations which invest new capital.

The Bronx Express roared into the Stadium yesterday, and before the awed gaze of 45,227 fans rolled right over Bobby Feller, who attempted to flag it down. The Yankee toppled the Indians, 4 to 3, in a tense, exciting battle and thus stretched their league lead to eight games, a new high for the season.

The Army Air Corps Ferry Command, organized last month to pick up airplanes at factories throughout the nation and put them down at Atlantic Coast ports for shipment to Great Britain, made its first delivery yesterday to the Naval Air Station at Floyd Bennett Field.

Close to 200,000 applications have been filed for Treasury Department licenses under the President's proclamation of June 14, requiring them for transactions with the nationals of Continental European countries, Wilbert Ward, assistant vice president of the National City Bank of New York, told members of the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc., at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

For two hours yesterday Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was the heroine to a host of children, inspecting their boats and trains, listening to their songs, watching them at rest and then sampling their home-made chocolate nut cookies.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 22 -- Long Island Sound, or rather the air above it, played another tantalizing prank on skippers and crews out today for the third session of the Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week. For 232 craft that were out there was but a panting southeast breath to begin with, over another set of shortened courses.

BERLIN, July 22 -- United States political intriguing is today made responsible for the diplomatic impasse between the Reich and Bolivia and the incident is exploited as fresh evidence of the American determination to create United States hegemony over South America.

Jaeckel's budget shop, which is just one year old, invited the fashion press to its second birthday yesterday afternoon to inspect its second output of "inexpensive" furs. The special message that this department has to broadcast is that at a comparatively low price, that is for Jaeckel, furs can be had to which the same care in design and workmanship is given as to the luxury models.

The Federal Communications Commission opens public hearings today to determine "whether or not joint control of newspapers and radio broadcasting stations tends to result in an impairment of radio service under the standard of 'public interest, convenience and necessity.'"
NEW YORK Mrs. Briggs S. Cunningham has come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Mount Auburn, Cincinnati.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, July 23 -- While Russian troops successfully contained violent German attacks toward Leningrad on the Pskov-Porkhov line, hard fighting' suddenly developed northeast of Leningrad when combined German-Finnish forces assaulted Russian positions in the neighborhood of Petrozavodsk, on Lake Onega, it was reported today.

LONDON, July 22 (U.P.) -- Diplomatic sources reported tonight that a close relative of Queen Helen of Italy had been interned in Germany after refusing an offer from King Victor Emmanuel to become the Regent of Montenegro.
THE visitor said he was invited out to lend a hand on deck in the Larchmont Race Week on Long Island Sound and, unfortunately, he accepted.

JERSEY CITY, July 22 (AP) -- Mickey Rocco's eighteenth home run of the season broke a 4-4 deadlock in the tenth inning today and gave the Buffalo Bisons a 5-to-4 verdict over the Jersey City Giants in the fourth game of a five-game series.

In an unusual action, representatives of three Federal agencies interrogated individually yesterday the twenty-eight dismissed WPA teachers and workers, charged with disorderly conduct after picketing Mayor La Guardia's home at 1274 Fifth Avenue last Friday, when they appeared in Harlem Magistrates Court for a hearing.

New York City had last week one of its healthiest periods, with the death rate falling to the lowest point of the year, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner. The death rate for the week ended July 19 was 7.9 to 1,000 population, the best record for any single week so far this year.

ROME, July 22 -- President Roosevelt today is called Public Enemy No. 1 of the American people by the Italian press, which presents his message to Congress asking for the extension of the one-year enrollment of the United States Army as another proof of his imperialist ambitions.

"The Stars Look Down," Dr. A. J. Cronin's adaptation of his novel, will have its local premiere this morning at Loew's Criterion. The drama, produced in England and directed by Carol Reed, deals with Welsh miners and features Michael Redgrave, Margaret Lockwood and Emlyn Williams.

ST. LOUIS, July 22 -- For a time today, Erich W. Marchand of Clayton, Mo., one-time Harvard varsity player, enjoyed the lead in the finals for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation when he won his third-round game from Fred Anderson of St. Louis.
CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- The Cubs, home from a disastrous Eastern trip, celebrated their return to Wrigley Field with a 16-hit, 13-to-2 slaughter of the Braves today.

Cooperation between the public schools and the State Employment Service in obtaining jobs for high school graduates and students compelled to leave school was recommended yesterday in an interim report by the Board of Education's special committee on vocational education.

Crescent Beach at Great Kills, Staten Island, with 800 feet of water-front land and thirty-two cottages and other buildings, has been sold to Walsh Properties, Inc., through MacNaughton Greggio, Inc., brokers, in conjunction with Samuel Ginsberg.
BOSTON, July 22 (AP) -- Home runs by Ted Williams, Jimmy Foxx and Jim Tabor accounted for five tallies today as the Red Sox defeated the White Sox, 6 to 2, in the first game of the series.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- An application was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding the dissolution of the Gary Electric and Gas Company and acquisition of the assets of the Gary Heat, Light and Water Company, an operating subsidiary, by the Northern Indiana Public Service Company.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Spurred by reports of new aggressive moves by Japan in the Far East and the belief of competent authorities that the Axis is planning another thrust westward in Europe, Administration spokesmen put a "rush" order today on legislation to retain selectees, National Guardsmen and reservists in the Army for the duration of the emergency.
BERLIN, July 22 -- The Boerse was narrow and soft throughout today's session. The losses were mostly confined to limits below 2 per cent. Bremer Wolle lost 3 and Kloeckner 3.
Visitors to the Statue of Liberty seldom miss reading a bronze-in-scribed poem that, together with two dedicatory tablets, graces the second landing on which every one pauses for breath.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The House Ways and Means Committee has had the happy idea that it can raise more money by the simple device of penalizing marriage. It recommends that husband and wife should be compelled to report their incomes jointly so that by being forced to add these incomes to each other each would pay a higher rate than otherwise.

Richard M. Scammon has been forced to resign as research secretary of the University of Chicago's radio department after challenging General Robert E. Wood, chairman of the America First Committee, to a debate on the occupation of Iceland, according to charges made public here yesterday by Ulric Bell, chairman of the executive committee of Fight for Freedom, Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Immediate construction of a $70,000,000 pipeline system to carry 250,000 barrels of crude oil daily from the East Texas fields to the Eastern seaboard was urged upon the oil industry today by Harold L. Ickes, the Petroleum Coordinator, just after Congress completed action on the bill authorizing Federal aid for private pipeline building.

LONDON, Wednesday, July 23 -- Shipyards on the River Seine a Le Trait, near Rouen, France were bombed yesterday by British Blenheim aircraft in an air offensive that has been kept up at undiminished pace, the Air Ministry stated.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The population of the United States will grow, but at a steadily decreasing rate, until 1980 or 1985, after which a decline in numbers will begin, according to Census Bureau estimates reported today by J.C. Capt, director.

WHITE PLAINS. N.Y., July 22 -- Mrs. Walter Reynolds, the home-club champion, playing superb golf despite an inability to hit her usual long drives, scored 42, 39-81 at the Knollwood Country Club in the second round of the women's Westchester and Fairfield open golf championship today and took a two-stroke lead at 87, 81-168 in the twelfth annual fifty-four-hole medal-play event for the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy.

The Mellon Securities Corporation headed a large group of investment firms that submitted yesterday the only bids for $135,000,000 of Commonwealth of Pennsylvania 1 1/2 per cent tax-anticipation notes. Up to a late hour last night there had been no official award of the obligation.

Additional contributions to the Greater New York Fund and progress in the social gains made by this agency were reported at a luncheon held yesterday in the Hotel Astor in honor of James A. Farley, chairman of the campaign for the $5,000,000 fund.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Jesse H. Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, disclosed at his press conference today that the United States had offered, as an offset to Soviet purchases of machine tools and war materials here, to buy substantial amounts of strategic materials from Russia.

Millinery merchants have an opportunity to develop their largest sales volume in history this Fall, according to Joseph A. Monaghan, merchandising manager of the Emporium, San Francisco. He told more than 100 millinery buyers and merchandise managers at a clinic sponsored by the Millinery Merchandising Executives Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday that the only way of capitalising upon their opportunity for record sales was to use imagination and skill in both buying and selling.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 23 -- Scores of persons were killed and wounded and several houses, a hospital and a school were heavily damaged when a strong force of German bombers attacked this Soviet capital last night for the second night in succession, it was reported today.

A long shot that "paid all right," according to the man who backed it, was described yesterday morning in the offices Harry Winston, 620 Fifth Avenue, who bought for $700,000 the third largest diamond ever found, the Presidente Vargas, and took a chance of losing a fortune if the process of dividing it into stones of salable size should go wrong.

BERLIN, July 22 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's message to Congress yesterday and Bolivia's ouster of the German Minister were coupled by authorized spokesmen and the German press today as new proof that "Roosevelt is planfully proceeding against the Axis and Europe, and in so doing is endeavoring to make South American States his stooges."

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Roosevelt made it plain today that defense agencies are taking steps to prevent mass unemployment resulting from a sharp curtailment in the production of passenger automobiles, which some defense officials believe eventually may exceed even the 50 per cent reduction tentatively set by Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 23 (U.P) -- German forces, after having been stalled for days by bitter Russian resistance in the Ukrainian region, have driven to the area of Zhitomir, only eighty miles south-west of Kiev, the Red Army acknowledged today.

MOSCOW, July 22 -- The first month of the Russian war with Adolf Hitler's Germany has ended. During these last thirty days hundreds of thousands of persons have been annihilated, millions have been crippled, millions orphaned and made homeless.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The population of the United States will grow, but at a steadily decreasing rate, until 1980 or 1985, after which a decline in numbers will begin, according to Census Bureau estimates reported today by J.C. Capt, director.

WHITE PLAINS. N.Y., July 22 -- Mrs. Walter Reynolds, the home-club champion, playing superb golf despite an inability to hit her usual long drives, scored 42, 39-81 at the Knollwood Country Club in the second round of the women's Westchester and Fairfield open golf championship today and took a two-stroke lead at 87, 81-168 in the twelfth annual fifty-four-hole medal-play event for the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy.

Earnings of the Republic Steel Corporation and its subsidiaries for the first six months of this year were more than double those of the corresponding period of 1940, it was announced yesterday. The net profit amounted to $13,618,716, equal, after dividend requirements on the preferred and prior preference stocks, to $2.22 a share on 5,670,628 common shares.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Maritime Commission called today three separate conferences to meet here to determine a proper "national uniform basis for payment of war bonuses to officers and crews of American merchant ships."

American armed forces are in Iceland with the express purpose of replacing British forces and the latter will be withdrawn when United States soldiers are there in sufficient strength to warrant it, Thor Thors, Icelandic Consul General in New York, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Administration is trying to prevent the crippling of power plants, railroads and industries in Latin America by establishing a new committee to facilitate the export of raw materials and prefabricated goods to Mexico, Brazil, Argentina, Costa Rica and several other Latin-American countries.

Declaring that Mayor La Guardia's broadcast over WNYC, the city station, constituted the "most overworked commercial on the air today," Vice Chairman Joseph T. Sharkey of the City Council criticized the Mayor and his third-term backers yesterday for using the city station to announce his candidacy at the Fall election.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 22. -- After several weeks of conferences RKO and Orson Welles today announced the program for the actor-writer-producer-director for the new season.
LONDON, July 22 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

First Step Although nobody at the New York Stock Exchange will speak of the plan of reorganization as if its passage were a foregone conclusion, the fact remains that few in Wall Street doubt that it will be approved by the membership.

AUGUSTA, Me., July 22 -- America would not tolerate any invasion by dictatorial powers which would interfere with its territorial rights or institutional privileges, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia of New York, National Director of Civilian Defense, declared here today.

BERLIN, July 22 (U.P.) -- A picture that the German press had promised would "tear the lid right off Roosevelt" turned out tonight to show the President of the United States sitting amid a group of men all wearing Masonic aprons.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 22 -- A New Jersey player, Miss Carolyn Cassidy of Crestmont, paced a field of 120 players to take low gross honors in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament over the long, rolling Lakeville Club course today.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 22 -- Polo players preparing for the national twenty-goal championship, which is scheduled to get under way at the Meadow Brook Club this week, saw action in a pair of round-robins on the J.S. Phipps estate today. G. H. (Pete) Bostwick's Blue team and Devereux Milburn's Reds registered victories.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Rear Admiral John H. Towers told the House Naval Affairs Committee today that a program for production of 6,000 four-engine bombers threatened to disrupt other defense plans, including the Navy's aviation and ordnance programs and the Army's general aviation schedules.

By the time we are spending thirty-six billion dollars a year for defense we shall need fully a hundred billion kilowatt-hours a year simply to fill Army and Navy orders. This means a considerable addition to the amount of power normally required. To find that power we must enlarge our existing power plants and build new ones.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Wheat borrowed sufficient strength today from cotton and securities to sell at somewhat higher prices. There was no material pressure in the way of hedging and while some of the local operators took the buying side they were unable to bring about more than a moderate upturn, part of which was lost later on continued heaviness in the spot market.

The elimination of a "bottle-neck" that had caused a shortage in a product vitally important in the production of steel and copper was announced yesterday for the Department of Justice. This was said to be the result achieved when four corporations and seven individuals failed to contest charges of violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act and submitted to fines totaling $76,500.

The vacant plot 85 by 120 feet at the northeast corner of Railroad Avenue and Third Street, Great Neck, L.I., was sold by the Gilerest Realty Corporation to the Lenaul Corporation and will be improved with a one-story taxpayer containing six stores.
The sale of one private residence and the leasing of another on the East Side were announced yesterday by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.

Approval by the board of governors of the reorganization plan of the New York Stock Exchange is expected today. If this is voted the matter will be placed before the membership in the form of constitutional amendments designed to take effect on Sept. 30.

The Long Island Lighting Company will file shortly with the Public Service Commission an application for approval of a refinancing program involving approximately $41,000,000, Edward F. Barrett, president of the concern, announced yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 22 -- Eliminating verbiage from the communiques issued by both sides, neutral observers point out today that Russian resistance seems as stubborn as ever and that in any case it compels the German High Command to prepare a succession of manoeuvres to overcome it.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A prediction that the House Military Affairs Committee would approve a Congressional resolution proclaiming a national emergency was made today' by Chairman May after the committee had heard General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, describe in secret session the danger, to the United States and Western Hemisphere in the present international situation.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Branding the proceedings illegal, the American Newspaper Publishers Association told the Federal Communications Commission today that four subpoenaed executives in the newspaper field would refuse to appear as witnesses in the commission's investigation of newspaper ownership of radio stations.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Although trading was slow and uneven, prices of hogs were steady to 15 cents higher today, reflecting a reducteion in receipts. Cattle prices were strong, but Spring lambs closed mostly steady, with some lower.

LOS ANGELES, July 23 -- Asserting that critics of the defense program were right in saying that it was in danger and that Washington was "in confusion," Wendell L. Willkie called on the American people tonight to urge their representatives in Congress "to make the wheels go around, and to make them, go around faster than anybody thought they could go around."
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The War Departement released the following orders today, dated July 21:

ST. LOUIS, July 23 -- The best showing made so far against Reuben Fine, open champion of the United States Chess Federation, was by Bruno Schmidt of Detroit, who, while holding him to a draw in the last round of the preliminaries, had him at a disadvantage for a considerable time due to a misstep in the opening.

Governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to abolish the committee system, cut the board to twenty-five members from thirty-two, and change the method of electing a nominating committee. The proposed changes will be submitted today to the membership in the form of amendments to the constitution.

The governing board of the Theatre Authority will meet Tuesday to decide whether to change its system of operation or to appeal a recent ruling of the Treasury Department that if the Authority received a percentage of the receipts from benefit performances the sponsors of such performances would have to pay the Federal amusement tax.

BERLIN, July 23 -- Germany's armed forces are carrying out their operations against the Russians with success on all fronts, according to the information released in Berlin today for the consumption of the foreign press.

The last remaining untenanted store in the Hotel Savoy Plaza, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, has been leased for a gown shop by Frances Kalb, who is moving from 270 Park Avenue when extensive alterations in the new quarters are completed.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 23 -- A party in 1940 to the most brilliant final-round match seen here in many years when he four times stood within a stroke of victor over Robert Riggs, Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., today was eliminated in the third round of the fifty-fourth invitation tennis tournament of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The new common stock which American Power and Light proposes to create under its integration plan will be issued to holders of the company's present $5 and $6 preferred stocks on a share for share basis.

LONDON, July 23 (AP) -- Singapore and other British Pacific outposts were reported tonight to have been "forewarned and forearmed" with new R.A.F. contingents to meet a Far-Eastern climax, expected here to arise within twenty-four hours from Japanese demands on French Indo-China.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Canadian Government has adopted a gasoline and lubricant conservation, measure banning the sale, delivery and distribution of these items to motorists between 7 P.M. and 7 A.M. weekdays and Sundays.

CINCINNATI, July 23 -- The Dodgers aren't magicians, but after tonight they may be rated as the leading puzzle-solvers of the league. For they beat Elmer Riddle, coming from behind to inflict upon that masterly young Cincinnati hurler his first defeat of the campaign, and thereby remained tied with the Cardinals for first place.

LONDON, July 23 (U.P.) -- Well-informed financiers have received an intimation that preparations are under way to freeze Japanese assets in the United States and Britain. It was not revealed whether the measure would be applied in any case or as an eventual reprisal against Japan because of her southward move in Indo-China.

VICHY, France, July 23 -- France has accepted "in principle" Japanese demands for virtually complete military control of French Indo-China to prevent that rich Asiatic colony from falling under British domination, it was said here tonight.
Stock brokers, bankers and executives of business concerns are listed among the latest renters of apartments in the city. Leasing was heavy along the upper East Side.

TOKYO, July 23 -- After a year of labor, the Ministry of Education has just compiled a new textbook entitled "The Way of the Subjects of the Emperor" that is intended for distribution to the high schools and colleges as well as to the public generally.

Speaking at Los Angeles yesterday, Mr. Willkie spiked the fallacy that the debate now going on in this country "is somehow between a peace party and a war party." The logic of the case which he presented at the bar of public opinion is compelling. It may be indicated by a few excerpts:

The Republican leaders of four of the five counties in the city met yesterday at the National Republican Club, but withheld, for the time being, any statement on Mayor La Guardia's candidacy for re-election.

Mixed Time Figures? London is now strongly inclined to believe that an invasion of the British islands this year is out of the question, regardless of the outcome of the fighting in Russia. But if Hitler postpones his final drive until next Spring, it means three years of a war that began in September, 1939.

CHUNGKING, China, Thursday, July 24 -- A series of Japanese actions, foreshadowing major Japanese military activities in Southern Asia within the next day or two, was revealed by Admiral Yang Hsuan-chieng, head of the intelligence section of the Chinese National Military Council, at a special press conference here yesterday.

MOSCOW, July 23 (U.P.) -- The Soviet Government asserted today that it possessed proof that Germany, foreseeing the "inevitable failure" of her blitzkreig tactics, was secretly preparing to launch massive poison gas attacks against the Red Army.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 23 -- Boys and girls under eighteen took over Larchmont Race Week for their sixteenth annual junior regatta today and, except for the number of starters and the size of the sailors, it wasn't much different than when their elders were in charge on Monday and Tuesday.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 23 -- Frank A. Erickson, wealthy New York bookmaker, appeared at the Morris County Court House here at 4 o'clock this afternoon to surrender to arrest on the charge of atrocious assault and battery with intent to kill, preferred against him on Tuesday by Milton F. Untermeyer, 62-year-old member of the New York Stock Exchange.

Most of the properties figuring in yesterday's Bronx transactions were residential buildings, including apartment houses and smaller dwelling units. One plot of vacant land near the Parkchester housing group was taken for improvement with a synagogue, and another parcel of two tenements will giva way to a laundry building.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- In an effort to prevent profiteering in rents in national defense areas, the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply reported today that Fair Rent Committees had been organized in twenty-one cities, and urged the creation of others where abuses appeared.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 23 -- "What is the eagerness to hand over this country to the United States on the pretext of financial help that never will come?" Major Elias Belmonte, alleged pro-Nazi leader of Bolivia, asked in a letter, dated Berlin, June 9, and addressed to Ernest Wendler, German Minister, who was expelled yesterday j from Bolivia.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- William S. Knudsen, OPM director general, Governor Van Waggoner of Michigan and R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, C.I.O., warned today that an arbitrary, sudden cut of 50 per cent in the rate of automobile production would throw thousands of auto makers out of work.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Engineers Public Service Company of New York, the last of the big holding company systems to hold out against geographical integration under the "death sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, was ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to divest itself within one year of its interest in the Puget Sound Power and Light Company and its subsidiaries and the Key West Electric Company.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 23 -- Opposition of the Catholic Church to totalitarianism, which was "condemned in principle" as long ago as 1864 by Pope Pius IX, was stressed today at the Conference on Religion in the "World at Harvard Summer School by the Rev. Michael J. Ahern of Weston College.

Trading in locally dressed fresh meats yesterday was fair to good on most classes of traefer meats. Demand for kosher beef and lamb was slow and kosher veal only fair. Prices on kosher veal, lamb and steer beef were about steady. Pork cuts steady, steer beef hinds and ribs were strong to 50 cents higher, with other major cuts strong to mostly higher.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 23 -- A team which was not conceded a look-in when the tournament got under way a month ago, rode into the final of the Meadow Brook Club's annual twenty-goal polo championship on Cochran Field today by turning back Aknusti, 12 to 8, in a play-off to decide the Brook League victor.

Declaring that if the people permit the President and the War Department to keep trainees indefinitely under arms this country soon will be engaged in an aggressive war in another hemisphere, Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, denounced yesterday what he he called "a crab-wise approach to war."

Credit Control With the seeds of inilation -- as measured by rising prices -- already well sprouted, there is strong indication that important steps will be taken soon by the fiscal authorities to tighten the_strings of credit control, it was Intimated in high banking quarters yesterday.

While sufficient time has not elapsed for a conclusive test of consumer reaction to wool goods labeling, the apparent lack of interest by the public in such labels is coming as a surprise to both national advertisers and retailers. In the eight days in which a variety of wool products have been labeled, there has been little comment by consumers and few questions have been asked of store clerks.
As an economy measure, the Board of Education voted yesterday to dismiss 106 of the 156 swimming teachers in the New York City school system, at a saving of $150,000 to $200,000 annually.

LONDON, July 23 -- Though British foreign policy continues to cling to the notion that what Japan does in the Far East will be determined by what happens in Europe, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today found significance in the Japanese press campaign, against Britain.

BERLIN, Thursday, July 24 (U.P.) -- A German military spokesman acknowledged last night that the German spearheads pointed at Moscow and Leningrad were constantly compelled to fight off "extremely ferocious Soviet counterattacks" launched by masses of fresh troops.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- General Marshall was reported tonight to have told the House Military Affairs Committee that three South American nations are faced with possible Nazi uprisings.

Growing caution among traders as the Far Eastern, situation became more critical, although the market was without definite news as to when or where the expected outbreak of new hostilities would occur, caused a decline in volume of trading to one-half the total of Tuesday and further realizing in the industrial issues.

Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga is scheduled to hear today argument on a motion filed by defendants to dismiss a stockholder's derivative action in behalf of the United States Rubber Company to recover more than $6,000,000 in assets allegedly wasted by officers and directors of the concern.

The six-family apartment house, 100 by 100 feet, at 1211 Frisco Street, adjoining Mott Avenue, in Far Rockaway, Queens, has been sold by Rose, Bert and Donald Hauser to the Abgert Realty Corporation in a transaction negotiated by the Lewis H. May Company, brokers.

In the House of Representatives a few days ago a bill establishing the dangerous principle of general pensions for World War veterans was passed in cavalier fashion, without debate and without even a record vote, at a time when members had been assured that no important legislation would be acted upon.

Supreme Court Justice Charles V. Froessel in Brooklyn dismissed yesterday a derivative suit brought by minority stockholders of R. Hoe Co. to recover $3,000,000 from the Guaranty Trust Company of New York and others in connection with various actions by the officers, directors and bankers of R. Hoe Co. concerning the financial difficulties of the company in recent years.

A study of the loan-cotton situation made by the Cotton Exchange here shows that as of May 31, 1941, the Commodity Credit Corporation held 6,126,482 bales of cotton from the 1934 and 1937 loans. Although there are no figures available, it is understood that these stocks are composed of cotton of high average quality.

The National Broadcasting Company's new short-wave listening post at Bellmore, L.I., said to be the most highly developed and sensitive of its kind in the country, was dedicated yesterday afternoon at ceremonies stressing its value in the scheme of national defense.

Mrs. James Butler, widow of the late president of the Empire City Racing Association and son of the founder of the Butler chain of grocery stores, has sold her five-story town house at 55 East Eighty-second Street to Thomas Crimmins Burke, a well-known attorney, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Office of Production Management approved today proposals to increase pig iron capacity by 6,508,950 tons, the largest expansion in the history of the industry. OPM officials also stated that they were "exploring" the possibility of increasing steel ingot capacity by 15,000,000 tons.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture is considering plans, authoritative sources said today, for sale in the open market of cotton from government-owned stocks in a move designed to prevent prices from advancing to artificially high levels.

Net income of the Freeport Sulphur Company for the June Quarter this year amounted to $953,419 after all charges, including depreciation, depletion and reserve for taxes, compared with $636,578 in the similar period a year ago. These earnings are equivalent to $1.20 each on 796,380 shares of common stock, compared with 80 cents a share for the second quarter of 1940.

Awakened interest in the work of Alice Duer Miller has prompted Dodd, Mead to add to its publication list for next month an omnibus volume called "Summer Holiday," which will include two of the author's novels and three long stories.

The thirty-two-family apartment house at 741 East Third Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Frances Greenberg and Martha Fisk to Meier and Sarah Bloch for cash above a first mortgage of $72,500 held by the Bank of New York and Trust Company.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals here refused yesterday, in a 2-to-l decision, to uphold a National Labor Relations Board order directing the disestablishment of an independent union that had won a contest with a Congress of Industrial Organizations affiliate.

LONDON, July 24 -- The outcome of the Russian campaign was said by the Ministry of Economic Warfare today to be the most vital factor in Germany's labor problem. Increasing difficulties are seen bound to beset Reichfuhrer Hitler on his home front unless the energies now absorbed in fighting the Soviet Union can be released.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A three-month task of writing a defense tax bill was completed tonight by the Ways and Means Committee, and the bill will be introduced Friday for consideration by the House next week. As finally approved by the committee, the measure calls for new revenue of $3,529,200,000, which is $29,200,000 above the goal set when Secretary Morgenthau in April urged additional taxes to help finance the defense load.

Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, was taxed yesterday by Emil K. Ellis, counsel to the City Council investigating committee, with having owned a greater number of Soviet bonds than he had admitted at previous hearings.
BOSTON, July 23 (AP) -- Thorny (Lefty) Lee kept twelve Red Sox hits well scattered today while hurling his eleventh victory for the White Sox, 10 -- 4.

Trois Pistoles, French-bred son of Vatout, won a race at Empire City yesterday that he might not have captured outright on his home heath in France if horses and track could have been transported to the other side on some magic carpet. The margin was a nose, one of those scant noses which the judges use the camera to decide.

HOLYWOOD, Calif., July 23 -- British production, at a virtual standstill during recent months, will be resumed by three Hollywood studios within the next ninety days, it was announced today. Anna Neagle and Herbert Wilcox will leave for London this week to prepare an untitled story for RKO based upon the life of the late Amy Johnson, the English aviatrix.

Six factors, all of which are directly concerned with the increasingly important role of government in business, will influence business in the future, according to the survey in the August issue of Banking, official publication of the American Bankers Association.

JERSEY CITY, July 23 (AP) -- Jersey City made it three out of five in its series with Buffalo tonight, taking the fifth and final game of the series, 6 to 4. An explosive seventh frame, during which the Little Giants pushed over four counters on five hits after two were out, settled the issue.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 23 -- The usually reliable Istanbul correspondent of the newspaper Aftonbladet cites a neutral military expert just arrived there from Moscow as follows: "It is a complete error to believe that the resistance of the Russian Army could be broken in eight weeks."

CHICAGO, July 23 -- An early break in cotton caused a moderate decline in wheat futures in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today, but the break brought in support from mills, and later shorts tried to cover and found offerings light.

The recurrent question of control of returns, which trade authorities estimated yesterday cut $20,000,000 annually from sales of coats and suits in the New York wholesale market, was attacked a new yesterday by the fair trade practice committee of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board.

NEWARK, N.J., July 23 -- The failure of Federal authorities to obtain authorization from the local building inspector and the State Department of Tenement House Supervision for construction of a 300-unit defense housing project here brought the threat of legal action today from the local and State officials.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Law-suits by the United States to recover about $15,000,000 from the Swiss Bank Corporation and the Societe Suisse pour Valeurs de Metaux of Basle have been settled by a compromise payment of $2,020,769, Francis Biddle, acting Attorney General, announced today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the light of the dreams and writings of German imperialists of the past fifty years, events of the past two years seem to follow a terrifyingly simple pattern that need not have shocked the world at all! What was and still is shocking is the fact that the world -- the Anglo-Saxon world -- should not have taken Pan-Germanism more seriously.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 23 -- Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Mumford was hostess at a tea and the previews of three new exhibitions held this afternoon at the Guild Hall Galleries. Mrs. Edward H. Jewett, Mrs. Victor Harris and Mrs. N.A. Campbell were at the tea table.

Two alleged loan sharks who, about two and one-half years ago, "moved in"' on the Consolidated Edison Company building at 4 Irving Place and 125 East Fourteenth Street, late yesterday afternoon were busily dunning seme of the corporation's employes when Detective William J. Beggs of the main office division ordered them to accompany him to District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office.

New York will have three more days in which to clear its cupboards of unneeded aluminum for the benefit of the government's scrap collectors. Mayor La Guardia, who originally had wanted the job completed the first three days of this week, directed yesterday that the time limit be extended to Saturday midnight.

SALEM, N.H., July 23 (AP) -- Chuckle, a bay daughter of Haste-Tyche, who was claimed by J. Dobbs for $2,500 at Delaware, won the featured Salem Stakes for 2-year-old fillies at Rockingham Park today. Chuckle beat the favored Begda after a fine stretch duel.

As a result of discussions concluded late yesterday, stockholders of the Pathe Film Corporation will receive soon from E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. a formal offering of du Pont common stock which, at current market values, would be the equivalent of more than $15 a share, it was announced by Kenneth M. Young, president of the film concern.

ST. LOUIS, July 23 -- With four out of nine rounds of the open championship tournament of the U.S. Chess Federation disposed of, Reuben Fine of New York, victor a year ago at Dallas, leads with four straight to his credit, and appears to have laid the foundation for another triumph.

Threats of an embargo against Japanese imports brought consternation to the importing community here yesterday and aroused varied reactions in the different markets. The raw silk market advanced sharply as speculators and other traders in futures rushed to cover and actual users bought heavily in the spot market.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 23 -- Princeton captured the laurels in the seventh annual outing of the College Club of New York at the Nassau Country Club today when its five-man golf team scored 382, a new low for the tournament. The Orange and Black was led by Dr. J.T. Emert, who reeled off a 73.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 24 -- In alarm lest the reorganization of the Japanese Cabinet with the emphasis on the change of Foreign Minister should signify a change in Japanese policy, Adolf Hitler is reported to have informed Japan of the future course of world events as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Leon Henderson was called "a dangerous figure, a threat," at a Senate hearing today. Mr. Henderson was criticized by Senator Connally when he appeared before the Defense Investigating Committee for questioning about his price-fixing policies.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 23 -- Mrs. Oliver Gould Jennings entertained with a dinner and bridge this evening.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. Walt Disney's latest feature, "The Reluctant Dragon," will have its local premiere at the Palace. The picture, which is released through RKO, combines "live-action" and cartoon animation.

BERLIN, July 23 -- The Boerse opened weak today with losses between 1 and 2 per cent all along the line. A recovery set in toward noon and continued to the end with closing quotations near the top levels for the day, although in only a few cases higher than yesterday's close.

Mrs. Margaret Boyle, daughter of the late Charles C. McChord, former chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, and well known in Washington society, was held in $2,500 bail yesterday in the Felony Court for a hearing next Tuesday in the alleged theft of $54,000 in gems she had obtained on memorandum from a jeweler here.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Like the word "facilities" in the lease-lend act, the word "supplies" in the final version of the property seizure bill could be stretched to cloak an attack on the American system of free enterprise and private possession, should executive authority at any time be so disposed and the courts uphold it.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The National Defense Mediation Board made recommendations tonight for settlement of the strike at the Bendix (N.J.) plant of Air Associates, Inc., manufacturers of aircraft parts for the Army and Navy.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Representatives of three western railroads told a Senate subcommittee today that vast mineral resources throughout the West awaited development by private enterprise or defense industry.

In the cool recesses of a midtown shop, a pale, gray-blue cup-board out of some Provencal pantry swings wide the hand-painted panels of its doors to display a wealth of delicacies from hither and yon. Charming blue-and-silver boxes of specially blended coffees stand beside the small jars of chow chow and tremendous cannisters of shrimp chips from Honolulu.

VICHY, July 23 -- Although "certain military measures of a temporary character" may be taken by Japan in French Indo-China, it is utterly untrue to speak of anything: in the nature of an ultimatum -- such is the official view here today of developments in the Far East, of which it was not permissible to speak yesterday and to which it is not yet certain that the morning newspapers will refer tomorrow.

The most distinguished house-to-house canvassers ever to visit West Eleventh Street strolled down that thoroughfare yesterday. A man and a woman were taking pride in the fact that they were among the first solicitors in the Parents and Neighbors drive in the city campaign of the United Service Organizations for National Defense, Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Navy aircraft program, which has ordinarily the highest priority rating in the defense program, suffered a temporary setback when emphasis swung to the four-engined bombers now going into production for this country and Great Britain, Secretary Knox revealed today.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 23 -- A par-shattering 70, highlighted by five sparkling birdies, sent Al Brosch vaulting into the lead today in the Long Island open golf championship on the breeze-swept Lido Golf Club course as the midway mark was reached in the twentieth annual 72-hole medal-play title tourney.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., July 23 (AP) -- William N. Reynolds's Volstadt earned consideration as a Hambletonian contender by beating the Winter book favorite, Bill Gallon, in the $3,000 Richfield Trophy Trot for 3-year-olds today.

ST. LOUIS, July 23 -- For close to three hours at Sportsman's Park today, the Giants waged a desperate battle against the Cardinals in a bold bid for victory. But their attack was slow getting started, never attained the desirable maximum in power and defeat became the lot of the Terrymen, 5 to 4, in twelve nerve-tingling innings.

The American Power and Light Company, a major sub-holding unit in the 3,000,000,000 Electric Bond and Share Company system, took steps yesterday to comply with the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act by filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission a comprehensive plan of geographic integration and corporate simplification.

Japanese troop movements by sea and rail yesterday brought the Far East to a new crisis -- a crisis that was perhaps part of a worldwide "war of nerves" -- as the Vichy French accepted Japanese demands for bases in French Indo-China.

TRENTON, July 23 -- Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, who was defeated yesterday by Governor Charles Edison in the fight over compromise of the railroad tax case, still regards himself as the State Democratic "boss." He referred to himself as leader today in a bristling statement which drew from the Governor the comment that "the big wind is still blowing."
Improved earnings were reflected in the reports of three oil companies which announced results for periods ended on June 30.

The coupon rate on the proposed new issue of $15,000,000 Remington Rand, Inc. fifteen-year sinking fund debentures will be raised to 3 1/2 per cent from the 3 1/4 per cent rate filed originally by an amendment to the registration statement to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 23 -- German agents operating in Teheran, are attempting to foment disorders and inflame the Armenian population to sabotage and revolt against the present Iranian Government, promising money now and territory later for a "Greater Armenia" after the war, according to disclosures by high foreign diplomatic sources here today.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Equifox, a 4-year-old owned by Howard Wells of Lexington, Ky., won the first running of the race named for his famous sire, the $5,000 added Equipose Mile Handicap at Arlington Park today.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The program of the Federal Government for combating the shortage in motor fuels was widened in three spheres today.

LONDON, July 23 (U.P.) -- Germany's second big offensive in the battle of Russia appears to have spent its force after two weeks of tiatanic struggle with the Soviet defenders holding solidly every-where except in two sectors, where the Germans made slight advances, authoritative British quarters said today.

As visioned by the editors of fourteen consumer magazines and three mail order catalogues with fashion appeal, the typical reader of each is a chic and comely miss or matron, always faultlessly turned out whether the price tag on her "little frock" reads $1 or $200.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, July 24 -- After having met with costly checks for six consecutive days, the German Army's efforts to widen the Smolensk-Moscow drive, particularly between the Russian guard points of Soloveva and Prost, finally were abandoned yesterday in favor of "defensive preparations," Russian commentators said.

PITTSBURGH, July 23 (AP) -- With the bases filled, Vince DiMaggio's fourth-inning double was the deciding blow tonight as the Pirates defeated Philadelphia, 5 to 2, and moved to within one game of the fourth-place New York Giants.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- William S. Knudsen, director general of the Office of Production Management, stated today that the production of training planes and pursuit ships was coming along "all right," that makers of naval patrol planes were meeting a "fair schedule," but that "lots of work remains to be done" to bring the output of heavy bombers up to expectations.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 14 -- Bids will be opened in August for a new air service in the State of Maranhao on that northern coast of Brazil which just now has far greater strategic than commercial importance -- in the opinion of the United States Army, at any rate.

Consumer response to the opening of mid-Summer furniture sales in New York this week ran well ahead of last year, according to preliminary reports of department heads last night. They reported that, while sale prices were somewhat higher than those of last year on some lines, little price resistance was shown.

Sale Aids Men's Wear Men's wear trade was stimulated yesterday by the start of the first sale on Palm Beach suits in seven years. Multiple sales were frequent, but some stores were hampered by inadequate stocks. Furnishings departments were also helped by the rush of customers, and volume for the week as a whole is expected to be lifted sharply over the like 1940 period.
MOSCOW, July 23 (AP) -- The following statement was issued today by Tass, official Soviet news agency:

LONDON, Thursday, July 24 -- Despite the fact that mist restricted visibility over the Strait of Dover yesterday, the Royal Air Force spent most of the daylight hours on another widespread hunt for enemy shipping, Blenheim bombers ranging along the French coast and sinking one coastal vessel and damaging another.

BAILEY ISLAND, Me., July 23 -- Henry Strater of the Ogunquit Tuna Club once more proved that he knows how to take the local tuna, for he was high rod again today, bringing in three of the eight caught during the second day of the Maine tuna tournament.

The American Peace Mobilization, which was consistently anti-war during the life of the Soviet-Nazi pact but changed its stand soon after Hitler invaded Russia, announced yesterday the change of its name to the American People's Mobilization.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 23 -- Miss Grace Amory of the host club today added a 79 to her 75 of yesterday and practically clinched the title in the tenth annual women's Long Island medal play golf tournament at the Cedar Creek Club.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The War Department today awarded contracts totalling $94,816,299, among which was one for $16,945,430 for aircraft engines which went to the Lycoming Division of Aviation Manufacturing Corporation.

Trade rivalry between the United States and Germany had no part in pushing Germany into the war no matter how much the Reich would like people to accept such a theory, Franklin Johnston, editor of The American Exporter, told the Kiwanis Club's weekly luncheon meeting in the Hotel Mc-Alpin yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Announcements by isolationist newspapers and committees that the result of the polls they have conducted show 70 or 80 per cent of the American people opposed to war are of little value. The surveys so carefully conducted by Dr. Gallup prove that the American people from the beginning of the war have wanted to do two contradictory things.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (AP)-- The Athletics nosed out the Browns, 5 to 4, tonight with the aid of Frankie Hayes's homer in the sixth with one on base. John Berardino hit a home run for St. Louis with one aboard in the seventh.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Dick Errickson pitched the Braves to a seven-hit 6-to-1 victory over the Cubs today to even their series at one game each.

The House Ways and Means Committee has shown courage, and much greater wisdom than the President and his Treasury advisers, in rejecting the Administration's recommendation to delete the average earnings method of computing corporation excess profits. This would have forced corporations to compute their tax liability in relation to the percentage they earned on invested capital.

The ominous rumblings in the Far East and the thunder of clashing armies in Russia should not drown out the important statement of Acting Secretary of State Summer Welles on American war aims. The time, the place and the definiteness of this declaration give it extraordinary significance.
BERLIN, July 23 (AP) -- The German High Command communique "from the Fuehrer's Headquarters" said:

Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange suffered yesterday the widest break in a month, following a four-day upward sweep which had established gains of more than a cent a pound and carried the 1942 deliveries above 17 cents level for the first time since early in 1930.

The American Clipper arrived from Lisbon early yesterday morning carrying twenty-four transatlantic passengers, including seven United States, British and Canadian diplomatic and defense officials, and twenty-six passengers from Bermuda.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Dutch Leonard scattered Detroit's nine hits tonight, while Washington bunched its blows off Buck Newsom to defeat the Tigers, 6 -- 1 before a crowd of 17,000. It was the Senators' second straight victory over the 1940 American League champions.

Minneapolis, Minn., will enter the market on Aug. 12 with $1,446,000 of public relief and permanent improvement bonds for which bidders are to name the rate of interest. The bonds, dated Sept. 1, 1941, are to mature on Sept. 1, 1942 to 1961.
