The three-masted auxiliary schooner Vema, formerly one of the largest and most luxurious American yachts, which was turned over to the United States Maritime Com- mission by her owner, Georg Unger Vetlesen of 1 Beekman Place, for $1 on Feb. 18, last, was put into commission yesterday for use as a training vessel attached to Hoffman Island in the Lower Bay.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I believe that graduates of the old Roxbury Latin School, founded in 1645, will be gratified in case THE TIMES corrects its statement and gives credit to "old Roxbury" as the school which the late George Lyman Kittredge attended and from which, he was graduated to later honors.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We read with interest in THE TIMES of July 17 that Professor Carle C. Zimmerman of Harvard called upon patriotic Americans to have more children and recommended an average of four children to the family.
Sales activity at near-by lake communities continued active last week; according to brokers and developers specializing in that type of property.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: IT seems rather petty to continue a dispute for so long at the expense of the helpless reading public, but I feel that Mr. Burgess, in his reply to my letter of June 29, is himself guilty of what he, perhaps justly, accused me: "creating a straw man to knock down."

The recent introduction of a new race of iris, known as Fall-bloomers, rebloomers or remontants, which flower in the Spring and again in Autumn, marks a great forward step in the development of this flower. The Fall-blooming iris blossom early, when the Miniature or Dwarf Iris are in full flower, and produce another crop of flowers in September and October, even continuing on into November unless cut down by heavy frosts.
Jack Dempsey is slated to appear in the role of judge at he fourth annual Wildwood Kennel Club show to be held at the McGregor Golf Club in Saratoga Springs on Sunday, Aug. 17.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- French Indo-China is France's largest and most important overseas possession, the Department of Commerce said this week.

DICKENS, Priestley, Link-later and many others have written novels about America after a brief visit. Kafka has written a novel about America without even having seen it. When he began it, in 1913, he bad met no Americans and knew little English.

LONDON, July 26 (AP) -- Russia now has fallen within the scope of the United States policy of supplying war materials to the Allies "wherever democracies are fighting Hitler," informed quarters declared today, and Russia's needs have been outlined from Washington.

MOSCOW, Sunday, July 27 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau reported today that two German infantry divisions had been crushed in the Smolensk zone, where the Red Army and Air Force apparently have held the German invaders in bloody combat for eleven days.

Central Park, its sidewalks ringing with roller-skates, its leaves dusted with Summer heat, is the scene of Marjorie Fischer's new story which is in the same happy vein as "Street Fair." The Park was Eddie's refuge when he had to take care of Sammie.

THE first official report of what South America thinks of the American Ballet Caravan has now been received from Lincoln Kirstein, the director of the company. Based on admittedly incomplete returns, it nevertheless augurs well for the success of the tour itself and for the great improvement in cultural relations between the two continents.

LISBON, Portugal, July 26 (AP) -- Prince Carl of Sweden and Frederick A. Sterling, United States Minister to Stockholm, sailed unexpectedly aboard the United States Navy transport West Point which started homeward tonight with American consular officials expelled from Axis and Axis-occupied countries.

Realty trading in Manhattan has reached the highest degree of activity for a Summer market in several years and is featured by sales of properties by institutions which find an opportunity to reduce their portfolios, although the selling is on terms considerably less satisfactory than would be expected under normal conditions.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, July 15 -- It is said here that when Dr. Getulio Vargas was Governor of his native State of Rio Grande do Sul and planned his revolution in 1930, two of his four secretaries were let into the secret while the two others were not.

ANNOUNCEMENTS of the programs that Dmitri Mitropoulos will give next season in this city with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra include a special concert of music by Ferruccio Busoni. The program will be given by three artists, two pupils of that master, one of them his devoted proponent, as a memorial observance taking place seventy-five years after the composer was born.

TROY, N.Y., July 26 -- Fighting a game that was of the losing kind rather than the winning and passing up several opportunities that would have made things much easier for him, Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie today captured his fourth New York State amateur championship, waging an uphill battle to beat Tommy Pierce, 22year-old Vermonter who belongs to the Troy Country Club, by 1 up in the thirty-six-hole final.

CARROTS AND "A" -- Carrots and alfalfa are vast sources of vitamin A for any national emergency, reports Dr. Harold M. Barnett of the Barnett Laboratories, Long Beach, Calif., to the American Chemical Society. Vitamin A is essential to normal vision.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP) -- The Tigers snapped their eight-game losing streak with a 4-to-2 triumph today over the Athletics, who tossed away a chance to gain a virtual tie with Chicago for fourth place. It was the first defeat in six games for Philadelphia.

MRS. FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT confesses to only one foreboding about American women now mobilizing for defense activities. She is fearful of the spread of a Sam Browne belt complex and the flimflam it symbolizes.

ZAMBOANGA, P.I. -- In area Zamboanga is legally the biggest city in the world. But it doesn't look it as your inter-island steamer drifts past this palm-fringed spread of coastal villages on the Sulu Sea. A Mohammedan community in the Southern Philippines, it has a total area of 1,059 square miles, compared with New York's 310 square miles, Tokyo's 833 square miles, London's 699, Los Angeles's 442.5 and Berlin's 348 square miles.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 26 -- Creation of the Princeton Archives of American Civilization in the Princeton University Library was announced today by Julian P. Boyd, librarian. The purpose of the new project is the collection and preservation of all forms of records relating to all important aspects of American civilization.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, July 27 (AP) -- An extremist group among Japanese Army and Navy officers, putting their heads together in non-stop conferences, was known today to be urging seizure of Shanghai's entire International Settlement.

MEXICO CITY -- One of the most effective advertisements in America is that on a billboard set up beside a transcontinental highway in Arizona. Timed to catch the eye of the motorist when the heat and distance have his spirits at their lowest ebb, it depicts a happy traveler by train enjoying a cooling highball in an air-cooled parlor car while he watches the Arizona desert slip by, and it says simply:

THE new seventeen-car streamliner City of San Francisco left Chicago last night on its inaugural trip to San Francisco and on Aug. 3 the new City of Los Angeles, also a seventeen-car train, will be placed in service. Addition of these trains provides on these routes 39 3/4-hour service every three days between Chicago and California's two largest cities.

German foreign indebtedness before the outbreak of the war was so considerable that sufficient funds would not have been availabue for the purchase of raw materials and for other purposes which the "freezing" orders of the United States aimed to frustrate had measures not been taken to evade payment of the debts, according to Evsey S. Rabinowitch, international lawyer.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 26 -- Creation of the Princeton Archives of American Civilization in the Princeton University Library was announced today by Julian P. Boyd, librarian. The purpose of the new project is the collection and preservation of all forms of records relating to all important aspects of American civilization.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, July 27 (AP) -- An extremist group among Japanese Army and Navy officers, putting their heads together in non-stop conferences, was known today to be urging seizure of Shanghai's entire International Settlement.
More sympathetic consideration on the part of assessors toward older types of improved realty is urged by William J. Demorest, executive vice president of Wm. A. White Sons.
MAX EASTMAN is the author of a little pamphlet entitled "A Letter to Americans," which every American would do well to read and ponder. The gist of it is contained in the following paragraph:

THE aim of this book, says the author in his introduction, is to "show the average American what France was like during the seventy years she was a democracy." And the means used, Richard Walden Hale Jr. explains, is to "try to see the French as they saw themselves," by looking at the French Parlialiament, which he terms the "collective mind of the nation."

ONE wonders now as to the altitude of the eyebrows that went up during the last few years when Sunday supplement writers depicted gliders carrying all sorts of invading troops. Or even of those that climbed toward the crown of the head when Prime Minister Winston Churchill warned the English last Winter that the Germans might use troop-carrying gliders for an invasion stab.
ATLANTA, Ga., July 26 -- To the question, "What is Talmadge up to?", two contradictory answers are available.

Or even of those that climbed toward the crown of the head when Prime Minister Winston Churchill warned the English last Winter that the Germans might use troop-carrying gliders for an invasion stab.

PROKOFIEFF has written a Sixth piano sonata and Vladimir Horowitz is going to introduce it in this country next season. The score came through the mails from Russia about a fortnight ago. It was sent without comment by the composer himself to his friend Horace Parmalee of Columbia Concerts Corporation.

THERE will be no test of proposed revisions in the contract bridge laws at the coming national tournament at Asbury Park, N.J. According to William E. McKenney, secretary of the American Contract Bridge League and chairman, of the national laws commission, there is no necessity for an immediate test, as revised laws will not be published this year in any event.

A foretaste of what may happen to small retail dealers, who in the past have consistently flouted the requests of manufacturers on price maintenance and other trade practices, was given last week when one radio manufacturer dropped some 250 accounts prior to instituting a strict price maintenance program.
BAY HEAD, N.J., July 26 -- Racing activity on Barnegat Bay reached an all-season high today as hundreds of Jersey coast yachtsmen from Beach Haven to Bay Head gathered here for a week-end of sailing.

The freighter Stella Lykes, which is to be delivered by the Bethlehem Steel Company, Mariner's Harbor, S.I., to the Lykes Brothers Steamship Company of New Orleans on Wednesday, will be the hundredth ship turned over to an operator in the Maritime Commission's 500-ship long-range building program.

Since Nazi Germany began its invasion of Soviet Russia last month, there has been a complete reversal of the Communist party line in this country regarding the war, which has made itself felt not only in the pronouncements of the Communist party of America itself, but also in those of various organizations that have been called Communist "front" or "transmission belt" groups.

The number of open-market sales of Manhattan real estate recorded during June was slightly higher than in May and above the figure for the same month last year, according to the monthly sales report of the Real Estate Board of New York.

IN attempting the neat trick of pulling twenty-six different kinds of radio drama out of his creative hat, the ambitious Norman Corwin next will turn for inspiration to the Old Testament, from which he plans to adopt a trilogy.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 26 -- Miss Elizabeth Carpenter Frazer, daugh- ter of Persifor Frazer 3d, of this place and Philadelphia, and of Mrs. Glendinning Frazer of Chestnut Hill, Pa., was formally introduced to society tonight at a dance given by her father and stepmother at Oakwood, their villa here on Narragansett Avenue.

THIS is a book about a great American river that has been, and is, rarely referred to except with the aid of superlatives. Its present chronicler has so steeped herself in its history, topography and quality as to write of it as something lived with, part of herself, so intimately known that hyperbole is out of the question.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Army's first organized force of air-transported landing troops, a special trained battalion available for any hemisphere defense emergency, is being formed in the Panama Canal Zone.

WASHINGTON. MORE than eight years ago a stocky ex-captain of infantry with a good job, a family and a mortgage took a two-year leave and a cut in salary to help build up a new organization. The two-year leave lengthened to a permanent absence, and today Stephen Early, secretary to President Roosevelt, is almost as much of a fixture in the Administration as is the President himself.

Real estate boards in various parts of the country have pledged through the National Association of Real Estate Boards their aid and cooperation to the Council of National Defense in guarding against undue rent increases in defense areas.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The legal prohibition against the appearance of children in theatrical productions in Washington will be lifted if a bill which the House of Representatives passed on July 14 and sent to the Senate, becomes law.

"A fundamental change in the method of applying the rental subsidy granted by the Federal Government through the United States Housing Authority" is recommended in a report entitled "Graded Versus Proportional Rents in Public Housing" prepared by Beatrice Greenfield Rosahn in cooperation with the committee on housing management of the Citizens Housing Council.

THE third in the current series of concerts by the Naumburg Orchestra will be given in memory of its founder, Elkan Naumburg. This concert will be played on the Mall in Central Park Thursday night and will be free to the public.
Retail trade in the New York area averaged 15 to 20 per cent higher last week than a year ago. Grocery sales ran rather more than 15 per cent ahead of 1940.

TOKYO, July 26 -- Within a few hours after President Roosevelt's order freezing Japanese assets and credits in the United States was announced, the Japanese Government retaliated by freezing the assets and credits of American and Philippine nationals and corporations within the Japanese Empire.

To spur immediate voluntary saving of one-third the gasoline normally used by motor vehicles from Maine to Florida, the Petroleum Industry District 1 Marketing Committee for National Defense began today to publish a 1,000-line advertisement that will appear in 500 daily newspapers.

On Calling Names Among the 30,000-odd men and women in "Who's Who in America" the Gallup survey finds that the percentage of those who want to enter a shooting war against Germany is twice as high as among the general public.

HOLLYWOOD. KATHARINE HEPBURN, who made the theatre men eat their words three years after they had called her "box-office poison," has achieved the ultimate in Hollywood success. She has dictated what is considered to be one of the most astonishing contracts to be signed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

BAYSHORE, L.I., July 26 -- A fleet of eighty-six sailing craft participated in the season's initial invitation regatta of the Bayshore Yacht Club today. A steady southwester blew over the course throughout the competition.

Clothes hangers may be filled with pretty Summer frocks, and clothes closets stocked with shorts and slacks and bright-hued shirts, but all of this glamour will not see a girl through even a brief Northern Summer unless she knows how to keep it in good condition.

ATTACKING furiously, pouring enough shells into her victim to sink with dispatch a ship twice the size, a German raider sent quickly to the bottom last August, 1,000 miles off West Africa, the coalladen British freighter Anglo-Saxon. In the intensity of the attack and the helplessness of the victim the incident was probably not unlike hundreds of others.

THE trial-and-error system being an old if frequently painful institution in the show business (else all plays would be hits, and all radio programs would have a Joe DiMaggio average in the Crossley ratings), the Columbia Broadcasting System's "Forecast" series shrewdly dramatizes the fact that there is no such phenomenon as a sure thing.

THERE is a curious human story that is played every night just before the curtain goes up on "Claudia" at the Booth Theatre. With no effort at concealment it has, however, remained a secret between the stage manager and the Naughton family -- Claudia, David and Claudia's mother.

August fur sales and mid-Summer furniture events accounted for the bulk of consumer activity in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles last week, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

HOLLYWOOD. TEMPERAMENT, in this latter-day Hollywood, has for the most part subsided into a still small voice. Producers with an assembly-line schedule nipping at their heels are rarely amused when a star kicks up his or her respective heels, and even among most of the performers themselves it is no longer considered quite fashionable.
"I LIKE children who are --." What qualities do you think of? Do you like children who are happy, responsive, imaginative, unselfish, well-behaved?

LONDON. A REPORT presented by A.J. Hoppe, one of the directors of the firm of Dent, of the recent sales of Everyman's Library casts an interesting light upon the preferences of the reading public in wartime.

With three former Golden Gloves victors pacing the workouts, the Camp Upton boxing squad concluded its third week of training yesterday preparatory to taking on the Fort Hancock, N.J., representatives in a boxing carnival at the Long Island camp's new arena Friday night.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 26 -- Robert L. Riggs Jr. stood forth as the player of the year to beat on turf today after winning the fiftyfourth annual invitation tennis tournament of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn. THE war that Hitler started two years ago has reached TVA's great province here in the Southern highlands and stirred it to an activity compared with which the mighty dam-building, soil-saving, electricity-producing campaign of the past eight years seems in retrospect almost leisurely.

Eddie Cantor, whose last Broadway appearance was in "Whoopee" thirteen years ago, will return to the stage this Fall in a musical version of the 1935 comedy success, "Tliree Men on A Horse," by John Cecil Holm and George Abbott, it was announced yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, July 27 -- The prompt, sweeping reaction to Japan's new move in Indo-China manifested by Anglo-American freezing of Japanese assets and trade, has caused lively satisfaction here. Warm approval also greeted the American freezing of Chinese credits, which caught the "Free China" capital almost completely by surprise.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (AP) -- The on-rushing Athletics, fighting to finish in the first division for the first time since 1933, swept a double-header from the Tigers before 25,609 fans at Shibe Park today, 8 to 1 and 7 to 0.

HELSINKI, Finland, Monday, July 28 (AP) -- Finnish forces in the Repola sector near the lower "waist" of Finland have destroyed a Russian artillery regiment and routed an infantry regiment by a pincers movement, it was officially announced today.

Asserting that export freight is moving through the Port of New York without congestion or delay, the Port of New York Authority took issue yesterday with remarks attributed to Major Gen. Edmund B. Gregory, Quartermaster General at Washington.

LONDON, July 27 -- Harry L. Hopkins, President Roosevelt's lease-lend coordinator, tonight pledged all possible aid -- "and immediately" -- to Russia in her war with Germany and pictured Germany as caught between two hostile camps supplied by America.

Tin and Silver Experts of the OPM, worried about a possible shortage of tin, most of which comes to us all the way across the Pacific from the strategic southeastern corner of Asia, are thinking seriously of using as a substitute, at least for some of its uses, nothing less than silver.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 27 -- Golf's "Joplin Ghost" of other years -- lean Horton Smith -- rode to the St. Paul open championship on a magical putter today.

BERLIN, July 27 -- Official admonitions and warnings and especially the appeal to industry to abstain from investing its liquid funds in shares seemed this time to have exercised the desired effects upon the stock market. Prices continued to sag during the greater part of the week and some of the leading stocks, including the I.G. Farbenindustrie, lost as much as 10 points.

Endorsement of Mayor La Guardia's third term candidacy is expected today from the Republican county leaders of Manhattan, Brooklyn and Richmond at a meeting to be held at 12:30 P.M. at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.

BERLIN, July 27 -- While the new Eastern campaign continues to absorb the interest of the world, the Reich is quietly consolidating its industrial position on the continent of Europe through a tightening of its control over the manufacturing capacity and the skilled man power of occupied countries.

At John Day they say that Pearl Buck's next book, now in progress, will be again of China, will have a theme of "ordinary life going on in the midst of war" and will be written in the mood and vein of "The Good Earth."

PITTSBURGH, July 27 -- Authorization of major expansions in the iron and steel capacity of the United States recently announced in Washington has led observers in the industry to the belief that defense officials are now taking a longer range view of the nation's total emergency requirements than previously had been indicated.

CHUNGKING, China, July 27 (AP) -- Japan is making feverish preparations for an opportunistic move in either of two directions, south into Thailand or northward into Russia's Siberia, operatives of the Chinese Intelligence Service reported today.

SHANGHAI, July 27 -- While receiving increasing reports of the freezing of Japanese credits, Shanghai remains outwardly calm, although speculation and conjecture on the next Japanese moves constitute the main topic of conversation in practically all circles.

Boris Blumin of New York, former Canadian chess champion, was the first to get a draw against Reuben Fine in the open championship at St. Louis. By the time of adjournment in their fifth-round game, one of Fine's pawns had reached the seventh rank, only to b blocked there.

BOSTON, July 27 (AP) -- Cleveland's wilting Indians salvaged the final game of their three-game series with the Red Sox, 4 -- 0, today as Joe Heving returned to haunt his former team-mates with a six-hit masterpiece.
MOSCOW, Monday, July 28 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique early today:

TOKYO, Monday, Juyl 28 (U.P.) -- The Japanese Government today followed up its freezing of United States assets in Japan by applying the freezing regulation to Canadian assets in the Empire while the Japan-created State of Manchukuo took similar action against Manchukuo assets of the United States and Great Britain.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, July 27 (AP) -- Japan will station, a powerful force within striking distance of Thailand when she lands troops, numbering at least 24,000, in Southern Indo-China, it was reported by a reliable source today.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A sharp debate in the Senate this week over the passage of the service extension resolution appeared probable today. Senator Robert R. Reynolds, chairman of the Military Affairs Committee, asserted that passage of the service extension resolution would mean that Congress had authorized the United States to enter the war as an "active, participating, shooting ally of Russia and Great Britain."
FRANKTON, Ind., July 27 (AP) -- Hillbilly and cowboy musicians from far and wide set about today forming a rival organization to the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers (ASCAP).

Charles Amendoles of La Tourette headed the qualifiers for the municipal golf championship and the Newbold Morris Trophy in the competition conducted by the Department of Parks at Forest Park, Queens, yesterday. Eighty golfers representing public courses in the city teed off and thirty-six survived for match play to be held at La Tourette, Staten Island, on Saturday.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 27 -- In the first match of the twenty-goal national polo championship, Los Tamaraos turned back Aknusti today on Hitchcock Field of the Meadow Brook Club, 8 to 7. The team that caries the name of a famous club in the Philippines from which its back, A.B.

Long-range planning of defense housing to provide adequate living quarters for workers in armament industries without leaving blighted areas in the post-emergency period is one of several recommendations contained in a solution of the problem proposed by the National Committee on the Housing Emergency.

TRENTON, July 27 -- "The smartest politics is good government," Governor Charles Edison said today in a speech at an outing of Mercer County Democrats here. It was the Governor's first public appearance since Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City announced Friday night that he was "handing over" the State leadership of the party to him.

The American Export liner Excalibur is due to arrive today from Lisbon via Bermuda with 213 passengers. Among those on board are Alexander Makinsky, secretary of the Rockefeller Foundation; Telesforo Calderon, Dominican Minister to Rome, and Pola Negri, moving picture actress.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 27 -- Carl Buhr's Tidsfordriv, Don Laflin's new Temperance and Harry Becker's Tusker were the winners today in the annual regatta of the handicap yacht racing class on Long Island Sound.

ROME, July 27 -- The forcing of the Valletta harbor defenses at Malta by Fascist naval units early yesterday supplies most of the press today its comments, which, while proclaiming the success of the enterprise, tell the Italian people that all the crews aboard the Mas -- E-boats or small torpedo craft -- used in the raid had either been killed or taken prisoners.

The cotton futures markets were unusually active last week, with quotations moving from one high level to another. On the New York Cotton Exchange, active futures contracts scored net gains of 94 to 98 points for the week, and, in the last three weeks, the prices of futures have risen successively, through the 15-cent, 16-cent and 17-cent levels.

LONDON, July 27 (AP) -- Daring young Italian Fascists who made a torpedo and speedboat attack on Malta met with disaster and their expedition probably was wiped out with seventeen tiny craft smashed, the British said today.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Monday, July 28 -- Mayor Hague replied to Governor Edison's speech in a statement issued from City Hall early this morning after the Mayor had been in telephone communication with, his lieutenants from Tucson, Ariz., where he is on vacation.

The Department of Markets is completing the organization of its emergency home defense program, with special stress on the problem of primary food distribution, according to Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr., whose annual report for 1940, in summarized form, was made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Imports from the Netherlands Indies reached a high record of $169,074,000 in 1940, compared with $92,971,000 in 1939, the Department of Commerce reported today. United States exports to the Netherlands Indies amounted to $53,781,000, compared with $35,420,000, and were the largest for any year since 1920.

Anxious to maintain its record as one of the few nations that has never defaulted on a foreign loan, either public or private, Japan has decided to continue to make interest and sinking-fund payments on all its dollar bonds, Tsutomu Nishiyama, Japanese financial commissioner in New York, announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, Monday, July 28 (AP) -- "The Blitzkrieg is a washout," Russia's official press spokesman declared today as the Red Army continued to combat the German spearheads in the zones defending Moscow, Leningrad and Kiev.

CAMPO GRANDE, Brazil, July 27 -- Important questions of South American policy in the current international crisis will be discussed on Tuesday when President Getulio D. Vargas of Brazil meets General Enrique Penaranda de Castillo, President of Bolivia, at the Brazilian city of Corumba, near the junction of the Brazilian, Bolivian and Paraguayan frontiers.

Sincere believers in Jesus Christ have abundant reasons to rejoice, despite the troubled times in which we live, the Rev. Dr. John H. McComb, the pastor, said last evening in a sermon in the Broadway Presbyterian Church, at 114th Street.
LONDON, July 27 (AP) -- A joint Admiralty, War Office and Air Ministry communique said today:

BERNE, Switzerland, July 27 -- The sixth week of the Russo-German conflict opened at dawn today with German troops continuing their main thrust against the Russian positions in only two sectors of the front -- the Zhitomir area in the south and the Smolensk area in the center -- and with no more success than on previous days.

WITH FINNISH TROOPS IN RUSSIA, July 27 (U.P.) -- Finnish troops in a double-barreled advance northeast of Lake Ladoga were reported tonight to be threatening two vital Soviet communication lines, the Murmansk Railroad at Petrosavodsk and the Svir River, a link in the Stalin Canal.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, July 27 (U.P.) -- H.J. Van Mook, Netherlands economic expert in recent negotiations with Japan, met with foreign exchange officials in special session today, presumably concerning freezing of Japanese assets.

CHUNGKING, China, July 27 -- Chinese military opinion held the belief today that the Japanese at present would only consolidate in French Indo-China and go no farther south for the time being while keeping ready for the main attack on Siberia.

VICHY, France, July 27 -- Among the several clues followed today by the French State police after the murder yesterday of Marx Dormoy, Leon Blum's former Minister of the Interior, is one leading to two men and a woman who had taken rooms in the hotel near Montelimar where M. Dormoy lived under police surveillance.
NEW YORK Colin Bryce Henderson of the British Ministry of Shipping and Mrs. Henderson, of London, are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 27 -- After winning the sixth of a series of seven races conducted by the International Star Class fleet of Great South Bay to select a crew for the world championship on the Pacific Coast, Eddie Ketcham Jr. of Babylon declined to compete in the final contest today.

WEEK ENDED JULY 26,1941 Activity in the foreign exchange market during the past week was practically at a standstill. Only a small number of transactions were reported and quotations moved within a narrow range. Rates for Japanese and Chinese currencies were not available on Saturday due to President Roosevelt's proclamation of July 25, to "freeze" the assets of these countries.

The welterweight championship of the world will be the stake tonight, when Fritzie Zivic, Pittsburgh boxer who rules the 147pound division, opposes Freddie (Red) Cochrane of Elizabeth, N.J., in a bout listed for fifteen rounds at Ruppert Stadium in Newark.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Mill buying, a decline in hedging pressure and a heat wave in the United States Northwest which is believed to have resulted in considerable premature ripening and light-weight grain resulted in a higher level of wheat prices last week.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 27 -- With seven named for the American Legion Handicap and eight for the historic Flash Stakes the month-long race meeting at this watering place is scheduled to begin tomorrow with the official expecting great success.

The health of isolated Newfoundland families that are reported to have survived for generations on dried fish and potatoes will be studied by the New York Post-Graduate Medical School, a division of Columbia University, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Although the assets of insured banks were appraised by examiners in 1940 at more than 99 per cent of their book value, certain banks in the Middle Atlantic States still have far too much real estate and should get rid of it, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported today.

SKINNERS CORNER, Va., July 27 -- Lieut. Gen. Hugh. A. Drum, commanding general of the First Army, with headquarters in New York, and Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair will inspect the field training of the Forty-fourth Divsion from Fort Dix this week, field headquarters of the Second Army Corps announced today.

Buying activity slowed somewhat in the wholesale market last week, especially on apparel, and manufacturers concentrated on the problem of deliveries on the large volume of business already placed. Major lines continued to be withdrawal from sale as the result of shortages and increasing prices.
Formation of the Loyal Americans of German Descent, a pro-democray, anti-Nazi organization, with directors, sponsors and charter members in eighteen States, was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Maybe it was the heat or the humidity. Perhaps it was a combination of both. But, whatever the cause, Giant pitching bogged down today at Wrigley Field and so did the Giant infield. Thus the Cubs romped off with a game that gave them their first series of the year over Colonel Bill Terry's band.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 27 -- In addition to keeping in touch with Washington today, President Roosevelt found time to see at least one caller on matters of state.

IPSWICH BAY, Mass., July 27 -- The outlook for the Massachusetts State tuna tournament, which is scheduled to get under way tomorrow, on the heels of Maine's highly successful derby, could not be better, for the tournament committee reports that there are tremendous schools of big bluefins in the bay.

Many Americans who would never think of becoming Communists were led to become active members in organizations which followed, or at least paralleled, the party line. When Stalin was Hitler's silent partner the British, these organizations held, were fighting an imperialist war which was no concern of ours.

"Unless the power of rottenness, selfishness and greed that permeates our democracy is broken, God help us when we go out to save the world and bring freedom to men in chains," the Right Rev. Leopold Kroll, Episcopal Bishop of Liberia, West Africa, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 27 (U.P.) -- The United States marines have taken up gardening.

Five new films are scheduled to arrive during the week. On Wednesday the Paramount will bring in "The Shepherd of the Hills," a Technicolor production with John Wayne, Harry Carey, Betty Field, James Barton and Beulah Bondi as the principal players.

ST. LOUIS, July 27 (AP) -- The Cardinals gained on second-place Brooklyn today, making their lead two games, as they split a double-header, losing the first game to the Braves, 12 to 10, but winning the second, 8 to 6.

Refugees of England, Inc., 511 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday that half of the funds raised at its benefits would go to the United Service Organizations or to local American charities. This policy will be followed, it was explained, for the duration of the current USO drive to obtain funds for recreational centers near military and naval establishments.

Cooperative effort among nations will have to be based on the principle that "God hath made of one blood all the nations of the world," if such effort is to bring real and lasting peace, Bishop Francis J. McConnell, Bishop of the New York Methodist Area, said yesterday in his sermon as guest preacher at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.
PITTSBURGH, July 27 -- If Leo Durocher and the Dodgers don't see the Pirates again until 1942 it will be too soon.

The current Far Eastern crisis, affecting as it does such important commodities as silk, tin and rubber, may have a serious effect on advertising, particularly of silk products. In the event that silk imports are curtailed sharply, both national and local advertising of silk hosiery will be restricted considerably.

LONDON, July 27 -- A pact between Poland and the Soviet Union -- one of the most remarkable feats of diplomatic legerdemain to come out of this war -- is expected to be signed here any day this week. So delicate is the situation involving the agreement that all concerned are holding their breaths and hoping for the best.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Senators swept a double-header with St. Louis, 4 -- 3 and 5 -- 3, today to climb out of the American League cellar and drop the Browns into eighth place. Washington saved an even break in the four-game series.
The Bronx Zoo was richer yesterday by seventeen birds and one spider, following the return after five weeks of a one-man voluntary expedition to Mexico.

LONDON, July 27 -- The feeling engendered in financial circles here by the government's white paper on the danger of inflation is that no real contribution has been made toward a settlement of the problem which admittedly is causing a lot of anxiety.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The necessity for increasing the electric energy available to this arsenal of democracy is ably presented in THE TIMES'S editorial "Our Vast Power Program."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent speech of Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles is one of the most significant utterances made by any statesman in many years. The interpretation of his statement presented in your editorial of July 24, "American Peace Aims," is also stirringly significant.

LIMA, Peru, July 27 (AP) -- The repulse of 5,000 "invaders of our national territory" and the capture of three Ecuadorean outposts were reported here today as Peru delayed her official answer to a tripartite request for a halt in border hostilities.

Last week started out in financial markets with another rise; which, however, was not sustained. For a day or two, prices were bid up on home business activities; later in the week, developments in Japanese relations took the front of the stage, and prices lost their gains.
MOSCOW, July 27 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique early today:

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 27 -- President Roosevelt's list of German, Italian and native pro-Axis agents, known in Latin America as "the South American blacklist," has created a problem for Central American coffee growers. Lack of instructions concerning the application of the proscriptions created uncertainty, as they do not know whether they can do business with the listed firms, whether American ships will carry cargo for them.

MANILA, Monday, July 28 -- Lieut. Gen. Douglas A. MacArthur, the United States Army's new Far East Commander, has called a conference of military chieftains here later today to determine the date of mobilization of the Philippine Army preparatory to inducting the 140,000 trained Filipino reservists into the American armed forces under President Roosevelt's order.

AMSTERDAM, July 27 -- Politico-military developments created last week a reserved trend in the share markets of the small Continental European countries, especially under the influence of Far Eastern events, with trade generally shrinking.

The country has long been ready to accept the conclusion that the defense program cannot reach its maximum dimensions except at the cost of drastic curtailment in the lines of normal civilian production that most closely compete with it for labor and materials. The most important of these is the automobile industry, in which Leon Henderson has proposed a production cut of 50 per cent.

VICHY, France, July 27 -- Food supplies continue to give the government much concern. As previously reported, the wheat crop this year is expected to be favorable and should suffice for the country's needs. The harvest and bringing in of the crops, however, are encountering many difficulties.

The parable of the unjust steward teaches us to emulate that worldling in his zeal, but to transfer that zeal to the things of the spirit, the Rev. Robert E. Woods said yesterday morning in the sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

CINCINNATI, July 27 (AP) -- The Reds and Phils divided a double-header today to end their four-game series at 2-all. After losing the first game, 2 -- 0, on a pair of unearned runs, the Phils made a dozen hits to win the nightcap, 8 -- 1.

Several thousand New "Yorkers of the swimming, diving and toedipping varieties enjoyed a cool, refreshing holiday yesterday as they initiated the "swimming hole" in the Flushing Meadow Park Amphitheatre and sun-bathed on its concrete "beach."

Conceding that these are difficult days in which to hold the Christian faith, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, said yesterday morning in his sermon that it is important to realize that the Christian gospel is not idealism but realism.

It is the duty of men of faith to dream and to labor for their dreams, the Rev. Dr. Morgan Phelps Noyes of Montclair, N.J., said yesterday in a sermon at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Fifty-sixth Street and Broadway.

LONDON, Monday, July 28 -- For the first time since the night of June 26-27, Londoners heard the air-raid sirens early today, and Nazi planes throbbed over the metropolis again amid the booming of anti-aircraft guns and a brilliant searchlight display.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27 -- With this city's $25,000,000-a-year hosiery industry threatened by a serious silk shortage as a consequence of the United States Government's credit-freezing action against Japan, the head of the Hosiery Workers Union here today urged that immediate action be taken to assure production of silk substitutes on a vastly greater scale and at a sharply stepped-up pace.

People always speak in wartime as if Christ is discredited, the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood said yesterday morning in a sermon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street. Dr. Norwood's answer was that Christ told us the way in which we should live and that we should not blame Him for the results of not living that way.
BERNE, Switzerland, July 27 -- The only thing clear regarding the war in Russia is that it has entered on the sixth week and that the decisive battle has yet to be fought.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your contributor "European" made a statement in his letter published July 20 which, it seems to me, calls for a reply. When he says: "And, to be sure, American trade barriers have contributed to spread misery in Europe. I wrote about ten years ago that the United States with its excessive duties has heaped up another world crisis on the first," he is guilty of exaggeration.
BOZEMAN, Mont., July 27 (AP) -- Wilbur Love Cummings, 60, prominent New York attorney and business man, died last night of injuries suffered when an unruly horse threw him.
If the champions of the many near-by seaside and mountain resorts were even approximating the truth yesterday, there was less room at those retreats then than there is in the subway this morning.

VICHY, France, July 27 (AP) -- The German - controlled Paris press started a campaign today for a military accord between France and Germany for the defense of Dakar and other French African possessions from possible American attack.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 27 -- The German Embassy, enlisting the aid of the Argentine Foreign Ministry in its efforts, had late tonight failed to get a shortwave radio transmitter that was seized Friday by the Congressional committee investigating un-Argentine activities while a diplomatic courier was bringing it to the embassy by airline from Peru.

A two-alarm fire that began early yesterday in the basement of a four-story tenement at 321 East Houston Street caused the death of a handyman and slight injuries to a fireman and three rescued tenants and disrupted telephone service to the Sheriff Street police station three blocks away.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Maritime Commission will make every effort to protect established ship line operators of the American merchant marine, to unify the operation of our ships and to avoid unfair competition with lines which have surrendered some of their ships to the commission to help meet the national emergency.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- In an attack on interventionists and Communists, the Most Rev. Francis J.L. Beckman, Catholic Archbishop of Dubuque, Iowa, warned members of Congress "to put on the brakes" to keep this country at peace.
A thirty-six-inch water main broke at 125th Street and Lexington Avenue at 5:10 P.M. yesterday, causing a major tie-up on the east side branches of the IRT subway division.

ANOTHER portfolio of landscapes and portraits by the wittiest living political caricaturist comes out this morning, "Low on the War: A Cartoon Commentary of the Years 1939-41," with a special introduction by Mr. Low himself and about 150 drawings in all.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 27 -- Plans for the production of two Metro-owned film properties, "Mr. and Mrs. North" and "Joe Smith, American," took shape over the week-end with the formation of a new production unit at the studio involving Dore Schary and Harry Rapf. Schary, who has been a scenarist at Metro for seven years, disclosed that three associate producers, Jack Chertok, Sam Marx and Irving Asher, will work with the unit.

Despite the pessimism and head-shakings of the older generation, New York City boys and girls appear to be pretty good specimens of typical young Americans. They read worth-while juvenile books, help their parents about the house, go to the movies once a week, listen to the radio an hour and a half each day, and really like to go to school.
As the Russo-German campaign enters its sixth week it is obvious that the Red Air Force is a considerable factor in the continued Russian resistance.

On the eve of the initiation of a program aimed at remedying the physical defects of young men subject, to the draft law, selective service officials made public yesterday a report that indicated the program had an opportunity of accomplishing much good.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 27 -- Arthur J. Secor, financier, philanthropist and art connoisseur, died in Toledo Hospital today, three hours after he was found in his home with a bullet wound in his head. He was 83 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A number of loans and lease agreements for the acquisition of defense facilities were announced today by Federal Loan Administrator Jesse Jones.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.

Last week the Irving Fisher Index of wholesale commodity prices reached another new 1936-41 high, rising from 95.4 to 95.9. The outstanding price change of the week was the rise in the price of silk, which was reflected in three of the group indexes.
Even the mighty Yankees, it seems, cannot keep their impressive streaks going forever.

Only sentimentalists will mourn the gradual passing of one of New York's typical "institutions," the pushcart peddler. For he is disappearing from the city streets, pushed aside by the opening of municipal enclosed retail markets. Thrifty housewives are learning to patronize these markets for economical, reliable wares.

VICHY, France, July 27 -- Political strife is discountenanced in the unoccupied zone, yet party lines have not been entirely eradicated. Former Leftists complain of discrimination, while former Rightists allege that "Freemasons and Popular Frontists" are insidiously opposing the new order.

CAMP CLAIBORNE, La., July 27 -- A group of pigeon fanciers enrolled in the 280th Signal Pigeon Company has turned one of the most peaceful of hobbies into a reliable means of communication for the United States armed forces.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., July 27 (AP) -- Benjamin Lee Whorf, insurance company executive whose hobby won him recognition as an expert on the ancient Aztec and Mayan civilizations, died yesterday at his home at the age of 44.

JUST before he headed for Saratoga, where the horses will start running this afternoon, this observer caught up with Racing Secretary John B. Campbell and heard him discuss horses and courses at some length. As a conversationalist John B. is not a self-starter. Sometimes it's necessary to ply the whip and spur. To make him break from the barrier on this occasion mention was made of the criticism of racing in New York this season.
Victories by Ted Schein and Bernard Diamond, both of Manhattan, highlighted yesterday's competition in the New York City public parks men's singles tennis championship tourney at Randalls Island.

Herbert Hoover Jr., president of the Consolidated Engineering Corporation, and E.E. Hoskins, chief engineer, have entered into an agreement with R.E. Gillmor, president, and Preston Bassett and R. B. Lea, vice presidents of the Sperry Gyroscope Company, under which Consolidated will take over the work of the Sperry company in the vibration and strain-measuring equipment field, it was announced yesterday.

TOKYO, July 27 -- Speaking for the government and Japan's big business, Masatsune Ogura, the new Finance Minister, who formerly headed the Sumitomo concern, declared today that because of the British and American economic sanctions Japan must hasten her construction of an East Asiatic sphere of self-sufficiency.

JERSEY CITY, July 27 (AP) -- Jersey City defeated Toronto in both ends of a double-header today to make it three out of four in the series. The scores were 4 -- 3 and 4 -- 0. Johnny McCarthy's double, which scored. Gibby Brack from second base, gave the Little Giants the verdict in the eleven-inning opener.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 27 -- Among the luncheon hostesses here today were Mrs. Paul Fitzsimons, Mrs. John Jacob Astor, Mrs. William B. Bristow, Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Duncan at Bonnicrest, in honor of their guest, Mrs. Theodore Freylinghousen; Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt at Beaulieu, where Miss Rosemary Warbirton Holbrook Smith, Stanley Reed Jr. and Lloyd Griscom were week-end guests, and Mrs. George H. Hull at Roselawn.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 27 -- When the jury in Federal District Court pronounced Enoch L. (Nucky) Johnson guilty of evading the income tax laws the cloak of Republican leadership slipped off his shoulders, bringing to an end a reign of thirty years.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Urging that we deliver all needed war supplies to Great Britain, even at the cost of losing lives and ships, Admiral William H. Standley, retired, declared this afternoon that it was only in conformity with our historic past that the United States should "clear the Atlantic of these Nazi pirates who serve the cause of human slavery, and challenge our right to free use of the high seas."

TOKYO, July 27 (AP) -- The freezing of assets of British and American nationals in retaliation for Washington and London action against Japanese assets was a development in what the newspaper Kokumin called a life and death struggle.

Consolidated net profit of the General Motors Corporation and subsidiaries for the second quarter of 1941 amounted to $53,579,568, or $1.18 a common share, compared with $46,546,999, or $1.02 a share, in the same period of 1940, according to a report for publication today.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 27 -- Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred J. Funk gave a large supper party tonight on the beach, in front of Cobble Court, their place on the ocean, for their daughter, Miss Joan Funk.

Cooperation with civil defense committees and eternal vigilance as the price of safety was urged yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Samuel Henry Prince, a professor in Kings College, Halifax, Nova Scotia, in his sermon at St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, 128 West Sixty-ninth Street.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 27 -- Sparkling putting in the pinches enabled Robert Sealy Jr. of Seawane and Jarvis S. Hicks of Rockaway Hunt to win the first annual invitation best-ball golf tournament of the Rockaway Hunting Club, 1 up, from Ernest P. Bernuth and Courtlandt Dixon, home club team, today.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 27 -- After voting disapproval of a tentative agreement drawn in negotiations with the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company of Kearny, 3,000 members of Local 16, International Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C.I.O., decided in executive session at the armory here this afternoon to hold a new and secret vote on the proposal and on the plan for a "modified union shop" as recommended by the Defense Mediation Board.
SAIGON, Indo-China, July 27 -- Japanese forces have started moving Into French military positions in Cambodia on the border of Thailand, according to unconfirmed reports here tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The War, Navy and Commerce Departments proposed today to the various States that they take steps at once to issue a new and uniform "delayed birth certificate."

MONTREAL, July 27 (AP) -- Newark, behind fine pitching by Russ Christopher and Allan Gettel, gained two victories over Montreal today to tighten its grip on first place in the International League. The scores were 3 -- 1 and 1 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on July 19 amounted to 254,048,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, a decrease for the week of 1,519,000 barrels, the net result of a decrease of 1,773,000 barrels in domestic crude and an increase of 254,000 barrels in foreign crude.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 25 (Delayed) (AP) -- A detailed report that Germany planned to partition European Russia when and if she conquers the Soviet Union up to the Urals mountain divide and then offer a "painless peace" to the British Empire gained credence today in pro-British circles who said it came from an Axis diplomat.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Corn prices last week again held to within narrow limits here, a feature being persistent buying of the December which is attributed to distilling interests. The government continues to offer cash corn at 75 cents, basis Chicago, to consumers and this is said to act as an effective "ceiling" on advances.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Realizing and hedging sales dominated the lard market last week, and prices averaged lower. Even the threat of curtailment of oil imports from the Far East failed to have much effect on sentiment. Packers say, however, that there is evidence of improvement in the domestic demand for cash lard, pointing out that the price of loose lard gained around 20 cents per 100 pounds on the September position last week.
SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 27 -- Eight years after her first triumph here Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Cooke of New York won her second Seabright Bowl today.

LONDON, July 27 -- In London's first war manoeuvre pitting the Home Guard against the regular army, 400 Canadian troops enacting the role of air-borne enemy invaders "captured" the capital's largest telephone exchange in eighty minutes today.

BERLIN, July 27 (AP) -- D.N.B., official German news agency, indicated a German advance to within forty-five miles of Leningrad today as other German war reports told of Nazi planes dropping hundreds of thousands of pounds of demolition and incendiary bombs on Moscow.
LONDON, Tuesday, July 29 -- Three German raiders failed to return to their bases with the small enemy force that tombed London early yesterday.
As the Russian campaign lengthens into its second month, the outcome of the unprecedented struggle in the East looms ever larger on the horizon of the war.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Far Eastern crisis caused the Orfice of Production Management today to ask industrial consumers of tin not to increase their stocks of it and to stop replacing current consumption until half their present supply was exhausted.

Following is the joint statement issued yesterday by Thomas J. Curran, Manhattan Republican chairman; John R. Crews, Kings County Republican chairman, and Robert S. Woodward, Btaten Island Republican chairman, endorsing the La Guardia-McGoldrick-Morris ticket:

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 28 -- An unusually fine field that includes almost every prominent American player with the exception of Miss Helen Jacobs and Miss Helen Bernhard, as well as three from Great Britain, began play today in the annual invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 28 -- Joseph E. Widener's Roman and the Manhasset Stable's Amphitheatre won the stake races as Saratoga opened today amid mud and rain, but with a brave show of its traditional glitter and gayety.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Wheat made a strong start and a tame finish today. Scattered buying developed at the opening which lifted the December and May to new seasonal high prices, but there was not the snap to the buying which prevailed late last week and the market started to ease, although support by professional traders was noticeable.

WASHINGTON, July 28 --Administration leaders in the Senate today deferred until Thursday consideration of legislation extending the active military service of selectees, National Guardsmen and Reserve officers, hoping thereby to marshal forces for the quickest possible action in the end.

A shortage of raw materials In the Fall will probably hold down production of musical instruments, at a time when demand will be at the highest level in years, manufacturers said yesterday at the opening of the fortieth annual Music Industries Convention and Trade Show in the Hotel New Yorker.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, July 28 -- The Government of the Netherlands Indies today suspend ed last year's agreement under which sufficient oil was to be sold to Japan to keep her fleet -- third largest in the world -- in full operation. The move, taken after consultation with Great Britain and the United States, was clearly understood here to involve a risk of war.

ROME, July 28 -- The possibility that Japan will attack the United States and Britain before these two powers have time to reorganize their defenses in the Far East is suggested today by Virginio Gayda, who points out that in this way Tokyo would steal a march on its potential enemies, as Germany did in Norway, Greece and Russia.
Three young Americans who escaped from, the Nazis in occupied France related their experiences yesterday when they, arrived at Jersey City on the American Export Liner Excalibur from Lisbon.

The American hosiery industry, although, still hoping that arrangements may be made for obtaining a continuing supply of raw silk from Japan, set in nation yesterday efforts to obtain sufficient substitute materials to supply the 47,000,000 dozen silk stockings normally bought by American women.

HAMILTON, Ont., July 28 (Canadian Press) -- Uniformed soldiers from army trade schools in Hamilton, who said they were acting on their own initiative and under orders from no one, marched to the plant of the National Steel Car Company tonight and began breaking up picket lines an hour after a strike at the plant had been called.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 28 -- With the Seabright Bowl in his possession, Robert L. Riggs started out in quest of the Southampton Cup today as the fifty-first annual invitation tennis tournament got under way at the Meadow Club.

A syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., will offer to the public today a new issue of $15,000,000 Remington Rand, Inc., fifteen-year 3 1/2 per cent debentures due on July 1, 1956. The debentures will be priced at 103 3/4.
CHICAGO, July 28 -- "I'll have a good story for you fellows tomorrow."

WHERE there's so much smoke, it's Pittsburgh. Those Pirates are aflame. Apparently Manager Frisch finally built a fire under them. They have been playing the best ball in the National League for a month or more. The balance sheet has them ten and a half games behind the pace-setting Cardinals, but, in the losing column, they are only eight games behind.

BERLIN, July 28 (AP) -- Germany struck again today at Bolivian charges of a German conspiracy to overthrow the La Paz government and a "third power" was accused by a spokesman of the crude forgery of a letter involved in the incident.

The Yankees will try to start a brand new winning streak today when they open a three-game series with the Tigers at the Stadium. The McCarthymen won nine in a row before losing on Sunday to the White Sox in the second game of a double-header.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Hot weather dressed trade tended today to offset moderate receipts and hog prices were steady to 10 cents higher and cattle values mixed. Lamb prices closed around 50 cents lower as moderate receipts failed to attract big buyers who had purchased 9,500 head directly.

CHUNGKING, China, July 28 -- The Chinese Government spokesman yesterday issued a formal statement expressing gratification for the "prompt and energetic" measures taken by the United States and the British Empire to counter the new Japanese moves in French Indo-China.

The sixth annual convention of the Dance Educators of America, Inc., began yesterday at the Hotel Park Central an extended program of instruction and demonstration in the newest developments in all phases of the dance.

GREAT FALLS, Mont., July 28 -- A poll of the State on the question "Would you vote for Wheeler for Senator today if an election were held?" and on "How did you vote on Senator last November?" is being taken by The Great Falls News.

Aid for the Bluejackets of the British Merchant Marine and Navy Who are fighting on the front line of the Battle of the Atlantic will be mobilized by Bundles for Britain, Inc., through "Bundles for Bluejackets," a new division of the American relief organization, it was announced yeaterday.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, July 29 (AP) -- Japanese who control Shanghai operations of the Chinese maritime customs, technically on behalf of the Nanking regime, notified local freight handling companies yesterday that henceforth they must submit export applications before shipping any commodities included in a comprehensive Japanese list.

BERLIN, July 28 -- German war correspondents on the Russian fronts express great indignation because of the "bandit" tactics that the Russians are said to be employing. With each defeat inflicted upon the Soviet, according to reports of the Nazi propaganda correspondents, the more wide-spread has been the adoption of these tactics by the Russians and the greater the ferocity and cold-bloodedness with which they carry them out.

BARABOO, Wis., July 28 (AP) -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., chairman of the Republican National Committee, warned Wis-consin Republicans today that America was threatened with a dictatorship as an aftermath of the war.

After an absence of seven years from the Broadway stage, Irving Kaye Davis will be represented this season by a comedy-drama of his authorship entitled "Cap and Gown." It will be sponsored by Halsey Raines, in association with Harry Blaney and Robert Marko, who have established offices at 226 West Forty-second Street.
CHICAGO, July 28 -- The house-hold washer and ironer industry today found itself entangled in conflicting orders concerning production from two Federal defense agencies.

Japanese Freezing Order With dealings in Far Eastern exchanges at a standstill as a result of the reciprocal fund-freezing orders by this country and Japan, considerable confusion prevailed in local banking circles yesterday concerning just what the general licenses issued by the Treasury Department almost simultaneously with the freezing order permit the various Japanese banks and agencies here to do.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve system in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 23: Increases of $81,000,000 in obligations guaranteed by the United States government and $121,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and a decrease of $194,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

GROTON, Conn., July 28 (AP) -- The death of 35-year-old Mrs. Richard H. Monks of Montville, bride of a week, whose body was found floating in the Thames River yesterday, was described by Edward J. Hickey, Connecticut Police Commissioner, today as his "most baffling case in a long time."

DEAL, N.J., July 28 -- In spite of a windstorm and rain that temporarily inundated the course, the scores in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's twelfth annual New Jersey Shore fifty-four-hole medal play tournament were remarkably low today.

The stock market was buoyant yesterday under the leadership of railroad and steel shares, many of the former group rising to new highs for the year, and trading volume attained 938,350 shares, the largest turnover since last Tuesday, which touched off a five-day recession.
ST. LOUIS, July 28 -- Today was an open date for the Dodgers, but it wasn't exactly a day of rest, for the Flatbush hopefuls arrived in this center of the Midwestern heat belt in a restless mood.

Trading in the wholesale meat markets yesterday was fair to slow. Steer beef hinds and ribs were steady. Lamb prices were weak to lower. Fresh pork cuts and veal hindsaddles were selling at steady prices. Early kosher trade was slow, with steer chucks and plates about steady. Lamb fore-saddles weak to lower, veal foresaddles weak.

Store Sales Here Rise 23% Sales of department stores in New York and Brooklyn last week were 23 per cent ahead of a year ago, according to the flash report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This compares with a gain in the previous week of 18 per cent.

In a normal year American industry buys machine-tools valued at $100,000,000. Last year the bill came to $450,000,000, and this year it will reach $750,000,000. We have here evidence enough of a crying need. Even $750,000,000 could not pay for all the machine-tools that could be used immediately.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 28 -- J.L. Dodge of Orangeburg drove his bay gelding Hollyrood Garnett to victory at $13.10 for $2 in the final heat or me Gosnen Driving Club Handicap Trot on the opening day of the Grand Circuit meeting at Historic Track today.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, July 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- A British submarine captain, just returned from Mediterranean operations, described today the sinking of an Axis convoy off Crete by "knocking them off like wooden ducks in a snooting gallery."

Devereux Milburn Jr., of the Meadow Brook Club and Al Brosch, Bethpage, combined to win the weekly amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island P.G.A. with 32, 32, 64, eight under par, at the North Hills Golf Club in Douglaston yesterday.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 28 -- After leading the special prowomen's event on gross and net scores with Mrs. Sylvia Whitman of the Hummocks Club this morning, Louis Barbaro, young Hummocks pro, teamed with W.L. Bartro, vice president of his club, to lead a strong field in the proamateur flight of the weekly Westchester P.G.A. tournament held at the Sunningdale Country Club today.
American Writing Paper Corporation -- Six months to June 30: Net profit, $95,734, after bond

VICHY, France, July 28 -- French observation of the Far East situation today indicated the feeling that the tension had slightly lessened between Japan and the United States and the British. The prevailing impression was that while moves that might cause a crisis are being taken, all the countries involved are hesitating to take any irremediable step.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 29 (AP) -- The Russians announced in a communique' today that the German offensives aimed at Moscow and Kiev were "breaking" and that Red Army soldiers were counter-attacking in some areas.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 28 -- Wallace Beery will toe starred in "Butch Minds the Baby" at Universal if current negotiations between that studio and Metro-Gold-wyn-Mayer for the loan of the player are concluded, it was learned today.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 28--An attempt to enlist the support of Latin-American countries in Adolf Hitler's "holy war" against Russia and communism is seen in a note received by the Foreign Office here from the government of Francisco Franco in Spain.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 28 -- Reports circulating in high foreign diplomatic circles here today lent strength to rumors current in Istanbul and Ankara that the Soviet Union shortly would issue a declaration pledging itself to a hands-off policy toward the Dardanelles.

Something more significant than the "V" campaign is happening in Europe. As if in response to a prearranged signal, all at once the imprisoned nations of that prostrate continent begin to stir. Those who have seen "Prometheus Bound" in its original setting of dark crags and twilit skies will remember the breathless moment when the giant first heaves and stretches under the rocks and chains that hold him to the ground.

Works of art by nearly a hundred artists were placed on view yesterday at the Grand Central (Terminal) Art Galleries, to remain on exhibition until Nov. 13, when the annual drawing by lay members will take place. Oils, water-colors and small sculptures are included.

LONDON, July 28 (U.P.) -- Indications reached London tonight that the anti-Axis powers' financial and commercial restrictions against Japan were likely to be applied mildly. For example, the United States and the Netherlands Indies are expected to continue to license substantial oil exports to Japan.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 28 -- A large contingent of society folk was in the boxes at the clubhouse when Saratoga's 1941 racing season opened this afternoon in a drizzling rain, which caused the ending of the day's svents after the fourth race.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 28 -- The Chamber investigating committee, after a sitting lasting almost all day today, decided to give partial satisfaction to the German Embassy's demand for restitution of the objects contained in its seized diplomatic pouches.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, July 29--Indications that the long-awaited main Russian counter-offensive had been in progress for at least two days were seen yesterday in neutral reports on the fighting in the Smolensk sector.

Deliveries and dealings in silk futures on the Commodity Exchange, Inc., were suspended yesterday temporarily by the board of governors at the request of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply. The move was taken as the result of the tense situation between the "United States and Japanese Governments and the "freezing" of all Japanese assets here.

LONDON, July 28 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- The Netherland Government, announcing a limited realignment of Cabinet portfolios, took occasion today to proclaim anew to the world a determination to liberate the Netherlands from German occupation without compromise or negotiation with the Nazi regime of Adolf Hitler.

Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, justified the qualification of three candidates for city jobs yesterday after the Council committee investigating civil service had produced evidence of court convictions against the three.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 28 -- President Roosevelt cut short his week-end tonight. On reaching Washington tomorrow he will confer with Congressional and Cabinet leaders on pending legislation, the proposed price control measure and the Far Eastern situation.

TRENTON, N.J. Tuesday, July 29 -- The legislature met in joint session at midnight at the request of Governor Charles Edison to hear him make a plea for passage of a bill for a constitutional convention.

NEWARK, N.J., July 28 -- Freddie Cochrane, Elizabeth welterweight, will have to wait until tomorrow night for his chance at the championship of his division. Scheduled to meet Fritzie Zivic at Ruppert Stadium tonight for the latter's world welterweight title, Cochrane saw his big opportunity deferred twenty-four hours by a rainstorm at about 6 o'clock.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I would be very touch interested to know whether Secretary Ickes's pleas to the public to cut consumption of gasoline are having any effect. I personally feel that by putting gasoline savings on a voluntary basis very little will be accomplished.

Thomas J. Curran, John R. Crews and Robert S. Woodward, leaders of the Republican organizations in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Richmond, yesterday formally endorsed for re-election the slate of Mayor La Guardia, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick and New-bold Morris, President of the City Council.

WASHINGTON, July 28--A broadened income tax base designed to obtain revenue from all persons with income and a general sales tax are probable features of next year's revenue measure, Representative Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, indicated today before the Rules Committee.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The price of cotton futures rose above 17 cents on the New York Cotton Exchange for the first time since 1930, according to the quotations reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 23. This is the result of a deliberate policy on the part of this Administration.

FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., July 28 (AP) -- Secretary Knox asserted in a speech here tonight that "if the time ever comes when we Americans are unwilling to fight to preserve the freedoms we have inherited, those freedoms will be destroyed and taken from us by a stronger breed of men."

Most New York women appeared unimpressed yesterday by the threat to their supply of silk stockings, but some, in the higher income groups, began to accumulate Supplies of favorite brands against the day when current Stocks of raw silk run out as a result of the expected stoppage of imports from Japan.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 29 -- Economic warfare in the Pacific spread yesterday when the Manchukuoan Government and Japan's authorities in occupied China joined Japan in freezing American and British assets in their respective territories, while the Netherlands Indies and New Zealand followed the lead of the United States and Great Britain.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Blair' Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of $750,000 of trade school and funding bonds of Norwich, Conn., on their bid of 100.556 for 1 3/8s. The bonds, dated Aug. 1, 1941, will mature serially on Aug. 1, 1942 to 1961.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 -- Forty or fifty Japanese ships were notified by radio tonight that they might enter Pacific Coast ports without fear of seizure by this government, but some of them, including the liner Tatuta Maru, carrying more than 100 Americans and a cargo of $2,500,000 worth of raw silk, were hesitant about taking advantage of the offer.

The annual report of General Mills, Inc., covering the fiscal year to the end of May, indicates a consolidated net income of $5,251,733 after all taxes, reserves and a contribution of $406,375 by the company to the fund of the employe retirement system.

There is every reason for strong public support of the constitutional amendment which will come up for vote this Fall, diverting $60,000,000 of grade-crossing elimination bonds to the expansion and improvement of highways and parkways. The State Council of Parks, of which Commissioner Moses is chairman, is about to open an educational campaign to acquaint the people of the State with the advantages of this step, which has been twice approved by the Legislature.

ANNISQUAM, Mass., July 28 -- The Massachusetts State tuna tournament got off to an early start this morning, but the rain and fog which drenched and blanketed Ipswich Bay all day supplied very bad fishing conditions, and when the boats pulled in late this afternoon only two fish were hauled on the dock scales.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Harold L. Ickes, petroleum coordinator, in a radio talk tonight pleaded for voluntary curtailment of the use of oil products in the East, and indicated that consumption figures of the next two weeks will tell whether compulsory rationing will be put into effect.

VICHY, France, July 28 -- Several minor aspects of "collaboration" were reported today. It was confirmed, for instance, that henceforth postal cards mailed between the occupied and unoccupied zones would no longer be limited to seven lines of text.

A lesson can be read from the life of Benjamin Lee Whorf. His fellow-townsmen of Hartford, Conn., knew him as an executive in one of the city's many insurance companies. But throughout the nation anthropologists, paleontologists and archaeologists esteemed him as one of the inner circle who could decipher and interpret the mysterious writings that remain from the vanished Mayan, Aztec and Toltec civilizations of Central America.
If Mayor La Guardia has his way an aluminum practice violin, once the property of Jascha Heifetz, will be auctioned Thursday night at a concert at Lewisohn Stadium, at which Mr. Heifetz will play.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Full priorities control was imposed today on calcium-silicon, used in the refining of high-grade steels needed for defense production, by E.R. Stettinius Jr., director of priorities for the Office of Production Management.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28 -- A jury of nine men and three women was chosen in Federal District Court today to try J. Warren DaVis,' retired "Federal Circuit Court judge, and Morgan. S. Kaufman of Scranton, an attorney, a second time on a charge of conspiring to obstruct justice and to defraud the government.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Speaker Rayburn stated today that price-control legislation would be introduced this week. Other sources hinted that, besides applying to industrial products, the legislation would contain, a compromise pro-vision for control of farm prices.

A general strike of 8,000 skilled electricians -- 1,500 of them maintenance men -- will go into effect this morning under the direction of Electrical Workers Union, Local 3, A.F. of L., in an effort to compel the Consolidated Edison Company to employ members of the local on the company's Waterside plant at Thirty-ninth Street and First Avenue.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 28 -- Mrs. Herbert Shipman gave a reception at the Gushing Memorial Building of the Art Association this afternoon to mark the opening of an exhibition and sale of her floral water-colors. It was held for the benefit of the British War Relief and the U.S.O.

CENTRAL CITY, Colo., July 28 (U.P.) -- Sheriff Oscar Williams said today that Joe Snyder, 55, a recluse trapper with many enemies, was chained to the rafters of his cabin two months ago and left to starve.
SKINNERS CORNER, Va., July 28 -- A hot sun turned out to be a greater enemy to the Forty-fourth Division today than its theoretica opponent, the Green Army Corps in a two-day war game.
