KEY WEST, Fla., July 28 (AP) -- Construction of new naval bases at this important Caribbean defense center stopped completely today when about 600 carpenters, painters and plumbers affiliated with the American Federation of Labor walked out in sympathy with 800 laborers who had struck for higher pay.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Miscellaneous supply contracts awarded today by the War Department totaled $1,735,001. The following awards, not previousy published, went to concerns in the New York area:

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Changes which the railroads propose to make in working rules affecting members of the five operating brotherhoods were presented in detail by management representatives to union spokesmen at a meeting here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 28 -- Carl H. Pforzheimer, chairman of the Westchester County Planning Commission, charged today that the Board of Supervisors was violating the spirit and the text of the county charter by moving to acquire a site in Purchase for a county airport without first referring the question to the commission for study.

DETROIT, July 28 (AP) -- Henry Ford, who will be 78 years old on Wednesday, believes that out of the war now affecting most of the world's peoples will come an era filled with "opportunity for every-body who can stop looking backward, face about and go forward."

Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was feverish and price changes were highly irregular as the market tried to adjust itself to developments in Washington and abroad. After opening with small gains and advancing 20 to 27 points in the first hour, prices broke sharply to as much as 9 points below Saturday's closing levels and then rallied slightly to close 2 points higher to 7 points lower for the day.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 29 (AP) -- Koh Ishii, Japanese Cabinet Bureau of Information spokesman, announced today that Japan had frozen the assets of the Netherlands and the Netherlands Indies.

Judge Robert A. Inch, sitting in Brooklyn Federal Court, reduced yesterday sentences previously imposed on four defendants because he had learned that one of the defendants headed a concern making national defense products. The men had received varying sentences for "kiting" checks to the amount of $10,000.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Kichisaburo Nomura, the Japanese Ambassador, was told by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, today that under present conditions the Treasury would grant clearances to Japanese vessels.

The colorful but unhygienic pushcart was hauled another step toward oblivion yesterday when Mayor La Guardia dedicated the Moore Street Market in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn and promised he would not permit unjustified rises in prices or profiteering in New York City.

ANOTHER filial Father-Was-a-Local-Character biography comes out today, this time one about an old-school newspaper man in Southern California who smoked ten or twenty cigars a day, never refused a drink and never went to church: "Father and His Town,"* by Richard Barry.

BERLIN, July 28 -- The battle of Smolensk, the "all-decisive battle of the invasion of Soviet Russia" and the "greatest battle of materiel" in all history, according to Berlin's descriptions of it, was officially reported by the Supreme German Command today to be approaching its successful conclusion.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- In an impassioned "statement of facts" which was applauded by many in the galleries and not challenged in three hours of debate, Senator Wheeler asserted today that Secretary Stimson's "near treason" charge was "a deliberately cunning" attempt to create "the utterly false and spurious impression" that he had encouraged American soldiers to resist any attempt to keep them in service over a year.
BEAVER LAKE, N. J., July 28 -- Two children whose parents are separated were killed with their maternal grandparents here late last night when fire attributed to a lightning bolt razed their home.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Apparently considering inadequate the voluntary plan of the $2,750,000,000 United Corporation for sterilization of its control over its four subholding companies and reduction of its holdings of their securities, the Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing here on Sept. 16 to consider a more drastic solution of the corporation's position under the Holding Company Act.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The base on which Secretary of War Stimson placed his attack on Senator Wheeler last week, and the text of the Secretary's rebuke, invited the consequences of today when many members of the Senate rallied to Mr. Wheeler's support.

ATLANTA, July 28 -- Governor Eugene Talmadge, who has had several tiffs with the Roosevelt Administration, turned down today a personal request from President Roosevelt for establishment of day-light time in the eastern half of Georgia as a defense measure.

The application by a Swiss corporation for the purchase of the United States interests in the Silesian Holding Company, controlling zinc and coal properties in what was Poland, has been denied by the Treasury Department, according to an announcement made here yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, July 28 (AP) -- From the far corners of the football world poured a steady stream of messages of condolence today over the sudden death of Coach Howard Harding Jones.
A check on mystery novels shows that the next two weeks or so will yield a bumper crop. At least fifteen titles are due, including several by the better-known writers.

AMSTERDAM, July 28 -- The Bourse was dull after a somewhat lower opening, but later rallied to close irregular. Domestic industrials were not much changed except A.K.U. which lost 2 3/4 at 141 5/8 and Unilever 1 1/4 at 128 1/2. Philips rose 1 1/8 to 222 1/2.

The Crucible Steel Company, in its semi-annual statement issued for publication today, shows a net income for the six months ended on June 30 of $2,924,430 after deductions of $2,358,412 Federal income taxes, $2,478,720 excess profits taxes, $1,289,054 anticipated increase in Federal taxes and $500,000 reserve for extraordinary contingencies.

The board of directors of the National Postal Meter Company, Inc., announced yesterday that the company would offer to sell 4,000 shares of new preferred stock and 4,000 shares of new common stock to International Business Machines Corporation, for $200,000, and would offer to exchange 13,832 shares of its Class A stock for certain assets which it desires to acquire from that company.

Bmobs Over Stepney How the people of London's East End stand up under the the German bombs and how the authorities and private agencies go about the job of relief has nowhere been so well told as by Cecily Carter Goodhart in a short Atlantic Monthly paper, "Out of House and Home."

VICHY, July 28 (U.P.) -- Reports of Chinese troop concentrations near the frontier of French Indo-China, where the Japanese have won new bases, aroused uncertainty and alarm in government quarters today.

President Roosevelt's order freezing Japanese funds in this country and making transactions involving Japanese-owned assets subject to special license effectively halted a substantial volume of the trade Japan has been carrying on with Central and South American countries, foreign traders said here yesterday.

The opening of "Forty Thousand Horsemen," a picture, dealing with the Anzacs, which was filmed in Australia and which was scheduled to arrive at the Globe on Saturday, has been postponed to Aug. 9. . . . "Tom, Dick and Harry" played to 236,748 persons in the first eleven days of its run at the Music Hall ending Sunday night.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 28 -- Sparked by Johnny Kinder, State open titleholder, the Plainfield Country Club team of Dr. James Lyerly and Kinder today won the New Jersey P.G.A. amateur-pro tournament at Homestead with a nine-under-par 63.

It's all in the life of a second engineer, but Robert Kerr, a sturdy Scot from Greenock who looks as if he should have no nerves, is still a bit shaky. As a matter of fact his hands tremble like leaves even with the fists clenched.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- An estimated total of 182,486 Federal employes received Civil Service status and others the right to promotion and transfer between now and Jan. 1, pending acquisition of classified status, under an executive order signed by President Roosevelt Saturday and issued today at the White House.

In his capacity as Director of the Office of Civilian Defense, Mayor La Guardia endorsed yesterday a new radio signal device designed by the Radio Corporation of America to provide instant communication to all homes and defense centers in the nation, especially in the event of air raids, as "of the greatest possible value to our national defense."

Details of the "flight strips," or auxiliary landing areas alongside public highways in various parts of the country, that are to be built under a recent Congressional authorization were revealed yesterday.

Ninety per cent of the courses of study now offered In the American public schools are inadequate and do not prepare the students to live in a democratic society, Dr. Herbert B. Bruner of Teachers College charged yesterday in a report of a five-year investigation.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 28 -- Plans have been completed for a showing of the motion picture, "Cavalcade," by Noel Coward, on the night of Aug. 6 at the Southampton Theatre for the benefit of the American Theatre Wing of the British War Relief Society and the Camp Upton Hospital fund of the American Red Cross.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Senator Norris is legally and sensibly right in his contention that the Vichy conspiracy is not the sovereign government of France and should be no longer recognized as such by the Government of the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The First Supplemental Defense Appropriation Bill, carrying $8,063,238,478, was passed today by the House and sent to the Senate. Its passage was delayed from last Thursday because of objection by Representative Merlin P. Hull, Progressive, of Wisconsin, to the inclusion of an item of $35,000,000 for a War Department Building just across the Potomac River, which will house its 40,000 workers and will be the largest office building in the world.

When some particularly unfit person gets to be head of an important committee of Congress by the accidental route of "seniority," the folly and danger of this system become especially evident. Such is the case today on the Senate Military Affairs Committee, the chairman of which is now Senator Robert R. Reynolds of North Carolina.

DETROIT, July 28 (AP) -- Another group of the motorcar industry's assembly plants closed today, their 1941 model production concluded. A few others are still "behind on deliveries and are continuing operations, but with one or two exceptions all will stop assembly work on this year's models before the week-end.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, expressed today the united opposition of his organization to the St. Lawrence Waterway project, asserting that it was economically, unjustified and in time would displace at least 50,000 American workingmen.

L.S. Goldsmith, associate counsel of Lawrence Gumbinner Advertising Agency, has withdrawn as director of the advertising account of the Goodall Company, makers of Palm Beach clothing, and a new advertising agency will be appointed soon to develop 1942 promotional plans.
LONDON, Tuesday, July 29 -- The British Foreign Office made known early today that Finland had broken off diplomatic relations with Britain.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. W. Henry Williams have arrived at the Pierre from Newport, R.I.

ROME, July 29 -- British planes carried out a daylight raid over some Sicilian towns yesterday afternoon, causing slight damage and injuring an unspecified number of persons, today's communique said. The bombers flew at a low altitude.

Open-market quotations for the Hong Kong dollar were resumed yesterday in foreign exchange circles following cessation of trading on the two previous business days. Although the accounts of the British Crown Colony of Hong Kong were not affected by the United States "freezing" order on Friday, which covered Japanese and Chinese accounts here, the dislocation of the market relationships of the Oriental exchanges made it impossible to quote accurately the Hong Kong rate.

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. William C. Burdett and their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Burdett, have arrived from Brazil and are at the Waldorf-Astoria, where they have been joined by another daughter, Miss Agnes Burdett, who came from Macon, Ga.
LONDON, July 29 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today followed up Prime Minister Winston Churchill's warning of a possible invasion, of these islands with a warning of an even subtler attack.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- A patchwork bill intended to give cotton and wheat fanners higher prices for their crops this year was approved by the Senate today after more than five hours of wrangling and voting.
AN easy way to become dizzy is to start mulling over the middleweight division in boxing. Who is the middleweight champion of the world? That's where the argument starts.
VICHY, France, July 29 -- Action against "black markets" is to be intensified in an effort to obtain equitable distribution of all foodstuffs and rationed commodities, it was learned today.

A state-wide program to train women volunteer workers in skills that will be useful not only during the national emergency but in long-range community planning was outlined yesterday by Mrs. Winthrop Pennock, director of the Division of Women's Activities of the State Council of Defense.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Libby, McNeill Libby today filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement that was submitted on Jan. 16, this year, disclosing that the 1,500,000 shares of its $7-par-value common stock that were not taken up by the original underwriters from their owner, Swift Co., now will be offered to the public.

RUMSON, N.J., July 29 -- A Keen putting blade helped Mrs. Charles Whitehead of Plainfield to turn in a perfect women's par score of 38, 38 -- 76 today on the Rumson Country Club course and gain a three-stroke lead in the second round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's twelfth annual New Jersey Shore tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- About 140 representatives of the newspaper, magazine, book publishing and printing industries, meeting today to nominate a printing and publishing committee as a division of the Pulp and Paper Products Defense Industry Advisory Committee, were assured today that there was no prospect of a shortage of newsprint.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Class I railroads had earnings of $433,538,408, before interest and rentals, in the first six months of 1941, compared with $245,523,110 in the same period last year, the Association of American Railroads reported today.

Reporting to stockholders at the annual meeting held yesterday, James H. Rand Jr., president of Remington Rand, Inc., said that net earnings in the three months ended on June 30 more than doubled those of the corresponding quarter a year ago.
Mr. Churchill's declaration yesterday that the Battle of the Atlantic is moving in Great Britain's favor is borne out not only by known figures for ship losses but also by other factors.

ANNISQUAM, Mass., July 29 -- The sun shone brightly, the wind puffed faintly, the ninety contestants in the Massachusetts State tuna tournament chummed constantly, but the tuna decided they would seek out less dangerous waters, and when the last boat pulled in at the Chard and Wilkinson dock today the tournament committee shrugged to a man and walked slowly and sadly back to its headquarters.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,869,950 barrels daily, an increase of 193,900 over the 3,676,050 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 22,850 barrels more than the calculation of 3,847,100 daily by the Bureau of Mines for July.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A tentative decision to rush to the Senate floor tomorrow the resolution extending the Army service of selectees, National Guardsmen and reserve officers for the duration of the national peril was reached by administration leaders today after the "non-interventionists" decided against a filibuster or other tactics of delay.

Nervousness and irregular price changes characterized trading in futures yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Losses of 21 to 26 points in the late morning trading were erased partially by an irregular upward movement in the afternoon, but a further reaction developed in the final hour and closing quotations were at net losses of 19 to 24 points for the day.

The demand continued slow yesterday and supplies appeared more than ample in most classes of rail stock. However, despite the inactive demand, steer hinds and ribs were holding at steady prices. With local supplies fairly well absorbed, lamb sales slowed up and the market was weak to $1 lower. Veal hindsaddles sold in sizable quantities at steady prices.
DENVER, July 29 (AP) -- Robert F. Archibold Sr., New York business man, died in a hospital yesterday of the effects of a paralytic stroke suffered three weeks ago in Central City. His age was 74.

Fifteen per cent of New York City's school children do not have normal vision and are in need of glasses or other corrective treatment, it was indicated in a three-year study, the results of which were made public yesterday at the Board of Education.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 29 -- More than 300 members of the Summer colony attended this afternoon the British War Relief concert and tea held at Kenarden Lodge, estate of Mrs. John T. Dorrance. The artists were Karin Branzell, Metropolitan Opera contralto, and Vincenz Ruzicka and Celius Dougherty, duo-pianists.

For the third year in succession the team of Mr. and Mrs. Andre Kostelanetz -- she is better known as Lily Pons, coloratura soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Association -- made a joint appearance as guest artists at the Lewisohn Stadium last night.

BOSTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Browns continued their jinx over the Red Sox today, taking the first game of the present series, 3 to 2, behind the six-hit pitching of Johnny Niggeling. It was his third triumph of the season over Boston.

The late Summer and Fall plans of Harcourt, Brace were made known yesterday. The house plans a list of some thirty new books, several reissues and special editions and an extensive juvenile list. Fiction releases will include the book on which Virginia Woolf was working at her death, "Between the Acts," and "Men Working," a first novel by William Faulkner's brother John.

Echoes From Arcady Republican endorsements. Democratic nominations, Fusion designations, county organizations, borough chairmen, district leaders, Tammany Hall, straight votes, split tickets, opposition candidates, running-mates, partisan, nonpartisan -- how good it is to see these good, simple, healthy faces out of a good, simple, healthy world reappear on the front page!

Eddie Leonard, greatest minstrel of his day, was found dead of apparently natural causes yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Imperial, Thirty-second Street and Broadway, after his wife, Mabel, had reported him missing from their home at the Hotel King Edward, 120 West Forty-fourth Street, Monday evening.

TRENTON, N.J., July 29 -- A little before the Legislature recessed at 4 o'clock this morning until Nov. 13, Arthur F. Foran of Hunterdon County and Alfred E. Driscoll of Camden County, both Republicans, resigned their Senate seats.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 29 -- Norval Hamilton Busey Jr., 67, of New York City, formally a paper manufacturer in Lee, was killed early today when his car crashed into a truck on the Pittsfield-Lenox Road. State police said he probably fell asleep at the wheel.

BENDIX, N.J., July 29 -- The work stoppage at the Bendix Borough plant of Air Associates, Inc., manufacturers of airplane parts for the Army and Navy, was ended today through the mediation efforts of the National Defense Mediation Board in Washington, according to a statement issued here tonight by Loren J. Houser, acting regional director of the United Automobile Workers Union (Aviation Division), C.I.O., on his return from an NDMB conference.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Secretary Stimson apologized tonight to Senator Wheeler for charging him with deliberately circularizing soldiers in training camps to resist military service beyond one year.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The President at his press conference today turned aside a questioner who wanted to know if coordination of power is to be added to that of petroleum products under Secretary Ickes, saying there might be some news on that subject three weeks hence.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- Moderate receipts in the livestock markets had little or no effect on prices today as dressed trade demand slackened in the face of the continued hot weather, and prices were generally steady to 25 cents lower.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial "Joint Tax Returns" of July 23 you speak of "this discriminatory device against married couples."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 29 -- The gardens of Bayberry Land, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight F. Davis in the Shinnecock Hills, provided a picturesque setting for the Children's Fair held there this afternoon for the benefit of the Camp Upton Hospital Fund of the American Red Cross.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Sumner Welles, acting Secretary of State, said today that recent developments had demonstrated that "the totalitarian powers are striving to disturb he peace of this hemisphere and to extend their disruptive control over the affairs of American republics."
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 29 (AP) -- The Jersey City Giants climbed to within a game of fourth place by beating the Rochester Red Wings, 7 -- 6, tonight.

LONDON, July 29 (U.P.) -- In reply to a Soviet request for reaffirmation of the Russo-Japanese treaty, Japan has suggested that Russia demilitarize her great Far Eastern, base at Vladivostok and give "certain assurances" with regard to "the movement of Russian armed forces in the Far East," it was reported tonight.
PITTSBURGH, July 29 (AP) -- Jupiter Pluvius scored a timely assist today as the Pirates polished off the Braves, 5 -- 3, for the Bucs' tenth victory in their last eleven games.

Despite blackouts, Great Britain's cities have been bombed again and again. Shielding and dimming lights or turning them out altogether is apparently no great protection. Moonlight, starlight, parachute flares, reflections from rivers and the sea have robbed the night of its security.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Lefty Al Smith hurled Cleveland to a 5 -- 1 victory over Washington today to give the Indians' fading pennant hopes a much-needed stimulus.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, July 29 (U.P.) -- Japan will lose 1,306,000 tons of crude oil and petroleum products annually from the Netherlands Indies if the government refuses to approve more exports to Japan following yesterday's suspension of the Tokyo-Batavia petroleum agreement, oil men said today.

ST. LOUIS, July 29 -- In the most extended exhibition, of futility either team has displayed this season the Cardinals and Dodgers played twelve innings to a 7-7 tie this afternoon and evening, the struggle being ended by darkness.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 -- Charles M. Housel, a private detective, called as a government witness in the second trial of J. Warren Davis, retired Federal Circuit Court judge, and of Morgan S. Kaufman on charges of conspiring to sell justice, testified in Federal District Court today that William Fox, former motion-picture producer, conferred with Kaufman in a hotel in Atlantic City a few weeks before entering into voluntary bankruptcy proceedings.

Every eventuality in a baseball umpire's life from, a split-second decision on the ninth-inning squeeze play to determining how highly polished an arbiter's shoes should be was portrayed dramatically yesterday on a magnetized demonstration board by "Professor" Ernest C. Quigley, former supervisor of National League umpires and present instructor in Physical Education at Teachers College, Columbia University.
A petition of the American Airlines, Inc., to reopen its mail pay case in either oral arguments or further public hearings was denied yesterday by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

Even before presenting the new tax bill to the House, Representative Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, has announced that another tax bill will be necessary. It will be necessary, he says, to lower personal exemptions and impose a general consumption tax.

A compilation of the nation's defense expenditures of $17,164,915,000 in the last fiscal year as made by the Office of Government Reports at 45 Broadway shows that California led all the States with a total received by concerns of $2,061,525,000.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 29 -- Sortavala, the first of the four Finnish cities ceded to Russia in the Moscow peace agreement, has been recaptured and the Finns have pushed on to Tuulos, beyond the former frontier. According to reports published in this evening's Finnish newspapers, troops entered the burning city Sunday and yesterday.

Walking may tie a lost art, but not to the Tigers. Five of them strolled in the seventh inning at the Stadium yesterday, forced in the two runs that broke a 3-all deadlock and Detroit inarched off with a 6-3 victory over the Yankees.
ANKARA, Turkey, July 29 -- Reports from abroad reaching foreign, military quarters here this afternoon said German land and sea forces were being moved in Bulgaria at an accelerated rate.

The Petroleum Corporation of America had on June 30 net assets equivalent to $7.92 a share on each of 1,911,300 shares, according to a pamphlet report released today. Including the market value of the one-fifth of a share of common stock in the Consolidated Oil Corporation, which was distributed to shareholders of the investment company on May 16, the net asset value was $8.60 a share, against $8.05 on Dec. 31.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 -- Jimmy Dykes, who usually is one of the principals, acted as peacemaker today in a fight that broke out between southpaw Edgar Smith of the White Sox and Al Simmons of the Athletics after Smith had shut out the Athletics with four hits, 1 to 0.

Arthur G. Klein, Democrat, was chosen yesterday in a special election to fill the unexpired term of the late M. Michael Edelstein as Representative in Congress of the Fourteenth district on the lower East Side. The final vote was Klein, 8,674; George A. Hastings, Republican, 3,337, and Leonard H. Wacker, Labor, 714.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 29 -- The stage was set today for an attractive round of competition tomorrow in the fifty-first Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.
CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- The Cubs bombarded five pitchers with fourteen well-timed hits today to defeat the Phillies, 12 to 4, in the first of their four-game series.

The map tells much of the story of Japan's new adventure in the South China Sea, but it does not tell all. For the Japanese fighting forces it spells another approach toward the oil, rubber and tin of the Netherlands Indies. Conceivably, Japan could do without American petroleum or gasoline if it had full control of the Borneo product.

Deliveries have become so extended in the men's furnishings field that yesterday a number of manufacturers in various lines withdrew offerings completely, some until the end of the year. The situation was further complicated by the threatened stoppage in all raw silk imports and neckwear manufacturers temporarily refused new orders on silk goods.

Reports here yesterday indicated that, while no final arrangements have been made, there was reasonable ground for hoping that some quantities of raw silk may be permitted to be imported despite the fund-freezing actions by the United States and Japan.

The third meeting between Billy Soose, world middleweight champion, and Georgie Abrams of Brooklyn, now a member of the United States Naval Reserve, will take place tonight at Madison Square Garden. Since the men will enter the ring over the class limit of 160 pounds, Soose's title will not be at stake in this ten-round encounter that is expected, to attract 10,000 spectators.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 30 -- With the abrogation of the oil pact between the Netherlands Indies and Japan at a time when Japan's oil imports from the Americas have become doubtful because of the freezing of Japanese assets by the United States and the solidarity of other American oil countries with the United States, the economic warfare in the Pacific has begun to approach critical stage.

ALBANY, July 29 -- The action of Dr. Ernest E. Cole, Commissioner of Education, in refusing an endorsement of the medical license of Dr. Otto Marburg, Austrian neurologist, was upheld today by the Court of Appeals, 5 to 2.

The men's shirt and pajama Industry now has a backlog of orders four times as great as that of a year ago and may be unable to meet retail demand at the start of the holiday season, according to the monthly survey yesterday by the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Roosevelt met with Democratic leaders from the capitol in the usual legislative conference. His callers included Sumner Welles, acting Secretary of State; Senor C.E. Alfaro, the Ecuadorean Ambassador, and Dr. Don H.V. La Fornte, special envoy of Ecuador; William Green, president of the A.F. of L., and Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

To THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of July 27 Professor Griswold, regarding the super-taxing of marriage, says: "He who puts his trust in unconstitutionally today in matters of this sort seems to disclose a rather surprising unawareness of the happenings of the past few years."

BERLIN, July 29 -- In its communique today, the German High Command revealed little of importance of its operations on the Eastern Front. Other reports from the Russian theatre also gave slight indication as to how quickly or slowly the German forces are advancing against the tenacious resistance of the Red Army.

The most important debate in Congress since the adoption of the Lease-Lend Act is scheduled to begin today, when the Senate takes up the proposal to extend the present period of training for selective service men and National Guardsmen. The question to be decided is whether the United States will have an adequate national defense in a time of crisis.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 29 (AP) -- R.A.F. Middle East headquarters issued this communique today:
ALBANY, July 29 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the State Labor Board lacked the power to set aside a union contract if industrial strife thereby would be promoted.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- The first serious rift in the negotiations of the railroads with their employes over wages and working rules developed today. The fourteen non-operating unions flatly refused requests of the Western and Southeastern carriers for changes in rules governing working conditions and arrangements and insisted that the wages aspect of the dispute lie taken up at once.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 29 -- Recovering from an illness that kept her idle for ten days, Florimel, 3-year-old filly owned by E. Roland Harriman, won both heats of the Coaching Club Trotting Oaks, feature event on today's Grand Circuit card at Historic Track.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Mrs. L.R.P. Jordan, 75, of Reidsville, Ga., experienced today a thrill for which she had long hoped -- one look at President Roosevelt before she goes totally blind.

An appeal for an adequate supply of raw materials will be made by the National Association of Band Instrument Manufacturers, it was decided yesterday at a meeting in the Hotel New Yorker held in conjunction with the fortieth annual Music Industries Convention and Trade Show.

NEWARK, N.J., July 29 -- Fredie Cochrane did what few boxing followers thought he could. The Elizabeth welterweight won the world championship of his division tonight by registering a wholly unexpected triumph over Fritzie civic, veteran Pittsburgh warrior, in a fifteen-round clash at Ruppert stadium.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Office of Production Management and the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply reached a temporary armistice today in their dispute over which will take the responsibility for ordering drastic cuts in automobile production.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 29 -- A benefit dinner dance for the British War Relief Society, Inc., at the Maidstone Club on Saturday night will bring hundreds here from all the Hamptons.

With Federal income and excess profits tax provisions six times as high as a year ago, the United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday a consolidated net profit of $24,814,751 for the second quarter of 1941, equal, after preferred dividends, to $2.12 a common share, and comparing with $19,201,008, or $1.48 a share, in the 1940 period.
BERLIN, July 29 (AP) -- The German High Command, issued this communique:

OTTAWA, July 29 (U.P.) -- The huge $150,000,000 - Arvida, Que., plant of the Aluminum Company of Canada was seized Thursday night by 300 men who held the plant until Sunday in what may have been a well-organized enemy attempt at sabotage, C.D. Howe, Minister of Munitions and Supply, revealed tonight.

Buyer Registrations Off Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 810, which compared with 1,031 in the previous week and 981 in the similar period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Combined net earnings of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation, including those of the National Surety Corporation, amounted to $9,163,703 for the first half of this year, compared with adjusted net income of $7,298,002 for the corresponding six months of 1940, according to the report of Henry Ittleson, chairman, and Arthur O. Dietz, president, for publication today.

Thomas A. Rickert, second vice president of the American Federation of Labor and since 1904 president of the United Garment Workers of America, died late Monday night in his apartment at the Essex House, 160 Central Park South. He succumbed to a heart attack after his return from his office.
VICHY, France, July 29 (AP) -- The text of today's agreement, entitled "A protocol between France and the Japanese Empire concerning the common defense of French Indo-China," follows:

SKINNERS CORNER, Va., July 29 -- Troops of the 44th Division were commended today by Major General Henry C. Pratt, Commander of the Second Army Corps, for their performance, despite intense heat, in a two day defensive manoeuvre ending this morning.

BERLIN, July 29 -- The complete economic subjugation of Latin-America is the avowed aim of "the new dollar diplomacy," of the United States, according to the official analysis today in the German press of the effects which the freezing of Japanese assets by the United States and Britain might have on world trade.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, July 30 -- The Smolensk sector in Western Russia was the scene of bloody battles as the Russian counter-offensive against the Germans continued to develop successfully, according to information received here today.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 29 -- Great Britain's two remaining respresentatives in the women's invitation tennis tournament were eliminated today on the turf courts of the Maidstone Club.

MONTREAL, July 29 (Canadian Press) -- Johnny Lindell pitched his fifteenth victory tonight to save Newark's record of not losing a double-header this season. Lindell stopped Montreal, 9 -- 3, after Ed Head, Royal right-hander, had gained his fifteenth triumph in the opener, 4 -- 3.
LONDON, July 29 -- Reports that the Polish Government here is about to come to an agreement with Russia received strong confirmation today when General Wladislaw Sikorski, the Polish Premier, said:

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Wednesday, July 30 -- A convoy of fifteen Japanese naval ships arrived here today with troops as the Japanese sped the occupation of bases in Indo-China. The arrivals here followed the movement of Japanese forces into near-by Cam Ranh, French Indo-China naval base 800 miles from Manila.

A form of salary kick-back involving circumvention of the Lyons Residence Law was described to the City Council committee investigating civil service yesterday by Deputy Purchase Commissioner Albert Pleydell, who said a New York University professor employed by his department at $275 a week had been used to mask the employment of a nonresident of the city.

U.S. Steel Costs The wage increase of 10 cents an hour made by United States Steel Corporation effective April 1 was almost wholly absorbed by the increase in volume of business between the first and second quarters of 1941, the quarterly report issued yesterday shows.

LONDON, July 29 (AP) -- With yesterday morning's air raid fresh in their minds, thousands of Londoners passed last night in subways, shelters and basements, but German bombs fell only at three points in East Anglia, causing a few injuries and slight damage.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Wheat fluctuated in an uncertain manner on the Board of Trade today, easing early on scattered selling only to turn strong later on short covering induced by the fact that the President's message on price control legislation is scheduled to be delivered to Congress tomorrow.

J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping, declared yesterday in his semi-annual report to the board of managers that the American shipbuilding effort had reached such magnitude that further expansion might necessitate reversion to such expedients as concrete vessels of the type built in World War days.

The New York County Democratic Committee, better known as Tammany Hall, unanimously ratified last night at its quarters in East Seventeenth Street the citywide slate of William O'Dwyer for Mayor, David H. Knott for Controller and M. Maldwin Fertig for President of the City Council.

MANILA, Wednesday, July 30 -- After a conference with President Manuel L. Quezon, Lieut. Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today a general plan for the integration of the armed forces of the Philippines into the United States Army forces in the Far East.

ALBANY, July 29 -- The American Guild of Musical Artists received sanction from the Court of Appeals today for an injunction to restrain the American Federation of Musicians from asserting jurisdiction over the Guild's instrumental virtuosos.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., July 29 -- Miss Lois Mclntyre of the Riverside Yacht Club of Riverside, Conn., took one-quarter of a point lead today in the series for the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound and the Syce Cup.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 29 -- Thirty-four Axis planes were destroyed, many other damaged and numerous airdrome troops killed or wounded as Royal Air Force planes roamed over Sicily yesterday, machine-gunning and bombing the Axis air bases there.

To THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is the purpose of this letter to compliment THE TIMES upon its editorial "Soil Versus Sidewalks," which appeared in the issue of July 21. As far as it goes, this editorial offers an unusually keen understanding and appreciation of the Real Estate Board's views and policies in connection with the contemplated movement to publicize the advantages of living in Manhattan.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 29 -- The demonstrative Finnish gesture of breaking off diplomaitc relations with Great Britain has provoked deep dismay in authorized and other Swedish circles because it revealed in a flash the degree of dependency of the Finnish Government on Berlin.

A plea for special tariff treatment for the Philippine Islands when they attain independence in 1946 was voiced yesterday by Louis Wagner, president of the Philippine Advertising Club, who was guest speaker at a luncheon meeting of the Export Advertising Club in Midston House.

Only incidentally did Mr. Churchill refer to the threat of German invasion in his challenging speech yesterday in the House of Commons, and this reference, like the warning that "it would be madness to suppose that Russia or the United States are going to win the war for us," was clearly intended to keep the armed forces and the British spirit at "concert pitch."

An egg tomato -- subject for conversation this week among local grocers -- is not a weird and wonderful hybrid but just the name for one of the 513 kinds of tomatoes grown in the United States. Tomatoes vary in color from white to bright red.

Following an announcement on Monday that the Treasury Department had refused to permit sale of European coal and zinc properties of the Silesian Holding Company, the Silesian-American Corporation filed yesterday a petition for reorganization under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Laws.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 29 -- An impromptu reception was accorded Mrs. Dodge Sloane by clubhouse boxholders near her box this afternoon after two of her thoroughbreds won in the second racing day's events here. Guests in her box were Mrs. Robert L. Clarkson, Robert L. Clarkson Jr. and Mrs. James Simpson Jr.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, will place on public view today a group of recent acquisitions, this material illustrating exploits in various fields of fantastic art, Dada and Surrealism. Part of it has been placed in the regular gallery of accessions on the main floor, the rest in a gallery just to the left of the entrance on the third floor.

Rationing of oil products along the Atlantic seaboard, which would affect consumers from Maine to Florida, is under consideration by the Office of Petroleum Coordinator, it was learned here yesterday, and may be started within the next two weeks.

Stocks went through a mild shaking-down movement yesterday and at the close were irregularly lower. The rubbers and the rails did best and steels were the worst in a market which saw a volume of 962,710 shares and 835 individual ssues traded, the largest and broadest since last Tuesday.

DETROIT, July 29 (AP) -- Tyrus Raymond Cobb returned to the scene of his baseball triumphs today as a golfer and in something less than sensational play defeated Babe Ruth, 3 and 2, in the rubber match of their charity links series.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Railway management and labor have joined hands to help the Office of Production Management in meeting a shortage of skilled men in defense industries, which is now estimated at a minimum of 1,400,000.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 28:

LONDON, July 29 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill, defending Britain's production effort before the House of Commons today, de clared that the United States "is giving us aid on a gigantic scale and is advancing in rising wrath and conviction to the very verge of war."

NEWPORT, July 29 -- There were several informal dinner parties this evening before the opening of the third week of the Casino Theatre season when "The Circle," with Karen Morley was presented. Mrs. Beverley Bogert and Mrs. Hamilton McK. Twombly had boxes for the performance and there were several large parties in the audience, one of them entertained by Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt.

"The Shepherd of the Hills," a Technicolor screen version of the Harold Bell Wright novel, will open this morning at the Paramount. The picture, which was directed by Henry Hathaway, stars John j Wayne, Betty Field and Harry Carey and features Beulah Bondi, James Barton, Marjorie Main and Samuel S. Hinds. . . .
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Roosevelt at his press conference today was not prepared to discuss the Far East.

Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, yesterday notified stockholders that the quarterly dividend on the common stock had been reduced to 40 cents from the 50 cents paid previously. This action, in effect, places Consolidated Edison common stock on a $1.60 annual dividend basis, contrasted with the $2 annually which had prevailed since March, 1937.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Alexander C. Brown, vice president of the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company, told the House Rivers and Harbors Committee today that the St. Lawrence seaway would do "irreparable harm" to the iron ore industry and open the Middle West to low-cost foreign goods.
LONDON, July 29 -- Following is a partial text of Prime Minister Churchill's speech in the House of Commons today:

LENOX, Mass., July 29 -- Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Clark Feathers gave a reception this afternoon at Waterford, their home here, to introduce their daughter, Miss Henrietta Kavanaugh Feathers, to their older friends. The house was decorated with garden flowers.

A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. is understood to have submitted the high bid yesterday for $1,983,000 of sewer bonds of San Diego, Calif., although no official award of the issue was announced last night. The syndicate bid par for $500,000 as 3 1/2s, $65,000 as 2s and $833,000 as 1 3/4s, or a net interest cost basis of 1.9385 per cent.

The Manhattan Republican organization rejected by formal vote last evening the candidacy of Stanley M. Isaacs for renomination for Borough President, and thus ended Mr. Isaacs's chances for the nomination by united Fusion groups, unless he can reopen his case by winning in the Republican primary.

An advertising appropriation of about $2,500,000 was announced yesterday as the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer budget for 1941-42 by Howard Dietz, executive in charge of promotion. The budget will be in large measure devoted to newspaper space with national magazines and other media used extensively.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Roosevelt intimated today that Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, was likely to become defense coordinator of all energy, electric power as well as fuel.

The National Association of Life Underwriters announced yesterday the appointment of a committee that will offer the services of life insurance agents to the government in the sale of National Defense Savings Bonds.

Patsy Giovanelli, young East New York lightweight, scored an upset victory over Harry Jeffra of Baltimore, former bantam and featherweight champion of the world, at the Queensboro Arena in Long Island City last night. More than 3,500 persons saw Giovanelli stage a belated rally to win this gruelling eight-round battle.

Work on six defense projects in the Navy Yard in Brooklyn was halted when 8,000 electricians, members of Electrical Workers Union, Local 3, A.F. of L., began a general strike yesterday morning. One thousand construction Jobs involving hundreds of millions of dollars were tied up throughout the city.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Office of Production Management stated today that there would be a sharp reduction in the number of radio sets manufactured in the next year, but that sufficient aluminum and other materials would be provided for maintenance and repair of existing sets.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Moving to coordinate the activities of aviation units and ground forces, the Army created five Air Support Commands today within the framework of the Air Forces Combat Command.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, July 30 (AP) -- American and British properties in the whole of Shantung Province have been placed under "protective custody" by the Japanese, reliable informants reported today, following the closing down of American and British oil plants at Tsingtao and Dairen.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 30 -- The High Command of the Red Army, in a communique reporting a continuation of fighting in the three chief battle areas, announced today that Russian troops had dislodged German forces from positions in the Smolensk sector in a series of counter-attacks that inflicted severe losses on the invader.
VICHY, France, July 29 -- The protocol for French-Japanese "defense" of Indo-China was signed in Vichy this morning. Simultaneously it was reported Japanese troops were entering bases in Indo-China.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Senate Naval Affairs Committee released today Secretary Knox's official assurances that the Navy was firing only in self-defense and that it was neither convoying British merchant ships nor operating within the European combat zones.

On the basis of a survey of twenty-one key defense cities throughout the nation, the National Association of Manufacturers reported yesterday that relief rolls had been cut more than half; that employment was at the highest rate since 1929, and that the already acute shortage of skilled labor would be doubly serious by Winter.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 29 -- The part a slow track can play in the outcome of a horse race was illustrated today when C.V. Whitney's homebred Parasang won the $7,100 Wilson Stakes, with the Belair Stud's Fenelon a well-beaten second.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A group of members of the House, opposed to the mandatory joint tax returns for married couples, forced postponement today of floor consideration of the $3,529,200,000 defense revenue bill and caused leaders to ask for a modification of the rigid parliamentary rule which had been granted to it in committee.

Elizabeth Leo Wheaton, who combines writing with running her home in Texas City, Texas (population 5,748), and whose husband obligingly cuts in half everything she writes, received yesterday $2,500 for her first novel, a picture of Negro life in a small town.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 29 -- Jackie Cooper and Bonita Granville will play the leads in William Diterle's second production at RKO, "Syncopation," formerly entitled "The Band Played On," the studio announced today. Valentine Davies and John O'Hara are writing the scenario from a story by Davies dealing with the history of jazz.

The first death due to infantile paralysis this year was reported last week, it was announced yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner. Seventeen cases of this malady have been reported since Jan. 1, considerably below the normal expectancy.
OTTAWA, July 29 -- The Duke of Kent arrived here today on a bomber from England to study Canadian air training. His flight across the Atlantic took nine hours.
MANILA, July 29 (AP) -- Manila, alarmed by the Far East crisis, took steps today to provide air-raid shelters and planned its first practice evacuation of civilians.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Senator D. Worth Clark of Idaho said today that the United States "should take over control" of all Latin America and Canada, and President Roosevelt and others promptly denounced the suggestion.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 (U.P.) -- The Japanese Government tonight held the big passenger liner Tatuta Maru and eight smaller Japanese ships at anchor off Pacific Coast ports, awaiting United States assurance that the vessels and cargoes would not be seized if they entered American territorial waters.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 29 -- Associate Justice Stanley F. Reed of the United States Supreme Court told a Freedom Bell rally in Beardsley Park tonight that the forces of democracy must unite for an all-out effort, sacrificing whatever individual ambitions may be necessary and relying on President Roosevelt and his staff for the conduct of foreign affairs, in order to meet the totalitarian resources of the Nazi threat to the American way of life.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 29 -- Capitalizing on a backfield that first shut down on the opposition and then scored seven of their twelve goals, Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes turned back Broadhollow in the last of the first-round matches in the national 20-goal polo championship today and qualified to meet Great Neck in one of the semi-finals Thursday.

Although the city's part in the national drive for scrap aluminum was to have ended last Saturday, sizable collections were made yesterday, the most impressive yielding 2,000 pounds of discarded parts of airplanes at La Guardia field.
ROME, July 29 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique:
The largest craft so far acquired by the Signal Corps of the United States Army for its "navy" will be launched at 1 P.M., Friday, at the Jakobson Shipyard, Inc., on West End Avenue, Oyster Bay, L.I.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 30 -- Mr. and Mrs. George Flint Warren Jr. gave a dinner tonight at Wyndhaven, their place in Water Mill. Among their guests were Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler, Mr. and Mrs. Francis Rogers and Mr. and Mrs. T. Arthur Ball, Commander and Mrs. Robert King Awtrey of Washington, D.C., and the Misses Nancy and Alice Awtrey will join Mr. and Mrs. Warren this week for a month's visit.
LONDON, July 30 -- Following is the text of the agreement signed today by the Russian Government and the Polish Government-in-Exile:

ST. LOUIS, July 30 -- News from the western banks of Old Man River is very sad, indeed. For Billy Southworth's Cardinals, emulating that famous stream, kept right on rolling along today and Lippy Leo Durocher's runner-up Dodgers now are three games behind the league leaders.

I AM a week late with the news about Howard Fast's historical novel, "The Last Frontier,"* but the book is so good a book that it would still be news weeks or even months from now. Mr. Fast has written highly praised, and overpraised, books before. This time he has turned out, at the age of merely 26, a remarkable and even distinguished novel.
CHICAGO, July 30 -- The starting line-up of the College All-Stars -- selected by millions of fans throughout the nation to meet the Chicago Bears at Soldier Field on Aug. 28 -- was announced today.

A patrolman about to telephone to police headquarters the license plate numbers of a taxicab reported to contain fleeing hold-up men had his work cut short yesterday afternoon when the cab and the men themselves appeared.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 30 -- Ginger Rogers's appearance in the screen version of "Lady in the Dark" appeared probable today with the announcement by Paramount that a deal for her to make one picture a year for three years for that studio is in final stages of negotiations.

Offering to the public was made yesterday by a syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. of $1,983,000 of San Diego, Calif., sewer bonds at prices that attracted a broad investment demand both here and in the West. The syndicate managers announced that only $268,000 of the issue remained in the account late in the day.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The United States extended diplomatic recognition today to the Provisional Government of Czecho-Slovakia in Great Britain under the Presidency of Dr. Eduard Benes. Similar action had previously been taken by Britain and Soviet Russia.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 30 -- Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Mumford gave a luncheon today at the Devon Yacht Club for Mrs. Ten Eyck Wendell, Mrs. W.V. Walker, Mrs. Cedric Seaman, Mrs. Arthur Tillotson, Miss Elizabeth Hayes, Mrs. John Adams Mayer and Mme. Queena Mario.
SHANGHAI, July 30 -- Foreign observers here declare Japan's interest has shifted from the south to the north because Japanese troops are moving into positions in Manchukuo.

During an address at New York University on the international situation, Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs yesterday defined his stand on "subversive activities," later declaring that it would be his answer to those who challenged him in the coming local political campaign for having appointed Simon Gerson to office.

MONTREAL, July 30 (AP) -- Hank Borowy, who became a father today, celebrated the event by pitching his thirteenth victory of the season for the Newark Bears tonight, downing the Montreal Royals, 9 -- 5, to keep the club's five game margin in first place in the International League.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- In an impressive plea for the United States to retain selectees, National Guardsmen and Reserve officers under arms "for the duration," Senator Thomas of Utah told the Senate today that Germany had a trained fighting force nearly five times greater than when Hitler gave the signal which started the new world war in September, 1939.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Defense of the Pacific Coast by the United States and Canada was discussed today with President Roosevelt by Mayor La Guardia of New York. The Mayor, American chairman of the Joint United States-Canadian Defense Board, met with the board yesterday in Montreal.

The semi-annual report of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company mailed to stockholders yesterday disclosed a consolidated net profit of $11,568,401 for the first half of the current year. The result was after all charges and compares with $9,837,012 in the six months to June 30, last year.
CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) -- Tot Pressnell's brilliant relief pitching gave the Cubs an even break with the Phillies in a double-header today.

DEAL, N.J., July 30 -- Coming from behind to card a great 79 on a rain-drenched course, Mrs. Dewitt Untermeyer of the home club won the women's metropolitan twelfth annual New Jersey Shore tournament with an aggregate score of 245 as this fifty-four-hole event was concluded on the Hollywood links today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, July 16 -- Since one of the major obstacles to Pan-American cooperation is the fact that in many parts of South America influential groups shy at the very word "democracy," the character of the government and those who run it has a direct bearing upon foreign relations.

Georgie Abrams, Washington fighter now serving with the United States Navy, received the decision over Billy Soose, recognized by the New York State Athletic Commission as the middleweight champion of the world, in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

Dun Bradstreet, Inc., founded in 1841 by Lewis Tappan as The Mercantile Agency, will celebrate its hundredth anniversary tomorrow. Mr. Tappan was a silk merchant and a member of Arthur Tappan Co. when that company, together with hundreds of other large organizations, failed in the great panic of 1837.

An underwriting group headed by Van Alstyne, Noel Co. will offer today to the public 150,000 shares of common stock of the Memphis Natural Gas Company. The stock will be priced at $5 a share, representing a total market value of about $750,000.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Senator George of Georgia made a difficult choice today, but a choice that was applauded by his friends and should be by all those citizens who want a strong, sound official voice in post-war economic reconstruction. He chose to relinquish his post as chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations to become chairman of the Finance Committee, in succession to the late Senator Harrison.

Strength in the Canadian dollar, which rose 1/8 cent yesterday in the free market to 88.62 cents, was a feature of the session in foreign exchange. Aside from the tourist demand for Canadian dollars, it was reported that the New York Postoffice conducted heavy "covering" operations yesterday in Canadian exchange, reflecting month-end requirements of the postal authorities.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- President Roosevelt, in a letter sent today to nearly 14,000 chairmen who participated in the celebration of his fifty-ninth birthday, when a net total of $2,104,460 was raised through balls and other events for the battle against infantile paralysis, warmly thanked them for their efforts.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y ., July 30 -- Mrs. Payne Whitney's Century Note, full brother to Twenty Grand, sustained many admirers today when he plowed his way through Saratoga's slow racing strip to take the Hermis Handicap at a mile and a furlong.

The report of Atlas Corporation for the six months ended on June 30 shows a net asset value of $50,288,637, equal, after preferred stock provisions to $11.81 a share on the common stock, against $11.43 a share a year ago. On Dec. 31, last, the value was $12.27 a common share.

ALBANY, July 30 -- Candidates to whom have been awarded State tuition-paying Cornell scholarships were announced today by the State Education Department. One candidate is named for each Assembly district after a series of competitive examinations.
ROME, July 30 -- The Axis is now justified in regarding the United States Navy as that of a belligerent power, Virginio Gayda announces in today's Giornale d'Italia.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, announced today, after conferring with President Roosevelt, that Harry L. Hopkins, lease-lend co-ordinator, had gone to Moscow from London at the direct request of the President to discuss expediting war materials to the Soviet Union.

OTTAWA, July 30 -- Although Munitions Minister C.D. Howe has given some explanation of last week's seizure of the important aluminum plant at Arvida, Que., when 300 workers occupied the premises for four days, allowing certain deterioration, a great deal of mystery still surrounds the workers' action.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 30 -- The passage of German travelers across Turkey into Iran has been accelerated during the past forty-eight hours. Despite Iranian assurances that German tourist travel in Iran is no more than usual and that the probable total of German tourists and commercial travelers in Iran is no more than about 500, information from diplomatic sources here indicate that the influx of Germans is increasing steadily.

Any claim to public support which might have been made by Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A.F. of L., on the basis of its dispute with the Consolidated Edison Company has been forfeited by the tactics of the local in calling a general strike of its members.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 31 -- In a speech before the General Mobilization Inquiry Commission, which met yesterday to consider imperial ordinances for increasing Japan's self-sufficiency, Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye said that, with the hostilities between Germany and Russia, the European war had reached a new turning point and that its ultimate result could not be easily predicted.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The proposed expenditure for the St. Lawrence Seaway could not be justified by benefits to commerce and navigation anywhere, said Walter P. Hedden, a member of the staff of the Port of New York Authority, appearing as a witness today before the House Rivers and Harbors Committee.
The Victory "V" served a strategic purpose yesterday during a gathering of lively competitors at the Children's Air Society's lower West Side center, 219 Sullivan Street.

Great Britain's air offensive against Germany will "really start" about Sept. 1, when the nights are longer, and the Nazis "will have to invent a new word for Blitz" when it begins, Noel Monks, air correspondent of The London Daily Mail, who recently arrived from England, declared yesterday.

The first full fiscal year of operation of the city's unified transit lines has produced revenues $28,000,000 in excess of operating expenses, it was indicated yesterday. This amount falls about $7,000,000 short of the $35,000,000 carried in the city's expense budget to meet interest and amortization charges on the bonds issued to finance construction of the Independent Subway System, now the IND division of the unified network.

The Wheeling Steel Corporation and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $4,689,196 in the first six months this year after $2,068,813 provision for Federal income taxes. This was equal to $6.60 each on 569,674 shares of common stock after dividend requirements on the preferred issue.
SOUTHPORT, Conn., July 30 -- Only one race could be sailed today in the women's championship of Long Island Sound for the Syce Cup because of an eventual total lack of stirring air.

The Grant-Lee Theatre, with a seating capacity of 1,000 at 817 Abbot Boulevard, Palisades, N.J., has been leased for twenty-one years toy the Harold S. Eskin Amusement Enterprises of 17 East Forty-second Street, Manhattan, from the Freed Realty Company.

SALEM, N.H., July 30 (AP) -- Syl's Jimmy, the even-money choice, came from far back at Rockingham Park today to win the $2,500 added Maplewood Stakes for 2-year-old colts and geldings by a nose. C.B. Gooch's Rodes K. was second and Frank Lubanovich's Opportunity third, with Incoming the fourth horse across the wire.

BERLIN, July 30 -- On the basis of the terse phraseology of today's communique of the Supreme German Command, the Reich's forces operating in the vital Smolensk sector of the Eastern Front have been and still may be on the defensive.

Men's Wear Stocks Thin More frequent complaints on thin stocks were heard among local men's wear stores this week, as retail trade continued at a brisk pace. The Palm Beach sale continued to draw well and other Summer suits moved freely.

TRENTON, July 30 -- The State Supreme Court today upheld a legislative act repealing the ban on the holding of stakes when it reversed the conviction of an Orange man who had been indicted for being a stakeholder for money wagered on horses on Nov. 26, two weeks after the Legislature repealed a law making stakeholding a misdemeanor.

Resumption of work at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn and on other vital defense construction by striking members of Electrical Workers Union, Local 3, was predicted yesterday as a result of the intervention of Sidney Hillman, co-director of the Office of Production Management in Washington.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The House voted today, 203 to 168, to take up the $3,529,200,000 defense revenue bill under a "semi-closed" rule which will permit an outright vote on whether to delete the mandatory joint income tax return for husbands and wives.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- A license permitting the Japanese liner Tatuta Maru to withdraw funds needed to pay for fuel required to return to Japan was granted by the Committee of Treasury, State and Justice Department officials responsible for the administration of the foreign fund freezing orders.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Hinting that Japanese "fishing" activities in Hawaiian waters were a blind for espionage work, Elmer L. Irey, chief coordinator of Treasury law enforcement agencies, today termed the indictment of 71 Japanese and three Honolulu fishing companies in March as the most important case developed during the last fiscal year.
LONDON, July 30 (U.P.) -- Harry

OTTAWA, July 30 (Canadian Press) -- The Duke of Kent, who is in Canada to inspect operation of the British Commonwealth Air Training Plan and other phases of the war effort, will leave Ottawa Sunday afternoon on his tour of Western Canada, it was announced tonight.

Though titles of thirty-six story properties are listed for production during the 1941-42 season, Gradwell L. Sears, general sales manager for Warner Brothers, did not commit the studio to any definite number of films in announcing the product schedule yesterday at the closing session of Warners' annual sales convention at the Blackstone Hotel in Chicago.

ANNISQUAM, Mass., July 30 -- The contestants in the Massachusetts State tuna tournament are convinced that the Ipswich Bay bluefins are one with the balm in Gilead, for here it is deadline time and no fish hanging on the rack at the dock.

PITTSBURGH, July 30 (AP) -- The Braves defeated Pittsburgh, 3 to 2, tonight in an exciting ten-inning game in which Big Jim Tobin held his former Pirate teammates to a lone hit for seven innings, then almost was beaten.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Four committees composed of thirty-three educators and other prominent persons were appointed by President Roosevelt today to advise the government on planning and executing the program to improve cultural relations with Latin-American nations.

VICHY, France, July 30 -- While little is happening in Vichy -- at least on the surface -- the Paris press is attacking the government with constantly increasing violence, but with arguments that do not vary from one paper to another.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in Washington that because of a decision handed down in Albany on Monday by the Court of Appeals the city will "have full charge of all the activities" of the Free Trade Zone on Staten Island.

CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) -- Mrs. Monte Weil's English Harry, stouthearted son of Mowlee-Honesty, set all the pace in the two miles and a furlong of the Mike Hall Purse over the grass course at Arlington Park today, and at the end had enough left to beat J.C. Lewis's Dark Phaona by a head.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered five companies manufacturing pins, paper clips and fasteners used as office supplies to cease and desist from a combination or agreement "which results in price fixing and other practices."
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Howard Bruce have come to the Ambassador from their home in Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Senator Connally of Texas, veteran of two wars who holds that "a vigorous and firm foreign policy is essential to secure respect for our rights abroad and the security of our people at home," was designated chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today.

Operations of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company in the second quarter this year resulted in a net income of $1,793,108 after all charges, including $1,420,000 provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes, equal to $1.01 a share on 1,776,091 shares of nopar capital stock.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial and many press opinions commenting upon the American President's order to freeze Japanese funds express the belief that this is the turning point of American policy toward Japan, the beginning of a "positive" policy and the end of appeasement.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress on price controls follows:
Rallies in the final hour checked the sagging tendency of stock prices and wiped out most of the earlier losses. The closing was mixed, with rubber stocks the best performers.
BERLIN, July 30 (AP) -- The High Command issued this communique today:

Net income of the Continental Oil Company and its subsidiaries for the quarter ended on June 30, amounted to $2,642,082, after taxes and all deductions, according to the report issued for publication today. The result is equivalent to 56 cents a share on 4,682,267 capital shares and compares with $1,007,852 or 22 cents a share for the 1940 quarter.

CHUNGKING, China, July 30 (U.P.) -- Japanese bombs today slightly damaged the United States gunboat Tutuila of the Yangtze River patrol, endangered the American Embassy and other Anierican-owned properties, and caused many casualties in what probably were the heaviest air raids Chungking has undergone.
SAIGON, French Indo-Chin, July 30 (AP) -- Japanese troops poured by the thousands into congested Saigon harbor and into Cap St. Jacques, at the mouth of the Saigon River, today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 30 -- The Town of Mount Pleasant and residents of the Valhalla area applied today to Justice Graham Witschief in Supreme Court here for an injunction against further operation of a private airport on a 185-acre plateau adjoining Valhalla.

Several executives in the Welfare Department were favored by having the qualifications for civil service examinations tailored to their own background and experience, the City Council investigating committee was told yesterday by Edward W. Williams, a former executive in the department.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The United Gas Improvement Company was ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to divest itself of ownership and control of thirteen non-utility subsidiaries which were found to be "not reasonably incidental or economically necessary or appropriate to the operations of any system retainable by the company."

The Book-of-the-Month Club's selection of John Gunther's "Inside Latin America" as a reserve title will mean that Harper's will not bring out the book on Oct. 1 as planned. The book club's schedule is complete through October, so that the earliest date on which the study could be released is November.
MOSCOW, Thursday, July 31 (AP) -- Heavy German losses in men and materials in the raging Battle of Smolensk were reported by the Soviet Information Bureau today.

In the deserted "open spaces" at Belmont Park race track, two New York City truck drivers won local championships in the first "truck roadeo" held in the metropolitan area. Both will compete this afternoon at the same place for State titles.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- A two-run rally in the ninth inning, climaxed by Cecil Travis's double into deep left field, gave the Senators a 7-6 victory over the Indians tonight. Bobby Feller, trying for his twentieth victory of the season, was removed for a pinch hitter in the ninth after yielding nine blows.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 -- Bank employes from three States were called as witnesses by the government today in an attempt to trace five $1,000 bills from William Fox, former motion picture producer, to J. Warren Davis, retired Federal Circuit Court judge, as part of an unsecured loan which was made, the government charges, to win judicial favors.

LONDON, July 30 -- The exiled Government of Poland today signed a long awaited agreement with the Soviet Union in the British Foreign Office. Prime Minister Winston Churchill presided over the brief ceremony.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- The railroads asked the National Railway Mediation Board tonight to take charge of their dispute with the "Big Five" operating brotherhoods over the railroads' request for revision of rules governing working conditions and methods of establishing wases.

President Roosevelt's proposal for virtually over-all control of commodity prices was received with reluctant approval by many business men yesterday, even though they are traditionally opposed to any extensions of government controls over business.

BOSTON, July 30 -- At today's bid opening on 1,000,008 pairs of service shoes at the local Army base, manufacturers asked prices on leather-soled footwear averaging about 6 cents per pair higher than those at which contracts for a similar quantity were awarded late in June.

Reacting sharply to President Roosevelt's request to Congress for broad price-control legislation, the cotton market sustained yesterday the widest break since March 11, 1935. At the day's lows prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were $3.60 to $5.30 a bale below Tuesday's close and $5 to $6.15 below the highs set in the first hour.

A suite of ten rooms and four baths in the building at 920 Fifth Avenue has been leased by Colonel John J. Watts, chairman of the board of directors of the Mason Hanger Co., Inc., contractors, through the Carpenter Realty Company and Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc.

Two new films will reach Broadway screens today. At the Capitol, Metro's "Ringside Maisie," the latest in the "Maisie" series, which again stars Ann Sothern in the title role, will be the newcomer. Directed by Edward L. Marin, the romantic comedy features George Murphy, Robert Sterling, Virginia O'Brien and Maxie Rosenbloom.
LONDON, July 30 -- A definite warning that Japan's new move southward might lead to war was given by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in the House of Commons today.

Real estate men in the New York district expressed little surprise at President Roosevelt's special message to Congress yesterday asking for control of rents, since he and other Federal officials were reported previously to have suggested to the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply that studies be made looking to that end.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Statistics on income of newspaper-owned and other radio stations, indicating that the former were in the aggregate the more profitable, were challenged as "misleading" before the Federal Communications Commission today by attorneys for newspaper-affiliated stations.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 -- Operations were suspended at the Courtland Division mill of the Gotham Silk Hosiery Company tonight, officials stated, because of the government order freezing silk earmarked for the company in warehouses in this country.

Clifton Webb will portray the leading male role in Noel Coward's "Blithe Spirit," now described as a farce, it was announced yesterday by John C. Wilson, who intends to bring the play to Broadway early in November. Before arriving here, the attraction will be given a practice whirl out of town for three or four weeks.

Japanese Bonds The market for Japanese dollar bonds yesterday again reflected the uncertainty, if not apprehension, over the payment of interest and sinking fund requirements under the license system. It now appears to be not a question of how anxious or willing the Japanese Government is to continue full service on its obligations but rather how the special licenses applied for by the paying agents will be treated by the Federal authorities.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Securities registered under the Securities Act in the first six months of 1941 aggregated $1,384,726,000, or almost 54 per cent more than in the same period of 1940, when they were $898,471,000, the trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

As the German war machine continued locked with tremendous Russian forces in a still indecisive battle on the Eastern Front yesterday, moves in two other far-flung theatres of war modified slightly the strategical picture.
Thomas E. Dewey, the first reform District Attorney Manhattan has had since the days of Whitman and Jerome, announced yesterday that he was not a candidate for re-election.

TARTUS, Lebanon, July 30 -- The most influential element of the Vichy forces, which were beaten and brought to sign a convention for the cessation of military operations more than a fortnight ago, are still doing their best to keep up an uncompromising and even hostile spirit toward the British and particularly the Free French.

LONDON, July 30 (U.P.) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden revealed today that Britain has warned Iran against the menace of "excessively large numbers of Germans" in that country and urged the Iranian Government to move at once to stamp out the danger.

Dr. Diogenes Escalante, Venezuelan Ambassador to the United States, arriving here yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Rosa after a two-and-a-half months leave, expressed opposition to a proposal by Senator D. Worth Clark of Idaho that this country take over control of Latin America and Canada.

Two months after its purchase from the estate of Iona Nicol, the five-story American basement dwelling at 149-51 East Seventy-eighth Street has been resold by Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, to a client of Raymond D. O'Connell, attorney.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 30 -- Mayor Frank Hague, in a new statement issued today in his controversy with Governor Edison, declared:
LONDON, July 30 -- Remember the handkerchief your mother used to pin to your dress when you were a child? This childhood precaution is the latest fashion for grown-ups in England.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Formal representations were made to the Japanese Government by the United States today over the bombing of the American gunboat Tutuila at Chungking, China.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 30 -- After visions of Japanese concentration camps had kept American passengers anxious for six days, the liner Tatuta Maru docked here this afternoon.

The Studebaker Corporation reports a net profit of $1,313,877 for the first half of 1941, equal to 59 cents a share on its capital stock, against $957,309, or 43 cents a share, in the 1940 period. For the second quarter net income was $1,133,418, or 51 cents a share, against $445,806, or 20 cents a share, in 1940.
