The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and the National Broadcasting Company were reported last night to be near agreement terminating the dispute that has kept ASCAP music off the NBC networks since Jan. 1.

A large suite of offices on the twenty-fifth floor of the building at 551 Fifth Avenue has been leased by Louis A. Roselaar, importer and cutter of diamonds, whose cutting plant is at 93 Nassau Street. Mr. Roselaar is the fourth generation of his family to be identified with the diamond industry.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Warning that the nation's 1941 traffic fatalities would exceed 40,000 for an all-time high mark unless the trend was checked, the National Safety Council today announced that the automobile accident toll for six months was 16,810.

LONDON, July 30 -- The economic warfare waged by Great Britain around the world has been far more efficient over the last six months, owing to the increasing measure of support received from the United States, it was said here today.

27 Years Ago From the course of events in Cochrane vs. Zivic and in Attention vs. Whirlaway, what is one permitted to hope in the case of Nazi vs. Russian around Smolensk? The well-informed reader hardly needs to be told that a pugilist named Cochrane night before last took the welterweight championship away, from a man named Zivic, though the odds were 4 to 1 against Cochrane.

California camembert is a credit to America in the opinion of a distinguished Manhattan banker who is largely responsible for the presence of a very special cheese in this city. Made on the sunny coast by a gentleman from Bordeaux with machinery imported from his former French factory, the little cakes are as creamy and crusty and utterly delicious as anything ever eaten in the city of light and laughter.

MOSCOW, July 30 -- Harry L. Hopkins, declaring that "anybody who fights Hitler anywhere is on the right side," tonight offered Premier Joseph Stalin an immediate flow of United States war supplies to aid Russia's fight against Germany's armies.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 29:

PEIPING, China, July 30 (AP) -- The conviction that Japan is preparing for a great assault on Soviet Siberia if the Red Army is smashed by Adolf Hitler's legions is growing in informed Chinese circles in Peiping.

Further rate advances by Brazilian newspapers next year, following a large number of increases this year, were predicted in the first number of a monthly bulletin issued by Cicero Leuenroth, director of Empreza de Propaganda Standard, Ltd., Rio de Janeiro agency, and received here yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 30 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East communique said:

MOSCOW, July 30 -- After an eight-day journey through the Armenian, Georgian, Azerbaijan and Daghestan Republics, across the Northern Caucasus, along the Don River basin and into the Western Ukraine and Central Russia, this correspondent is convinced that a great part of the Soviet wheat crop is already harvested.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- A 3.4 percent rise in the cost of living in the last three months was said by government statisticians today to have been one of the major reasons why President Roosevelt asked Congress to pass price-control legislation.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- President Roosevelt warned Congress in a special message today that "we face inflation unless we act decisively and without delay," and requested broad statutory authority for the establishment of ceilings on prices and rents and to curb excesses in the field of installment credit.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 30 -- Countess Laszlo Szeohenyi, Mrs. Richard P. Strong, Mrs. William R. Hunter and Mrs. E.S.R. Brandt will be hostesses on Friday afternoon at the reception and tea opening an exhibition by local artists and artist members at the Art Association.

A nation-wide reduction in passenger train service is in view as a result of a survey started by the railroads of the country, it became known yesterday. The reduction is being studied because of a shortage of steel with which to make passenger cars.

Senator Wheeler and Secretary Stimson must each feel a little better today, the Senator because Mr. Stimson has apologized for certain statements, and the Secretary perhaps for the same reason. The Secretary intimated in his press release of July 24 that the Senator had "circularized soldiers in the training camps" and that this action "came very near the line of subversive activities against the United States, if not treason."

SEAGIRT, N.J., July 30 -- Governor Charles Edison, whose appeal for a legislative call for a constitutional convention fell on deafears in the Legislature last Monday night when he appeared before a joint session of the two bodies, disclosed today that he is considering the calling of a convention by proclamation.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- President Roosevelt in a message to Congress requested authority to establish ceilings for prices and rents to combat inflation. He nominated Rexford Guy Tugwel to be Governor of Puerto Rico.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP) -- Sam Chapman smacked a home run with one on in the eleventh inning tonight to give the Athletics a 5 to 3 victory over Chicago after the White Sox had tied the ball game in the ninth with a two-run rally.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., July 30 (U.P.) -- Four new signals for football officials to use in notifying the spectators and the press box of rule violations during a football game will be seen on most collegiate gridirons this Fall.

SHANGHAI, July 30 -- German commercial firms in Shanghai, which have been sending to Germany war materials assembled from nearly all Far Eastern countries, are facing bankruptcy. A month before the outbreak of the Soviet-German war, German shipments valued at more than $60,000,000 were sidetracked on Soviet railways and were confiscated following the outbreak of war.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission announced formally today that four combination passenger-cargo ships originally ordered to augment the "Good Neighbor Fleet," have been acquired by the Navy.

THE Ty Cobb-Babe Ruth golf scores are something to put away and forget. Ty proved to be slightly the better golfer, but the road company competition demonstrated that Craig Wood, Sam Snead and Ben Hogan need not shiver in their golfing shoes in fear of fierce competition from the old diamond heroes.

SINGAPORE, Straits Settlements, July 30 (U.P.) -- British Empire forces in Malaya are prepared to move against any Japanese threat against Thailand as well as the Netherlands Indies, it was indicated strongly today.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Rexford Guy Tugwell of New York was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be Governor of Puerto Rico. He will succeed Guy J. Swope, who resigned to become Director of the Division of Territories and Island Possessions.

The arrest yesterday of two men, one alleged to be a policy banker and the other a controller, by policemen who posed as taxicab drivers broke up what the police described as the largest policy bank to be operated in the city since the death of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, who is reported to have received more than $50,000 a day.

The three-story industrial building at 5-19 Forty-seventh Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by Thomas Ruth to Samuel T. Kantor, manufacturer of printing inks. The C. Grant Keck Organization was the broker, George C. Butler acted for the seller and Myers Sherwin were attorneys for the new owner.

BERLIN, July 30 (AP) -- British torpedo planes and fighters launched from an aircraft carrier in the Arctic Ocean attacked a northern Norwegian port in coordination with assaults by Russian planes today, but the raid was "shattered completely" with twenty-eight British craft destroyed, the official German radio and news agency reported tonight.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, July 31 (U.P.) -- More British and American business concerns throughout China are reported to have been taken into "protective custody" by Japanese. If there is a severance in economic relations, British and American business interests in areas of China controlled by Japan and the Nanking Government will be destroyed.

Reginald Thomas, 41 years old, a Negro, was to be sentenced yesterday in General Sessions for the stabbing of a patrolman five years ago in a Communist demonstration in Harlem, but Judge John J. Freschi had to defer action until today.

The provision in the defense revenue bill for a mandatory joint income tax return is assailed by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in a letter made public yesterday by John C. Jackson, president of the New York State Bar Association.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, July 31 -- Driving forward in a series of successful operations, Russian troops continued to pound the German positions in the Smolensk, Zhitomir and Novorzhev areas yesterday in the fifth day of their counter-offensive against the German mechanized divisions trying to push toward Moscow, Kiev and Leningrad, according to reports received here.
HILLSIDE, N.J., July 30 (AP) -- Freddie (Red) Cochrane, the new welterweight boxing champion, was notified today by his local draft board to appear for physical examination tomorrow.

A.E. Staley Manufacturing Company, Decatur, Ill., filed yesterday with, the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington a registration statement covering the proposed offering of 4,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock, $5 series of no-par value, and 50,000 shares of common stock of $10 par value.

In the present stage of our defense program governmental price-fixing has unfortunately become unavoidable. But it is of the first importance that we recognize from the very beginning its true place among our economic controls. It would be senseless, for example, to begin placing ceilings on prices without considering first of all what causes prices to rise and what the effect of fixing them has upon our defense effort and our whole economy.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 30 -- Although bombed every two hours and shelled between times, the Tobruk garrison finds that its chief worry is a shortage of beer, an officer just back from the isolated town said today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 30 -- Dr. and Mrs. D. Phillip MacGuire entertained with a luncheon today at their home for Colonel Edward R. Bradley and his siste, Mrs. Katherine Bailey; Mr. and Mrs. James Butler Jr., William Barnes, Miss Beatrice Batler MacGuire and Stuart MacGuire.

Rain washed the Yankees out of a single game with the Tigers at the Stadium yesterday into a double-header with the Bengals today. The first contest will start at 1:30 P.M. Detroit will strive to hand the Bronx Bombers their third and fourth defeats in a row.

The provision in the defense revenue bill for a mandatory joint income tax return is assailed by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in a letter made public yesterday by John C. Jackson, president of the New York State Bar Association.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, July 31 -- Driving forward in a series of successful operations, Russian troops continued to pound the German positions in the Smolensk, Zhitomir and Novorzhev areas yesterday in the fifth day of their counter-offensive against the German mechanized divisions trying to push toward Moscow, Kiev and Leningrad, according to reports received here.
HILLSIDE, N.J., July 30 (AP) -- Freddie (Red) Cochrane, the new welterweight boxing champion, was notified today by his local draft board to appear for physical examination tomorrow.

A.E. Staley Manufacturing Company, Decatur, Ill., filed yesterday with, the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington a registration statement covering the proposed offering of 4,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock, $5 series of no-par value, and 50,000 shares of common stock of $10 par value.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Mrs. John L. Whitehurst of Baltimore, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, said today that women were discriminated against in the civilian defense program.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 30 -- Dr. and Mrs. D. Phillip MacGuire entertained with a luncheon today at their home for Colonel Edward R. Bradley and his siste, Mrs. Katherine Bailey; Mr. and Mrs. James Butler Jr., William Barnes, Miss Beatrice Batler MacGuire and Stuart MacGuire.

Rain washed the Yankees out of a single game with the Tigers at the Stadium yesterday into a double-header with the Bengals today. The first contest will start at 1:30 P.M. Detroit will strive to hand the Bronx Bombers their third and fourth defeats in a row.

Ladenburg, Thalmann Co., as special agent, has notified holders of city of Porto Alegre, Brazil, forty-year 7 per cent bonds that sufficient funds have been deposited to make a payment of 13.325 per cent of the face amount of the coupons due on Feb. 1, 1939, amounting to $4.66 3/8 for each $35 coupon and $2.33-3-16 for each $17.50 coupon.

INWOOD, L.I., July 31 -- Henry Osten of Garden City, first-seeded entrant, gained the final in the boys' division of the metropolitan boys' and junior tennis championships by defeating Lynton Baldwin of Brooklyn, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 0, at the Inwood Country Club today.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 31 -- In one of the major upheavals of the season, Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Cooke of New York and Miss Virginia Wolfenden of San Francisco were eliminated today from the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club.

The cotton market ended the 1940-41 season yesterday on a note of pessimism, as prices of both spots and futures tumbled 30 points, extending the losses incurred in the last three days to more than 1 cent a pound. Declining 27 to 35 points on the day, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange have showed total losses of $5.55 to $6.10 a bale since Monday.

A group headed by Lazard Freres Co. received yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,000,000 city of Waterbury, Conn., on a bid of 100.737 for 1 1/2. The bonds, dated July 1, 1941, and maturing serially July 1, 1953 to 1956, were reoffered at prices to yield from 1.30 to 1.40 per cent, according to maturity.

MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 1 -- Strong Red Army counter-attacks have hurled back the German invaders with heavy losses in the bitterly contested Smolensk approach to Moscow, the Soviet Information Bureau reported today.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 31 -- Governor Charles Edison expressed displeasure toward the Republican-controlled Legislature today when he signed a measure appropriating $25,000 for the investigation of the State Highway Department, just half of what he had requested.

TOKYO, July 31 (AP) -- The highest officials of Japan's Foreign Ministry cast aside diplomatic routine today to make a full and hurried apology to the United States for the Chungking bombing of the United States gunboat Tutuila -- even before such an apology had been formally demanded.

Reports that the Japanese steamer Tatuta Maru, which docked in San Francisco Wednesday, would clear for home without unloading brought consternation to a score of importers here who have shipments of general merchandise on the vessel.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., July 31 -- Long Island Sound was just a blank today, with no wind whatever and its gray waters blended by heat into the same-colored horizon. As a result, not a race could be held in the Syce Cup series for the women's yachting championship of that body of water.

LENOX, Mass., July 31 -- The Berkshire Symphonic Festival swung into its eighth year tonight, a secure and going concern. Nor rain, nor threat of it, nor wet roads could stay it from beginning the new season with a full house. For the first time since the festival began every reserved seat for the opening concert had been sold days before the event.

New securities offered to the public here in July aggregated $254,124,000, of which $228,698,000 represented forty-one bond issues and $25,426,000 eight stock issues. These figures compared with emissions totaling $210,052,000 in June, this year, when $194,501,000 was accounted for by fifty-five bond issues and $15,551,000 by nine stock offerings.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 31 -- Visiting women tennis players, who are here to take part in the fifteenth annual women's invitation tournament for, the gold cups donated by the late Secretary of the Treasury William H. Woodin, were dinner guests tonight at the Maidstone Club of Mrs. Russell Hopkinson, Dr. A.E. Neergaard and other members of the club's tennis committee.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The manpower of the Army has now reached 1,506,500 officers and enlisted men, or more than double the figure of Jan. 30, Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, announced today. He also said that the health of the Army was better than at any time since the present emergency began.

SALEM, N.H., July 31 (AP) -- Jockey Jimmy Lynch came through on the rail inside the last sixteenth of a mile today to score with Robespierre in the featured Alton, a $5,000 claiming event, at Rockingham Park.

Fox Fur Jackets Advanced Advances in fur garments continued yesterday and prices of fox jackets formerly wholesaled at $42.50 moved up to $47.50 with some producers. Others formerly priced at $89.50 were advanced to $97.50.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 1 (U.P.) -- The government information board spokesman announced today that Japan and Thailand had signed an economic agreement whereby the latter will extend to Japan credits of 10,000,000 bahts [about 15,000,000 yen.]

Closings of hosiery mills for lack of raw silk supplies are not likely to become numerous in the near future, according to market opinion yesterday. The closing of one of the plants of Gotham Silk Hosiery Company resulted from a special situation which is not general in the industry, according to Roy E. Tilles, president of the concern.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 31 -- Mrs. F.J. Holleran of the Greenwich Country Club won low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's West-Chester and Fairfield Golf Association when she toured the Country Club of Fairfield course in 40, 45 -- 85 today.

Reporting the company's largest gross volume of business during the six and twelve months ended on June 30, 1941, A.E. Duncan, chairman of the board of the Commercial Credit Company, said yesterday that the consolidated gross volume for the first six months this year rose to $557,493,639 from $416,712,086 in the same period of 1940.
The Bay Ridge, Flatbush, Park Slope, Bensonhurat and downtown areas shared in the Brooklyn realty activity reported yesterday, when a number of three-story residential buildings went into new hands.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The United States should make a choice now between a decision to help defeat Germany by a long war, lasting probably five years, or a decision to try to overwhelm the Nazis by means of a short war to end in 1943, says Louis Marlio, French economist, in a booklet issued today by the Brookings Institution.

LONDON, July 31 (AP) -- Major Sir Herbert Paul Latham, 36 years old, graduate of Eton and Oxford and Conservative Yorkshire Member of the House of Commons, who lives in modernity in a "haunted" castle, has been arrested under military law, it was announced today with Parliamentary formality.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- President Roosevelt discussed today with Constantine A. Oumansky, the Soviet Ambassador, and the Russian military mission now in this country the Russian military situation and United States aid to the Soviet Union.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 31 -- Robert L. Riggs, Frank Kovacs, Gardnar Mulloy and Ted Schroeder gained their alloted brackets in the semi-finals of the Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club today, but that was only to be expected.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Miscellaneous contract awards totaling $12,978,869, were announced today by the War Department. Exclusive of construction awards, concerns in the New York area received the following contracts, not previously published:

Loring M. Hewen, vice president of Wm. A. White Sons, brokers, has purchased from the Home Life Insurance Company and will occupy an estate on Chicken Valley Road, adjoining the grounds of the Piping Rock Club, Locust Valley, Nassau County.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: According to a recent statement by the New York Safety Council, New Yorkers form a community of jay walkers. The council in making its report of motor vehicle fatalities to this city stresses the fact that more than one-half of the persons killed were crossing streets against lights or at other than designated intersections.

More and more the stock market is dividing itself into sections, seldom advancing or declining as a whole. "Mixed" has become the most popular word in the glossary of market analysis. Yesterday, for example, stocks closed "easier and mixed," and yet not a single one of the ten most active issues lost ground.

CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- Arlington Park closed its highly successful thirty-four-day meeting today with a smashing five-length victory for the bargain thoroughbred of the year -- Alsab, a juvenile surprise purchased by Albert Sabath, Chicago attorney, for $700 a year ago.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- Interest in wheat futures was at a minimum today with traders awaiting further developments in regard to the agricultural bills now before Congress. Prices on the Board of Trade here held within a range of slightly less than 1 cent a bushel and closed near the bottom with losses of 1/8 to 1/2 cent, the latter on the September which went to 2 1/8 cents under the December.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (U.P.) -- Office of Production Management officials predicted today that iron and steel would be rationed "in early August" to assure defense industries adequate supplies.

LONDON, July 31 -- Damages of one farthing -- the smallest coin made in Britain -- were awarded in King's Bench Court today by Justice Sir Cyril Atkinson to Archibald Henry Maule Ramsey in a libel suit against the New York Times Company of New York and the New York Times, Ltd., of London.
Stores were leased by several retail enterprises in midtown hotels and apartment buildings in transactions made known yesterday.

"Please hurry; the President is waiting," was the message that greeted the visitor at the threshold of the Catete Palace in Rio de Janeiro, causing him to gallop up the winding, red-carpeted stairway to the evident relief of the relay of anxious attendants at successive levels.

MADRID, July 31 (U.P.) -- Spanish Fascists accused the United States today of plotting to muster a Spanish Republican army under General Jose Miaja for possible use in the event that the United States attempted to occupy the Canary Islands.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. yesterday began a citywide drive against unlicensed repossessors of automobiles, whom he characterized as racketeers who annually repossess 20,000 cars illegally at a cost to New Yorkers of $1,000,000.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, July 31 -- A fully equipped Japanese Army of crack troops; obviously ready for action and taking nothing for granted, formally occupied Saigon today and with smart precision took up strategic positions.

His face redesigned toy plastic surgery beyond recognition, Jacob (Kuppy) Migden, accused of having pointed the erring Singer in the "mistaken identity" murder of Irving Penn in the Bronx two years ago, was captured in St. Louis and flown here yesterday to face a first-degree murder charge.

SKINNERS CORNER, Va., July 31 -- Outnumbered three to one, a small "Red" army commanded by Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf kept the main body of the Forty-fourth Division engaged today in a mock battle which is a field inspection of the Forty-fourth by G.H.Q.

TORONTO, July 31 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs beat Newark, 5 -- 4, tonight in the opener of a fourgame series. Singles by Merullo and Morgan and Johnny Hill's outfield fly provided the winning margin in the ninth inning at the expense of Fred Johnson.

BRUNNEN, Switzerland, July 31 -- In the middle of a war-torn and apprehensive Europe Switzerland tonight began to celebrate her "Independence Day" -- the day on which 650 years ago thirty-three men gathered in the Ruetli glade to create the nucleus around which grew the country of Switzerland and to swear loyalty to one another and the determination to fight for their most precious heritage -- individual freedom.
A BOOKISH doctor's thesis, or perhaps a book column for a Summer day, might be written about the books that are read and mentioned and discussed in contemporary books.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: This morning I have read a letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES under the heading "West Point Methods Criticized," which was signed by Herbert S. Sackler.
MONTREAL, July 31 (AP) -- The Royals ended Roy Henshaw's six-game winning streak tonight with a 5-3 victory over Jersey City to tighten their grip on third place in the International League standing.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 31--Reports circulating in foreign military circles here tonight said that an undesignated number of German troops was being moved from the Russian front to Bulgaria. These reports lacked official confirmation.
MOSCOW, July 31 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:

MOSCOW, July 31 (U.P.) -- Harry L. Hopkins, United States leaselend administrator, said tonight, after a three-hour conference with Premier Joseph Stalin concerning United States aid to Russia, that his short visit to Moscow had "added to my confidence that Hitler will lose."

BURLINGTON, Ia., July 31 (AP) -- Vice President Wallace, the nation's new economic defense chief, dedicating an "arsenal of liberty," declared tonight that the United States must show complete willingness to fight, if necessary, if there is to be any chance for peace.

CINCINNATI, July 31 -- What is happening to the Giants these days is no longer comedy. Their plight has become serious. Matters have reached a stage where the club even refuses to accept a game as a gift.
Today is Aug. 1. Sunday ends the sixth week of the Russian campaign.

MEXICO CITY, July 31 (AP) -- Mexico rejected tonight a request from the German Government that the Mexican Government protest to the United States against Washington's blacklist of pro-Axis firms here.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Resolutlons urging speedy and favorable action by the Federal Communications Commission on qualified applications for permits to operate FM radio stations, without prejudice to newspaper interests, were presented at today's FCC hearing by John R. Latham of New York, executive vice president of the American Network, Inc., and by John Shepard 3d of Boston, president of FM Broadcasters, Inc.

Morris U. Schappes, suspended City College tutor, after spending thirty-four days in a Tombs cell, was released yesterday in $10,000 cash bail, to await the outcome of his appeal from his General Sessions conviction for perjury in his testimony betore the Rapp-Coudert Legislative Committee.

LONDON, July 31 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England today showed note circulation had risen another u5,775,000, to a new record of u658,430,000, in the week ended on July 30.
ALBANY, July 31 -- Industrial work training in the program of the Civilian Conservation Corps as "a necessary added spur to defense production" was proposed by the State today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 31 -- In the swamps and tundras of the coastline leading from Petsamo to Murmansk, on the northernmost sector of the Russian-German front, the Germans have actually been compelled to retreat.
Trading in the locally dressed fresh meat markets today was slow on virtually all classes of traefer meats. Steer beef was lower, veal steady, lamb slightly firmer, fresh pork weak to lower.

ST. LOUIS, July 31 -- Smarting from their futile performances in two games here, the Dodgers today burst out in a rash of extra base hits, beat the Cardinals, 9 -- 5, and left later for Chicago again only two games back of the National League leaders.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of Lincoln MacVeagh, who returned recently from his post as Minister to Greece, as the first Minister to Iceland.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 31 -- "Boy Wonder," by Paul Jarrico and Richard Collins, was purchased today by Universal for production by Bruce Manning, successor to Joe Pasternak as the studio's leading producer. Jarrico, who recently wrote "Tom, Dick and Harry" for RKO, and Collins have been engaged to prepare the scenario for November filming and it is expected that Robert Stack will have the title role.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora has leased a large corner apartment in the Apthorp, 390 West End Avenue, where Wood, Dolson Company, Inc., the agents, report that only three units remain vacant out of a total of 145.

The Cities Service Company took steps yesterday to comply with the integration provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act by filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan calling for a complete divestment of its extensive utility holdings.

Leading oil companies, with headquarters in New York, announced last night that they would comply with the request of Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, for the closing of all service stations along the Atlantic seaboard from 7 P.M. to 7 A.M. seven days a week.

While backlogs, shipments, billings, employment and payrolls of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation all reached new high records in the second quarter of 1941, earnings declined as a result of a sharply higher rate of taxation, Eugene G. Grace, president, reported yesterday.

BERLIN, July 31 (U.P.) -- The High Command claimed today that twenty-eight of about forty British planes attacking the Far Northern Norwegian port of Kirkenes yesterday were shot down. German military sources denied knowledge of a British air raid on Petsamo, Finland's main northern port, as reported in London.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Charges were made by Senator Wheeler in the Senate today that the motion picture industry was carrying on propaganda for war and he coupled this assertion with an attack on Wendell L. Willkie for alleged warlike activities.

ANNISQUAM, Mass., July 31 -- With the wind in the south and backing to the east rapidly, the committee in charge of the Massachusetts State tuna tournament decided to postpone the last day of the tournament until tomorrow, and the "No Fishing Day" banner was flown from the weighing-in dock at dawn.

BOSTON, July 31 (AP) -- After losing, 16-11, to the lowly Browns for the seventh straight time, the Red Box rallied behind Rookie Tex Hughson's six-hit pitching today to gain a 4-1 triumph in the night-cap, which was called after the first half of the eighth inning because of darkness.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company reported yesterday to its stockholders that the net profit for the first half of 1941 amounted to $6,247,247, after provision for Federal income taxes. This is equivalent, after preferred stock dividends, to 80 cents a share on the 6,372,786 shares of common stock outstanding, and compares with $4,799,865, or 75 cents a share, for the first half of 1940.
LONDON, July 31 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique today:

Winding up its fourth combination bargain electrical appliance campaign yesterday, Consolidated Edison Company of New York announced that it would start a fifth campaign on Monday which will run as long as the manufacturers can continue to supply the customer demand.
Dividends declared in July were, in the aggregate, the largest for that month since 1937, despite reduced payments by two big corporations.

Asserting that the growing scarcity of scrap steel and pig iron was becoming more and more serious to the steel industry, which may not be able to maintain present rates of production unless new supplies are found, Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said yesterday there was no use in building new steel plants until the problem has been solved.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., July 31 -- A group of 244 employes of Charles Pfizer C., Inc., a New York City chemical manufacturing concern, received bequests totaling $237,000 in the will of the late Emile Pfizer of Gladstone, N.J., former president of the company.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- The Phillies knocked Charley Root out of the box in the three-run second inning today and beat the Cubs, 7 to 2, to earn an even break in the four-game series.

"Charley's Aunt," Twentieth Century Fox's remake of the Brandon Thomas stage comedy with Jack Benny in the title role, will have its local premiere this morning at the Roxy. Kay Francis, James Ellison, Anne Baxter, Edmund Gwenn, Reginald Owen, Laird Cregar, Arleen Whelan and Richard Haydn have supporting roles in the comedy, which was directed by Archie Mayo. . . . "The Bride Came C.O.D." will begin its second week today at the Strand.

Samuel Elkind, who recently bought the eight-story building at 377 Fourth Avenue from the Dry Dock Savings Institution, resold it yesterday to the Fourth Avenue Estates, Inc. Adams Co. were the brokers in both deals.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 26 amounted to 897,399 cars, the association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,971 cars or 0.2 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, but 179,361 cars, or 25.0 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 241,868 cars, or 36.9 per cent, more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Congressional tax authorities said today that newspapers and radio stations were specifically exempted from excise taxes proposed in the new tax bill on leased wires and long distance telephone calls, provided that they use these facilities either for the collection or dissemination of news.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Final details of the Treasury's plan to issue two series of tax anticipation notes which were announced today indicated that the income derived from them would be subject to an Federal taxes, present and future, and estate, inheritance, gift or other excise taxes, whether Federal or State, but not to other taxation on principal or interest by any State, possession or local taxing authority.

CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- Reductions in receipts brought stronger prices only to heavy butchers today as light and medium weight hogs sold at weak to 10-cent lower values, but failed to halt the downward trend in cattle prices. Lamb values were steady to slightly higher.
PITTSBURGH, July 31 (AP) -- The Braves scored seven runs in the eighth and ninth innings today but failed to catch the Pirates, who won by 9 to 8.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31 -- Many small parties were given last night at the dinner dances at the Saratoga Lake Club-house. Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt was host at Piping Rock. Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lustig of New York and Mr. and Mrs. Warren Wright of Chicago entertained at Arrowhead Inn.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The 45-calibre automatic pistol of the Army will be virtually displaced by a new weapon, a semi-automatic carbine, in what Secretary Stimson called today, "one of the most significant changes of weapons for the Army that has ever taken place."

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The bombing of the United States gunboat Tutuila at Chungking, China, by Japanese airplanes yesterday was declared a closed incident tonight when the Japanese Government officially expressed its regret and offered to pay for the damage done.

LONDON, July 31 -- Emergence of Premier General Wladyslas Sikorski as the strong man of Poland has apparently followed in the wake of the signing of the agreement between his government-in-exile here and the Soviet Government.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- New business placed with manufacturers and manufacturers' deliveries reached record heights in June, according to a report today by the Department of Commerce.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., estimates its earnings for the second quarter ended on July 5,1941, at $1,904,000 after interest and all charges including provision for all Federal taxes, normal Federal income taxes being computed at 30 per cent, according to a report issued yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 31 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

The tale the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets has to tell about the prices we will pay for this week-end's meals is none too cheerful. Eggs of both grades have gone up still another cent. Grade A whites are selling now for an average of 48 cents a dozen, with the range 45 to 57 cents, while Grade B mixed eggs have risen to a 37 cents average.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- From a reporter's note-book, on the third day within a week when Acting Secretary of State Welles went outside the diplomatic dictionary to encourage the belief in Tokyo that our Far Eastern policy of appeasement is ended:
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Adams Jr. of Boston are at the Ritz-Carlton.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- All gasoline filling stations in thirteen Atlantic Coast States, the District of Columbia and in parts of four other States, including New York, are expected to close every night between 7 P.M. and 7 A.M., starting next Sunday, under a recommendation issued today by Harold L. Ickes, Defense Petroleum Co-ordinator and supported by the oil industry.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 31 -- The first attempt by Enoch L. (Nucky) Johnson to upset the verdict of a jury which found him guilty last week of evading income tax payments in 1936 and 1937 ended in failure today when Judge Albert B. Maris of the United States Circuit Court denied a motion for a new trial.

Last March Fred Steinman, 42-year-old bricklayer, of Queens Village, was sentenced to jail for reckless driving and fleeing from the scene when the automobile he was driving struck and injured a 5-year-old girl, Ann Schumacher, of 155-103 230th Street, St. Albans, Queens, while she was playing on the sidewalk near her home.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- President Roosevelt elevated Vice President Wallace today to a key post in the defense organization when he created an Economic Defense Board and made the Vice President head of it.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., July 31 -- Two pictures of one soldier, taken a year apart, will come fairly near telling the story of the Ninth Division, which celebrates its first anniversary tomorrow with all of official North Carolina in attendance when the division passes in review for the fourth and last time before Major Gen. Jacob L. Devers, who leaves the following day to assume command of the Armored Force of the United States Army.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 31 -- The right of Mayor Frank Hague and his four fellow City Commissioners here to spend city funds for advertising their opposition to the recently enacted railroad tax compromise bills will be contested Monday by Judge Ashley B. Carrick of the Fourth Criminal Court here.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 31 -- A widespread plot for seizing national and provincial government by a sudden insurrection was discovered by the police in Parana, capital of the Province of Entre Rios, according to various newspaper reports reaching here.

AMSTERDAM, (Via Berlin), July 31 -- Dutch-Indian issues on the Bourse were weak today on the situation in the Far East. Royal Dutch lost 3 3/4 to 238 7/8, Amsterdam trading was off 7 1/2 to 410 and Amsterdam Rubber 7 to 262 1/4. Domestic industrials were irregular.

A bronze plaque dedicated to Hugo Blumenthal, "in grateful recognition of his many years of devoted service to the Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing," will be unveiled this afternoon in the main foyer of the school in Ninety-eighth Street near Fifth Avenue, at special ceremonies to be attended by the faculty, graduates and directors of the school, trustees and staff of the hospital, and specially invited guests.

Three suggestions for meeting the threat of "inflation" in the United States are advanced by the National City Bank in the August edition of its bank letter. These are: Reduction in non-defense spending; increased sales of Treasury bonds to individual investors; broadening of the tax system to reach the bulk of consumer incomes.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 -- United States importers, claiming ownership of cargo items aboard the Japanese liner Tatuta Maru, filed libel actions in the Federal District Court of Northern California late today seeking possession of the property.

The oldest free country in the world, Switzerland, celebrates today the six hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the beginnings of its freedom. The simple, homely instincts of the farmers and townspeople around the Lake of Lucerne in 1291 are as fresh and understandable today as they were then.

William Saroyan's hope that the expected influx of visitors to New York would make it worthwhile for him to extend the run of his play, "The Beautiful People," failed to materialize. From the Coast the producer-playwright-director yesterday authorized his local representative.

The Maritime Commission is planning to issue another requisition order within a few days calling for the eventual transfer of four passenger-cargo liners now ordered for the United States Lines, it was reported from Washington last night.

The Navy transport West Point, formerly the luxury liner America, was nearing New York last night at the end of her special "repatriation" voyage, on which she carried to Europe 464 ousted Axis consular officials and their families and returned with a similar group of American "official" families from Axis lands.

Complying with the request of Sidney Hillman, co-director of the Office of Production Management, Electrical Workers Union, Local 3, yesterday ordered 286 striking electricians employed at the navy yard in Brooklyn back to work.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

A six-hour carnival, "too good to interrupt," in the opinion of Borough President Isaacs, was held yesterday in the heart of the garment district Roped off to traffic, Thirty-fifth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, welcomed an army of celebrities and found itself temporarily transformed into a ballroom for jitterbugs.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 -- Paced by Benny McCoy's fourth-inning home run with the bases full, the Athletics routed the White Sox, 9 to 2, today to supplant Chicago in fourth place. This marked the first time in ten seasons Philadelphia has been in the first division of the American League so late in the season.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- General debate in the House over the $3,529,200,000 defense tax bill continued today, with only a brief flurry of denunciation of the provision for mandatory joint returns for married couples to lighten the discussion.

AS was to be expected, Ty Cobb's all-time baseball team, sparkling with American League stars at seven of the eight everyday positions, caused an outburst from the "morgue," Just down the corridor. Around a newspaper shop the "morgue" is where the clipping and reference files and other aids to rapid research are kept handy for consultation.

OTTAWA, July 31 (Canadian Press) -- Notes in circulation increased $4,067,000 to $403,473,000 in the week ended yesterday, the Bank of Canada reported today. Dominion Government deposits decreased $2,960,000 to $24,913,000 while chartered bank deposits increased $20,478,000 to $216,023,000.

One would think that the Russians would not have to try very hard to rise to the level of what the Nazis call "the European rules of war." The European rules, as the Nazis have interpreted them in practice, do not derive from those established by the late Marquis of Queensberry.

Secretary Ickes's recommendation for the closing of gas stations along the Atlantic seaboard from 7 P.M. to 7 A.M. was received gloomily last night by attendants at the city's service stations. Many of them vented their wrath upon Mr. Ickes for giving no thought to the fact that the plan may cause them to lose their jobs.

PEIPING, July 31 (AP) -- The Japanese Army announced through the press today that, because of alleged infiltration of "Chungking agents who are trying to create Japanese-American Incidents in North China," Japanese authorities were taking protective measures regarding American establishments throughout this area.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 30:

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Sales by independent retailers were 20 per cent higher in June than they were in June, 1940, it was reported today by J.C. Capt, Director of the Census. For the first six months of 1941 they were also 20 per cent higher than during the equivalent period last year, this figure being based on reports from 23,558 firms.

Fifty acres on County Line Road, three miles west of Lakewood, N.J., were sold by Robert A. Huntley, trustee, to the J.S. A. Building Company of Brooklyn, which plans to divide the property into five-acre plots and improve each site with a six-room house.

The Manufacturers Trust Company announced yesterday that Justice George E. Brower of the State Supreme Court had approved an agreement made by State Superintendent of Insurance Louis H. Pink whereby the bank would take over by merger the mortgage servicing contracts and trusteeships now held by the Mortgage Corporation of New York.

The Southern Pacific Company announced yesterday that it had repaid $6,000,000 of its debt to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, reducing the amount to $7,000,000, and that it had arranged, subject to approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission, to borrow $20,000,000 from banks to repay the balance of debit to the corporation and to refinance $13,000,000 owed to banks by the road.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 31 -- Here, and doubtless throughout the world, the Battle of Smolensk has become known as a second and much greater Verdun. Information for the most part is fragmentary and contradictory, each of the belligerent capitals giving out its own.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- A priorities order is in preparation which will curb substantially, if not completely, the flow of raw silk into hosiery mills and other civilian manufacture, officials of the Office of Production Management said today.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Non-agricultural employment increased by 484,000 between May and June, and reached a new record of 38,790,000, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins said today.

Slight Biblical Change It is a rare quotation that gets itself quoted correctly, literatim, verbatim and punctuatim. But on the other hand, it does not often happen to anybody to go so far astray as Senator Gillette of Iowa did by the mere change of a single word.

LONDON, Friday, Aug. 1 -- The Royal Air Force stepped up late yesterday its offensive across the Channel and over the Nazi-held coast of Europe -- an offensive resumed in strength Wednesday after a lull because of storms.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Department store sales during the week ended July 26 rose 27 per cent above the corresponding week of 1940, compared with last week's rise of 23 per cent, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. During the four-week period ended July 26 there was an increase of 24 per cent over the similar period last year and for the year up to that date an increase of 15 per cent.

Although trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in July was the heaviest for any month this year, it was the second smallest of any corresponding month in eighteen years. The turnover in stocks, however, for the first seven months of 1941 continued at the dullest pace in twenty-three years, or since 1918.

Richard W. Lawrence, New York City chairman of the United Service Oranizations, announced yesterday that, with many employe group solicitations still incomplete, $3,299,473 of the city-wide quota of $3,500,000 had been raised. Mr. Lawrence spoke at the final gaththering of committee chairmen and campaign workers at a luncheon at the Hotel Commodore.

Continuing a trend of the last few years, publishers this Summer are again bringing out full lists of varied books, doing away with the literary hiatus that once existed, except for light fiction, from Spring to Fall.

An all-Brahms program presented last night at the Lewisohn Stadium, with Jascha Heifetz as soloist, attracted more than 17,000 persons. Hans Wilhelm Steinberg conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for the first time this season at the concert, which undoubtedly would have drawn a larger crowd had the weather not been unsettled.

The Yankees moved out of reverse with such rapidity at the Stadium yesterday that they almost stripped the gears. Having lost two in a row, they turned about and took a pair from the Tigers to the great delight of a gathering of 14,795 and thus increased their lead over the idle Indians to twelve games.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 31 -- A large audience filled the ballroom of The Elms, home of Miss Julia A. Berwind, this afternoon for the piano recital that was given to aid the Refugees of England and the United Service Organizations. The artist was Prince George Chavchavadze, who with his wife, have been visiting Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Prince at Marble House.

Oil Supplies In curious coincidence with Secretary Ickes's order yesterday closing service stations along the Atlantic seaboard for twelve hours daily were the report from Texas that Mexico was demanding additional quantities of gasoline and the statement in Washington that Russia had asked for two United States tankers.
BERLIN, July 31 (AP) -- The German High Command's communique today follows:

BERLIN, July 31 -- It is impossible, on the basis of the military news about developments on the Russian front that was released in Berlin today, to form any accurate judgment as to the progress of the German invasion after its first forty days.

Declaring that fair-trade agreements had proved valuable to both dealers and manufacturers in the drug and other trades, Chris Koch, marketing counsel, urged musical instrument dealers yesterday to write to their suppliers suggesting that the manufacturers put their merchandise on a fair-trade basis.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- A curb on installment selling, to be incorporated in a price-control bill, was explored by President Roosevelt today at a conference with Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Leon Henderson, head of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Federated Department Stores, Inc., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a registration statement covering the issue of 206,630 shares of common stock of no-par value, 75,000 warrants to purchase common stock and 10,000 bearer scrip certificates.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There is little doubt that your recent editorial "Soil Versus Sidewalks" has stimulated much thinking about a situation that is uppermost to the minds of innumerable city dwellers.

WASHINGTON, July 31--June sales by 2,845 wholesalers totaled $272,210,000, 32 per cent higher than a year ago, according to an announcement today by Census Director J.C. Capt. This is the greatest year-to-year gain during the past five years except for the May, 1941, rise, which was also 32 per cent.

Reflecting the rising tide of defense financing and the financing of expanding trade and industry generally, commercial loans of the sixteen regularly weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in this city rose $18,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $2,318,000,000, the highest level in several years.

The value of the agreement signed in London between the Soviet Ambassador and the Polish Government in exile will depend on the spirit in which the details are worked out. It ends the state of war existing since the Russians took possession of more than half of Poland as a result of the Nazi-Soviet pact of 1939 and declares invalid the frontiers established as a result of that deal.
With a record gain of 37.3 per cent reported by cities outside New York, bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday advanced 24.2 per cent over the amount for the corresponding week a year ago.

Representatives of both major parties, and of Fusion groups as well, worked yesterday on the rounding out of borough tickets to supplement the city-wide slates already named, with several distinct developments.

The rush of New York women to stock up on silk hosiery because strained relations with Japan have threatened to shut off silk supplies assumed major proportions yesterday. It had begun in a moderate way on Monday, chiefly in stores catering to the higher income groups, but by yesterday it had spread to department stores handling popular-priced merchandise, shoe chains and small independent specialty stores.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31 -- Dini, the horsemen's jewel of consistency, won again today and once more her praises were ringing.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Far Eastern crisis was a subject of an hour-long conference in the White House late today between President Roosevelt and Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, but from what standpoint was only barely intimated.
MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:

LONDON, July 31--Lashing out in wide-range attacks aimed at impeding the flow of German reinforcements to the Russian front, British air forces today reported destructive blows against two Arctic ports near the Soviet border.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Leo Durocher tossed his three newly acquired players into today's game and their debuts were a mixture of success and failure as the Dodgers beat the Cubs, 5 -- 4, in a free-hitting contest before a ladies' day crowd of 20,947.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 1 -- President Riato Ryti, in an interview with the foreign press today, expressed the wish that "whoever wins this war may have the power and ability to create a better European order," with security for small powers.

BERLIN, Aug. 1 -- The report of the I.G. Farbenindustrie for 1940, issued today, is indicative of the role which the German chemical trust plays in the Reich's war economy. With nominal capitalization of 800,000,000 marks, I.G. Farbenindustrie is not only the largest privately owned corporation in Germany, but also a dominant factor in the production of such strategic materials as synthetic gasoline, nitrogen, rubber, staple fiber and magnesium metal.

Japan has found the going easy in Indo-China. With the cooperation of the French Goverment at Vichy, occupation has proceeded so smoothly that, regardless of the warnings from Washington and London, Japan is apparently preparing the next step in her progress southward.
The decision in the Russian campaign -- that is, the decision as to whether or not Germany is to win a definitive victory before snow flies -- may well be reached in the climactic month of August.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Johnny Vander Meer, double no-hit star of the 1938 season, turned in a two-hit performance against the Braves today to give the Reds a 5 to 1 victory. It was the fourth triumph in a row for the world champions.
President Roosevelt's ban on exports of motor fuel and aviation gasoline will seriously affect Japan, men in the oil trade said last night.

The Newspaper Guild of New York, an affiliate of the C.I.O., has been chosen as the collective bargaining agent for the 587 editorial and news department employes of THE NEW YORK TIMES, a counting of the ballots cast in a recent National Labor Relations Board election disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Miscellaneous contract awards announced today by the War Department totaled $31,428,008.26. Among these were the following, not previously published, exclusive of those for construction which went to concerns in the New York area.

LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 2 -- During daylight yesterday Blenheim bombers of the Royal Air Force's Coastal Command attacked a German convoy off the Belgian coast and, according to the Air Ministry, left one ship of about 2,000 tons burning and sinking.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1 -- Miss Hope Knowles of Philadelphia, victor over Miss Virginia Wolfenden in the quarter-finals, scored another notable triumph today when she defeated Miss Louise Brough, national girls' champion and conqueror of Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Cooke, to gain the final of the invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club with Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles.

Frank S. Hogan, Democratic designee for District Attorney in New York County, is an administrative assistant in District Attorney Thomes E. Dewey's staff and was chief of staff in the Hines case and co-prosecutor with Jacob Grumet, Assistant District Attorney, in the Lekpe case.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by one State and thirty-four municipalities aggregates $6,874,931, compared with $16,306,417 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $37,859,670.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York in commenting yesterday on the further expansion in the volume of bank credit in use in July pointed out that the principal factors continued to be the increases in holdings of United States Government direct and guaranteed securities and the growth in commercial, agricultural and industrial loans.

The report of the National Steel Corporation and its subsidiaries issued yesterday for the three months ended on June 30, disclosed a net profit of $5,291,430 after depreciation, depletion, interest, provision of $4,483,923 for Federal income and excess profits taxes.

A new theatrical firm called Avocet Production Corporation has been incorporated in Albany to sponsor a musical comedy, the locale of which is Mexico. "Hands Across the Border" is its title. Billy K. Wells and his wife, Eleanor, are preparing the book and Maria Grever the songs.
Home from one of the strangest voyages ever made by an American liner, the big armed transport West Point of the United States Navy docked here yesterday afternoon with 388 passengers.

In the slowest day since July 24, the stock market yesterday jogged moderately lower, with only the rails holding out against the downward trend. Deals were 678,990 shares, compared with 853,940 on Thursday.

In connection with the legislation to control prices the President and his advisers are considering measures to restrict installment credit. This type of credit has come to occupy so important a place in our economic life that it can scarcely be excluded from any plans for guarding against inflation.

MONTEREY, Calif., Aug. 1 -- Two Army planes of the Eighty-second Observation Squadron locked wings while climbing through a dense fog near Fort Ord today. Three of the four occupants were killed in the resulting fall or were drowned in the Pacific Ocean.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 1 -- With the Reich's armed forces engaged on the Russian front, German diplomacy is believed to be working in seclusion to prepare the next phase of the diplomatic offensive. While the army looks eastward, diplomacy, entrusted with the task of consolidating the "new order," looks westward.

It was water, water everywhere yesterday afternoon on 110th Street, between Third and Lexington Avenues, when six new fire extinguishers were exhibited by their inventor, Lucian Mantell, before two members of the Fire Department.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Leon Henderson, Price Control Administrator, today granted an increase ranging from 11 to 24 cents per pound for superfine combed cotton yarns, but turned down the industry's plea for high prices on less fine yarns.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- Chester T. Birch, home club ace who has two legs on the cup, today showed the way to a field of seventy-five players competing in the Briar Hills invitation golf tournament.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: This a further reply to John Lancaster of New Canaan, Conn. On checking past records I found out the following facts in reference to Mrs. Opal Hill's golf score of 66.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 1 -- Manufacturers of nondefense products must depend primarily on their own ingenuity and initiative in solving the problems resulting from shortages of materials, not on the government. Donald M. Nelson, director of purchases in the OPM, emphasized in a speech today before 650 New Jersey industrialists and business leaders.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 -- William Fox, former motion picture producer, denied in Federal District Court that unsecured loans totaling $27,500, which he testified he made to J. Warren Davis, retired Federal Circuit Court judge, were extended for any corrupt purpose.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin) Aug. 1 -- The Bourse opened below yesterday's close but later a sharp rally developed especially in the Dutch Indian issues. Domestic industrials also were in demand. A.K.U. rose 2 to 145 1/2, Phillips 3 7/8 to 226 6/8, Unilever 1 3/8 to 129 7/8, Amsterdam Trading 3/4 to 410 3/4, Amsterdam Rubber 2 to 264 1/4, and Royal Dutch 1 3/8 to 240 1/4.

Although instructions against discussing the war were issued to United States consular officials from Axis-controlled countries before they arrived here yesterday on the Navy transport West Point, several of them described effects of the conflict on such cities as Bremen, Frankfort-on-Main, Rome and Genoa.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 -- A charge that American motion-picture companies "have been operating as war propaganda machines almost as if they were directed from a single central bureau" was made tonight by Senator Nye before an America First Committee rally at the Opera House.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- With Fenelon in the Merchants' and Citizens' Handicap, and Requested named for the United States Hotel Stakes, the first Saturday program of the Saratoga Association will be run tomorrow with the expectation of a crowd of 15,000.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 1 -- Recreational activities highlighted this week's program for the 244th Coast Artillery (New York's old Ninth) after it had returned to Camp Pendleton, Virginia Beach, last week-end from a 600-mile motor convoy into the Blue Ridge Mountains.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- Court Jester, 2-year-old pacer owned by Trainers Rupe Parker and Fred Egan of Aiken, S.C., showed again today that he is the best juvenile pacer out this season at Historic Track when he won the $6,155 Village Farm Stake.

FORT HANCOCK, N.J., Aug. 1 -- A gas drill for members of medical detachments of the three Coast Artillery regiments at Fort Hancock will be staged on the post Monday. The exercises are planned to instruct them in treatment of civilians and soldiers in a bombed area during a gas attack.

New York Stock Exchange memberships have been transferred from the late James C. Fuller to Carl Scholtz and from Edward S. Munro to Thomas N. Dabney of F.L. Dabney Co. Mr. Dabney has become both a special and general partner.

CAMP CROFT, S.C., Aug. 1 -- Private William McChesney Martin, former president of the New York Stock Exchange, completed thirteen weeks training as an Army selectee today and remarked that the Army was "much less of an ordeal than I thought it would be."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, accused the German Government of bare-faced impudence and denounced it scathingly today for having demanded in a note to the Mexican Government that Mexico protest the United States blacklist of pro-Axis firms or suffer reprisals from the Nazis.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 -- Rather than risk having its luxury ship Tatuta Maru detained indefinitely in an American port through court action, the Nippon Yusen Kabusiki Kaisya Line today ordered stevedores to begin unloading every piece of cargo from the liner moored at a San Francisco pier.

BERNE, Switzerland. Aug. 1 -- Overshadowed in importance by the intensity and dimensions of the Smolensk engagement, operations on the Southwestern Leningrad Front, at Novorshev, consisted throughout today mainly of artillery duels, followed at each point by many mechanized drives from both sides.

The city of Tacoma, Wash., will enter the market on Aug. 25 with a new issue of $4,000,000 of light and power revenue bonds, for which bidders are asked to specify a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent. The bonds will be dated Sept. 1, 1941, but the city's officials will consider proposals on two different bases.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Dutch Leonard, veteran knuckleballer, stopped the White Sox with an eight-hit performance today as the Senators won, 8 to 2.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 1 -- Ogden H. Hammond, former United States Ambassador to Spain, and Mrs. Hammond have arrived to visit Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt at Beaulieu for the week-end. Mrs. Vanderbilt entertained with a small dinner at her home tonight.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 1 -- The Giants today plunged deeper with their headlong dive. In the opening contest of a four-game series with Frankie Frisch's Pirates at Forbes Field the Terrymen swallowed their sixth straight defeat, touching their season's high in the manner made famous by Wrong Way Corrigan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- President Roosevelt tonight tightened the anti-Axis program of economic encirclement by redefining the United States petroleum export policy in such a way that Japan will be deprived of all further gasoline that could be used for aviation, and placing other petroleum exports to Japan on a pre-war quota basis.

The Yokohama Specie Bank, Ltd., fiscal agent for the Japanese Goverrment 6 1/2 per cent dollar bonds, due Feb. 1, 1954, on which interest and sinking fund payments fell due yesterday, received late yesterday a special license to make such payments, subject to the usual restrictions in respect to the release of blocked funds.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 1 -- All Switzerland was gay with hundreds of thousands of flags of hundreds of different varieties today as the country celebrated its 650th anniversary, but it was with sober dignity that the 4,000,000 inhabitants marked the day with symbolic pageants expressing their deep-rooted unity.

An East Side residence with ornate exterior and several unusual interior features changed hands yesterday, when Edward L. Bernays, public relations counsel, and his wife and partner, Doris E. Fleischman, bought the two-and-one-half-story dwelling at 163 East Sixty-third Street.

Although the cotton futures market continued to fluctuate nervously yesterday as traders found themselves unable to form definite opinions on the terms of the proposed price-control bill, the news that cotton and other farm products would be at least partially exempt rallied the market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Secretary Perkins formally discharged Mrs. Helen Miller, an industrial economist, today, acting on the ground that the latter's affiliations with organizations close to the Communist Party impaired her usefulness to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, and would shake the confidence of the public in the work of the bureau.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Japan, moving again in the direction of British interests in the Far East, has demanded that Thailand grant her military bases and control of the Thai rubber, rice and tin production, it was reported authoritatively here today.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: For altogether too many years sports followers have compared baseball players by means of their batting averages. While it is admitted that no simple satisfactory figure can ever be evolved that will scientifically evaluate a player's total baseball worth, it can be argued that there is available a better means of getting at a player's batting prowess than what now constitutes the batting average.

Scrap aluminum weighing 57,260 pounds, certified by the Department of Markets and collected in Manhattan last week in the nation's aluminum-for-defense drive, yesterday was removed from bins in which it had been deposited by the public to a yard at 158th Street and Riverside Drive, according to the office of Manhattan Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs.

A letter arrived this morning from Switzerland. It was written a month ago on the shores of a high lake set like a clear aquamarine in a ring of mountains. It is set in almost the exact center of Western Europe; from an upland near by you can see France and Germany.

Two agencies of the Federal Department of Labor joined yesterday in obtaining injunctions against the alleged use of child labor and the underpayment of women home-workers in a division of the garment industry here. As a result about 750 workers will receive payments totaling $34,243, including payments to individuals of as much as $374.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- General debate closed today in the House on the $3,529,200,000 Defense Tax Bill with a sharp and concerted attack on the joint tax return provision, and a private prediction by Speaker Rayburn that this would be deleted when the measure comes to a final vote Monday.

IN "The Airmen Speak"* the airmen of the R.A.F. speak of their experiences in the untranquil air, on land, above the seas, and over the dark European Continent. They speak tersely and informingly, without bombast, hate or vain-glory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Federal Communications Commission took action today to force the appearance of two newspaper executives at its hearings aiming at formulation of a policy on newspaper ownership of radio stations.

SOMEWHERE IN SOUTHEAST ENGLAND, Aug. 1 -- All along this important theatre of warfare where Royal Air Force Spitfire and Hurricane fighters and bombers these days make ceaseless attacks on German-occupied France, British aviation and naval authorities have stretched a "lifeline" principally on behalf of their own fliers but incidentally for the benefit of enemy airmen who attack this country.

Moving across the starting line off Kings Point in a dying easterly at noon yesterday, a fleet of eight deep water yachts headed toward Block Island in the twenty-first annual Bayside-Block Island auxiliary handicap race, a non-stop contest of 225 miles.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 1 -- Two victories in the working hunter division by Martin Vogel Jr.'s imported chestnut gelding Demas marked the opening session of the sixth annual Jersey Shore Horse Show today at Mr. and Mrs. William Buchsbaum's Boxwood Farm.

LONDON, Aug. 1 (U.P.) -- Wing Commander Whitney Willard Straight of the Royal Air Force, American-born millionaire sportsman, tonight was believed to be a prisoner of the Germans after having been shot down over the English Channel yesterday during a British attack on German shipping.

While 286 striking electricians returned to their jobs on six defense contracts at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn yesterday morning, little possibility was held out for a settlement over the week-end of the general strike of some 8,000 members of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, of the A.F.L., against private construction contractors in the city.

TORONTO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs staged a furious last-inning spurt tonight, but it fell two runs short of overcoming a seven-run deficit. So the Newark Bears squared the current series at one game each with a 9-7 triumph.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- Governor Herbert H. Lehman and Mrs. Lehman occupied the Governor's Box at the races today with a party of friends, and earlier gave a luncheon at the trackside restaurant. In the party were Mrs. Arthur Lehman, the Governor's sister-in-law; Mrs. Peter Lehman, his daughter-in-law, Mrs. Albert Prosch and Mrs. Walter Hirsch.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Senator Wheeler mentioned that Canadians were not so heavily taxed as Americans are and that Canada did not even have conscription.
ROME, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I saw in yesterday's papers the picture of a female dog that is going to be shown around by Mrs. M.C. Liotta, assistant to the president of the Humane Society.

When France fell this country's security was threatened. It was then that we turned to conscription and rearming. More than a year has passed since that time, but our danger is even greater. We are faced now with the possibility of war in two oceans and perhaps on both continents of the Western Hemisphere.

Great clouds of lightning-swift falcons, fierce birds of prey that are to be armed with specially designed knives harnessed to their bodies, may soon be tearing enemy parachute troops to shreds if experiments now under progress by the Army Signal Corps at Fort Monmouth, N.J., prove successful, it was disclosed here yesterday.

Tammany Hall upset the entire Fusion movement yesterday by announcing, as its candidate for District Attorney, Frank S. Hogan, one of Thomas E. Dewey's chief assistants and a man who had played a large part in sending some of Tammany's own people, including James J. Hines, to jail.

Two pictures arriving this morning complete the week's roster of new film offerings. Opening at the Rialto will be "Lady Scarface," starring Judith Anderson in the title role, in the first of RKO's attractions to be released this season under the new consent decree.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- A special stage was completed today in Raymond Hall, the Fort Slocum auditorium here, for a performance Sunday evening by Phil Spitalny and his all-girl orchestra in a broadcast of their "Hour of Charm" program over a national network.

About a hundred physicians, nurses, trustees of the Mount Sinai Hospital and directors of the Mount Sinai School of Nursing attended the ceremonies of the unveiling in the school foyer yesterday afternoon of a bronze plaque in honor of Hugo Blumenthal, who retired on Jan. 1 after thirty years of service to the school, twenty-five of which he served as its president.

The retirement of Sir Angus Fletcher as Director of the British Library of Information here will be regretted by an extensive section of the American public to which it has become an invaluable source and reference center. His readiness to provide authentic information about British affairs and his unfailing courtesy in dealing with requests for such information have brought him a wide circle of friends and acquaintances.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Japanese liner Tatuta Maru received permission by the Treasury today to unload her cargo in San Francisco after Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles had last night assured Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, the Japanese Ambassador, that the libel actions which some American importers had started against it would not modify the official assurance already given to Tokyo that the Tatuta Maru and other Japanese ships would be granted clearance.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Benny Warren's eleventh-inning homer gave the lowly Phils a 2-to-1 victory over the first-place Cardinals tonight and saved a well-earned decision for the veteran Si Johnson, who had shut the Redbirds out on two hits until the ninth inning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Control Administrator, today established, effective Aug. 5, ceiling prices for Douglas fir plywood, and peeler logs from which the plywood is made, and wiped out a 6 per cent price increase which went into effect last May 15.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 1 -- A grave shortage of fuel -- due in part to lack of shipping, in part to a decrease in exportable surpluses in producing countries -- has created a serious problem for Argentina, which is about to take emergency measures designed to reduce nonessential consumption and achieve rational distribution of what stocks are available.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 31:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1 -- Simone Simon, who will be seen in RKO's recently completed "Here Is a Man" after a three-year absence from the American screen, today received her second assignment from the studio, the romantic feminine lead in "Call Out the Marines," formerly "The Marines Are Ready."

A bondsman and a man who during prohibition days received $100 a week from the government for informing on bootleggers were convicted by a jury in Federal court yesterday of conspiring to obstruct justice.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- President Roosevelt today highly praised the Russian stand against Nazi aggression. He added that aid to Russia would be provided on a cash basis because the Soviet Government did not need lease-lend assistance.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 1 -- Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches won her fourth New Jersey Women's Golf Association one-day tournament by taking gross laurels with 39, 42 -- 81 over the Upper Montclair course today.

The Mayo brothers, Charles and William, authorized the University of Minnesota Press five years ago to publish a history of their work in expanding a small-town clinic to its position of international fame. Full-time exploratory work has been carried on by a staff, and from this material H.B. Clapesattle, a historian and chief editor of the press, has written "The Doctors Mayo."

New York newspaper linage last month was encouraging in view of the small gains since the start of the year. According to a compilation based on Media Records figures, eight papers registered an increase of 5.1 per cent.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 1 -- One of the most important features of the scientific measurement of public opinion is the opportunity provided for comparing the views of the general public with the views of those usually considered among the most successful and best informed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Administration submitted to Congress today a program to avert inflation through price ceilings and rent controls, but a revolt of farm State members of Congress forced a last-minute revision under which food costs may advance considerably before they are subject to Federal controls.

The action of the Office of Production Management in commandeering all aw silk supplies in this country means that an industry normally doing a retail volume of $450,000,000 annually will have to be suspended unless some arrangements are made for the importation of additional quantities of raw silk from Japan.

Mr. Ickes's call for the closing of gasoline pumps at service stations and garages between 7 P.M. and 7 A.M. should bring home to the motorists the fact that gasoline conservation is not merely a distant ogre. How effective the plan will be depends upon the cooperation of the public in heeding its spirit as well as its letter.

With the leading oil companies yesterday notifying their division managers along the Atlantic Coast to close service stations between the hours of 7 P.M. and 7 A.M. daily, beginning tomorrow night, the first general order affecting the gasoline-consuming public to be issued by Secretary of the Interior Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, apparently was going into effect without any serious hitch.

SKINNERS CORNER, Va., Aug. 1 -- Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, First Army commander, who with other ranking Army officers has just completed a field inspection of the Forty-fourth Division, said today that the Fort Dix unit was "improving greatly."

ANNISQUAM, Mass., Aug. 1 -- Harry Ryan of the New York A.C. Anglers today took the top award in the Massachusetts State tuna tournament, which has been in progress on Ipswich Bay for the past five days.
