When the scorching Summer sun shimmers on city pavements and makes even a shady rural lane a sultry spot, when cliff dwellers and their country cousins alike answer the call to dinner with lassitude, muttering like pathetic parrots -- with a menacing eye on a well-meaning cook -- "It's too hot to eat."

Glazunoff's Sixth symphony was the special feature of last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Hans Wilhelm Steinberg, at the Lewisohn Stadium. The rest of the program consisted of Wagnerian numbers, including the Prelude and Liebestod from "Tristan und Isolde," the Bacchanale from "Tannhaeuser," the overture to "The Flying Dutchman" and the Ride of the Valkyries from "Die Walkuere."

The report of the Radio Corporation of America and subsidiaries for the first half of this year, made public yesterday by David Sarnoff, president, shows a net income after all expenses and charges of $5,306,494. After payment of preferred dividends this was equal to 26.6 cents a share on the corporation's 13,881,016 common shares, and compares with $3,185,221, or 11.3 cents a common share, in the six months to June 30, 1940.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., Aug. 1 -- New York's old Seventh Regiment -- the 207th Coast Artillery, antiaircraft -- rolled out of this cantonment early yesterday morning on a two-day command post exercise as Colonel Ralph C. Tobin started the unit on an intensive training program preparatory to the Fall war games.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The hope was expressed by President Roosevelt at his press conference today that the boundary dispute between Ecuador and Peru could be settled amicably and peacefully, in view of the armistice signed yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 1 -- Minister of Interior Miguel Culaciatti had a two-hour conference this morning with the Chief of the Army General Staff, General Rodolfo Maiques, and their prolonged talk awakened intense curiosity and much speculation.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- One woman was drowned, another killed and a man critically injured early this morning when a speed boat owned and operated by Calvin Pardee 3d of Hazleton, Pa., and a smaller boat were in collision on Lake Placid.

There was no evidence of any pick-up in yesterday's markets on traefer meats. Supplies of all classes appeared ample. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to 50 cents lower. Pork loins were weak and spareribs higher. Lamb prices were slightly irregular, with a better feeling in some sections and steady in others.

Raw silk stocks in New York and Hoboken warehouses on Aug. 1 amounted to 47,208 bales, a fairly important decline from the 53,436 bales in stock on July 1, according to regular monthly statistics issued yesterday by the Commodity Exchange, Inc.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Here's the same old complaint -- them Giants. I've been waiting all Summer in the forlorn hope that after all Terry would pull a rabbit out of his hat and land a first-division spot.

MOSCOW, Aug. 1 -- After seventeen days of the second major German offensive, concentrated in the key Smolensk area and supported by subsidiary drives in the Ukraine and Leningrad directions, it is now clear, according to official information here, that Russian counter-attacks not only are enabling the Red Army to hold its positions all along the 1,800-mile front, but are forcing back the Wehrmacht considerable distances at several points and annihilating invading units at others.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 1 -- With breezes returning to Long Island Sound today, even in fluctuating form, the final three races for the Syce Cup were sailed. The trophy was won by the Riverside Yacht Club for a year.

Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder approved yesterday a proposed settlement in a minority stockholders' suit brought in on behalf of the Empire Power Corporation against Ellis L. Phillips, president, and the estate of George W. Olmsted, former treasurer of the corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- President Roosevelt was disclosed today to be favoring a policy of certifying small firms to which are denied essential materials under defense priorities orders, contracts for prime defense orders or subcontracts which will prevent them from going bankrupt or from dislocating workers.

New bonds offered to the public here this week totaled $21,417,000, featured by the appearance of the first industrial bond flotation since early in July, when the $13,700,000 of McKesson Robbins debenture 3 1/2s were offered. This week's flotation compare with $139,963,000 placed on the market last week, which included $135,000,000 of tax-anticipation notes of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Treasury started today its tax-anticipation note program by selling $1,200 of notes to President Roosevelt and was able to crown its day by announcing that $1,000,000,000 of defense savings bonds had been bought by the public.

The New Tax Notes Banks reported a flood of inquiries yesterday regarding the new tax-anticipation notes of the Treasury which had just been put on sale. There was, however, no rush to buy, as the public can buy the notes at any time this month and obtain interest from Aug. 1.

The three-family dwelling at 637 East 229th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Constance Marinelli to Clodomiro Del Principe for cash above a first mortgage of $8,000, in a transaction negotiated by P. C. D'Onofrio, broker. The parcel is assessed at $12,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Faced with a shortage of more than 5,000,000 short tons in 1941, the Office of Production Management put pig iron today under full priorities control to insure that foundries get enough pig iron for defense castings and other products and to regulate the distribution of pig iron among steel plants with defense orders.
LONDON, Aug. 1 (U.P.) -- The weekly Economist today called on

Representatives of many consumer groups in this city, including William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, presented testimony at a hearing conducted jointly yesterday by the United States and New York State Departments of Agriculture, opposing any increase in the cost of milk production that might be passed on to the consumer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Chief radio aide of the Army amateur radio system was the title bestowed today upon Dr. Lawrence J. Dunn of Brooklyn in appointing him civilian representative to aid the chief signal officer of the Army.

The Procter Gamble Company reported yesterday that its consolidated net profit of $10,805,454 for the quarter ended on June 30 was the best in the history of the company. The profit, equal to $1.66 a common share, compared with $6,355,345, or 97 cents a share for the June quarter last year and with the previous quarterly peak of $8,198,490, or $1.26 a share, earned in the March quarter of 1937.

The mansion at 17 East Fifty-first Street, built in 1909 by the late Frank Knight Sturgis at a cost of $1,000,000 and recently acquired by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman for men in the military services and defense industries will be opened formally tomorrow.
FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 1 -- Fifteen thousand officers and men of the Ninth Division and more than 4,000 guests celebrated today the first anniversary of the activation of the division.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Steps that were described as a move toward giving India at least Dominion status were explained today to the House of Commons by Leopold S. Amery, Secretary of State for India. The House generally was enthusiastic, but questions revealed a belief that it would not be more than a temporary measure.

At a local celebration of the 650th anniversary of the confederation of Switzerland, Dr. Victor Nef, Swiss Consul General in New York, declared last night that Switzerland was an isalnd of "peace, independence, progress, culture and social justice in a shaded and black Europe."

FORT DEVENS, Aug. 1 -- Although the majority of soldiers at Fort Devens can swim, even the more proficient are "sinkers" when forced into the water with full Army equipment, but that is what the Army is demanding.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- In a move to solidify all possible support behind the Administration's Army service-extension resolution, Democratic leaders in the Senate proposed a "compromise" plan today under which selectees, National Guardsmen, reserve officers and enlisted men might be held in camp for a period limited to eighteen months beyond their original tenures instead of "for the duration."

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Aug. 1 -- Non-commissioned officers of Fort Monmouth are to be accommodated in the new housing area at Shrewsbury about Sept. 1. The area, about a mile from here, includes sixty-four housing units which vary from two to six family apartments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (U.P.) -- Defense officials said today that five newly constructed plants have begun production of twenty-seven-ton medium tanks ahead of schedule. They estimated that the total output of medium and light tanks this year would total 3,000 units.

HIGHWATER, Que., Aug. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian and United States government officials gathered here today to witness the welding together at the international border of a yet-uncompleted 236-mile oil pipeline from Portland, Me., to Montreal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Emil Rieve said that of the total workers who would be adversely affected by the silk stoppage, 100,000 are hosiery workers. The other 75,000 work in the silk thread, ribbon, hatband, velvet, necktie fabric, dress goods and sundry industries.

VICHY, France, Aug. 1 -- For weeks a showdown has been impending regarding the internal situation in France and "collaboration" with Germany. There are signs tonight that it may be near. There may possibly be developments tomorrow after the customary Saturday meeting of the Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Office of Production Management today ordered stoppage of all processing of raw silk by non-defense industries, effective at midnight tomorrow. The order will freeze all raw silk supplies in the United States.

FORT DIX, Aug. 1 -- From now on, if picnickers who stray into the forbidden twenty-square-mile land, lined with artillery and small-arms firing ranges, have their luncheons interrupted by shell fire, it will not be the fault of the Fort Dix Army authorities.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1 -- The tennis match of the turf court season to date will be staged at the Meadow Club tomorrow.

BERLIN, Saturday, Aug. 2 -- About 45,000 Russian prisoners and 205 cannons have been captured by the Germans in the Smolensk sector of the eastern front, D.N.B. official German news agency, reported yesterday. It said driving Soviet units were cut off from the main body of their trapped forces and then forced to surrender.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 1 -- The British "V-for-Victory" campaign is hugely successful in Greece, where all German and Italian efforts to halt pro-Allied demonstrations have failed almost completely, it is reported by reliable eyewitnesses just arriving in Turkey from Athens.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 1 -- Bulgarian troops in large numbers are moving into frontier fortifications beyond Svilengrad and Ljoubimec near the Bulgar-Turkish border, it was reported by reliable foreign diplomatic sources here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Cash expenditures in connection with the armaments program totaled about $1,000,000,000 in July, the largest amount since the World War.

ROME, Aug. 1 -- British planes yesterday carried out daylight raids over some Sicilian towns, doing slight damage and causing some victims, today's communique said. In Messina, it was said, one man was killed and a few wounded, while some damage was caused to buildings when the raiders dropped their bombs from "a very great height."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1 -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Coulter gave a dinner with dancing tonight at the Galley for their daughter, Miss F. Delaplaine Coulter, who will be introduced to society in the Autumn at the Tuxedo ball, and for their house guest, Miss Grace Maynard, debutante daughter of Mrs. Samuel R. Maynard of Utica, N.Y.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 1 -- The maximum sentence of ten years' imprisonment and a fine of $20,000 was imposed today upon Enoch L. (Nucky) Johnson, 58-year-old Atlantic County Republican political leader, for evasion of income taxes for 1936 and 1937.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 1 -- The Iranian Government has replied to the British note recommending the expulsion of German agents from Iran, according to foreign diplomatic sources here today, informing the British Government that the Teheran authorities have taken all the measures necessary to preserve peace and order.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- An assertion that, had sufficient Great Lakes facilities been existent, 526 ships now being built in shipyards on salt water for the Navy and the Maritime Commission could have been constructed on the lakes and moved to the sea without any deepening of the St. Lawrence River, was made before the House Rivers and Harbors Committee today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 1 Utilization of the Rye Lake tract in Purchase for a Westchester County airport would result in a health hazard to New York City's water supply, of which Rye Lake is an important part, a committee appointed by Mayor La Guardia to survey the situation reported today to Westchester officials.

Many visiting clergymen will preach tomorrow in the pulpits of New York including several from Canada. A number of pastors will commute from their Summer homes to preach this and successive weeks. Some ministers are voluntarily taking shorter vacations as an economy measure for their church budgets.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Japanese Times Advertiser, Foreign Office mouthpiece, expressed today Japan's determination to get rubber, tin and oil in the South Orient regardless of what it termed a "de facto embargo" against Japan in Malaya by the United States and Britain.
Fight for Freedom, Inc., announced yesterday the formation of an advisory board of seven to advise it concerning events in France that might have a parallel in the United States.

Tax as Blessing Another big political boss is going to jail as the result of carelessness with the income tax. To love and admire the income tax is not altogether easy for the ordinary good citizen who reads the schedules for next year's taxes, but this is only a momentary hesitation.

NEW YORK Princess Martha of Norway entertained at luncheon yesterday in the Norse Grill of the Waldorf-Astoria for her brother, Prince Carl of Sweden, who arrived on the West Point yesterday from Lisbon, Portugal.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Thirty-six hours after landing here in a military occupation that has no visible ultimate limits, Japanese men and machines still were streaming from Saigon's docks tonight, carrying ever-mounting quantities of munitions and supplies.

The Kings County Democratic executive committee dropped Kings County Judge George W. Martin from its county ticket yesterday. City Court Justice Louis Goldstein was named for the Criminal Court bench in place of Judge Martin.

Inelegant though it might have been, Vernon (Lefty) Gomez's pitching against the Browns was highly effective at the Stadium yesterday. After all, one couldn't possibly improve on a shut-out, and when Senor Gomez blanked the St. Louis outfit, 9 -- 0, the fact that he had issued eleven bases on balls was dismissed as insignificant by a ladies' day gathering of 8,730 fans.

The board of directors of the American Society of Authors, Composers and Publishers yesterday approved in general the terms of an agreement whereby ASCAP music would return to the National Broadcasting Company networks and its owned and operated stations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Negotiations for the "Big Five" operating brotherhoods presented today to representatives of the railroads arguments supporting demands for a wage increase of 30 per cent. The arguments were based upon five points:

OTTAWA, Aug. 1 -- Canada answered critics of her war effort today when it was announced that a large section of the Third Division, under the command of Major General C.B. Price, had arrived safely in Britain after a speedy Atlantic crossing.

In an effort to determine the proportion of business that is done on a speculative basis, the board of manager of the New York Cotton Exchange has sent to member firms a questionnaire requesting such information, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Construction or improvement projects involving the expenditure of $80,810,110 on 288 airports were disclosed today on the immediate program of the Civil Aeronautics Administration. Brig. Gen. Donald H. Connolly, CAA Administrator, said the projects were approved by a board made up of the Secretaries of War, Navy and Commerce.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 1 -- There was no public concert today at Tanglewood, where the eighth annual Berkshire Symphonic Festival is in progress, but that did not mean an abatement of the musical activity on the grounds here and in the vicinity.

French Government finances before the war had long been in a precarious state. Their present virtually hopeless condition, outlined in a recent number of The Economist, is only in small part attributable, however, to past faults. The problem, it is true, would not have been easy to cope with in any event, but it has been made completely insoluble by Nazi policies and measures.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Aug. 2 -- -- A squall and a calm played a big part in the eighth regatta of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association today and only three races were finished over the Toms River course.

THE International Dance Festival at Jacob's Pillow, near Lee, Mass., will present as its fifth week-end event a new dance team in its official debut. On Friday and Saturday afternoons at 4:45 Lisa Parnova and Barton Mumaw, who are to tour together next season, will give their first program as partners.
Urban home financing attained a volume exceeding two billion dollars in the United States during the first six months of the present year, announces the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

Commercial vehicles, including trucks and taxicabs, were exempted yesterday from the curfew on gasoline sales that becomes effective throughout the Eastern seaboard at 7 o'clock tonight. The ruling excluding such vehicles from the twelve-hour ban on sales was announced in a telegram received here from the office of Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, Federal Petroleum Coordinator.

NO doubt you have never heard of Colleen Ward. A radio actress of considerable experience, having appeared in such microphone productions as "Big Town," with Edward G. Robinson; "Second Husband," with Helen Menken, and currently in WEAF'S "Lorenzo Jones," and various "strip" shows, she is never mentioned in the radio listings, nor does her picture grace the pages of fan magazines.

MR. MATSON has done a neat job of finishing the novel Thorne Smith left incomplete at his death. No one would ever know that any but the shaky Smith hand had set up these fantastic creatures and more incredible situations.

THIS is a heartening book. While laymen with no serious historical pretensions loudly proclaim the "wave of the future" and others no less vociferously announce it to be merely a "wave of the past" under another name, Benedetto Croce, recognized philosopher and historian of authority, now comes forward to tell us that there is only one authentic wave, but it is an eternal one and encompasses the past, present and future.

"THE trawler went on fishing." This most telling line occurs several times in Leo Walmsley's book about the British men and boats that gather food from the sea in wartime and sweep from the ship lanes the menacing mines of the Nazi.

Plays for children which are original, spontaneous, requiring not too elaborate production and yet possessed of real substance are, with the exception of certain old favorites, hard to find, as group leaders and teachers can testify.

Machine tools, presumably for use in new munitions and supply plants to be constructed deep in Russia's interior and away from Nazi bombers, are the No. 1 item on Soviet Russia's requisition list turned in to American authorities last week, according to information obtained here yesterday from exporters who maintain close business contacts with the Soviet.

Captain P.C. Mahady, district cadet training instructor in the New York office of the United States Maritime Commission, has resigned to enter private business and has been succeeded by Harold V. Nerney, former assistant supervisor in charge of administration of the Commission's training program at Washington, it was announced here last week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Alex Taub, designer and development engineer for Vauxhall, Ltd., the British subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, has been named by the Office of Production Management to aid in converting the American automobile industry to defense work just as he helped to convert British auto plants to the manufacture of arms.
THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity entered new high ground last week when it advanced to 133.3. It stood at 131.5 for the week ended July 19 and at 107.3 for the week ended July 27, 1940.

AS Americans know, sometimes to their cost, we in England have a liking for domestic comedy. It gives ordinary playgoers a never failing kick to see themselves onstage -- a size or two larger than in life perhaps -- grappling with life's difficulties in the home.

THE most exciting job in the world today is no doubt that of the "officers and men of the Royal Air Force" some of whom spoke over the British radio last Winter and now speak again in the transcripts published in this compilation.

SOMETIMES the words of the oracles are downright confusing. Since way before Homer they have had a tantalizing occupational habit of speaking from both sides of the mouth. Thus the faithful, their heads chock-full of enigmas and paradoxical double-talk, come away little the wiser.

WORK by some fourscore artists associated with the Grand Central Galleries is on view until Nov. 13 in the annual Founders Show at the Vanderbilt Avenue division of the institution. As might be anticipated, the overwhelming majority of the paintings are by artists well known in the academic field.

ROYAL VISITOR: An American-built, four-engined bomber in British service landed last week in Canada. Aboard the plane, which made the flight from Britain in nine uneventful hours, was a royal passenger -- the Duke of Kent.

Miss Helen Germaine, national public parks champion, and Miss Ann Freeman, both of Manhattan, made their way into the final round of the women's singles by scoring victories in the New York City public parks tennis championships on the Central Park courts yesterday.

LONDON. THE functions and necessary qualifications of what is professionally known as a "publisher's reader" are not commonly understood, and Cecil Palmer has been rendering a useful service by some comments on the subject in replying to a letter he has lately received from a stranger.

ST. MICHAELS, Md., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Ernest Chase and John Bramble of Baltimore carried off the coveted Miles River Trophy for unlimited displacement class runabouts today in the feature event of the Miles River Club's twentieth annual regatta.

The Coca-Cola Company reported yesterday for the three months ended on June 30 earnings of $16,675,727 before income taxes. This compared with $12,210,503 for the second quarter of 1940. After all charges, including dividends on the Class A stock and reserves for estimated tax requirements, net profit for the last June quarter amounted to $9,162,727, equivalent to $2.29 a share.

THE millionth visitor crossed the threshold of the National Gallery of Art, Washington, last Sunday, that institution reports. This means an average of more than 7,500 visitors daily since the gallery opened to the public on March 18.

Beginning tomorrow the University of Chicago's Graduate Library School will attempt to analyze the impact of newspapers, motion pictures and radio on public morale in time of crisis. This is a departure from strict adherence to library problems.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Oakleigh Thorne have come to the Pierre from Washington.

WASHINGTON. THE distant gleam of white marble, a glimpse of stately building rising into a majestic dome, is already attracting visitors a little bit out of the well-defined sight-seeing paths here in the capital, even though the structure will not be finished and formally opened until next Spring.

VANCOUVER -- Huge tractor trains, led by bulldozers that can plow their way through snow-drifts at twenty miles an hour, are traversing one of the wildest overland routes in Canada, carrying supplies for the chain of air bases now being established between the United States and Alaska on British Columbia territory.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 2 -- With a unanimity seldom expressed on public questions, the Pacific Northwest is urging stiff resistance to Japanese expansion. Isolationists as well as interventionists have approved the cutting off of trade with Tokyo, and many people in both factions have demanded even more emphatic action in the Far Eastern crisis.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- Secret reports said to indicate that the actual authors of Vichy's foreign policy are the German authorities in Berlin have been captured by Free French forces in Syria, according to an announcement today at General Charles de Gaulle's headquarters here.

To serve as Great Britain's "number two man" in this country under Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador, Sir Ronald Campbell, knighted recently after his work in the Balkans, arrived yesterday on the Atlantic Clipper at La Guardia Field.

Early excitement over the National Sweepstakes and Gold Cup Regratta at Red Bank on Aug. 16 and 17 the largest regatta by all odds in the country this season, will begin tomorrow night. The old and famous Monmouth Boat Club at Red Bank, which has presidents instead of commodores to command its fleet, will compliment both Tom Field Jr. and the Sweepstakes Regatta Association at a club gathering and stag supper.

ANNISQUAM, Mass., Aug. 2 -- The Massachusetts State tuna tournament was another proof of the fact that you just can't set apart four days to take a lot of fish, for wind, weather and plain luck play too important a part in this sport.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 -- The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals refused today to release Enoch L. (Nucky) Johnson, Atlantic County Republican leader, in bail pending disposition of his appeal from conviction on charges of evading payment of $38,700 in income taxes in 1936 and 1937.

The color and seasonal habits of peonies are patiently being changed by Dr. Earl B. White, a dentist of Washington. Two weeks or more before the common double-white, blue-pink and blue-red Chinese varieties bloomed in his neighbor's gardens last Spring Dr. White was examining the first orange-red and rich coral single blossoms on the hybrid peonies which he developed from a few seeds obtained by painstaking cross-pollination.

A relic that belonged to ancestors of Winston Churchill, British Prime Minister, has been acquired lately by an American museum. It is a fifteenth-century bronze baptismal font, which remained in the possession of the Churchill family from the time it was acquired by John Churchill, first Duke of Marlborough (1650-1722), until about the mid-nineteenth century.
PREPARE your mind to accept a slender silhouette in your Fall dress. It is already firmly ensconced in the season's picture. To be sure, there are variations on it that provide extra flexibility.
A CERTAIN airman with a taste for the classics was identified some years ago as Lawrence of Arabia. In East Anglia an air-gunner, nearing his sixties emerges similarly as Wilson of Persia.
LONDON, Sunday, Aug. 3 -- An American-built Flying Fortress bombed the docks at the North German naval base at Kiel in a daylight raid yesterday, officials said early today.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- Reports that Japan is sending reinforcements to Manchukuo via Korea are generally credited in responsible quarters here. Obviously these reports suggest the possibility that has always been feared since the Russo-German war started -- that Japan would attack Russia either under German pressure or because the Tokyo government thinks that now is a good time to settle scores with a traditional enemy.
PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 2 -- Where does American public opinion stand today on the crisis in the Far East?

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2 -- On the broad shoulders of Hal Schumacher the Giants rose to victory today, snapping a six-game losing streak as they whitewashed Frankie Frisch's Pirates in ten tense innings. The score was 2 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Although about a score of vessels are continuously afloat carrying, among them, something more than 150,000 tons of crude rubber toward our ports, the efforts of the government to build up a reserve of 400,000 tons of this essential material have so far failed.

AT a recent meeting of the board of directors Henry McIlhenny, curator of decorative arts of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, was elected president of the Robin Hood Dell Concerts to succeed Samuel R. Rosenbuam, who tendered his resignation because of increased business responsibilities.

If the Army and Navy find it necessary to turn to substitutes for silk in the production of parachutes and powder bags, the fault will lie with no one but government agencies, according to views expressed privately if somewhat vociferously in the industry last week.

THE papers had reported the opening of Commissioner Moses new bicycle path in Central Park, where motors and even pedestrians -- were strictly forbidden. We decided to rent a bicycle and see for ourselves what was going on.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Following is the list of individuals receiving from corporations compensation for personal services in excess of $75,000 for the calendar year 1939 or fiscal years ending in 1940, as made public today by Secretary Morgenthau:
BALTIMORE, Aug. 2 -- The Rev. Joseph M. Renaud, S.J., chaplain at the Mercy Hospital here for the last eighteen years, died today after an illness of several months. He was 80 years old.

DETROIT -- While the controversy rages over automotive production during the coming season, the nation's car dealers currently are interesting themselves in the annual preview of next year's products and plans, as being revealed by the factories in various cities around the country.

IN this year of stress, the chances are that Broadway's movie-goers are not likely to see "Mystery In Swing." Nor is it likely that they will care, for that matter. But tonight, some four miles north of Times Square, a representative quota of Harlem's citizens, seated in the Odeon and Renaissance Theatres and at the Harlem Opera House, are probably enjoying the seventy minutes of this all-Negro mystery-musical.

Just to show that it is not provincial, the New York City school system has issued an invitation to outstanding educators, regardless of where they reside, to apply for teaching and administrative positions here. A definite campaign is under way to bring "new blood" into the city, thus avoiding the dangers of excessive inbreeding.

Mistakes in the location of industrial plants are costly not only to the manufacturer but also to the community and its citizens, points out Glenn E. McLaughlin, chief of the industrial location section of the National Resources Planning Board.

THIS posthumous work of the great Czech writer was published at Prague soon after the occupation of Czecho-Slovakia, in the Spring of 1939. Karel Capek died on Christmas Day of 1938 and this was the first book published after his death.

TOKYO (Sunday), Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- Japan stepped up the greatest mobilization of armed might in her history today as the press predicted further military expansion southward in addition to the occupation of French Indo-China.

TOKYO, Aug. 2 -- When the third Konoye Cabinet was formed July 13 and the bellicose Yosuke Matsuoka was replaced as Foreign Minister by the moderate Admiral Teijiro Toyoda, there was general expectation of a change in Japanese policy that would ease the tension in the Pacific and perhaps open up possibilities for a rapprochement with the United States and Britain.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 2 -- Japan is waiting for favorable developments elsewhere before entering Thailand, Foreign Minister Quo Tai-chi said at his press conference here today.

Hans Wilhelm Steinberg made his third appearance of the season as conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night at the Lewisohn Stadium in a program which featured Ania Dorfmann as soloist in the Mendelssohn piano concerto in G minor.

American housewives last week were paying an average of 42 cents for a pound of butter. That was a rise of 12 1/2 cents since the beginning of the war. Housewives were also paying more for eggs, meat, sugar, onions and other foodstuffs. Newlyweds out to buy furniture had to pay prices 15 per cent higher than those of 1939.

The wisdom of the British Government in resisting demands for a detailed and specific statement of its war aims is being justified by events. It is impossible to make a blueprint of the post-war world when no man knows which nations will be friends or foes, or, for that matter, what kind of Europe will be left when the last gun has been fired and the last bomb dropped.

Tom Strafaci of Dyker Beach, the defending champion, defeated M. Horgan of Mosholu, 6 and 4, as match play began in the municipal public links tournament for the Newbold Morris Trophy yesterday at the Clearview course in Queens.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 2 -- Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles won the women's invitation tennis tournament of the Maidstone Club for the Woodin Gold Cup today with a crushing victory over Miss Hope Knowles of Philadelphia.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 2 -- Serge Koussevitzky waited only until the second concert of the eighth annual Berkshire Symphonic Festival here tonight before reaffirming his espousal of the cause of Shostakovich's Fifth symphony. The work of the Soviet Union's most gifted living composer had a place of honor on tonight's program at Tanglewood.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on July 26 were 252,728,000 barrels, against 254,048,000 at the end of the preceding week, a decrease of 1,320,000 barrels, comprising decreases of 1,140,000 and 180,000 barrels in stocks of domestic and foreign crude, respectively.
Youth! Ah, youth.' Thou lovely thing! Time of beauty's blossoming! Fascism doth surety bring Of our people's liberty.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2 -- Tonight's dinner dance for benefit of the British War Relief Society, Inc., given at the Maidstone Club, was a great success, attended by hundreds from all the Hamptons. Mrs. Prank Parsons Shepard headed the committee arranging the event, with Mrs. A. Wallace Chauncey as vice chairman.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Aug. 2 -- As longshoremen proceeded with the loading of valuable cargo from the Japanese liner Tatutu Maru, Federal Judge Martin I. Welch today signed an order dismissing all libel actions brought this week by American importers for recovery of their merchandise aboard the ship.

A NEW type of explosive rivet now being commercially manufactured in this country, which is so designed that it may be used without fear of serious injury as it will not detonate in mass and is insensitive to shock and friction, speeds up airplane production, according to aeronautical experts, by eliminating costly equipment and unnecessary labor.

SKINNERS CORNER, Va., Aug. 2 -- Sentimental and historically-minded Southerners of Caroline County are about to present a mild protest to the Army "for perpetrating a mistake in nomenclature," which will continue through the years unless remedial action is taken.
FORTHCOMING BOOKS FICTION "ARIADNE SPINNING." Eleanor Green. (Doubleday, Doran) September.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Aug. 2 -- A program for improving the health of the nation was outlined today at his Summer home here by John B. Kelly, new Federal director of health training, who said he would enlist leaders in the athletic world to help him accomplish his aims.

CANCELLED to order, a familiar phrase to philatelists, means a procedure accomplished by representatives of the government under postoffice regulations. But a little "out of order" from the generally accepted definition is a newly discovered practice involving a cancellation machine a long way from home.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Referring to the recent Sforza-Simovic controversy regarding Trieste, and the several letters to THE NEW YORK TIMES which followed, a few words from a Croat might help to elucidate certain debatable points.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The United Federal Workers of America, C.I.O., will continue its fight for the reinstatement of Mrs. Helen Miller, who was discharged by the Department of Labor, until "Secretary of Labor Perkins is forced to recognize the elementary principles of trade unionism."

YOU have to see it to believe it. Six fencing bouts are on in the salle d'armes of the Foils Club in New York City. Six pairs of "duelists," men, women and mixed, wearing masks and white fencing jackets, thrust, lunge, parry and riposte. Blades flash and ring. "Pick them out," Alexander Hern, maitre d'armes, says proudly.

OTTAWA -- W.P. Mulock, Canada's Postmaster General, has announced that arrangements have been completed for exchange of stampless letters in an official form between Canadians and residents, including prisoners of war, in enemy countries, through Le Comite International de la Croix Rouge (The International Red Cross Committee) at Geneva, Switzerland, on payment of a postal charge of 25 cents.
WHETHER Wagner's "Die Meistersinger," which was dropped from the Metropolitan repertory last year, will be revived during the coming season has not been announced definitely as yet by the management.

PROBABLY it is not by accident that the eleventh entry in Elizabeth Bowen's brilliant collection of short stories has been chosen for the title-piece. One could hardly ask a better title for this lavish, bright, stylized garland of sketches and character studies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The emphasis placed by the official economic plan of the Soviet Union for 1941 upon production of special types of machines and metallurgical facilities was interpreted here as indicating a weakness in the Russian industrial armor which may be reinforced under the projected United States aid plan.
MONTREAL, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Paced by the veteran Gilly Brack, the Jersey City Giants pounded out an 8-3 victory over the Montreal Royals in an International League game today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 2 -- The extraordinary confidence of the people of the immense Soviet Union that it will be they who destroy the flower of the German Army and contribute the greatest blow toward smashing Adolf Hitler's military power, just as more than a century ago they swallowed up the finest soldiers of Napoleon's imperial troops, is one of the first things to impress a traveler in wartime Russia.

BECAUSE of the role the southern and eastern shores of the Mediterranean play in the current war the volume of Mr. Raoul Aglion, a former attache of the French Legation at Cairo and a student of the Near East, offers reading which is as informative as it is interesting: and the book's interest is twofold.

THERE is nothing wrong with Basic English except that we don't like it Obviously a simplification that reduces the vast reaches of our Language to a vocabulary of 850 words or so has much to commend it when one wants to teach foreigners to speak and read English as quickly as possible.

BRIAR HILLS, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Mike Cestone, metropolitan amateur golf champion, hasn't been in the letter-carrying business all these years for nothing. Trekking his way around his mail route in Montclair, he has learned never to take two steps where one will suffice and he's following the same plan in the Briar Hills invitation tourney.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- The Saratoga racing season which opened on Monday and will continue throughout this month, draws turf followers from all sections of the United States. The population of this old Indian village, which normally is about 15,000, is more than doubled during August by the influx of members of society, racing men and their assistants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Although export licenses issued for the shipment of arms and war materials to foreign countries during the first six months of the year totaled $866,663,037, actual exports under the licenses up to June 30 reached a total of only $312,331,156, the Department of State reported today.

TORONTO -- Canada's Far North is no longer just a man's country. The woman have come with their husbands. They are pioneering today on Canada's last frontier. They can be found but a short distance north of the railway, which signifies the end of civilization, and hundreds of miles above the Arctic Circle, where the seasonal change in scenery is from a white, windswept icefield to a barren rocky waste.
The popularity of the cocker spaniel is still increasing according to an analysis of the American Kennel Club registrations for the first six months of 1941.

THE August lists have a fair representation of new Mozart recordings. Whatever the reason, new Mozart releases are always welcome, and not only to those who regard the composer as their particular shining star in the musical firmament.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Washington Park opened its rich program of fourteen stakes before 18,000 spectators today, with Mrs. James F. Waters's veteran Talked About turning on a fine furst of speed in the stretch to capture the opening added money event of the meeting's thirty-two-day program -- the $5,000 Chicago Handicap.

The report of the Ways and Means Committee on the 1941 revenue bill, introduced in the House of Representatives on July 26, contains a comprehensive study of the subject of mandatory joint returns of husband and wife. The discussion of this new tax feature covers more than twenty of a total of sixty-nine pages, not counting the minority report.

THE largest expanse of wilderness country in the United States, abounding in fish and game, is but three days' travel from New York City. In many places in the Central Idaho Primitive Area the nearest road is more than thirty miles distant and the nearest postoffice more than fifty.

CLEAR thought, moral earnestness and hard hitting mark this little book, which urges America's place beside Great Britain and explains the pressing issues of the war. The author is a New York lawyer who reminded Americans of their wartime responsibilities in a widely read and much reprinted letter to the Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES in January, 1940.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Most people unconnected with the shipping business and, indeed, many of those in the business seem to experience considerable difficulty in understanding tonnage figures as applied to ships.

THERE were no bands, no throngs and no battery of press agents on hand to meet Pola Negri, glamorous siren of the latter-day silent films, upon her return from Europe last Monday after almost a six-year absence.

FROM the point of view of the knowing soul who has mastered the art of entertaining in the wide open spaces, the last rose of Summer blooms far too soon. Nor need the open spaces be luxuriously wide. A few precious feet of urban terrace or a pocket handkerchief of a garden has been the setting for many an al fresco party.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 2 (AP) -- H.H. (Holly) Mandly Jr. of Hartford, to whom, the experience isn't new, and Ted Bishop of Auburndale, Mass., rangy former professional, will meet tomorrow in a thirty-six-hole battle for the New England amateur golf title.

WONDERFUL gent, that Larry the Red MacPhail. He's a purchasing agent extraordinary. Whenever the pennant prospects of the Dodgers sag even a trifle, the gallant MacPhail gallops off in all directions and comes back with fresh hirelings to add strength to the Flatbush Flock.

SOUTH Street waterfront fried in Summer heat. The breeze patted your face like a hot towel, with little gusts lifted from the simmering bay. Inside Seamen's Church Institute, though, it was cool. One flight brought you to the British Merchant Navy Club.

SUPERIOR, Wis., Aug. 2 -- George Franck, backfield star of Minnesota's great team last Fall, reported to Coach Steve Owen at the camp of the New York Football Giants this afternoon, donned a uniform, and worked out with the squad in a dummy scrimmage.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Saratoga, owned by Thomas L. Gustin of Holicong, Pa., and driven by Thomas Berry, won the Village Farm Stake for 3-year-old pacers today on the closing Grand Circuit program at Historic Track. The event had a value of $3,500.

LONDON, Aug. 2 (U.P.) -- Military observers here believed tonight that a slight advantage had passed to the Red Army after six weeks of war, and information received in Russian quarters said that ten German armored divisions, numbering approximately 110,000 men, 4,500 tanks and 30,000 other vehicles, had been "destroyed, badly mauled or disorganized" on the Eastern front thus far.

THERE was a time not many double-features ago when Hollywood wouldn't listen to contraltos, tenors, sopranos, baritones, etc. except on the radio, and even the torch warblers found it difficult to gret a hearing by producers outside of the night spots.
BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Lefty Grove got off to a shaky start today in bidding for his 301st major league pitching victory and the Tigers defeated the veteran Red Sox southpaw, 6 to 5.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, July 23 -- The strategic war materials agreement concluded for two years between Brazil and the United States on last May 15 has proved to be a monkey wrench in the Axis war machine. It has both closed the door to Axis purchasing agents and enabled Brazil to get rid of export surplus materials, while also insuring the United States a steady source of supply for certain strategic materials.

THE Bennington Festival will get under way on Saturday evening with the first of nine dance performances in the little theatre of Bennington College, making Vermont once more the Summer center of the modern dance as it Has been annually since 1934.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Gathered here tonight at the American Yacht Club were the sailing craft, their owners and crews that will start tomorrow on the season's largest cruise. It has been augmented by the decision of the New York Yacht Club not to hold its annual series of port-to-port runs.

Within the high, forbidding walls or the Kremlin a native of Sioux City, Iowa, last week was cordially received by Joseph Stalin. The Iowan, tall, gaunt and smiling, was Harry L. Hopkins, regarded by many as President Roosevelt's closest adviser. For the Russians the Hopkins visit was a triumph, a tangible sign that six weeks of Soviet resistance to the Nazi war machine had startled and impressed the world.

THE great religions of the world long have been subjects of intensive study by Western scholars. A great number of books have dealt with their beliefs and practices and most of their major writings have now become easily available in translation.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H. -- Bretton Woods colonists will hold a frankfurter roast on the flat rocks in the Ammonoosuc River tomorrow evening, with group singing and a dance later in the Mount Washington Moon Room.
