General Ion Antonescu, dictator-Premier of Nazi-controlled Rumania, has quit his post in the German war machine as a result of quarrels between Adolf Hitler and Rumanian leaders, according to a British radio report last night, and clashes between Rumanian divisions and German Elite Guard units have damaged morale so severely that Hitler has replaced the Rumanians with Italians on the Bessarabian front against Russia.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Ever since it was announced that the Russians were reverting to their revolutionary system in field operations -- the installation of political commissars beside every senior officer -- the Russian armies have been given up for lost. It is commonly assumed that any hindrance to complete control by military professionals must lead to disaster.

STRONG waves from Tokyo are striking the shores of Eastern America, carrying hot verbal shots aimed at recent United States moves in the Far East. For the past two months evening waves from Japan have been blanketed by unfavorable atmospherics in the Arctic.

THOSE who seven years ago, succumbed to the fascination of "And Quiet Flows the Don" are sure to appreciate as much, or even more, the continuation and conclusion of the celebrated novel which has now appeared under the title of "The Don Flows Home to the Sea."

Recent reports from builders and developers in practically all of the residential centers in Queens and Nassau Counties are practically unanimous that the present Summer season has witnessed the largest volume of home buying and construction that has been seen in the suburban communities of Long Island for several years.

Word from Washington that price ceilings on farm product could not be fixed at less than 110 per cent of parity sent wheat and cotton into wild upswings in yesterday's brief market. Wheat rose 3 cents a bushel. Cotton shot upward $4.75 a bale.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Gary Cooper received $482,819 in the calendar year 1939, according to the Treasury's compilation of compensation paid by corporations in excess of $75,000 made public today. His income came from Samuel Goldwyn Company, Inc., Ltd., $295,106, and Paramount Pictures, Inc., $187,713.

THE war situation has compelled the Surinam postal authorities to resort to temporary use of a rubber hand stamp. This Netherlands colony's postal paper was formerly made in Holland, now under Nazi occupation.

"WHAT shall I do when -- ?" It is the question parents most often ask, and there's no single answer, worse luck. They're sometimes told, "It isn't what you do, so much as how you do it; it's your attitude that counts." At which, possibly, some parents may mutter, "Attitude -- what do you mean, 'attitude'?"

It is a regrettable fact that imagination and initiative in developing or using new weapons of war have come in the present conflict mainly from the German side. One thinks of magnetic mines, self-sealing tanks in airplanes, dive bombers, modern airplane and tank development, the use of parachute troops and gliders.

OTTAWA, Aug. 2 -- A junior air force for teen-age boys, designed as a preliminary training program of the Royal Canadian Air Force, has been started under the auspices of the Department of National Defense at Ottawa. Known as the Air Cadet League of Canada, the teen-age organization follows closely the air force pattern of ranks, training and uniform, the boys appearing as junior versions of their older brothers in the Royal Canadian Air Force.
Whatever the world at large does about "war and rumors of wars," the month of August will be filled to the brim with athletic battles here in our peaceful U.S.A.

ANNA STEN will be joining the cast of "Separate Rooms" during the week of Aug. 18, the former film star being scheduled to start rehearsals a week from tomorrow in the role Glenda Farrell had. With his troupe again set, Alan Dinehart, co-star and producer of the comedy, is turning his attention to a Fall itinerary, which, it seems, is on the formidable side.
MOSCOW, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

MATES Hidden behind the excitement and the spectacle of the season's great horse races is a quiet and homely factor whose importance is known to all horsemen. This is the presence in the horse's commodious box stall of an animal companion.

Asserting the money spent in Canada by travelers from the United States plays a large role in increasing Canada's supply of dollars, Arthur S. Kleeman, president of the Colonial Trust Company and head of the Credits for Canada Committee recently organized by him, said yesterday that the Dominion was in need of all the dollar exchange obtainable to buy war materials in this country.

To the Music Editor: WE are just concluding our season with the fourteenth subscription concert which has already been given with great success in Tel Aviv and Jerusalem. At this concert once again I had the orchestra condu t itself, and I must say that our musicians gave an excellent performance.

THE murder game started from a rainy-day whim for a retrospective stumping of the experts -- "we're smarter than Sherlock Holmes and the rest." So ten bright representatives of the idle rich drew lots for murderer and murderee and worked out elaborate assurance of the criminal's anonymity.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 2 -- Light and variable winds made the Stamford Yacht Club's forty-ninth annual regatta, the thirteenth in the Long Island Sound championship series, a trying occasion for a number of the leading skippers today.

COMMERCIAL television is a month old. While the new art is yet too young to permit full appraisal of its scope as an instrument of entertainment, there is a marked indication that television already is a strong contender for a niche alongside of broadcasting and the theatre.

THE annual national tournament at Asbury Park, N.J., largest contract bridge tournament of the year, begins at the Asbury Park Convention Hall tomorrow afternoon. Play will proceed through the week and probably will not end until Monday, Aug. 11.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- In spite of what Lippy Leo Durocher deemed and denounced as rank umpiring, the rampant Dodgers overcame the handicap of three runs presented as a gift to the Cubs in the first inning and came on to win the second contest of the three-game series, 9 -- 6, today.

Overnight news from Washington that, under the terms of the proposed price-control bill, the ceiling price on cotton would be set at 110 per cent of parity, instead of 100 per cent as had been the general belief, resulted in an opening advance of 52 to 90 points in the prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.

TRAINEES' HEALTH -- An experimental program for salvaging the health and physical fitness of a group of volunteers from among the 43 per cent of the trainees now being rejected, was described before the Population Association of America by Dr. G. St. J. Perrott, chief of the division of public health methods of the U.S. Public Health Service.

William S. Knudsen, director of the Office of Production Management, and William M. Batt, deputy OPM production division director, will be the principal speakers at the sessions of the New York City Defense Production Clinic on Aug. 13 and 14, it was announced yesterday.
GUATEMALA CITY -- Visitors to this city are now able to visit the site of another city, Kaminal Juyu, fifteen centuries old, only three miles drive from the capital.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Slugging made up for three errors and numerous fumbles that didn't get into the box score today as the Cardinals downed the lowly Phillies, 11 to 7, to maintain their one-game lead over Brooklyn.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 2 -- A diamond given in trust ten years ago to the Right Rev. James Dewolf Perry, Bishop of Rhode Island, has been transformed into a little hewn-log Episcopal missionary church nestling in the forests of the Hoback Basin in Wyoming.

BELGIUM'S fifth semipostal series, issued to raise funds to finance the development of the Abbey of Notre Dame d'Orval in Southeastern Belgium, about twenty miles from Sedan, reached New York last week. Twelve denominations carry six designs which picture the activities of the Orval friars in earlier centuries.

LAURELTON PARKWAY, the link of the belt system that skirts the Queens-Nassau borderline from Southern Parkway to Cross Island Parkway, is fast becoming dotted with playgrounds under the Park Department-WPA program for creating as much play space along the parkway routes as possible.

BUFFALO, Aug. 2 -- The "phenomenal" growth of the United Automobile Workers-C.I.O. in the last year is the keynote of the annual report prepared by President R.J. Thomas for the sixth annual convention of the union, which opens here on Monday.

THERE is a story -- probably apocryphal -- that when James Gleason was playing in his own prize-fighting slang classic, "Is Zat So," (he co-authored it with Richard Taber) back in 1925, he was scheduled to address a Columbia drama class.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Federal Government ordered tonight the rationing of rayon yarn "to avert complete dislocation of the silk hosiery and civilian silk weaving industry" in which 175,000 workers are employed and for which no raw silk may be processed after midnight tonight.
VICHY, France, Aug. 2 -- It is being recalled here tonight that, on one of his tours early this year, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain said, in effect:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Allocation of $21,088,125 for operation of the National Youth Administration student work program, which will aid about 500,000 needy students during the 1941-42 academic year, was announced today by Aubrey Williams, NYA Administrator.

BERLIN, Aug. 2 -- The German invasion of Russia has ended its seventh week, and although most Germans unquestionably anticipated that their legions would win another smashing Blitzkrieg victory there is nothing in today's communique that indicates victory is just around the corner.

TRAVEL Lines: The Tobacco Trail Association (formerly the Washington-Florida Short Route Association) plans a motorcade to Richmond, Va., in early September, with tobacco men from Baltimore, Md., to Darien, Ga., participating....

WARWICK, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Eugene Clifford, publisher of The Orange County Leader and a former New York newspaper man, died in St. Anthony's Hospital here today at the age of 55. Mr. Clifford's home was at Florida, N.Y., where he had been publishing The Leader for the last seven months.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I. -- For vacationists who savor a dash of romantic legend with their Summer recreation, there are few other places so satisfactory as an island in the sea. Islands create legends in much the same way as oysters create pearls -- by coating the memory of an unhappy experience with a lovely opacity.

Educators everywhere are responding with "superb" enthusiasm to the program of the United States Committee on Educational Reconstruction, Dr. Reinold Schairer, research director, reported yesterday, about a year after the committee was formed at Princeton to nake plans for the educational rehabilitation of a post-war world.

Earnings of the steel industry before providing Federal income and excess-profits taxes and reserves for other contingencies in the second quarter of 1941 were 18.7 per cent higher than in the first quarter, despite an increase of 10 cents an hour in wages on April 1, which lifted the average pay about 11 per cent over the first quarter.

TORONTO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The lastplace Toronto Maple Leafs held the International League-leading Newark Bears to an even split today, scoring a 3-2 opening-game decision before dropping the seven-inning nightcap, 8 to 3.

THE year has already brought us one excellent biography of Clara Barton, that by Mildred Mastin Pace, but there is still plenty of room for Mrs. Nolan's life of that woman whose invincible courage and service deserved every commemoration.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 2 -- The economic war between Japan and the United States has resulted in an immense increase in the cost of living of all Shanghai residents, foreign and Chinese. Provision stores dealing in imported goods declare they are unable to import replacement stocks and are attempting to cut individual purchases while increasing prices daily.

THE title of this excellent analysis of Germany's ills is something of a misnomer. Certainly, we get the impression that there is too much of Mr. Hyde and too little of Dr. Jekyll. To hitch your wagon to a star is supposed to be a fine thing, but for an entire nation of 80,000,000 souls to hitch its wagon to an evil star is quite another matter.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Successive hits by Jeff Heath and Hal Trosky in the ninth inning enabled the Indians to beat the Athletics, 3 to 2, in the opener of their series today.

CHICAGO, Aug 2 -- Proposed price-control legislation which provides that no ceiling be placed on the leading grains at less than 110 per cent of parity resulted in strong dealings in futures on the Board of Trade here today.

ROME, Aug. 2 -- Discussing Italy's Army in the newspaper Regime Fascista, Roberto Farinacci strongly criticizes its organization and advocates "totalitarian" reforms that would eliminate imperfections and defects shown in past performances.

Skunk and Honey Protect Food The odor of skunk mixed with honey may replace rat traps and poison in the protection of feedstuffs from rodents, according to a report submitted to the American Chemical Society by Leonard A. Ford of State Teachers College, Mankato, and Donald F. Clausen of Minneapolis.

IT is good news to have a genuine comedy depending not on the war, but on "la vie humaine" for its interest, come from England these days. Better still when it is the work of one of the generation of writers who must have been playing around in very youthful rompers when Germany made her 1914 bid for European hegemony.

How five City College students constituted an informal ambassadorial party of good-will and good works for American education in Chile was related yesterday by the only one of them to return since they sailed for Santiago last year. He is Stanley Rogoff, 19-year-old senior at the college, who took his junior year at the University of Chile as winner of the Aaron Naumberg Scholarship for study abroad.

WOODS HOLE, Mass. -- The reputation of New England homes for remaining a long time in one place seems to run less true to form after one crosses the Cape Cod Canal. Summer visitors are heard to remark upon the surprising mobility of some of the Cape's buildings.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 2 -- Another "collaboration crisis" involving the "request" for a change in the Ministries of War and Interior in the Vichy Cabinet, as well as the right to "protect" the French North and West African naval and air bases from the "imperialistic designs of 'foreign powers,'" appears to be developing in Vichy tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The letters exchanged between President Roosevelt and Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee, together with Secretary Morgenthau's memorandum on the pending tax bill, were as follows:
CINCINNATI, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Braves broke the Reds' latest winning streak at four games today as young Tom Earley outpitched the veteran Paul Derringer for a 6-to-1 victory.

NOT usually regarded as an organization given to kicking up its heels in song, dance and other forms of entertainment, the Treasury Department of the United States of America now finds itself a munificent sort of host to the radio public.

The extent to which the agricultural bloc is "in the saddle" so far as price-control legislation is concerned is a great deal more than many business men directly affected by the bill introduced on Friday realize, according to representatives of trade groups who spent the week in Washington with their ears open.

With a drastic rationing of gasoine expected to be put into effect along the Atlantic Seaboard, starting immediately after Labor Day, the oil refineries in Texas and the mid-Continent area are going to be faced with the problem of what to do with their excess supplies of motor fuel.

Women who keep house are getting a bit disturbed about what the defense effort is likely to do to their household supplies. For, of course, substitutes will have to be found for various metals. Plastics are the natural thing to look to in non-cooking ware.

With output of electric power registering new weekly peaks as the national defense program gathers momentum, an adequate supply of power throughout the nation to meet the increasing demands of production of war material has become one of the most important issues of the day.

HANOVER, N.H. -- The State of New Hampshire will stage a week-long Craftsman's Fair Aug. 11-16, to indicate the progress that has been made since its pioneer movement started a decade ago. The eighth annual fair will be held at Dartmouth College, which has turned over Alumni Gymnasium and other facilities to the League of New Hampshire Arts and Crafts.

DETROIT, Aug. 2 -- The first of 9,000 Rolls Royce-Merlin engines, similar to those with which Spitfires and Hurricanes have fought off the German air attack on England, were put on the testing block today at the new Packard aircraft engine plant here and began running with a roar which Lord Halifax.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Southpaw Edgar Smith scattered seven hits and showed perfect control as the White Sox turned back the Senators, 3 to 1, today and evened the series ot one game each. It was Smith's eleventh victory of the year.

Twenty-three of the volunteer ambulance drivers who sailed on the ill-fated Egyptian liner Zamzam yesterday heard their courage and discipline praised by the master of the ship, Captain William Gray Smith, in a letter dated May 15.

Stockings are of extreme importance to a woman's poise, so the news that the supply of filmy silk hose has been definitely curtailed has disturbed many women a good deal. There isn't much sign of unusual business at some hosiery counters; at others there is evidence that there is a run on -- instead of in -- stockings.
AUGUST has long been a favorite month with Americans, no stay-at-homes in any month, for vacations. This August they appear to be out to break all past records.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Aug. 1:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Ways and Means Committee rejected today President Roosevelt's surprise request for changes in the pending tax bill which would modify the husband-wife joint return clause, raise the excess profits tax for large corporations and broaden the income tax base.

Beating the Yankees still is considered a sterling accomplishment, but now the other clubs in the league are trying to devise some method of scoring on them. Marvin Breuer pitched the third straight shut-out for the Bombers before 10,758 at the Stadium yesterday and no one has scored on Joe McCarthy's heroes in thirty successive innings.

VICHY, France, Aug. 2 (U.P.) -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Vice Premier Francois Darlan and General Maxime Weigand were reported tonight to be standing in a solid bloc against pressure from Nazi sources, said to include a written threat to placo relations between Germany and France, as of tonight, on a basis of conqueror and conquered nation.

THE nation's gain in department-store sales over a year ago broadened to 27 per cent in the July 26 week, and there was every indication that similar gains would continue through August. Major reason for the sharper rise was the fact that much of industry is running right through the Summer without the usual let down, thus keeping payrolls high.

THE time to prepare for peace is now. The object of war is peace. But peace is impossible unless we are ready to accept the risk of war. Peace is dynamic, not static. And "security" is its deadly enemy.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Aug. 2 -- In commemoration of the 150th anniversary of Vermont's entrance into the Union, the Bread Loaf Printers at Middlebury College's School of English have finished setting the type and printing a book of ten Vermont ballads as their contribution to the State's sesquicentennial celebration.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Construction employes at two government munitions plants in the St. Louis area -- the $89,000,000 small arms ammunition plant and the $34,000,000 TNT plant at Weldon Springs -- failed to report for work on the 8 o'clock shift today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 2 -- Miss Elise Fisher Reeves, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Reeves of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and this city, joined the ranks of the season's debutantes here tonight when she was formally presented to society at a dinner dance given by her parents.

The Nazis will probably take it as an offense that among the symbols which appear on the new weather map, of which the first copies have been made available in Washington, appears an ominous "V." They will not be appeased by an explanatory table which shows that the "V" stands for squalls.

You will turn to the latest Oppenheim for escape from the horrors of today into the more agreeable horrors of the one hundred and eleventh book to come from that facile pen. You will not be deceived, for the entertainment is most diverting.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- During the last week there has been much talk in the House of Commons about production, including the speech by Prime Minister Churchill in which he admitted faults but defended the present set-up and warned of invasion.

EGON PETRI, the eminent Dutch pianist, will perform Busoni's piano concerto at the Busoni memorial concerto to be given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, with Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, on Dec. 28 in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Petri was a pupil of Busoni.

OSLO, German -- Occupied Norway, Aug. 2 -- Reich Commissioner Josef Terboven was empowered today to declare a state of emergency -- backed by authorization for sentences of death or imprisonment -- to preserve public order, security and economic life in Norway.

CHAIRMAN: Senator Tom Connally of Texas, whose first act as a member of Congress was to vote for the declaration of war against Germany in 1917, last week became chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. A stanch supporter of the Roosevelt Administration's foreign policy, Mr. Connally declared that no nation should be allowed to become "too big for its britches."

GIRARD, Ohio, Aug. 2 -- Shooting one of the greatest competitive rounds of the golf season, a 63, seven under par, this morning, smooth-stroking Craig Wood took a six-hole lead over big Vie Ghezzi today in their battle for the unofficial world championship.

To the Radio Editor: WHEN we listen to radio news programs these days it seems as if the advertising announcements are steadily encroaching upon what we really listen for. None of us objects to the presence of advertising on radio; but lately the sponsors seem to be crowding out the news itself.

WHEN young Eric Gill decided that he wanted to be an artist instead of an engineer, he entered the Chichester Art School and before long found himself on the way toward a promising security as an art teacher.

Centering around an original theme, birds in decorative art, the exhibition now on at the Decorators Club, 745 Fifth Avenue, offers some compensation for having to be in town in August. Here is a chance to spend a refreshing half hour viewing screens, pottery, tole trays and wallpapers picturing varied types of bird life.

PALENVILLE -- Because understanding parents fostered the fondness of a young boy for wild animal life, the youthful curiosity matured into a profession for a man who today conducts, in the Catskill Mountains, one of the world's unique game preserves.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Improving sharply, as some expected he would, over his previous slow-track effort, Fenelon today drove home a head winner of the thirty-ninth Merchants' and Citizens' Handicap before 15,163 persons at the Saratoga track.

HERE is a book rather difficult to classify, though there can be no doubt whatsoever about its considerable charm. Ostensibly an autobiography, it is much more than that. Exquisitely written, it is particularly entrancing -- and valuable -- as a picture of Russian life and character before the author was born.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 2 -- After the hard Finnish offensive, carried out for two weeks and resulting in territorial gains deep into Karelia, there seem to have been a slight standstill for the last week while mopping-up operations and rebuilding of supply lines has taken place.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Senator Walter F. George, Democrat of Georgia, asserted today that "if Japan engages in no further aggression" this country could work out a barter arrangement under which trade could continue with the Japanese Empire.

TOKYO. SLOWLY but inevitably, like the Deluge of the Scriptures, the war is spreading throughout the world and beginning to engulf all nations. With the declaration of American-British economic sanctions against Japan and Japan's retaliatory action in kind, the European war and the China war become joined and the first stage of total world war is reached in the Pacific.

A phenomenal improvement in the economic position of South America such as few would have forecast a year ago is apparent from recent foreign trade statistics. The trade of these countries with the United States in the second year of the war is showing an abrupt reversal of the trend for the first year and now we are buying more from our "good neighbors" to the South than they are buying from us.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (U.P.) -- Secretary Knox joined the White House secretariat today in appealing to newspapers to cooperate in secrecy concerning President Roosevelt's cruise.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Broad intimations that Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's government at Vichy was giving away the French Empire piecemeal to the aggressor nations, and a warning that the relations of the United States with Vichy, and with French colonial governments, would be guided by the measure in which they resisted the Axis powers, were contained in a formal statement made here today by Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles.

THERE is only one Hamid and he needs no prophet. From top man on a pyramid of Arabian tumblers he has leaped in less than a quarter century to the top of another pyramid, the world's largest booking agency for outdoor acts of all kinds.

FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT has created several hundred buildings, written an autobiography and numerous articles for magazines, lectured a good deal and taught many aspiring young architects. He is, therefore, rather fully on record.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Congressional farm group, having succeeded in forcing a revision in the Administration's price and rent control bill to forbid price ceilings on agricultural commodities below 110 per cent of parity, gave notice today that it still was not satisfied and would seek an amendment to the bill putting a floor under agricultural prices.

New varieties of vegetables developed in various parts of the country and now being tested at the New Jersey College of Agriculture and Experiment Station, as well as new strains of tomatoes and peppers developed by the institution, will be among the highlights of this year's Vegetable Field Day at Rutgers University, New Brunswick, on Saturday.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A strike by 600 carpenters and a holiday by other American Federation of Labor craftsmen brought construction work to a virtual standstill today at Northern Ohio's two big Army ordnance plants, Plum Brook and Ravenna.
Miss Rodger has written a rather touching and believable story of young people who marry too suddenly, have a terrible time getting acquainted and finally work out a happy adjustment.

Four United States ships of war, under Commodore Matthew Calbraith Perry, sailed into Japan's Yedo Bay on a July morning in 1853. They had come to open the self-isolated archipelago of Nippon to Western trade. Their decks were cleared for action if the inhabitants resisted.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 2 -- Miguel Culaciatti, Minister of the Interior, in a letter addressed to the Chief of Police of the Federal capital today, instructed him to prevent all activities of the "Superior Council of Argentine Nationalism" because this body, being organized on military lines, violated the Constitution.

INCREASED use of plastics by the automobile industry will be reflected in 1942 motor cars in which more than 120 parts will be made of these relatively new materials. This figure is the result of a survey of the larger motor car manufacturing plants of the plastics department of the du Pont company.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- The British ignored en masse today an urgent government request to stay at home this week-end, the August Bank Holiday, so that gasoline could be saved and railroads could be kept clear for freight and coal traffic vital to Britain's war effort.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- President Roosevelt plans to leave tomorrow for New London to board the Presidential yacht Potomac for a week's vacation in New England waters.

Beginning in June, 1940, with funds for the construction of twenty-four defense housing projects, the USHA now has a program calling for the construction of 101 projects to provide homes for 30,902 families engaged in defense work, Nathan Straus, Administrator of the USHA, points out.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the second year of a mortal struggle for the freedom of Europe and of the world, preposterous claims and polemics about the passage of certain regions from one European State to another may only have a result to persuade many old, honest isolationist Americans that the Europeans are still a lot of incurable mad dogs.

In a four-month tour of South America, touching all of the ten republics, this correspondent has found among many Catholics, lay and clerical, marked suspicions of the influence of the United States and in some cases a leaning toward the totalitarian side.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 -- The century-old yards of the Cramp Shipbuilding Company, once the largest in the nation, entered full tilt into the race to build a two-ocean Navy today with the laying of the keel of the 10,000-ton cruiser Miami.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 2 -- Brazil's trade in the first half of the current year registered a strong gain over the six months to June 30, 1940, despite the virtual ending of commerce with Europe. United States purchases of strategic war needs increased, also cotton exports and coffee.

SWEETWATER, B.C. -- The pioneers were always in a hurry. They appeared on the west coast of America, seeking gold, long before the vast lands in the middle of the continent had been conquered. Even today, decades after a later generation of pioneers rushed to Alaska and the Yukon Territory, a magnificent wilderness, much of it still unexplored, exists between the northern outposts and the end of the continental highway system to the south.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 2 -- Further progress in ascertaining the chief contenders for the hunter and jumper crowns was made today as the sixth annual Jersey Shore horse show continued at Mr. and Mrs. William Buchsbaum's Boxwood Farm.

CINCINNATI, OHIO. THIS year the Cincinnati Summer opera is celebrating its twentieth anniversary. While the Summer opera season draws visitors from many different parts of the country, the nightly audiences of three to four thousand people are primarily enthusiastic Cincinnatians who follow the opera j with the same kind of gusto as that j which they apply to the activities of the Cincinnati Reds.

TWO years ago Marshal Goering was moved to derisive laughter by the mere thought of American aircraft production. And well he might have been if he was thinking only of output at the time, for during 1939 the aeronautical industry in this country produced only 2,400 planes.

All is in readiness for the opening tomorrow of one of the richest light-harness racing meets over staged at the famed Good Time Park one-mile triangular track in Goshen, N.Y. It will command the attention of the nation's trotting and pacing devotees throughout the week.
Tishah b'ab services commemorating the 1,871st anniversary of the destruction of Jerusalem and the burning of the Temple by Roman Legions will be held in synagogues today.

There are probably few women who, at one time or another, are not completely discouraged about their appearance. They feel dolefully that they have permitted themselves to become slovens, slatterns. The ensuing gloom is best dispelled by an evening devoted to most extensive, luxurious grooming, in which a long, fragrant tub bath -- instead of a shower -- plays an important part.

Time Numbers, Pass Not every waking moment in the nation's capital is devoted to national defense, which is as it should be. Some margin must be left for life's other claims. Early in the week the National Gallery of Art in Washington had its millionth visitor since the opening on March 18.

A PROGRAM marking the centenary of the birth of Antonin Dvorak will be given at the Stadium Thursday night. Herman Adler, the Czech conductor, who makes his Stadium debut Tuesday, will direct the Dvorak concert.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The dangerous third rail is eliminated by a new subway car patented (No. 2,251,230) by Earl J.W. Ragsdale of Norristown, Pa. The car also provides a new system of piped ventilation which adds to the comfort of passengers.

It would be beyond reason, as any one who knows the Glen Hazard Boys would agree to expect them to set out on an apparently simple treasure hunt without running into complications. They find plenty of them, when, having just caught their breath from adventure in the West, they join their old friend Harry Linden and his father, who is trustfully planning on a rest cure, in Florida to search for the pirate Gasparula's treasure.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Fortunately, the time has not arrived yet in this country when utmost thriftiness of all kinds of materials becomes a national virtue and an imperative necessity. None the less, shortage is noticeable already in a few items, especially in materials whose sources are abroad.

The largest single group in the Fusion coalition that elected Fiorello La Guardia to the post of Mayor in 1933 was the Republican party. Four years later G.O.P. votes, again part of a coalition, helped make Mr. La Guardia the first "reform" Mayor to win two terms in office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Although the forty-three State Legislatures in regular session during the first half of 1941 were largely preoccupied with new problems arising out of the defense emergency, they did not entirely neglect measures to enhance the security of teachers in the public schools.

HOLLYWOOD. SINCE Columbia's $2,500,000 misadventure with "Arizona," the studio is displaying great caution in filming "Texas." The yarn, which deals with driving a herd of cattle along the Chisholm Trail to the railhead at Abilene, is not to be confused with "The Texans," which treated the same exploit with Joan Bennett making the thousand-mile trip without disturbing a single hair in her Westmore coiffure.

A flexible curriculum sensitive to the demands of the national defense program will be maintained at Columbia University throughout the present emergency, Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, provost of the university, pledged yesterday.

With each passing week the astonishment of the world is growing at Soviet Russia's resistance to the Nazi war machine. For a long time military experts were skeptical about the Red Army, and economists, analyzing the resources of the U.S.S.R. in case of a Russo-German war, were inclined to minimize Russian resistance.

Retail trade in the New York area last week was 20 to 25 per cent ahead of a year ago, with all departments showing gains. The largest increases were in home furnishings and hosiery, the latter owing to consumer efforts to guard against the impending silk shortage.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2 -- In one of the most masterful performances he has ever turned in, Robert L. Riggs Jr. conclusively established his superiority over Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., today to win the Southampton invitation tennis tournament for the fourth time.

FOR the first time in photographic history, instantaneous photography in total darkness with invisible light is now possible. According to the Wabash Photolamp Corporation, a specially designed flash bulb known as the Wabash Superflash Blackout bulb is available for use in blackouts and in places where the ordinary visible flash cannot be used, such as photographic darkrooms, theatres, etc.

An appeal for aid in the evacuation of 420,000 British children still in the London area was received airmail from J.B. Priestley and made public here yesterday by the American headquarters of the Foster Parents Plan for War Children.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Simultaneously with the observance this month of the fiftieth anniversary of the Cornell University Library in its present home, a movement has begun to bring added support to this "heart of the university."

Frank S. Hogan, administrative assistant to District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, accepted yesterday the Democratic designation for the District Attorneyship of New York County with the "complete consent and approval" of Mr. Dewey.

A brand-new speed-boat regatta, unsung with the usual fanfare of trumpets and tub-beating of publicists, climbs up into the limelight this afternoon and promises, eve from its inception to become welcome and important addition to the Summer series of race meets.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- The principal August event in the Poconos will be the twelfth annual Pocono Mountains Horse Show, on Aug. 21, 22 and 23 at the Arena in the Clouds, Mount Pocono, for the benefit of the Monroe County General Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Not many months hence, if the proposed price controls are put on the statute books in their present form, the political considerations which are largely responsible for their incompleteness will probably get a severe test. Many economists, especially those who have studied or had direct experience with the problem during and just after the World War, do not believe the test can successfully be met.

A LITTLE less than 150 years ago Ludwig van Beethoven created his Fifth symphony. As introduction to that heroic score, which humanity has taken to its heart as the most popular of all works in its form, he fashioned the motto theme of four notes, of which Schindler said, "Thus fate knocks at the door" -- the four notes which have rung down the last 100 years and are the cornerstone of the symphony.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Aug. 2 -- Painted white and surmounted by a statue of the Goddess of Liberty, the 1,000th tank to be made by the American Car and Foundry Company at its Berwick plant for the United States and Great Britain was formally presented to the government at elaborate ceremonies this afternoon.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As our new strategic outpost may soon prove to be a turning point in the Battle of the Atlantic, what sort of an island is Iceland? It is the most interesting of all paradoxes. Here are 40,437 square miles lying so far north that a tip touches the Arctic Circle, yet the climate is comparatively warm from the Gulf Stream that encircles its coast.

The Board of Higher Education is asking the City Planning Commission for a new $1,650,000 School of Technology building for City College, it was revealed yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, acting president of City College. In the capital outlay request for 1942, sent to the commission by Ordway Tead, president of the Board of Higher Education, $800,000 is sought as an initial appropriation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The statement of Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles on the French agreement with Japan regarding Indo-China follows:

SEVERAL dozen of the best contract bridge players in the United States -- and several hundred who aspire to rank with them -- are gathering today in the Municipal Convention Hall off the Boardwalk in Asbury Park, N.J., for that strangest of sporting events, a national championship bridge tournament.

In the two decades between the close of the last World War and the beginning of this one it was fashionable and smart to say that there was no such thing as a good war, and that one would go to jail before he would be drafted into the Army. There were many who said these things and meant them at the time.

WATCH HILL, R.I., Aug. 2 -- Watch Hill's outstanding event of the season will be the second annual Flower Fete to be held Wednesday for the benefit of the American Red Cross. Sponsored by the Watch Hill Improvement Society, the fete enlists the Summer and year round residents of this resort, Westerly and Weekapaug.

The careless granting of advertising allowances to retail dealers by the national manufacturers is rapidly disappearing as a business practice and the immediate prospect is for either much stricter control over such allowances or their elimination entirely, according to opinions expressed last week by both manufacturers and retailers.

For the third successive year, the Summer School of Catholic Action will hold a week's session on the campus of Fordham University in the Bronx, beginning Aug. 18 and lasting through Aug. 23. It will be the fourth session of the school held this year, following similar meetings in St. Louis, Pittsburgh and Boston.

ROME, N.Y., Aug. 2 (AP) -- This Central New York city, where Fort Stanwix was raised and the digging of the Erie Canal begun, turned another historic shoveful today to start the construction of a $20,000,000 Army air depot. Mayor E.L. Ethbridge managed the controls of a snorting bulldozer to scoop up a chunk of sod.

Robert Anderson Shaw, former Mayor of Teaneck, N.J., member of the law firm of Phillips Avery at 1 Wall Street and specialist in estate and trust law, died Friday night in a hospital here, after a week's illness at the age of 70. He made his home at 88 Morningside Drive.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the R e t of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final adjustments.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The national lifeguard championships will be held here on Aug. 20. More than 5,000 persons are expected to line the beach and Boardwalk to watch the display of split-second action in boat and swimming rescues.

TOKYO, Aug. 2 -- The Japanese Government, telling its people that the international situation had grown explosive, further stepped up its already war-geared domestic economy today to make the nation economically self-sufficient and independent of American supplies.

To the Drama Editor: THE worthy and patriotic folks who have interested themselves in entertainment for the soldiers might profit by the experience of 1917-18. Thoroughly adequate theatres, each with a fully equipped stage and seating around 2,000 to 3,000, were provided in every cantonment. Shows, mostly of the light, musical show type, without big "names," and numbering twenty-five to fifty persons, played under straight percentage contracts.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Aug. 3 -- Germany's Eastern Blitzkrieg is now a complete failure and the Nazi Army has suffered casualties totaling more than 1,500,000 men during the first six weeks of its Russian campaign, it was announced today by the Soviet Foreign Office spokesman as simultaneous advices from the front reported the shattering of three more crack Nazi divisions and the destruction of a German column of 300 tanks.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Aug. 2 -- Except for minority isolationists, the sentiment concerning Japan at this American gateway to the Orient seems to boil down to a favorite phrase of the American language: "They are asking for it, let's let them have it."
BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 2 -- Six weeks of all-out fighting on the Russian front have failed to give the German armies a favorable decision in National Socialism's epic war against Communism.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- About 6,000 manufacturers were asked by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today to report on how their defense and non-defense orders are being affected by shortages of basic materials.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 2 -- Barring worry over the war, happy days are here again for the Middle Western farmer. Look in whatever direction one may from this watchtower the prospect is one of agricultural prosperity. It is a prosperity compounded of two parts, good crops and good prices.

SAFETY, especially in an emergency, often depends in part upon ability to bring a car to a stop in the minimum possible distance. To effect the stop, the driver usually must remove his foot from the accelerator, place it on the brake pedal and apply pressure.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- There'll be plenty of bearing down by both sides when the Ryder Cup professionals battle Bobby Jones's challengers at Detroit Aug. 23-24 in their United Service Organizations benefit match.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 -- Recent graduates of colleges all over the country numbering 222, whose degrees are in liberal arts, business administration, teaching, and other non-technical fields, concluded today the first phase of the "Production Engineering for Defense Industries" program of the University of Pennsylvania.

Wholesalers and retailers are especially interested in the price control legislation currently being introduced in Congress because of the adverse effect upon their sales of a continuation of the present upward trend of living costs.

THAT paragon of manhunters, Sherlock Holmes, is making ready to renew his artful crusade on the side of right for the delectation of America's armchair detectives. On the night of Oct. 5 at 10:30, as they say in the best pulp tradition, he will take up the trail of an ethereal crime wave that is expected to stretch into the Spring, on a WEAF network of sixty-eight stations.
BERLIN, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Today's German communique, issued from "the Fuehrer's headquarters," follows:

THE British Performing Right Society, founded in 1914 for the protection of composers and music publishers during the World War, was revived two years ago and is now, by royal patent, a permanent institution. The reason for the new status, according to Leslie Boosey, the chairman, is the unprecedented public demand for music of all sorts.

TOKYO, Aug. 2 -- With the addition today of New Zealand and South Africa to the list of countries that have frozen Japanese assets and whose assets Japan has frozen, the whole British Empire is now lined up with the United States in economic warfare against Japan.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., Aug. 2 -- A hint that a corps of domestic workers may soon supplant the enlisted personnel of the Army in doing kitchen police and fatigue details, thereby freeing regular soldiers for full-time attention to military training, was given today by Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, commanding officer of the 207th Coast Artillery (Anti-aircraft) Regiment.

The embargo on raw silk from Japan created a grave problem in the silk market last week, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. The immediate effect was the withdrawal of all prices by hosiery mills, mill agents and jobbers.

"TELL us if 16-year-old French boys would be accepted in the R.A.F." It was not an adventure-seeking youngster who wrote that to the British Broadcasting Company, but his mother, a soldier's wife, listening with her son every evening to the English radio which brought the only news the French could believe.

IN the absence of the bronze plaque that will probably be put up some day at station WNEW to commemorate the event, let it be noted that it was on Aug. 6, 1935, at midnight, that the fidgety but musical Stan Shaw inaugurated the all-night stint known as the "Milkman's Matinee."

AND now the "flivver" plane of the private flier has showed the cavalry what it can do. Fourteen of the small 65-horsepower planes -- ten Piper Cubs, two Aeroncas and two Taylorcraft -- were demonstrated for the Army during the recent manoeuvres of the Third Army in the desert country around El Paso, Texas, recently.

MUSIC has played a part in the development of motion pictures almost since the beginning. Many of us remember vividly the days when piano players whooped up the tempo as events on the silent screen approached a climax.

THE literature of book collecting seems to invite the talents of amiable volunteers who are ready and willing to encumber the amateur with advice. Their contributions range from selected bibliographies and checklists to recommended lists, essays and personal reminiscences.

While representatives of steamship operators conferred with the United States Maritime Commission at Washington last week on changes in maximum time-charter rates brought about under the Ship Warrants law, signed last month by President Roosevelt, shipping men here speculated on the possible effects of the measure.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- When President Roosevelt recently ordered the construction of 312 "ugly duckling" freighters to increase shipping tonnage speedily he revived an industry which had all but died.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Aug. 2 -- Mount Holyoke College students will look to the classroom and the laboratory as their first line of defense training in 1941-42, as new courses have been instituted and established ones revised in the light of contemporary events.
As the general strike of electrical workers continued yesterday, union leaders agreed that additional strikers might return to work on vital defense projects.
The sixth week of the Battle of Russia ended last night with the Nazi-Soviet legions still locked in titantic struggle in and around the Stalin defensive zone.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Nothing even resembling an upset was forthcoming today as the fifteenth annual Eastern grass court tennis championships got under way at the Westchester Country Club. However, only five men's and the same number of women's matches were contested.

COLLECTORS are born -- not made. The itch to acquire whole cases full of Kien Lung porcelain, or some such, is not a thing that overtakes you suddenly at 40 because you have become a very cultivated fellow. It really began at the rather dazed age of 3, by having pockets fuller than any one's else, and being incensed when some authority made you empty them out.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2 -- Several hundred members of the Summer Colony and their tennis week house parties attended the annual ball held tonight in the Colonial Ballroom and the Japanese Room of the Meadow Club to mark the conclusion of the club's fifty-first invitation tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON. THE United States, which is supposed to be the land of pork-barrel diplomacy, is finally elevating to its highest White House counsels a copybook diplomat, a professional in manner, outlook and appearance.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 20, Henry Bernstein makes certain statements concerning Marshal Petain which may sadly mislead the American people.

IT is just a year since the great exodus of children began from the other side of the Atlantic. In the twelvemonth more than 7,000 youngsters, 4,000 of them British, have been uprooted from their homes and brought to this country. It is now possible to appraise this vast social experiment, involving not only adjustments for the children but for the families caring for them.

Nearly every radio talk and newspaper article on garden sanitation urges the amateur gardener to burn the debris resulting from his clean-up of the border and garden in the Autumn. He is further admonished: "Don't put it on the compost pile."

More than 300,000 troops of the Third Army are converging on the pine country of East Texas and Western Louisiana for preliminary training which will develop next month into the largest peacetime manoeuvres in the history of the United States.

With a few exceptions the filling station owners of New York and the metropolitan area complied last night with the twelve-hour curfew on gasoline sales and the same was true of the rest of the Eastern seaboard.

Earle A. Mitchell's Grayling, a converted Class Q sloop representing the New Rochelle Yacht Club, won the Bayside Yacht Club's twenty-first annual Bayside-Block Island auxiliary race, finishing the 225-mile trip at 4:35 yesterday morning.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Pilot Officer Gregory Augustus Daymond, 20year-old member of the American Eagle Squadron of the Royal Air Force, became today the first member of the unit to destroy a German bomber.

Centuries ago the Norsemen dammed off a fjord at low tide, built ships on the mud flats and launched the finished ones by cutting the dam at high tide and letting the sea flow in. A similar method could be used to build along the lower Mississippi the ships that are now sorely needed.

FORT KNOX, Ky., Aug. 3 -- Colonel N. Butler Briscoe, post commander, disclosed today that a soldier had been wounded fatally during a guardhouse riot here on Wednesday night and that guards were forced to turn a fire hose on 350 milling prisoners after rifle shots fired over their heads failed to restore order.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Bob Feller finally chalked up his twentieth victory of the season today as the Indians split a double-header with the Athletics.

BERLIN, Monday, Aug. 4 (U.P.) -- A titanic battle of encirclement -- perhaps the decisive conflict of the entire Russo-German war -- is raging along a twisting 900-mile front from Lake Peipus to the Southern Ukraine as "fanatical" Red troop struggle to free themselves from a series of traps, German military quarters said today.

The first section of the newly developed Shore Road Park, Brooklyn, has been completed, the Department of Parks announced yesterday. It adjoins the Belt Parkway and is bounded by Shore Road, extending from Bay Ridge Avenue to Seventy-second Street.

Conservation of materials and emphasis on dealer service are rapidly becoming the chief keynotes in copy appeals in a number of industries seriously affected by defense production. Temporarily, at least, straight product selling has been relegated to the background.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The article "Roads Would Cut Passenger Runs" in THE TIMES is provocative of many thoughts. Unquestionably the average road would like very much to reduce its passenger service -- especially its local or short-haul passenger service. The war emergency might make a very good excuse for so doing.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 3 -- Royal Air Force planes ranged over the Mediterranean during the past two days, bombing Axis-controlled islands and searching out and attacking Axis warplanes, it was reported today. Effective raids were carried out on Crete, Lampedusa and Sicily, resulting in heavy damage to merchantmen, several bombers starting numerous fires and explosions, the report said.
NEW YORK Colonel 'Godwin Ordway, U.S.A., and Mrs. Ordway have arrived at the Vanderbilt from Washington.

There's no telling what the Weather Man will do next. Yesterday, according to his own admission, was a lovely day. But instead of enjoying it, as most people in the city did, he spent his time collecting statistics for the day, for last month, and even for the history of the Weather Bureau, which is currently celebrating its fiftieth anniversary.

VICHY, France, Aug. 3 -- By far the most interesting financial item last week was the promulgation of the new law modifying the code putting a tax on the profits from stock purchases after March 19. The tax was intended to reduce the profits of speculators and to check price increases that were considered harmful.
SEATTLE, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A gunman bent on robbery recklessly raked a basement saloon-club with bullets just before daybreak today, leaving three men dead and seven others wounded.

A new technique in secondary picketing, growing out of the 929-day-old Brass Rail Restaurant strike, sulted Saturday afternoon in the serving of a summons upon a union representative in a motorboat offshore at Jones Beach by State Patrolman Frank McConin in a State channel patrol boat.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 3 -- George Schrafft, 21-year-old Harvard grad who is awaiting an Army call and hopes for an air service assignment, had another sensational speed boating session here today. Most of the hydroplane pilots of the country have usually finished behind and seldom ahead of his amazing Chrissie IV, and today was no exception.

The Lords of the British Admiralty have expressed their gratitude to Bundles for Britain, Inc., and to its donors for the gifts of knitted garments and wool that have been supplied to the Royal Navy almost since the outbreak of the war.
LONDON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:
CINCINNATI, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The seventh-place Braves scored a pair of shut-out victories over the Reds today, 5 to 0 and 3 to 0.

VICHY, France, Aug. 3 -- Having made up his own mind on current problems, which include "collaboration" as well as internal problems, and having so informed his Cabinet last night, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain was as serene as ever today.

BERLIN, Aug. 3 -- The Berlin Boerse displayed a quiet attitude last week, with the markets exceedingly narrow and price fluctuations either way usually not exceedingly 1 or 2 points. The stock market developed, however, a somewhat stronger tone on Friday and Saturday.

TOKYO, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- Japan moved ahead today with her expansion program for a "new order" in the South Pacific and the press, filled with caustic criticism of the United States and Britain, hinted that the next major move might be against Thailand.

The Germans keep insisting that their primary interest in Russia is not to take territory but to destroy the Red Army. This may or may not have been true when the Russian campaign started, but it is certainly true now. In six weeks of fighting Russians they have learned at heavy cost that they acted more wisely than they knew when they signed the Nazi-Soviet pact and Immobilized this fighting force.

LONDON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Hints that Britain may soon open a Northern European front of her own on Germany's flank to help Russia abounded in London this quiet holiday week-end. Britain is known to have prepared a shock force for just such a job.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- The Far East continues to dominate discussions on the London commodity trade. While the democracies announced counter measures to the Japanese aggression their effect on the commodity markets remains uncertain. Freezing of the Japanese assets and the dependence on future shipments to Japan under licenses may mean a strong blockade or very little.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3--Finding the Cubs the most hospitable group they have encountered since leaving Brooklyn, the Dodgers left tonight regretfully after winning, 10-2, to sweep the three-game series and run their victory streak to four games.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The British have placed thousands of their finest troops, mainly tough Australians and the pick of the best Indian regiments, on the Malayan-Thai border in expectation of a showdown with the Japanese.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Liquidation by holders of September contracts developed in the lard market here last week, and prices declined sharply to the lowest level in about a month. As a result of the decline in the September, loose lard gained rapidly on the future, going to a discount of around 1 1/4 cent a pound, compared with 1 cent recently.

Arthur D. Koppel, the well-known builder, will reside at 242 East Seventy-second Street, where he has leased an apartment through Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers, who also reported renting in 25 East Eighty-sixth Street to Alan Burgheimer; in 436 East Seventy-third Street to Dr. George Bosworth Brown, and in 136 East Thirty-sixth Street to Miss Hannah Levinson.

The wholesale market was comparatively quiet last week with the bulk of Fall purchasing already completed. Merchandise ordered three and four weeks ago was beginning to move. Reorder activity picked up. There was a genuine response to the "V" campaign and the insignia was featured on handbags, jewelry, blouses, dresses and millinery.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 3 -- Word that several Bolivians had been arrested yesterday in Germany and German-occupied territories aroused indignation throughout this country today, although demonstrations organized after the news was broadcast last night were curbed by the state of seige in effect here.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- Chinese Communist quarters here hinted today that the Yenan Communist government was preparing for amicable relations with the Kuomintang [Nationalist party], especially in the post-war reconstruction period.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- New seasonal high prices for December and May wheat were established last week as the result of a let-up in hedging pressure, scattered buying attributed to mills and to the effect of the proposed price control legislation.

Third and fourth year medical and dental students in Class A schools who are selective service registrants, physically and otherwise qualified, are eligible for commissions as second lieutenants in the Army and ensigns in the Navy, it was announced yesterday.

Warning leaders of the nation and the church against being lulled into inactivity in the present world crisis, the Rev. Dr. James Palmer called upon Christians everywhere yesterday morning to change their lives and "be what God intended us to be."

The Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, declared that "the fact that we cannot enter at once into our hopes of peace and brotherhood and justice does not mean that these hopes lack reality in our kind of a world, but only that the time is not yet."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 3 -- For the first time since the beginning of the Russian campaign a Swedish newspaper has mentioned today that on the internal German front all is not well, thus confirming the impression of neutral observers here.

With the one-way traffic plan for the Willis Avenue and Third Avenue bridges over the Harlem River scheduled to become effective at 6 A.M. tomorrow, Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday the new regulations and routes for Bronx-bound and Manhattan-bound traffic.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued the following communique tonight:

The Summer air has a fresh, salty taste as it blows in from the sea, and the smell of seaweed mingles with its tantalizing tang. Summer is the time for seafood, and we warmly welcome the advent of a newcomer to the distinguished company of our finny favorites -- lobster newburg, New England clam chowder and sword-fish steak.

Tricks That Confuse One trouble with our inventor friends is their persistent habit of confusing us. First they produce some new device that changes our way of life. It introduces an artificiality -- a convenient one, perhaps, or an exciting one-but still an artificiality.

Wide fluctuations, accompanied by the heaviest trading in several years, featured dealings in the cotton futures market last week. Following an advance in early trading into new high ground, the market experienced the first big break since prices began to rise sharply early in May on President Roosevelt's message to Congress asking for price-control legislation.

Publicly announced gifts and bequests, to charities and related projects, in seven large cities in the United States during the first six months of 1941 totaled $43,051,198 as compared with $45,927,457, a decline of $2,876,259, during the same period in 1940, according to a study made by the John Price Jones Corporation, fund-raising consultants of 150 Nassau Street, released yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A super brain trust designed to out-think any other nation is being organized in the United States.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 3 -- Despite a strong comeback attempt in the closing events, the Holly Tree Farm's Grey Simon yielded the conformation hunter championship today to Mr. and Mrs. W. Haggin Perry's Cornish Hills as the three-day Jersey Shore horse show ended at Mr. and Mrs. William Buchsbaum's Boxwood Farm.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- In celebration of the sixty-ninth birthday of King Haakon, Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard made a short-wave broadcast tonight direct to the people of Norway from Station WRUL at Boston. He pledged to them the sympathy and the help of the people of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- More employment may become available for men between the ages of 45 and 65 as a result of an exchange of letters between Senator Hayden, Democrat, of Arizona, and John M. Carmody, Administrator of the Federal Works Agency.

The value of "things guns can't destroy" was emphasized as the goal of living in a sermon yesterday morning at Emmanuel Baptist Church, Lafayette Avenue and St. James Place, Brooklyn, by the Rev. Dr. Clarence Hill Frank, executive secretary of the Detroit Council of Churches.

BERLIN, Aug. 3 -- Germans who spread "silly rumors" that the Reich Government is contemplating confiscation of savings deposits should be taken before the Peoples Tribunal, Fritz Reinhardt, Assistant Minister of Finance, declared yesterday in a categorical denial of such rumors.
LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Operators on the Stock Exchange here last week were able to regain some of their optimism that had been overshadowed by events in the Far East.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- More than a third of all money lent by the Farm Security Administration to more than 900,000 farm families who were unable to get credit from other sources has been repaid, although a large part of it is not yet due, said Secretary Wickard today.
BRIARCLIFF MANOR, Aug. 3 -- The exception rather than the rule in golf, this was a day when the jinx that fastens itself to a player who is 2 up with five to go lost its grip.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 3 -- Certification of a C.I.O. union as bargaining agent for 300 truck drivers and inside workers employed by fourteen Minneapolis furniture stores was denied today by the State Labor Board.
Sales of housing properties by institutions featured realty activity in Brooklyn over the week-end.
The full length of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, nearly one-tenth of a mile from door to altar, was visible for the first time to worshippers yesterday during morning services.
LONDON, Monday, Aug. 4 (U.P.) -- The R.A.F. early today launched another savage assault that spread fiery havoc for twenty miles along the French invasion coast.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 3 -- Impending serious shortages in pig iron and steel-making scrap at important steel centers have diverted the attention of the industry and of defense production officials from the long-range aspects of steel capacity in their relation to emergency requirements to the more imminent problem of assuring a sufficient flow of these materials in order to forestall possible sharp interruption in the national steel output.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- A government - convened conference of automobile management, labor and government experts to formulate a program for preventing a threatened dislocation of the automobile industry due to defense requirements was advocated here today by R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, C.I.O.

LONDON, Aug. 3--The British Navy has knocked out another Italian cruiser, according to the Admiralty, which announced today that a submarine had scored two hits on a 6-inch-gun warship identified as either the Eugenio di Savoia or the Emanuele Filiberto Duca d'Aosta.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Eric McNair's homer with one aboard capped a winning rally for Buffalo in the sixth inning of the nightcap for an even split with Newark today. The spurt of three runs led to a 5-to-3 verdict after the Bears had romped off with the opener, 4 to 1.
MONTREAL, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Jack Graham's twenty-sixth home run, putting him within one of the Montreal record, gave the Royals an even break with the Jersey City Giants today.

VICHY, France, Aug. 3 (AP) -- In an unusual Sunday morning session Marshal Petain conferred today with the naval and military leaders of his inner Cabinet and the atmosphere in government circles was calm despite the Paris press campaign for closer collaboration with Germany.
BERLIN, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

LONDON, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- For the first time during the six-week war, British military authorities today gave the Russian Army a general strategic advantage over the Germans except in the Ukraine, where the Nazi Army was believed attempting a gigantic pincer movement around Kiev.

The truce that Marshal Henri Philippe Petain made with Adolf Hitler has not brought peace to France. Instead it has brought hardship, hunger and humiliation. In trying to save a part of their homeland from the Nazi jackboot, the men of Vichy have all but lost an empire.

Strict economy in authorizing new capital projects in the last eighteen months has enabled the city to increase by $82,053,324 its unencumbered borrowing capacity within the constitutional debt limit, creating a "cushion" of $111,960,891 as of July 1, 1941, which is more than three times the safety margin of $29,907,567 on Jan. 1, 1940, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick disclosed yesterday.

Judith Kelly of Beverly, Mass., wife of a Boston lawyer and mother of two children, has won the 1940-1941 Harper Prize Novel contest, it was announced yesterday. She received 510,000 for her book, "Marriage is a Private Affair."

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- In a fresh northerly breeze over a jump of sea, the fleet on the American Yacht Club's cruise left here at noon today, starting off Parsonage Point buoy on the 77 1/2-mile run through Long Island Sound to Fishers Island.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The Senate is expected to pass tomorrow or Tuesday the compromise resolution to extend the service of selectees. National Guardsmen and reserve officers to a maximum of thirty months.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Anticipating possible defeat of the compulsory joint income tax return in the new $3,529,200,000 tax increase bill tomorrow, members of the Ways and Means Committee are considering an alternative to submit to the House in that event which would provide for filing of separate returns by all married persons, it was learned today.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Mrs. Ernest R. Adee of this place has announced the engagement of her granddaughter, Miss Barbara Bradley, to Shelton Pitney Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pitney of Morris-town, N.J. The wedding will take place here next month.
BOSTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Tigers swept a two-game series with the Red Sox by winning today, 6-3, behind Hal Newhouser.

In a manifesto issued yesterday to mark the twenty-seventh anniversary of the beginning of the World War, Loyal Americans of German Descent, a newly formed organization with headquarters at 285 Madison Avenue, declared that the present war was "not one of rival imperialisms but a fight to the finish between democracy and Hitlerism."

Declaring that the final victory in the present world conflict will be in the realm of faith, the Rev. Frederick W. Norwood of St. Andrews-Wesley United Church, Vancouver, B.C., urged in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, his congregation to pray for a victory with justice.
Unless there is a late entry or two, only four new films will arrive on Broadway during the week. The present schedule follows:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On July 24 Justice Morris Eder, in the Bronx Supreme Court, denied the application of a guardian who sought to invest in defense bonds funds his son received in a negligence action award. Justice Eder said he had to make such a ruling because State law specifically limits the disposition of such funds, but he added that he believed the law should be amended.

Organization of thirty regional groups "to spread understanding of exchange markets in general and of the Curb Exchange in particular" has been announced by George P. Rea, president of the New York Curb Exchange. They will work with the public relations department of the institution.

The United States Steel Corporation's report for the quarter ending June 30 gives a fairly clear idea, both of increased company earnings which have come with the great defense purchases, and of the extent to which the Government has drawn by taxation on these profits.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: After reading your recent editorial on the Arab Near East I would like to add a few remarks.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- A curious lull that has come over the war, so far as the British are concerned, in the last two weeks almost demands an interim report upon the war as the British see it at the moment.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- President Roosevelt's request for power to regulate prices and rates is viewed as clear evidence that he sees the danger of inflation looming immediately ahead. How far the application of such power will react on inflation difficulties now accumulating here cannot be gauged, but that vigorous action in both countries would prove of benefit to both can scarcely be denied.

VICHY, France, Aug. 3 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain is about to receive the draft of a new labor charter for France, and it is announced today that a first decree may be issued in a few weeks. The labor world has been Chafing over delay in preparation of this charter.

The Maritime Commission has rejected all bids offered by six shipbuilding concerns for the construction of a fleet of small coaster freighters of 2,800 deadweight tons, and may new continue with its plans by negotiating directly with shipyards without the formality of offering bids.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices continued its advance to new 1936-1941 high ground as it rose from 95.9 to 96.5. Just as was the case the previous week, most of the gain resulted from the sharp rise in the price of silk, and this rise was again reflected in other groups.

With the Yanks, apparently, everything must be done in the grand manner. So it happened that before the astonished gaze of 37,829 onlookers at the Stadium yesterday the mighty Bronx Bombers, who for a month and more had been grinding the American League to a pulp, blew both ends of a double-header to -- of all people -- the lowly Browns.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 3--Cotton futures here, highly nervous over Washington legislation prospects, were under water from the start to finish last week, showing maximum losses on Thursday of above $5.50 a bale. Later, the market leveled out but it apparently was still upset over such an out-and-out demand of powers from the President to fix maximum prices on farm products.

The report of the Flintkote Company and its subsidiaries, issued for publication today, shows a net income for the twenty-eight weeks ended on July 12, 1941, of $1,016,264 after provision of $536,579 for Federal, State and foreign taxes, including $61,516 for accrued Federal excess-profits tax.

Frank S. Hogan, the assistant district attorney whose selection as the Tammany candidate to succeed Thomas E. Dewey took Fusion forces by surprise last week, appeared almost certain last night of getting the Republican and Fusion nomination also.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) -- State governments are spending almost $6, ,000 on advertising this year -- plugging everything from Idaho baked potatoes to choice sites for Army arsenals, and many State Treasuries are recouping the money from the tills of their favored State products, the Council of State Governments reported today after a national survey.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Many parties are being given here for house guests who have arrived for the second week of racing.

The Montauk surfcasters have been finding their sport rather unexciting during the sunlit hours, but the boys who are willing to stumble around the rocks at night and cast a plug have found a fair return for their efforts.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 3 -- Bostwick Field and the Hurricanes galloped into the final of the national twenty-goal polo championship at the Meadow Brook Club today when the postponed semifinal matches were played off as a double-header.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 3 -- The leading contract bridge experts of the country were assembling here today for the annual national championship tournament that begins tomorrow afternoon at the Asbury Park Convention Hall.

The world needs a greater appreciation of the holy sacrifice of the mass, "the same sacrifice as the sacrifice on the cross, the very center and foundation of Catholic worship and the heart and source of Christian life," the Rev. William F. King, one of the assistants at St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared yesterday in his sermon at the 11 o'clock mass.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 3 -- Conflicting influences governed the course of prices on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange last week with the result that an irregular movement persisted in a small volume of trading. Nevertheless, despite temporary lapses into depression, there was, at no time, any urgent unloading.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- The action of the corn market here last week was a duplicate of that in wheat, an early decline because of scattered selling being followed by a sharp advance on Saturday following announcement of details of the price-control bill.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 3 -- Six thousand members of Local 15, Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., at a meeting today behind closed doors in the Mosque Theatre here, decided almost unanimously to accept with one exception the recommendation of the National Defense Mediation Board as a basis for settlement of contractual differences with the Federal Drydock Shipbuilding Corporation in Kearny.

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 4 -- The Royal Air Force battered Berlin, Hamburg, Kiel and Cherbourg over Saturday night, delivering its biggest blows on the Nazi capital early yesterday in what the Air Ministry described as one of the heaviest raids ever made there.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 3 -- The worst trip a Giant team has experienced in many years came to a sorrowful end at Forbes Field today. Before 25,688 howling fans Colonel Bill Terry's boys dropped two games to the Pirates.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Rent control is a timely and urgent topic of discussion in defense circles, from the President down. Already the ugly head of rent profiteering is rearing itself in many communities.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 3 -- All leading newspapers today bring an appeal to the citizens of Helsinki who during the evacuation left the capital, urging them to prolong their stay in the country districts as the food supply here is severely hampered by traffic difficulties.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 3 -- At the beginning of the seventh week of the Russo-German war and with less than two weeks to go before the heavy Autumnal rains set in in the Ukraine, the German High Command appears to be making a desperate bid to complete operations on the southern front and break through to Kiev.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 3 -- Serbian resistance is being steadily maintained against the Germans in Yugoslavia, despite fierce reprisals, according to information today from foreign circles at Ankara and Istanbul.
