Robert Russell Bennett's "Symphony in D for the Dodgers," which was to have received its first concert presentation on last Wednesday's postponed program at the Lewisohn Stadium, came to performance yesterday evening in that amphitheatre with Hans Wilhelm Steinberg on the podium.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 3 -- Good news for the heat-parched troops of the Forty-fourth Division came today in the announcement by Lieut. Col. C.A. Noble, post supply officer, that iceboxes in all the mess halls will be electrified, making most of the bulk ice available for use in Summer drinks (non-alcoholic).

MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 4 -- The Red Army reported today a stonewall defense of Kiev against a German encircling drive and other sources told of the recapture of two villages in counter-attacks that threw the Germans back still farther from the Smolensk gateway to Moscow.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 2 (delayed) (U.P.) -- Turkish military observers, who were convinced that the Germans would score a quick victory over the Russians when the war started six weeks ago, admitted tonight the possibility of the Soviet soldiers holding out until next Spring.

Both stocks and bonds were fairly strong last week. Naturally, our relations with Japan were closely watched. With "economic sanctions" applied, the position is at least delicate. On the other hand, Japan evidently wishes not to create a diplomatic crisis.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3 -- Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., national doubles champion with John Kramer, and Gardnar Mulloy of Miami won the Southampton invitation doubles tournament today on the Meadow Club courts.

WEEK ENDED AUG. 2, 1941 Business in the foreign exchange market last week passed over without incident, price changes and turnover being small and the already sluggish condition of the market being abetted by the elimination of the Japanese and Shanghai currencies through the "freezing" order of President Roosevelt at the preceding week-end.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3 -- There was a round of entertaining throughout the day for tennis week guests at estates in the colony. Prince and Princess Francis J.M. Windisch-Graetz gave a luncheon today at Rosemore, their home in Great Plains Road, for Archduke Otto of Austria and his brother, Archduke Felix, who are visiting the Prince and Princess.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some time ago an article appeared in your paper concerning the disfavor in which the French language seems to have fallen in the schools of New York and in other parts of the country. This has been attributed in part to the political situation in unoccupied France.

Even before the Government decided that our commercial dealings with Japan must be curtailed, silk was doomed. Year after year rayon, nylon and other artificial fibers were displacing it. Even the hosiery market, the last stronghold of silk, was invaded by nylon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Miscellaneous contract awards announced yesterday by the War Department totaled $37,956,681.60. Among these were the following, not previously published, which were granted to companies in the New York area:

"The King's Maid," written by Ferenc Molnar since his arrival in the United States in January, 1940, will be tested by Oscar Serlin, producer of "Life With Father," during the week of Aug. 25 at the Bass Rocks Theatre, Gloucester, Mass. Sam Jaffe will have the leading male role, and Teresa Wright will have the chief feminine assignment.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 3 -- Mr. and Mrs. Dave Hennen Morris entertained with a luncheon at Bogue Chitto yesterday for the Mount Desert Island Y.W.C.A. Speakers included Wallace K. Harrison and Miss Clara Roe.

Consumption of all hosiery in the first half of 1941, as measured by mill shipments, ran 14.6 per cent ahead of last year, according to the regular monthly statistical compilation issued by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.
SKINNERS CORNER, Va., Aug. 3 -- Some 1,925 vehicles were rolling over Virginia highways tonight, carrying 15,000 troops of the Forty-fourth Division back to Fort Dix, their home station.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 -- Paramount's "Air Raid," which has been kept on the shelf for three years because of the changing international situation, will be rewritten with an American background and produced this Fall with Robert Preston in the male lead and Ralph Murphy directing.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial "Machines to Make Machines" you point out that even $750,000,000 would not pay for all the machines that could be used immediately-that is, in this country. What about Free China? China's lifeline, the Burma Road, can take only 12,000 tons of cargo a month.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 3 -- The Anglo-German war of diplomacy in Iran continued to occupy the attention of Ankara diplomatic circles today as the Germans issued charges that the British were seeking the expulsion of all Germans in Iran, and the Teheran press published long articles insisting that Teheran was calm and undisturbed by the struggle going on in the capital.

Vincent Sheean's first novel with an American setting, "Bird of the Wilderness," to be issued Aug. 21 by Random House, is said to be not autobiographical but it will set forth the formative influences upon an imaginative boy brought up in a small town in the author's native State, Illinois.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 3--Dropping the cares of official duties for a long-sought rest at sea, President Roosevelt sailed tonight from the New London Submarine Base for a week's salt-water vacation.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 3 -- In Ohio the corn belt begins. This great agricultural empire has been called the gift of the gods. It is an area unequaled for productivity and fertility. It Is farmed by probably one of the most skilled groups of producers.

An investor who two weeks ago purchased the two five-story houses at 2178 and 2180 Fifth Avenue, northwest corner of West 133d Street, in Harlem, Has extended his holdings by purchasing the adjoining five-story building at 5 West 133d Street.
Prime Minister Winston Churchill's "invasion warning" last week emphasized at a time when such emphasis was needed the importance of the tremendous operations in other theatres of action than Russia.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Morton Cooper and Lon Warneke scored identical 6-to-1 triumphs for the Cardinals in a double-header with last-place Philadelphia.

GIRARD, Ohio, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Playing the cool game that has kept him among the nation's leading golfers for twenty years, Craig Wood today won the unofficial world championship with a 5-and-4 victory over Vic Ghezzi.

ROME, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- When the Russian compaign is ended the Axis powers will unleash a "furious counterblow" against Britain and the United States in both Europe and the Pacific, Virginio Gayda, authoritative Fascist commentator, wrote to by in the newspaper Voce d'Italia.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 3 -- A perfect mid-Summer day, clear and windswept, brought the first week of the eighth annual Berkshire Symphonic Festival to a record-breaking end. The thousands began pouring in before noon, and an hour before concert time the lawn was swarming with sightseers and people taking their ease in the warm sun.

Within the last week it became clear that we are now entering upon a new phase of the national defense effort. This is the phase in which civilian sacrifice for defense becomes an actuality. There have been two preceding phases. The first was the period of plans, orders and appropriations; the second, the period of tooling up, of converting industrial facilities from peacetime to defense requirements.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 5 -- Koh Ishii, Japanese Government spokesman, announced today that Japanese shipping to the United States had been suspended indefinitely and that resumption would depend on whether the United States made it commercially possible.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 4 -- Minister of Finance Arthur de Souza Costa, visiting Sao Paulo and addressing Santos coffee exporters, defended today the policy of the National Coffee Department placing a new minimum price on coffee for export as a measure necessary to protect the market and the growers.

County Judge Charles S. Golden in Queens handed, down a decision yesterday broadening the powers of John Harlan Amen, special attorney general investigating the Queens paving contracts ring. Judge Colden ruled that the prosecutor had the authority to prosecute for any criminal offense in violation of any State law if the crime was applicable to or in respect of violations of the antimonopoly statutes.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Seeded players in the national boys' and junior tennis championships advanced to the third round in the first day's play today at Culver Military Academy. There were 105 matches.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 4 -- The Forty-fourth Division, on the way to its home station at Fort Dix, N.J., passed through here in two large convoys tonight, taxing the efforts of the Baltimore Police Department.

The seven-story apartment house at 604 West 115th Street, in the vicinity of the Columbia University campus, has been purchased by the 604 West Corporation, an investing client of Schimmer, Kerner Feder, brokers, from Prime Equities, Inc., for an indicated consideration of $13,500 above a first mortgage of $99,750 held by the Mutual Life Insurance Company.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 4 -- A perfect golf shot that hit the cup and bounced out, stopping one foot away, gave Andy La Pola, golf professional at the Preakness Hills Country Club, victory today in the New Jersey division of the tenth annual World-Telegram Hole-in-One tournament.
BOSTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Jimmy Foxx celebrated his return to service today by clouting his sixteenth home run of the season, giving the Red Sox a 7-to-6 victory over the Athletics in a series opener.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It seems that some people need a cigarette in order to enjoy music. Last night I was in the Stadium and throughout the performance little sparks glimmered up here and there, right and left. Why do people go to these concerts if they are not there with their minds?

Councilman Alfred E. Smith Jr. called upon Mayor La Guardia yesterday to remove Paul J. Kern immediately as president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, on the ground that he had countenanced "an intolerable condition in civil service administration."

Comparable to Christmas crowds were the eager, pushing women who lined up three-deep yesterday at silk stocking counters in all city department stores. The belief that a shortage of "sheers" was near due to government curbs caused customers to jam up for an all-day session of buying that resulted in some stores having to summon extra salesgirls, hire special guards and limit the number of pairs sold to each buyer.
BUFFALO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Newark beat second-place Buffalo tonight, 4 to 2, to boost its league lead to six and a half games.

Add to the list of openings this week "Ellery Queen and the Perfect Crime," which will arrive at the Rialto on Saturday. Ralph Bellamy, Margaret Lindsay and Charley Grapewin again are featured in this latest of Columbia's series of detective dramas. . . .

NEWPORT, Aug. 4 -- Mr. and Mrs. W. Harold Hoffman and Mr. and Mrs. R. Beverley Corbin entertained dinner guests this evening, and Mrs. Clarence W. Dolan opened her home, Seaweed, for another of the Monday evening duplicate parties.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The United States has made a formal commitment to supply the Soviet Union with military weapons and supplies and to give "favorable consideration" to transporting them in American ships.

ROME, Aug. 4 -- The life and death struggle between Russia and Germany was described by Premier Mussolini at Mantua during his farewell speech to the Blackshirts leaving for the Eastern Front as the solution of an "ironclad dilemma -- fascism or bolshevism; Rome or Moscow."

A plot of 7,500 square feet adjoining the Ewen Park Apartments at 511 West 232d Street, northwest corner of Riverdale Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, has been purchased by the Bijou Realties, Inc., owners of the apartment house, and will be improved with a one-story garage for the use of tenants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- A defense revenue bill, described by a Representative as the "greatest tax bill ever imposed by a civilization upon its people," was passed today by the House by a vote of 369 to 40, and sent to the Senate, which may debate it some time in September.

BERLIN, Tuesday, Aug. 5 -- German sources reported early today that Nazi columns were fighting encircled Russian troops south of Kiev in a battle of annihilation "now in full swing" and paralleling destruction of Soviet forces near Smolensk.

According to reports from the bottom fishing boats out of Long Island and New Jersey ports the seabass fishing dropped off slightly in several spots over the weekend, but the increased number of mackerel taken more than compensated for this, and the fluke fishing is improving every day.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The great battleship Warspite heads an augmented British naval squadron sent to guard the empire's interests in the Far Eastern seas, it was reported here tonight.
TORONTO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Jersey City took the home-run route to gain a 5-3 victory in the second game of today's double-header for an even split with the Maple Leafs, who won the opener, 2-1.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 4 -- Aid for the beleagured but undaunted Tobruk garrison came unexpectedly from the air yesterday when South African Air Force units, flying Maryland [Martin] bombers and escorting Tomahawks [Curtiss] and Hurricanes raided Axis gun positions within range of the city's defenses.

Guy J. Swope, who is retiring after six months as Governor of Puerto Rico to take the post of Director of the Division of Territories and Insular Possessions of the Department of the Interior, arrived here yesterday on the Porto Rico liner Coamo.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I put in a plea for the guards on duty at the Metropolitan Museum of Art during the Summer months?

The Ukraine, although only one sector in a battle front stretched from the Arctic to the hot beaches of the Black Sea, is a country bigger than France and almost as populous. One-sixth of the population of the entire Soviet Union is concentrated in the rolling plains between the Dniester and the Don.

VICHY, France, Aug. 4 (U.P.) -- The French Government tonight assured the United States, in an authorized statement, that it refused to surrender empire military bases to Germany or any other power and announced that strategic Dakar had been placed in a "full state of defense."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Secretary Morgenthau declared at a press conference today that a Congressional proposal, backed by Southern Senators, to freeze some 7,000,000 bales of loan cotton was "terrible" and "wicked."

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 4 -- Continuing their pressure against the Byelaya Tserkov arm of the German pincers in the Kiev area, Russian forces today inflicted heavy damage on German supply lines attempting to reach the spearhead of the German advance units, which were said to have been halted south of the Ros River.

The first class in a project to train 100,000 civilian volunteers in Red Cross first aid methods and techniques was started yesterday at the Red Hook Health Center, 250 Baltic Street, Brooklyn, with a brief ceremony in which representatives of the Health Department, the American Red Cross, the Works Progress Administration and the Office of Civilian Defense participated.

The New York County Republican organization, Mayor La Guardia, and the Fusion leaders headed by Samuel Seabury yesterday accepted the results of the Tammany coup that nominated Frank S. Hogan, a chief assistant to Thomas E. Dewey, to succeed him as District Attorney.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The War Department today awarded contracts totaling $5,278,900. Awards to concerns in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, not previously published, follow:

VICHY, France, Aug. 4 -- Authorized sources indicated tonight that France would refuse to grant the Axis military facilities in North Africa such as Japan got in Indo-China even if Vichy considered the North African territories menaced by attack.
LONDON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Prices of grains on the Board of Trade here soared today to new seasonal high levels on wheat, oats and rye and soy beans as a result of general commission house buying which disclosed less pressure than of late.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The present debate in Congress on the question of extending the term of military service for draftees, National Guardsmen and Reserve officers could be simplified if the discussion were limited to defining the purposes of the law as enacted.

New dance steps for the coming season will have a decided military swing and tempo, typical of the spirit of the times, according to Leroy H. Thayer of Washington, president of the Dancing Masters of America, Inc., which opened in convention Sunday at the Hotel Astor.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 4 -- Denton S. Quick, Essex County Sheriff, and five other defendants charged with conspiracy to violate internal revenue laws relating to the operations of illicit stills went on trial in Federal District Court here today.

A flood of virtually worthless rayon stockings will go on the market within a few months and may permanently deprive the rayon industry of its opportunity to replace silk in the hosiery field it was predicted by executives of rayon-yarn producing companies yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 4 -- Shipping and iceberg patrols of the Coast Guard now are fully armed and prepared for more serious work, Rear Admiral Russell R. Waesche, commandant of the service, said here today.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 4 -- The reason for that startling twin upset which the Yankees experienced in the Stadium yesterday seemingly was explained today. In keeping with the fashion of the times, it apparently was one of those strategic manoeuvres for the purpose of withdrawing' to a better position.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 4 -- An undisclosed number of persons was arrested yesterday and today by the Colombian national police in a major round-up of suspected fifth columnists, War Minister Jose J. Castro Martinez said.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 5 -- Royal Air Force planes bombed German factories and communication lines at Hanover and Frankfort on the Main and the docks at Calais before dawn yesterday. One British bomber failed to return, the Air Ministry said.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: That the Senate seems to have learned nothing from the devastating mistakes of the World War was demonstrated in THE TIMES'S headline "Senate 'Freezes' Crop Loan Stocks." This subservient measure would prevent the government from marketing its loan stocks of six million bales of cotton and 300,000,000 bushels of wheat during the European war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Since February of this year the Commerce Department has made confidential representations in 4,050 cases to United States importers and exporters, concerning the effect of their transactions on hemispheric defense.
An underwriting group or nation-wide scope and headed by Glore, Forgan Co. will offer 1,500,000 shares of the common stock of Libby, McNeill Libby to the public today at 5 5/8 a share.

Rentals in buildings east and west of Central Park predominated in the lists of new residential tenancies received yesterday. Eight additions were reported in the roster of one house which is still under construction.

PATERSON, N. J., Aug. 4 -- One hundred Paterson silk workers were thrown out of employment today in the wake of the government's silk freezing orders as manufacturers and city leaders speeded plans to avert a major economic breakdown by pressing Washington for a more adequate supply of rayon.

Japan is not out after The the traditional riches of the Gorgeous Orient when she drives East southward against the Netherlands Indies for oil, rubber, tin and manganese, or north against Siberia for the sub-Arctic fishing grounds.

The Congressional farm bloc is closing in upon the Administration's price-control bill with the evident intent to pervert the measure into one which will boost, rather than control, agricultural prices. Having first announced they would accept no ceiling for farm prices below "parity," the goal of the past eight years, the members of the farm bloc next boosted their demands to 110 per cent of parity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The following exchange of correspondence between Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, and Constantine A. Oumansky, the Soviet Ambassador, was released today by the Department of State:

Two months ago, when gloom was a foot thick -- after the fall of Crete, after the conquest of Yugoslavia and Greece, after the reverses in North Africa -- it was hard to get a hearing for the opinion that the great fundamentals of moral and material power still lay on Britain's side, and that Hitler would never win this war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Important changes in the law applying to amortization of defense plants, designed to clarify some of the provisions and greatly to simplify the administration of the law and the carrying out of the defense program, were disclosed today to have been made by Secretary Stimson and Secretary Knox, and to be pending in the House Ways and Means Committee.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Throughout the width and length of Jacob Riis Park there is not a weathervane to be seen.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- The first week of the Chicago Fall Market, in which every trade exhibit was open, started today with a record-breaking buyer attendance and sales 20 to 25 per cent and more ahead of the corresponding date of last year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- William Green, President of the American Federation of Labor, urged today that defense authorities plan conversion of plants to other purposes before issuing any more such sweeping orders as that last week which, closed down all raw silk processing operations.

Edgar J. Nathan Jr., named yesterday by the Republican Executive Committee as its candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, has been active for many years in Republican politics and Jewish philanthropic and religious groups. He is also a personal friend of Stanley M. Isaacs, the incumbent Borough President, who will oppose him in the Republican primaries.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Ernie White, 24-year-old rookie ace of the pacesetting Cardinals, pitched his sixth victory in seventeen days today, turning back the weak-hitting Cubs for a 4-to-2 triumph.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- Her billowing sails a pretty picture in the gleam of an almost rounded moon, De Coursey Fales's schooner Nina swept in past the North Hill reed bell buoy, near North Dumpling lighthouse, the winner in the large cruising division on the American Yacht Club's first run, that of 77 1/2 miles from Parsonage Point at Rye.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 4 -- A new "master" plan for coordinating Nassau County's civil defense was adopted here today at a meeting in the office or County Executive J. Russel Sprague. Confusion in civilian defense preparations throughout the county has resulted from the defense council's recent abandonment of a county-wide registration.

Among the projects for which plans were filed yesterday were a six-story apartment in Forest Hills, Queens, estimated to cost about $385,000, and a group of twenty-three small homes costing a total of $119,600 in Flushing. The details of these and other plans follow:

Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and three others charged with the murder of a Brooklyn candy store proprietor in 1936 went on trial yesterday in Kings County Court before Judge Franklin Taylor. The entire day was taken by members of the blue-ribbon panel explaining to Judge Taylor why they thought they could not serve on the jury.

Monday, Aug. 4, 1941 Changes have been made in the list of stocks comprising THE NEVT YORK TIMES rail average. Erie (old), Missouri-Kansas-Texas and Pittsburgh West Virginia have been removed and for them have been substituted Erie (new) w.i., Gulf. Mobile Northern and Western Maryland.

LONDON, Aug. 4 (UP) -- A Russian army of more than 500,000 men, led by General Grigory M. Stern, was reported in advices reaching London tonight to be preparing to launch Russia's first major offensive on the Karelian Isthmus, about sixty-five miles north of Leningrad.

GUAM, Aug. 4 -- A typhoon swept this tiny Pacific island outpost of the United States yesterday, causing heavy damage to crops but no loss of life. Buildings at the post of the United States Marine Corps were damaged.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Roosevelt has vetoed the $320,000,000 defense highway bill. He made clear in a message to the Senate that he considered the measure to build and improve roads for military purposes had been made a pork-barrel affair, raising costs unduly.

Modern magicians have managed a miracle. It may materialize in no less prosaic a place than the kitchen stove of the American housewife, or in the kitchen of her distant British sister, where everything that happens is of sharp and desperate significance.

Fall advertising campaigns in a number of industries on which production is due to be curtailed by defense requirements are now in preparation, but both manufacturers and agencies are in the dark as to the extent of these campaigns until they know what output reductions will be ordered.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- After marking time for two days, the Eastern turf court tennis championships got under way in earnest at the Westchester Country Club today, with ranking players checking in from Southampton and East Hampton and the field taking on the aspect of a national tournament.
Death Reported Fireman Hugo O. Moeller, formerly a member of Engine Co. 317, residing at Minlsink Hills, Pa., died July 23.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- Rising to the occasion over his home course, Herman Barron teamed with Stanley Kallman, an amateur from his club, to win the best-ball honors with 33, 32 -- 65, six under par, in the weekly tourney of the Westchester County Golf Association over the Fenway course today.

Bach's works are not played often at Summer concerts, but last night two of his concertos, with six different featured soloists, were given at the Lewisohn Stadium at Hans Wilhelm Steinberg's fifth and final concert of the season there with the New York Philharmonie-Symphony Orchestra.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:

China eventually will take an allout offensive against Japan that will doom the Far Eastern Axis partner to decisive defeat, it was predicted last night by Chen Chieh, former Chinese Ambassador to Germany, who arrived here Friday on the West Point.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 4 -- Several young women who will be introduced to society next Winter in New York are serving on the junior committee, members of which, will act as ushers at the showing of the motion picture, Cavalcade," by Noel Coward, on Wednesday night at the Southampton Theatre for the benefit of the American Theatre Wing of the British War Relief Society and the Camp Upton Hospital fund of the American Red Cross.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, expressed satisfaction today with results of the first blackout of Eastern gasoline filling stations.

The first transactions here in the Shanghai yuan since Chinese accounts in the United States were "frozen" by executive order ten days ago, were reported yesterday. The deals, however, were under special license granted by the Treasury Department to cover specific accounts.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 4 -- A three-way tie for first place featured the first session of the national contract bridge championships here today. Mixed teams of four competed in the opening event this afternoon in Convention Hall. Men's pairs and women's pairs began play tonight for the national titles in their fields.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 4 -- Judge Ramon Vasquez, who is cooperating with the Congressional committee investigating anti-Argentine activities, led a raid today on the Circulo Teutonia, a German club whose offices in the building of the German bank had previously been raided by the committee's agents.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- William F. Bleakley, Westchester's first County Executive under the charter that became operative two and a half years ago, gave up that position this afternoon and the Board of Supervisors appointed Herbert C. Gerlach of Ossining, Finance Commissioner in Mr. Bleakley's cabinet, as his successor.

ROME, Aug. 4 (AP) -- British planes machine-gunned southern Italian airports at Catania and Reggio Calabria, causing some damage and casualties, the Italian High Command declared today. Catania is a Sicilian air base and Reggio Calabria is across the Strait of Messina in southernmost Italy.
The Index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- Miss Majorie Harrison, Syracus University senior, whose father is golf professional at the Ausables Forks course up-State, today began the defense of her New York State women's championship in such fashion as to awe her challengers.

The House of Representatives yesterday passed the record-breaking 3,200,000,000 tax bill. In so doing it eliminated the objectionable provision requiring joint returns of husbands and wives. But under the House rules it was foreclosed from considering the worst feature of the bill -- its failure to broaden the tax base by lowering personal exemptions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Excess profits tax returns for 1939 were fewer by 4,539, or 0.9 per cent, than in 1938, but the number of returns with net income for excess profits tax computation increased 29,595, or 17.4 per cent, the Treasury reported today.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- The anti-Communist faction won a test vote over the party's defenders at the opening today of the annual convention of the United Automobile Workers of America, C.I.O.

New York City will be host to a Civilian and National Defense Exposition, the first of its kind in the nation, from Sept. 20 through Oct 18, in the Grand Central Palace, 480 Lexington Avenue, it was announced yesterday by George A. Sloan, Commissioner of Commerce for New York City.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Higher food and clothing prices were sought today by the farm bloc in Congress.

Steel Operations The general impression in steel circles yesterday was that the decline of 1.3 per cent in the operating' rate was due to the shortage of scrap steel and pig iron, the principal raw materials of steel production.

GOSHEN. N.Y., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Doc Parshall's chances of becoming the first owner to train and drive his own Hambletonian winner became slim tonight when it was discovered the veteran Ohioan's highly regarded Perpetual was a doubtful starter in Wednesday's renewal of the nation's No. 1 trotting stake.

Stanley Isaacs was endorsed last night for re-election as Borough President of Manhattan at a meeting of the City Fusion party at the Hotel Woodward after he had declared that he was in the race to stay regardless of "what party turns me down" and after he had defended his record.
Despite widely expressed skepticism, it began to appear yesterday that the gasoline curfew, which became effective Sunday night, may have saved gasoline after all.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your recent editorial "Raiding the Treasury" has just been called to my attention, and I think you were unduly I excited about what the veterans should get. In many cases they would get much more by applying for an old-age pension or relief.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 4 -- Turkish official circles expressed bewilderment and annoyance tonight at the text of an editorial in The Times, London, on Aug. 1, which, according to Turkish sources, sought to convey the impression that Russia must dominate Eastern Europe after the conclusion of any peace ending the war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Implying that there was a probability that another merchant ship would be sent to the Far East to bring home American citizens now marooned in Japan and in other parts of East Asia, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that he was studying the problem created by the fact that more than 100 Americans are now seeking to return to this country from Japan.

VICHY, France, Aug. 4 "Watchdog of legal processes, but not judge of whether measures are opportune," the Council of State has just rejected an appeal by a French woman who, under a decree of Nov. 18, 1939, was assigned to enforced residence.
Playing before a New York crowd last night for the first time in two weeks, the Dodgers and the Giants put on a sort of Pier 6 brawl at Ebbet's Field for the entertainment of 28,637 fans.

CHICAGO. Aug. 4 (AP) -- Curtailed receipts brought strength to the livestock market today and some classes were up as mucn as 25 cents a hundredweight. Hogs were up mostly 10 to 15 cents, although trading was uneven and some weights were steady with last Friday's average.
ROME, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The following communique was issued today by the Italian High Command:
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 4 -- Mrs. John T. Dorrance entertained with a dinner and bridge at Kenarden Lodge tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Brig. Gen. Adna R. Chaffee, who has been holding temporary rank of Major General, was nominated for permanent promotion by President Roosevelt today. Simultaneously, the President sent to the Senate the nominations of six Brigadier Generals for promotion to temporary Major General, ten Colonels and Lieutenant Colonels for the temporary rank of Brigadier General, and the promotion of seven men from Lieutenant Colonels to Colonel.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports. Figures in most cases are subject to audit and final adjustments.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended July 30 aggregated $9,564,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 2:

Fifty red caps from many eastern terminals assembled yesterday at City Hall to testify in the investigation of their wage and working conditions now being conducted by the wages and hours division of the United States Department of Labor.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Details of the armament, performance and equipment of Britain's Beau fighters were released today for the first time. It is a large machine with a range of 1,500 miles -- and it has four cannon and six machine guns to make it the most powerful armed fighting plane in the world.

With the Atlantic sea lanes less dangerous since Germany has thrown its forces against Russia, the British War Relief Society launched yesterday an all-out drive to load every available ship with clothing for Great Britain, where those articles are now being rationed.

The new pig-iron and steel facilities to be erected by the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, Subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, at the Edgar Thomson works at Braddock, Pa., will add 860,000 net tons of annual pig-iron capacity when completed, it was learned yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The world champion Reds today scored their second run in four games, but it was hardly enough to delay the fast-charging Pirates, who won, 4 to 1, on the three-hit pitching of Johnny Lanning.
NEW YORK Colonel William M. Wright Jr., U.S.A., has come to the St. Regis from Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The minimum return which the government assures to cotton growers through its loan program was increased five cents a pound today in conformity with recent legislation calling for loans at 85 per cent of the parity price.

Trading in the wholesale markets yesterday was only fair to slow. Steer hinds and ribs sold at steady prices. Traefer chucks were 50 cents to S1 higher and other major steer cuts generally steady. Veal, lamb and fresh pork cuts also sold at steady prices. Kosher veal opened steady, other kosher meats strong to higher.

SOME golfers are flying high these days. Johnny Bulla and Samuel Jackson Snead, for instance. Johnny has his own plane and pilots it from tournament to tournament. Sam just goes for the ride. But Sam is taking lessons. Not golf lessons. Flying lessons.

Three long winning streaks will be placed in jeopardy tonight at Ebbets Field, where Chick Meehan will present the third in the series of popular-priced boxing shows. Heading the attractive card is a ten-round encounter between Izzy Jannazzo of Brooklyn and the Cocoa Kid of New Haven.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Dr. Charles Wooten Pipkin, dean of the Louisiana State University Graduate School, an authority in the field of political science, died here early today at Hotel Dieu. His age was 41.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Among the letters in THE TIMES was one suggesting a change in the designation of subway stations in order that passengers on the trains could determine the next stop.

A syndicate composed of the Equitable Securities Corporation, the Milwaukee Company, the Wells-Dickey Company and the Kingsbury Alvis Company will offer to the public today a new issue of $675,000 State of Louisiana 1 1/2, 1 1/4 and 1 per cent series "H" pension bonds, dated July 15, 1941.

All large advertising signs and theatre marquees in the Times Square area will be darkened for a half hour tonight a "blackout" to be carried out by Electrical Workers Union, Local 3, as a demonstration in the general strike of 7,000 electricians called by the union in its conflict with the Consolidated Edison Company.
The German campaign In Russia has entered the month of August and weather -- always a vital factor in the fate of armies -- assumes increasing importance with each passing day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Claude R. Wickard, Secretary of Agriculture, told the House Rivers and Harbors Committee today that the proposed St. Lawrence seaway would put American farmers in a better position to compete for world markets when the war is over.

The Viking Press Fall list was announced yesterday. There is only one novel, Marguerite Steen's "The Sun Is My Undoing" (Aug. 18). Some of the other titles considered high spots are "The Viking Book of Poetry," edited by Richard Aldington and Carl Van Doren's "Secret History of the American Revolution."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Department of Justice's Anti-trust Division and Federal Bureau of Investigation began today an inquiry into charges by Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, that there were monopolistic practices in the scrap iron and steel industry, resulting in evasion of price ceiling schedules and impairing the orderly flow of scrap needed for production of steel to fill defense orders.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 4 -- One of New Jersey's most colorful political figures, Theron McCampbell, died today at the Fitkin Hospital, Neptune, after an automobile accident near Neptune Saturday evening. He was 73 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Here is the roll-call vote by which the House struck from the Tax Bill today the provision requiring married persons to file joint income tax returns:

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 4 -- Dr. Francis Reynolds Haussling of Newark, N.J., a surgeon, died here today of a heart attack at the Summer home of a friend, Dr. William D. Crecca of Newark. Dr. Haussling lived and had an office at 661 High Street, Newark. His age was 66.

In the absence of any definite news upon which to form a bullish or a bearish judgment, the stock market moved lower yesterday for most of the five-hour trading period and recovered about one-half the losses hi the late transactions, with a volume of 633,190 shares, against 678,990 shares on Friday.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Aug. 4 -- A fleet of more than 140 sailboats, representing the eleven clubs holding membership in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association, participated in the opening of the twenty-sixth annual Race Week today.

The six-story apartment house at 453 Mount Prospect Avenue, Newark, was sold by the Commercial Casualty Company to the Julare Corporation, Julius Rosenberg, president, and will be remodeled into smaller units. John Carter Co., Inc., and M.S. Greene were co-brokers.

HAVANA, Aug. 4 -- Senator Emilio Ochoa, member of the powerful opposition Revolutionary party, suffered serious head injuries in a fight on the floor in the Cuban Senate tonight between Opposition and majority Senators.

The report of the North American Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, mailed yesterday to shareholders by Edward L. Shea, president, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges, of $21,615,950. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.08 a share on the company's outstanding common stock, and compares with $21,347,143, or $2.04 a common share, in the twelve months to June 30, 1940.
BERLIN, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The German High Command communique said today:

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- Samuel D. Riddle, veteran owner of Man o' War, sprang another surprise today when he sent out a filly, War Hazard, and watched her dash home first at $25.90 for $2 at the end of a mile which saw some other pretty keen fillies up the stretch.
According to present indications at least eight new plays will be tested next week in the Summer theatres. Two were to have had debuts heretofore, but were postponed. The list follows:

The FHA's new program of defense housing mortgage insurance is providing sound, modern living quarters through private capital for families in important defense areas at a total monthly carrying cost of between $27 and $41 a month, Administrator Abner H. Ferguson reported yesterday.

Details of the capital outlay budget for 1942 sent by the Board of Higher Education to the City Planning Commission revealed yesterday at the board's offices that $397,832 is being returned to the city as a surplus from past appropriations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- There is on foot a world movement for conquest by force, and for successful resistance to this resurgence of savagery and barbarism there is need for absolute unity among the American people, and among other free peoples who have not yet been conquered, Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, said today in the first official statement he has made since ill health forced him to relinquish official duties almost two months ago.

Reflecting developments in Washington on the proposed price-fixing legislation and on the Smith bill providing for the "freezing" of government-owned cotton for the duration of the European war, cotton prices fluctuated erratically yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Supreme Court having decided that Negroes are entitled to Pullman accommodations and other first class services equal to those white passengers receive on railroad trains, the Interstate Commerce Commission today announced that the complaint by Representative Arthur W. Mitchell, Democrat of Chicago, against the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railway Company would be reopened.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Senate set the stage late today for the first major test on the Army service extension resolution tomorrow. An agreement was reached to vote by 1 P.M. on the Taft amendment continuing the tenure of selective service trainees to a total of eighteen months, instead of two and one-half years as now proposed by the Administration.

Speaking at ground-breaking ceremonies for the $500,000 seaplane hangar to be erected at the marine terminal of LaGuardia Field for American Export Airlines, Mayor LaGuardia declared yesterday that in spite of his deep anxiety to see all available airplanes sent overseas to help end the war, he did not think commercial aviation in the United States should be crippled by the transfer of airline transports to Great Britain.

ROCKVILLE CENTER, L.I., Aug. 4 -- Jim Hopkins and Jack Mallon of the Garden City Country Club clipped eight strokes from par to win the one-day amateurpro golf tournament of the Long Island P.G.A. with a 34, 30-64 over the Rockville Country Club course today.

Despite increased taxes and greater expenses, earnings of Eastern Air Lines for the first six months of 1941 set a new record for the period, according to the semi-annual statement of Captain E.V. Rickenbacker, president and general manager, sent to stockholders yesterday.

Impressed by the British war effort and expressing confidence in ultimate British victory, Dr. George B. Kistiakowsky and Dr. Robert C. Elderfield, members of the National Defense Research Commission, returned here yesterday aboard the American Clipper after a two-month period in the British Isles.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 4 -- A second service picture to follow the pattern of "Caught in the Draft" was announced today by Paramount for Bob Hope and Dorothy Lamour under the title "Amateur Admiral." The studio assigned Ralph Spence and I.A.L. Diamond to write the scenario, and the photoplay is scheduled for production after "Snowball in Hell," in which Hope will be seen with Madeleine Carroll.

TIMBER POINT, L.I., Aug. 5 -- A fleet of twenty-three International Stars competed in the first of a series of five contests today for the Commodore George A. Corry Trophy in the annual race week of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association.

Nothing seemed able to unsettle the stock market yesterday. Leon Henderson's speech before the House Banking Committee caused hardly a ripple in trading, despite its implications that inflation will be difficult to avoid. Reports of Japanese war preparations were similarly without market echo.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Once again tearing up the old naval dictum that fighting vessels must not attack shore batteries because in doing so they risk a successful counter-attack, British destroyers have entered the roadstead of Alghero and the harbor of Porto Conte in Sardinia and shelled and severely damaged slipways and hangars without casualties, according to an Admiralty announcement today.

BERLIN, Aug. 5 (AP) -- German armies have turned suddenly southeastward from the direct road to Moscow and have made a major break-through sixty-two miles below Smolensk, the German High Command announced today, and thus tonight there appeared prospects of a vast attempt at encirclement of Kiev and the upper Ukraine.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 5 -- Ann Sheridan and Humphrey Bogart will be co-starred in "Nobody Lives Forever," by W.R. Burnett, which Warner Brothers acquired today for a reported $20,000. Robert Lord will produce the film, which deals with a New York night club owner and his singerwife, who came to Hollywood to pursue their careers. "Nobody Lives Forever" will follow "All Through the Night" on Bogart's schedule.
LONDON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued this communique today:

Page Girls in Wall Street The National City Bank has joined the list of Wall Street institutions that have endeavored to solve the employment problem by replacing page boys with page girls. The move is by no means an innovation in Wall Street.
Mixed trading in Manhattan realty was reported yesterday, with several apartment properties, a large loft building, a taxpayer and other parcels passing into new ownership.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your recent editorial "Japan's Isolation" you appear to stress the point that Japan is being driven to desperate action by its ruling military caste to divert attention from the military fiasco in China. The suggestion that the military alone are responsible for Japan's Asiatic policy is naive and erroneous.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 5 -- A flower sale was held here today in the gardens of the Parrish Art Museum under the auspices of the Garden Club of Southampton for the benefit of Bundles for Britain, Inc., and the British War Relief Society.

Three Japanese ship lines are to withdraw from the River Plate and Brazil Conferences, which are composed of traders operating vessels to ports in Brazil and along the River Plate in South America, it became known in shipping quarters here yesterday.

In the oldest section of the city there is a narrow, crooked street lined on either side by tall, important buildings. And at the very end where the sidewalk dips precipitously and the big buildings stop short, a bright beam of sunlight bursts through the thick shadows cast by their walls and touches the painted sign of a small shop that snuggles by their side.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Southpaw Al Smith outpitched Big Buck Newsom tonight and the Indians downed Detroit, 2 to 1, before 30,000 fans. Jeff Heath's triple in the sixth scored the Red-skins' two runs after the Bengals had taken a lead in the third on a walk, a sacrifice and Barney McCosky's single.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- The former United States destroyer Hunt, now the Broadway, took part in a recent action in which a German U-boat was destroyed, the Admiralty announced today. The Hunt is one of the fifty American destroyers that arrived in British waters last October and are now assigned to duty protecting North Atlantic convoys.

Fight for Freedom, Inc., announced yesterday that it had received "from leaders in the German underground movement" terms of a new peace proposal, expected to be put forward by the Reich within the next month.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 5 -- Former Judge Samuel Seabury and Mrs. Seabury entertained at Wyandanch Farm, their home on the Sag Harbor Turnpike, this afternoon for members of Old East Hampton, of which Harry L. Jeffreys is president.

With appliance manufacturers holding a meeting in Detroit yesterday and with a conference with the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply scheduled for next week, the final decision on the proposed reduction in major appliance output is expected by the middle of this month, company executives reported yesterday.

Fourteen new cases of diphtheria were reported last week among New York children, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday. Appealing for the cooperation of parents in eradicating the disease, Dr. Rice said "as soon as a baby is 9 months old he should be immunized against diphtheria."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Aug. 1 on the appointment of Lincoln MacVeagh as Minister to Iceland awoke a responsive chord in the minds of all those who have known Mr. MacVeagh's work in Greece in her darkest hour. It is fitting that he should go from a frontier post in the struggle of the Balkans to a frontier post in the Battle of the Atlantic.

India's most pressing needs in war materials are special kinds of steel and machine tools, according to Sir Shanmukham Chetty, head of the newly established Indian Purchasing Commission in the United States. Interviewed in his suite at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, he said that other Indian war necessities included trucks, lubricants, chemicals and medicinal supplies.

SUPERIOR, Wis., Aug. 5 -- Lou De Filippo, the big Fordham center, limped through the practice of the New York Football Giants today as a result of a bad cut on the shin sustained in yesterday's scrimmage. Some one's flying cleat opened a cut, and last night three stitches fixed the first injury of the season.

A shortage that undoubtedly will take a reverse turn and lighten the lives of staid business men was revealed yesterday when the National City Bank produced for inspection its corps of sixty girl runners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5--Further price increases are inevitable as the United States stands "at the brink of inflation," Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, told the House Banking and Currency Committee today at the opening of hearings on the Administration's price and rent control bill.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- After four days of competition in the Eastern turf court tennis championships at the Westchester Country Club, the tournament committee found this evening that it had performed the unusual trick of inducting every one of the sixteen seeded players in the men's and women's divisions into the round before the quarterfinals.

Mrs. Priscilla St. George Duke, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. St. George, was married to Allan A. Ryan yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents in Tuxedo Park, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by Judge Henry Bacon Merritt of Goshen, N.Y., in the presence of the bride's parents, her grandmother, Mrs. Price Collier, and Jay Rutherfurd, who was best man.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Aug. 6 -- Soviet sources reported today that German forces, concentrating their main efforts on the southern arm of the attempted pincers operations against Kiev, had suffered severe losses in men and materiel yesterday as they tried unsuccessfully to hammer a hole through the Russians' Rossi River defenses south of the Ukrainian capital.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Bell Aircraft Corporation of Buffalo, manufacturer of the Aircobra fighter, has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission 100,000 shares of $1 par value common stock, to be offered to the public at a price to be supplied by amendment to the registration statement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The decision of the United States to supply the Soviet Union with military weapons and supplies puts Japan in a new position of danger and uncertainty, in the opinion of military and naval observers here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES has queried the Vichy government in order to ascertain the truth about the charges of slave labor performed by Spanish, German, Austrian, Czech and Polish refugees in the construction of the Trans-Saharan Railroad, made by me in a recent article in The Nation.

Manufacturers of hosiery at tempted unsuccessfully yesterday to purchase rayon yarn to make possible their transition from a silk-using to a rayon-using industry. but producers were unwilling to book orders pending detailed instructions from Washington.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Pirates put together two big innings today to beat the stumbling Reds, 7 to 5, for the world champions' fifth straight defeat.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., had estimated consolidated earnings of $18,000,000 in first half of 1941, according to the semi-annual report of John A. Brown, president, mailed to stockholders today. This includes full equity in the six months' estimated earnings of Standard-Vacuum Oil Company, in which the company has a 50 per cent interest.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 5 -- Four sections of the country -- New England, Middle Atlantic, South and Far West -- vote in favor of extending the draft training period for longer than one year, while two sections -- the East Central and West Central -- vote against it in the final returns of the institute's survey of public opinion on the issue.

ALBANY, Aug. 5 (U.P.) -- Mayor Herman Hoogkamp refused today to replace Robert E. Whalen, chairman of the City Defense Council, as requested by Mayor La Guardia of New York, Director of Civilian Defense.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Bisons recovered their batting eyes to conquer the Newark Bears tonight, 7 to 4, and square the series at two-all and protect their second-place berth from the onrush of the Montreal Royals.

"Keep Covered." the Michael Wallach-Pat C. Flick farce, is announced to open Sept. 16 at the Royale Theatre. It will open a tryout engagement on Sept. 8 at Ford's Theatre, Baltimore. "Keep Covered" is being produced by Morris Sarnoff.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 5 -- From all parts of Yugoslavia there continue to come reports of the undercover war of Serbian Chetnik guerrillas against German occupational forces and the Croat Quislings, and of the ruthless punishment meted out against the insurrectionists.

Some advertising executives, making comparisons with the last war, are predicting that as a result of the present emergency, advertising volume will show substantial gains in the next few years. Others are pessimistic about the outlook, pointing out that during a year when industrial production, sales and national income are reaching new highs, advertising volume is running only a few per cent ahead of 1940.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5--Rumors that President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill had met or were to meet at sea or in some New World port were neither confirmed nor denied by Washington officials tonight, apparently because none knew for certain whether they were true or false.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The first five men up for the Phil-lies smashed three singles and two doubles good for four runs today, but it didn't mean a thing, as the Braves exploded six runs in the seventh to win, 10 to 9.

Production at the Shenango tin plate plant of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation at New Castle, Pa., will reach capacity on Aug. 18, when ten additional hot mills will be placed in operation. With resumption of the additional units, all forty of the hand mills of the Shenango plant will be in operation for the first time since late 1939.

TOKYO, Aug. 5 -- According to press reports, Japanese troops, marching across the plains of Cambodia, reached the new frontier between French Indo-China and Thailand at noon today, while Thai troops were lining up on the other side of the border, and British mechanized troops were taking up positions on the Malayan-Thai border to the south.

Our State Department has informed the Russian Ambassador in Washington that we will give the Soviet Union all "practicable" economic assistance and grant "unlimited licenses" for the export to Russia of "a wide variety of articles and materials," presumably including weapons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Two large contracts for airplanes and parts were among the $39,627,376 in contracts announced today by the War Department. The plane contracts were for $14,518,707 to Vultee Aircraft, Inc., of Downey, Calif., and for $12,610,125 to the Beech Aircraft Corporation of Wichita.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Dixiana Stable's Night Glow, carrying only 98 pounds, ran to a photo-finish victory in the Hastings Purse for 3-year-olds at Washington Park today before a crowd of 9,000, and paid $32, $12.80 and $6 across the board.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Thailand, carerully gauging the attitude of the United States in determining how to react to the pressure of an expanding Japan, has established a tank headquarters near the border of Japanese-occupied Indo-China, it was announced officially today.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 5 -- The British Minister to Afghanistan, Lieut. Col. Sir William Fraser-Tyler, has made representations to the Afghan Government similar to the proposals already placed by the British before the Iranian Government suggesting the expulsion of unnecessary German travelers and residents from that country, it was reported by leading diplomatic circles here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5--Administration forces in the Senate cleared the first major hurdle today in their program for extending the period of military service for selectees, National Guardsmen and Reserve officers, but ran head-on into another, which had the leaders baffled tonight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Profit taking and hedging pressure, combined with uneasiness as to the outcome of proposed price control legislation resulted today in the wheat market showing an easy undertone the greater part of the day.
An official of one of the major oil companies said yesterday that gasoline ration cards already had been drawn up for New York State and probably had been printed.
ROME, Aug. 5 -- Harrowing tales about how Italians are persecuted in the United States are being printed by the Italian press in the form of interviews with Italians returning from New York.

Population changes, mounting taxes and debt pose increasingly complex financial problems for school administrators, Dr. Rufus D. Smith, provost of New York University, warned 500 educators yesterday at the closing Summer session assembly on war sponsored by the N.Y.U. School of Education.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 5 -- Faced by an energetic Ar- gentine demand either to destroy the wireless sending set found in a German diplomatic pouch, and the cause of a diplomatic incident between Argentina and Germany, or else send it back where it came from, the German Embassy today submitted a request to the Foreign Ministry for authorization to send the set back to Europe by airplane.

The reasons for cessation of business in or removal from the State by business concerns during the eight years ending in 1940 will be surveyed by a group of trade associations and labor unions which were represented yesterday at a meeting in the Hotel Commodore called by Jones W. Mersereau, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, and James C. Quinn, secretary of the Trades Union Council of New York City.

Awaiting tonight's return floodlight engagement with the Giants at the Polo Grounds, the Dodgers yesterday took advantage of the lull by creating news with the announcement they had purchased two minor league stars for September delivery.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The pennant-bound Yankees, aiming to make a triumphant evacuation of the Potomac, today fell victims of what might be described as fanatical sniping from the rear.

Herman Adler, Czech conductor who was formerly chief conductor of the Ukrainian State Orchestra in Kiev and who fled from Prague when Hitler took over his native country, last night made his debut as a conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium.

MONTAUK, L.I., Aug. 5 -- Wasaka, Gilbert Warner'a 37-year-old sloop, again showed up her younger rivals today, taking the first division prize on the American Yacht Club's second cruise run as she did on the first one. H.A. Kaiser's six-meter sloop Ture and the 32-footer Larikin, under charter to Roy Manny, were the other victors.

TORONTO, Aug. 5 (Canadian Press) -- Two unearned runs in the seventh inning gave the Jersey City Giants a 3-2 victory over the Maple Leafs tonight as the veteran southpaw Carl Fischer suffered his twelfth consecutive loss.
A consolidated net income of $7,014,854 was made by the Phelps Dodge Corporation and its subsidiaries in the six months ended on June 30, according to the report issued for publication today.
NEW YORK Commander John Murray Thornton, U.S.N., of the United States Naval Academy, Annapolis, Md., and Mrs. Thornton are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Fifteen Republican leaders, including Alfred M. Landon and former President Herbert C. Hoover, joined today in an appeal that "Congress put a stop to step by step projection of the United States into undeclared war."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Prohibition of multiple ownership of broadcasting stations in any one area is proposed by the Federal Communications Commission in an order issued today on which oral argument is scheduled for Oct. 6.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Major Gen. R.L. Eichelberger, Superintendent of the United States Military Academy, explains in his letter in your columns why a recent visitor saw the cadets at West Point being instructed only in close-order drill. The superintendent states that the cadets were members of the large new fourth class, admitted on July 1.

Buyers' July Total Down 16% Buyers arriving in the New York market during the week ended yesterday numbered 761 as against 810 in the previous week and 927 in the like period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 5 -- Indi- cations that Governor Charles Edison was exerting his influence in selecting an Essex County Democratic slate for the approaching primaries, thus widening the rift between himself and Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, who recent- ly "relinquished" the State Democratic leadership to the Governor, were seen today in the aftermath of a four-hour conference at the Little White House here.

STROUDSBURG, Pa., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Two bank messengers were robbed of $76,00 today in a street holdup carried out with split-second timing by four gunmen who escaped into the wooded hills of Northern New Jersey.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 5 -- Reginald Stewart, internationally known concert pianist and conductor, has been appointed director of the Peabody Conservatory of Music, succeeding Otto Ortmann, whose resignation becomes effective Sept. 1, it was announced today by Dr. J. Hall Pleasants, president of the board of trustees.

TOKYO, Aug. 5 -- The Foreign Office announced today that the Japanese Government had protest- ed to the Government of Ecuador against rumors, incorporated in Ecuadorean official announcements, of Japanese participation in Peruvian border clashes and also against the incidents growing out of such reports.

The four-story walk-up with twenty suites on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 6302 Polk Street, West New York, N.J., was sold by State Banking Commissioner Louis A. Reilly, liquidator for the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company, to Joseph Deischer.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 4:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- By a vote of 241 to 136 the House today adopted the Property Requisitioning Bill. Three amendments were added to the measure as passed by the Senate, thus necessitating a conference to iron out the differences.

An order put through by the Portuguese Government about a month ago to the effect that aliens will not be permitted to travel directly from the United States to the nine islands of the Azores group, but must first obtain clearance by going through Lisbon, was revealed yesterday with the departure of the Atlantic Clipper for Bermuda, Horta, the Azores, and Lisbon.
BOSTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- After kicking away a three-run lead, the Red Sox bounded back today to take a 6-5 decision from the Athletics and sweep the two-game series.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,695,250 barrels daily, a decrease of 174,700 from the 3,869,950 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 151,850 barrels less than the calculation of 3,847,100 daily by the Bureau of Mines for July.

Travelers arriving from France yesterday on the American Export liner Excambion declared that British air attacks on German bases in occupied France were becoming very effective, but that the British airmen were making every effort to protect the French people.
ROME, Aug. 5 (AP) -- An Italian High Command communique today said:

Strong opposition to the War Department's proposal to erect a $35,000,000 group of office buildings in Arlington, Va., for 40,000 workers was expressed yesterday by a spokesman for the Commission of Fine Arts, who charged that the buildings would encroach upon land that has been dedicated to the future use of the National Cemetery at Arlington.

Izzy Jannazzo, Brooklyn welterweight contender, scored a clean-cut ten-round victory over the Cocoa Kid of New Haven in the feature bout at Ebbets Field last night. Jannazzo took command in the fifth and proceeded to amass a top-heavy lead on points.

HERE is an extraordinary little story laid in Yonkers, N.Y. It may sound like romantic fiction or even a fairy tale, but it happens to be literally true. Some readers will recognize it, for it has been mentioned in print from time to time before. John Masefield, poet laureate of England, tells it tenderly and shrewdly and with a certain finality in his latest book, called "In the Mill."*

THIS is the great day in the Land o' Goshen (N.Y.). It's Hambletonian Day. That's the harness hoss classic of the year, with the 3-year-old trottin' crown and about $40,000 at stake. Here's a truly rural sport in a truly rural setting; a country town, merry villagers, tall corn growing around the race track and great reins-men holding the ribbons over the backs of the best youngsters of the trottin' breed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Hanson W. Baldwin, in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 23 in his article "Potential United States Bases," suggests the joint use of Freetown with the British with an advanced base at Bathurst, British Gambia, instead of the much discussed port of Dakar.

Human barricades that formed Monday around silk stocking counters in department stores, under the spur of the tension with Japan and resulting in government curbs on silk, spread yesterday to the underwear and yard goods departments, as stores reported a mounting demand for all silk commodities.

Chalky Wright, Los Angeles Negro featherweight who will meet Joey Archibald, champion of that division, next month, scored a knockout victory over Paco Villa of Mexico City in 1:51 of the sixth round of a scheduled eight-round feature bout at the Queensboro Arena last night before a crowd of 4,500.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- Representatives of 100,000 members of automobile clubs in the State pledged today to comply with any gasoline saving regulations issued by Carroll E. Mealey, State Petroleum Products Conservator, and to extend financial aid if needed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Inter-State Cigarette Merchandisers Association of Newark, N.J., and five member associations operating cigarette vending machines in New York, New Jersey and nearby States today were ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to cease certain agreements in restraint of competition.

VICHY, France, Aug. 5 -- "Marshal Petain is not the man to allow himself to be convinced by a press campaign that he should change his position." That statement appears in the Paris-Soir -- that is the version of that newspaper printed in Paris -- in the course of a dispatch from its Vichy correspondent.

This is the first of a series of articles in which an American war correspondent tells the story of his arrest and imprisonment or four months by the German forces in occupied France and discloses information he gleaned from other prisoners and Nazi guards.

The city and the Board of Higher Education must restore $100,000 to the 1941-42 budget for the continued operation of Townsend Harris High School, Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga ruled yesterday. The school's appropriation was reduced from $295,297 to $195,297 by the Board of Estimate on the recommendation of Mayor La Guardia, as a first step toward the abolition of the school by eliminating next Fall's incoming class.

The war in the air continued to claim the military spotlight in Western Europe and the Mediter- ranean yesterday as British bombers struck at widely separated points on the periphery of German-occupied Europe.

Mr. Edgar J. Nathan, selected by the Republican Executive Committee for President of the Borough of Manhattan, is in the prime of life, just 50, welleducated, a lawyer of distinction. In the Constitutional Convention he was a member of the important committee on judiciary.

The Parker Appliance Company, manufacturer of aircraft accessories and parts for general manufacturing and transportation industries, reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on June 30, net income of $1,257,209 after providing $1,270,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes.

A group composed of Shields Co., Harvey Fisk Sons, Inc. and Foster Marshall has received the award of $659,100 of State of Idaho institution improvement bonds on a bid of 100.14 for 1 3/8s. The bonds, dated Aug. 15, 1941, will mature on Aug. 15, 1961, optional for call on Aug. 1, 1943.

The Standard Oil Company of Ohio yesterday filed with the Cleveland regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the proposed offering of 186,667 shares of common stock of $25 par value.

While the general strike at 1,000 construction jobs of 7,000 members of Electrical Workers Union, Local 3, A.P.L., continued yesterday, the union authorized its men to return to eighteen more jobs, including defense work, hospitals and projects involving health and life.

Without the aid of such favored props as lucky horseshoes or rabbits' feet, Captain Arnold Doughty of Atlantic City went out alone on a 32-foot cruiser and came back to the dock with one white marlin, eight tuna and twelve bonito, having handled his boat and fought the fish at the same time.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A heavy Axis aid raid on the Suez Canal and the Nile delta last night killed ninety persons, injured 106 and caused property damage near the waterway, the Egyptian Ministry of Interior announced today.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Aug. 5--The professionals came into their own in the Westchester division of the tenth annual World-Telegram hole-in-one tournament today when Johnny Vasco of the Sunset Knolls Golf Club at Ossining placed a No. 6 iron shot 1 1/2 inches from the pin on the 155-yard ninth hole of the Leewood Country Club.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- This mecca of the light harness horse world is buzzing with activity and gossip tonight, for trotting enthusiasts, in typical Hambletonian fashion, are taxing the housing facilities and debating the chances of the contestants in tomorrow's classic.

LONDON, Aug. 5 (U.P.) -- News that additional British Army and Air Force reinforcements reached Malaya yesterday was released here today simultaneously with hints that the government expected some sensational new Japanese move in the near future and was preparing to deal with it.
BERLIN, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The following communique was isued today by Adolf Hitler's headquarters:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- There is good reason to believe that the Vichy Government is still discussing with the German representatives in Paris the demands brought back from Berlin by German Ambassador Otto Abetz, which aim at enforcing in French North and West Africa a scheme of "common defense" on the Indo-China pattern
MOSCOW, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 5 -- The pre-tournament favorite team, composed of three Philadelphians and a New Yorker, won the contract bridge mixed team-of-four championship in the national tournament at the Convention Hall here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- While the Administration bent efforts through its price control bill to prevent an inflationary trend which, President Roosevelt said, threatens to undermine the defense effort, leaders from the farm States in Congress today took another step in the opposite direction.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- The nation's railroad workers, estimated as totaling 1,130,000 to 1,370,000, were asked tonight by their leaders to authorize a strike after railroad representatives refused their demands for wage increases. The railroads estimated that the increase sought would add $900,000,000 annually to their costs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an order under the geographical integration section of the Public Utility Holding Company Act which will pare the $589,706,862 United Light and Power Company's public utility system to two or more systems of which the larger will have a capitalization of some $240,000,000 and narrow its operations from twelve to six States.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 5 -- Tommy Platt of Cold Spring Harbor sailed his Atlantic Class boat to two victories today to take a substantial lead for the junior sailing championship of Long Island Sound at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.
A top-to-bottom survey of the American Museum of Natural History by Dr. Alexander Grant Ruthven, president of the University of Michigan, has been under way since May, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Domestic livestock, American agriculture's richest sources of income, are producing at full emergency rates to meet wartime demand, and are yielding farmers prices 17 to 78 per cent greater than a year ago, market statistics indicated today.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- One of the biggest upsets in its twelve-year history occurred in the New York State women's golf championship at Siwanoy today as Miss Shirley Podret, 20-year-old Poughkeepsie girl, eliminated Mrs. Harry McNaughton of Plandome in the opening round.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Kunio Akiyama, spokesman for the Japanese forces in China, said today that a minor clash of Japanese and Soviet border troops occurred near Manchuli about two weeks ago. Manchuli is just inside extreme Western Manchukuo on a railway to Siberia.

The naming of borough tickets by the major political parties was completed yesterday when the Kings County Republican organization, headed by John R. Crews, named a ticket headed by Special Sessions Justice Matthew J. Troy for Borough President and William Stanley Miller for Surrogate.

A large penthouse apartment in 1049 Park Avenue has been leased to John Goodwillie, assistant publicity director of R.H. Macy Co., through Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc., agents, and Gilliam McVay, Inc., brokers, one of the reports covering residential leasing received yesterday disclosed.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- The good fortune of Mrs. Ethel V. Mars, mistress of the Milky Way Farm, continued today when her Black Raider, already stake winner in the West, showed his speed to Easterners. There wasn't much to it as the black colt strode through the stretch to score by two lengths before 8,678 fans in the $4,825 Saratoga Sales Stake for 2-year-olds sold here the season before.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Office of Production Management asked the nation's steel companies today to rush submission of proposals for expanding their bessemer ingot production capacity. That method of steel making requires very little scrap, a shortage of which has developed to threaten continuance of the steel industry's high production rate.

HAVANA, Aug. 5 -- The crisis in the Cuban Congress resulting from last night's free-for-all battle on the floor of the Senate between Opposition and Majority Senators became acute this afternoon when four Opposition groups voted to abstain from all Senate activities until "the necessary guarantees for the minority have been restored."

FALLS VILLAGE, Conn., Aug. 5. -- Dr. Hugh Cabot of Boston declared here today that group practice of medicine was "the only cure" for present-day duplication, inefficiency and high costs, which he said were leaving a large part of the population without adequate medical care.

Virtually 94 per cent of secondquarter earnings and 80 per cent of six-month earnings of the United Aircraft Corporation were applied to provisions for Federal income and excess profits taxes for those periods, according to the quarterly report issued yesterday.

For half an hour last night the fish didn't swim in the Wrigley sign in Times Square; Fred Astaire and Rita Hayworth vanished from the illuminated square on which their likenesses danced for the greater glory of Wilson whiskey, and the coffee in the magnified Silex bubbled no more, though steam forlornly still hissed from it.

HAWTHORNE, N.Y. -- Louis Padgett, 38, of 1835 E Street, N. W., Washington, was taken into custody here this afternoon after his apprehension by Connecticut State Troopers at the railroad station at Pawling, near the Summer home of Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney of New York County.
