BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- Ten delegates of the Allis-Chalmers local of Milwaukee, which had a seventy-nine-day strike delaying vital defense orders, were barred from seats today after a stormy debate at the convention of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O.

BERLIN, Aug. 5 -- The tone of today's Supreme High Command communique, plus bits of information picked up about Berlin, suggest that after more than a fortnight in which the Soviet troops held" the invading forces at bay, the Germans are again advancing.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Vern Olsen and Bill Nicholson pulled the Cubs out of a five-game losing streak today, sparking them to a 6-to-2 triumph over the league-leading Cardinals.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 5 -- Bronzed by a broiling Virginia sun and scarred by numerous tick, chigger and other insect bites, more than 15,000 members of the Forty-fourth Division returned this morning after two weeks of manoeuvres at the A.P. Hill Military Reservation observed by officers of the Second Army Corps, First Army and General Headquarters.

Nearly all sections of the city shared in the commercial renting activity reported by brokers yesterday. Areas receiving new tenants included the Fourteenth Street section, the midtown vicinity and the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Senate debated the military service extension bill and rejected the Taft amendment, concluded Congressional action on the bill deferring men over 27 from mili- tary service and recessed at 4:52 P.M. until noon tomorrow.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 5 -- Bronzed by a broiling Virginia sun and scarred by numerous tick, chigger and other insect bites, more than 15,000 members of the Forty-fourth Division returned this morning after two weeks of manoeuvres at the A.P. Hill Military Reservation observed by officers of the Second Army Corps, First Army and General Headquarters.

The possibility that the general strike of 7,000 members of Electrical Workers Union, Local 3, A.F.L., will be certified to the National Defense Mediation Board for settlement appeared yesterday with the receipt of information from Washington that this procedure was favored by Sidney Hillman, co-director of the Office of Production Management.

Easy to Escape Impressive attendance figures are quoted to show that the public likes "Charley's Aunt" on the screen quite as much as it did on the stage at the beginning of last season. Social psychologists and disappointed moralists will shake their heads and say something about another desperate effort to escape from the grim realities of today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, told the House Banking and Currency Committee today that the government must have power to curb excesses in installment buying to wage a successful fight against inflation.

Detention in five French, internment camps during a period of eight months failed to break the spirit of 70-year-old twin sisters who arrived here yesterday from Casablanca, French Morocco, on the Portuguese liner Guine.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 6 (U.P.) -- Reports abroad that a British naval squadron was cruising in the Gulf of Siam were denied by a high Thai authority today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The average American, if he exists, should have had $73.06 in his pocket at the end of July, according to the monthly Treasury statement of United States money in circulation.

Approval by the conference committee of the House and Senate of the Smith bill to "freeze" government-owned cotton stocks for the duration of the war yesterday stimulated the cotton market. After opening strong at 9 to 16 points above Monday's closing quotations, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange extended their gains to 18 to 25 points before profit-taking pared them to 8 to 11 points net higher for the day.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Mrs. James P. Donahue entertained with a small dinner at Arrowhead Inn last night for her house guest, Mrs. William C. Breed of New York.

The retail millinery and lingerie concern known as CYF of Paris, which for forty years has been established on the European Continent, plans to open a New York store at 532 Madison Avenue which will be decorated and furnished as a duplicate of that operating in France.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6 -- Mrs. Henry Walters gave a large luncheon at Sherwood today, and will give a similar party tomorrow.

With industrial accidents in the nation increased 20 per cent as the result of expanded production for defense, the National Committee for the Conservation of Manpower in Defense Industries, a government-created body, has issued a plea for cooperation by plants with defense contracts in promoting industrial safety, and has urged that small plants with sub-contracts, in which most accidents occur, seek the committee's services.

BOSTON, Aug. 6 -- The Yankee blitz movement to an American League pennant was still throttled down to half speed today, when Joe Cronin's unfathomable Red Sox held Joe McCarthy's juggernaut to an even break in a midweek double-header that drew an astonishing sell-out crowd of 34,427.

First wholesale price revisions on branded lines of women's full-fashioned hosiery were made yesterday and they indicated that numbers retailing at less than $1 will be out of the picture in the near future. This is a return to the basis of January, 1940, when rising prices of raw silk took the 79-cent, 85-cent and 89-cent numbers out of the branded lines.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Pirates won their fifth straight and their seventeenth in twenty games today when they romped off with an easy 13-to-3 triumph over the Cubs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a plan of reorganization for the Wabash Railroad Company and at the same time authorized the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to acquire control of the reorganized Wabash.

Local 16 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., went on strike at midnight last night in the Kearny, N.J., yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, where 16,000 workers were engaged on defense contracts totaling $450,000,000.

There's no telling what the 12-year-old gray gelding, King Tut, was thinking as he plodded slowly yesterday morning on East 173d Street, the Bronx, pulling a wagon filled with vegetables. The sun was beating down, the neighbor's children were shouting happily as they played their games, and Charlie Gedseg of 1867 Bathgate Avenue who had hired King Tut and the cart from a near-by stable, was hawking his wares.

Of the 100 largest national advertisers in newspapers, magazines, radio and farm journals only twenty-four are in industries which are encountering production problems due to priorities and shortages of materials, according to a compilation yesterday.
Spokesmen for large oil companies gave assurances yesterday that, despite the shortage of petroleum products, rationing of fuel oil to heat houses in this area would not be necessary this Winter.

VICHY, France, Aug. 6 -- Full explanations of France's policy in the defense of her empire are contained in a formal note handed, it is learned here tonight, to United States Ambassador William D. Leahy for transmission to Washington.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Results of the first month of a project intended to discourage air-minded Japanese beetles from dead-heading to the uninfested zone via commercial airliners were disclosed here today by R.W. Sherman of the Japanese beetle control division of the Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine of the United States Department of Agriculture.

Cow beef and pork loins were exceptionally hard to move yesterday. Veal and calf business was only fair to slow. Other classes moved fair. Steer hinds and ribs were weak to 50c lower, some sales of calf were lower and the cow market was fully 50c-$1 lower. Kosher beef opened about steady, veal and lamb steady.

MOSCOW, Aug. 6 -- With the Russian Air Force apparently assuming considerable initiative, sweeping behind the German lines to bomb airports and to strafe and bomb German mechanized formations, artillery batteries and infantry concentrations, official reports make it clear that Nazi efforts to get a new offensive under way by applying pressure in previously calm sectors are not yet meeting with any particular success.

The twelve-story building containing one store and fourteen lofts at 30-32 West Fifteenth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, was sold by Henry F. Caldwell Co. to Henry Goelet, operator. It is 50 by 110 feet and was conveyed subject to a new first mortgage of $111,800 for ten years with interest at 3 per cent.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- The favorites are having hard going in the New York State women's golf championship.

William F. Carey, Commissioner of Sanitation of New York, who is serving as a special adviser in the construction division of the Office of Production Management, was elected yesterday chief executive of the $61,000,000 International Utilities Corporation, a utility holding company controlling electric, water and gas properties in Canada and the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -- Joseph Buffington, retired 86-year-old senior judge of the Third Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, testified today that because of physical infirmities he adopted opinions written by Judge J. Warren Davis, one of his two associates, as his own in the years 1936-37-38.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Favorable action by the House Rivers and Harbors Committee on the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project was forecast today after the committee had received the approval of President Roosevelt of a plan to include it in the 1942 omnibus flood control bill.

Net sales of the American Viscose Corporation in the first six months of 1941 rose to $38,130,128 from $28,633,648 for the comparable period last year, according to the semi-annual report of John G. Jackson, chairman of the board, issued for publication today.

LONDON, Aug. 6 (U.P.) -- Two German spies who landed in Britain elaborately equipped to send information to the Continent were executed at Wandsworth Prison today, according to a Home Office announcement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Three defense officials announced today a coordinated program, both immediate and long-range, to re-establish the silk hosiery and other civilian silk industries, maintain the employment of as many as possible of the 175,000 displaced silk workers and to assure for the country an adequate supply of hosiery and other articles formerly made of silk.

Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan announced in no uncertain terms yesterday that he was in the race for re-election to stay. Even if defeated in the primaries, he will run as an independent, he said.

The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that it had absorbed the Scandinavian Seamen's Union in its recently formed Pan-American Department, a separate unit designed to provide organizational facilities and protection for seamen sailing on American-owned foreign flag vessels.

After Councilman Joseph E. Kinsley had described the alleged paying of Welfare Department employes out of relief taxes instead of budget funds as "an out-and-out swindle," the Council committee investigating civil service voted yesterday to adjourn without date.

There are those who -- like Tish's lively spinster friend, Aggie -- go through life in a series of sneezes. They were once called hay fever victims but now are more elegantly known as allergic to pollen. And news of especial interest to these long-suffering souls hinges on a honey that makes its appearance on the shelf of a city store in a stout and sturdy container.

The heaviest shipping loss sustained by Great Britain in any single month was in March, 1941, when 326,631 tons were sent to the bottom by German submarines, mines, surface raiders and long-range bombers. Combined British and Allied losses of merchant vessels reached a peak of 533,902 tons in June, 1940 -- the month of the evacuation from Dunkerque.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Top-ranking Gardner Larned of Chicago beat a game Cincinnatian, Marshall Chambers, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, in the junior singles fourth round of the national juniors' and boys' tennis tournament at Culver Military Academy today.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Rhodophyceae are running amok in the once blue waters of the Atlantic Ocean from Atlantic Highlands to Sea Girt, giving the surf a reddish hue, tickling the gills of fish and clogging the pipes through which salt water is pumped to beach club pools.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Reds came to life today to gain a 5-to-1 victory over the Cardinals behind the eight-hit, seven-walk, nine-strikeout hurling of Johnny Vander Meer. It was Vandy's tenth decision of the year.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 6 -- More than 200 members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the weekly tombola luncheon at the Bar Harbor Club today, after which many watched the matches of the annual Maritime Tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Southern Pacific Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue $20,000,000 of promissory notes to nine banks on security of 120,000 shares of capital stock of the Pacific Fruit Express Company, a Utah corporation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- "Shocking conditions" in the housing of armament workers were reported by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, meeting here today. A trend was noted toward serious price inflation, but the council warned against giving what it termed dictatorial powers to any Federal agency in that connection.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Thornton Lee held the Browns to six singles as the White Sox won the second game of a double-header today, 5 to 2, to break even, the Browns having won the first, 9 to 6.
BERLIN, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of July 31 shows the following changes compared with that of July 7, in thousands of reichsmarks:

In sight of several hundred persons who were hurrying to work yesterday morning just before 9 o'clock, twenty-five members of two rival C.I.O. unions engaged in a free-for-all-fight at Twenty-fourth Street and Sixth Avenue. During the melee Irving Israel Pickover, a 28-year-old picket, of 3059 Brighton Fourteenth Street, Brooklyn, was stabbed in the heart.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Administration's "compromise" plan for extending the active military service of selectees, National Guardsmen and Reserve officers was saved in the Senate by a surprise victory late today, and this appeared to have set the stage for certain adoption of the measure, probably tomorrow.

FALLS VILLAGE, Conn., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Earle S. Draper, Assistant Federal Housing Administrator, asserted tonight that one of the war's lessons was that densely inhabited urban housing projects "are an invitation to the bomber."

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- A steady stream of Japanese troops and equipment is flowing into Manchukuo and there is every indication that Japan is preparing for an immediate effort to occupy Vladivostok and other strategic points in Eastern Siberia as soon as an expected Russian military collapse in Europe begins, according to travelers who reached here today from Dairen.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 5:

Trustees of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation yesterday asked representatives of five leading investment banking houses for a comprehensive refinancing program for the Virginia Public Service Company, a subsidiary.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Wheat futures sold at new high prices since 1927 today on a rush of buying created by additional talk of inflation, Price Administrator Leon Henderson's prediction of a sharp rise in the cost of living and a report that Senate and House conferees had agreed on a proposal to freeze the government-owned stock of wheat secured by farmer defaults on loans on the 1940 wheat crop.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Heads of three organizations supporting the Administration's foreign policy issued a joint statement tonight deploring "the interjection of party issues" into discussions of international affairs. It was a reply to one issued yesterday by Herbert Hoover, Alfred M. Landon, Frank O. Lowden and other Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Rubber Reserve Company, which has become the sole buyer of crude rubber imported into the United States from the Far East, will make crude rubber available to the manufacturing industry at the dock or warehouse in New York at 22 1/2 cents per pound for No. 9 ribbed smoked sheets, with appropriate differentials for other types and grades, it was announced today by Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator.
LONDON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique today said:

Total entry for the United States amateur golf championship at Omaha, Neb., Aug. 25-30 is 643 -- the smallest since 1937 -- the United States Golf Association announced through The United Press yesterday.

The semi-annual report covering operations of the American Woolen Company and its subsidiary, the Pocono Company, but excluding operations of its other subsidiary, the Textile Realty Company, disclosed a net profit of $4,905,625 for the first six months of 1941.

TIMBER POINT, L.I., Aug. 6 -- Adrian Iselin 2d of the Western Long Island Sound fleet, led twenty-three International Stars around a nine-mile triangular course to win the second of a series of five races for the Commodore George A. Corry Trophy as the annual Great South Bay race week continued today.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 6 -- Reports circulating in high foreign diplomatic circles at Ankara today said that Germany had renewed her peace offensive efforts during the past week or ten days, putting forward definite proposals for an armistice with Great Britain through American and other foreign circles at Istanbul and in other neutral capitals.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 6 -- Claire Trevor and Brian Donlevy will be teamed in Columbia's gangster comedy, "Let the Eagle Scream," if negotiations for the actor's services are successful, it was learned today. Miss Trevor, who is now on loan-out to Metro for "Achilles," will again be available to Columbia on Sept. 1, while Donlevy will be borrowed from Paramount if his schedule can be arranged to include the assignment.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 6 -- Peter Duble, who is defending for Indian Harbor the title won last year by Dick Middleton, went back into the lead for the Long Island Sound junior sailing cnampionship off the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club today by winning the fourth race of the series.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- The first three days of the Chicago Fall market has developed a volume of buying beyond the ability of many wholesalers to handle.

The efforts of the United States to reinforce the economic position of South America in the interests of inter-American security are bearing increasing fruit. The outbreak of the war forced South America to turn to this country for a wide variety of goods previously obtained from Europe, without in any way increasing its ability to pay for them.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- Drawing a favorable contrast between the state of Britain now and a year ago, Clement R. Attlee, Lord Privy Seal and a member of the war Cabinet, in reviewing the war in the House of Commons today nevertheless sounded a solemn warning against any undue optimism.

Japan has "lost the war in China already and would be happy to get out of it." Dean Henry H. Meyer, director of the graduate division of religious education at Boston University, said last night in an interview here on his return from an eight-month visit to China.

DEAL, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Donald L. Moore of Essex Fells, winner of the New Jersey seniors' golf championship in 1939, took low-gross honors in the annual Summer tournament of the seniors on the Deal Golf Club course today.

Otto Ludwig Preminger has taken an option on "Woodrow Wilson," by Howard Koch and John Huston, which had been previously held by John Houseman of the Mercury Theatre. Mr. Preminger says that he has not completed any plans for its production, but hopes to have it ready for a late Fall premiere.

JOHN FAULKNER, younger brother of William Faulkner, has written a vivid first novel with the bland title of "Men Working." It will be a little too painfully vivid for some tastes, no doubt, but it is sound, honest, unaffected American reporting, and excellent comedy and good sociology, as well.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Contracts totaling $4,645,195 were awarded by the War Department today. The following awards, not previously published, went to concerns in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- After pursuing the even tenor of their way for four days, the favored array in the Eastern turf court tennis championships hit the rocky road en route to the quarter-finals today at the Westchester Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Office of Production Management recommended today the construction of a $23,097,000 high-speed steel plate mill at the Sparrows Point (Md.) plant of the Bethlehem Steel Company.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 6 -- Neutral military observers here are puzzled, even startled, by the news from the Russian front. German reports assert that "the Battle of Smolensk is over" and that all attention is now turned to the Battle of Kiev, capital of the Ukraine -- this without troubling to exploit the reported success on the central front. It is so contrary to all rules of war that many wonder what it means.

Shareholders of the International Paper and Power Company were called yesterday to a special meeting in Boston on Sept. 25 to vote on a plan of corporate simplification under which a new International Paper Company would replace the paper and power concern and its subsidiary, the International Paper Company.

BUFFALO, Aug. 6 -- An assertion that the government would have to "dictate" a firm policy if the automobile industry failed to offer a workable plan for integrating curtailment of automobile production with the defense program was made today by Walter P. Reuther, director of the General Motors department of the United Automobile Workers of America (C.I.O.).

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Whirlaway, top horse of 1941, made a champion's return to Eastern racing when he captured the Saranac Handicap before 9,958 persons today, but he also called up an old ghost in whether or not the camera finish favors the outside horse.

LONDON, Thursday, Aug. 7 -- Flying fast through the night, with a gale at their backs, a large force of British bombers early yesterday morning caused widespread destruction in Frankfort on the Main, Mannheim and Karlsruhe, the Air Ministry said.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Prices of hog and beef cattle receded as much as 25 cents today as the market was under pressure of liberal receipts. Spring lambs were fairly steady and fat yearlings and sheep around 25 cents higher.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Braves shut out the Phillies, 6 to 0, tonight behind the five-hit hurling of Emanuel Salvo. Si Johnson pitched two-hit ball for the Phils for six innings, but weakened, and the Braves pounded him for four runs in the eighth.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Aug. 7 -- Russian troops, counter-attacking stubbornly in the face of overwhelming odds, were reported yesterday to have smashed through the spearheads of German forces on both ends of the central Ukrainian front -- around Korosten and Byelaya Tserkov.

Three new films will open in mid-town houses this morning. Columbia's "Here Comes Mr. Jordan," starring Robert Montgomery, will be the newcomer at the Radio City Music Hall. The comedy, which was directed by Alexander Hall, features Evelyn Keyes, Claude Rains, James Gleason, Edward Everett Horton, Donald MacBride, Rita Johnson and John Emery.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES has been receiving many compliments on the articles sent up from South America by Mr. Callender, in many cases justly deserved. Nevertheless, even he may nod occasionally is he does in his article published in the issue of Aug. 3 headed "Latin Catholics Suspicious of the United States."

MOSCOW, Aug. 6 -- As a factual answer to German contentions that the Nazi air force has destroyed the enormous Stalin automobile factory, which is one of Moscow's greatest industrial landmarks, foreign correspondents today were permitted to tour the plant, which was found to be operating at full capacity, in no way damaged by raiders, and turning out even more than the regular peacetime production of trucks and cars.
LONDON, Aug. 6 -- Two American Red Cross nurses emerged today as major heroines of the Battle of the Atlantic.
Warren Lincoln Travis, who styled himself the "world's greatest weight lifter," left a will in which he asked that a contest be held to find a man who could equal his feats of weight-lifting.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Edmund Overton, 21-year-old home club player, won the Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day tournament today when he romped over the familiar terrain of the Pelham Country Club for a 72, scoring a four-under-par 33 and a 39.

TORONTO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Smart pitching jobs by Dick Fowler and Porter Vaughan gave the Toronto Maple Leafs a pair of victories over the Jersey City Giants tonight, 7-2 and 5-1, giving the Leafs a 3-2 edge in the five-game series.
On the basis of both Russian and German communiques, it appears probable that the tremendous campaign in Russia is entering a new phase.

Detective Thomas Gallagher is unable to tell a man's address by the dust on his shoes, but give him a suspect's name and description and his doggedness will take care of the rest. This was proved yesterday when he returned -- on the last day of his vacation -- to the Flushing precinct with a man he has sought since April.

The school tuna are plentiful now in the Montauk area, according to a wire just received from Captain Charles Tuma, who went out Tuesday with a party of two and brought back sixty tuna ranging from twenty-five to sixty pounds each.
West Side houses drew the largest share of the new residential tenancies announced yesterday.
BERLIN, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler's headquarters issued this communique today:

Concerning the New Tax Notes Despite the descriptive literature an the government's new tax anticipation notes distributed to the banks and redistributed to their customers, the constant flow of requests to the Federal Reserve Bank, which is issuing the notes in this district on behalf of the Treasury, reveals several points of confusion.

BERLIN, Aug. 6 -- After weeks of almost absolute silence on the course of the invasion of Russia, the Supreme Command of the German armed forces released at noon today a series of special communiques, partly recapitulating the results of the operations on the Eastern Front from the break through the Stalin Line announced on July 12 up to the present.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The United States, it was learned today, has unfrozen millions of dollars worth of Soviet orders in this country and presumably the flow of American supplies to the fighting Russians already has begun.

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 6 (AP) -- A military investigation was started today into a sudden flare-up of gunplay on a crowded Fayetteville-Fort Bragg bus soon after midnight that sent two soldiers to their deaths and four others to the post hospital.

BERLIN, Aug. 6 (AP) -- With trumpet fanfare the German High Command today reported gigantic victories over the Russians on each of the three main sectors of the Eastern Front and, indicating that the Soviet troops had fallen by the millions, led the official news agency D.N.B. to assert that the Red Field Army could be regarded as "having fallen victim" to the German drive.

The note handed to the American Ambassador at Vichy yesterday is in answer to the questions raised by Under-Secretary Welles when he asked for specific assurances that the French Government would reject German demands for military concessions in North Africa.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., in addition to being Secretary of the Treasury, is a farmer, and a successful one. He is, moreover, a mild-spoken man, little given to extreme statements. When he says that the Congressional legislation to force up farm prices by "freezing" Government stocks of cotton and wheat is "terrible" and "wicked," we may safely assume that he has not overstated the case.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 6 -- "It appears from questions addressed to newspapers," says a Swedish Government communique, "that some confusion reigns in the minds of the people" as to the rules of international law.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- With only Senator Vandenberg defending President Roosevelt's stand, the Senate voted 57 to 19 today to override the Chief Executive's veto of a $320,000,000 defense highway program.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Newark Bears came from behind to down the Bisons tonight, 5 -- 2, and win the series of five games. A crowd of 8,973 saw the Herd lose second place as Montreal handed the Baltimore Orioles a six-teenth straight setback.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Dutch Leonard, veteran knuckleballer, turned in an eight-hit performance as the Senators defeated the Athletics, 5 to 1, tonight. It was Leonard's twelfth victory of the season against 10 losses.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Six new champions ascended national skeet thrones today, setting four new records and tying two others, as the clay target scatter-gun classic got away to the most auspicious start in its history.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I noticed your recent review of the book "Democracy or Anarchy?" by Dr. F.A. Hermens of Notre Dame, crusader against proportional representation, and have since been reading the book.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Aug. 6 -- The closing on the Bourse was quiet. The market was irregular and slightly higher. A.K.U. lost 1-5/s to 144, and Philips 1 1/4 to 234, but Unilever rose 1/4 to 131 5/8, and Royal Dutch 1/2 to 248 3/4. Amsterdam Trading was unchanged at 422 after selling at 417.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 6 -- New York players won both the men's and women's pair championships in the National Contract Bridge tournament here today. Neither of the winning pairs had been among the favorites. The men's title went to Simon Rossant and Joseph E. Low, with 476.1 points; the women's title to Mrs. Mae Rosen and Mrs. Erwin Seligman, with 471.7 points.

A suit brought by the government against the Masonite Corporation and nine other companies in the hardboard industry, charging violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act, was dismissed yesterday by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Enthusiastic urban and rural dwellers, 40,000 strong, thronged Good Time Park today for the Hambletonian's sixteenth trotting and saw the heavily-favored Bill Gallon supply a triumphant crowning touch to Owner R.H. Johnston's first quest for honors in the light harness world's premier attraction.
NEW YORK Mrs. William Lewis Beale of Washington has arrived at the St. Regis.

Edwin Franko Goldman held his annual memory contest last night at the concert of the Goldman Band on the Mall in Central Park. An audience of 20,000 attended, and 2,000 of these submitted their guesses of the twenty-five anonymous works played during the first half of the program.

Men's Wear Sales Active Men's wear trade continued very active this week, with all types of goods selling, retail executives reported here yesterday. Sales of Summer clothing pulled very well and furnishings and sportswear were also active, despite the fact that there were fewer $1 shirt specials than last year.
An apartment house and a vacant taxpayer site were among the Brooklyn properties involved in the trading reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Secretary Ickes, National Defense Petroleum Coordinator, outlined today a program for voluntary curtailment of the use of motor fuel by commercial vehicles in the East. It was estimated to save 20 to 30 per cent of gasoline.

BRISBANE, Australia, Aug. 6 -- The United States cruisers Salt Lake City and Northampton, making their first call here since leaving the Pearl Harbor naval base, took the city completely by surprise. It was remarked that, unlike the squadron visiting Australia last March, the warships are painted in dark gray battle dress, strikingly indicating increased American preparedness.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- There was $38,729 at stake in one race in this otherwise peaceful town today. Hence all the excitement. It began early in the morning when strangers began drifting around the barns at the Good Time track asking after the health of Perpetual, the brown colt that Doc Parshall was going to try to drive to victory in the Hambletonian.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Tigers were at bat seventeen times against three Indian pitchers in today's third inning and their eleven runs was the biggest half-inning of the season. The final score was 11 to 2.

A full, silvery moon smiled broadly on a scene of wildest joy last night for those legions of baseball fans who followed their Dodgers into the Polo Grounds. However, for the crushed Giant fans in the gathering of 52,791, the largest National League night crowd of the season, there was a sardonic twist to the smile of the man in the moon.

MOSCOW, Aug. 6 -- At a conference to enable reporter to meet the Moscow heroes and heroines who are supervising anti-fire patrols in the capital, five women and one man told how London defenses had been studied long before the German invasion of Russia, and preparations were made to meet the fire-damage threat.

Paul Wellman's novel, "Angel With Spurs," which was to have been a feature of Lippincott's Fall fiction list, has been postponed until Spring. Mr. Wellman, headed west on a vacation before he set himself to the finishing touches on the book, was stricken with appendicitis.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The vote by which the Senate rejected the proposel to limit additional service of Army personnel to twelve months was as follows:

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Dairymen of the New York City milkshed pressed their fight for higher returns today by proposing a further price-fixing base that would adjust the price of fluid milk to that of milk used in making cheese and evaporated milk.

TOKYO, Aug. 6 -- Haunted by the spectre of encirclement by an American, British, Chinese, Netherlands Indies and Soviet alliance, Japan was further alarmed today by reports that Britain was preparing to occupy vital points in Thailand to protect the land flank of Singapore.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 6 -- Many members of the Summer colony attended the showing of the motion picture "Cavalcade," which was given tonight at the Southampton Theatre for the benefit of the American Theatre Wing of the British War Relief Society and the Camp Upton Hospital Fund of the American Red Cross.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The United States joined Britain today in seeking to avert an occupation of Thailand by Japan. Secretary of State Cordell Hull declared that a Japanese move into Thailand would be a matter of concern to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- A striking increase, compared with last year's figures, in underwriting participations in issues registered under the Securities Act and offered for sale in the three months to June 30, is disclosed in a report by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 6 -- Playing sub-par golf in both morning and afternoon rounds, Jack Koster and Ed Kringle of the Shelter Rock Club won the amateur best-ball handicap championship of the Long Island Golf Association with a score of 136 -- 10 -- 126 at the Nassau Country Club today.

Buying was selective on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Of the 715 issues traded, 240 rose, 267 declined and 208 ended the session unchanged, with the apparent trend to the soft side, although a firmer note appeared here and there.

Helen Traubel, who triumphed with three different orchestras here last season by singing the Immolation scene from Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung," repeated her success last night in the scene before an audience of 10,000 persons in her first appearance as soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium.

An offer by the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company to pay $1,000,000 in cash to the Radio Corporation of America, in full settlement of all claims involved in several pending suits by RCA stockholders, was presented to Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy in connection with the trial of one of the actions, instituted in Supreme Court by Rose Druckerman and eleven other RCA stockholders.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., Aug. 6 -- Crossing the stretch of open sea from Montauk here, the racers on the American Yacht Club cruise had another fine run today. Winners on this, the third squadron event, were P. Mackay Sturges's blue-hulled 32-footer Sapphire in the cruising division, J.A.B. Smith Jr.'s small yawl Screwball III, and J.K. Starkweather's International sloop Freya.

Black silk socks for men may soon become as scarce as silk stockings for women. Men's hosiery, particularly black, yesterday joined the ranks of silk commodities high in demand at department stores as a result of recent governmental curbs on silk.

The National Defense Mediation Board indicated in Washington last night that it would recommend to President Roosevelt that he take over the strike-bound plant of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Corporation in Kearny, N.J., unless a speedy agreement could be reached for resumption of work on defense contracts totaling $450,000,000.
The silk rush to the "Klondike" counters of the city's department stores and women's apparel shops continued yesterday as boom-town conditions prevailed for the fifth day.

TIMBER POINT, L. I, Aug. 7 -- M. A. F. De Marigny of the Bahamas fleet triumphed today in the third of the aeries of five races among International Stars for the Commodore George A. Corry Trophy, a feature of the annual race week of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association

H. L. Aller, president of the American Power and Light Company, announced yesterday a comprehensive refinancing program for the Florida Power and Light Company, subsidiary, involving a capital contribution of $26,300,000 by the parent concern

In commemoration of the centenary of Antonin Dvorak's birth, a program devoted to works by that Czech composer was presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Hermann Adler, last night at the Lewisohn Stadium.

Despite the fact that there has been a substantial increase in national income this year, the standard of living has not risen proportionately, one marketing authority pointed out yesterday. Sellers of merchandise, who operate on the theory that the increased income is just so much extra money available for the purchase of all types of goods, are making a mistake, he said.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A firmer tone ruled in the hog and cattle markets today as receipts were curtailed. Spring lambs held fully steady. Hogs were unevenly steady to 15 cents higher, reflecting also 1/2 cent higher values in the dressed trade, where light loins were up to 23 1/2 to 25 cents a pound.

A drop of nearly 50 per cent in the mortality rate from pneumonia through the use of sulfa drug's was recorded by Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, Hospitals Commissioner, in his annual report to Mayor La Guardia yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Announcement that the Senate had passed a conference report to freeze government holdings of cash wheat for the duration of the war stimulated fairly general buying of wheat futures today and carried prices up 1 1/2 cents a bushel at one time to a new seasonal high level for the May.

LONDON. Aug. 7 (AP) -- The extent of British military aid to Thailand if that country should be attacked by Japanese forces massed in neighboring Indo-China will be governed by tha willingness of the United States to cooperate with action stronger than economic blockades, it was stated authoritatively today.

"Viva O'Brien," the new title for the Latin-American musical here-tofore known as "Hands Across the Border," was scheduled yesterday to open here during the week of Sept. 29. It was announced that Chester Hale, who will stage the dances, and Clark Robinson, who will design the scenery, will be co-producers with John Hickey, who first announced the musical last week.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Newark capitalized on the eight-hit pitching of Hank Borowy tonight for a 3-1 victory over the Red Wings after the home club's Clem Dreisewerd had eked out a 2-1 decision against the Bruins in the seven-inning twilight half of a double bill.
Reports of Japanese demands upon Russia yesterday -- though unconfirmed and probably, at this stage, untrue-nevertheless indicate the probable direction of the next Japanese move in the Orient.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- The British, digesting reports that Japan is massing troops in the north against Vladivostok and in the south against Thailand, are now inclined to hope she will drive north, but fear she will move south.

LONDON, Friday, Aug. 8 -- Despite wintry weather, marked by snow and sleet over the North Sea Royal Air Force bombers made strong attacks on Germany and German-occupied territory through Wednesday night and yesterday, blasting Frankfort-on-the-Main, Mannheim and Karlsruhe for the second night in succession.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 7 -- Completing a carefully planned three weeks' mountain - climbing Blitzkrieg, our small party of seven reached the base camp at the head of Delta Creek Wednesday, after the first successful ascent of Mount Hayes, 13,740 feet, the highest virgin peak in the Alaskan interior.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 7 -- The two principal contract bridge events of the year were under way in the national tournament here today as masters' pairs and teams of four fought for titles billed as world's championships by the American Contract Bridge League.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $2,047,419,646 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price a share of all listed stocks on July 31 was $28.46, compared with $27,07 at the end of June.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- The two players with the finest records for the tennis season to date went down in the biggest double reversal of the year today in the Eastern turf court championships at the Westchester Country Club.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Aug. 7 -- After an easy opening a rally developed on the Boerse under the lead of the shippings. Dutch Indian issues closed firm. A.K.U. lost 1 5/8 to 142 3/8, Unilever rose 3/8 to 132 3/8, Philips 1 5/8 to 235 5/8, Royal Dutch 1 1/2 to 250 1/4, Amsterdam Rubber 2 1/2 to 278 1/4 and Amsterdam Trading 7 to 429.

Short of room for its great and growing personnel, the War Department wants to build "the largest office building in the world" just at the chief entrance to Arlington Cemetery and on the thirty-five-acre plot of land set aside twenty years ago as part of the national cemetery.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 7 -- The Fleet Air Arm raided both Augusta and Gherbini in Sicily early yesterday, one flight doing double duty by first bombing Gherbini and then diving and machine-gunning searchlight positions at Augusta while the light crews were seeking to catch the main group of raiders.

Bank clearings for twenty-three leading cities of the United States in the week ended Wednesday amounted to $6,477,139,000, an increase of 17.9 per cent over the $5,492,814,000 in the similar period of 1940, according to Dunn Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Price changes in the wholesale commodity markets in the week ended on Aug. 2 were principally for certain foodstuffs and industrial materials. The Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today that its index of nearly 900 price series rose 0.5 point to the highest since April, 1930.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 7 (U.P) -- Thailand has no intention of granting military bases either to Japan or Britain, a source close to the Premier, Field Marshal Luang Bipul Songgram, said today.

Earning assets of the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in this city showed a further rise of $18,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The rise lifted the total for these banks above $12,000,000,000 for the first time.
Three foreign ships requisitioned by the United States are to be turned over to the Navy today for use as auxiliaries, it was disclosed yesterday at the offices of the Maritime Commission.
A large multi-family building in the Kingsbridge area figured in one of the leading Bronx realty deals yesterday.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7 (U.P) -- The official Soviet spokesman, S. A. Lozovsky, asserted today that German internal morale was buckling and that "war weariness" had increased immensely within the Reich as a result of the German Army's heavy losses on the Russian fronts.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Spencer Scott, last year's winner of the Hambletonian Stake for C. W. Phellis of Greenwich, Conn., triumphed today in the Trotting Derby at Good Time Park. Facing four of his Hambletonian rivals, Spencer Scott scored two decisive victories over Dunbar Bostwick's Nibble Hanover, who had raced to a record of 1:58 3/4 two weeks ago.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 7 -- The Tigers trimmed Bob Feller today, 4 to 3, but it took them thirteen innings and three hours and forty minutes. Singles by Barney McCosky, Mike Higgins and Bruce Campbell accounted for the deciding run.
Mrs. Albert D. Beers and her daughter, Miss Louise Harris Hoy of Plainfield, will entertain with a luncheon today for Miss Ridgeley Vermilye, who will be wed tomorrow to William A. Gilroy Jr.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A rapid and widespread rise in the general level of prices, caused by a growing lack of supplies sufficient to match increased demands, is reported by the Federal Reserve Board in its bulletin for August. Prices of some agricultural products, including grains and cotton, are substantially higher, the board points out, although stocks are larger than last Summer.

Nine thousand members of the United Wholesale and Warehouse Employes Union of New York marched three miles yesterday afternoon on the lower East Side after attending a funeral service for Irving Israel Pickover, 28-year-old member of Local 65, who was stabbed Wednesday morning during a labor dispute at Twenty-fourth Street and Sixth Avenue.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Middle East R.A.F. communique said today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Following are the detailed Senate votes today on approving an amendment to limit the extra military service of selectees, National Guardsmen, reserves and regulars to eighteen months and on giving $10 a month extra pay to men serving more than twelve months:

The midtown film roster remains unchanged today as "The Bride Came C.O.D." enters its third and final week at the Strand, and "Charley's Aunt" begins its second week at the Roxy . . . Off Broadway, the Russian film, "Soviet Frontiers on the Danube," starts the third week of its engagement at the Irving Place Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- There were some questions as to the effect of the Mead pay rise amendment to the service extension bill. Some War Department attorneys expressed the opinion that as it passed the Senate it provided for retroactive increases for men who have already completed more than one year's service in the Army.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Senate's vote today on the resolution to extend the service of trainees, National Guardsmen and reservists in the Army by eighteen months was as follows:
CIANO dove off the motor boat. Presently he bobbed up with water dripping from his eyes and said to Virginia Cowles:

After nearly two years of war the general health of the British people is "very excellent," Dr. Wallace H. Cole, for the last six months director of the American Hospital in Britain, Ltd., reported yesterday when he arrived here aboard the Dixie Clipper.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Aug. 8 -- Russian resistance on all three main sectors of the Eastern Front continued successfully throughout Wednesday night and all of yesterday to hold repeated German thrusts against their lines, it was asserted in the communique issued at midnight by the Russian High Command.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A delegation of British trades union leaders will visit the United States soon in an effort to establish an Anglo-American "labor front" against Adolf Hitler, it was revealed tonight.

LONDON, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- The Red Army has repulsed six German assaults on the outer defenses of Kiev and forced the Nazis to swing southward in an effort to outflank the Ukrainian capital, according to reports reaching London tonight.

BUFFALO, Aug. 7 -- Delegates to the convention of the United Automobile Workers of America-C.I.O. who favor close cooperation between the American and British labor movements were disappointed today when R.J. Thomas, president of the union, canceled an exchange of greetings with Herbert Morrison, British

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 7 -- Three more games were played in the Meadow Brook Club's twelve-goal polo championship today, with the veteran Charles Armstrong's Los Rancheros moving into the lead in the Meadow League and Bostwick Field and Pegasus tying for first place in the Brook League.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- Another message from the Potomac, the absence from Washington of four ranking naval and military leaders and the continued lack of official denials were thought by some here today to give color to reports that President Roosevelt might be meeting Prime Minister Churchill.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Many luncheon parties were given in the Terrace Restaurant at the track today. Peter A.B. Widener was host to Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Salmon, Mr. and Mrs. John C. Clark entertained for Mr. and Mrs. Russell A. Firestone, Mrs. Richard C. duPont gave a party for Mrs. George T. Weymouth, Eugene E. duPont and Mr. and Mrs. R. Roy Freck.

LONDON, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- A high Norwegian source reported tonight that Germany was fortifying the coast of Norway and building air and submarine bases, apparently in fear of a possible British invasion.

A year ago it was the Senate that led the way for the House in the adoption of the Selective Service Act. Now the Senate once more has led the way by voting to authorize an extension of the original twelve-month period of training. The act itself provided for such an extension in case Congress found "that the national interest is imperiled."

OTTAWA, Aug. 7 (Canadian Press) -- Notes in circulation increased $6,872,000 to $410,345,000 in the week ended yesterday, it was shown today by the Bank of Canada. Dominion Government deposits decreased $132,000 to $24,781,000, while chartered bank deposits increased $576,000 to $216,599,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The text of the resolution extending the period of service of those inducted under the Selective Service Act, National Guardsmen and Reservists, as amended and passed by the Senate, is as follows:

ROME, Aug. 7 -- Captain Bruno Mussolini, 23-year-old son of Premier Mussolini, was killed at 10 o'clock this morning near Pisa while experimenting with a bomber that had been assigned to the squadron he headed. Two other members of the crew were killed and five wounded in the crash, which occurred as the four-engined plane was preparing to land on the San Giusto airfield.

A trial committee of the Board of Higher Education announced yesterday that it had unanimously found Arthur R. Braunlich Jr., City College tutor in English, guilty of "flagrant neglect of duty and conduct unbecoming a public teacher," and recommended his dismissal.

BERLIN, Aug. 7 -- What remains of world markets at the close of the second year of war is rapidly gravitating toward the United States, which through its dominating position is also virtually dictating world prices of many commodities, according to an economic survey in the semi-annual report on prices and currencies published today in Berlin by the Reichskreditgesellschaft.

Houghton Mifflin made known yesterday its plans from Sept. 1 to the year's end. There will be a new novel by Ben Ames Williams in September, "The Strange Woman"; and a reissue of an early John Buchan adventure novel, "The Power-House."

Howard C. Hopson, once dominant figure in the $1,000,000,000 Associated Gas and Electric Company system, who is serving a five-year sentence in the Federal Penitentiary for mulcting the system of nearly $20,000,000, signed an agreement on Monday in the penitentiary whereby virtually all of his assets and those of his immediate family are to be turned over to the Associated Gas and Electric estate and the Federal Government, it was disclosed yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In addition to the excellent reasons given in THE TIMES by Harold J. Coolidge Jr. for our occupation of Dakar, there are political considerations in Latin America which add weight to the argument.

BOSTON, Aug. 7 -- As those official communiques from abroad might put it, the Yankee pennant drive is still moving along "according to schedule," but unhappily the schedule appears to be operating in reverse.
LONDON, Aug. 7 -- The Russian war has produced an underground panic throughout Germany, according to indications in statements by neutral travelers just out of the Reich.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Contrary to expectations, the House by the narrow margin of two votes today sustained President Roosevelt's veto of the $320,000,000 defense highway authorization bill.
WITH THE FINNISH ARMY ON THE RUSSIAN FRONT, Aug. 7 (AP) -- For the Finnish soldier at the front there always is the comforting feeling that his general is right near him.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Defense officials predicted today that as many as 5,000 factories might be closed before the end of the year by lack of critical and strategic materials and that "priorities unemployment" might result in the temporary or permanent displacement of more than 1,000,000 workers.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- The Soviet Union today quietly forged another link in its chain of diplomatic relations with European nations when arrangements were completed with Belgium at a meeting in the British Foreign Office. There Soviet Ambassador Ivan M. Maisky and Premier Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium reached an agreement for an exchange of representatives between their governments.

MOSCOW, Friday, Aug 8 -- Supported by tanks, new concentrations of artillery and fresh reinforcements, the German General Staff is working to get another fierce offensive started in the direction of Smolensk, which is the traditional invaders' high road to Moscow, but, according to official information here, the Red Army is fighting stubbornly and holding the Wehrmacht in check.

The Dry Dock Savings Institution sold to a client of the P. Zaccaro Company the five-story office building with showrooms at 309-11 Fifth Avenue, between Thirty-first and Thirty-second Streets. The property is 56 by 150 feet and is assessed at $380,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Senate passed tonight, by a vote of 45 to 30, legislation empowering President Roosevelt to continue the active military duty of enlisted men, selectees, national guardsmen and reserve officers eighteen months beyond their present tenures, and sent it to the House which is scheduled to begin consideration of a similar measure tomorrow.

Settlement of the general strike of 7,000 electricians, members of Electrical Workers Union, Local 3, now in its second week, appeared to be approaching yesterday as a result of moves in New York and Washington.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 1 (AP) -- In the most stunning upset this tourney has seen in recent years, Budge Patty of Los Angeles staged a brilliant uphill battle today to defeat top-ranked Gardner Larned of Chicago, 0 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 7 -- 5, in the junior singles quarter-finals of the national boys' and juniors' tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The French note handed to Ambassador William D. Leahy yesterday, heralded in Vichy as containing assurances that France's African Empire would be protected from the Nazis, turned out, upon its receipt today in Washington, to contain no new assurances.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Department-store sales showed much less than the usual seasonal decline from June to July, according to the latest reports of the Federal Reserve Board, and the board's adjusted index rose from 104 to 113. Sales last week rose 27 per cent above the corresponding period of last year, the same increase as in the week previous.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A shortage of aviation gasoline in this country can be averted only by immediate expansion of refining facilities to keep pace with foreign and domestic requirements, Secretary Ickes, defense petroleum coordinator, said today.

With the time for filing nominations for members of the New York County Democratic Committee expiring next Tuesday, it appeared yesterday that twelve Tammany Assembly district leaders, a smaller number than that indicated a month ago, face contests at the primary election in September.

The design for a statue of Christopher Columbus by an artist of the New York City WPA Art Project, which Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, said did not look "like anything we have read about Columbus," has been approved by the Art Commission of the City of New York, it became known yesterday.

The working man stepped into a new and glamorous role yesterday morning, to inspire a fresh fashion theme for college girls' campus togs. B. Altman selected the work-a-day get-ups of the men who are making the wheels of the defense machinery whirl as the inspiration for a refreshing group of sports fashions.

ODD things happen in Brooklyn, and not only at Ebbets Field. It long has been the notion in this corner that there must be something in the Brooklyn climate that makes men -- to borrow a phrase from Robert Herrick -- "nobly wild, not mad." The Artful Dodgers and their ardent rooters could be offered as Exhibit A in that respect.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Aug. 7 -- Thunderbolt, the Army's first fighting falcon, the bird kingdom dive bomber that can descend at speeds up to 300 miles an hour and spot a mouse a quarter of a mile away, went into training at the pigeon lofts of Fort Monmouth today.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Leading a great array of golfing talent from the Eastern seaboard that played from early morning until sundown, Steve Berrien of Upper Montclair and his 18-year-old partner, Robert Montgomery, captured the qualifying medal with a card of 34, 32-66, six under par, in the annual John G. Anderson Memorial best-ball golf tournament on the East course of the Winged Foot Country Club today.

Officials of the city of Yonkers, N. Y., announced yesterday further details of their proposed offering of $500,000 of tax-anticipation notes. Bids will be considered on next Tuesday. The obligations will be dated Aug. 14, 1941, and will become payable on April 14, 1942.
CANBY, Minn., Aug. 7 -- Minnesota, the bread-and-butter State -- its farm production consists of wheat and dairy products-is feeling the impacts of the defense program in sharply higher farm income.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- More than 100 representatives of the silk hosiery, throwsting and rayon industries and officials of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations met today with government officials to plan first steps for rehabilitating the civilian silk industry.

BERLIN, Aug. 7 -- All information available in the German capital late tonight indicated that the German legions had begun to move with an accelerated tempo on several sectors of the huge Eastern Front and that it had become possible for them again to employ the "Blitzkrieg" tactics of a war of movement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 2 amounted to 883,065 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 14,334 cars, or 1.6 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, but 165,138 cars, or 23.0 per cent, more than for the corresponding wee.k last year and 226,512 cars, or 34.5 per cent, more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Held scoreless for five innings, the Chicago White Sox tallied in every stanza thereafter to wallop the St. Louis Browns, 11 to 1, tonight as Buck Ross set the tail-enders down with seven hits.

Garages and gasoline service station operators were looking forward last night to the week-end demand for motor fuel as a test of the 7 P.M. to 7 A.M. curfew requested by Harold L. Ickes, Federal Petroleum Coordinator. Operation of the curfew in the New York area since last Sunday, they said, had shown a trend toward smaller retail sales, but this had not been sufficiently marked to form the basis for any real conclusions.
Captain Thomas S. King, U.S.N., Mrs. King and their daughter, Miss Elizabeth King have come to the Biltmore from the United States Naval Academy, Annapolis, Md.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange continued to drift aimessly yesterday in virtually the same price range that had prevailed throughout the week, with industrials slightly higher and the sails a shade lower in a featureless market.
The HOLC sold to V. Martino the two-family house at 227 Jane Street, Weehawken, N.J., through the Marsella Realty Company and Joseph M. Henehan, brokers.

Thomas E. Dewey, national chairman of the United Service Organizations, which is providing recreation facilities in military and naval camps, announced yesterday that its first drive for funds among civilians had reached the goal of $10,765,000.

ALBANY, Aug. 7 (AP) -- An immediate increase of milk prices to producers in the New York milk shed was urged upon Federal and State officials today to keep on the land farmers who otherwise might "surrender to the attractions of industry."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Here is the roll-call vote by which the House failed today to override President Roosevelt's veto of the $320,000,000 defense highway authorization bill:

With traders inclined to wait for the government's crop report, to be released at noon today, cotton prices fluctuated narrowly yesterday in quiet trading on the New York Cotton Exchange. Opening at over-night gains of 4 to 7 points, the market drifted lower until the final hour, when a rally developed.

A one-day stoppage of 6,000 employes at the Fifty-sixth and Twenty-seventh Street shipyards of the Bethlehem Steel Company in Brooklyn was staged yesterday by Local 13 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., in protest against what the union characterized as the company's "stalling" in negotiations for an agreement.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation and bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

Production of coke pig iron in July reached a new high level at 4,770,778 net tons, compared with 4,553,165 tons in June, according to an Iron Age survey. Output on a daily basis last month showed a gain of 1.4 per cent, compared with June, or from 151,772 tons in June to 153,896 tons in July.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 7 -- The second week of the Berkshire Symphonic Festival, which began tonight at Tanglewood, is designed, in part, to honor the memory of one of the three or four towering geniuses of musical history -- Mozart.

KEARNY, N.J., Aug. 7 -- At least fifty persons in an area of three square miles were affected by chlorine fumes tonight, many seriously, after a break in a pipe through which liquid chlorine was being pumped into the plant of the Standard Napthalene Company from a tank car on a siding.
MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The section of today's Soviet Information Bureau communique replying to the German High Command's figures on Russian losses follows:
SHARON, Conn., Aug. 7 -- "If you want some old-fashioned woodchuck shooting," the letter read, "meet me some morning around 6 o'clock, and don't forget the gun."
MOSCOW, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:

Re-election of the members of the La Guardia administration on the issue of good government was urged last night by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, and Councilman Robert K. Straus at a meeting of the Affiliated Young Democrats at the Hotel Piccadilly.

Chief City Magistrate Henry H, Curran, whose public life has frequently been marked by the philosophy that the pen is mightier than the sword, has again taken his clarion quill in hand and dispatched a moderately impassioned appeal to his old friend, Representative James W. Wadsworth, in Washington, opposing Congressional consideration of the proposal to change the name of Ellis Island in New York harbor to "Liberty Isle."
For the fourth time since its inception two years ago, the giftware and furniture enterprise known as "The Waldrons" is expanding its quarters in the British Empire Building, Rockefeller Center.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 7 -- A new type long-range dive bomber, said to be 100 miles an hour faster than the German Stuka, was examined at the Brewster factory at the Newark Airport today by William S. Knudsen, director of the Office of Production Management, who is touring Eastern defense plants.

LONDON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- War Secretary H. D. R. Margesson told the House of Commons today, in a written reply to a question, that British Imperial forces left behind a total of 25,680 prisoners and dead in the evacuations of Greece and Crete.

VICHY, France, Aug. 7 -- General Maxims Weygand, proconsul in Africa, may in the future attend with greater frequency meetings of Secretaries of State usually held in Vichy on Fridays, as well as the Cabinet councils which follow normally on Saturdays.

TORONTO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Tom Draper Jr., a big, amiable St. Louis amateur who "just happened to drop into Toronto on a holiday," fired a par-smashing 67 over the Lambton course today to take the first-round lead in the Canadian open golf championship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Inflation cannot be curbed "if wages or any other cost is allowed constantly to rise" Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, told the House Banking and Currency Committee today.

Mrs. Manuela Hudson Vanderbilt has started suit for divorce in New York County against Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, 28-year-old sportsman and racing leader, it was confirmed yesterday by Mr. Vanderbilt's attorney, Sol A. Rosenblatt of 630 Fifth Avenue.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 7 -- G. H. Flinn Jr. of Pittsburgh returned a par 73 to win the medal as the annual three-day invitation golf tournament of the National Golf Links of America started today. C. J. Dunphy, last year's medalist, and Henry Picoli tied at 74.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Jersey City Giants blasted Hal White's hopes for a double celebration tonight when they belted him for a dozen hits, including two homers, and beat the Bisons, 9 to 4, in the opener of the series.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : THE TIMES'S editorial "Russia as an Ally" in effect argues against direct help to Russia, although admitting that "the longer Russia fights, the better it will be for us." Three arguments are given.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 6:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The first shipment of gasoline to Russia left Los Angeles a week ago. It was sent in steel drums on a Russian ship, "and the first Russian tanker will be over here to load before the end of the month," Oil Coordinator Harold L. Ickes announced today.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 7 -- The ever-battling Cardinals regained the National League lead from the Dodgers today by breaking loose in the eleventh inning to beat the Reds and Bucky Walters, 3 to 2.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 7 -- Shortages, totaling $4,834 in Fort Dix oPst Exchange funds are being investigated, it was disclosed today with the announcement that two boards of officers had been appointed by Colonel Cassius M. Dowell, post commander, to study circumstances in connection with the shortages.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- "Good news for America and bad news for America's enemies" is contained in reports of government agencies which "prove conclusively that the national defense program, through the skillful toil and loyal support of American workers, is now proceeding full blast, ahead of schedule and beyond all expectations," William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said in a nation-wide broadcast tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The intelligence unit of the Bureau of Internal Revenue was congratulated today by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau for the successful prosecution of the income tax case against Enoch L. (Nucky) Johnson, Atlantic County (N.J.) political leader, who was convicted last Friday in Camden on charges of evading payments for 1936 and 1937.
ROME, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- Italy tonight mourned the "glorious death" of Captain Bruno Mussolini. The 23-year-old aviator was a reckless believer in his father's credo, "Live dangerously."

Wider participation for small business in the defense program was promised to the American Business Congress, organization representing intermediate-size and smaller manufacturers and business concerns, in a letter signed jointly by William S. Knudsen, Director General of the Office of Production Management, and Sidney Hillman, Associate Director General.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 7 (AP) -- S. Lewis Huteheson, 33-year-old star from New York City and Greenwich, Conn., won the 20-gauge championship, but today's honors in the seventh annual national skeet tournament belong to Mrs. M. L. Smythe, diminutive Aurora, Ohio, sharpshooter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Eighty-six proposed amendments to the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 were presented today to Congress by the Securities and Exchange Commission and a committee representing the financial industry.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Lord Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, who served as Viceroy of India from 1926 to 1931, said today on hearing of Tagore's death:

Local importers, who have received documents calling for payments for goods which are piled up on the wharves in Kobe, Yokohama and Tokyo, complained here yesterday that they were confronted with "liquid liabilities" and "frozen assets."

German forces of occupation in the Netherlands are finding the Dutch a determined people. It is no great discovery. The Spaniards in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries found them so, and the Dutch have not changed. A new conquest of their lands has left them unconquered in spirit.
