ROME, Aug. 1 (AP) -- An Italian High Command communique today said:

Both good and bad news will greet week-end shoppers as they make their rounds. Meat prices, which have shown many disheartening increases in recent weeks, have in many cases fallen back to more comfortable levels. But the Consumer's Service Bureau of the Department of Markets counteracts this cheerful information with a report that butter and eggs have risen even farther into the high brackets.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Revenue receipts and expenditures close of business Aug. 5:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 7 -- Ernst Lubitsch closed a deal today with Alexander Korda for production of "To Be Or Not To Be," withdrawing from an association with Walter Wanger on the picture because Wanger's schedule will not permit its filming in September.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- As the Senate Finance Committee prepared to begin hearings tomorrow on the $3,206,200,000 defense tax bill, Senator George, committee chairman, said today that the committee's plan to seek to make up prospective revenue lost by House rejection of the mandatory joint return provision might lead to farreaching revision of the tax proposal.
BERLIN, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today from "the Fuehrer's Headquarters":

LONDON, Aug. 7 (AP) Note circulation continued its record-break-ing climb, reaching u667,024,000 for the week ended Aug. 6, the statement of the Bank of England disclosed today. Circulation figures have edged upward steadily since late January with the exception of two weeks marked by a decline and one unchanged week.

Russia's Forgotten Men Berlin says that Stalin is throwing into the battle line not only men without military training but actually prisoners from the concentration camps. Berlin no doubt takes special pleasure in the second item.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 -- William E. Brown Jr., who was attorney for the trustee in the bankruptcy litigation of William Fox, testified in Federal District Court today that the creditors of the former motion picture producer were discriminated against by Judge J. Warren Davis and the Third Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

Penniless and hungry French war veterans recently released from German prison camps are roaming the streets of Lyon, according to cables received by the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, 4 West Fiftyeighth Street.

Trading in steer hinds and ribs and some of the smaller cuts of fresh pork yesterday was good. Demand for pork loins and cow beef was very slow, veal only fair. Lamb fair. Cow beef sold weak to lower and other classes steady.

Excess Reserves Dropping $185,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, excess reserves of member banks of Federal Reserve System in the aggregate touched $1,925,000,000, the lowest level since February, 1939. The latest decline reflected first-of-the-month interest and dividend transfers, the substantial net increase in purchases of new Treasury bills and, to some extent, payments for the government's new tax-anticipation notes.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., Aug. 7 -- In a race today around this island, certainly the first one of yachts in a fleet, R. Graham Bigelow's Tiny Teal, Gilbert Warner's Wasaka and J. K. Starkweather's Freya were winners.

Seven new names have been added to the tenant roster of the twelve-story and penthouse apartment house nearing completion at 44 East Sixty-seventh Street, according to Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., agents. The lessees are W. Darley Keith of the Aluminum Company of America, Emil Ludicks, Mrs. William L. MacGready, Mrs. A. E. Hevenor, Mrs. Bertram Q. Platt, Mrs. Evelyn Brenner, and, through Pease Elliman, Inc., Harry J. Louis.

Hitler is the prisoner of his conquests. As the gaoler of Europe, he has proved that the Continent is not self-sufficient, and he is therefore driven on and on by the remorseless necessity of acquiring more territory in order to sustain what he has. He is likewise the victim of his own military success.

TO THE EDITOR of THE NEW YORK TIMES: Regarding George P. LeBrun's letter published in THE TIMES of Aug. 1, let me emphasize that the term "jaywalker" is not in any sense to be construed as an indictment of all pedestrians but rather a term commonly accepted and understood as referring only to those pedestrians who refuse to watch for lights or cross at points other than intersections.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 7 -- Germany has threatened to break off diplomatic relations with the Iranian Government over the expulsion of German nationals from Iran, it was learned today from high diploatic sources here. The German warning was contained in a note presented by the German Minister, Herr von Ettel, to the Iranian Premier.

Hosiery manufacturers tried with little or no success yesterday to acquire stocks of combed cotton yarns, but they found that the meager supply of British yarns which were in this country had been quickly bought up and that domestic spinners were too busy making yarns for use in Army uniform cloths to turn out additional hosiery yarns.
LONDON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

TOKYO, Aug. 7 -- Disclaiming any aggressive intentions against Thailand or any desire for a "joint defense" agreement with Thailand similar to that concluded with French Indo-China, Japanese official quarters declared today that yesterday's statements of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Secretary of State Cordell Hull regarding a dangerous situation in East Asia "were based on no warrantable facts."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- After the OPM conference on shifting the silk hosiery industry to rayon and other fibers it was said no answers were obtained to many of the puzzling technical questions involved.

L.H. Korndorff, president of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, made public late last night a statement reviewing chronologically the events leading up to the strike at its shipyard in Kearny, N.J., which, he contended, "demonstrates beyond doubt that the sole issue involved is the demand of the union for a closed shop."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Safe blows by Jake Early and Roger Cramer, coupled with three walks and an outfield fly, brought the Senators two runs in the ninth inning for a 5-4 victory today over the Athletics.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Contracts amounting to $23,014,617 were awarded by the War Department today. Concerns in the New York area received the following hitherto unpublished contracts:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Chief points of agreement and disagreement between the reports on revision of the securities laws submitted today to Congress by the Securities and Exchange Commission and a committee from the financial industry follow.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 7 -- The Chinese High Command is making sure that any Japanese attack from Indo-China into Yunnan will be met by one of the strongest armies that China has ever assembled. New plans for Chinese military operations in the border region have just been completed at Kunming during conferences there between General Ho Ying-ching, the Chief of Staff, and General Lung Yun, Governor of Yunnan.

In sustaining yesterday the President's veto of the $320,000,000 defense highway bill the House of Representatives did a good day's work. By contrast the Senate's record in overriding the veto is a sorry one. By its action the Senate showed itself willing to subordinate national interests to selfish politics.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Pirates climbed another step toward a contending position in the National League today when Al Lopez hit a homer in the ninth inning to beat the Cubs, 4 to 3, for Pittsburgh's sixth straight victory and its eighteenth in twenty-one games.

BERLIN, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- Reports circulating among the German people that Nazi gains in Russia have been achieved only at a heavy price in killed and wounded today brought insistent assertions from the High Command and military spokesmen that the German casualties had been "moderate."

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 7 -- After a comparatively quiet period there is again some activity on the Finnish front. It must be anticipated, however, that for some time no military reports of importance will be obtainable here.

In her kitchen in up-State New York, a country wife artfully combines the colorful bounty of good things from her garden and captures their essence in the sturdy, glass-lidded jars of home-made relish, which are quickly carried into town to be sold.

BERLIN, Aug. 8 -- On at least two of the three principal sectors of the extensive Eastern Front the German legions were reported today to be in steady advance and the plight of the Russian forces increasingly desperate.
Death Reported RETIRED FIREMAN Retired Fireman Thomas Brady, formerly a member of Engine Co. 265, residing at 163-13 Baisley Blvd., Jamaica, L.I., died, Aug. 7.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Prices of wheat fluctuated in an erratic manner within a range of about 1 1/2 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade today. There was backing and filling on commission house and professional operations, with some liquidation apparent in the September.
CULVER, Ind., Aug. 8 (AP) -- For the second straight year Bobby Falkenburg of Hollywood, Calif., shares the national boys' tennis doubles championship.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 8 -- Dr. Carl R. Woodward, secretary of Rutgers University for the last five years, has resigned to accept the presidency of Rhode Island State College, Kingston, R.I., effective Nov. 1. The announcement was made today by Dr. Robert C, Clothier, president of Rutgers.

The Rev. Paul Floyd Jones, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Eustis, Fla., has accepted a call to the pastorate of the North Presbyterian Church, 525 West 155th Street. Mr. Jones, who Is 37 years old, and the Rev. Dr. Merle H. Anderson, pastor of the North Church for the last eight years, have arranged an exchange of pastorates.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 8 -- Two of the favored teams were eliminated from the field in the contract bridge masters' team-of-four tournament today. The other seeded teams, including the defending champions, the Four Aces of New York, and another New York team headed by Waldemar von Zedtwitz, survived and will play in the semi-final round tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Plans for using standard broadcasting stations in times of military emergency to issue air-raid warnings, communiques, announcements and other messages to the people of the country were made public today by the Defense Communications Board through James L. Fly, chairman of the DCB and of the Federal Communications Commission.

FORT DIX, Aug. 8 -- A new procedure for the induction of selectees here instead of at their respective State induction stations will be started at the Fort Dix Recruit Reception Center Tuesday, Aug. 26, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 7:
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Mr. and Mrs. William Ziegler Jr. had as luncheon guests before the races today Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Tweedy and Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Garden.

Chief Magistrate Curran complains to Representative Wadsworth that somebody in the House wants to change the name of our Ellis Island to Liberty Isle. Docile as signers to petitions, two hundred Representatives have approved the proposed renaming. To Washington Ellis/Island may be only an immigration district; to New Yorkers it is still one of their old insular possessions gobbled up by the Government.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 8 -- The captains of five Italian vessels that were damaged by their crews as they lay in the Port of Newark several months ago and Captain Carlo Bonati of the Royal Italian Navy and forty-one of the ships' crew members were sentenced to prison today by Federal Judge William F. Smith.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 8 -- Navy Minister W.M. Hughes, commenting on the Pacific situation, said yesterday that whether there was peace or war depended on Japan. Australia had done nothing to disturb the peace but was just sitting up and taking notice, he declared.

Of late years we have heard much of "brain waves," more grandly called electroencephalograms by the neurologists. Hans Berger of Jena, the man who discovered and applied them, is dead. The belated news of his passing deserves some comment because of the high importance of his work.

BERLIN, Aug. 8 -- The German High Command said tonight the the jaws of a mammoth German trap had destroyed twenty-five divisions of the Russian armies in the Ukraine and inflicted losses totaling more than 200,000 men on the Red Army forces of Marshal Semyon Budenny.

The Playwrights Company has decided to postpone the return engagement of "There Shall Be No Night," by Robert E. Sherwood, from Oct. 20 until February of next year. It is now planned to open the Pulitzer Prize play on Oct. 6 in Wilmington, Del., and tour it southward through the Carolinas.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Aug. 9--The Russian Army, according to the midnight Moscow bulletin, continued through Thursday night and most of yesterday to fight stubborn actions on almost the entire length of the eastern front.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Following is a table illustrating the Treasury's plan for the "simplified" computation of taxes by persons of small incomes. It shows the amounts they would pay under it as a result of the lower exemptions recommended today by Secretary Morgenthau, with the basic rates those provided in the tax bill recently passed by the House.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Paul Erickson, 23-year-old right-hander of the Cubs, stopped the Pirates with one hit today to score his first major league pitching victory, 1 to 0, and end a Pirate winning streak at six games.

FREDERIC PROKOSCH'S "The Skies of Europe"* is a novel of Paris and Spain and Bavaria and Austria and Italy in the warhaunted years between the Spring of 1936 and the early, catastrophic Autumn of 1939, drenched in melancholy and fine writing, sinewy and sharp in its notations on man's fate, Intricately orchestrated, yet, on the whole, curiously inert, boneless.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Miss Barbara Allan Bement, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Dennison Bement of Deerfield, Mass., was married here today to David Mansfield Frederick, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. George Frederick of New York and Greenlawn, L.I.

Efforts of out-of-town interest to lure the coming Joe Louis-Loi Nova world heavyweight championship boxing bout away from New York have met with failure Finis was definitely written to them yesterday when Promote Mike Jacobs announced that Louis is to defend his crown against the Californian in the Yankee Stadium on Friday night, Sept. 19.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The House Rivers and Harbors Committee voted today to include the controversial St. Lawrence seaway and Florida ship canal project in an omnibus rivers and harbors bill, which some members estimated might require appropriations totaling a billion dollars.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Smaller receipts today brought more dependable action to the livestock market as steady prices prevailed in the cattle and sheep markets and steady to 10 cents higher values generally in the hog section.

New bond financing consummated this week was in the smallest volume in almost six months, emphasizing the seasonal apathy in the market for new flotations of fixed-interest bearing obligations. New offerings this week amounted to $8,306,100, compared with $21,417,000 last week.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 8 -- Ethel Waters, Negro blues singer and star of last season's Broadway musical, "Cabin in the Sky," will make her screen debut in RKO'S "Syncopation" if current negotiations are concluded, it was learned today from William Dieterle, who will produce and direct the picture.
Uptown apartment houses figured in several of the Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 8 -- Tommy Platt of the Cold Spring Harbor Yacht Club prevailed in the fifth and deciding race for the junior yachting championship of Long Island Sound off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today, beating Peter Duble of Indian Harbor across the line by more than three minutes.
LONDON, Aug. 8 (U.P.)--Current British-American discussions are expected to produce the sternest warning that a group of great powers ever has addressed to Japan, it was understood tonight.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: John Kieran's recent column on Ty Cobb's all-time baseball selections emphasized to me the disparity in men's minds as to nominations for all-star teams and places in the Baseball Hall of Fame.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- An emergency program for mixing available silk and rayon supplies with other yarns in the manufacture of hosiery and thereby preventing the sudden dislocation of more than 100,000 hosiery workers was set up today by defense agencies.

The International Utilities Corporation, of which Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey was elected chairman last Wednesday, filed yesterday in Supreme Court a suit to prevent holding of an extraordinary stockholders' meeting called at the request of an independent stockholders' committee with the avowed object of ousting the present board of directors.

NEW ROCHELLE. N.Y,. Aug. 8 -- A $110,000 WPA grant for improvements at Fort Slocum, including renovation of buildings, landscaping of grounds and reconstruction of roads and seawalls, was reported today by the post command.

Weakness in the final hour on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday sent stocks to the lowest levels of the session and of the month. Oils and aircrafts were especially weak. Volume in the final hour was about 200,000 shares and raised the day's total to an unimpressive 553,680 shares, against 497,120 on Thursday.

Joseph A. Levenson, who has been a Republican Assembly district leader for thirty-nine consecutive years and first held such a position in 1894, will not be a candidate for re-election as leader of the First Manhattan Assembly District East, it became known yesterday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 8 (AP) -- General Henri Fernand Dentz and other senior Vichy officers in Syria and Lebanon have been interned by the British occupying authorties.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 8 -- Mrs. John T. Dorrance entertained with a dinner tonight at Kenarden Lodge. Among her guests were Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Montague, General and Mrs. J. William Kilbreth, Mr. and Mrs. E. Victor Loew, Mr. and Mrs. William I. Schaffer, Prince and Princess Burhaneddin, Mr. and Mrs. Dwight C. Harris, Mr. and Mrs. Tristram Colket, Mr. and Mrs. George Strawbridge, Mrs. Reginald de Koven and Mrs. Shepard Fabbri.

With production of steel in July the fourth largest on record, at 6,821,682 net tons, according to the monthly report of the American Iron and Steel Institute, output for the first seven months was at the record total of 47,730,225 net tons, or 71 1/4% per cent of production in the whole of 1940, which was the largest full year on record.

A Government spokesman in Tokyo protests that his country is being encircled and that Japan's peaceful intentions in Thailand have been misunderstood. This has a plaintive and familiar ring; it sounds like an echo from Berlin. Adolf Hitler once made similar complaints about French and British "misinterpretation" of his warlike moves in Central Europe.

All banks in this city and on Long Island are being circularized by the New York State Bankers Association, recommending that they urge their customers who may save metal working facilities, to attend the two "Defense Production Clinics" to be held here next week.

The French Line freighter lle de Re, which left her Staten Island pier on April 17 with a cargo of Red Cross foodstuff for unoccupied France, returned to New York for the first time yesterday, carrying a full load of Algerian cork.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Utility and Industrial Corporation has been called in Wilmington, Del., on Sept. 18 to vote on merger of the company into the General Finance Corporation. Utility and Industrial, an investment trust, had total assets of $1,733,675 on June 30, including $367,730 cash and $1,355,175 investments at market.
BUFFALO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Rallying briskly for three runs on their eighth turn at the plate, the Buffalo Bisons squared the series with the Jersey City Giants tonight by taking a 6-to-4 decision.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Aug. 8 -- Two ensigns court-martialed at the naval air station here May 20 after their low-flying plane had decapitated a woman working in an Alabama turnip field were dismissed from the service and sent to prison today. They were convicted of involuntary manslaughter.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 8 (U.P.) -- Japan has ordered all nationals not in military service to evacuate a wide area along the Siberian border in Western Manchukuo, reliable sources said today. Observers reported that Russian-Japanese relations might be nearer the breaking point than Japanese relations with Thailand.

SO the big fight is going to be held in the Yankee Stadium on the night of Sept. 19. The J. Louis-L. Nova debate for the heavyweight championship of the world. This could -- and probably will -- stir up plenty of excitement. The contenders have been catching up on the Shuffler. Some night one of them is going to come out ahead. It might be the night of Sept. 19. Or it might not.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Information reaching Berne from foreign military quarters in Berlin indicated tonight that the German High Command was forced to revamp its Russian campaign to a long-term basis about July 15, when it became evident that Blitzkrieg plans would fail.

A membership meeting of 7,000 striking electrical workers, to be held at Manhattan Center, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, at 2 P.M. today, is expected to act on a proposal for the strikers to return to work, possibly Monday.

The curfew on retail sales of gasoline between 7 P.M. and 7 A.M. has resulted in a substantial decline of business in the New York area since last Sunday and promises to result in still greater declines in the next few weeks, according to reports submitted yesterday at a meeting of the Gas Station Council of Metropolitan New York, held in the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- The second and most important of Chicago's three Fall market weeks closed today with the Association of Commerce revising its estimate of orders booked thus far to $30,000,000, as compared with earlier forecasts of from $22,000,000 to $25,000,000.

MOSCOW. Aug. 8 -- The badly dented German Army continued to maintain the pressure of a four-pronged drive against the stanch Soviet defenses today, but so far as can be learned here, despite unceasing Nazi attacks, there has been no striking change in the positions assumed earlier this week.
Berlin claimed new victories in Russia yesterday as Moscow ridiculed previous German "achievements."

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 8 -- In a special communique issued by the Moscow radio late tonight the Russian High Command announced that its bombers made an extensive armed reconnaissance over Western Germany and visited Berlin last night, dropping "quantities of incendiary bombs with a few explosives."

The recommendation yesterday of Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. for a "substantial lowering" of personal income-tax exemptions is entirely consistent with, the broad principles which he himself laid down when the defense tax bill was first considered by the House Ways and Means Committee, although it is at variance with recommendations then made by the Treasury's own tax experts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Maintenance and repair parts will be made available immediately to more than 150,000 producers, manufacturers, and agencies in nine industrial classifications under a new plan made public today by the Office of Production Management.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: May we have space to answer the letter by E.R. Tolfree in last Saturday's TIMES adversely criticising the exhibition and motherhood of our little mongrel mascot "Mrs. Jiggs"?

The Era of Credit Control It is remarked in banking circles and certainly not without reason, that this country is entering a period of stricter credit control. Taxation and fiscal policy are keystones of such control, and the gradually tightening system of priorities in defense production may be described as selective control of the credit situation.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Little Miss Joanne Barr, 19-year-old daughter of the Rye Club pro, Duncan Barr, and a girl skater of note, today managed to keep the record straight in the twelfth annual New York State women's golf championship at the Siwanoy Country Club.
Store rentals led the commercial leasing reported yesterday with several women's wear establishments and restaurants taking new quarters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The probability that President Roosevelt will be asked to commandeer the strike-bound Kearny, N.J., yard of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Corporation increased today as Ralph Bard, Acting Secretary of the Navy, again asked the company to accept the recommendation of the National Mediation Board that it grant a "maintenance of membership" clause to the C.I.O.'s Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers.

There was little or no change in yesterday's wholesale dressed-meat market. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to strong. Cow beef was weak and dull, veal hindsaddles ind lamb were steady. Pork was uneven, Fresh hams stronger, other pork cuts steady. Kosher beef opened higher, veal was about steady, lamb was strong.

Two new Columbia melodramas will open in Broadway theatres this morning. The new entrant at the Rialto will be "Ellery Queen and the Perfect Crime"; the third in the series based on the Ellery Queen detective novels. Ralph Bellamy in the title role, Margaret Lindsay, Charles Grapewin and James Burke again are featured in the principal roles...

ROCHESTER, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Rochester's Red Wings handed the league-leading Newark Bears their first double-header loss of the season tonight, Hy Vandenberg stopping the Bruins on four hits in the first game, 8-0, and Hank Gornicki eking out a 3-2 nightcap verdict.

On the margins of the Russian campaign, more than in the earlier phases of this interlocking war, movements are in process which will affect the outcome of the struggle as much as the actual engagements in the field. One thinks of the Volga on a faraway August day and how its slow brown current merged into the level ground on either side.

Forty-three employes of The Daily News, some of them on the newspaper for fifteen years, face dismissal Aug. 19 as the result of a letter to the management from Nat Einhorn, executive secretary of the Newspaper Guild of New York, demanding their discharge because they had become delinquent members of The News unit through, failure to pay assessments and dues, it was revealed yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the last week of July the House of Representatives passed a bill appropriating $35,000,000 to build in Arlington County, Va., one of the largest office buildings in the world to house approximately 30,000 employes of the War Department. It was stated that $4,000,000 rent now paid in private buildings would be saved.

CAMP CROFT, S.C., Aug. 8 -- With 8,000 selectees graduated from this infantry replacement training center during the last month, the second period of instruction for the Seventh Training Group, comprising nine battalions which specialize in rifle-infantry instruction, is regaining its strength with shipments of troops, mainly from the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 8 -- The Japanese Army spokesman declared today that he had heard Moscow's denial of border clashes between Soviet and Japanese forces along the Manchukuoan border, yet noted that the Soviet denial had not specified dates.

Fall advertising campaigns in the men's wear field will get under way earlier than usual as a result of the current shortage of Summer goods, retail store executives reported yesterday. Next week a few stores will start to offer regular Fall lines three to four weeks earlier than usual and some copy to promote the introduction of these goods will appear.

Rule of Thumb More than any other sacrifice in their rationed diet the British are said to miss sorely their cheese. It has seriously affected the British workingman's traditional luncheon of cheese and beer, and a very good combination it is, not only for the midday meal but even better out of the icebox approximately one hour before midnight.

The city of Topeka, Kan., will enter the market next Friday with a total of $606,669 new securities. The financing will consist of $490,000 of auditorium and public works bonds, for which bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 5 per cent, and $116,669 of paving and sewer bonds bearing a fixed interest rate of 1 per cent.

SHELTER ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 8 -The long course of thirty-one and one-half miles from Block Island here proved too much in light air today for most of the racers on the final run of the American Yacht Club's cruise. Only eight of the craft in the cruising division could finish before the time limit expired tonight.
LONDON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique today:

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Headed by the defending champion, 19-year-old Dick Shaughnessy of Dedham, Mass., ten Shooters broke 100 targets in a row today to pace a field of 205 through the first section of the 250-clay, three-day test for the national all-gauge skeet championShip.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The Wisconsin Power and Light Company asked today authority of the Interstate Commerce Commission to issue and sell $30,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds, Series A, due on Aug. 1, 1971, and $3,000,000 of 2 1/4, 2 3/4 and 3 per cent unsecured notes due serially on Feb. 1, 1942, to Aug. 1, 1951.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 8 -- As a climax to four days of sweeping air attacks on cities in Hunan, Kwangsi, Kiangsi, Shensi and Kansu Provinces, Japanese planes subjected Chungking to a short but intensive bombing today.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 8 (AP) -- R.A.F. Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- How "freezing" of foreign funds fits into the national defense set-up owing to the fact that it is simultaneously a system of exchange and trade control is explained in the current issue of Foreign Commerce Weekly, the organ of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

Frank Hendrick, 67-year-old attorney, Union League Club member and one-time aspirant for the Republican nomination for United States Senator, who in recent years was involved in income tax difficulties with the Federal Government, has been missing from his Queens home since July 11, the Missing Persons Bureau at Police Headquarters disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The War Department today announced that it had awarded contracts amounting to $14,192,709. Contracts awarded to concerns in the New York area follow:

VICHY, France, Aug. 8 -- Contrary to custom, there was no meeting of Secretaries of State here this evening. Doubtless this was because Vice Premier Francois Darlan, who normally presides over such meetings, returned from Paris after 6 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Under questioning by Senator Barkley at the Senate hearing today, Secretary Morgenthau said that the Treasury's recommendation for joint tax returns was not in conflict with the President's request for modification of the joint return requirement originally approved by the House Ways and Means Committee but rejected by the House.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The White Sox trounced the Browns, 16 to 2, today as Bill Dietrich tossed a neat four-hit performance. Taft Wright, who rapped out his fifth and sixth homers of the season, and George Dickey accounted for nine runs between them.

Top-seeded Jim McDaniel of Xavier University, New Orleans, paced the field in the men's singles division of the New York Tennis Association State open tournament into the semi-final round yesterday by beating Donald Ellis of Brooklyn, 6-1, 6-3, at the Cosmopolitan T.C. The other semifinal berths were grained by Richaid Cohen, John Chandler and Joseph King.

TIMBER POINT, L.I., Aug. 8 -- J.H. and E.S. White of the Western Long Island Sound Star fleet, although recalled for beating the gun, finished first today in a fleet of twenty-one competing for the Commodore George A. Corry Trophy.

Personal sacrifices In the present world crisis will be urged by clergymen in sermons tomorrow in the churches of the New York area. Especially will it be suggested that motorists cut down on pleasure trips to save gasoline for national defense. Because tomorrow will be the last Sunday before the close of the Summer sessions at Columbia and other universities farewell sermons will be preached to the students in churches near the campuses.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The conviction that Russia will answer the prayers of every Briton and defeat Germany is today slowly gathering force among the people here. Attempts to offset this with a measure of sober judgment is being made by the press, which tends to discount wishful thinking after so many disappointments.

With the kindly cooperation of Professor Casey Stengel's Braves, plus their own earnest efforts, Leo Durocher's Dodgers yesterday vaulted back into first place in the National League, moving ahead of the idle Cardinals by three percentage points. The score" was 6 -- 2.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (UP) -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared tonight that the European conflict "is no longer foreign war," and enjoined trade unionists to hew "a great battle line against enemies of our nation."

RYE, Aug. 8 -- Donald McNeill, the national champion from Oklahoma, and Frank Kovacs of Oaklahd, Calif., finalists at Southampton and Newport last year, gained the two remaining brackets in the semi-final round of the Eastern grass court tennis championship at the Westchester Country Club today and will face each other on turf for the first time this season tomorrow at 3:30 o'clock.

Not more than 1,500 concerns would be affected by proposals requiring companies with $3,000,000 in gross assets and 300 shareholders, with certain exceptions, to follow the proxy regulations and restrictions on insiders' trading as contained in the Securities Act of 1934, it was revealed yesterday in a further study of reports by the financial industry and the Securities and Exchange Commission on amendments to the securities acts.

Britain's army in the Near East is getting large quantities of oil from Iraq, Iran and the Red Sea Coast of Egypt, it was said yesterday by three United States oil men who arrived on the American South African liner City of New York from Cape Town.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I am definitely shocked to think there are people who would write such a letter as the one from E.R. Tolfree, which appeared in THE TIMES last Saturday.

BERLIN, Aug. 8 -- "Dollar imperialism," as reflected by United States political and economic policy toward Latin America, was denounced in the German press today in an authoritative discussion of "Roosevelt's stranglehold on Latin America."

NEW YORK President Justice and Mrs. Pelham St. George Bissell and their daughter, Miss Ophelia Louise Bissell, have returned to their Summer home, at Freeport, L.I., from a visit to the Rideau Lakes, Canada.
The index is baaed on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group Is given.

The appointment of a public relations officer for the four city colleges under the Board of Higher Education, with the title of assistint to the president of City College, was disclosed yesterday in an announcement by Dr. Harry N. Wright. Forty-six other appointments to teaching and administrative posts for the City College Fall semester were made.

VICHY, France, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Military observers in Vichy estimated today that the Germans had lost 1,500,000 men and the Russians 2,000,000 men on the Eastern front. The aggregate casualties thus far -- on the forty-eighth day of the war -- were described here as having already made the campaign the bloodiest in history.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin) Aug. 8 -- The market opened firm today and after a spell of profit-taking closed firm. Shippings and rubbers were the market leaders. The shippings were as much as 5 points higher and the rubbers 4. Unilever rose 5/8 to 133.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Alleging an unlawful combination to suppress competition in the manufacture, sale and distribution of milk and ice cream cans, the Federal Trade Commission has issued a complaint against the Milk and Ice Cream Can Institute, the industry's trade association, and also against a promoting and organizing group and nine manufacturing corporations which sell some 1,000,000 milk and ice cream cans a year.

Retail stores and resident buyers are becoming seriously concerned by the steady rise in men's furnishings prices, which seems to have no limit. Establishment of ceiling prices on cotton goods has failed to halt advances in shirts and manufacturers are warning buyers that the end is not yet in sight.
BERLIN, Saturday, Aug. 9 (AP) -- This communique was issued early today:

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.
A wire from Frank Tuma at Montauk reports the hooking of a blue marlin estimated at about 700 pounds, but as the fish finally broke off the weight will never be narrowed down to ounces.

ALBANY, Aug. 8 -- Hearings on a proposed revision of prices paid to farmers under the New York City milk marketing order came to a close tonight after Owen D. Young had proposed that the Federal government buy up surplus milk the way it does cotton and other farm products.

BUFFALO, Aug. 8--Anti-Communist forces at today's session of the convention of the United Automobile Workers-C.I.O. decisively defeated a committee report intended to permit Lew Michener, alleged tool of the Communists in the North American Aviation strike, to resume his post as regional director on the West Coast.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- This is a year of upsets for champions, and the John G. Anderson Memorial golf tournament, being contested on the east course of the Winged Foot Club, proved no exception today when Willie Turnesa and Udo Reinacn of Fairview, winners of the event last year, were eliminated in the second round by Thomas K. O'Brien and Edmund Overton of Femam, 3 and 2.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Secretary Morgenthau's formal statement on the new tax bill before the Senate Finance Committee today was as follows:

Brisk renting is reported in the Castle Village apartment development on Washington Heights by Nehring Bros. Inc., the agents, who submitted yesterday a list of twenty-two new lessees, including a number of professional and military men and business executives.

LONDON, Aug. 8 (U.P.)--The British Air Ministry reported today heavy Royal Air Force attacks during the night on Essen, Hamm and Dortmund, where bombers striking "in force" dropped a "great weight of the heaviest bombs."

Herschel Brickell, successor to Harry Hanaen as editor of the annual "O. Henry Memorial Award Prize Stories," has invited Mr. Hansen to serve as one of the judges in selecting this year's prize winners. Dr. Blanche Colton Williams, also a former editor of the annual, and Edith Merrielees, author of "The Story Writer," are the other judges.

Service on the thirteen bus lines in Queens operated by the Triboro Coach Corporation was badly disrupted yesterday because of a strike called at 4 A.M. by the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, now engaged in a jurisdictional dispute with the Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railway and Motor Coach Emploves of America, an A.F.L. affiliate, with which the company has a contract expiring in November, 1942.

Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in July, amounted to $31,584,854,520, a gain of 1.7 per cent over June, and of 24.3 per cent over the returns in July a year ago. The total was the heaviest for any month since March, 1937.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- If Japan imagines she finds herself dangerously encircled, she has accomplished that encirclement herself, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today at his press conference.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Ten days of grueling experience in which war conditions were simulated as closely as possible comprised the period of field training of a Harlem regiment, the 369th Anti-Aircraft Unit, at Pine Camp. This period ended Tuesday when the regiment returned to home base at Fort Ontario.

BOSTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Senators, who haven't won a game this season in Boston, never had a chance today to break that spell as the Red Sox let loose with a six-run barrage in the first inning and coasted to a 15-8 victory.

VICHY, France, Aug. 8 (AP) -- General Maxime Weygand, the Vichy regime's North African commander, arrived here by airplane today for a series of important conferences on empire defense. The trip was decided upon after an exchange of notes with the United States concerning French African outposts.

CALDWELL, N.J., Aug. 8 -- Challenging the results of a National Labor Relations Board election at the Curtiss-Wright propeller plant near Caldwell, the International Association of Machinists tonight stepped in to take control of an unauthorized work stoppage of 300 of the 1,500 employes of the plant and called a strike effective tomorrow morning.

TRENTON, Aug. 8 -- New Jersey's Secretary of Agriculture, Willard H. Allen, called upon housewives today to take up again their almost forgotten skills of canning and preserving to help save the State's bumper peach crop of nearly 2,000,000 bushels, which is now ripening.

By negotiations during the period for declinations and substitutions of candidates between Aug. 13 and 19, Samuel Seabury and other leaders of the Fusion movement hope to present a more solid front against the candidates of Tammany and the Democratic organizations of the other boroughs of New York City, it was said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Asserting that defense officials and production management had failed to plan expansion of supplies of important commodities and that this failure was a contributing cause of threatened inflation, Leon Henderson predicted today that the nation would pay "dearly" as unemployment temporarily increased by as many as 2,000,000 men in the near future due to the closing of consumers goods factories for lack of materials.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 8 -- Eight hundred men of the 122d, 261st and Twenty-first Coast Artillery and of the Seventieth Engineers made the trip to the Long-wood estate of Mr. and Mrs. Pierre S. du Pont for the Brandywiners' presentation of "The Fortune Teller" on Tuesday night, going in a fifty-truck convoy under the command of Captain Gilbert E. Chase of the 261st.

With only three of the scheduled offerings amounting to more than $1,000,000 each, new State and municipal financing on the calendar for next week by sixty municipalities will total $10,617,164. This compares with $7,774.931 new securities sold this week and with a weekly average of $36,919,521 of new issues for the year to date.

ROME, Aug. 8 -- The official Stefani Agency outdoes itself today in two violent attacks on President Roosevelt published in the Italian press. One of them, referring to a reported offer to help Thailand oppose the Japanese, ends by terming the President "the most wicked man on the five continents."
BERLIN, Aug. 8 (AP) -- A German High Command communique "from the Fuehrer's headquarters" said today:

If the theorists of the dictatorships hadn't consistently boasted that war is natural and normal and good for people it might not be fair to judge them by the kind of life that war creates in their territories. But their reasoning makes it fair. This is the life they wanted and the life they have made.

More than 175 officers of the State guard from all parts of New York State will take their first field training the week of Aug. 17 to 23 at Camp Smith, Peekskill, N.Y., it was announced yesterday at guard headquarters, 80 Center Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Modification by eighty-two stock and mutual casualty insurance companies of their underwriting rules to enable motorists to carry passengers to and from work for pay was reported today by Secretary Ickes.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Brittanic, a bay horse owned by L. O. Blake of New York, and driven by Harry Craig, won the first division of the Progressive trotting stake, feature of the Grand Ciruit meeting finale today.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8 (UP) -- Brotherly love didn't count for a thing tonight, and Kiyoshi Nakama of Hawaii replaced his brother Bunmei as champion in the distance event of the national A.A.U. swim competition.
FORT CUSTER, Mich., Aug. 8 -- It's Corporal Henry Greenberg now, in charge of a five-man antitank-gun crew.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., Aug. 8 Tests of the five-dollar gunsight which emerged from the Tennessee brush during Second Army manoeuvres six weeks ago were witnessed this week by every officer in the twenty-one artillery regiments, as well as the field artillery replacement center, at every spare minute they had.

Retailers were assured yesterday by Yolande, Inc., that shipments of hand-made lingerie and blouses of pure silk would continue through August and September, and that deliveries for the rest of the year "probably" would be made on schedule.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture forecast today this year's cotton crop at 10,817,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight in its first official estimate this season, based on conditions on Aug. 1.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Although the greater part of those who knew of the prowess of the late Smiling Mickey Welch, former pitcher of the Giants, have paid their final debt to nature, I love to think of him as the baseball idol of my youth.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Calling for an "all-out" revenue program to help pay for "all-out" defense, Secretary Morgenthau recommended today a further substantial broadening of the income-tax base and simultaneous steps to remedy defects in application of the principle of "ability to pay" up and down the revenue structure.

The course of events in recent weeks which has brought diplomatic, economic and military relationships between Russia and the United States in closer harmony has not been without interesting repercussions in the financial community.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 8--The German Military Intelligence Service has dispatched two of its leading agents from Berlin to Iran via Turkey, and the two officers are proceeding tonight from Istanbul to Teheran, it was learned from the highest diplomatic authority here this evening.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 8 -- In our time, when democracy is the dominating factor of our way of life, we must draw support from the masses of the people for our orchestras, not from any one rich person, Serge Koussevitzky, conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, declared in a brief address at Tanglewood this afternoon.
City Court Justice Thomas J. Brady has purchased the property of Charles P. McMorrow in the Town of North Salem, Westchester, for occupancy.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 8 -- The red waters that caused much apprehension and considerable inconvenience along the North Jersey coast had disappeared almost completely today and bathing along a twenty-mile stretch of the shore front was back to normal.

OTTAWA, Aug. 8 -- Canada's Army is steadily expanding. Today Colonel J.L. Ralston, Defense Minister, announced authorization to form a sixth division so that the Dominion would have three in Britain and three in training at home enlisted for overseas service.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The Cunard White Star liner Georgia has been "damaged by enemy action," it was announced today. No troops were aboard, it was added in a reply to earlier reports that the ship was carrying soldiers. Only one member of the crew was injured.

Alexander Smallens, who has the most concerts to his credit of any of the conductors busied at the Stadium this Summer, returned to the podium of that amphitheatre last night in a program culled from the German, American and French repertories.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 -- The careening course of the Yankees in the upper levels of the American League's stratosphere took some more amazing twists and turns tonight as the gyrating Bronx Bombers, amid the tumultous shouts of 29,270 gleeful Philadelphians, went tumbling down to another defeat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The House began consideration of the draft extension bill today, with prospects growing that even sharper modifications regarding retention of selectees than those adopted by the Senate might be forced into the measure before final enactment.
Even the pitiful Phillies are making it difficult for the Giants these days!

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The Cunard White Star liner Georgia has been "damaged by enemy action," it was announced today. No troops were aboard, it was added in a reply to earlier reports that the ship was carrying soldiers. Only one member of the crew was injured.

Alexander Smallens, who has the most concerts to his credit of any of the conductors busied at the Stadium this Summer, returned to the podium of that amphitheatre last night in a program culled from the German, American and French repertories.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 -- The careening course of the Yankees in the upper levels of the American League's stratosphere took some more amazing twists and turns tonight as the gyrating Bronx Bombers, amid the tumultous shouts of 29,270 gleeful Philadelphians, went tumbling down to another defeat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The House began consideration of the draft extension bill today, with prospects growing that even sharper modifications regarding retention of selectees than those adopted by the Senate might be forced into the measure before final enactment.

Irving Crump, whose "Boys' Book of Forest Rangers," "Boys' Book of the U.S. Mails," "Boys' Book of Policemen," and many others, have long been popular and useful, now gives us a book of animal stories. "Out of the Woods" contains eleven lively, readable tales of wild animals or of partially tamed animals that return to the wild for a time.

The policy of hosiery manufacturers, initiated in the raw silk crisis last week, of allotting their production to retailers on the basis of the customers' takings over a stated period, might well be extended to various other merchandise lines and provide the most effective means of preventing hoarding, both by retailers and by the public, in the view of Sidney Reisman, vice president and merchandise manager of Bloomingdale Brothers.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Amphitheatre further mixed the juvenile championship situation, by coming back with smashing victory today in the Saratoga Special, which was witnessed by 18,287 persons, largest crowd of the season.
TIRES A price ceiling on automobile tires was recently fixed. Nearly 60,000,000 automobile tires are sold in the United States every year. They are valued at more than $450,000,000.

KYLIE TENNANTS novel, "The Battlers," is a preview not only of the toughness but of the resourcefulness and the tenacity of the indocile, unbeatable breed from "down under" that "has already," to quote THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 27, "won imperishable lau- rels" in the fight against totalitarian aggression.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Britian's coal discussion reached a climax this week when the problem was made the basis of a thorough debate in the House of Commons. The debate indicated the substantial dissatisfaction of all parties in the government's handling of the coal question in recent months.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 9 -- Permission to use the Indiantown Gap, Pa., military reservation was requested of Second Army Corps headquarters, in Wilmington, Del., today by Forty-fourth Division headquarters. It is desired to use the reservation from Aug. 23 to Sept. 13 when the Twenty-eighth Division is scheduled to be training on the A.P. Hill reservation in Virginia.

THESE letters from a selective service soldier to his Ma are no manual of what every citizen should know about the Army, but for all that they are extremely illuminating. Oscar Purkey's papers convey a convincingly accurate jeep's-eye view of Army life.

In a move for closer relationships with Latin-American business men, the National Association of Retail Grocers is having its complete "grocers' study course," used in the National Grocers Institute which it sponsors, translated into Spanish for distribution to retailers in the Central and South American countries.

Plans have been completed for the gala dinner and moonlight dance to be given under the auspices of the Friends of Children, Inc., to be held Thursday evening at the Westchester Bath Club, Mamaroneck. Proceeds from the event will be used to further the work being carried on in England by the beneficiary.

IN the year of a salt-water sports fisherman there are two events of considerable importance. First is that day when, after a Winter of idleness, he swings into action once more. Second is the day when the tuna return.

PRACTICALLY everything else having happened to "Uncle Tom's Cabin" since an August night in 1852 at Purdy's National Theatre, New York City, there would seem to be no valid reason why the radio, too, should not finally do something about it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The vigilante, who brought law and order to the "wild and woolly West" long, long ago, is coming back in style. The Roosevelt Administration wants every citizen to be a price policeman and will place its main reliance for enforcement of the proposed price and rent control bill, now before Congress, upon volunteer, part-time, unpaid members of local fair-price and fair-rent committees.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9 -- Department store sales averaged a 28 per cent advance, which lifted the cumulative increase to 16 per cent for the year to date. Most marked gains occurred in departments handling house furnishings, appliances and radios.

The general strike of 7,500 electrical workers aimed primarily at the Consolidated Edison Company was terminated yesterday afternoon by a unanimous vote of several thousand members of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A.F. of L., at the Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street near Eighth Avenue.

Improved fiscal policies and better tax collections are bringing a reduction in the tax burden on real estate in New Jersey, according to the results of a study by the New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce, which reports that 316 of the State's 565 municipalities, or 56 per cent, have lowered their all-purpose tax levies for this year.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Aug. 9 -- The annual festival series of dance performances sponsored by the Bennington School of the Arts was opened here tonight in the theatre of Bennington College with the first presentation of a new work by Doris Humphrey entitled "Decade."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 9 -- Readjustment of coffee quotas for export is expected in trade circles here and it is felt that such a move would be of particular benefit to American coffee exporters.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will conduct an all-day Summer conference of the Central Good Neighbor Committee next Saturday on the Roosevelt estate at Hyde Park, it was announced yesterday by Dr. John L. Elliott, Senior Leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture and chairman of the Good Neighbor Committee.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Aug 8:

Construction of a $136,000 addition to the Chemistry Building of City College on its uptown campus will begin this month, Dr. Harry N. Wright, acting president of the college, announced yesterday. The new structure will contain four stories and a basement, connecting the Chemistry and Mechanical Arts buildings and occupying a plot seventy-five feet long and thirty feet wide.

Savings, building and loan associations throughout the country made last month loans aggregating $133,640,000, the largest volume for any one-month period in the last twelve years. The figure brings to $653,156,000 the volume of financing made by these groups in the first half of this year, the United States Savings and Loan League reports.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Food Minister Lord Woolton warned the British today that they could not expect any increase in the present meat ration until the end of the war. The present ration is one shilling two pence worth a person a week.

An increase of close to $2,000,000,000 in the farmers' annual cash receipts, and a considerably greater increase in the cost of farm products to the country, would be the direct results of the farm bloc's proposed 110 per cent parity price program.

THE seventh annual exhibition of the Putnam County Art Association has opened at Memorial Hall in Carmel, N.Y., and will continue through Aug. 16. Shown along with the work of artists such as Walter and Magda Pach, Edmond Amateis, Alice Judson, Robert Nisbet and Ernest Hamlin Baker, are examples of local amateurs' best efforts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Reports that German public morale is suffering have been received in increasing volume by intelligence branches here this week, and there have been certain developments leading responsible officials to believe that renewed Nazi pressure upon the French Government in Vichy is being exerted in the hope of gaining a diplomatic victory that will tend to restore German confidence.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The apparent ease and comparative speed with which the Senate passed this week the Selective Service Extension Resolution would seem, on their face, to confirm President Roosevelt's command over matters dealing with international affairs and defense, both with Congress and the country.

TO start the saga of Don Bernard on a slightly negative note, it doesn't seem likely that the majority of voters care greatly about the career of a radio director, since they neither see nor hear him, unless they happen to be members of the family or next door neighbors.

WHEN Johnny comes marching home on leave from his camp or ship, the thoughts of his feminine relations and friends turn at once to their kitchens and to the special treats that they can prepare for him there. Service food used to be substantial and filling, but very little else, and the Johnnies of other national emergencies were hungry for almost everything.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Elmer Riddle, victor in eleven straight before he lost two games, went back into winning ways today when the Reds defeated the Cubs, 7 to 2, with a volley of twelve hits.

STATE lines in this country mean less and less in legal, economic or traveling terms. One can cross 3,000 miles of land and four centuries of history in a day. One doesn't notice State lines from the air, unless they happen to be also mountains, lakes or rivers.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 9 -- The usually well-informed correspondent of the Aftonbladet reports today from Istanbul that German deliveries to Turkey are far behind schedule, due largely to the British bombing of the German industrial regions.

The fourth annual Atlantic Coast Tuna Tournament is scheduled to get under way at the crack of dawn tomorrow morning, and with fifteen teams from salt water fishing Clubs up and down the coast entered, the Mud Hole tuna will get enough free food to carry them through the Summer.

Others talked more -- in fact, a great deal more -- but Emil Schram was the most interesting figure at the ceremonies in Washington on Thursday which saw the eighty-six proposed Securities Acts amendments presented to Congress. It was the first time that the former chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, now the president of the New York Stock Exchange, had appeared publicly in Washington "on the other side of the fence."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Rigid adherence to a forty-hour week by all processors of silk, rayon and hosiery was asked today by the Office of Production Management to help meet the threat of unemployment to many of the industry's 175,000 workers.
Paul Waner, once a Dodger and the friendly room-mate of Curt Davis, was just another Borgia to Leo Durocher's pennant chasers and the 14,239 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday.

AFTER a long period of complacency during which only minor changes were deemed necessary in Hollywood's solar system, there has come of late a good deal of genuine concern anent finding suitable replacements for those stars who are waning today.

The addition of two star backs and a talented center yesterday completed the personnel of the 1941 Eastern College All-Star football squad for the sixth annual Tribune Fresh Air Fund game with the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds on Wednesday night, Sept. 3.

While the establishment of the industry advisory committee set-up with the Office of Production Management and with the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply is still in the formative stage, business men who have had experience with it in the last month reported yesterday that the arrangement will help government and business to understand each other's side better.

Mystery Meeting? Washington last week had a mystery. So did London. The President was away from the capital, cruising on his yacht Potomac somewhere in the waters of the North Atlantic. Under Secretary of State Sumner Welles was likewise out of town, his whereabouts unrevealed.

One lesson any one can learn from the present emergency is how much like a three-dimensional picture puzzle this engineering civilization of ours is. A single missing element and we might be sunk. We learned the other day that there was a shortage of, among other things, cadmium, goatskin and neophrene.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Opposition developed in the Senate Finance Committee today against further broadening of the income tax base. As an alternative, Senator Brown of Michigan suggested a modified form of sales tax applied chiefly to luxury items.

TORONTO, Aug. 9 -- Although he had to cope with a tremendous gallery that jostled him and scrambled all over the course through his last two rounds, Sam Snead of Hot Springs, Va., won the Canadian open golf championship for the third time in four years today by shooting sub-par golf on both of his final rounds for a seventytwo-hole total of 274, six under par.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- "Invasion" is a word of magic for the British people. It acts as an "open sesame" for their reserves of courage and endurance. Last Summer -- after Dunkerque -- it had one meaning; today it is beginning to have another meaning -- it conjures up pictures of victorious Allied armies marching into Germany.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force Command issued this communique today:

Deliveries to date have been fair on the whole despite abnormal conditions prevailing in various commodity markets, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. The hosiery problem was even more acute in the wholesale market than in retail stores.

THE amazing thing about New York is that there is always something new to see. You may have lived here all your life, but you never expected to see cacti flourishing and seals having the time of their lives on Fifth Avenue.

Familiar Common Fraction It is pleasant, for a change, to see one-third of something quoted in a cheerful connection. We refer to the big "1/3" on the automobile stickers proclaiming that the driver is using one-third less gasoline.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Nervous fluctuations were in evidence in the wheat market today within a range of around 1 cent a bushel, an early break coming on scattered liquidation and local selling on a report that some bearish news was coming out of Washington.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 9 -- The fourteenth race of the Long Island Sound championship series was almost a complete washout today. Of the ninety starters in the regatta sponsored by the Port Washington Yacht Club, only a handful of small fry were able to get around the shortened courses before the 7 o'clock deadline.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Threatened with a shortage of silk for artillery powder bags, the Army has developed a cotton substitute acceptable for most purposes. The Navy also has developed a synthetic silk substitute, details of which are withheld.

BERLIN, Aug. 9--As the German invasion enters, its eighth week, German reports indicate that the tactics of a large-scale war of movement are being employed with increasing success in the southern Ukraine.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Although polls showing that anti-war sentiment is strongest in the Midwest and that the overwhelming majority of voters in that area are anxious to avoid armed conflict must appear correct to any traveler in the central part of the country, they do not tell the whole story.

Don't keep flowers in the ice-box containing fruit is the advice given by the United States Department of Agriculture as a result of extensive experiments conducted recently. The department has found that fruit such as apples, bananas, pears, etc., is a source of ethylene gas, which shortens the life of cut flowers and blooms.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: MR. ROBERT VAN GELDER'S article on Hervey Allen in the Book Review of July 6 prompts me to write about a much neglected novel by Mr. Allen. I refer to "Action at Aquila."

LONDON. WRITING a month or so ago I reported that few signs had hitherto appeared of any reducduction of bulk in book production, but anticipated that a tendency in that direction would show Itself before long.

ACCOMPLETELY realistic and inherently heartening picture of good hope for France is contained in the latest work of the French journalist Pierre de Lanux, which is also a new volume in the Voix de France collection of books now being published in New York in the French language.

Timely indeed is this authorita- tive work on the gladiolus, written by a horticulturist who has spent years of his life in the study and practical culture of "glads." The book is aimed at the amateur grower and home gardener, though there are excellent chapters on propagation and commercial culture, growing for exhibition, etc.

TOKYO, Sunday, Aug. 10 -- Somewhat more moderately the press continues to present to the Japanese people a picture of the United States and Britain trying to induce Thailand by threats and promises to join them in checking Japan's southward progress.

Michigan is the third State to adopt an urban redevelopment corporation act. It is similar to the New York and Illinois laws. The Michigan act was recently signed by the Governor and will become effective in January. In California a similar measure is before the Legislature and, according to H.U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, plans are under way for future legislation in Massachusetts, Ohio, Minnesota and Texas.

HAVANA, Aug. 9 -- The immediate closing of all German, Italian and Spanish consulates throughout Cuba and banishment from Cuba of all consular officials of these three nations was provided for in a motion introduced in the Senate this afternoon by Senators Agustin de la Cruz and Miguel Suarez Fernandez, members of the powerful Oppositionist revolutionary party.

Officials of the National Maritime Union, which absorbed last week the Scandinavian Seamen's Club, hailed the move as an important step in the union's longrange plan to form, a national seamen's union embracing all groups in the United States.

The Phillies tried to steal a ball game yesterday at the Polo Grounds, but the Giants thwarted the desperate plot. As a reward, the Terrymen romped off the field with victory in their possession to celebrate their longest winning streak since July 13-14, two straight.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 -- After a week of frantic hauling at the controls, Joe McCarthy finally got the motors of his Yankee Bombers functioning again today and the result immediately became more in keeping with what folks had come to expect.

AUGUSTA, GA. -- Tobacco Road, fictional habitat of Jeeter Lester, Sister Bessie and other characters in the Erskine Caldwell novel and play, still lazily winds its serpentine length along the ridges past Augusta, but this year its Summer siesta is being disturbed.

There has never been another war in which government press agents have worked so hard. Never before have the communiques of the warring nations been so contradictory and never before has it been so difficult to know the current results of the fighting. In other words, there is a lot of lying going on.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 9 -- The fourth raid on the Suez Canal area this week, which took place last night, killed eleven persons, wounded seven and caused slight damage, it was reported today.

A serious attempt to raise the harmonica, usually considered little more than a toy, to the status of a legitimate solo instrument capable of holding its own on a symphonic program was made by Larry Adler at last night's concert at Lewisohn Stadium.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Victory hopes held by New Yorkers competing in the John G. Anderson Memorial amateur best-ball tourney wilted completely under a scorching, vitality-sapping sun today as New Jersey and Maryland teams gained the final of the annual fixture at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- The lethal, all-court attack with which Donald McNeill crushed Frank Kovacs in the final of the Southampton and Newport tournaments last year spent its force against a much-improved and strictly serious Kovacs today in the semi-finals of the Eastern turf court tennis championships at the Westchester Country Club.

WHILE Spencer Tracy does nothing in the forthcoming "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" to disturb the biographical dead heat he is at present running with Paul Muni, he does take a long dive into previously untried cinematic waters.

NORMAN, Okla., Aug. 9 -- Under the sponsorship of Oklahoma University and the direction of Dr. Henry D. Rinsland, Professor of School Measurements at the university, the Oklahoma WPA vocabulary project has established what is considered a reliable children's vocabulary for each grade in the elementary school.

EVERY once in a while you run across a house that forever after stands out brightly in your memory. Looking back it is difficult to think of any one striking feature to explain this; the house was probably of average size, and in it there were no priceless antiques, fabulous furnishings or remarkable food.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Aug. 2 amounted to 252,535,000 barrels, according to data reported by the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the total of the preceding week, this represented a decrease of 193,000 barrels, comprising a decrease of 589,000 in stocks of domestic crude but an increase of 396,000 in stocks of foreign crude.

BUDD SCHULBERG said that after the publication of his "What Makes Sammy Run?" he had to leave Hollywood for a couple of months. "It was too embarrassing." "Sammy" is the novel in which Schulberg traced and analyzed the rise of a newspaper office boy to a mogul position in the movie studios.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Three of the nation's top notch marksmen, one from the East Coast, one from the slopes of the Pacific, and one from Texas, recorded scores of 200 today to pace a field of 305 into the final stages of the national skeet championship.

MOSCOW, Aug. 9 -- "In case of the forced retreat of Red Army units, all rolling stock must be evacuated * * * not a single pound of grain must be left to the enemy * * *. Collective farmers must drive off their cattle * * * all valuable property must be destroyed without fail.
LA GUARDIA FIELD, the world's largest airport in terms of traffic, last week began preparing for its eighth major airline tenant, American Export Airlines.

The subtitle accurately describes this book. It is not, as the authors explain, a history of Boston, but a picture book, where in words, and in forty-five delightful colored illustrations from paintings by Paul Hawthorne, we find presented in authentic, vivid, detailed fashion incidents in Massachusetts history and the manners, customs and usages of Boston men and women from the landing of the first settlers through the first quarter of the nineteenth century.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The Navy Department has issued a fifty-two-page booklet or glossary on "Nomenclature of Naval Vessels" for use in apprentice schools and for persons engaged in shipbuilding. It explains the meaning of hundreds of technical words and tells just what a ship is.
