TIME was when "I hope all your children grow up to be radio announcers" was considered quite a nifty comeback. That was fifteen years or so ago, when radio was very young. Since then, both "the wireless" and most of the unfortunately regarded offspring have grown up.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- The steady growth in tournament attendance will soon necessitate some changes in the policy which has heretofore governed national championship play. Some players who now rank as "qualified masters" will probably have that ranking taken away from them.

IN retail trade the rebound from the July slack period appeared to be sharper than usual during the week. The jump in sales, marking the end of Summer slowness, was contributed to in spectacular fashion by the rush on silk hosiery and other silk products.

THE praise of Basic English expressed in this column a week ago has already led to an increase in the use of the United States mails that may gladden the heart of the Postmaster General. The man who wrote the letter had this to say:

Residential rental conditions throughout the country have not yet reached a point which would justify investment in rental housing in the majority of urban localities. This situation is stressed in the recent semi-annual survey of realty conditions in the United States just concluded by the National Association of Real Estate Boards.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 9 -- Charles A. Lindbergh charged tonight that American defense policy was marked by hypocrisy and subterfuge.

When American women began last week to crowd around the hosiery counters of the nation's department stores and specialty shops clamoring for silk stockings they nearly halved a supply that would have lasted for five average months.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 9 -- Some 5,000 persons wagered $22,659 through the pari-mutuels today in the first legal horse race gambling in New Jersey in forty-four years, as the Freehold Trotting Association inaugurated a 13-day light harness meeting on the half mile oval.

Dr. Harry N. Wright, acting president of City College, disclosed yesterday the establishment of a new administrative policy toward members of the evening sussion faculty, whereby teachers will be appointed on the same basis as for the day school and overtime will be eliminated.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Playing a courageous game of golf against an opponent whose marvelous recovering and putting would have broken almost any one's heart except her own, Miss Virginia Guilfoil, 25-year-old Syracuse girl, today reached the zenith of her golfing career by winning the New York State women's championship.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Aug. 10 -- The Russians give absolutely no indication that the German offensive, reported officially to have been halted thirteen days ago, has been able effectively to get under way again.

THE Ninety Men of the Philadelphia Orchestra, under Eugene Ormandy, will give a post-season gala benefit concert tomorrow night at the Robin Hood Dell, with Artur Rubinstein, pianist, as soloist in an all-Tchaikovsky program.

IT is a lucky thing that John Henry Wrenn saved the letters he received from Thomas J. Wise in connection with his book purchases. They form an important link in the complicated chain of evidence in the case of the Wise forgeries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--Steel, most basic of war materials, was placed under 100 per cent priority control by the Office of Production Management today to insure that defense requirements are met "uncompromisingly ahead of non-defense needs."

Repairing Italian Ships When the government last April took over twenty-eight ships (twenty-seven Italian and one German) in our ports it was found that their main engines and vital control parts had been crippled. Whole sections had been broke out of cylinder walls and heads.

IN 1853 Commodore Matthew Perry sailed into a Japanese harbor with four United States warships. His was the mission of opening a way to Western trade. Gifts were extended to the Nipponese, and the following year a trade treaty was signed between Japan and the United States.

A series of conferences between shipowners, seamen's representatives and government authorities will start in Washington this week under the auspices of the United States Maritime Commission for the purpose of seeking a lasting solution to the irksome problem of war emergency pay for seamen.
ROME, Aug. 9 -- A run on toilet soap that the newspaper Giornale d'Italia said has equaled six months' demand in the past three days led today to warnings and protests in all newspapers.

VERSOIX, Switzerland, Aug. 9--If it has not already done so, the Vichy Government is on the eve of concluding with the Reich an offensive and defensive alliance directed against Russia, according to a well-informed foreigner at present en route to the United States after a prolonged stay in the unoccupied zone.

Although retailers have built their basic stocks of apparel on the expectation of an increase of 10 to 15 per cent over last year's rather satisfactory Fall volume, they were not sufficiently covered at opening prices to prevent some moderate advances in their retail prices this Fall, according to merchandise executives who discussed the situation last week.

TAKING a gamble on past performances, it seems safe to advise that WABC's audience is in for something unpredictable in the line of entertainment, what with the iconoclastic Orson Welles scheduled to return to the microphone Sept. 15 at 10 P.M., after a year's absence.

Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, after opening 3 to 9 points lower, yielded further in the short session yesterday and closed at net losses of 23 to 27 points. At the lows of the session the market showed declines of 25 to 29 points.

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity declined during the week ended Aug. 2 as a result of conflicting trends, among which those making for recession predominated. The index dropped to 132.1 from 133.3 for the week ended July 26.

Federal Housing Administrator Abner H. Ferguson announced yesterday that small-home construction under the FHA program, concentrated chiefly in defense industry areas, reached new high levels during July.

THIS delightful picture book, loved by generations of children in the original German and in the edition with English text by Helen Dean Fish, published by Stokes in 1930. is now available in an edition completely manufactured in this country.

SWORN IN: On the rostrum of the United States Senate last week a new member was sworn in. He was W. Lee O'Daniel, former Governor of Texas, elected last June to fill an unexpired Senatorial term. A Fort Worth flour salesman who campaigned for the Governorship with the help of a hillbilly band, Mr. O'Daniel introduced an antistrike bill as his first act on Capitol Hill.

THE late Hugh Walpole had an enormous gilft for storytelling. "I write as I breathe," he once remarked. A little this gift bas betrayed him, for easy writing sometimes led him into devious paths. One can understand how he was deeply interested in the idea of the exploration of the relationship between a blind man and his beautiful young wife.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Colonel Van Santvoord Merle-Smith, New York investment banker and Army reserve officer now on active duty, was ordered by the War Department today to service as this country's first military attache to Australia.

Germany's reasons for breaking relations with China -- by recognizing Japan's puppet regime at Nanking -- are discussed here by the former Chinese Ambassador to Berlin, who arrived in New York recently on the United States transport West Point after three years' residence in Germany.

WITH the news that Kirsten Flagstad will not return to America next season, and the accident which may delay Marjorie Lawrence's return to the casts, the question arises as to what status the Wagnerian repertory will have next Winter at the Metropolitan Opera House.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 9 -- The British are preparing to take vigorous direct action in Iran within ten days to force the expulsion of the large numbers of Germans from Iranian territory, according to information disclosed to this correspondent by high foreign military and diplomatic sources today at Ankara.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The capital gains tax has been part of our fiscal structure for about twenty years. Under low rates it provided abundant revenue. Under high rates it provided little or no revenue. At times it even caused a reduction of receipts from the income tax. Always it has been a fund-freezing device without license privileges, and has been a detriment to our economy.

Canada's solution of the problem of emergency housing in the war defense areas was described in a symposium on emergency housing recently held in a Summer session at Columbia University by Dr. Samuel H. Prince, chairman of the Nova Scotia Housing Commission.

There are two stories in this volume: "The Sailors' Rendezvous" and "The Saint-Fiacre Affair." The only connection between the two is that Inspector Maigret of the Police Judiciaire appears in each of them. The first one deals with the murder of the captain of a trawler which has just returned from a fishing trip.

The young things trooping off to college this Fall will, their fond parents hope, emerge in four years alight with learning, glistening with culture. However, just as important to the girls as their classroom work is the extra-curricular course in glamour, which they take willy-nilly; a course in which -- in some enviable, uncanny fashion -- they all seem to contrive to get A's.

FOR the greater convenience of the home movie fan, Eastman has introduced the new Kodascope Eight-33 projector. Affording finger tip control of major projection functions, the motor switch, speed control, and lamp switch are located two 200-foot reels, and splicing and lubricating outfits.

LONDON, Sunday, Aug. 10 -- Completing the eighth week of Britain's big air offensive in the West, Royal Air Force fighter and bomber squadrons made widespread raids throughout yesterday over Northern France and Northwestern Germany, blasting Kiel and Hamburg in "heavy and successful attacks" before dawn.

LONDON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Indications here tonight were that the two R.A.F.'s -- the British Royal Air Force and the Red Air Force -- were gathering strength and momentum for the most intensive and far-flung attacks of the war, the Russians to use mammoth six-motored bombers to span the the eastern battle lines.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 9 -- As the eighth annual Berkshire Symphonic Festival resumed tonight at Tanglewood with audiences still mounting to new record figures, authorities of the festival association and the Boston Symphony Orchestra -- the two organizations whose cooperation makes this evening the most important of its kind in the land -- were beginning to think ahead to next year.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies in July showed a larger gain over a year ago than in the month previous, according to a compilation by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The July gain amounted to 25.7 per cent, compared with 16.9 in June, 23.1 in May and 26.2 in April.

Battle of Russia The Ukraine is Russia's richest province. Upon its 450,000 square miles of forest, steppe and fertile black soil live 35,000,000 people, a fifth of the Soviet's population. Its grain and sugar beet farms make it the nation's breadbasket and sugar bowl.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 -- About 350 union carpenters, working on two $10,000,000 drydocks at the Philadelpnia Navy Yard, left their jobs today in protest against a reduction in overtime pay rate.

WASHINGTON. THAT man Ickes is at it again. The waspish Secretary of the Interior. who has become the personal devil of many \vho have never seen him but who have been unable to escape his words and deeds, has now -- as Petroleum Administrator -- moved to curtail our gasoline supply and has threatened to reduce the heat in our homes next Winter, if he thinks it necessary.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 9 -- Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their week-end house guests attended the annual Midsummer Ball held tonight at the Southampton Beach Club. Blue and white floodlights illuminated the ocean-front terrace and the breakers in front of the clubhouse, and blue floodlights were used in the lighting of the pool off the rear terrace and the hedges surrounding the grounds.

BERLIN, Aug. 9 -- The increase from six months to one year in the length of service and the increased number of girls called up for labor service are frankly interpreted as only a partial answer to Adolf Hitler's demand for more work for women, Berlin commentators state.

"Blitzkrieg on the American Elm" is a phrase that aptly describes the enormous damage which has been done to the elms in and about the lower Ohio River watershed. Mature trees of great stature in apparent sound health may die in three to thirty months after the symptoms first appear.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- Physicians in seven Northwest States are working against a sleeping sickness outbreak which is said to have caused at least seventy-five deaths in the last month.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Asserting that the United States faces a dangerous and perhaps fatal depression unless the groundwork for a peace production program is laid it once, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor urged today that President Roosevelt invite representatives of industry, labor and agriculture to meet with government leaders as a planning agency to devise methods for shifting from war production to peace production when peace comes.

THE English language is the largest, most complete and elastic tool for the expression of ideas that the world has ever known, but it is surprising how few of the people who use it daily can tell you the precise number of words it contains -- 414,825.

By Dec. 1, all personnel placements in the city by the New York State Employment Service will be handled on an industrial rather than a geographical basis, M. Joseph Tierney, assistant director in charge of the metropolitan area, announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD. WHAT promises to be a distinguished series of Summer productions got off to a noteworthy start on July 30 when David O. Selznick of the films presented Eugene O'Neill's "Anna Christie" at the Lobero Theatre in Santa Barbara, with Ingrid Bergman in the title role, J. Edward Bromberg as old Chris and Damian O'Flynn as the rambuctious Mat Burke.

WITH stress put on economy of the new Americar during the national defense emergency, Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., announced 1942 models last week. Presented in three body types each of passenger and commercial vehicles, the Americar retains 1941 exterior contours.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- More Republican support for the administration of price and rent controls by a five-member non-partisan board was indicated at hearings before the House Banking and Currency Committee today as it became apparent that the Administration bill would be long delayed in final enactment despite the pressure of supporters who contend that prompt action to halt rising prices is necessary to avert inflation.

MOSCOW, Aug. 9 -- This begins as the tale of a blind beggar, who sat by the roadside near the Russians' fighting front playing an old accordion and gaining scraps of bread and a few small coins from soldiers, and ends as one of the more fantastic spy stories this incredible war has produced.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Aug. 10 -- Fighting on the Eastern Front developed yesterday into the largest battles thus far in the Russo-German conflict. In the northern, central and southern sectors the Germans, taking the initiative, hurled masses of men and materiel against the stubbornly resisting Russians.

THE Summer stock company has become a distinctive feature of the American Summer scene. There is hardly a vacation district along the Eastern seaboard that hasn't some form of local theatrical enterprise in the way of Community Players, Little Red Barns and Broadways-by-the-Sea.

TRAVEL LINES: Both active and armchair travelers will read with pleasure and profit a new book on the Hawaiian Islands, "Hawaii, U.S.A.," by Bob Davis of The New York Sun and George Armitage, Secretary of the Hawaii Tourist Bureau. . . .

RECORDINGS of contemporary music may not be big money-makers, but each month there are new releases of compositions of our own time. Probably the composers would ask for more, and you could not blame them.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- One young man was killed instantly and five were injured, two critically, when an automobile in which they were homeward bound from a house party crashed into a guard rail on the Hutchinson River Parkway here early today.

The city netted $79,890 from the operations of the Foreign Trade Zone or free port in Staten Island during 1940, according to a report made public yesterday by Mayor La Guardia. The report, prepared by Dock Commissioner John McKenzie and Deputy Commissioner R.S. Allyn, placed the total value of receipts and shipments handled by the zone in 1940 at $164,425,270, representing a gain of 156 per cent over the 1939 total.

Susan Courage does not know whether she is running with the hare or hunting with the hounds. Murder has been done and she has in her possession something which she believes will show why and by whom the murder was committed, but she does not know what that something is nor what to do with it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Almost a hundred Canadian officers and non-commissioned officers are studying mechanized war technique with the Army's armored force, while sixteen Latin-American pilots will begin a refresher course in Texas Aug. 23.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Aug. 11 will be the twenty-second anniversary of the Constitution of Weimar, which on that day, in 1919, was signed and promulgated by Reichspresident Friedrich Ebert.

DID you fly into rages as a child? Sulk, quarrel, answer back, fuss about food? Or didn't you?

VICHY, France, Aug. 9 -- Essential features of France's endeavor to abolish labor strife by a corporative organization will be the limitation of unions to distinct professions and the dealing with disputes within the professions separately and strictly among those directly affected, it was learned today.

VICHY, France, Aug. 9 -- American and French conceptions of the world were pictured as completely opposed in a statement given today to the American press in Paris by Fernand de Brinon, representative of the Vichy government in occupied France.

One of the choice residential sections of Brooklyn which, despite the startling changes in recent years, has consistently retained its old-home atmosphere is the Brooklyn Hill area. It includes the region extending from Fort Greene Park to Classon Avenue.

THE Museum of Modern Art opened last week another of its small traveling exhibitions, this one entitled "Stockholm Builds" -- a series of admirable enlarged photographs of recent architectural developments. The photographs, by George E. KidderSmith, are mounted on plywood panels, which contain also diagrams and brief explanatory text.

EACH of the three tales included in this volume received honorable mention in the second Mary Roberts Rinehart mystery contest, and each well deserves that distinction. They are not short stories nor even short novels.

A ship without guns and without protecting armor, the gleaming white U.S.S. Solace, with a green band and a red cross on each side denoting her noncombatant status as a floating hospital, was commissioned by the Navy at Pier 46, Conover Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.

An adequate defense against gas attacks was outlined here, yesterday by Lieut. Col. Harold Riegelman of the Chemical Warfare Reserve during an interview in which he said that sufficient quantities of protective devices must be kept constantly on hand for surprise attacks, while careful training in their use must be given both to the public and to the Army.

PREDAPPIO, Italy, Aug. 9 (AP)--Premier Mussolini buried his son, Captain Bruno Mussolini, beside his grandparents in the family crypt at San Cassiano Cemetery today with Fascist rites in a military atmosphere.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The Navy Department announced tonight that it planned to take over Pier 92, on the Hudson River in New York City, formerly used by the Italian Line. A naval receiving station will be established there, the announcement said.

Combat aviation tactics will be employed in at least 50 per cent of the record field exercises being held by the First Army's corps and divisions beginning on Friday, it was disclosed yesterday in a new training memorandum issued by Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding general of the First Army.

Retail trade in the New York area last week ran about 30 per cent ahead of 1940, stimulated by hosiery volume, good response to fur sales and continued heavy buying of home furnishings. Sales of furniture and major appliances were reported at 40 per cent over a year ago and men's wear sales at 15 to 20 per cent ahead of last year.

Despite the steady rise in building costs, John S. Fitzpatrick, President of the Flushing Federal savings and Loan Association, predicts a continued advance during the year in the sale of small homes.

BUFFALO, Aug. 9 -- After two hours of acrimonious debate on the administration of the AllisChalmers local in Milwaukee by Harold Christoffel, the convention of the United Automobile Workers-C.I.O. decided today to make another effort to hold a democratic election among the local's 4,000 members so that they might send delegates to the session here.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 9 -- A whirlwind finish, enabled the Pegasus quartet to score its second straight victory in the Brook League of the Meadow Brook 12-goal polo tournament today. The Jersey riders defeated Bostwick Field, 9 to 7.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

EVER since his "Fire on the Andes" and "The Coming Struggle for Latin America," Mr. Beals has been the most diligent and persevering dealer in Latin-American literary wares. His stock-in-trade ranges from the political and the economic to the purely fictional.

Negotiations between John P. Morrissey and representatives of the Affiliated Young Democrats for Mr. Morrissey's withdrawal as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Borough President of Manhattan have failed, Harold R. Moscovit, State president of the Young Democrats, said last night.

MUSICAL activities of the Summer season at Chautauqua, N.Y., have reached mid-tide. Capacity audiences continue to attend the concerts of the symphony orchestra, under Albert Stoessel, given in the Chautauqua Amphitheatre seating 8,000, and the other events all draw crowds.

There is a beautiful galaxy of perennials which grow so easily and freely from seed that a dozen packets, well chosen and well grown, may readily provide plants enough to fill the largest hardy border. Now that Summer's worst heat is past it is a simple matter to prepare open, though protected, seed plots for their sowing, or else to press the cold frames into use again.

A large-scale expansion program to meet the increasing demands of the national defense program for electric power is under way throughout the $1,000,000,000 Associated Gas and Electric System, now undergoing reorganization proceedings under the direction of Willard L. Thorp and Denis J. Driscoll, trustees.

The reports last week of a meeting between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill directed attention to the joint problems of collaboration which confront the United States and Great Britain. In such a meeting the world would be the canvas and mankind the agenda.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Pushing over two runs in the ninth, the Newark Bears salvaged the final game of the Rochester series, with a 6-4 verdict today. Russ Christopher, whose triple sparked the winning three-hit rally, got credit for the decision though Allen Gettel pitched the last frame.

Included in the new defense highway bill approved by Congress is a provision authorizing Federal aid in furnishing off-street parking in cites and towns. This, points out Herbert A. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, furnishes an interesting precedent.

MOSCOW, Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- Vice Commissar of Foreign Affairs S.A. Lozovsky said tonight in commenting on Soviet air raids on Berlin that "the German people are now aware that no place in Germany is safe from bombings."
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 -- Frankie Frisch's red-hot Pirates are really taking this pennant drive business seriously.

MUSSOLINI is a baboon's brother in a few of Low's cartoons. Stalin, despite his puffy jowls, has some of the look of an old fox busting the lock on a henhouse door. Goebbels is a supercilious but enraged monkey; Goering is a wind-inflated hog; Ribbentrop a dissipated, scavenging bird.

One afternoon last week a perspiring out-of-town business man touring the financial community paused in front of 40 Wall Street, reassured himself of the sign of the Bank of the Manhattan Company over the door, and determinedly mounted the broad steps that lead to the main banking floor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes approved today plans of the city of San Francisco "for complying with the Raker Act by the establishment of a $63,000,000 publicly owned and operated system" to distribute electricity from the Hetch Hetchy power project.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Family connections in Axis countries, which have recently been made a reason for barring refugees from the United States, have become a factor in choosing new government workers and in assigning duties to existing members even of the civil service.

BUSINESS between Great Britain and Germany is going on as usual, and the short waves help to tell the story. On one hand, the Nazi-dominated stations enthusiastically report a successful muster of continental volunteers to fight the "Bolshevist menace."

OF all sports played in the city, tennis is about the most photogenic. As photographic subject matter it provides a wide range of possibilities -- from stirring action shots to good still life. Consequently, until the courts close late this Fall, it should supply one answer to the ubiquitous question asked by photographers: "Where to? What next?"

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 9 -- Howard Schenken, three-time winner of the masters' pair championship, and his partner, M.D. Maier, retained the lead they assumed at the end of the second session and led the seventy-two-pair field into the final round of the masters' contract bridge pair championship here today.

A NEW $2,000,000 municipal airport to serve defense and civil aviation may be erected on the sandy wastes off Jamaica Bay in the Idlewild district of Queens if the city authorities act on the recommendation of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, which has offered to contribute $860,000 toward the establishment of a 500-acre flying field on that site.

A State-wide campaign to persuade motorists that it is imperative to save gasoline, undertaken in the belief that if persuasion works compulsory rationing will be unnecessary, will get under way Wednesday at simultaneous meetings in thirty New York cities.
BACK ON THE JOB: A tall soft-spoken Tennessean returned last week from a "vacation" to his office in the many-columned State Department Building, which flanks the White House in Washington.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 9 -- An agreement banning strikes and lockouts for one year was reached today by negotiators for the New York Shipbuilding Company, holder of $500,000,000 defense contracts, and Local 1 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, an affiliate of the C.I.O.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Harold L. Ickes's propaganda campaign to induce motorists in the East to use one-third less gasoline threatens to become "a shooting war" at any moment.

John H. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, sounded a warning yesterday that homes for defense workers must be built at once. He declared that the government will have to take over the job with public funds if private industry does not meet the emergency.

Reuben Fine of Kew Gardens, open, champion of the United States Chess Federation, will be a strong favorite in the annual midSummer meeting of the New York State Chess Association, which will open in the James Colgate Students Union on the Colgate University campus, Hamilton, N.Y., next Saturday.

DETROIT, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Tigers regained fifth place today in the American League in their seesaw battle with the Athletics by defeating the Browns, 3 to 0, behind the six-hit pitching of Lefty Hal Newhouser. It was the third straight victory and the fifth in six starts for the Tigers.

HERE is a book written in England by an Englishman. Mr. Williams is a journalist and an intellectual. His sympathies are with British Labor. He is polite but inclined to be superior to institutions -- monarchy, aristocracy, schools, churches and the rest.

After going through what they have gone through to buy a dozen, or eighty, or even three pairs of stockings (plus one of nylon) women consider their silk hose as treasures beyond price. Already they are considering ways and means of conserving their gossamer hoard of glamour.

LISBON. A SERIOUS attempt to establish a national ballet in Portugal has just been made with the organization of the Companhia do Verde-Gaio, which opened its first season of "bailados portugueses" on July 25 at the Coliseu dos Recreios in Lisbon.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Alsab, a bargain colt Albert Sabath, Chicago attorney, purchased a year ago for $700, and Misty Isle, 3-year-old filly owned by Joseph E. Widener, Philadelphia, ran to smashing victories before 20,000 at Washington Park today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Army figures that a soldier just entering service had a chance of better than one in four of becoming at least a corporal and thereby raising both his rank and his pay.

The nightly raids of the Royal Air Force are stretching farther into the interior of Germany. They are going well beyond the Rhine and striking with increasing force; a few days ago a heavy attack was made on the German capital. The German official report belittled the results, but this was to be expected.

Weakness which marked the closing hour on Friday was carried forward into yesterday's two-hour session of the New York Stock Exchange and by the close losses ranged from fractions to 2 points. Steels, aircrafts and chemicals had the heaviest losses.

On his way to survey British coordination in the Far East, Alfred Duff Cooper, former Minister of Information for Great Britain, is expected to arrive this afternoon at La Guardia Field on one of two Clipper flying boats that left Lisbon yesterday morning.

Proper land planning for home building, explains the FHA, means the process of adapting a specific area of land to the economic, social and physical factors which determine its ultimate value for residential purposes. Such adaptation is achieved by the planning of the land, by establishing zoning and protective covenants, and by otherwise creating and maintaining the quality of a neighborhood.

Creation of a special Federal banking agency, operating under the Federal Reserve Bank or the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and empowered to take over drafts of importers covering merchandise tied up in the Far East by Japan's refusal to permit shipment to the United States, was urged here yesterday by Harry S. Radcliffe, executive secretary of the National Council of American Importers, Inc.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Uncle Whiskers, Mr. and Mrs. J.A. Hale's fine 4-year-old bay gelding, scored in both conformation and manner of going today over the handsome chestnut gelding Beau Soleil, owned by Mary Spencer Kimball of Watertown, to win the open class for light and middleweight hunters at the second session of the Sagamore horse show.

The rush of women to hosiery counters of New York department stores last week was an appreciable factor in boosting sales in other departments, according to merchandise executives, who asserted than many women made numerous purchases of goods other than hosiery.
GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 9 -- Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw has opened her Summer home, Mountain of Echoes, Hillsdale, and was a dinner party hostess tonight at Red Lion Inn, Stockbridge.

To the Art Editor: MAY we call your attention to a letter just sent to Francis Henry Taylor, director of the Metropolitan Museum, by the Artists Coordination Committee? In view of the current interest in Art Week, your readers might find it of interest.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Billy (Malolo) Smith Jr. of Hawaii, whose middle name means Flying Fish, churned through to his second National A.A.U. outdoor swimming championship tonight, defeating a field of seven in the 400 meter free-style in the fast time of 4:47.6.

The training of pilots in the future will be a function of the public schools, Dr. Roland H. Spaulding, associate professor of education at New York University and head of the School of Education Civilian Pilot Training program, declared yesterday in an interview.

SUMMER festivals continue to hold the spotlight in the dance world. At Bennington College in Vermont the annual dance series was scheduled to get under way last night with the first performance of a new work called "Decade" by Doris Humphrey.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 9 -- In the belief that graduate instruction in industrial design can be more effectively carried on at the present time by an institution which has wide connections already established with the technical side of industry, officials of the California Graduate School of Design and the California Institute of Technology have announced the consolidation of the two schools.

A thirty-night meeting opening tomorrow at the Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury under the Old Country Trotting Association's direction will mark the return of harness horse racing to Long Island after a four-week recess. Races are scheduled every night, except Sundays, through Sept. 13.

TOKYO, Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- The Japanese press supported charges of Anglo-American-Russian "encirclement" designs today with allegations that the United States was establishing naval fuel depots in Australia.

ATMORE, Ala., Aug. 9 (AP) -- Thousands of tiny silk worms are eating their skins off here in a continuous feast of mulberry leaves, an experiment which sponsors hope may make the United States independent of Japanese silk.

The American public has good reason to be ashamed of its record of traffic accidents during the first half of this year. The National Safety Council reports a toll on the streets and highways of 16,810 for the first six months. This is an increase of 2,390 deaths, or 17 per cent, as compared with the already poor record of the same period last year.

Now offered in light-hued or blond wood finishes are early English or Tudor styles of furniture, which until recently have always been reproduced in age-darkened oak. Carving in the vine and acanthus leaf motifs, usually associated with Tudor furniture, appears at its best on this lighter finish, which simulates the natural color of newly cut wood.

EVEN without a fretful glance at the calendar you can tell when Summer is fully installed on Broadway. Things are strangely quieter. By night the Times Square signs light up as gaudily as ever, and their public is on hand in considerable numbers to gape while strolling; but in the scene as a whole, old habitues detect a difference.

LONDON, Aug. 9 (Reuter) -- The ordeal through which the Poles are passing makes them feel that the days of September, 1939, were by comparison "a time of happiness and sunshine," according to a manifesto entitled "Underground Poland Speaks" that recently reached here.

BUFFALO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Southpaw Roy Henshaw pitched a brilliant one-hit game tonight as the Jersey City Giants blanked Buffalo, 2 to 0. Henshaw faced only twenty-eight Bisons as Mayo Smith's single interrupted his string of perfect pitching in the third inning.

THE American Air Mail Society will hold its twelfth annual convention at the Hotel Claridge in Atlantic City on Friday, Saturday and Sunday. An attraction will be the first-day sale of the 10-cent purple air-mail stamp at a branch convention postal station to be set up by the Postoffice Department.

The economics of building today summons the architect to a wider field of activity, according to a report of the committee on the architect and society of the American Institute of Architects which says modern conditions require him to function as a "master builder."

Fordham University will bring the year-long commemoration of its centenary to a close with a three-day celebration on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, Sept. 15, 16 and 17, when the presidents and leading alumni of more than five hundred colleges and universities throughout the world, as well as national, State, municipal and religious leaders will assist in the triduum ceremonies.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 9 (AP) -- National defense needs have caused a drastic shortage of raw material for the baseball parks, says General Manager Branch Rickey of the St. Louis Cardinals, but ha believes that the minor leagues will gain in the crisis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Ignoring Germany, Japan and Italy, but conferring with the American republics concerned, the United States Government has suspended for the duration of the present emergency the International Load Line Convention, signed at London on July 5, 1930.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Aug. 9 -- Champion Flornell Glamorous, from the Mardormere Kennels of Glen Head, L.I., and shown by Percy Roberts of Noroton, Conn., was named best in show at the first exhibition held by the Ocean City Kennel Club today, by G.V. Glebe of Bryn Athyn, Pa.

REGULATIONS prohibiting the transfer of money to many foreign countries are having a marked effect on the business of selling stamps in the United States and are hitting the pocketbooks of those American collectors who are trying to keep up with new issues which, despite the war, are constantly rolling from the presses.

UNTIL a few months ago the East Indies seemed to most Americans to be a sort of incredibly distant lotus-eater's paradise visited occasionally by tourists. Today, with Japan moving to the south, they have become a focus of world attention.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The widespread shift from French to Spanish as the choice of a foreign language by American college students calls for remonstrance. At Vassar College, which is probably typical, the loss in French in the three upper classes is over a third, while the numbers in the Spanish department have apparently approximately doubled.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were nominally steady today after a week of small net gains principally reflecting decreased receipts at outside markets, although arrivals here were slightly larger. Corry Trophy, emblematic of the International Star Class championship of the annual Race Week of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association, passed today from Edward V. WELLINGTON, New Zealand. AUSTRALIA'S Light Horse, still the spearhead of the defenses of the nation in many regions where autos find travel hard, is the hero of a film which Universal Pictures, aided, stimulated and maybe financed in part by the New South Wales State Government, has produced under the title "Forty Thousand Horsemen."

The morale of Army troops stationed at the Panama Canal is exceptionally high and military contingents there are "ready for any emergency," according to Major Gen. Sanderford Jarman, who recently left his post as commander of the Panama Coast Artillery to take over a new assignment as commander of the Camp Stewart Anti-Aircraft Center in Georgia.

As more and more companies reach peak operations, the possibility of absorbing rising material and wages costs and higher taxes is becoming less and from now on such increased expenses will have to be reflected in selling prices, where possible, management engineers pointed out yesterday.

WITH the flow of traffic through the Lincoln Tunnel steadily increasing, Port of New York Authority officials are carrying out work to complement completion of the twin tube just north of the one now in use.

The Nassau Country Club at Glen Cove is holding its fourth annual girls invitation tennis tournament under the auspices of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association, beginning tomorrow at 11 A.M. The matches will be played on the famous grass courts of the club, which are known all over the world.

ROME, Aug. 9 -- Captain Bruno Mussolini was buried in the family crypt at Predappio, near Forli, this morning amid unprecedented evidence of national mourning. To the thousands of persons who turned out in Pisa and along the railroad line to Forli were added many thousands more who flocked in from all parts of Romagna, the region of Italy from which the Mussolinis come.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: In your issue of June 1 your reviewer and I are rapped over the knuckles by Miss Agnes Hayes for imputed ignorance as to the Borgias. She refers to a note published by you relative to my forthcoming book "Forgotten Waters."

LONDON. (By Wireless). OVER many bomb-wrecked shop fronts hangs a sign saying "Business as Usual." It is a bravely impudent way of thumbing the nose at sudden death and devastation, but it is scarcely fair to the actual truth. Business in fact is being carried on under special conditions -- damage by bombs, wartime regulation of supply, limitations and rationing-which make it most unusual.

DEALERS in automobiles the country over, trying to analyze the precarious position in which they know they will find themselves in the months ahead, are concerned very deeply about price control as well as production control which they expect to come out of Washington.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Aug. 2, in which you pointed out the urgent need of allowing food and medical supplies to be sent to Greece, has been received with a feeling of gratitude by all those who are aware of the present plight of the heroic population of Greece, in all its seriousness, and who fear that the health and vitality of these people are being sapped irretrievably.

Red Bank, which rightfully calls itself "the river sports center of the East," will be host on Saturday and Sunday for America's foremost speed-boat regatta. The two-day program probably will be the largest motor-craft racing event ever held anywhere.

Fresh evidence comes continually to hand of successful scientific research between elements of the aircraft industry, between the aircraft and automobile industries, and between the Government and both industries. A case in point is the collaboration between Sperry Gyroscope Company and Consolidated Engineering Corporation of California in studies of vibration, strain and metal fatigue.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 9 -- Fifth-ranked Budge Patty of Los Angeles beat off a rally by second-seeded Vic Seixas of Philadelphia today to win the national junior tennis championship, 6 -- 3, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 0, 4 -- 6, 10 -- 8, at Culver Military Academy.

A border with more than 125 different kinds of annuals is one of the most colorful spots in the present outdoor flower display at the New York Botanical Garden, open free to the public every day during daylight hours. Horticultural varieties of sunflowers are prominent at this season in the background of the border.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 9 -- The White Sox blasted the Indians for five runs in the fourth and a pair in the tenth, including Taft Wright's homer, to give Fireman Bob Feller his eighth defeat of the season today, 7 to 5.

SMALL towns, country editors and fathers have had somewhat of a vogue of late, probably because they take our minds off more gloomy subjects. Mr. Barry has combined all three of them in what seems to be a truthful book, and which is certainly an interesting, if not precisely distinguished, product.

A FORTNIGHT ago stress was laid on the prime importance of developing a fresh, honest, independent critical approach to art -- this apropos of the joint dealers' exhibition at the Fine Arts Building, and in an effort to help strengthen the bond of true understanding that unites, that should increasingly unite, artist and public.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 9 -- Equally important with the money raised for foreign civilian relief by New Jersey College for Women during the past year was the experience of the college community in collective action, according to Dr. Margaret A. Judson, assistant Professor of History and chairman of the college's Committee on Defense and Relief.

Miss Crawford, whose "Hello the Boat," an excellent picture of life along the Ohio in 1817, has been very popular with young readers since its appearance several years ago, has written in "The Secret Brother" a story of the present day and has used a plot with a strong appeal for children.

The best-in-show award at the sixty-sixth annual all-breed show of the Westminster Kennel Club to be held in Madison Square Garden Feb. 11 and 12 will be made by Herman E. Mellenthin of Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 9 -- Is the Battle of Smolensk over? The question is still puzzling competent neutral circles here. It is admitted that it has been the greatest battle or modern times and that the cost has been appalling. But has fighting ceased?

HOLLYWOOD. WITH the settlement of the nine-week Disney strike, 312 members of the Screen Cartoon Guild have returned to the payroll, and normal work has resumed on five features and eight short subjects which Disney has in production.

DETROIT -- First of the 1942 crop of automobiles -- typifying the feats automotive engineers have been able to perform with the substitution of nondefense materials -- will make their formal public debut Aug. 16 when Hudson and Willys place their next season's models on display in dealer showrooms throughout the country.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 9 -- If the American people themselves wrote the Federal income tax bill this year they would institute many far-reaching tax reforms. The tax base would be considerably broadened, the mass of "little fellows" who are at present exempt from income taxes would have to pay something, and the rich would pay considerably less than the sums provided in the tax bill which passed the House of Representatives early this week.

NARRAGANSETT, R.I., Aug. 9 -- The annual mid-season swimming meet for children and junior members of the Dunes Club takes place tomorrow at noon at the club swimming pool. A fancy dress party for the children will be held Thursday afternoon in the club room, while for the grown-ups a Circus party is planned for the evening of Aug. 29 at the Dunes Club.

The mounting tension in the Far East will be reflected at Columbia University next Fall in a program of intensive training in the Chinese, Japanese and Russian languages to equip government and commercial personnel, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, provost of the university.

CALDWELL, N.J., Aug. 8--Production practically came to a standstill today at the Curtiss-Wright propeller plant, one of the key defense industries of the country, as a strike of members of the International Association of Machinists, A.F. of L., kept all but a skeleton force from their benches and lathes.

DETROIT -- First of the 1942 crop of automobiles -- typifying the feats automotive engineers have been able to perform with the substitution of nondefense materials -- will make their formal public debut Aug. 16 when Hudson and Willys place their next season's models on display in dealer showrooms throughout the country.

The tax base would be considerably broadened, the mass of "little fellows" who are at present exempt from income taxes would have to pay something, and the rich would pay considerably less than the sums provided in the tax bill which passed the House of Representatives early this week.

NARRAGANSETT, R.I., Aug. 9 -- The annual mid-season swimming meet for children and junior members of the Dunes Club takes place tomorrow at noon at the club swimming pool. A fancy dress party for the children will be held Thursday afternoon in the club room, while for the grown-ups a Circus party is planned for the evening of Aug. 29 at the Dunes Club.

The mounting tension in the Far East will be reflected at Columbia University next Fall in a program of intensive training in the Chinese, Japanese and Russian languages to equip government and commercial personnel, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, provost of the university.

CALDWELL, N.J., Aug. 8--Production practically came to a standstill today at the Curtiss-Wright propeller plant, one of the key defense industries of the country, as a strike of members of the International Association of Machinists, A.F. of L., kept all but a skeleton force from their benches and lathes.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices dropped from 96.5 to 96.2. After having risen steadily for the past month, the raw materials, textiles and industrial raw materials indexes experienced a sharp decline when the government ceiling on the price of silk became effective.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 10 -- Howard Schenken and M.D. Maier of New York won the masters' pair championship at contract bridge this afternoon, making a strong finish to retain the lead they had held since the end of the second session.

A jurisdictional strike that has seriously disrupted service on thirteen Queens bus routes of the Tri-Boro Coach Corporation since Friday was reported last night to have been settled with an agreement under which 350 of the company's 380 employes will return to work this morning.

After the judge advocate of the German, court-martial at Le Creusot Ijad satisfied himself that I was deliberately working against the best interests of the German Army of Occupation, the questioning switched to my interview with Marshal Henri Philippe Petain.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 10 -- Switzerland's double task in these difficult times was defined today by Federal Councilor Karl Kobelt, head of the Federal Military Department (corresponding to War Minister), as that of safeguarding its national defense and its food supply.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Aug. 10 -- The second novelty of the Bennington Festival of the Modern Dance was presented tonight in the shape of a new work by Martha Graham entitled "Punch and the Judy." Though it is a fairly short piece, running half an hour or less, and as far as content goes is not to be classed as a major work, it is in its own vein another triumph for its creator.

Attendance figures at beaches in the New York area yesterday indicated that, whatever effect on gasoline consumption the present conservation campaign might be having, motorists did not give up their usual Sunday outings.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 10 -- Further changes will take place in the personnel of the Forty-fourth Division prior to its departure for manoeuvres in North Carolina this Fall as the result of findings of boards of officers appointed this week-end to examine sergeants.

Eason Oil Company -- June quarter: Net income, $35,428, equal to 9 cents a share on 314,192 shares of common stock, contrasted with net loss of $28,095 in June quarter last year. Six months to June 30: Net income, $45,460, equal to 10 cents a common share, contrasted with net loss of $47,879 in first six months of 1940.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Royal, Air Force Command issued this communique today:
MOSCOW, Aug. 10 -- The Soviet today honored 1,207 heroes of the defense of its western frontiers. Thirty-one received the Order of Lenin and 444 the Order of the Red Banner.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The ten United Automobile Workers delegates from the Allis-Chalmers local to whom seats were denied at the Buffalo convention, last week were renominated today at what an opposition spokesman termed a "surprise meeting" attended by only a fraction of the union's membership.

Wholesale market prices continued to rise during: the past week. Manufacturers maintained their efforts to make shipments on merchandise ordered some weeks back. Production was held up in a number of lines because of slow deliveries from mills.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Total expenditures on new construction in 1941 will be about $10,200,000,100 as the result of the addition of a large volume of private residential construction to the building program associated with the defense effort, resulting in a total almost 50 per cent higher than in 1940, the Commerce Department reported today.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 10 -- Following the sharp rise of Saturday a week ago, cotton futures moved nervously to lower levels in a week crowded with important news. The market was irregular and easier all last week.

Active and imaginative boys of an earlier generation used to read about the Persian invasions of Greece, the decline and fall of Rome, the Crusades, the Hundred Years' War and the Thirty Years' War, the Spanish Armada, the Napoleonic wars, the Revolutionary War and the Civil War.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- After a survey of the Philadelphia Navy Yard with the cooperation of its officials, the United Federal Workers of America, C. I. O., reported today that construction of battleships and other naval vessels was seriously hampered by large labor turnovers in which hundreds of skilled workmen are leaving government yards for private employment at higher pay.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 10 -- A 60-yard shot by G. H. (Pete) Bostwick paved the way for a 9-to-8 Bostwick Field victory over the Delhi poloists at Bostwick Field today. The goal, registered as the result of a penalty against Ebbie Gerry, tied the score at 8 all in regular time.

The Rev. Francis F. Reh warned yesterday in his sermon at the 11 o'clock mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, where he is an assistant, that perhaps the United States was becoming too like the Pharisee who judged others instead of himself and could only "pray in a cheap self-exaltation in comparison to his neighbors."
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. William B. Trowbridge are expected to arrive at the Plaza today from Oracle, Ariz.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Newark's Bears still held the Indian sign over Syracuse's Chiefs today, defeating them in a double-header, 8 to 6 and 2 to 1, to maintain a five-game lead over second-place Montreal.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10 -- The Hawaiian Island swimming team, wrapped up its third national A. A. U. title today as two members of its all-star squad established American records.

Five new films will arrive on Broadway this week. Tomorrow Metro's remake of "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde," starring Spencer Tracy with Ingrid Bergman and Lana Turner, will open at the Astor on a continuous run, popular price policy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Most Rev. Joseph. M. Corrigan, titular Bishop of Bilta, was advised today by the Vatican that he had been reappointed, in response to the petition of the trustees of the Catholic University of America here, as rector of that institution.

BERLIN, Monday, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The German Air Force scored a direct hit on the Kremlin with a heavy bomb and showered "many thousands of incendiaries" and explosives on Moscow Saturday night in the heaviest raid of the war on the Russian capital, German sources reported early today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Democratic leaders were revealed tonight to have rallied sufficient support over the week-end so that they feel confident the House will approve at least a twelve-month extension of military service, with a reasonably good chance that it might follow the Senate's lead and make it eighteen months.

PANAMA, Aug. 5 -- As Axis intrigue and undercover activities in Latin America continue to come to light, as evidenced recently by the expulsion from Bolivia of the German Minister there,it is now possible to report that here in Panama United States authorities are well aware of powerful and well-organized Axis groups ceaselessly at work.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 -- In spite of a late and cold Spring, German agricultural authorities are still looking forward to a fair average wheat and rye crop in Central Europe, although much will depend on the weather during the gathering of the harvest, which is now in full swing in the greater part of Germany.

Alfred Duff Cooper, former British Minister of Information, arrived here yesterday on the Atlantic Clipper, en route to Singipore, where he said he would seek to coordinate political control of the Far Eastern units of the empire.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 10 -- Among those giving dinners at the Maidstone Club tonight were Mr. and Mrs. Ira Washburn, Mr. and Mrs. William Harrington, Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Hardy, Mr. and Mrs. Peter Lamont, Lawrence A. Baker Jr., Miss Martha A. Burke, Dr. and Mrs. Richard Bennett and Ivan Obolensky.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 10 -- Entertaining continued today for many out-of-town guests at estates throughout the colony. Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler gave a luncheon today at the Southampton Beach Club for Count Carlo Sforza, former Italian Minister of Foreign Affairs and Ambassador to France, and Countess Sforza, who are spending the week-end with Dr. and Mrs. Butler at Leny Cottage, their home in First Neck Lane.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 -- A spokesman for Drydock Associates, representing the contractors building two big drydocks at the Philadelphia Navy Yard, said tonight that 348 carpenters who left their jobs yesterday would return tomorrow pending arbitration of their protest against a reduced Saturday overtime rate.

"Demolish religion a thousand times and it will still lift its head in men, crying 'Life does have eternal meaning,'" the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday in preaching on "What Keeps Religion Going?" at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.
LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique this evening:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There seems to be a good deal of confused thinking about whether we should enter the war on a so-called shooting basis. Difficult as that question is, is it not after all a simple matter so far as the principles are concerned upon which the answer should be based?

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 10 -- The second week of the eighth annual Berkshire Symphonic Festival, which came to a close at Tanglewood this afternoon, topped all other similar periods of the venture's short but flowering life. Almost 30,000 persons attended the three concerts of the long weekend, exceeding last week's record of 26,000.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 10 -- The revolt in Serbia and Montene gro has reached the proportions of open warfare, according to reports from reliable foreign sources today at Ankara and Istanbul, and Serbian Chetniks now control certain villages in the interior of Central Serbia and Southern Macedonia.

KEARNY, N. J., Aug. 10 -- The 500 A. F. of L. workers who have been honoring the C. I. O. picket line at the strike-bound plant of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company will resume construction of a large wet basin and three shipways inside the plant tomorrow morning.

Charges that certain employes of the Welfare Department were being improperly paid from emergency relief tax funds were called false yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, who took official cognizance of accusations made last Wednesday at a meeting of the City Council committee investigating the Municipal Civil Service Commission and its president, Paul J. Kern.

With the tuna reported to be plentiful from the Mud Hole to Barnegat Ridge, the prospects for a successful derby are excellent, and the fifteen teams which will put out of the Belmar Yacht Basin early today to compete in the Atlantic Coast Tuna Tournament are very hopeful.

Odd Subject-Matter The Summer news brings its usual seasonal sensation from the Teachers College of Columbia University. It would be surprising, indeed, if such news failed to emanate at this time of year from Morningside Heights.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- "Small business enterprises in the United States are hanging on the ropes," Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican, of Massachusetts, said today when he announced the appointment of a Republican Small Business Study Committee consisting of sixteen Republican members of the House.
The volume of ship construction now on the ways or on order reached a new high of 945 vessels of 5,833,570 gross tons during July, according to the August Bulletin of the American Bureau of Shipping.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- Liquidation by holders of September and October lard contracts featured trading in that commodity last week. While there were numerous rallies, each bulge brought in additional free selling attributed to longs.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 10 -- Swedish reports from Norway announced today that the "Falkenhorst Li e" had been completed from Kristiansand to Trondheim and that from now on Norway could be considered "invasion proof."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Vichy government's apparent move toward closer collaboration with Germany encouraged Administration leaders in the belief today that the House would approve an extension of service for the Army's rank and file.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Mrs. Helen S. K. Willcox's letter, which appeared under the caption " 'Freezing' of Crop Stocks," is interesting and most of the points developed are sound, but unsubstantiated assertions weaken its effectiveness.

With no settlement in sight of a controversy between workers and management, the Caldwell, N. J., propeller plant of Curtiss-Wright, where members of Aircraft Lodge 703 of the International Association of Machinists went on strike Friday morning for higher-wages and changes in hours and working conditions, prepared to open its gates this morning to those workers who wished to return.
The Russian campaign, which entered its eighth week yesterday, is unquestionably the bloodiest of the war.

The British War Relief Society, Inc., 730 Fifth Avenue, reported yesterday that it had cabled $262,495 in cash gifts to Great Britain for civilian relief last month. It also shipped 3,509 cases of clothing valued at $767,147, 5,647 cases of purchased materials valued at $415,697 and 4,404 cases of clothing for other war relief organizations.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- After pairing with other partners and having indifferent success in former John G. Anderson Memorial tournaments at the Winged Foot Golf Club, Billy Dear and Karl Kellerman, New Jersey stars, collaborated today to win the honors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Brig. Gen. Russell L. Maxwell, Administrator of Export Control, announced today that a Clearance Section had been established in his office through which a United States exporter or manufacturer or a foreign importer may submit export proposals on articles and materials deemed essential to the economic life of friendly countries.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Aug. 10 -- Dr. Robert D. Leigh, first president of Bennington College, announced today his resignation, effective Sept. 1, at a special meeting of the faculty and trustees. He is to resume his activities in the social sciences as a temporary member of the School of Economics and Politics of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (U.P.) -- Federal Security Administrator Paul V. McNutt declared tonight that Japan should be warned now that any further aggression in the Far Bast would be met by the "united force" of the United States, Great Britain and the Netherlands.

Miss Gloria Callen and Miss Marilyn Sahner, both from the Women's Swimming Association, successfully defended their senior metropolitan championships yesterday at Manhattan Beach. The former retained the 100-meter back-stroke crown, while Miss Sahner repeated in the 440-yard free style.

Dean Dixon, 26-year-old Negro conductor, who earlier in the season was called to public attention by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and who conducted two concerts with the NBC Summer Symphony Orchestra in June, made his debut last night as conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium.

WELLINGTON, N. Z., Aug. 10 -- New Zealand newspapers see grave risks for Japan if she continues her southward course. They declare it is uncertain whether the recently demonstrated economic solidarity of the democracies against Japanese aggression is sufficient to restrain the proponents of the southward drive.
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., and Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles are the Eastern, grass court tennis champions for 1941, succeeding Robert L. Riggs and Miss Alice Marble.

When the silk shortage loomed there was, as every one knows, a rush of females to buy silk stockings. There was no corresponding rush of males to buy silk neckties -- or any kind of neckties, in fact. The necktie business probably remained firm, but that was the best that could be said about it.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A straight-shooting Texan from San Antonio, 41-year-old C. H. Poulton, won the national all-gauge skeet championship at the seventh annual tourney today, beating 28-year-old Alex Kerr of Beverly Hills, Calif., in the longest shoot-off the clay target classic has witnessed.

Satisfied that the emphasis placed upon advertising and merchandising in the last year was a major factor in bringing domestic sales of canned shrimp up to the highest level in the industry's history, the Shrimp Canners National Advertising Association, at its first annual meeting, decided to expand its program for the coming year.

Suffering and danger are the stepping stones to heroism and unselfish sacrifice, the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Prince, a professor in King's College, Halifax, N.S., asserted yesterday morning in a sermon at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 128 West Sixty-ninth Street, near Broadway.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 -- The Reichsbank's note circulation reached a new wartime high of 16,030,000,000 marks on July 31. This amount was 465,000,000 marks higher than the last peak of 15,565,000,000 marks on June 30. The unusual gain may be the result of greater war expenditure in connection with the Russian campaign, according to informed financial circles.

VICHY, France, Aug. 10 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain went to the races this afternoon -- it was the last day of the Vichy meeting -- accompanied by General Maxime Weygand, proconsul of French Africa, an old cavalryman and a great judge of horses.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 (U.P) -- Boasting that "the great Soviet war machine has been beaten," a Nazi spokesman tonight predicted the imminent fall of Odessa and the near-by Soviet naval base at Nikolaev to a Jriple-pronged German offensive smashing into the Ukraine.

ROME, Aug. 10 (U.P.) -- The Axis is expected to summon, eight European nations into conference within two weeks to "solidify Axis Europe" against the rapid moves of the United States toward greater intervention in the war, according to reports in Rome tonight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Reds spoiled "Charley Root Day" today by defeating the Cubs and their veteran pitcher, 3 to 1, to sweep the two-game series. It was Chicago's ninth defeat in eleven starts.

Salvation for the world today can come only with a rededication to the single-minded purpose of Jesus Christ, complete devotion to God, the Rev. Dr. William P. Merrill, pastor emeritus of the Brick Presbyterian Church, said yesterday in his sermon at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- An increasingly healthy condition in agriculture in this country is reflected by a report on the farm real estate market issued today by the Department of Agriculture, which shows that Federal Land Banks now hold less than $100,000,000 worth of farms, which is a low record since 1934.

CARBONADO, Wash., Aug. 10 (U.P.) -- Eight experienced mountain climbers were toiling up Mount Rainier tonight in an attempt to rescue Leon Brigham Jr., 21-year-old University of Washington football player, who fell into an eighty-foot crevasse in Giant Carbon Glacier this afternoon.

One fact the very young generation may not realize when it reads its war news. That is that it has had the good luck, whatever else in the way of bad luck it may have had, to be born and reared at a time when military glory has no meaning except for those who are in madhouses or ought to be there.

BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Alejandro Carrasquel, Washington's Venezuelan hurler, chalked up his fifth victory of the season today in the second half of a double-header with the Red Sox to give the Senators an even split in the four-game series.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 10 -- Stubbornly fighting Russian troops continued to hold their positions in the Leningrad defense region, and in the Smolensk sector, according to information reaching Berne tonight.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 10 -- The diplomatic crisis in Iran appears to be nearing the climactic stage tonight, as reports circulated in high foreign diplomatic circles in Ankara regarding imminent British action to force the expulsion of German agents from Teheran and Tabriz in the face of German threats of a rupture in Iranian-German diplomatic relations.

MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 11 -- The eighth week of the Russo-German war began yesterday with the Nazi offensive apparently bogged down almost everywhere along the front, despite German General Staff efforts to readjust the original tactics to break the stanch resistance of the Red Army ang accelerate the advance before the heavy Fall rains and the terrible Russian Winter.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Last week witnessed a mild struggle between the gilt-edge list and the industrials for first place on the score of activity in the stock markets. Growing optimism over peace prospects again provided the impetus for the rise among the industrials, although the prime investments apparently were due for some reaction.
A three-fold plan to ease traffic congestion at Twenty-third Street and Thirteenth Avenue, beneath the West Side Highway, was made public yesterday by Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs.

The British housewife is permitted now to spend the equivalent of about twenty-three cents for meat each week for each member of her family. Lord Woolton, the Minister of Food, has said that this amount is unlikely to be increased until after the war. To Americans this may seem like a pitifully small meat allowance, but it does not tell the whole story.

McALESTER, Okla., Aug. 10 -- Warden Jess Dunn of Oklahoma State prison, two convicts and a county jailer were slain today in a bloody bid for liberty by four long-term prisoners who shot the warden, held as a hostage, when officers closed in.

BUFFALO, Aug. 10 -- With the convention of the United Automobile Workers of America entering its second week tomorrow, behind the scenes activity was in progress that may have an important bearing on control of the next convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

VICHY, France, Aug. 10 -- For the first time since the beginning of the war the Bank of France published today the full statement of its balance sheet. The statement gives the position of the bank as of July 10 and July 17, 1941, thus affording an opportunity to observe fluctuations over the period of one week.

OTTAWA, Aug. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's national income increased 11.5 per cent in the first six months this year compared with the same period of 1940 and the Dominion Bureau of Statistics said tonight the increase reflected the "sustained industrial stimulus of the war."

PARIS, Aug. 10 (via Berlin) -- While -- to believe the Paris press -- the ultimate fate of France now hangs in the balance, political circles here that assert they are well informed regarding Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's every thought and intention say that, while the old soldier perhaps may not always know what he wants, he definitely knows what he does not want.
BERLIN, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin) Aug. 10 -- The Bourses in the small Continental European countries continue to be swayed divergently by numerous conflicting factors causing highly irregular trends not only as between the Bourses themselves but also on each individual Bourse between the various kinds of stocks, even a single day often showing a divided movement.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 10 -- After thirty hours of investigation, quietly but energetically carried out, the Ministry of the Interior announced tonight that a statement would be issued to explain the importance of an alleged Nazi movement that had been brought to light when six prominent leaders of pro-totalitarian activity had been arrested on charges of being associated with a "militarized" organization.

Last week's financial markets hesitated, and, on a moderate business, lost ground slightly. This may have been because of the week's confusing news from Russia and from Japan, or because of the equally confusing developments in Congress and in the Administration bureaus.

An eight-room Cape Cod residence and five acres of land on CId Morristown Road, Bernardsville, N. J., have been sold by Mrs. William W. Porter to William F. Adam of Summit. Eugene V. Welsh was the broker.

The threat of bagging a twin bill and sweeping a series from the aimless Phillies proved too much for the fading Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds. So Colonel Bill Terry settled for a split before 9,877 fans.

As the pinch of priorities begins to take hold the country faces the prospect of thousands of factories being forced to close down for lack of essential raw materials and hundreds of thousands of men being thrown out of work. Defense officials have predicted that as many as 5,000 factories may stand idle, and Price Administrator Henderson thinks that "priorities unemployment" may easily exceed 2,000,000 persons.

OSSINING, Aug. 10 -- Richard Whitney, former president of the New York Stock Exchange, who will leave Sing Sing on parole tomorrow morning to take up a new life as manager of a Massachusetts dairy farm, prepared today to say good-bye to the prison where since April 12, 1938, he has lived as Convict 94,635.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- In a world-wide broadcast addressed to the United States, Queen Elizabeth tonight expressed the conviction that American generosity "is born of your conviction that we fight to save a cause that is no less yours than ours."

The American counterpart of that standard reference volume, "The Oxford Companion to English Literature," is now completed after five years of work and will be published by Oxford on Sept. 4. Into 888 pages James D. Hart has crowded hundreds of biographical sketches, 893 summaries and descriptions of important American novels, short stories, plays, essays and poems.

George S. Counts, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, and president of the American Federation of Teachers, has been picked to run for the City Council in Manhattan as a representative of the American Labor party, George Marlin, acting State director of the party, announced yesterday.
Several provisions in the proposed Federal revenue and tax bill are opposed by the Merchants Association of New York because they "cripple business, create uncertainty and hamper defense efforts."

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 10 -- In contrast to the Long Island championship regratta yesterday, when there was no breeze and but a handful of small craft finished over short courses, there was a fine northerly of 15-knot strength today for the special Sunday races of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 10 -- A twenty-two-month contract with the New York Shipbuilding Company, embodying the union shop clause and hitching wages to the cost of living, was ratified today by the membership of Local 1, Industrial Union of Marina and Shipbuilding Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate.

Dr. Willard C. Rappelye, our Commissioner of Hospitals, reports that in 1933 the city's mortality rate for pneumonia was 29.3 per thousand, against 9.7 in 1940 for those who were treated with sulfonamide compounds, which is cheering news for physicians and for millions throughout the country who once faced death when one of the thirty-odd varieties of virulent pneumococci had invaded their systems.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 10 -- A long-smoldering dispute between John Garfield and Warner Brothers flared up this week-end, as the actor's representative charged the studio with broken faith and the studio, on its side, suspended Garfield from salary for the second time in recent weeks.

LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth writes all her addresses, and spent much time on today's talk, even giving two hours of a journey home from Hull on the royal train to the composition. She has received many compliments on the ease and naturalness of her little speeches, and time and again rehearses lines until every last little inflection has been explored, every word and phrase mastered for the desired effect.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The House tomorrow will begin voting on amendments to its resolution to extend the military service of selectees, Guardsmen, Reserve Officers and enlisted personnel of the regular Army.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Contracts of a total value of $6,1S4,602 were awarded by the War Department yesterday. The following, not previously published, went to firms in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey:

HEWLETT, L. I., Aug. 10 -- Brilliant putting by George (Laddie) Van Nostrand of Oakland enabled him and William A. Winant 3d to defeat the medalists, James G. Murray Jr. and George Stuhler of Valley Stream, 5 and 3, in the final of the seventh annual Arthur Man Memorial member-guest tournament at the Sewane Golf Club today.

That minor rebellion Casey Stengel's Braves staged Saturday afternoon was put down by the Dodgers with emphatic finality yesterday at Ebbets Field, as they took both ends of a double-header, 14 -- 4, 4 -- 0, before a crowd of 29,455 contented Flatbush fans.

MILWAUKEE,. Aug. 10 -- John Cudahy, former United States Ambassador who spent eight years in Europe, appealed in a speech here tonight for President Roosevelt to raise his voice as an arbiter in the name of world peace. The time was ripe for the success of a feasible peace proposal, he said.

In six weeks of field manoeuvres in Louisiana beginning today the 250,000 officers and men of the Third Army will consume gargantuan amounts of food and drink, according to statistics revealed yesterday that go far to support the contention of dietetic authorities that the American soldier is by far the best-fe fighting man in the world.

With the time for filing designations for party nominations expiring at midnight Tuesday, no progress was made over the week-end toward eliminating any of the prospective contests and any changes that may be made apparently will have to come during the six-day period for declinations and substitutions.

Apartment buildings on the East Side are attracting new tenants for Fall occupancy, according to lists of latest rentals reported over the week-end by brokers and managing agents. Numerous rentals in London Terrace featured the activity on the West Side.

The opening of the late Summer meeting of the night trotting races tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I., will inaugurate a five-week program of trotting and racing events. There will be eight races each night through Sept. 13.
