MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 11 -- Powerful formations of British Blenheim bombers with fighter escort made another series of daytime sweeps over the French coast to points inland in Northern France yesterday. Other Royal Air Force units bombed a German supply ship, setting her afire, and damaged two Nazi escort vessels in an attack on enemy traffic in the Channel.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Rochester preserved its two-and-one-half-game margin over the fifth-place Jersey Giants today, splitting a double-header with the visitors. Clem Dreisewerd got credit for the Red Wings' 4-3 first-game victory, while Harry Feldman relieved Hugh East to take the nightcap for Jersey City, 8 -- 7, in eight innings.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 10 -- Captain and Mrs. Marion Eppley gave a dinner tonight at Beacon Rock in honor of their week-end guests, Admiral Adolphus Andrews and Mrs. Andrews.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Cardinals stopped fast-climbing Pittsburgh, 3 to 2 and 4 to 2, today, dropping the Pirates nine and one-half games out of first place and temporarily squelching their hopes of making it a three-team race.

TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 11 -- Although official quarters have repeatedly disclaimed any thought of a joint defense agreement with Thailand similar to that with IndoChina, the Japanese press, in continuing its campaign against "encirclement" by the United States, Britain, China, Netherlands Indies and Russia, is beginning to advance that idea.

For most of the world automobiles and silk stockings are the true symbo of the American way of life. If you tell a Russian worker that the great majority of American wage slaves drive to their sweatshops in their our cars, he rejects this tall tale as capitalist propaganda.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The recent exchange of letters between President Roosevelt and Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee, in which both agreed that the exemptions should be lowered for income tax purposes, represents a definite move backward for the national economy.

VICHY, France, Aug. 10 -- A Swiss newspaper recently published some interesting statistical data showing that the European countries are trading much more among themselves than with overseas nations, and more especially than with the United States.

IF there are any young lady novelists in the United States like Kylie Tennant of Australia I never heard of them. Miss Tennant (now Mrs. L. C. Rodd) is the author of "The Battlers." She was born in Sydney about thirty years ago. In the interval she has been, she says, a barmaid, a visiting church worker, a radio broadcaster, a journalist, a clerk, a copy-writer, a chicken farmer and, finally, a tramp.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The WHite Sox floored the Indians twice today, Ted Lyons getting his eleventh triumph of the season, 5 to 2, and Thornton Lee his fourteenth, 2 to 1. The Sox swept the three-game series and ran the Indians' losing streak to five games.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- Trading in corn showed a material expansion here last week as the result of a crop scare. This was instrumental in advancing the December and May positions to new seasonal high prices and it put the September 2 1/8 cents a bushel above the asking price of 77 cents for government-owned grain held here.

Harness racing under floodlights will return to the Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L. I., tonight when the Old Country Trotting Association opens a thirty-day meeting that will run through Sept. 13. The Inaugural, a $1,000 event for 22 Class trotters, will feature tonight's program.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10 -- The steel trade had expected the action of the Office of Production Mangement late yesterday in issuing an order putting all iron and steel under mandatory control, with the efective date Sept. 1. In effect, all defense requirements thus will be placed immediately ahead of any orders on steel books and which are for nondefense use.

VICHY, France, Aug. 10 -- Application of the government's new social program is progressing as rapidly as possible. The Professional Organization Committee has finished its third session on administration of the code and a labor charter will be promulgated most likely early in September.

Following the sharp recovery at the end of the previous week, cotton prices again turned downward last week. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange registered net losses for the week of 60 to 64 points.

The bell tolled at 5:18 o'clock yesterday morning for the old Brooklyn Fulton Street trolley. At 5 A.M. the first of the sleek, new buses started rolling. Yet, save for Everett A. White, president of the Brooklyn division of the New York Car-Riders Association, and four other sentimentalists, the occasion went virtually unnoticed.
DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Aug. 10 -- Five children of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Love perished early today in flames which destroyed a 150-year-old highway toll house in which they lived seven miles east of here.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The widening circle of suppressive action against alleged Axis plotting in South America has brought seizure of arms caches and several arrests in the snowcovered region of Puerto Montt, Chile, a principal center of German colonization on the continent.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 -- The Yankees apparently have caught their second wind and what the remainder of the American League will catch from now on is a matter that soon may stagger the imagination.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- Developments in Washington in regard to price control and other farm legislation dominated the action of the wheat market last week and brought sufficient new buying to lift prices on futures on the Board of Trade to new highs since 1937, with the May selling at $1.19 % a bushel, or 4 7/8 a cents above the government loan price at one time.

George Jessel announced yesterday several changes in plans for his forthcoming musical, "High Kickers." It will not open on Labor Day in Chicago, as had been announced, as the start of rehearsals has been deferred until the last week of this month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Office of Production Management was said by officials today to be considering increasing the proposed 10,000,000-ton annual steel capacity expansion program to 15,000,000 tons.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 11 -- With German forces hurling much stronger mechanized forces against them, Russian troops in the Sinjucha River and Bug River areas of the Ukraine continued to fight desperately throughout last night and most of today in an effort to crush the German offensive from Lipovets and drive the invader back to his original lines.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 -- A new version of the ancient "The Beggar's Opera" had its pre-Broad-way showing in the rural setting of the Bucks County Playhouse at New Hope tonight, with the benefit of a competent cast, attractive sets and a sold-out house.

IN the Aug. 6 issue of Variety there was the usual assortment of wonders. On a film page it was reported that "Kiss Boys" was doing oke in Cleve., nabbing a cool $10,500 at the State. On a radio page the headline read "Three Webs Meet Fly Again" -- a blend of historical fact and sheer genius. On other pages there were items relating to burlesque, concerts, coin machines, legit, literature, and so forth.

Under the influence of a combination of depressing factors, the cotton market lost yesterday more than SI a bale. Opening prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 5 to 11 points lower and the list gradually drifted lower to close with net losses of 21 to 23 points.

Cutting of diamond "melee," or small stones of one-tenth of a carat or less, which have been scarce in this country since the German invasion eliminated the diamond-cutting centers of Antwerp and Amsterdam, has just been started in this country.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 11 -- Vera Zorina and Ray Milland will be starred by Paramount in the screen version of a new novel by W. Somerset Maugham which the studio purchased today for $65,000. The story, as yet untitled, deals with the life of an Austrian girl married to an Englishman and living in wartime London: it will be published this Fall.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The National Mediation Board, which handles labor relations disputes involving the railroads and airlines, intervened today in an effort to prevent a walkout of 1,150,000 operating and non-operating railway employes who are balloting on strike action.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 -- Both the heat and Frank Frisch's words melted the ice in the bucket in which he was soaking an injured foot.
BERLIN, Aug. 11 -- The German forces operating in the Southern Ukraine were officially reported in Berlin today to be making rapid progress in their pursuit of an already yielding Russian enemy.

CALDWELL, N.J., Aug. 11 -- With official Washington making no outward move to seek a settlement of the strike of A.F. of L. machinists at the Caldwell propeller plant of Curtiss-Wright, the strike today moved peacefully through the first full working day with the strikers gaining additional recruits.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East communique said today:

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- Japan is "urgently concerned" over shipment of United States supplies to Russia through the Siberian port of Vladivostok, the government Information Board spokesman said today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 11 -- Women of the Summer colonies of this and adjacent resorts are active in the arrangements for a novel party to be held Wednesday afternoon on the grounds of the new American Indian Museum in Water Mill for children from wartorn countries wno are now spending the Summer at estates in the Hamptons.

The Duke of Windsor, who last traveled through this country to his Canadian ranch seventeen years ago as Prince of Wales, will repeat the trip some time between the middle of next month and the middle of October, it was learned yesterday.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- By a roll-call vote of 1,558 to 1,460, delegates to the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., convention today disqualified Lew Michener, suspended West Coast regional director, from running for re-election because of his part in the North American Aviation Company strike.

The State of California made the award of a new issue of $3,303,371 of general fund registered warrants yesterday to the Merchants National Bank of Sacramento. The bid was par, plus a premium of $1,748, the interest rate one-half of 1 per cent.

William F. Carey, Commissioner of Sanitation of New York and newly elected chairman of the board of the $61,000,000 International Utilities Corporation, made yesterday a personal appeal to the corporation's 14,000 stockholders to retain in office the present new management of the holding company, which operates electric, water and gas properties in Canada and the United States.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 12 -- The Japanese Government was operating today under wartime economic powers granted by the National Mobilization Act as its Minister to Washington warned the country that the United States was now ready to meet any further Japanese advance in the Pacific, whatever the consequences.
BOSTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Given a surprising four-run lead by his Philadelphia team-mates, Walter (Boom Boom) Beck scored his first triumph of the season today, defeating the Braves, 6 -- 3.

Yesterday at Ebbets Field wasn't billed as the Giant Killing Day, but it could have been so advertised. What the Dodgers did to Colonel Bill Terry's shattered and crippled forces was downright shameful, but it was necessary to preserve Brooklyn's three-point lead over the runner-up Cardinals.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial "Markets for Our Neighbors" you inform that "increasing efforts are being made to develop permanent markets in the United States for South American products not hitherto sold here," and you comment that "such efforts deserve every encouragement from the United States."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today estimated this year's corn crop at 2,587,574,000 bushels, and the wheat yield at 950,953,000 bushels, both figures based on Aug. 1 conditions. A month ago the forecasts were 2,548,709,000 and 682,321,000, respectively.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11 -- Many members of the Summer colony gathered at the Art Association tonight for a song recital given by Mrs. Reginald B. Lanier, soprano. She was assisted in her program by Alessandro Niccoli, violinist, while Mrs. Lewis A. Armistead served as accompanist for both.

Price contracts on a half-dozen brands of Schenley Distillers Corporation providing for price reductions ranging from 10 to 40 cents a quart, depending upon the brand, were sent out to retailers in metropolitan New York over the week-end by Schenley.

Cities will get priority ratings on metal supplies, machinery and materials fur the maintenance and repair of their functional services in sufficient quantity to continue those services satisfactorily, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday at the Summer City Hall.

Almost all residential sections of Manhattan shared in the apartment renting activity reported yesterday by brokers. Both the east and west sides of the midtown area received generous shares of the business.

H.G. Wells's thirty-two-year-old novel, "The History of Mr. Polly," is with us again, having been rediscovered by Sinclair Lewis and his fellow-sponsors of the Readers Club. It has a sharp point still and might have been written particularly for today. Its hero, a human peg born for a square hole in life but forced to occupy a round one and thereby consigned to futility, typifies a vast, unhappy host of men and women.
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

The bridge team of Waldemar von Zedtwitz, Edward Hymes and Samuel Fry Jr. of New York and A. Mitchell Barnes of Atlanta, Ga., won the championship in the masters' team-of-four tournament at the Cavendish Club last night by defeating the Four Aces in the closest match on record in the tournament.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Information Bureau, issued the following early today:

Mr. and Mrs. C. Temple Emmet of this city and Stony Brook, L.I., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Mrs. Margaret Chanler Emmet Kinnicutt of Far Hills, N.J., widow of Francis H. Kinnicutt of this city, to John Benton Prosser of this city and Sarasota, Fla., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Hallan Prosser, which took place Saturday afternoon in the Chapman Memorial Chapel of Christ Episcopal Church, West Seventy-first Street.

Dr. A. Wellington Taylor, dean of the New York University Graduate School of Business Administration, called upon the government yesterday to draft, immediately, a ouncil of scholars to plan for world-wide post-war economic reconstruction.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Victory in the pro-amateur best-ball event staged by the West-chester P.G.A. at the Mount Kisco Country Club today went to the home club pair of Bill Goldbeck and James M. Robbins, who toured the par 72 layout in an amazing 29, 35 -- 64.

IT'S true what they said about Joe Cronin. Some time ago there was circulated a sinister rumor that the noted player-manager of the Fenway Millionaires, one of the best curve-ball hitters in baseball, was a fugitive from the amateur tennis game. The whisper was that, as a youngster around San Francisco, he had a racquet and was an amateur tennis star before he discovered that he could make more money playing baseball.

The semi-annual statement of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and its subsidiaries, mailed to stockholders yesterday, disclosed a net profit for the first six months of 1941 totaling $6,196,756, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.23 on each of 2,059,168 shares of no-par common stock, excluding treasury shares.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 11 -- The special Cabinet session convened by Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies sat all day today discussing the Pacific situation. The chiefs of the three armed services attended the meeting.

Albert N. Williams, president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, announced yesterday that net income of the company for the first six months of this year amounted to 53,435,899, after operating expenses, taxes and other charges.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Senator Robert R. Reynolds, 57-year-old North Carolinian, said today that he and Miss Evalyn Washington McLean, 20-year-old daughter of Mrs. Evalyn Walsh McLean of this city, are engaged to be married.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In conquered territories Germans are provided with a handbook on behavior scientifically calculated to offset national prejudice. I arrived in America from England over a year ago, and I have longed ever since for a book of that description applicable to this country.
The Russo-German fighting, now in its eighth week, is undoubtedly costing both nations considerably in lives and equipment.

BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 11 -- President Roosevelt appealed today to colleges and universities, in a message read at the convention of the American College Publicity Association, to undertake with redoubled energy the task of defending and advancing the democratic way of life.

CHUNGKING, China, Tuesday, Aug. 12 -- More than economic sanctions against Japan by the United States and Britain will be necessary to keep the Japanese out of Thailand, Dr. Wang Shih-chieh, Minister of Publicity, declared today.

Despite the recent clash between their countries, military officers from Ecuador and Peru were "very good friends" during a trip from South America to this country, it was reported yesterday when they arrived on the Grace liner Santa Lucia.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Ex-President Hoover and fourteen associates have recently made public a statement in which they express approval of the lease-lend law but assert that President Roosevelt has unjustifiably gone beyond the purpose of that law in taking measures to insure the safe delivery of American munitions in Britain and in promising aid to Russia.

Argentine sportsmen have raised 2,000,000 pesos, roughly equivalent to $500,000, to underwrite preliminary expenses of the first Pan-American Games, which are slated to be held in Buenos Aires from Nov. 21 through Dec. 6 in 1942. This was announced by Francisco Borgonovo, treasurer of the host nation's organizing committee, at a luncheon in his honor yesterday at the New York Athletic Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A preliminary payroll check by the National Labor Relations Board indicated today that the Steel Workers' Organizing Committee, C.I.O., was entitled to exclusive bargaining rights at seventeen plants of Republic Steel Corporation in Ohio, New York and Illinois.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Assurances that Mexico was fully prepared to stamp out any Nazi, Fascist or Communist movements that might arise within its borders and that the United States could proceed with its national defense preparations without fear of totalitarian penetration in Mexico were given today by President Avila Camacho to the executive council of the American Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Eleven large oil companies submitted to Secretary Ickes today a plan for a new 1,820-mile pipeline system, the longest in the world, designed to pour 250,000 barrels of crude oil daily into the New York-Philadelphia area.
BERLIN. Aug. 11 -- First Lieut. George Bones of the Guderian Tank Army talked before foreign correspondents today about the taking of Smolensk and his general observations of life in Russia.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau reported early today that fighting had continued yesterday in the directions of Soltsy, Smolensk, Byelaya Tserkov and Uman.
One more imposing East Side residence was added yesterday to the rapidly growing list of private homes in that area which recently have undergone a change of ownership.

BELMAR, N.J., Aug. 11 -- More than 500 tuna, the largest number of fish ever taken in a tuna derby, were boated by the sixteen teams competing in the Atlantic Coast tuna tournament which opened today at this port and will be concluded Wednesday afternoon.

Seventy-one golfers representing clubs in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Vermont will tee off Thursday at the Deepdale Golf Club, Great Neck, L.I., in the metropolitan district's thirty-six hole sectional qualifying round. The fourteen low scorers will be eligible to participate in the forty-fifth national amateur championship at the Omaha (Neb.) Field Club Aug. 25-30.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (U.P.) -- Federal Judge James W. Morris took under advisement today an application by the Federal Communications Commission for an order to require James G. Stahlman, Nashville newspaper publisher, to testify at a commission hearing.

VICHY, France, Aug. 11 -- Postponed from Saturday, a full Cabinet Council was held this evening and lasted nearly two hours. Afterward a communique reported that the Ministers and Secretaries of State had passed much of that time discussing "current affairs."
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 -- A four-run second inning was the big splurge in the Cardinals' attack today which enabled them to whip the Cubs, 7 to 5, and keep on the heels of Brooklyn.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The White Sox and Browns today divided a double-header in which fifty-six hits were recorded. The Chicagoans won the opener, 14 to 9, and then bowed, 10 to 3.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Resisting suggestions by Republicans and some Democrats for price control administration by a five-member bi-partisan board, Leon Henderson, administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, told the House Banking and Currency Committee today that the threat of inflation with a rapidly rising price level required fast and decisive action by "a single, responsible administrator."

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Good shipping demand helped steady a weak opening in the hog marget today and was reflected in the partial recovery. The trade mostly was steady and the top was unchanged from Friday at $11.70. Medium weight and weighty steers opened 15 to 25 cents lower but closed weak to 15 cents off as shipping demand broadened.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Eddie Longacre's single off Relief Pitcher Bobby Coombs in the ninth with three on and two out drove in two runs and brought Syracuse a 5-to-4 victory over the Jersey City Giants tonight.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- A $1,093,953 bid for widening the pavement and construction of a center island on the eleven miles of the Hutchinson River Parkway between the Bronx and Westchester Avenue in this city was received today by the Westchester County Park Commission from the Rusciano Son Corporation of the Bronx, the lowest of six bidders.

With uniformed members of the Women's Voluntary Services at the wheels, nine sleek "R.A.F.-Blue" ambulances were on their way to Canada last night, the latest gift of the British-American Ambulance Corps.

Government operation of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company's plant at Kearny, N.J., closed for the last five days by a strike of 16,000 members of Local 16 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C. I.O., appeared certain yesterday as the company itself moved to have the government take over the plant for "immediate possession and operation."

BERLIN, Tuesday, Aug. 12 (AP) -- German troops now are advancing on "well-paved, broad highways leading straight to Kiev," Ukraine capital, while others are striking southward toward the Black Sea port of Odessa, German news dispatches said today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is clear from the dispatches that Hitler is preparing for an offensive against North and West Africa this Fall. He is desperately in need of a cheap victory to offset his Russian reverses. French Africa offers the best opportunity.

Donald Durant, former partner in Lee, Higginson Co., and at one time a representative in this country of Ivar Kreuger, the Swedish "match king," died yesterday on the northbound platform of the Hanover Square station of the Third Avenue Elevated, apparently of a heart attack.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11 -- Headed by Donald McNeill, the national champion, from Oklahoma, a field of sixty-four players began competition this morning in the twenty-fifth annual men's invitation tennis tournament at the Casino.

Edgar J. Nathan, recently chosen by the New York County Republican organization as its candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, may also be entered in the Labor party primary against Stanley M. Issacs, the incumbent, it developed yesterday.
ALBANY, Aug. 11 -- Gambling in Saratoga must stop immediately, not in a few weeks or days, but at once, Governor Lehman ordered today in letters sent to officials at the racing spa.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 12 -- For the first time in many months aerial hostilities on the Western Front between Britain and Germany were at a halt all day yesterday, apparently because of bad weather over the Continent.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 11 -- For the first time in modern Norway, capital punishment was carried out when at dawn today three Norwegians died before a German firing squad in Bergen.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Income payments to individuals in the United States in the first six months of this year were 14 per cent ahead of the corresponding period last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

"Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's remake of the Robert Louis Stevenson work, will have its world premiere at the Astor Theatre this morning. Performances will be continuous and at popular prices. Spencer Tracy portrays the title roles, and Ingrid Bergman, Lana Turner, Donald Crisp, lan Hunter, Barton MacLane, C. Aubrey Smith, Sara All-good.

The lights were on all last night in the Hotel Commodore headquarters of John R. Davies, who is seeking the Republican nomination for Mayor, but there was very little activity as ten young men lolled in sofas and chairs, waiting for money they claim is owed to them for getting signatures on Davies nominating petitions.

OSSINING, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- The barred doors of Sing Sing Prison opened. The tall, proud man, who entered through the same door three years and four months age stepped out, a brown paper pares in one hand and an onion sack full of his belongings in the other.

PEIPING, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Observers in this North China gate to Manchukuo and Mongolia expressed the conviction today that Japan's next theatre of action was more likely to be Siberia than Thailand -- and that the blow might fall any day.

The engagement of Tyrone Power and his wife, Annabella, in "Liliom," which opened last night at the Country Playhouse, Westport, Conn., will be interrupted after tonight's performance to enable Mr. Power to make a quick trip to Hollywood for retakes on his new picture, "A Yank in the R.A.F."

Befuddled by fast-moving events in the international scene and handicapped by the possibility of an even more far-reaching entrance of Washington into the price control and priorities fields, together with prospects of a broadened tax basis, the stock market reacted yesterday to the lowest levels since July 7.

Edmund Wilson, whose new book of literary studies is published today, takes his title. "The Wound and the Bow," from a play by Sophocles. The seven studies in the book deal for the most part with the relation between the creative abilities of authors and their psychological injuries and maladjustments.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 11 -- The Russian Government has warned the Iranian Government that Iran's persistent refusal to comply with Anglo-Russian demands for the expulsion of German agents and the purging of the strong German influence from Iran might force the Soviet to send Red Army troops into Iran, according to unconfirmed but apparently reliable reports to high foreign diplomatic sources here today

Rayon finished goods continued in heavy demand at advancing prices yesterday as reports indicated establishment of price ceilings on these goods by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply was imminent. Prices and bids for the available spot supply in second hands were substantially above the voluntary ceilings set last month on important constructions.

Joe DiMaggio went hitlese, Charlie Keller got only a lucky single and Marvin Breuer didn't stay around long enough, to become well acquainted. Whatever the reason -- it might have been some highly effective pitching by Jack Wilson -- the Yankees started the week at home on the wrong foot yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 -- The government rested its case today against J. Warren Davis, retired United States Circuit judge, and Morgan S. Kaufman, Scranton attorney, who are on trial in Federal District Court on charges of conspiracy to obstruct justice and to defraud the Government of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Aug. 6, 1941, aggregated $10,507,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A ceiling price of 12 cents a pound for copper, the schedule to be effective tomorrow, was set today by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply.

But Then, Again Aaron Copland's symphonic suite "Quiet City" had its first performance at the Lewisohn Stadium the other night. It was the composer's aim to create an atmosphere "evocative of the nostalgia and inner distress of a society profoundly aware of its own inner insecurity."

Dr. Canaille Dreyfus, president of the Celanese Corporation of America, reported to stockholders in a statement of operations issued for publication today that the volume of business in the second quarter of this year reached record levels.

A further slight decline in steel operations will occur this week, with production scheduled at 97.5 per cent of capacity, against 98.3 per cent last week and 99.6 per cent two weeks ago, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Miss Gail Wild of the home club and Mrs. DeWitt Untermeyer of Hollywood, the defenders, took a one-stroke lead with 42, 40 -- 82 in the sixth annual women's metropolitan golf Scotch-foursome tournament over the difficult lower course of the Baltusrol club today.

EAST OTIS, Mass., Aug. 11 -- Weary from long rail and sea journeys but still able to chat animatedly about the new sights they had seen so far in their brief stay in America, Girl Guides from fourteen American countries began arriving today for the Western Hemisphere Conference of Girl Scouts and Girl Guides which opened today at Camp Bonnie Brae.

The decision of the Office of Production Management to place defense requirements for steel "uncompromisingly ahead of nondefense needs" is a wise measure. It may, indeed, come as a surprise to a good many people to discover that steel had not previously been placed under 100 per cent priority control.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The speeding up of warship building, cutting the construction time on new men-of-war by an average of 12 1/2 per cent for each vessel, will give the United States its two-ocean fleet two years earlier than originally scheduled, Navy sources said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 9:

For a Bigger SEC Some observers profess wonderment at the fact that Wall Street has recommended a nine-man Securities and Exchange Commission with salaries of $10,000 to $15,000 a year to replace the five-man commission limited to $10,000 a year, since there have been complaints that SEC rule has been costly to the financial industry.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 11 -- Mrs. Owen Johnson is to be hostess at a public garden party at Inglaside, Stockbridge, Wednesday afternoon under the auspices of the Lenox Garden Club, for the benefit of the Berkshire Chapter of the Red Cross.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull declared today that the United States would discuss a settlement of difficulties with Japan only on a basis of the fourteen points he enunciated in July, 1937.
NEW YORK Charles Bruggmann, the Swiss Minister, and Mrs. Bruggmann have arrived from Washington and are at the Savoy-Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- It was decided at a conference of Speaker Rayburn, Democratic leader McCormack of Massachusetts and members of the Military Committee today to seek only an 18-month extension in the service bill as was approved by the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- In a far-reaching step that brought the effects of the defense program close home to the ordinary man, President Roosevelt set up today a system of control for the huge installment credit business carried on through the nation's banks, stores and personal finance companies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- For the second day the Navy Department received no report today from the yacht Potomac, on which President Roosevelt set sail on a cruise. In view of rumors that Mr. Roosevelt was meeting Prime Minister Churchill, this silence set up a new wave of speculation on such a possibility.
SMOLENSK, Russia (By Telephone Through Warsaw and Berlin) Aug. 11 -- I walked through the ashes of Smolensk today on a tour conducted by German military authorities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- In an effort to make the pending service extension bill less objectionable to a strong House opposition, majority leaders of the House Military Affairs Committee tentatively agreed today to offer an amendment making mandatory the dismissal at the end of their present terms of service of all soldiers whose business affairs or dependents would suffer from further service.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Evidence was offered today by a Dies sub-committee to prove that Miss Nancy Reed, recently dismissed as an investigator of the New York Department of Labor, had long been a prominent member of the Communist party.

Prunes -- fat and tender, with glossy black coats -- have pleasant associations with our childhood, when breakfast consisted of a big bowl of porridge, a mug of milk and often a bowl of succulent prunes that we were taught to eat slowly -- lifting them carefully with our own, small, battered silver spoon.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Miss Helen Jacobs of Greenville, Del., former women's national tennis champion, narrowly escaped being the victim of an upset today as she squeezed through her second round match with 19-year-old Miss Pearl Harland of Santa Monica, Calif., on the opening day of the seventeenth annual Essex County Club's invitation tourney.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that shipments abroad of United States currency last month amounted to $1,273,000 and that corresponding receipts were $1,898,000, thus giving a net inward excess of $625,000. This reversed the trend in June, when shipments were $4,571,000, with receipts only $612,000.

The New York Central System reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a net income of $11,858,506 after all charges and taxes, equal to $1.84 a share on the 6,447,413 capital shares. Railway tax accruals amounted to $23,077,638, including $4,637,736 Federal Income and excess profits taxes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Nine companies submitted bids to the Maritime Commission today for construction of sixteen small coastwise tankers at prices ranging from $494,000 to $994,000 each. The vessels are to be 220 feet long, with beam of 37 feet and depth of 14 feet 6 inches.

The European center of gravity shifts with the fortunes of war, but it returns to France with a regularity which shows how pivotal is the position of France in the plans of Hitler. Vichy is the scene of another of the periodic crises that are always approaching a climax and never quite reach the breaking point.

Work is under way on the Army air depot at Rome, N.Y. It is to be completed between now and next Spring, at a cost of 520,000,000. The site of Fort Stanwix was in that vicinity. Stanwix has its place in the dark record of the Revolutionary War and the Indian fighting.

CHENGCHOW, China, Aug. 3 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- A high Chinese military authority in this Honan city today told this correspondent that Chinese guerrillas had started a general counter-attack upon Japanese positions north of the Yellow River as a result of an "un-written British-Chinese alliance."
A number of individual leases calling for several floors featured the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday.

Seven thousand members of Electrical Workers Union, Local 3, who had been on strike for two weeks, returned to their jobs yesterday morning in accordance with a vote taken by the union membership last Saturday.

BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 11 -- By winning two first and as many fourth places in the initial four contests of a series of nine to determine the 1941 junior champion crew of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association, the entry of the Westhampton Beach Yacht Squadron, defenders, hung up a total of 30 1/2 points today.

LONDON, Aug. 11 (Reuters) -- Warner Brothers have bought 2,000,000 ordinary shares of Associated British Pictures Corporation from Mrs. John Maxwell, widow of the one-time chairman of the corporation. It is unofficially estimated that the value of the contract, the signing of which has been announced today, is $3,600,000.

Price increases ranging from 10 to 15 per cent over last year were reported yesterday at the opening of the National Luggage and Leather Goods Show, which will continue through Friday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Predictions were made of an exceptionally good holiday trade in this merchandise as buyer registration ran well ahead of the opening day of the 1940 show.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- The outside interest in wheat was at a minimum, today. Professional evening up for the government's crop report due after the close of the market, a break in corn and cotton and continued weakness in spot wheat carried prices off 1 to 1 1/8 cents a bushel, with the close at the bottom.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 11 -- After an absence of four weeks, harness racing returned to Roosevelt Raceway tonight as the Old Country Trotting Association ushered in its thirty-night late Summer meeting.
Fox Meadow Estates reported yesterday three sales in its development at Fox Meadow, Scarsdale, Westchester County, to purchasers who will improve their land with new dwellings.

BERLIN, Tuesday, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- Soviet forces guarding Odessa, Russia's great wheat port, were being evacuated across the Black Sea under constant pounding by the German Air Force to escape entrapment by the Nazi Blitzkrieg slashing southward through the Ukraine, informed quarters claimed today.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 11 (AP) -- A major shake-up in the Turkish Government was rumored in political quarters tonight, with Foreign Minister Shukru Saracoglu regarded as a probable choice to succeed Premier Refik Saydam.

LONDON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The German Army's double drive on the Black Sea ports of Odessa and Nikolaev may become the Reich's first major strategic triumph of the Russian campaign, informed quarters said tonight, and Soviet sources here lankly were worried.
MADRID, Aug. 11 (AP) -- An American Red Cross mission has completed the job of distributing nearly 20,000 tons of food, valued at $4,000,000, in six months of activity in Spain.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- In a statement made today regarding the Executive order for control of instalment credit, Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said:
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Phipps entertained at one of the breakfast parties today at the Trackside Restaurant.

Undaunted by the fact that they had to make a hole-in-one even to tie in the tenth annual World Telegram "Acers" tourney, 154 Long Island players teed off at the Bayside links yesterday, each one nursing a hope that a miracle might happen.

Requests for priority consideration on a wide variety of export orders received from Latin-American customers and held up by foreign traders here, until the manner in which the government planned to handle such commitments, was announced, were forwarded to Washington yesterday following word that the Administrator of Export Control, has opened a clearing, agency in his office.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The text of the executive order concerning instalment buying, issued by President Roosevelt today, read as follows:

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the followoing companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.

Official reports sent yesterday by the major oil companies to Federal Petroleum Coordinator Harold L. Ickes showed that gasoline sales in the first week of the 7-to-7 curfew went not down but decidedly up.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 11 (U.P.) -- Japanese ships will stop calling at Singapore next month and Japanese residents are leaving the Straits Settlements and Malaya as result of the tense situation following Britain's action in imposing drastic economic penalties on Japan, it was revealed today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- The Milky Way Farm's run of good racing luck continued today when Miss Discovery hammered out a head victory on the post over the fast-closing Moja in the feature race. There was a slight delay while the stewards considered an objection against the winner, but the result was confirmed, returning $9.40 for $2 to backers of Mrs. Ethel V. Mars's filly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A national "purchase tax" similar to one now in effect in England, and a personal "excess profits" levy to tap increases in wages and salaries due to defense activities, were recommended today to the Senate Finance Committee by the Investment Bankers Association of America for inclusion in the pending revenue bill.

Comet Rice Company will introduce, this month, the first rice fortified with Vitamin B-1 under the name of Vitafied Comet Rice and will promote it in an ambitious advertising campaign. A six months' drive in 122 newspapers, four national magazines and radio is scheduled and has been based on an extensive nation-wide marketing study during the past fourteen months.

This is the story of what Gino Francesehini, 19 years old, of 338 East Sixty-first Street, did in his effort to meet the 5 feet 7 inches height standard required in the Civil Service physical test for a Fire Department appointment.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11 -- Without abandoning their attack in the Smolensk region, the Germans have launched two new thrusts aimed at the Russians' main naval bases on the Baltic and Black Seas. Fierce fighting in both sectors is reported.

At the Troy Museum on Sept. 27, 1852, Cordelia Howard, daughter of the manager, made her first appearance on the stage as Little Eva in George L. Aiken's dramatization of "Uncle Tom's Cabin." Howard's wife, Caroline Fox, was Aiken's cousin. Aiken wrote the play at the request of Howard, who thought that the part of Little Eva was suited to his daughter and that of Topsy to his wife.

MANILA, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Japanese High Command is planning to place 180,000 troops in French Indo-China, the majority of them in West Cambodia adjoining the border of Thailand, it was learned authoritatively tonight.

A syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. won the award yesterday of a new issue of $2,716,000 of bonds of the city of Minneapolis, Minn. The bankers bid 100.157 for $1,270,000 of refunding bonds, due serially from Sept. 1, 1942 to 1951, naming the coupon rate as 1 1/2 per cent, and bid 100.2109 for $1,446,000 of public welfare and permanent improvement bonds, naming the interest rate at 1.70 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission ruled today that it would not be in the public interest for the Louisiana Arkansas Railway to acquire properties of the Rock Island, Arkansas Louisiana Railroad. It made its ruling in modifying its plan of reorganization for the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway to provide that the R.I., A. L. should be included in the reorganized Rock Island system.

LAST Winter the sun rose in Paris between 9 and 10 o'clock in the morning. This meant that everybody had to get up at what might as well have been midnight. Men and women went off to work and children went off to school in total darkness. All clocks in the occupied zone had been, by official order, set back two hours to correspond to clocks in the Reich.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Wheat showed a heavy undertone from the start today and, while there were several rallies which carried the price back to around yesterday's close, the upturns were the result of local short covering and they brought in hedging from the Northwest and Southwest.

Trading in locally dressed meats yesterday was rather quiet on most classes. Steer hinds and rib prices were steady. The cow beef market was weak to 50 cents lower. Bull beef sold at steady rates. Veal and lamb steady, prices were unchanged. Prices of pork cuts were also unchanged. Kosher steer beef, lamb and veal brought steady prices.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Except where sales were canceled because of limited inventories, reporting members of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers showed sharp increases in their July sales by comparison with 1940.
BERLIN, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Today's German headquarters communique follows:

With automotive the only classification to register a decline advertising in newspapers of fifty-two markets measured by Media Records increased 5.6 per cent last month over July, 1940. This gain brought the increase for the first seven months of the year to 3.5 per cent.

Richard H. Gregory, controller of the Western Electric Company for more than thirty years and a director for more than twenty, will retire from active service on Aug. 31 after forty-three years of service in the Bell System, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the company's board of directors.

A seven-room suite has been leased to Graham Hunter in 45 East Sixty-second Street through Douglas L. Elliman, Inc., brokers, who also arranged leases for Vermont Hatch, attorney, in 40 Fifth Avenue; for Mrs. Walker Edmonds, in 333 East Sixty-eighth Street; for William B. Robinson in Eastgate, and for Mrs. B.F. Foster in 277 Park Avenue.

Preparations on the forthcoming musical comedy, "Banjo Eyes," starring Eddie Cantor, will start in earnest with Mr. Cantor's arrival here on Friday. As already announced, the attraction is due Thanksgiving Week at the Hollywood Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- The United States is formulating a plan under which all German airline pilots in South and Central America may be displaced by Latin Americans trained in this country, it was disclosed tonight.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 13 -- The American and British stand in the Far Eastern crisis, as expressed in recent statements by United States Secretary of State Cordell Hull and British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, was formally conveyed to the Japanese Government by both United States Ambassador Joseph C. Grew and British Ambassador Sir Robert L. Craigie in recent interviews with Vice Admiral Teijiro Toyoda, Japanese Foreign Minister, it was understood in political circles here today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- Intimating that Britain might be preparing for an invasion of Nazi-held Western Europe, the Communist party organ Pravda said today that there was "every reason to expect" that the Royal Air Force soon would be capable of supporting land and sea operations against Germany.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- About 300 women from New York, New Jersey and Conecticut arrived on a special train today to protest against legislation to extend the period of service for selectees and National Guardsmen.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 12 -- Russian troops in the Ukraine continued to inflict heavy damage on German forces attempting to make drives from Lipovets against Odessa and Kiev, according to reports received here today. The German push toward Odessa is directed down the Sinjucha and Bug Rivers, while the drive against Kiev is aimed northward on either side of Byelaya Tserkov.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- Delegates to the U.A.W.-C.I.O. convention appealed today to Curtiss-Wright airplane workers "to join with us to raise the wage level of the aircraft industry." They exhorted the workers in a friendly manner to dislodge the Aircraft, independent union of Curtiss employes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- By a razor-edged vote of 203 to 202 the House approved the Army service extension bill this evening in essentially the form in which it was adopted by the Senate, but with minor amendments which will require sending it back to the Senate.

"Kiss the Boys Goodbye," a comedy with music from the play by Clare Boothe, will open this morning at the Paramount. Mary Martin and Don Ameche are starred in the Paramount production, which was directed by Victor Schertzinger, and Oscar Levant, Virginia Dale, Rochester, Connie Boswell and Elizabeth Patterson are featured in the supporting cast....

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12 -- Several informal dinners were given in the Summer colony last night before the opening at the Casino Theatre of "Mr. and Mrs. North." Mr. and Mrs. Beverley Bogert entertained a box party and Mrs. Hamilton McK. Twombly also had guests.
NEW YORK Mrs. Cary W. Magruder and Miss Polly Magruder have come from Newport, R.I., and are at the Vanderbilt.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 12 -- An $800,000 road reconstruction program was started today at Fort Dix when about fifty WPA laborers began widening the Fort Dix-Pemberton road, first of nine roads included in the project. The WPA and the State and Burlington County Highway Departments are cooperating in the improvement plan.

The four-story apartment house containing forty suites at 3776 Sixty-second Street, Woodside, L.I., was sold by the Stryker Arms Corporation to an investing client of Broadway Affiliates, Inc., brokers.
Nature and the Drama Gossip of the Summer theatres not infrequently has to do with a new play being tried out for Broadway production. It makes one wonder about the Christmas card manufacturers.

Giving the first official indication of the quantities of rayon which will be available to hosiery manufacturers under the recent OPACS allotment order, the E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. announced in Wilmington yesterday that it would offer 250,000 pounds of rayon yarn for August distribution to hosiery producers.
BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Tommy Livingston's thirteenth-inning double with Merrill May on base gave the Phillies a 2-1 triumph today and a sweep of their two-game series with the Braves.
LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Seven American officer pilots, eight Canadians, six British and one Australian were killed in the crash of a transocean plane bound from Britain across the Atlantic on Sunday.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and its operating subsidiary, the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey incorporated in Delaware, filed yesterday an answer in connection with the complaint of unfair labor practices issued against them by the National Labor Relations Board.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.
ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 12 -- Reports of new Anglo-Russian assurances and guarantees to Turkey were confirmed here tonight by official British, Soviet and Turkish sources.
MOSCOW, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique said today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Criticizing speculators who had pushed prices upward with "scare" stories of shortages, Leon Henderson, administrator of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply, today established a ceiling of three and a half cents a pound on 96 degree raw sugars, duty-paid, delivered in New York, and called on consumers to refuse to pay more than present retail prices.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- A joint Anglo-Soviet declaration, promising Turkey to go to her aid if she is attacked by a European power, was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Two Democratic members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee -- Guy M. Gillette of Iowa and Claude Pepper of Florida -- forecast a break in diplomatic relations between the United States and France as a result of Marshal Petain's announcement of collaboration with Germany.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 12 -- The last communique on the penetration west of Lake Ladoga issued by the Finnish High Command has been followed by new information indicating how considerable this Finnish victory has been. Large quantities of booty are said to have fallen into Finnish hands.

Advices reaching THE NEW YORK TIMES from European centers last night said that a serious clash of authority between General Maxime Weygand and Admiral Francois Darlan, the Vichy Vice Premier, might he expected within the next forty-eight hours following upon Admiral Darlan's assumption of the post of Minister of National Defense, in which the "protection" of all naval and air bases of the French Empire is completely under his personal direction.

The Maritime Commission has completed a survey of port facilities in New York harbor showing a substantial reduction in the amount of pier space in use despite the fact that cargo shipments handled are steadily increasing in volume.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Topics of The Times of Aug. 2 under the subtitle "Rights and Minorities" carries a veiled reference to Christian Science. While it does not mention that religion by name, the inference is unmistakable. I quote your writer: "We have, for example, a very well-known American minority which rejects the whole art and science of medicine."
BERLIN, Aug. 12 -- For the first time since the war began the Royal Air Force attempted today a daylight raid on the German industrial areas on a big scale.
VICHY, France, Aug. 12 -- The text of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's speech today follows:

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Bill Gallon, brown colt owned by R.H. Johnston of Charlotte, N.C., and winner of last week's Hambletonian, annexed both heats of the $2,210 Illinois Review Futurity for 3-year-old trotters at the State Fair Grounds today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 -- J. Warren Davis, retired senior judge of the Third Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, took the witness stand in his own defense in the Federal District Court today to deny that he borrowed $27,500 from William Fox, former motion picture producer, in exchange for judicial favors.

Justice Lloyd Church, who has been selected by the Democrats as their candidate for Controller in place of David H. Knott, has been on the Supreme Court bench for the past seven years. One of his chief assignments while on the bench has been the safeguarding of investors in large building mortgages involved in rehabilitation or reorganization proceedings.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- After an executive session of the United Automobile Workers-C.I.O. convention today the thousands of delegates visited the vicinity of two Curtiss-Wright Corporation airplane plants in this area in an effort to spread the union message to 17,000 employes, many of whom are members of an independent union.

The iron wheels of the German juggernaut move slowly across the immense prairies and the dark forests of Russia. They move into ambushes, into solid walls of armed resistance, into burned villages, into snares set by ubiquitous guerrilla bands. In no previous campaign has the great war machine been stalled so often or paid out so much blood and treasure for every step it advances.

Less than twelve hours before last midnight's deadline for filing designations for party nominations, David H. Knott filed with the Board of Elections his formal declination as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Controller.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12 -- Plans are under way for an outdoor amateur boxing carnival to be held on the night of Aug. 29, at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club for the benefit of the William Carey Camp of the Boys Club of New York.
LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

The clamping of a ceiling price of 3.50 cents a pound on raw sugar came as a surprise to the sugar trade here yesterday. But since a very small quantity of sugar had changed hands at that price recently it was stated that the order could go into effect without any serious disturbance, despite the fact that the top price is fixed at about 30 points below going quotations.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals downed the Chicago Cubs, 8 to 7, today in a see-saw battle and took over first place in the National League from Brooklyn, which lost two to the Giants.

Contracts awarded during July for engineering construction aggregated nearly $1,000,000,000, or more than in any month in the nation's history, it was disclosed yesterday. The month's weekly average awards were 30 per cent above the previous high reported for June, and 120 per cent over the July, 1940, average.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- For probably the first time in American history, the whereabouts of the President of the United States has been unknown for three days to the American people and to most, if not all, ranking government officials.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Adoption of a general manufacturers' sales tax as a substitute for some special excises in present law and the pending tax bill, and as a means for adding several hundred million dollars to the yield of the latter, was urged repeatedy before the Finance Committee as it continued hearings today on the $3,236,000,000 measure.

Governor Charles Edison, of New Jersey intervened yesterday in the strike of 16,000 employes at the shipyard of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company at Kearny, N.J., with a plea against government 'operation of the plant and a request that such action be withheld pending efforts by the State to settle the dispute.

GO back a few days. Sunday evening. Night over St. Louis. And a Flash in the dark. The old Fordham Flash, Flying Frank Frisch of great days around second base for the Giants and Cardinals, now Onkel Franz, manager of the Pirates, a man with sore feet, a thickening waistline, a thinning thatch and two dreadful bruises where he was hit close to the heart on Sunday in St. Louis.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Aug. 12 -- For the second year in succession Mrs. De Witt Untermeyer of Hollywood, recent winner of the New Jersey Shore tournament, and Miss Gail Wild of the home club won the annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Scotch foursomes championship today by adding an 83 to their 82 of yesterday for a total of 165 on the difficult lower course of the Baltusrol Golf Club.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Two of Britain's most famous fighter pilots, Wing Commander D.R. Bader, legless ace and former stunt flier who had shot down at least fifteen German planes, and Acting Flight Lieutenant E.S. Lock, who is credited with over thirty enemy machines, were reported missing today.

Pending the issuance of regulations covering the control of installment selling, major appliance manufacturers were reluctant to comment yesterday on the effects of such curbs, but on the whole they were not seriously disturbed by the outlook.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor expressed its "gratification" in a statement issued today that "every major proposal to shackle organized labor and destroy freedom of American workers has been soundly defeated" in the current session of Congress.

Increased activity of life insurance funds to help finance business and industry, government and home owners is indicated by an increase of about $343,000,000 in the purchases of securities and mortgages by life insurance companies in the first half of this year.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12 -- The third in a series of junior dances was given tonight at the Devon Club. The dances are arranged by a committee headed by Mrs. James B. Skidmore. Before the dance Mr. and Mrs. John N. Cole gave a dinner at their Summer home on Ocean Avenue for Miss Jane Cole and eighty young people.

Renewed assurance that America can feed her friends across the seas without pulling in her own belt was given us yesterday afternoon by Dr. Louise Stanley, Chief of the Bureau of Home Economics, when she arrived at La Guardia Field from Washington.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, outlined last night his personal course of vacation reading for this Summer, and named six of the books as recommended to those who seek to live the intellectual life.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- War Relic, the chestnut son of Man o' War and Friar's Carse, won the fifty-second Kenner Stakes in a slim field of three, having little more to do than gallop a mile and three-sixteenths this bright and sunny afternoon as 9,356 persons looked on.
Following are the primary designations for offices to be filled at the November elections. Asterisks denote incumbents.

Unofficial reports from Washington to the effect that goods for export have been given a priority rating immediately ahead of the needs of the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supplies caused considerable excitement among foreign traders here last night.
DETROIT, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A six-game losing streak of the Indians came to an end today, but it was Al Milnar, not Rapid Robert Feller, who turned the trick.

Cotton prices yesterday continued their decline for the fifth successive day under the impact of active liquidation and hedge selling supplemented by the touching-off of a large number of stop-loss orders. After opening 2 to 5 points below Monday's final prices quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange continued to lose ground, with closing levels at net losses of 36 to 41 points, or $1.80 to $2.05 a bale.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Hushed tension alternated with clamorous uproar when the House passed the Army service extension bill tonight by a single vote.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Right you are in your editorial "Priorities Unemployment." Instead of concentrating the bulk of defense orders in the hands of a few, we should do as Great Britain did and subcontract the work and materials among many small and scattered plants.

For the humiliating treatment accorded them on Monday by the Dodgers, the Giants yesterday took revenge in full measure and today the Brooklyn boys are back in second place, a game and a half behind the Cardinals and wondering What hit them.

After thirty one consecutive scoreless innings at the Stadium the Yankees cut loose with, a four-run barrage in the eighth yesterday, broke up a tense pitching duel between Spud Chandler and Dick Newsome, achieved a 4-0 victory over the Red Sox and soared lo a fourteen-game lead over the Indians.

Consolidated gross sales of radios, refrigerators, air conditioners and other products of the Philco Corporation were $35,211,279 in the first six months of the current calendar year, compared with $22,016,332 in 1940, James T. Buckley, president, announced in the semi-annual report made available today.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles, who had lost eighteen of their previous nineteen games, broke even with the Newark Bears tonight before a crowd of 7,892. Baltimore won the seven-inning opener, 8 to 6, coming from five runs behind, but lost the afterpiece, 4 to 2.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Chiefs dealt two vicious blows to Jersey City's hopes of graining the fourth position in the International League play-offs tonight with a double victory over the Little Giants, 7 to 6 and 6 to 5.

CALDWELL, N.J., Aug. 12 -- Robert L. Earle, vice president and general manager of the propeller division of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, tonight rejected a request for a conference with strikers at the Caldwell plant, pointing out that the question at issue was one to be decided by the National Labor Relations Board and not the company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Immediate national attention to post-war planning was called for today by the National Resources Planning Board. It asked public and private agencies to start work at once on the problem of transferring millions of men from "all-out production for defense to all-out production for normal living when this war is over."

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- France under the control of Vichy is now a full-fledged Fascist power -- that is the British view immediately following Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's announcement of "grave things." The first impression here is that Vichy seeks a dictatorship along the Italian model and in the process, will yield to every demand made by Germany.

More than 600 oil burner dealers of the metropolitan area yesterday pledged full support to an industry-wide "Save for Defense" drive in which fuel consumption savings of 25 to 30 per cent compared with a year ago will be sought through more efficient operation of oil burning heating plants in homes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's radio address and the decree that invests Admiral Francois Darlan with extensive powers over all French armed forces are in keeping with the diplomatic information consistently received from Vichy during the last fortnight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Livestock prices sagged as much as 15 and 25 cents a hundred pounds today as continued liberal offerings exceeded demand from packing interests. Medium and light weight swine were 10 to 15 cents off, with top values off 20 cents at $11.50. Heavier weights and sows were mostly steady to 10 cents off.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial "A Time for Statesmanship" you remark that a broadly based tax system offers the most effective means of meeting the problem of price control, and that leaving spending power uncontrolled would almost certainly result in failure.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Opening the last ninety minutes of general debate on the Army bill today, Representative Elston, Republican, of Ohio argued in the House that the nation was not in greater peril than a year ago and therefore there was no need for the extension of the term of service.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Harry Bobo, sensational Pittsburgh Negro slugger, knocked out Lee Savold of Des Moines tonight in the second round of their scheduled ten-round bout. The winner weighed 205 to 185 for Savold.

A New "Defrosting" The Treasury Department has relaxed the "freezing" order with respect to Portuguese accounts in this country, but it is to be noted that this "defrosting" applies only to the funds here of the Portuguese Government and of the Portuguese central bank.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 12 -- Dan Duryea, Broadway actor, was signed to a term contract today by Samuel Goldwyn and named for the villain's role, that of a gangster, in "Ball of Fire" with Gary Cooper and Barbara Stanwyck, which started this morning.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 12 -- Reports today revealed that the destuction of an Italian patrol which, on Sunday morning, attempted to capture a British outpost outside the defense perimeter, was entirely the work of a captain, a corporal and a private armed with a pistol, a Bren gun and a Thompson sub-machine gun.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- President Roosevelt declared in a letter to Secretary Wickard made public today that "food is a weapon against Hitlerism just as much as munitions." He added that "we need not only abundant production for ourselves and for other nations resisting aggression, but we need reserves to meet emergencies which can as yet be only dimly foreseen."

Buyer Registrations Up in Week Visiting buyers in the New York market during the week ended yesterday totaled 925, which compared with 761 in the previous week and 1,070 in the similar period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Two seeded players fell by the wayside today as the singles division reached the quarter-final round in the seventeenth annual Essex County Club women's invitation tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Plantation Pipe-line Company, which has been formed to build a 1,200-mile $30,000,000 oil pipe line from Baton Rouge to Greensboro, N.C., requested Federal assistance today in obtaining rights-of-way for the project which is planned to relieve the oil shortage on the Eastern seaboard.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 12 -- A thunderstorm yesterday afternoon ended the worst ordeal by air bombardment Chungking has ever endured. Japanese raids had gone on with only short intervals between them since Friday afternoon.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command today issued this communique:

The all-Sibelius program with Efrem Zimbalist as the soloist, which was cancelled on Monday night because of rain, last night drew a crowd of 11,500 to the Lewisohn Stadium. But the elements were still against it, for, through a sudden change in the weather, it was windy and cold.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,911,950 barrels daily, an increase of 216,700 over the 3,695,250 of the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 28,050 barrels fewer than the calculation of 3,940,000 daily by the Bureau of Mines for August.

With each passing day bringing additions to the status of the national-defense economy, the stock markets rounded out yesterday another stalemated session, which sessions, on balance, bid fair to establish some sort of a record for persistence.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- The Treasury issued today a general license "unfreezing" approximately $160,000,000 in Portuguese assets in the United States.

MOSCOW, Aug. 12 -- At both extremes of the enormous front between the Black and Baltic Seas, the German Army and Air Force maintained tremendous pressure during the last twenty-four hours, but the Red Army fought back.

BELMAR, N.J., Aug. 12 -- Although no final score was available on the results of the second day's fishing in the Atlantic Coast tuna tournament, due to the tremendous number of fish brought in today, it was known that the Brielle Martin and Tuna Club was still in the lead.

The theft of three valuable paintings, two Gainsboroughs and a fifteenth-century portrait of Charles the Bold, Duke of Burgundy, was reported to the police yesterday, a day after their disappearance from the apartment of their owner, Captain Daniel E.S. Sickles, on the twenty-ninth floor of the Savoy Plaza Hotel, had been discovered.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- A registration statement covering the issue of $30,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent first mortgage bonds, Series A, due on Aug. 1, 1971, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Wisconsin Power and Light Company of Madison, Wis.

VICHY, France, Aug. 12 -- Committing France to collaboration in the Nazi "new order" for Europe, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain today announced the first measures to impose his decision upon the nation. In a half-hour radio address he called upon all Frenchmen to unite in support of the course he deemed essential to national salvation.

Food prices in England have risen only about 20 per cent during the last year, Sir Otto Niemeyer, British financier, a director of the Bank of England, reported yesterday upon his arrival here on the Dixie Clipper.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- Elden Auker, Browns' pitcher, and First Baseman Joe Kuhel of the White Sox were fined $100 each today for starting a free-for-all fight during yesterday's doubleheader at Comiskey Park.

The State Labor Relations Board settled 431 strikes involving 22,345 employes during the four-year period between July 1, 1937, when the board was established, and July 1, 1941, according to figures made public yesterday. Strike cases filed during that period totaled 509, affecting 24,507 employes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The number of unemployed workers in the United States last month was 5,600,000, a decline of 300,000 from the June figure; 2,000,000 less than in January and almost 4,000,000 fewer than a year ago, according to a report of the Works Progress Administration made public today by Corrington Gill, Assistant Commissioner.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: So-called parity price figures issued by the government are based upon the thesis that during the years 1909-14 conditions were generally normal, and the prices of things the farmer sold were in fair relation to the prices of things he had to buy.
LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 13 -- Staging an impressive display of its steadily growing might, the Royal Air Force carried out its biggest offensive against Germany yesterday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- The British War Veterans Bagpipe Band, composed entirely of Britishers who fought in the World War, will play several numbers Thursday night at the Piping Rock Club during the annual dinner dance to aid the New York Women's Infirmary, the Saratoga branch of Bundles for Britain and Saratoga Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The number of unemployed workers in the United States last month was 5,600,000, a decline of 300,000 from the June figure; 2,000,000 less than in January and almost 4,000,000 fewer than a year ago, according to a report of the Works Progress Administration made public today by Corrington Gill, Assistant Commissioner.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: So-called parity price figures issued by the government are based upon the thesis that during the years 1909-14 conditions were generally normal, and the prices of things the farmer sold were in fair relation to the prices of things he had to buy.
LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 13 -- Staging an impressive display of its steadily growing might, the Royal Air Force carried out its biggest offensive against Germany yesterday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- The British War Veterans Bagpipe Band, composed entirely of Britishers who fought in the World War, will play several numbers Thursday night at the Piping Rock Club during the annual dinner dance to aid the New York Women's Infirmary, the Saratoga branch of Bundles for Britain and Saratoga Hospital.

When the House of Representatives voted yesterday on the proposal to extend the present period of military training under the Selective Service Act it had before it the advice of the two public officials above all others whose expert opinion on this question was entitled to respect.

Jack Hagen, a 58-year-old professional of all grades of experience, must rank as one of the outstanding short-hole golfers on record -- especially in the records of the World-Telegram hole-in-one tournament.
ROME, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:
BERLIN, Aug. 12 -- The Russian armies west of the Dnieper River in the Ukraine have been defeated and face eventual annihilation, informed quarters in Berlin declared this evening.

A considerable reshuffling of tenants of at least five of the Federally sponsored low-rent housing projects in this city, with the possibility that a few may be forced out altogether, is impending as a result of the boom in defense industries, it became known yesterday.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A Finnish military communique today said:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The announcement by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, French Chief of State, that France would collaborate in Reichsfuehrer Hitler's "new order" and join the anti-Soviet front that Nazi Germany has been attempting to form, was regarded here as a sharp blow, even though it came as anything but a surprise.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 12 -- Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies announced today after a meeting of the Cabinet that it had unanimously requested him to return to London as soon as possible in view of the continuing tension in the Far East.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12 -- A. 19-year-old California newcomer went on the center court at the Newport Casino today and vanquished Wayne Sabin of Reno, Nev., the player who ended Robert Riggs's winning streak at Rye and Frank Parker's at Seabright.

In his letter to the convention of the American College Publicity Association, President Roosevelt has urged the redoubling of "our efforts during these critical times to make our schools and colleges render ever more efficient service in support of our cherished democratic institutions."

Marshal Petain's weary acceptance of Hitlerian collaboration yesterday as the "only hope" of defeated France is in one sense a victory for Nazi power politics, but in another sense, as the Marshal's speech revealed, a very real victory for Germany's foes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Manufacturers of military aircraft delivered 1,460 airplanes in July, sixteen fewer than in the preceding month, due to shortages of propellers and other parts, the Office of Production Management reported today.

LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A body washed up on the Scottish coast was identified by means of a gold watch today as that of Kenneth Brown Collings, American war correspondent and aviator whose death in the sinking of a Canadian troop transport was announced on May 6.
Many sections of the borough shared in the Manhattan realty sales reported yesterday and the trading affected apartments, lofts and other business structures and vacant lots.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Dutch Leonard chalked up his seventh straight victory behind the seventeen-hit attack of the Senators today for a 9-to-3 triumph over the Athletics.

MAHWAH, N.J., Aug. 12 -- Saboteurs poured sand into the oil-cups of all power-house machinery in the strikebound American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company plant here some time early this morning, crippled a yard locomotive and Diesel-operated crane and flung rocks at from fifty to a hundred windows, according to Sheriff William R. Browne of Bergen County and associated investigators.

The thousands of persons who stared at a big billboard on a roof at the southwest corner of Forty-second Street acid Seventh Avenue yesterday knew there was something afoot but few of them ever learned exactly what it was.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Dutch Leonard chalked up his seventh straight victory behind the seventeen-hit attack of the Senators today for a 9-to-3 triumph over the Athletics.

MAHWAH, N.J., Aug. 12 -- Saboteurs poured sand into the oil-cups of all power-house machinery in the strikebound American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company plant here some time early this morning, crippled a yard locomotive and Diesel-operated crane and flung rocks at from fifty to a hundred windows, according to Sheriff William R. Browne of Bergen County and associated investigators.

The thousands of persons who stared at a big billboard on a roof at the southwest corner of Forty-second Street acid Seventh Avenue yesterday knew there was something afoot but few of them ever learned exactly what it was.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 13 -- Frank Parker evened a score with Bryan Grant today and Ted Schroeder quelled the violent two-handed forehand of Francisco Segura of Ecuador in the quarter-finals of the Newport invitation tennis tournament at the Casino.
Germany's adaptation to her own ends of the British "V for Victory" campaign now extends to legends stamped on mail sent abroad from occupied districts of Europe, it was indicated yesterday.
