WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Senate will be asked tomorrow to accept the House version of the Army service extension bill, thus avoiding the delay of a conference to reconcile differences. Quick agreement is expected, Senate Administration leaders said today.
To THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES:
BERLIN, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The German High Command communique, issued from "the Fuehrer's Headquarters," said today:

A ten-round return meeting between Maxie Shapiro, East Side lightweight, and Leo Kodak of Chicago will feature the boxing program to be presented by Chick Meehan at Ebbets Field tonight. The rivals fought last December, with Rodak capturing a close decision.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A British General Headquarters communique on the Middle East reported today:

Alleged "irregularities in the purchase of certain chemical supplies for Brooklyn and City Colleges" from a company owned principally by three chemistry professors of the two colleges, who kept their connection with the company a secret, were disclosed to the Rapp-Coudert committee investigating the public schools, at a hearing yesterday in the New York Country Count Houses.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- The 118 defendants indicted in Federal Court today on charges of violating the anti-trust laws were as follows:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The War Department today announced that contracts totaling $59,267,122 had been awarded. Concerns in New York receiving awards were as follows:

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 13 -- Mrs. Henry Austin Clark gave a luncheon today at Four Acres, her home in Main Street, for Mrs. George Edward Wood, who is visiting her cousin, Mrs. Theron Roundell Strong, at Asher Lodge. Mrs. Wood will leave on Sunday for New York and early next week will join her son, the Rev. Meredith B. Wood, at the Hoosac School, Hoosick, N. Y., where he has been appointed headmaster.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 13 -- Antitank troops of the Forty-fourth Division training on the A.P. Hill Military Reservation in Virginia will stage a demonstration of defense against mechanized warfare next Monday to Wednesday, it was announced here today.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- Admitting that the German drive into the Ukraine was "very serious," a British War Office official said today that future Soviet resistance would depend largely upon Russia's ability to replace her vast losses of men and materiel.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 14 -- While all the world is speculating about the new crisis in the Far East and even the Japanese press is clamoring for more information, Japanese Government quarters wrapped themselves in deep silence today.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 14 -- Baron Kiichiro Hiranuma, Vice Premier and Minister Without Portfolio in the Konoye Cabinet and leader of the conservative forces within it, was shot this morning by an assailant.
To THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES:

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 13 -- Squadron after squadron of Japanese planes continued to bomb Chungking and its suburbs today, persisting with an air siege against China's capital that has gone on with only short interruptions since Friday.

The twenty-fourth, season of concerts by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium came to a close in fine style last night. Artur Rubinstein, the soloist at the opening concert, was the soloist again. The program was a gala one.
Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's marriage of necessity to Nazi Germany has coincided, whether intentionally or not, with a strong German offensive in the Ukraine.
LONDON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique today:

LONDON, Thursday, Aug. 14 -- Roaring far and wide over Germany, the Norwegian coast, the Netherlands and occupied France, Royal Air Force planes bombed Berlin, the Krupp works at Essen and a dozen other points yesterday, spreading havoc wherever they went, according to the Air Ministry.

HAVANA, Aug. 13 -- The Cuban Government opened negotiations today through diplomatic channels, seeking "a satisfactory solution of the grave situation" facing the Cuban sugar industry as a result of the price ceiling fixed on raw sugar by the Office of Price Administration and Civilian Supply of the United States, Jose Manuel Cortina, Minister of State, announced tonight.

Declaring that present strikes were due largely to lack of a "strong and equitable labor policy" and the "inadequacy" of Federal labor machinery to deal with industrial disputes, the National Association of Manufacturers issued a statement yesterday calling for a "new bill of rights for American industry, workmen and management."

Reporting to stockholders on operations in the first six months of 1941, Robert C. Stanley, chairman and president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., announced yesterday a consolidated net profit of $17,315,607 after all charges, equal, after dividend requirements on the preferred stock, to $1.12 a share on 14,584,025 shares of no-par common stock.
An underwriting syndicate headed by G. M. P. Murphy Co. is offering today to the public 100,000 shares of Bell Aircraft Corporation common stock at $1 par value at $18.50 a share.

Ten employment agencies which now are on Sixth Avenue have taken quarters in the Employment Center Building, under construction at 76-84 Warren Street, which eventually is expected to house seventy such concerns.

William S. Knudsen, director general of the Office of Production Management, said yesterday that once defense production hits its peak, which should be by next July, "America can write its own ticket on war material, and this ticket can, as far as I am concerned, be twice anybody else's ticket."

Restraint The more Wall Street discusses the various proposals now before Congress for amendment of the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, the clearer becomes the conclusion that the financial industry actually asked for surprisingly little.

The two-story garage and store building at 1956 Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the N. W. Holding Company to a client of Joseph G. Platzner, broker, for cash above a first mortgage of $69,625. The property is assessed for $8O,OOO and is under lease at an average annual rental of about $10,000.
Hard-pressed Russian armies attempting to escape from the great Nazi trap in the Southern Ukraine are admittedly in grave peril; yet a long and bloody fight for Odessa still may be possible.

As a measure of cooperation with the gasoline conservation program, the Automobile Racing Club of America announced yesterday through The Associated Press that its annual race through the streets of Alexandria Bay, N. Y., set for Aug. 23, had been canceled.
MOSCOW, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A midday communique of the Soviet Bureau of Information said:

A group of twenty-one new leases in the thirty-story Century Apartments at 25 Central Park West, featured the reports of renting yesterday. Agents of other structures, including one new building, announced the addition of several tenants to their rosters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The House rejected today, by a vote of 254 to 51, the report of a conference committee eliminating House amendments to the Administration's Property Seizure Bill, permitting the President to seize munitions or machinery and supplies with which to make arms.

DETROIT, Aug. 13 (U.P) -- Governor Van Wagoner and an OPM official agreed today that the OPM's program of easing defense production bottlenecks by spurring subcontracting had bogged down "disappointingly" in Michigan.

FALLS VILLAGE, Conn., Aug. 13 (AP) -- John J. O'Neill, president of the National Association of Science Writers, charged tonight that the government had clapped "a censorship" on laboratories developing an element, which, if contained in a ten-pound bomb "would blast a hole twenty-five miles in diameter and more than a mile deep, and would wreck every structure within 100 miles."

THERE are sixteen major league baseball clubs and there's a job of firing to be done on twelve of them. To be brief and bitter about it, those clubs have nothing much to do now except build for next year and that begins with a firing job. Before the newcomers can come in, some of the older gents will have to be thrown out to make room.
Banks and mortgage companies figured prominently yesterday as the sellers of properties in Manhattan.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Denny Galehouse held the Indians to eight hits, allowed no runs after the first inning and smacked three singles himself as the Browns won today, 9 to 3.

The National Maritime Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, will seek new wage increases for seamen on United States merchant ships when negotiations are begun with twenty-eight East Coast passenger and freight ship operators for a new contract to replace the agreement that expires on Sept. 30, it was announced yesterday.

The annual hunt for the owners of unclaimed bank deposits will receive further impetus today, when the savings banks will advertise for claimants on 992 accounts that have remained dormant for fifteen years. Under the New York State law covering escheat banks are required to advertise annually for missing owners of deposits.

Louis J. Lefkowitz, chairman of the law committee of the New York County Republican Committee, and A. David Benjamin, holding a similar position in Kings, charged yesterday that the petitions, designating John R. Davies for the Republican nomination for Mayor contained grave irregularities, obtained photostatic copies of the petitions from the Board of Elections and began to check the signatures.

Negotiations for readjustment of wage schedules, of 85,000 dress workers in the New York area to meet higher living costs were progressing favorably yesterday, with the expectation that wage increases would be granted in most classifications.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- Devil Diver of the Greentree Stable captured the twenty-ninth, Sanford Stakes in a hard drive by half a length today, Stephen (Laddie) Sanford subsequently presenting the silver trophy to Mrs. Joan Shipman Payson, daughter of Mrs. Payne Whitney, owner of the winning colt.

Look back a year. It was in this week in 1940 that the Battle of Britain began. The Luftwaffe's first mass attack on England was made on Aug. 8. Three days later 400 Nazi planes raided the British Isles, and from that time until the bombing reached its all-time high, in mid-September, London and the port towns were subjected to a nightly pounding of increasing intensity.

BELMAR, N. J., Aug. 13 -- The Neptune Sportsmen's Club of Neptune, N. J., captured the Governor's Challenge Trophy, major award in the fourth annual Atlantic Coast tuna tournament, which was completed tonight. Sixteen tearns competed in the three-day event.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Preservation of the recordings of American Indian chants and ceremonials collected by the Smithsonian Institution, which were transferred, to the National Archives in March, 1940, is provided by a gift of $30,000 from Mr. and Mrs. Hall Clovis of Greenwich, Conn.

Leading converters of rayon piece goods left here last night to attend the conference called for this morning in Washington by OP ACS which may result in the establishment of price ceilings on finished fabrics. Market price and supply conditions on the eve of the meeting were confused and the hope was expressed, that the conference would produce clarifying results, although the difficulties of establishing finished goods ceilings were generally conceded.

Stock Exchange circles are preparing to fight a last-ditch battle on three amendments the Securities and Exchange Commission has proposed for Section 19 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Brokers look upon them as an attempt by the commission to deprive exchanges of all independence and liberty of action.

Paul J. Kern, president of the Civil Service Commission, yesterday vigorously denied charges by former Judge Alfred M. Talley that there was a "decay" of the merit system in New York City. Mr. Kern spoke at a meeting of the Kiwanis Club at the Hotel McAl-pin, where Mr. Talley spoke four weeks ago.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- How a woman reduced her weight 300 pounds in eighteen months by dieting was told in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Secretary Wickard said at a press conference today that the United States might have to subsidize the export of food to Europe after the war to create a world in which Americans could live safely. Meanwhile, he said, he hoped for international agreements to regulate the surpluses of wheat, cotton and other commodities backed up in many parts of the world.
Six residential properties In Scarsdale, Westchester, have been sold through Van Wert Swanson, brokers. Five of the sellers were institutions and one was an estate.

William Dow Boutwell, chief of the Division of Radio, Publications and Exhibits in the United States Office of Education, has written, in collaboration with five other authors, a 612-page compendium entitled "America Prepares for Tomorrow: The Story of Our Total Defense Effort."

BUFFALO, Aug. 13 -- Led by Harold Christoffel, their president, delegates from the Allis-Chalmers local marched into the convention of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., today to receive a noisy greeting after a committee of the convention had reported that they had been elected.

Plans for the sixth link in the chain of stores operated by Oppenheim Collins were announced yesterday when a site was leased in White Plains for improvement with a building to serve the concern's customers in Westchester Couhty. The store leased from the plans from the Hawxhurst Realty Company a shopping building to be erected for its exclusive use on the Post Road adjoining Altmans.

A little more than a week ago the Tribuna, published in Italy, printed an interview with Armando Tosi, manager of the Italian Restaurant at the World's Fair, in which Signer Tosi charged that panicky fears entertained here over the fifth' column menace had resulted in "bestial treatment" of Italian nationals detained in the United States.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 13 -- Mrs. Louis Ruckgaber and John Martin of the home club returned 82 -- 10 -- 72 today on the Nassau Country Club golf course to capture the mixed Scotch foursomes championship of Long Island. The tournament, sponsored by the men's and women's Long Island golf associations, is decided on net scoring.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The livestock trade steadied today after yesterday's downturn, with some strength showing on hogs and cattle regaining all of the loss. The top on hogs was up 5 cents to $11.55 a hundredweight. The dressed trade was about steady, with no change in loin values. Fed steers and yearlings were strong to 25 cents higher than yesterday.

BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 13 -- For "distinguished service" in the interpretation, of education in 1941, involving "the widespread coverage of news regarding education in all parts of the world," THE NEW YORK TIMES became the first recipient today' of a new annual award set up by the American College Publicity Association.

BERLIN, Aug. 13 -- According to official German reports, the German armed forces are successfully attacking on all fronts in the Russian theatre of war, including the sector east of Kiev, and are making particularly rapid headway in the Southern Ukraine.

LONDON, Aug. 13 (U.P.) -- The British Government today branded Admiral Francois Darlan, the French Vice Premier, as a dictator who is prepared, with his new broad powers, to force France into "further surrender" to Adolf Hitler's demands.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions. Additional tax charges under the Revenue Act of 1940 have been made against earnings in many reports.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Roger Steffan of 128 Central Park South of the engagement of their daughter, Miss | Pamela Steffan, to Henry Squire Reid Jr. of Los Angeles, son of Dr. and Mrs. Reid of Palm Springs, Calif., and Estes Park, Col.
BOSTON, Aug. 13 -- The Giants were on the high, road to bagging their second straight double-header at Braves Field today When a 22-year-old southpaw gummed up the works.

That the railroads are no more satisfied than the Red Caps with the ten-cent-a-package charge for porter service at terminals was indicated yesterday In testimony presented at the hearings now being held at City Hall on the question, pursuant to a resolution of the Senate, by the wage and hour division of the United States Department ment of Labor.

A strike of 8,000 installation workers employed by the Bell telephone system, which would tie up private, government and defense communication installation throughout the country, was threatened yesterday by the Association of Communication Equipment Workers, an affiliate of the National Federation of Telephone Workers, an independent organization.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Nibble Hanover, big bay trotter from Westbury, L. I., that broke three world records last month, turned on the speed again today to win the United States Trotting Association's $4,000 Stallion Stake in two straight heats at the State Fair Grounds.

The Southeastern Greyhound Lines has called a special meeting of stockholders for Sept. 19 in Lexington, Ky., to vote on proposals to authorize an issue of 7,000 shares of $100 par 6 per cent preferred stock and to acquire the Union Bus Company through an exchange of stock, according to a letter to stockholders from Guy A. Huguelet, president.
ROME, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Senate investigators said today that firms whose former officers or employes were in the Office of Production Management had received defense contracts totaling $2,882,000,000 up to April 30.

LONDON, Thursday, Aug. 14 -- Disclosure of a "clear division" between the Democracies and the Axis resulting from Anglo-United States talks was awaited today as the British Government prepared to issue "the most momentous announcement of the war" at 3 P. M.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- German penetration of Latin America through motion pictures is being resisted by the British and United States Governments, it was learned here today from the British. Ministry of Economic Warfare.

The British Treasury has approved the release of approximately $400,000 for continued advertising and promotion in this country of tea from India, Ceylon, Java and Sumatra, Benjamin Wood, managing director of the Tea Bureau, announced yesterday.

The semi-annual statement of the International Paper and Power Company signed by Richard J. Cullen, president, and mailed yesterday to stockholders, disclosed a net profit of $6,761,511 for the first six months of 1941 after provision of $9,075,053 for taxes based on income.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Albert W. Hawkes, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, denounced the closed shop "or its equivalent" today as "un-American and monopolistic," and appealed to leaders of organized labor to abandon it as one of their main objectives.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 13 -- Orson Welles's next screen appearance will be in "Journey Into Fear," with Joseph Cotten and Michele Morgan at RKO, it was learned today. What type of role Welles will play was not disclosed, but Cotten has been named for the lead, and it is understood that the producer-actor-director will be seen in a character part.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Bonds between the United States and the British Empire were strengthened today when Secretary Hull exchanged ratifications of treaties for peaceful settlement of disputes with the diplomatic representatives of Canada, Australia and New Zealand.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations took sides today against the Administration's proposal to widen the Income tax base in the quest for new revenue to finance the defense program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull confirmed today that the resignation of Hugh Gladney Grant as United States Minister to Thailand, which is threatened by Japanese occupation, had been accepted.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- President Roosevelt by an executive order has suspended the eight-hour day for mechanics and laborers employed by the War Department on public works necessary to national defense.

The enigmatic figure of General Weygand, the one symbol left of the "France Outre-Mer" that depends on Vichy, is the unknown quantity in the ambiguous situation following Marshal Petain's extraordinary declaration of policy. Until now Weygand has been the French "ace in the hole."

The appointment of Dr. Colin M. MacLeod, associate of Rockefeller Institute, as director of the Bacteriological Laboratories at the New York University College of Medicine was announced yesterday by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Piling up at the rate of $277.50 a second, the Federal debt went over the $50,000,000,000 mark today, or almost double the $26,596,701,648 reached in World War days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Important announcements as to American foreign policy are expected by official Washington, possibly tomorrow, as a result of activities attributed to President Roosevelt during his cruise in the Atlantic.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 -- Reports furnished to Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller by 2,280 manufacturing concerns in New York State indicate that employment rose 1.8 per cent between the middle of June and the middle of July. This is the season when factory employment usually drops to its lowest point of the year.

Reading' Company Gross revenues of the Reading Company for July were estimated at $6,756,000, an increase of 26 per cent over the $5,278,984 in July, 1940, Edward W. Scheer, president, said yesterday. Net operating income was placed at $1,100,000 against $1,142,302.

"Forty Thousand Horsemen," an Australian-made film, will have its local premiere this morning at the Globe Theatre. The romantic adventure, which will be released here through Goodwill Pictures Corporation, was made with the cooperation of the Department of Defense and the officers and men of the First and Second Australian Cavalry Divisions.

Appliance Stocks Melting The current rush on major electrical appliances, with, retail sales gains now exceeding the previous wholesale increases, will deplete distributor and store stocks faster than was expected, reports yesterday indicated.

BERLIN, Thursday, Aug. 14 -- German officials, claiming the destruction of 244 Russian and British planes in the twenty-four hours ended at 7 o'clock yesterday morning, acknowledged tonight that men, women and children of German cities had been "brought into the front lines" by enemy aerial assaults.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (U.P.) -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today he was awaiting a full analysis of new Vichy moves from Ambassador William D. Leahy before making any statement on United States relations with France.

A formal bid by Argentina for a larger share in the United States market was made here yesterday with announcement by the Argentine Trade Promotion Corporation that it has opened offices in Rockefeller Center to seek outlets in this country for a wide variety of Argentine products which are noncompetitive with American goods.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:
Seventy-seven players turned out for the metropolitan one-day tourney at the St. Albans Golf Club yesterday and, by sheer coincidence, 77 was the best score made.

There has become apparent in recent weeks a growing realization on the part of Government officials that the control of prices and the ultimate prevention of inflation involve far more than the mere fixing of price ceilings. These problems are inseparable from the whole broad field of Government fiscal and credit policies.

A BOOK reviewer once labeled Mark Antony DeWolfe Howe of Boston a Bostonian "of the ultimate Brahmin caste." Although it is scarcely politic of one in my position to make such a suggestion, Mr. Howe ought to have sued for libel. His witty little autobiographical volume called "A Venture in Remembrance,"* published this morning, shows why.

The stock market went through a mild hardening process yesterday, but the colorful performances of the day were provided by the commodities, with both cotton and grain futures up sharply. A substantial buying wave prevailed in these markets, born of the belief by speculators that Congress would approve the freezing of Government-controlled stocks of these staples, even though there was some fear of a Presidential veto of this move.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Buck Newsom, whose pitching victories for the Tigers totaled twenty-one last year, scored his ninth triumph of the current season today as his team defeated the White Sox, 4 to 1, aided by three Sox errors in the third inning.

CALDWELL, N. J., Aug. 13 -- While peaceful picketing continued at the strikebound propeller plant of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation here, three union representatives left for Washington today to confer with representatives of the OPM in an effort to end the walkout.

DEARBORN , Mich., Aug. 13 (U.P.) DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 13 (U.P) -- Ford Motor Company officials unveiled tonight Henry Ford's first plastic automobile at the annual community festival of this city. More than 10,000 spectators were present.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 13 -- Long shots continued their winning ways at Roosevelt Raceway tonight before a crowd of 6,400 harness horse followers who wagered 597,387. It was the third night of the late Summer meeting and, to keep things running in a cycle of three, winners in the first three dashes were outsiders.

Trading yesterday on fresh pork cuts was fairly active at strong to higher prices. The market on lamb and bull beef was steady to strong. Cow beef, veal and calf were about steady, while steer hinds and ribs were unchanged. There was no change in the kosher markets.

ROME, Aug. 13 -- The Italian force on the Ukrainian front has so far found that its greatest enemy is the incredible amount of mud it has to plow through, according to a dispatch from the Messagero's war correspondent, Lino Pellegrini.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Frank McCormick singled in the tenth inning to bring the Reds a 3-2 victory over the Cardinals before 30,151 fans tonight. Bucky Walters, Cincinnati pitcher, thus avenged an extra-inning loss last Thursday to Morton Cooper and recorded his fourteenth victory.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 12:

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., Aug. 13 -- President Roosevelt, after an unprecedented mystery cruise in a week of grave world events, is expected to come ashore in New England within a few days ready to open a new chapter in Anglo-American collaboration against Hitlerism.

With the forced allocation of certain looms in each coarse goods mill to the weaving of oshaburgs a distinct possibility, dry goods wholesalers feared yesterday that goods now on order would be further delayed. The osnaburgs will be required by the government for huge quantities of sand bags and present production is almost two-thirds shy-of the estimated annual requirements of 700,000,000 yards.

Since the beginning of the war there have been four votes in Congress on questions of critical importance. These votes came on repeal of the arms embargo, on package of the lease-lend bill, on adoption of the Selective Service Act and on the proposal to extend the period of training under that legislation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Steel companies have submitted plans for expanding ingot capacity by more than 12,000,000 tons at a cost which may run as high as $1,500,000,000, it was stated today at a meeting of the Steel Defense Industry Advisory Committee with officials of the Office of Production Management and other defense agencies.

Bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States declined $3,033,000 in July to $209,899,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The bank's regular monthly statistics of this market showed that the total outstanding at the end of July was $21,549,000 higher than the year before.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 13 (Australian Associated Press) -- Hopes for unity in the Australian Parliament received a setback today as a result of a demand that Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies resign before going to London.

NEWARK, N. J., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Frank Kelleher paced the Newark Bears to a 4-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles in the rubber contest of a three-game series tonight. He made three hits that batted in all four Newark scores.

The Weather Man, who watches the temperature the way a housewife does her roasts, was one of the few people in the city who spent much time talking about the weather yesterday. So far as most New Yorkers were concerned the sun was out, there were cool breezes, and there was really nothing to grumble about, which means the weather had little conversational value.

The scissors of fashion snipped away at long bobs yesterday as an early showing of Autumn chapeaux at Henri Bendel, 10 West Fifty-seventh Street, added an enticing argument to a general conspiracy in favor of "up-dos" and short curls.
VICHY, France, Aug. 13 -- Most Frenchmen today were digesting Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's broadcast last night, repeated this morning and printed in full in every newspaper in both zones.
NEW YORK Mrs. Dushan Simovitch, whose husband, General Simovitch, is Premier of Yugoslavia, is at the Ritz-Carlton, having arrived on the liner Uruguay.

It may come as no surprise to any one, least of all the team, affected, but the Phillies will win no pennant this season. For last night under the lights at Ebbets Field Doc Prothro's lads went down to a 7-2 defeat before the Dodgers. It was Philadelphia's seventy-eighth defeat, eliminating the club mathematically.
VICHY, France, Aug. 13 -- Paul Charbin, the new Secretary of State for Supplies, in a statement today upon assuming office begged the French people not to look to him for a miracle.

Miss Florence Langston Birdseye, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Miller Birdseye of 145 East Thirty-fifth Street, was married yesterday afternoon to Ensign Benjamin George Weil, U. S. N. R., son of Mrs. Arthur William Weil of 32 East Sixty-fourth Street, and the late Mr. Weil, in Trinity Episcopal Chapel, West Twenty-fifth Street.
Conserving fuel and energy, with perhaps an alert eye to the future, the Yankees continue to move along toward the American League pennant at half speed.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Bearish sentiment prevailed in the wheat trade early today and prices dipped slightly only to rally rapidly later on a report that a second leaselend bill would be sent to Congress soon which would allocate about one-third of the prospective appropriation of $6,000,000,000 for the purchase of foodstuffs.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 14 -- Evacuation of the city of Smolensk "a few days ago" was officially acknowledged early today in a Soviet communique that also revealed a German advance south of Leningrad to the region of Staraya Russa.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 13 (AP) -- For the second day in a row Miss Margaret Osborhe, 21-year-old San Franciscan, who is unseeded, upset the form sheet in the Essex Country Club's invitation tennis tourney, defeating third-ranked Miss Dorothy May Bundy of Santa Monica, Calif., today in a quarter-final singles match, 6-4, 6-3.

Paul F. Cullum, Mayor of North Bergen, N.J., purchased from the Stuyvesant Building and Loan Association the garage at 21-27 Bevan Street, northwest corner of Van Wart Alley, Jersey City. The building is a one-story brick structure on a plot 101 by 125 feet and has a capacity for the storage of fifty cars.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- A $63,000,000 government contract was signed today for the erection of plants to make metallic magnesium and other magnesium products vitally needed for war planes.
BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Aug. 14 -- The Russian withdrawal from Smolensk was carried out in good order and with no loss of men or materiel, according to Soviet advices received here today.

BERLIN, Aug. 13 -- Vice Premier Francois Darlan's promotion and Chief of State Henri Philippe Petain's speech yesterday met with approval here in Berlin, but of the two events the latter evoked the principal official comment.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- Britain's new weapon, the American-made fortress bomber, is spreading fear and contributing to an awakened spirit of revolt in Germany and occupied Europe, say dispatches reaching important quarters here by devious means.
SYRACUSE, N. T., Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Syracuse Chiefs swept their four-game series with the Jersey City Giants when Lynn Nelson pitched the Trite to a 6-and-5 decision tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A House investigating committee blamed government officials and members of Congress today for what it termed "an unreasonable, unwarranted and unjustified delay" in the construction of Eglin Field, Army aviation project in Florida.

News that the House had passed yesterday a bill freezing government-held cotton, reached the New York Cotton Exchange too late for the market to react directly to the action. However, anticipation of the vote was the main factor in the market as it broke out of a five-day decline to score net gains of 51 to 56 points, or $2.55 to $2.80 a bale, for the day.

Ben Howe, who recently said that "New York had obeyed the Irish like a lot of chloroformed stiffs," resigned yesterday as chairman of the City Fusion party at a luncheon meeting of its executive committee at the Park Central Hotel.

The government still is hopeful that the rationing of gasoline for motorists on the Atlantic seaboard may not be necessary, Dr. John W. Frey, marketing director in the office of Secretary Harold L. Ickeg, Coordinator of the Petroleum Industry, told State officials, representatives of the petroleum industry and large users of gasoline here yesterday.

Note the following bookings for three incoming attractions: Morosco, "Two Story House," the week of Sept. 8; Longacre, "The Distant City" (Len Doyle has been added to its cast), Sept. 17; Shubert, "Candle in the Wind," Oct. 13.

LUNENBURG, Mass., Aug. 13 -- Three Fort Devens soldiers from New York City were killed and a fourth was probably fatally injured early this morning when their car left the Shirley-Lunenburg highway, mowed down several stone markers and was wrecked against a tree.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- An indictment charging eighty-one meat packing companies with, conspiracy to fix prices of Easter hams in violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law was returned today by a Federal grand jury in Chicago.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 13 (U.P.) -- At least sixty persons were known dead today in a storm that has been sweeping over Central Chile for eight days, disrupting railroad and airline communications and power services and causing floods that wrecked dams and bridges.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Scoring five runs in the ninth inning on two hits, the Cubs surged from behind tonight to beat the Pirates, 6 to 4, before 24,373 fans. Charlie Gilbert, pinch hitting, drove in the tying and winning runs with a single.

Reflecting the substantial increase in business in the twenty-four weeks ended on June 14, profit of the Eastman Kodak Company, before provision for income taxes, rose 67 per cent to $20,252,899 from $12,092,274 for the corresponding period last year, according to a report issued yesterday by F. W. Lovejoy, chairman, and T. J. Hargrave, president.

PINE ORCHARD, Conn., Aug. 13 -- Miss Frances Drisler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Arthur Drisler of New Haven and Pine Orchard, formerly of Bronxville, N. Y., has completed plans for her marriage to Lieutenant Douglas Reid Schoenfeld of Fort Devens, Mass., son of H. F. Arthur Schoenfeld, United States Minister to Finland, and Mrs. Schoenfeld of Washington, D. C., and Pine Orchard.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Aug. 13 -- Mrs. June Blossom, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Blossom of New York and Hillcote, Fairfield, Conn., was married here this afternoon to Harold Predmore Moon of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, and Palm Beach, son of the late Harold P. Moon and the late Mrs. Attaresta Barclay Wheelwright of Wilmington, Del.

BELLPORT, L. I., Aug. 13 -- The entry of the Westhampton Beach Yacht Squadron was the victor in the series of nine races that was concluded today for the Gulden Trophy, emblematic of the junior championship of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 13 -- The Berlin correspondent of the Tribune de Geneve reports that the "perpetual air raid warnings" now sounded nightly in Berlin are beginning to get on the nerves of the capital's population.

Justin R. Whiting, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, announced yesterday plans for a $14,527,500 financing program for two of the holding company's subsidiaries -- the Mississippi Power Company and the Gulf Power Company.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 -- Governor Lehman sent to Warren County officials today a demand that any gambling there be stopped. He followed the same procedure as in his demands on Saratoga County officials, and sent identical letters to District Attorney Fred M. Beckwith and Sheriff Edgar J. Baker.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Baseball's scrappy little round man, James J. Dykes, cast his lot for another three years today with, his equally scrappy White Sox.

French Regime Fashions Time has come full circle for one celebrated phrase in French history. Marshal Petain said in his radio speech that the process of national reconstruction is being held up by many surviving partisans of the "old regime."
IF you want to escape from escape books, for a while you might be interested in reading Ernst Lothar's "A Woman is Witness,"* an unusually told novel about the life and death of the French Republic.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority and the Aluminum Company of Americs signed today an agreement under which Alcoa turned over its $2,000,000 Fontana (N.C.) dam site without cash compensation for construction by TVA of a $50,000,00 hydroelectric project and TVA tool over direction of Alcoa's five privately owned hydroelectric projects for integration with the TVA system under a twenty-year contract when the Fontana dam reaches a minimum operating stage in 1944.

Professional and business people figured in a number of the leading apartment leases announced yesterday. Buildings on three sides of Central Park appeared in the lists of new rentals furnished by brokers and renting agents.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES :
BERLIN, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The following German High Command communique was issued today:

VICHY, France, Aug. 14 -- Vice Premier Francois Darlan, new "strong man" of France, called upon the empire's armed forces today to shake off their despair and follow him and Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State, into closer and permanent "collaboration" with the Axis.

Uncertainty whether President Roosevelt would veto the bill freezing government-held cotton for the duration of the war, together with the general foreign situation, resulted yesterday in wide swings in the cotton futures market. After opening at overnight gains of 5 to 13 points, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange dropped to 41 to 51 points below Wednesday's final quotations and then rallied to close at net losses of 13 to 18 points.
If members of the East Side's "younger set" seeemd a bit patronizing yesterday, there was a reason.

Commodity Exchange The necessities of national defense having made the maintenance of a free auction market in so many metals and staples impossible, the Commodity Exchange has pared down its staff and limited its operations to the barest minimum, with the possibility that in a few months it will have no further trading to record, except, under certain conditions, in hide futures.

VICHY, France, Aug. 14 -- As an indication of the magnitude of the task of repairing war damages in France, Minister of Communications Jean Berthelot in a statement to the press here today said that 8,000,000 square meters [86,112,000 square feet] of wreckage had to be removed in preparation for the work.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 14 -- France, as represented by the Free French, received a guarantee of "a predominant position in Syria and Lebanon over any other European power," including, of course, Britain, in a letter written last Thursday by Oliver Lyttleton, representing the British Government, and made public here today.
